en: PART ONE
vi: PHẦN I
tr: BİRİNCİ KISIM
es: PRIMERA PARTE
vi_translation: PART I
tr_translation: FIRST PART
es_translation: FIRST PART

en: The Strings
vi: Những Dây Nối 8
tr: İpler
es: Los hilos
vi_translation: The Connections 8
tr_translation: Strings
es_translation: The threads

vi_translation: 1.This is the translated text.

en: The longest day of my life began tardily. I woke up late, took too long in the shower, and ended up having to enjoy my breakfast in the passenger seat of my mom’s minivan at 7:17 that Wednesday morning.
vi: 1. Ngày dài nhất trong cuộc đời tôi bắt đầu khá muộn. Tôi dậy trễ, ngâm nga quá lâu trong nhà tắm nên kết quả là phải thưởng thức bữa sáng trong chiếc minivan của mẹ vào hồi 7:17 sáng thứ Tư đó.
tr: 1 Hayatımın en uzun günü geç saatlerde başladı. O çarşamba sabahı geç uyandım, duşta çok zaman geçirdim ve kahvaltımı annemin minivanının yolcu koltuğunda saat 07:17’de yapmak zorunda kaldım.
es: 1 El día más largo de mi vida empezó con retraso. Me desperté tarde, me entretuve demasiado en la ducha y al final tuve que disfrutar del desayuno en el asiento del copiloto del monovolumen de mi madre, a las 7:17 de la mañana de un miércoles.
vi_translation: The longest day of my life started quite late. I woke up late, hummed for too long in the bathroom, and as a result, had to enjoy breakfast in my mom's minivan at 7:17 AM that Wednesday.
tr_translation: The longest day of my life started late. I woke up late that Wednesday morning, spent a lot of time in the shower, and had to eat my breakfast in the passenger seat of my mom's minivan at 7:17 AM.
es_translation: The longest day of my life started with a delay. I woke up late, spent too much time in the shower, and in the end, I had to enjoy breakfast in the passenger seat of my mother's minivan at 7:17 in the morning on a Wednesday.

en: I usually got a ride to school with my best friend, Ben Starling, but Ben had gone to school on time, making him useless to me. “On time” for us was thirty minutes before school actually started, because the half hour before the first bell was the highlight of our social calendars: standing outside the side door that led into the band room and just talking. Most of my friends were in band, and most of my free time during school was spent within twenty feet of the band room. But I was not in the band, because I suffer from the kind of tone deafness that is generally associated with actual deafness. I was going to be twenty minutes late, which technically meant that I’d still be ten minutes early for school itself.
vi: Thường ngày tôi quá giang thằng chiến hữu thân nhất, Ben Starling, nhưng hôm ấy Ben đã vi vu đến trường đúng giờ, cho nên tôi hết trông cậy được vào nó. “Đúng giờ” đối với tụi tôi là ba mươi phút trước lúc vào học, vì nửa giờ vàng ngọc trước hồi chuông đầu tiên chính là điểm sáng trong lịch trình xã giao của chúng tôi: tụ tập tán chuyện bên ngoài cửa phụ của phòng tập và biểu diễn nhạc. Đa phần bạn bè tôi chơi nhạc cụ, và đa phần thời gian rảnh ở trường của tôi được nướng trong phạm vi dăm bảy mét quanh phòng tập nhạc. Nhưng tôi không chơi nhạc cụ gì cả, vì tôi bị một chứng điếc thanh điệu, nói chung là có liên quan đến bệnh điếc thực sự. Hôm nay tôi sẽ bị muộn hai mươi phút, tức là về mặt kĩ thuật mà nói, tôi vẫn đến trước giờ vào lớp chục phút.
tr: Genelde beni okula en yakın arkadaşım Ben Starling götürürdü ama Ben, benim için yararsız hale gelerek, okula zamanında gitmişti. Bizim için “zamanında”, okulun başlamasından otuz dakika önceydi çünkü ilk zilden yarım saat öncesi sosyal programımızın en önemli bölümüydü: bando odasına giden yan kapının önünde dikilmek ve yalnızca konuşmak. Arkadaşlarımın çoğu bandodaydı ve okulda boş zamanınım çoğu bando odasının beş metre çevresinde geçerdi. Ama ben bandoda değildim çünkü genellikle gerçek sağırlıkla ilişkili olan ton sağırlığından muzdariptim. Yirmi dakika geç kalacaktım ki bu da teknik olarak, hâlâ ders saatinden on dakika önce orada olacağım anlamına geliyordu.
es: Solía ir al instituto en el coche de mi mejor amigo, Ben Starling, pero Ben había salido puntual, así que no pude contar con él. Para nosotros, «puntual» significaba media hora antes de que empezaran las clases, porque aquellos treinta minutos antes de que sonara el primer timbre eran el plato fuerte de nuestra agenda social. Nos quedábamos delante de la puerta lateral que daba a la sala de ensayo de la banda de música del instituto y charlábamos. Como la mayoría de mis amigos tocaban en la banda, yo pasaba casi todas las horas libres del instituto a menos de cinco metros de la sala de ensayo. Pero yo no tocaba, porque tengo menos oído para la música que un sordo. Aquel día iba a llegar veinte minutos tarde, lo que técnicamente significaba que aun así llegaría diez minutos antes de que empezaran las clases.
vi_translation: On regular days, I would hitch a ride with my closest buddy, Ben Starling, but that day Ben had already cruised to school on time, so I couldn't rely on him. "On time" for us meant thirty minutes before classes started, because the precious half-hour before the first bell was the highlight of our social schedule: gathering and chatting outside the side door of the gym and music room. Most of my friends played musical instruments, and most of my free time at school was spent within a few meters around the music room. But I didn't play any instruments at all, because I had a condition called tone-deafness, which is generally related to actual deafness. Today I would be twenty minutes late, which technically meant I would still arrive ten minutes before class started.
tr_translation: Usually, my closest friend Ben Starling would take me to school, but Ben, becoming useless to me, had gone to school on time. For us, "on time" was thirty minutes before school started because the half-hour before the first bell was the most important part of our social program: standing in front of the side door to the band room and just talking. Most of my friends were in the band, and most of my free time at school was spent within five meters of the band room. But I wasn't in the band because I suffered from tone deafness, which is usually associated with actual deafness. I was going to be twenty minutes late, which technically meant I would still be there ten minutes before class started.
es_translation: I used to go to school in my best friend Ben Starling's car, but Ben had left on time, so I couldn't rely on him. For us, "on time" meant half an hour before classes started, because those thirty minutes before the first bell rang were the highlight of our social agenda. We would stand in front of the side door that led to the high school band rehearsal room and chat. Since most of my friends played in the band, I spent almost all my free hours at school less than five meters from the rehearsal room. But I didn't play, because I have less of an ear for music than a deaf person. That day I was going to be twenty minutes late, which technically meant that I would still arrive ten minutes before classes started.

en: As she drove, Mom was asking me about classes and finals and prom.
vi: Vừa lái xe mẹ vừa hỏi tôi về trường lớp, thi cử và dạ hội tốt nghiệp.
tr: Annem arabayı sürerken bana dersler, finaller ve baloyla ilgili sorular sordu.
es: Mientras conducía, mi madre me preguntaba por las clases, los exámenes y el baile de graduación.
vi_translation: While driving, my mom asked me about school, exams, and the graduation prom.
tr_translation: My mom asked me questions about classes, finals, and the prom while she was driving the car.
es_translation: While driving, my mother asked me about classes, exams, and the prom.

en: “I don’t believe in prom,” I reminded her as she rounded a corner. I expertly angled my raisin bran to accommodate the g-forces. I’d done this before.
vi: “Con có bao giờ khoái dạ hội đâu mẹ,” tôi nói trong khi mẹ rẽ ở một góc phố. Lập tức, tôi điệu nghệ trở nghiêng món ngũ cốc cho cân bằng với trọng lực. Trò này tôi diễn nhiều rồi.
tr: “Baloya inanmıyorum,” diye hatırlattım, bir köşeyi dönerken. G kuvvetine uyum sağlamak için, kahvaltılık gevreğimin açısını ustalıkla ayarladım. Bunu daha önce de yapmıştım.
es: —No creo en los bailes de graduación —le recordé mientras giraba en una esquina. Incliné hábilmente mis cereales para ajustarlos a la fuerza de gravedad. No era la primera vez que lo hacía.
vi_translation: "I never enjoy parties, Mom," I said as she turned a corner. Immediately, I skillfully tilted the cereal to balance with gravity. I've done this trick many times.
tr_translation: “I don't believe in luck,” I reminded, while turning a corner. To adapt to the G-force, I skillfully adjusted the angle of my breakfast cereal. I had done this before.
es_translation: —I don't believe in prom dances —I reminded him as I turned a corner. I skillfully tilted my cereal to adjust it to the force of gravity. It wasn't the first time I had done it.

en: “Well, there’s no harm in just going with a friend. I’m sure you could ask Cassie Hiney.” And I could have asked Cassie Hiney, who was actually perfectly nice and pleasant and cute, despite having a fantastically unfortunate last name.
vi: “Ờ, đi cùng một người bạn thì có sao đâu con. Chắc chắn con có thể mời Cassie Hiney mà.” Dám là tôi mời Cassie Hiney lắm chứ, một cô bạn thực sự dễ mến, thân thiện và xinh lung linh, nhưng ngặt nỗi bạn ấy lại mang một cái họ vô địch về độ nhạy cảm[3].
tr: “Bir arkadaşla gitmenin bir zaran olmaz. Eminim, Cassie Hiney'yi davet edebilirsin.” Olağanüstü talihsiz bir soyadı olmasına rağmen, aslında gayet hoş, güzel ve sevimli olan Cassie Hiney’yi1 davet edebilirdim.
es: —Bueno, no hay nada malo en ir con una amiga. Seguro que podrías pedírselo a Cassie Hiney. Sí, podría habérselo pedido a Cassie Hiney, que era muy maja, simpática y guapa, pese a su tremendamente desafortunado apellido, que en inglés significa «culo».
vi_translation: “Well, what's wrong with going with a friend, dear?” “Surely you can invite Cassie Hiney.” I would definitely invite Cassie Hiney, a truly nice, friendly, and stunningly beautiful girl, but unfortunately, she has an extremely sensitive last name[3].
tr_translation: “There is no harm in going with a friend. I am sure you can invite Cassie Hiney.” Despite having an extraordinarily unfortunate last name despite, I could actually invite the quite nice, beautiful, and charming Cassie Hiney.
es_translation: —Well, there's nothing wrong with going with a friend. I'm sure you could ask Cassie Hiney. Yes, he could have asked Cassie Hiney, who was very nice, friendly, and pretty, despite her tremendously unfortunate last name, which in English means "butt".

en: “It’s not just that I don’t like prom. I also don’t like people who like prom,” I explained, although this was, in point of fact, untrue. Ben was absolutely gaga over the idea of going.
vi: “Không chỉ vì con không khoái dạ hội. Con không khoái cả những người khoái dạ hội,” tôi cố giải thích, dù thẳng thắn mà nói thì cũng chẳng phải. Ben mới là thằng rối rít bấn loạn về dạ hội này.
tr: “Sadece baloları değil, balolardan hoşlanan insanları da sevmiyorum,” diye açıkladım, aslında doğru olmamasına rağmen. Ben, kesinlikle gitmek için deli oluyordu.
es: —No es que no me gusten los bailes de graduación. Es que tampoco me gustan las personas a las que les gustan los bailes de graduación —le expliqué a mi madre. Aunque en realidad no era cierto. Ben se había emperrado en ir.
vi_translation: “Not just because I don't like the party. I don't even like the people who like the party,” I tried to explain, though to be honest, it wasn't quite true. Ben was the one who was all excited and frantic about this party.
tr_translation: “I don't just dislike balls, I also dislike people who enjoy balls,” I explained, even though it wasn't actually true. I was absolutely dying to go.
es_translation: —It's not that I don't like prom dances. It's that I also don't like the people who like prom dances —I explained to my mother. Although in reality it was not true. Ben had insisted on going.

en: Mom turned into school, and I held the mostly empty bowl with both hands as we drove over a speed bump. I glanced over at the senior parking lot. Margo Roth Spiegelman’s silver Honda was parked in its usual spot. Mom pulled the minivan into a cul-de-sac outside the band room and kissed me on the cheek. I could see Ben and my other friends standing in a semicircle.
vi: Mẹ rẽ vào trường, tôi giữ chặt cái bát sắp hết bằng cả hai tay khi đi qua mấy con lươn giảm tốc. Tôi liếc nhanh ra bãi đỗ xe cho học sinh năm cuối. Con Honda màu bạc của Margo Roth Spiegelman đỗ ở chỗ quen thuộc. Mẹ tấp xe vào một đoạn cụt ngay gần phòng tập nhạc và hôn lên má tôi tạm biệt. Tôi nhác thấy Ben và mấy thằng khác đứng giăng thành một đường bán nguyệt.
tr: Annem okula doğru döndü, kasisten geçerken iki elimle neredeyse boş olan kâseyi tuttum. Son sınıfların park yerine bir göz gezdirdim. Margo Roth Spiegelman’ın gümüş rengi Honda’sı her zamanki yerine park edilmişti. Annem arabayı bando odasının dışındaki bir çıkmaza doğru çevirdi ve beni yanağımdan öptü. Ben ve diğer arkadaşlarımın yarım daire şeklinde durduklarım görebiliyordum.
es: Mi madre giró hacia el instituto, y sujeté con las dos manos el tazón casi vacío al pasar por un badén. Eché un vistazo al aparcamiento de los alumnos de último curso. El Honda plateado de Margo Roth Spiegelman estaba aparcado en su plaza habitual. Mi madre metió el coche en un callejón situado frente a la sala de ensayo y me dio un beso en la mejilla. Al bajar vi a Ben y a mis otros amigos, agrupados en semicírculo.
vi_translation: Mom turned into the school, and I held the nearly empty bowl tightly with both hands as we went over the speed bumps. I quickly glanced at the senior student parking lot. Margo Roth Spiegelman's silver Honda was parked in its usual spot. Mom pulled the car into a dead-end near the music room and kissed me on the cheek goodbye. I caught sight of Ben and a few other guys standing in a semicircle.
tr_translation: My mom turned towards the school, and I held the nearly empty bowl with both hands as we went over a speed bump. I glanced at the senior parking lot. Margo Roth Spiegelman's silver Honda was parked in its usual spot. My mom turned the car towards a dead end outside the band room and kissed me on the cheek. I could see my friends and I standing in a semicircle.
es_translation: My mother turned towards the school, and I held the almost empty bowl with both hands as we went over a speed bump. I glanced at the senior student parking lot. Margo Roth Spiegelman's silver Honda was parked in its usual spot. My mother pulled the car into an alley in front of the rehearsal room and gave me a kiss on the cheek. As I got out, I saw Ben and my other friends, gathered in a semicircle.

en: I walked up to them, and the half circle effortlessly expanded to include me. They were talking about my ex-girlfriend Suzie Chung, who played cello and was apparently creating quite a stir by dating a baseball player named Taddy Mac. Whether this was his given name, I did not know. But at any rate, Suzie had decided to go to prom with Taddy Mac. Another casualty.
vi: Tôi đi đến chỗ chúng nó, vòng bán nguyệt lập tức giãn ra để thêm tôi vào. Chúng nó đang nói đến bạn gái cũ của tôi, Suzie Chung, cô nàng chơi cello và rõ là đã khuấy động dư luận khi cặp với một anh cầu thủ bóng chày tên là Taddy Mac. Tôi cũng chẳng biết đó có phải là tên thật của anh ta không nữa. Dù gì thì Suzie cũng đã quyết định đến dạ hội với Taddy Mac. Thêm một nạn nhân.
tr: Onlara doğru yürüdüm ve yarım daire hiç çaba harcamadan beni de içine almak için genişledi. Çello çalan ve görünüşe göre Taddy Mac adındaki beyzbol oyuncusuyla çıkarak herkesin ilgisini çeken eski kız arkadaşım Suzie Chung hakkında konuşuyorlardı. Taddy Mac gerçek ismi miydi bilmiyordum. Ama her halükârda Suzie baloya Taddy Mac’le gitmeye karar vermişti. Başka bir kayıp daha.
es: Me dirigí a ellos, y el semicírculo no tardó en abrirse para incluirme. Estaban hablando de mi exnovia, Suzie Chung, que tocaba el violonchelo y al parecer había creado un gran revuelo porque estaba saliendo con un jugador de béisbol llamado Taddy Mac. No sabía si era su nombre real. En cualquier caso, Suzie había decidido ir al baile de graduación con Taddy Mac. Otra víctima.
vi_translation: I went to where they were, and the semicircle immediately expanded to include me. They were talking about my ex-girlfriend, Suzie Chung, who played the cello and had clearly stirred up controversy by dating a baseball player named Taddy Mac. I don't even know if that's his real name. Anyway, Suzie had decided to go to the prom with Taddy Mac. Another victim.
tr_translation: I walked towards them, and the semicircle effortlessly expanded to include me. They were talking about my ex-girlfriend Suzie Chung, who was attracting everyone's attention by dating a baseball player named Taddy Mac, who apparently played the cello. I didn't know if Taddy Mac was his real name. But in any case, Suzie had decided to go to the ball with Taddy Mac. Another loss.
es_translation: I approached them, and the semicircle soon opened up to include me. They were talking about my ex-girlfriend, Suzie Chung, who played the cello and had apparently caused quite a stir because she was dating a baseball player named Taddy Mac. I didn't know if that was his real name. In any case, Suzie had decided to go to the prom with Taddy Mac. Another victim.

en: “Bro,” said Ben, standing across from me. He nodded his head and turned around. I followed him out of the circle and through the door. A small, olive-skinned creature who had hit puberty but never hit it very hard, Ben had been my best friend since fifth grade, when we both finally owned up to the fact that neither of us was likely to attract anyone else as a best friend. Plus, he tried hard, and I liked that—most of the time.
vi: “Êu ông ơi,” Ben đứng đối diện tôi và gọi. Nó gật đầu ra hiệu rồi đi. Tôi theo nó ra khỏi đám, đi vào phòng tập. Một gã nhỏ người da ngăm ngăm đã qua tuổi dậy thì nhưng chưa bao giờ kết thúc cái tuổi ấy một cách hoành tráng, Ben là thằng bạn chí cốt với tôi từ hồi lớp năm, khi cả hai rút cục đành thừa nhận rằng chẳng thằng nào đủ sức kiếm được đứa khác làm bạn thân. Cơ mà, nó đã rất cố gắng, và tôi khoái như vậy–phần lớn thời gian.
tr: Karşımda duran Ben, “Dostum,” dedi. Başını salladı ve arkasını döndü. Çemberin dışına çıkarak kapıya doğru onu takip ettim. Ergenliğe ulaşmış ama tam anlamıyla girememiş buğday tenli küçük bir yaratık olan Ben beşinci sımftan, yani ikimiz de başka kimseyi en yakın arkadaş olarak cezbedemeyeceğimizi sonunda kabullendiğimizden bu yana en yakın arkadaşımdı. Bir de Ben çok uğraşıyordu ve bu hoşuma gidiyordu... çoğu zaman.
es: —Colega —me dijo Ben, que estaba delante de mí. Movió la cabeza, se dio media vuelta, se alejó del círculo y entró. Lo seguí. Ben, un chico bajito y de piel aceitunada que a duras penas parecía haber llegado a la pubertad, era mi mejor amigo desde quinto, cuando al final ambos admitimos la evidencia de que seguramente ninguno de los dos iba a encontrar otro mejor amigo. Además, le puso mucho empeño, y eso me gustaba… la mayoría de las veces.
vi_translation: "Hey man," Ben stood opposite me and called. He nodded as a signal and then left. I followed him out of the crowd, heading into the gym. A small, dark-skinned guy who had gone through puberty but never quite finished it in a grand way, Ben had been my best friend since fifth grade, when we both finally admitted that neither of us could find anyone else to be a close friend. However, he had tried very hard, and I liked that—most of the time.
tr_translation: Standing in front of me, Ben said, "Buddy." He nodded his head and turned around. I followed him towards the door, stepping out of the circle. Ben, a small creature with wheat-colored skin who had reached adolescence but hadn't fully entered it, had been my best friend since fifth grade, ever since we both finally accepted that we couldn't attract anyone else as a best friend. And Ben tried very hard, which I liked... most of the time.
es_translation: —Colleague —Ben said to me, who was in front of me. He moved his head, turned halfway around, walked away from the circle, and went in. I followed him. Ben, a short boy with olive skin who barely seemed to have reached puberty, had been my best friend since fifth grade, when we both finally admitted the evidence that neither of us was likely to find a better friend. Besides, he put a lot of effort into it, and I liked that... most of the time.

en: “How ya doin’?” I asked. We were safely inside, everyone else’s conversations making ours inaudible.
vi: “Sao thế ông?” tôi hỏi. Chúng tôi đã an toàn trong phòng nhạc, những người xung quanh đang nói đủ để lấp đi câu chuyện của bọn tôi.
tr: “Nasılsın?” diye sordum, içeriye girmiştik, diğerlerinin konuşmaları bizimkinin duyulmasını engelliyordu.
es: —¿Qué tal? —le pregunté. Estábamos dentro, en un lugar seguro. Las demás conversaciones impedían que se oyera la nuestra.
vi_translation: “What's wrong, sir?” I asked. We were safe in the music room, the people around us talking enough to drown out our conversation.
tr_translation: "How are you?" I asked. We had entered, and the conversations of the others were preventing ours from being heard.
es_translation: —How are you? —I asked him. We were inside, in a safe place. The other conversations prevented ours from being heard.

en: “Radar is going to prom,” he said morosely. Radar was our other best friend. We called him Radar because he looked like a little bespectacled guy called Radar on this old TV show M*A*S*H, except 1. The TV Radar wasn’t black, and 2. At some point after the nicknaming, our Radar grew about six inches and started wearing contacts, so I suppose that 3. He actually didn’t look like the guy on M*A*S*H at all, but 4. With three and a half weeks left of high school, we weren’t very well going to renickname him.
vi: “Radar sẽ đi dạ hội,” Ben nhấm nhẳng. Radar là chiến hữu oách của bọn tôi. Nó bị gọi là Radar vì trông nó y chang một thằng thấp bé nhẹ cân đeo đít chai tên là Radar trong xê-ri M*A*S*H trên truyền hình ngày xưa, ngoại trừ 1. Radar trên ti-vi da không đen, và 2. Vào một lúc nào đó sau khi đã bị gán tên, Radar của bọn tôi cao thêm khoảng mười lăm phân nữa và bắt đầu đeo kính sát tròng, nên tôi nghĩ rằng 3. Nó trông không còn giống chú em trong M*A*S*H nữa, nhưng 4. Còn ba tuần rưỡi nữa là tốt nghiệp, chúng tôi chẳng buồn đặt tên mới cho nó nữa.
tr: Suratsızca, “Radar baloya gidiyor,” dedi. Radar diğer en yakın arkadaşımızdı. Ona Radar diyorduk çünkü şu eski televizyon dizisi 1 Argoda kalça, kıç anlamlarına gelmektedir, (ç. n. M*A*S*H'teki küçük gözlüklü adama benziyordu, tabii 1. Televizyondaki Radar zenci değildi ve 2. Ona bu lakabı takmamızdan bir süre sonra, bizim Radar on beş santimetre uzadı ve lens takmaya başladı, bu yüzden sanırım 3. Aslmda M*A*S*H'teki adama hiç de benzemiyordu ama 4. Liseye üç buçuk hafta kalmışken ona yeni bir lakap takmaya kalkışmayacaktık.
es: —Radar va a ir al baile de graduación —me dijo malhumorado. Radar era nuestro otro mejor amigo. Lo llamábamos Radar porque se parecía a un tipo bajito y con gafas de la vieja serie de televisión M*A*S*H al que llamaban así, salvo que: 1) El Radar de la tele no era negro, y 2) En algún momento después de haberle puesto el apodo, nuestro Radar creció unos quince centímetros y se puso lentillas, así que supongo que, 3) En realidad, no se parecía en nada al tipo de M*A*S*H, pero, 4) Como quedaban tres semanas y media para que se acabara el curso, no estábamos demasiado preocupados por la labor de buscarle otro apodo.
vi_translation: “Radar is going to the prom,” Ben grumbled. Radar is our awesome comrade. He is called Radar because he looks exactly like a scrawny guy with thick glasses named Radar from the old TV series M*A*S*H, except 1. TV Radar isn't black, and 2. At some point after being nicknamed, our Radar grew about fifteen centimeters taller and started wearing contact lenses, so I think that 3. He no longer looks like the guy from M*A*S*H, but 4. With only three and a half weeks until graduation, we couldn't be bothered to give him a new name.
tr_translation: Grumpily, "Radar is going to the prom," he said. Radar was our other closest friend. We called him Radar because of that old TV show 1 Argoda kalça, kıç anlamlarına gelmektedir, (slang. n.) He looked like the guy with the small glasses in M*A*S*H, of course 1. The Radar on TV wasn't black and 2. A while after we gave him this nickname, our Radar grew fifteen centimeters and started wearing lenses, so I guess 3. Actually, he didn't look like the guy in M*A*S*H at all but 4. With three and a half weeks left until high school, we weren't going to try giving him a new nickname.
es_translation: —Radar is going to the prom —he told me grumpily. Radar was our other best friend. We called him Radar because he looked like a short guy with glasses from the old TV series M*A*S*H who was called that, except that: 1) The TV Radar wasn't black, and 2) At some point after we gave him the nickname, our Radar grew about fifteen centimeters and got contact lenses, so I guess that, 3) In reality, he didn't look anything like the guy from M*A*S*H, but, 4) Since there were only three and a half weeks left until the end of the school year, we weren't too worried about the task of finding him another nickname.

en: “That girl Angela?” I asked. Radar never told us anything about his love life, but this did not dissuade us from frequent speculation.
vi: “Con bé Angela ấy hả?” tôi hỏi. Radar chả bao giờ hé gì về chuyện tình êu tình báo của nó cả, nhưng như thế cũng chẳng ngăn được bọn tôi bàn ra tán vào.
tr: “Şu Angela denen kızla mı?” diye sordum. Radar asla bize aşk hayatından bahsetmezdi ama bu durum bizim sık sık tahmin yürütmemizi engellemezdi.
es: —¿Angela? —le pregunté. Radar nunca nos contaba nada de su vida amorosa, lo que no nos disuadía de especular cada dos por tres.
vi_translation: “That girl Angela?” I asked. Radar never reveals anything about his love life, but that doesn't stop us from gossiping about it.
tr_translation: “With that girl named Angela?” I asked. Radar never talked to us about his love life, but that didn't stop us from frequently speculating.
es_translation: —Angela? —I asked her. Radar never told us anything about his love life, which did not deter us from speculating every now and then.

en: Ben nodded, and then said, “You know my big plan to ask a freshbunny to prom because they’re the only girls who don’t know the Bloody Ben story?” I nodded.
vi: Ben gật, rồi nói, “Ông biết kế hoạch vĩ đại của tôi chứ? Lôi một em thỏ non đến dạ hội vì chỉ có các em thỏ mới không hề hay biết sự tích về chàng Ben Bỉ Bựa.” Tôi gật gật.
tr: Ben başıyla onayladı. “Hani sadece birinci sınıftakiler Kanlı Ben hikâyesini bilmiyor diye o çıtırlardan birini baloya davet etmeyi düşünüyorum ya,” dedi. Başımla onayladım.
es: Ben asintió. —¿Recuerdas que había pensado invitar al baile a una novata, porque son las únicas que no conocen la historia de Ben el Sangriento? Asentí.
vi_translation: Ben nodded, then said, "You know my grand plan, right? Bringing a naive girl to the party because only the naive ones are unaware of the legend of Ben the Awkward." I nodded.
tr_translation: I nodded in agreement. “You know, I'm thinking of inviting one of those freshmen to the ball just because they're the only ones who don't know the Bloody Ben story,” he said. I nodded in agreement.
es_translation: Ben nodded. —Do you remember that I had thought about inviting a freshman to the dance, because they are the only ones who don't know the story of Bloody Ben? I nodded.

en: “Well,” Ben said, “this morning some darling little ninth-grade honeybunny came up to me and asked me if I was Bloody Ben, and I began to explain that it was a kidney infection, and she giggled and ran away. So that’s out.”
vi: “Chậc,” Ben nói tiếp, “thế mà sáng nay có một nhóc thỏ non xinh xinh lớp chín tìm tôi hỏi có phải tôi chính là Ben Bỉ Bựa không, tôi phải giải thích rõ ràng đó là chứng nhiễm trùng thận, con nhóc ấy khúc khích rúc rích cười rồi chạy đi luôn. Hết chuyện.
tr: ‘İşte,” dedi Ben, “bu sabah dokuzuncu sınıflardan küçük, sevimli bir tavşancık bana geldi ve Kanlı Ben olup olmadığımı sordu, ben de bunun bir böbrek enfeksiyonu olduğunu açıklamaya başladım, kız kıkır kıkır güldü ve kaçıp gitti. Yani her şey açığa çıktı.
es: —Bueno —siguió diciendo Ben—, pues esta mañana una novatilla muy mona se me ha acercado y me ha preguntado si era Ben el Sangriento. He empezado a explicarle que fue una infección de riñón, pero se ha reído y se ha largado. Así que se acabó.
vi_translation: “Tsk,” Ben continued, “this morning a cute little ninth-grade bunny came to ask if I was Ben Bỉ Bựa. I had to explain clearly that it was a kidney infection. The little girl giggled and ran away immediately. End of story.”
tr_translation: “So,” said Ben, “this morning a small, cute bunny from the ninth grade came to me and asked if I was Bloody Ben, and I started to explain that it was a kidney infection, the girl giggled and ran away. So everything is out in the open.”
es_translation: —Well —Ben continued—, this morning a very cute freshman came up to me and asked if I was Bloody Ben. I started to explain to her that it was a kidney infection, but she laughed and walked away. So that's it.

en: In tenth grade, Ben was hospitalized for a kidney infection, but Becca Arrington, Margo’s best friend, started a rumor that the real reason he had blood in his urine was due to chronic masturbation. Despite its medical implausibility, this story had haunted Ben ever since. “That sucks,” I said.
vi: Hồi lớp mười, Ben từng phải nhập viện vì bị nhiễm trùng thận, nhưng Becca Arrington, bạn thân của Margo, đã châm ngòi tin đồn rằng nguyên nhân thực sự khiến Ben tiểu ra máu là do nó đã thủ dâm vô độ. Dù vô căn cứ về mặt y học nhưng từ đó những đồn đại cứ bám dính lấy Ben. “Khiếp quá,” tôi không biết nói gì hơn.
tr: Ben, onuncu sınıfta böbrek enfeksiyonu nedeniyle hastaneye yatırılmıştı ama Margo’nun en yakın arkadaşı Becca Arrington, Ben’in idrarında kan olmasının gerçek nedeninin, kronik mastürbasyona bağlı olduğuyla ilgili bir dedikodu yaymıştı. Tıbbi açıdan inandırıcı olmamasına rağmen bu hikâye o zamandan beri Ben’in peşini bırakmamıştı. “Berbat,” dedim.
es: Dos años atrás habían tenido que ingresar a Ben en el hospital por una infección renal, pero Becca Arrington, la mejor amiga de Margo, se dedicó a extender el rumor de que la verdadera razón de que orinara sangre era que se pasaba el día masturbándose. Pese a que era clínicamente inverosímil, desde entonces Ben cargaba con esa historia. —Vaya mierda —le dije.
vi_translation: Back in tenth grade, Ben had to be hospitalized due to a kidney infection, but Becca Arrington, Margo's best friend, sparked a rumor that the real reason Ben was urinating blood was because he had been masturbating excessively. Although medically unfounded, the rumors stuck to Ben ever since. "That's disgusting," I didn't know what else to say.
tr_translation: Ben was hospitalized in the tenth grade due to a kidney infection, but Margo's best friend, Becca Arrington, spread a rumor that the real reason for blood in Ben's urine was chronic masturbation. Although not medically plausible, this story has haunted Ben ever since. "Terrible," I said.
es_translation: Two years ago, they had to admit Ben to the hospital for a kidney infection, but Becca Arrington, Margo's best friend, spread the rumor that the real reason he was urinating blood was because he spent the day masturbating. Even though it was clinically implausible, Ben had been burdened with that story ever since. —What a piece of crap —I told him.

en: Ben started outlining plans for finding a date, but I was only half listening, because through the thickening mass of humanity crowding the hallway, I could see Margo Roth Spiegelman. She was next to her locker, standing beside her boyfriend, Jase. She wore a white skirt to her knees and a blue print top. I could see her collarbone. She was laughing at something hysterical—her shoulders bent forward, her big eyes crinkling at their corners, her mouth open wide. But it didn’t seem to be anything Jase had said, because she was looking away from him, across the hallway to a bank of lockers. I followed her eyes and saw Becca Arrington draped all over some baseball player like she was an ornament and he a Christmas tree. I smiled at Margo, even though I knew she couldn’t see me.
vi: Ben bắt đầu vạch kế hoạch để chăn được một em, nhưng tôi nghe tai nọ ra tai kia, vì phóng mắt qua những người là người mỗi lúc một đông đúc ở hành lang, tôi đã thấy Margo Roth Spiegelman. Cô ấy đứng bên ngăn tủ đựng đồ, cạnh bạn trai của cô ấy, Jase. Margo mặc váy trắng dài đến đầu gối, áo xanh dương có in hình. Tôi thấy được hai bên xương quai xanh của cô ấy. Margo đang cười như nắc nẻ về chuyện gì đó–hai vai so về trước, đôi mắt to anh ánh nước ở khóe, khuôn miệng mở rộng. Nhưng hình như không phải cười vì điều gì Jase nói, vì cô ấy không nhìn Jase mà đưa mắt qua hành lang nhìn một dãy tủ đựng đồ khác. Tôi theo ánh mắt ấy và thấy Becca Arrington đang bám nhằng lấy một anh chàng bóng chày, cứ như nàng là vật trang trí và chàng là cây thông Giáng Sinh vậy. Tôi mỉm cười nhìn Margo, dù tôi biết cô ấy không thấy tôi.
tr: Ben, bir balo partneri ayarlayabilme planlarının ana hatlarını çizmeye başladı ama tam dinlemiyordum çünkü koridora üşüşen insan kalabalığının arasında Margo Roth Spiegelman’ı görebiliyordum. Dolabının hemen önünde, erkek arkadaşı Jase’in yanında duruyordu. Dizlerine gelen beyaz bir etek ve mavi baskılı bir üst giymişti. Köprücük kemiğini görebiliyordum. Kendini kaybetmiş halde bir şeye gülüyordu... omuzları öne doğru eğik, büyük gözlerinin kenarları kırışık, ağzı kocaman açık. Ama Jase’in söylediği bir şeymiş gibi görünmüyordu çünkü ondan uzağa, koridorun karşısındaki dolap sırasına doğru bakıyordu. Gözlerini takip ettim ve Becca Arrington’m bir beyzbol oyuncusunun her yerine asıldığını gördüm; kendisi bir süs eşyası, çocuk da bir Noel ağacıymış gibi. Beni göremeyeceğini bildiğim halde Margo’ya gülümsedim.
es: Ben empezó a contarme sus planes para encontrar a una chica, pero solo lo escuchaba a medias, porque entre la cada vez más densa masa de personas que llenaban el vestíbulo vi a Margo Roth Spiegelman. Estaba junto a su taquilla, al lado de su novio, Jase. Llevaba una falda blanca hasta las rodillas y un top estampado azul. Le veía la clavícula. Se reía como una histérica. Tenía los hombros inclinados hacia delante, las comisuras de sus grandes ojos arrugadas y la boca abierta. Pero no parecía reírse por algo que hubiera dicho Jase, ya que miraba hacia otra parte, hacia las taquillas del otro lado del vestíbulo. Seguí sus ojos y vi a Becca Arrington encima de un jugador de béisbol, como si el tipo fuese un árbol de Navidad y ella un adorno. Sonreí a Margo, aunque sabía que no podía verme.
vi_translation: Ben started planning to hook up with a girl, but I was only half-listening, as my eyes wandered over the increasingly crowded hallway, and I saw Margo Roth Spiegelman. She was standing by her locker, next to her boyfriend, Jase. Margo was wearing a knee-length white skirt and a blue shirt with a print on it. I could see her collarbones. Margo was laughing hard about something—her shoulders hunched forward, her big eyes glistening at the corners, her mouth wide open. But it didn't seem like she was laughing at something Jase said, because she wasn't looking at Jase; she was looking across the hallway at another row of lockers. I followed her gaze and saw Becca Arrington clinging to a baseball player like she was an ornament and he was a Christmas tree. I smiled at Margo, even though I knew she didn't see me.
tr_translation: Ben started outlining plans to arrange a prom date, but I wasn't really listening because I could see Margo Roth Spiegelman among the crowd of people swarming the hallway. She was standing right in front of her locker, next to her boyfriend Jase. She was wearing a white skirt that came down to her knees and a blue printed top. I could see her collarbone. She was laughing at something, completely lost in the moment... her shoulders hunched forward, the corners of her big eyes wrinkled, her mouth wide open. But it didn't seem like it was something Jase had said because she was looking away from him, towards the row of lockers on the opposite side of the hallway. I followed her gaze and I saw Becca Arrington clinging all over a baseball player; as if she were an ornament and the kid a Christmas tree. Even though I knew she couldn't see me, I smiled at Margo.
es_translation: Ben started telling me his plans to find a girl, but I was only half-listening, because amidst the increasingly dense crowd of people filling the lobby, I saw Margo Roth Spiegelman. She was next to her locker, beside her boyfriend, Jase. She was wearing a white knee-length skirt and a blue patterned top. I could see her collarbone. She was laughing hysterically. Her shoulders were hunched forward, the corners of her large eyes wrinkled, and her mouth open. But she didn't seem to be laughing at something Jase had said, as she was looking elsewhere, towards the lockers on the other side of the lobby. I followed her gaze and saw Becca Arrington on top of a baseball player, as if the guy were a Christmas tree and she an ornament. I smiled at Margo, even though I knew she couldn't see me.

en: “Bro, you should just hit that. Forget about Jase. God, that is one candy-coated honeybunny.” As we walked, I kept taking glances at her through the crowd, quick snapshots: a photographic series entitled Perfection Stands Still While Mortals Walk Past. As I got closer, I thought maybe she wasn’t laughing after all. Maybe she’d received a surprise or a gift or something. She couldn’t seem to close her mouth.
vi: “Ông rồ ga lấn tới đi chứ. Mặc kệ thằng Jase. Trời ơi, đúng là một nàng thỏ bọc đường mà,” Ben lảm nhảm. Chân đi nhưng mắt tôi vẫn liếc nhìn cô ấy qua đám đông, chớp lại trong tâm tưởng những khoảnh khắc có thể làm thành một loạt ảnh với tiêu đề Cái đẹp hoàn hảo lắng đọng, chỉ những kẻ phàm bước qua. Đến gần hơn, tôi nghĩ có thể Margo chẳng hề cười. Có thể cô ấy đã ngạc nhiên hoặc nhận được một món quà hay thứ gì đó. Hình như cô ấy không khép miệng lại được.
tr: “Dostum, şuna bir çakmaksın. Jase’i boş ver. Tanrım, bu kız şeker kaplı bir tavşancık.” Biz yürürken kalabalığın arasında Margo’ya ara sıra bakmaya devam ettim; hızlı, anlık fotoğraflar: Ölümlüler Geçip Giderken, Kusursuzluk Olduğu Gibi Duruyor başlıklı bir fotoğraf serisi. Yaklaştıkça, belki de her şeye rağmen gülmüyordu, diye düşündüm. Belki bir sürprizdi, belki bir hediye almıştı ya da öyle bir şey. Ağzını kapatabilecek gibi görünmüyordu.
es: —Deberías lanzarte, colega. Olvídate de Jase. Dios, la pava está para mojar pan. Mientras avanzábamos, seguí lanzándole miradas entre la multitud, rápidas instantáneas, una serie fotográfica titulada La perfección se queda inmóvil mientras los mortales pasan de largo. A medida que me acercaba, pensé que tal vez no estaba riéndose. Quizá le habían dado una sorpresa, un regalo o algo así. Parecía que no pudiera cerrar la boca.
vi_translation: "Step on the gas and go ahead." "Ignore that guy Jase." "Oh my God, she’s really a sugar-coated bunny," Ben mumbled. Walking, but my eyes still glanced at her through the crowd, capturing in my mind moments that could make a series of photos titled The Perfect Beauty in Stillness, only for mere mortals to pass by. Getting closer, I thought maybe Margo didn't smile at all. Maybe she was surprised or received a gift or something. It seemed like she couldn't close her mouth.
tr_translation: “Buddy, give it a light. Forget about Jase. My God, this girl is a sugar-coated bunny.” As we walked, I kept glancing at Margo through the crowd; quick, fleeting snapshots: a photo series titled Mortals Pass By, Perfection Stands Still. As we got closer, I thought, maybe she wasn’t smiling after all. Maybe it was a surprise, maybe she had received a gift or something like that. She didn’t seem like she could close her mouth.
es_translation: —You should go for it, buddy. Forget about Jase. God, that chick is smoking hot. As we moved forward, I kept glancing at her through the crowd, quick snapshots, a photographic series titled Perfection Stays Still While Mortals Pass By. As I got closer, I thought that maybe she wasn't laughing. Maybe she had been surprised, given a gift or something like that. It seemed like she couldn't close her mouth.

en: “Yeah,” I said to Ben, still not listening, still trying to see as much of her as I could without being too obvious. It wasn’t even that she was so pretty. She was just so awesome, and in the literal sense. And then we were too far past her, too many people walking between her and me, and I never even got close enough to hear her speak or understand whatever the hilarious surprise had been. Ben shook his head, because he had seen me see her a thousand times, and he was used to it.
vi: “Ừ,” tôi lơ đãng trả lời Ben, nhưng thực ra không để ý nghe nó nói vì tôi đang cố gắng nhìn Margo càng nhiều càng tốt mà không tỏ ra quá lộ liễu. Thật ra không phải vì Margo xinh. Cô ấy đẹp đến sững sờ luôn, theo nghĩa đen của từng từ. Và rồi bọn tôi đã ở quá xa chỗ cô ấy, có quá nhiều người đi đi lại lại giữa Margo và tôi, thậm chí tôi đã không đến đủ gần để nghe thấy tiếng cô ấy nói, hay để hiểu điều thú vị gì đã khiến cô ấy ngạc nhiên đến vậy. Ben gục gặc đầu vì nó đã thấy tôi nhìn Margo như vậy cả ngàn lần, đến mức nó đã quá quen rồi.
tr: “Evet,” dedim Ben’e, hâlâ dinlemiyordum, hâlâ fazla belli etmeden, olabildiği kadar Margo’yu görmeye çahşıyordum. Mesele çok güzel olması filan değildi. Margo tek kelimeyle müthişti, kelimenin gerçek anlamıyla. Sonra ondan çok öteye geçtik, onunla benim aramda çok fazla insan yürüyordu ve ben, konuşmasını duyacak ya da bu kadar komik olan sürprizin ne olduğunu anlayacak kadar yaklaşamamıştım bile. Ben başını salladı çünkü benim Margo’yu görüşümü binlerce kez görmüştü ve buna alışıktı.
es: —Sí —le dije a Ben. Seguía sin prestarle atención, seguía intentando no perder a Margo de vista sin que se me notara demasiado. No es que fuera una belleza. Era sencillamente impresionante, y en sentido literal. Y entonces la dejamos atrás, entre ella y yo pasaba demasiada gente y en ningún momento me había acercado lo suficiente para escuchar lo que decía o entender cuál había sido la desternillante sorpresa. Ben movió la cabeza. Me había visto mirándola mil veces y estaba acostumbrado.
vi_translation: "Yeah," I absentmindedly answered Ben, but I wasn't really paying attention to what he was saying because I was trying to look at Margo as much as possible without being too obvious. It's not because Margo is pretty. She's stunningly beautiful, in the literal sense of the words. And then we were too far from her, with too many people walking back and forth between Margo and me, that I couldn't even get close enough to hear her voice, or to understand what interesting thing had surprised her so much. Ben nodded because he had seen me look at Margo like that a thousand times, to the point where he was too used to it.
tr_translation: “Yes,” I said to Ben, still not listening, still trying to see Margo as much as possible without making it too obvious. It wasn’t about her being very beautiful or anything. Margo was incredible, in the truest sense of the word. Then we went far beyond her, there were too many people walking between her and me, and I couldn’t even get close enough to hear her talk or understand what the surprise, which was so funny, was. Ben nodded because he had seen me looking at Margo thousands of times and was used to it.
es_translation: —Yes —I said to Ben. I kept not paying attention to him, I kept trying not to lose sight of Margo without making it too obvious. It's not that she was a beauty. She was simply stunning, in the literal sense. And then we left her behind, too many people were passing between her and me, and at no point had I gotten close enough to hear what she was saying or understand what the hilarious surprise had been. Ben shook his head. He had seen me looking at her a thousand times and was used to it.

en: “Honestly, she’s hot, but she’s not that hot. You know who’s seriously hot?”
vi: “Ừ thì cô nàng nóng bỏng, nhưng không nóng bỏng đến mức ấy. Mà ông có biết ai thực sự nóng bỏng không?”
tr: “Doğrusu, Margo seksi ama o kadar da seksi değil. Kim cidden seksi biliyor musun?
es: —La verdad es que está buena, pero no tanto. ¿Sabes quién está buena de verdad?
vi_translation: “Yeah, she's hot, but not that hot. Do you know who is really hot?”
tr_translation: "Honestly, Margo is sexy but not that sexy. Do you know who is really sexy?"
es_translation: —The truth is that she's good-looking, but not that much. Do you know who is really good-looking?

en: “Who?” I asked.
vi: “Ai cơ?” tôi hỏi.
tr: “Kim?” diye sordum.
es: —¿Quién? —le pregunté.
vi_translation: "Who?" I asked.
tr_translation: “Kim?” I asked.
es_translation: —Who? —I asked him.

en: “Lacey,” he said, who was Margo’s other best friend. “Also your mom. Bro, I saw your mom kiss you on the cheek this morning, and forgive me, but I swear to God I was like, man, I wish I was Q. And also, I wish my cheeks had penises.” I elbowed him in the ribs, but I was still thinking about Margo, because she was the only legend who lived next door to me. Margo Roth Spiegelman, whose six-syllable name was often spoken in its entirety with a kind of quiet reverence. Margo Roth Spiegelman, whose stories of epic adventures would blow through school like a summer storm: an old guy living in a broken-down house in Hot Coffee, Mississippi, taught Margo how to play the guitar. Margo Roth Spiegelman, who spent three days traveling with the circus—they thought she had potential on the trapeze. Margo Roth Spiegelman, who drank a cup of herbal tea with the Mallionaires backstage after a concert in St. Louis while they drank whiskey. Margo Roth Spiegelman, who got into that concert by telling the bouncer she was the bassist’s girlfriend, and didn’t they recognize her, and come on guys seriously, my name is Margo Roth Spiegelman and if you go back there and ask the bassist to take one look at me, he will tell you that I either am his girlfriend or he wishes I was, and then the bouncer did so, and then the bassist said “yeah that’s my girlfriend let her in the show,” and then later the bassist wanted to hook up with her and she rejected the bassist from the Mallionaires.
vi: “Lacey,” Ben đáp, Lacey là một bạn thân khác của Margo. “Cả mẹ ông nữa. Tôi đã thấy mẹ ông hun lên má ông sáng nay. Đừng trách tôi nhé, thề có Chúa lúc ấy tôi đã trộm nghĩ: Ôi ôi, giá mà mình là thằng Q. Mà nữa, giá mà hai má mình mọc được tờ-rym thì sướng.” Tôi thúc cùi chỏ vào mạng sườn nó, nhưng tôi vẫn đang nghĩ đến Margo, vì cô ấy là huyền thoại duy nhất ở ngay cạnh nhà tôi. Margo Roth Spiegelman, cái tên dài sáu âm tiết ấy thường được nhắc đến đầy đủ, kèm theo chút thầm ngưỡng mộ. Margo Roth Spiegelman, câu chuyện về những chuyến phiêu lưu kinh điển của cô ấy có thể quét qua trường học như một cơn bão mùa hè: chẳng hạn như chuyện một ông già sống trong căn nhà đổ nát ở Hot Coffee, Mississippi, đã dạy Margo chơi guitar. Margo Roth Spiegelman, cô gái đã rong ruổi suốt ba ngày theo một đoàn xiếc–họ cho rằng cô ấy rất có năng khiếu biểu diễn nhào lộn trên dây. Margo Roth Spiegelman, cô gái đã uống một tách trà thảo mộc cùng ban nhạc The Mallionaires trong hậu trường sau một buổi biểu diễn ở St. Louis, còn họ uống rượu whiskey. Margo Roth Spiegelman, cô gái đã vào được buổi biểu diễn đó bằng cách nói với người soát vé rằng cô là bạn gái của tay guitar bass. Họ không nhận ra cô ư? Thôi nào ông anh, nói nghiêm túc nhé, tôi là Margo Roth Spiegelman, bây giờ nếu ông anh vào trong bảo anh chàng chơi guitar bass hãy nhìn tôi một cái, thì anh chàng sẽ bảo ngay với ông anh rằng tôi là bạn gái anh ta, hoặc anh ta muốn có tôi là bạn gái. Người soát vé làm như vậy thật, và tay bass đã nói “đúng bạn gái tôi đấy, để cô ấy vào đi.” Sau đó anh chàng muốn đi lại nghiêm chỉnh với Margo, và cô ấy đã từ chối tay guitar bass của The Mallionaires.
tr: “Lacey,” dedi. Lacey, Margo’nun diğer en yakın arkadaşıydı. “Bir de annen. Dostum, bu sabah annenin seni yanağından öptüğünü gördüm ve kusura bakma ama yemin ederim şöyleydim: Adamım, keşke Q. ’nun yerinde olsaydım. Ve bir de, keşke yanaklarımın penisi olsaydı.” Dirseğimle kaburgalarına vurdum ama hâlâ Margo’yu düşünüyordum çünkü o bitişiğimizde oturan tek efsaneydi. Altı heceli isminin tamamı, genellikle bir çeşit huşu içinde anılan Margo Roth Spiegelman. Epik macera hikâyeleri, okulda bir yaz fırtınası gibi esip gürleyen Margo Roth Spiegelman: Hot Coffee, Mississippi’de çökük bir evde yaşayan yaşh bir adam, Margo’ya nasıl gitar çalınacağını öğretmiş. Üç gününü sirkle gezerek geçiren Margo Roth Spiegelman... trapezde potansiyeli olduğunu düşünmüşler. St. Louis’deki bir konserden sonra, onlar viski içerken The Mallionaires’le kuliste bir fincan bitki çayı içen Margo Roth Spiegelman. Bu konsere, kapıdaki korumaya basçının kız arkadaşı olduğunu söyleyerek giren Margo Roth Spiegelman. “Beni tanımadınız mı? Haydi çocuklar, cidden ama adım Margo Roth Spiegelman, eğer oraya gidip basçıdan bana bir göz atmasını isterseniz, size ya kız arkadaşı olduğumu ya da öyle olmasını istediğini söyleyecektir.” Koruma tam olarak bunu yapınca basçı, “Evet, kız arkadaşım, gösteriye girmesine izin verin,” demiş, daha sonra Margo’ya asılmak istemiş ve Margo The Mallionaires’in basçısını reddetmiş.
es: —Lacey —me contestó, que era la otra mejor amiga de Margo—. Y tu madre, colega. Esta mañana he visto a tu madre dándote un beso y, perdóname, pero te juro por Dios que he pensado: «Joder, ojalá fuera Q. Y ojalá tuviera pollas en las mejillas». Le pegué un codazo en las costillas, aunque seguía pensando en Margo, porque era el único mito que vivía al lado de mi casa. Margo Roth Spiegelman, cuyo nombre de seis sílabas solíamos decir completo con una especie de silenciosa reverencia. Margo Roth Spiegelman, cuyas épicas aventuras circulaban por el colegio como una tormenta de verano. Un viejo que vivía en una casa destartalada de Hot Coffee, Mississippi, había enseñado a Margo a tocar la guitarra. Margo Roth Spiegelman, que había viajado tres días con un circo, donde pensaban que tenía potencial para el trapecio. Margo Roth Spiegelman, que se había tomado un té de hierbas detrás del escenario de los Mallionaires después de un concierto en Saint Louis, mientras ellos bebían whisky. Margo Roth Spiegelman, que se había colado en aquel concierto diciéndole al segurata que era la novia del bajista, ¿no la reconocían?, vamos, chicos, en serio, soy Margo Roth Spiegelman, y si vais a pedirle al bajista que venga a ver quién soy, os dirá o que soy su novia, o que ojalá lo fuera, y entonces el segurata fue a preguntárselo, y el bajista dijo: «Sí, es mi novia, déjala entrar», y luego el bajista quiso enrollarse con ella, pero ella ¡rechazó al bajista de los Mallionaires!
vi_translation: “Lacey,” Ben replied, Lacey is another close friend of Margo. “And your mom too. I saw your mom kiss you on the cheek this morning. Don’t blame me, I swear to God I thought: Oh man, I wish I were Q. And also, I wish my cheeks could grow some balls.” I elbowed him in the ribs, but I was still thinking about Margo, because she was the only legend living right next door to me. Margo Roth Spiegelman, that six-syllable name was often mentioned in full, accompanied by a bit of admiration. Margo Roth Spiegelman, the stories of her epic adventures could sweep through the school like a summer storm: for instance, the story of an old man living in a dilapidated house in Hot Coffee, Mississippi, who taught Margo to play the guitar. Margo Roth Spiegelman, the girl who traveled for three days with a circus—they thought she had a real talent for tightrope walking. Margo Roth Spiegelman, the girl who drank a cup of herbal tea with the band The Mallionaires backstage after a performance in St. Louis, while they drank whiskey. Margo Roth Spiegelman, the girl who got into that performance by telling the ticket checker that she was the bass guitarist's girlfriend. Didn't they recognize her? Come on man, seriously, I’m Margo Roth Spiegelman, now if you go inside and tell the bass guitarist to take one look at me, he’ll immediately tell you that I’m his girlfriend, or that he wants me to be his girlfriend. The ticket checker did just that, and the bassist said, “Yeah, that’s my girlfriend, let her in.” After that, the guy wanted to date Margo seriously, and she turned down the bassist of The Mallionaires.
tr_translation: “Lacey,” he said. Lacey was Margo's other closest friend. “And your mom. Dude, I saw your mom kiss you on the cheek this morning and sorry, but I swear I was like: Man, I wish I were Q. ’s place. And also, I wish my cheeks had a penis.” I elbowed him in the ribs but was still thinking about Margo because she was the only legend who lived next door to us. Her full six-syllable name, usually spoken with a kind of awe, Margo Roth Spiegelman. Epic adventure stories, Margo Roth Spiegelman who stormed through school like a summer storm: An old man living in a dilapidated house in Hot Coffee, Mississippi, had taught Margo how to play the guitar. She spent three days with the circus Margo Roth Spiegelman, who spent her time wandering... they thought she had potential on the trapeze. St. After a concert in St. Louis, while they were drinking whiskey, Margo Roth Spiegelman was backstage drinking a cup of herbal tea with The Mallionaires. Margo Roth Spiegelman, who got into this concert by telling the guard at the door that she was the bassist's girlfriend. “Don't you recognize me? Come on guys, seriously, my name is Margo Roth Spiegelman, if you go and ask the bassist to take a look at me, he will either tell you that I am his girlfriend or that he wants me to be.” When the guard did exactly that, the bassist said, “Yes, she is my girlfriend, let her into the show,” later he tried to hit on Margo, and Margo rejected The Mallionaires' bassist.
es_translation: —Lacey —she replied, who was Margo's other best friend—. And your mother, dude. This morning I saw your mother giving you a kiss and, forgive me, but I swear to God I thought: "Damn, I wish I were Q. And I wish I had dicks on my cheeks." I elbowed him in the ribs, although I kept thinking about Margo, because she was the only myth living next door to my house. Margo Roth Spiegelman, whose six-syllable name we used to say in full with a kind of silent reverence. Margo Roth Spiegelman, whose epic adventures circulated around the school like a summer storm. An old man who lived in a ramshackle house in Hot Coffee, Mississippi, had taught Margo to play the guitar. Margo Roth Spiegelman, who had traveled for three days with a circus, where they thought she had potential for the trapeze. Margo Roth Spiegelman, who had sipped herbal tea backstage with the Mallionaires after a concert in Saint Louis, while they drank whiskey. Margo Roth Spiegelman, who had sneaked into that concert by telling the security guard that she was the bassist's girlfriend, didn't they recognize her?, come on, guys, seriously, I'm Margo Roth Spiegelman, and if you're going to ask the bassist to come see who I am, he'll either say I'm his girlfriend or that he wishes I were, and then the security guard went to ask him, and the bassist said: "Yes, she's my girlfriend, let her in," and then the bassist wanted to make out with her, but she rejected the bassist of the Mallionaires!

en: The stories, when they were shared, inevitably ended with, I mean, can you believe it? We often could not, but they always proved true.
vi: Những chuyện ấy, khi được kể đi kể lại, luôn kết thúc bằng câu Thế đấy, có tin được không ta? Thường là không thể tin nổi, nhưng đó luôn là những chuyện có thật.
tr: Hikâyeler başkalarıyla paylaşıldığında, kaçınılmaz olarak Yani, buna inanabiliyor musun? cümlesiyle bitiyordu. Genellikle inanamazdık ama daima doğrulukları kanıtlanırdı.
es: Cuando comentábamos sus historias, siempre acabábamos diciendo: «Vaya, ¿te lo imaginas?». En general, no podíamos imaginárnoslas, pero siempre resultaban ser ciertas.
vi_translation: Those stories, when retold, always end with the phrase "So there, can you believe it?" Usually, it's unbelievable, but those are always true stories.
tr_translation: When stories were shared with others, they inevitably ended with the sentence "So, can you believe it?" We usually couldn't believe it, but their truth was always proven.
es_translation: When we talked about his stories, we always ended up saying, "Wow, can you imagine that?". In general, we couldn't imagine them, but they always turned out to be true.

en: And then we were at our lockers. Radar was leaning against Ben’s locker, typing into a handheld device.
vi: Bọn tôi đến chỗ ngăn tủ cá nhân của mình. Radar đang dựa lưng vào ngăn của Ben, tay bấm bấm máy tính cầm tay.
tr: Sonra dolaplarımızın yanındaydık. Radar, Ben’in dolabma yaslanmış, elde kullanılan bir alete bir şeyler yazıyordu.
es: Y llegamos a nuestras taquillas. Radar estaba apoyado en la de Ben, tecleando en su ordenador de bolsillo.
vi_translation: We went to our personal lockers. Radar was leaning against Ben's locker, tapping away on a handheld calculator.
tr_translation: Then we were next to our lockers. Radar was leaning against Ben's locker, writing something on a handheld device.
es_translation: And we arrived at our lockers. Radar was leaning against Ben's, typing on his handheld computer.

en: “So you’re going to prom,” I said to him. He looked up, and then looked back down.
vi: “Vậy là ông sẽ đến dạ hội tốt nghiệp,” tôi nói với nó. Radar ngước lên rồi lập tức cúi xuống.
tr: Radar’a, ‘Yani baloya gidiyorsun,” dedim. Yukan doğru baktı, sonra tekrar aşağı.
es: —Así que vas a ir al baile —le dije. Levantó la mirada y volvió a bajarla.
vi_translation: “So you will be attending the prom,” I said to him. Radar looked up and then immediately looked down.
tr_translation: I said to Radar, "So you're going to the ball." He looked up, then back down again.
es_translation: —So you're going to the dance —I said to her. He lifted his gaze and then lowered it again.

en: “I’m de-vandalizing the Omnictionary article about a former prime minister of France. Last night someone deleted the entire entry and then replaced it with the sentence ‘Jacques Chirac is a gay,’ which as it happens is incorrect both factually and grammatically.” Radar is a big-time editor of this online user-created reference source called Omnictionary. His whole life is devoted to the maintenance and well-being of Omnictionary. This was but one of several reasons why his having a prom date was somewhat surprising.
vi: “Tôi đang chấn chỉnh một bài viết trong Toàn Thư Đủ Thứ về cựu Thủ Tướng Pháp. Đêm qua thằng xỏ lá nào đó đã xóa toàn bộ bài và chèn vào câu Jacques Chirac đang bị đồng tính, một điều không chính xác cả về thực tế lẫn ngữ pháp.” Radar là biên tập viên cự phách của một trang thông tin tham khảo trực tuyến do cộng đồng mạng sáng lập, tên đầy đủ là Toàn Thư Đủ Thứ. Cả đời nó tận tâm cống hiến để duy trì và phát triển kho Toàn Thư này. Đây là một trong những lí do tại sao việc nó hẹn hò đi dạ hội lại là chuyện đáng ngạc nhiên đến vậy.
tr: “Eski Fransız başbakanıyla ilgili bir Omnictionary2 makalesine yapılan vandallığı düzeltiyorum. Dün gece biri bütün maddeyi silmiş ve ‘Jacques Chirac eşcinsel’ cümlesiyle değiştirmiş ki bu aslında hem gerçekler hem de dilbilgisi açısından yanlış.” Radar, kullanıcılar tarafından yaratılmış, Omnictionary adındaki bu internet referans kaynağının editörlerinden biri. Bütün hayatı Omnictionary’nin bakımına ve esenliğine adanmıştı. Baloya biriyle gitmesinin bu kadar hayret verici olmasının muhtelif nedenlerinden biri de buydu.
es: —Estoy destrozando el artículo del Omnictionary sobre un exprimer ministro francés. Anoche alguien borró toda la entrada y escribió «Jacques Chirac es un gay», que resulta que es incorrecto tanto semántica como gramaticalmente. Radar es un activo editor del Omnictionary, una enciclopedia online que crean los usuarios. Dedica su vida entera a mantener y cuidar el Omnictionary. Y esa era una de las diversas razones por las que nos sorprendía que hubiera invitado a una chica al baile de graduación.
vi_translation: “I am correcting an article in the Encyclopedia of Everything about the former Prime Minister of France. Last night, some rascal deleted the entire article and inserted the sentence that Jacques Chirac is homosexual, which is incorrect both factually and grammatically.” Radar is a top-notch editor of an online reference site founded by the online community, fully named the Encyclopedia of Everything. His whole life, he has been dedicated to maintaining and developing this Encyclopedia. This is one of the reasons why it is so surprising that he is going on a date to a gala.
tr_translation: “I am correcting the vandalism on an Omnictionary2 article about the former French prime minister. Last night, someone deleted the entire entry and replaced it with the sentence 'Jacques Chirac is gay,' which is actually incorrect both factually and grammatically.” Radar is one of the editors of this internet reference source called Omnictionary, created by users. His whole life was dedicated to the maintenance and well-being of Omnictionary. This was one of the various reasons why it was so surprising that he was going to the ball with someone.
es_translation: —I am fixing the Omnictionary article about a former French prime minister. Last night someone deleted the entire entry and wrote "Jacques Chirac is a gay," which turns out to be incorrect both semantically and grammatically. Radar is an active editor of the Omnictionary, an online encyclopedia created by users. He dedicates his entire life to maintaining and caring for the Omnictionary. And that was one of the various reasons why it surprised us that he had invited a girl to the prom.

en: “So you’re going to prom,” I repeated.
vi: “Vậy là ông sẽ đến dạ hội tốt nghiệp nhỉ,” tôi nhắc lại.
tr: ‘Yani baloya gidiyorsun,” diye tekrarladım.
es: —Así que vas a ir al baile —repetí.
vi_translation: “So you will be attending the graduation ball, right,” I reiterated.
tr_translation: “So, you are going to the ball,” I repeated.
es_translation: —So you're going to the dance —I repeated.

en: “Sorry,” he said without looking up. It was a well-known fact that I was opposed to prom. Absolutely nothing about any of it appealed to me—not slow dancing, not fast dancing, not the dresses, and definitely not the rented tuxedo. Renting a tuxedo seemed to me an excellent way to contract some hideous disease from its previous tenant, and I did not aspire to become the world’s only virgin with pubic lice.
vi: “Xin lỗi nhé,” nó nói mà chẳng buồn nhìn lên. Thằng nào cũng biết là tôi ớn vụ dạ hội. Hoàn toàn và tuyệt đối không có gì về cái dạ hội ấy hấp dẫn được tôi–nhảy điệu slow ư, nhảy nhạc bốc ư, váy vóc xúng xính ư, bộ vét đuôi tôm đi thuê ư, không gì sất. Đi thuê vét đuôi tôm đối với tôi là cách hoàn hảo để bị lây nhiễm một thứ bệnh kinh khủng nào đó từ người từng mặc bộ quần áo ấy, và tôi không ham là chàng trai trong trắng duy nhất trên thế gian này chăn trên mình cả một bầy rận mu.
tr: 2 Wikipedia’ya benzeyen bir internet ansiklopedisi. Kitapta bu isim kullanıldıktan sonra benzer bir internet sitesi açılmıştır ancak şu an hizmet dışıdır, (ç. n. “Kusura bakma,” dedi başını kaldırmadan. Baloya karşı olduğum, herkes taralından bilinen bir gerçekti. Baloyla ilgili hiçbir şey bana kesinlikle cazip gelmiyordu... ne yavaş dans etmek, ne hızlı dans etmek, ne elbiseler ne de kiralık smokin. Smokin kiralamak, bana önceki kiracısından gelen korkunç bir hastahğa yakalanmanın kusursuz bir yolu gibi görünüyordu ve dünyanın tek kasık biti taşıyan bakiri olmaya hevesli değildim.
es: —Perdona —me contestó sin levantar la mirada. Todo el mundo sabía que yo me negaba a ir al baile. No me llamaba lo más mínimo la atención: ni bailar lentos, ni bailar rápidos, ni los trajes, y todavía menos el esmoquin alquilado. Alquilar un esmoquin me parecía una excelente manera de pillar cualquier espantosa enfermedad del anterior arrendatario, y no era mi intención convertirme en el único virgen del mundo con ladillas.
vi_translation: “Sorry,” he said without bothering to look up. Everyone knows I dread the prom. Absolutely nothing about that prom appeals to me—slow dancing, fast dancing, fancy dresses, rented tuxedos, nothing at all. Renting a tuxedo, to me, is the perfect way to catch some horrible disease from whoever wore that suit before, and I have no desire to be the only pure guy in the world covered in a swarm of lice.
tr_translation: An internet encyclopedia similar to Wikipedia. After this name was used in the book, a similar website was launched but it is currently out of service, (tr. n.) “Sorry,” he said without raising his head. It was a well-known fact by everyone that I was against the ball. Nothing about the ball seemed appealing to me at all... neither slow dancing, nor fast dancing, nor the dresses nor the rented tuxedos. Renting a tuxedo seemed to me like a perfect way to catch a terrible disease from the previous renter, and I wasn't eager to be the world's only virgin carrying pubic lice.
es_translation: —Sorry —he replied without raising his gaze. Everyone knew that I refused to go to the dance. It didn't interest me in the slightest: neither slow dances, nor fast dances, nor the suits, and even less the rented tuxedo. Renting a tuxedo seemed to me an excellent way to catch any dreadful disease from the previous renter, and it was not my intention to become the only virgin in the world with crabs.

en: “Bro,” Ben said to Radar, “the freshhoneys know about the Bloody Ben story.” Radar put the handheld away finally and nodded sympathetically. “So anyway,” Ben continued, “my two remaining strategies are either to purchase a prom date on the Internet or fly to Missouri and kidnap some nice corn-fed little honeybunny.” I’d tried telling Ben that “honeybunny” sounded more sexist and lame than retro-cool, but he refused to abandon the practice. He called his own mother a honeybunny. There was no fixing him.
vi: “Này ông,” Ben nói với Radar, “các em thỏ non bé bỏng đã biết hết chuyện Ben Bỉ Bựa rồi.” Rút cục Radar chịu cất cái máy cầm tay đi, gật gật đầy thông cảm và thấu hiểu. “Dù sao,” Ben tiếp tục, “hai chiến thuật còn lại của tôi là vào Internet rao quảng cáo cần tìm người đi dạ hội cùng, hoặc bay đến Missouri bắt cóc một nàng thỏ ngon ngon, ngoan ngoan, ngu ngu nào đó về vậy.” Tôi từng cố nói với Ben rằng “nàng thỏ non” nghe có vẻ phân biệt giới và yếu đuối quá, không có chút cá tính nào cả, nhưng nó vẫn không chịu thay đổi thói quen. Cả mẹ nó cũng bị nó gọi là thỏ. Thật đúng là hết thuốc chữa với thằng này.
tr: “Dostum,” dedi Ben, Radar’a, “çıtırlar, Kanlı Ben hikâyesini biliyorlar.” Radar elindeki aleti sonunda bir kenara koydu ve anlayışlı bir şekilde başını salladı. Ben, “Her neyse,” diye devam etti, “kalan iki stratejim ya internetten bir balo partneri ayarlamak ya da Missouri’ye uçup mısırla beslenmiş hoş, küçük bir tavşancığı kaçırmak.” Ben’e “tavşancık” kelimesinin kulağa “retro”dan daha cinsiyetçi ve daha zavallı geldiğini söylemeye çalışmıştım ama bu huyundan vazgeçmedi. Kendi annesine bile tavşancık derdi. Ben’i düzeltmenin yolu yoktu.
es: —Colega —dijo Ben a Radar—, las novatas se han enterado de la historia de Ben el Sangriento. —Radar se guardó por fin el ordenador y cabeceó con expresión compasiva—. Así que las dos únicas estrategias que me quedan son buscar a una pareja para el baile en internet o volar a Missouri y raptar a alguna pava alimentada a base de maíz. Yo había intentado explicarle a Ben que «pava» sonaba bastante más sexista y patético que «retroguay», pero se negaba a dejar de decirlo. Llamaba pava a su propia madre. No tenía arreglo.
vi_translation: "Hey man," Ben said to Radar, "the little bunnies already know all about Ben the Jerk." Finally, Radar put away his handheld device, nodding sympathetically and understandingly. "Anyway," Ben continued, "my two remaining strategies are to advertise on the Internet for a prom date, or fly to Missouri to kidnap some cute, obedient, dumb bunny." I had tried to tell Ben that "bunny" sounded too sexist and weak, lacking any personality, but he still wouldn't change his habit. He even called his own mother a bunny. This guy is truly hopeless.
tr_translation: “Buddy,” said Ben to Radar, “the chicks know the Bloody Ben story.” Radar finally put the gadget he was holding aside and nodded understandingly. Ben continued, “Anyway, my remaining two strategies are either to find a prom date online or to fly to Missouri and kidnap a nice, little corn-fed bunny.” I had tried to tell Ben that the word “bunny” sounded more sexist and pathetic than “retro,” but he wouldn’t give up the habit. He even called his own mother “bunny.” There was no way to correct Ben.
es_translation: —Colleague —Ben said to Radar—, the freshmen have found out about the story of Bloody Ben. —Radar finally put away his computer and nodded with a sympathetic expression—. So the only two strategies I have left are to find a date for the dance online or fly to Missouri and kidnap some corn-fed chick. I had tried to explain to Ben that "pava" sounded much more sexist and pathetic than "retro-cool," but he refused to stop saying it. He called his own mother "pava." He was hopeless.

en: “I’ll ask Angela if she knows anybody,” Radar said. “Although getting you a date to prom will be harder than turning lead into gold.”
vi: “Tôi sẽ hỏi Angela xem có biết ai không,” Radar nói. “Cơ mà cua được một em chịu đi dạ hội với ông còn khó hơn cả chuyện luyện chì thành vàng.
tr: Radar, “Birini tanıyor mu diye Angela’ya sorarım,” dedi. “Gerçi sana bir balo partneri ayarlamak, kurşunu altına dönüştürmekten daha zor olacak.
es: —Le preguntaré a Angela si sabe de alguien —dijo Radar—. Aunque conseguirte pareja para el baile será más duro que convertir el plomo en oro.
vi_translation: “I will ask Angela if she knows anyone,” Radar said. “But getting a girl to go to the prom with you is harder than turning lead into gold.”
tr_translation: Radar said, "I will ask Angela if she knows anyone." "Though finding you a ball partner will be harder than turning lead into gold."
es_translation: —I'll ask Angela if she knows anyone —said Radar—. Although getting you a date for the dance will be harder than turning lead into gold.

en: “Getting you a date to prom is so hard that the hypothetical idea itself is actually used to cut diamonds,” I added.
vi: “Cua được một em chịu đi dạ hội với ông là chuyện khó nhằn đến mức riêng giả thuyết ấy thôi đã đủ sức rắn cắt được kim cương rồi,” tôi bồi thêm.
tr: “Sana bir balo randevusu ayarlamak o kadar güç ki, farazi fikrin kendisi bile aslında elmas kesmekte kullanılabilir,” diye ekledim.
es: —Conseguirte pareja para el baile es tan duro que solo de imaginarlo se pueden cortar diamantes —añadí.
vi_translation: “Getting a girl to agree to go to the dance with you is so tough that just the hypothesis alone is enough to cut diamonds,” I added.
tr_translation: “Setting up a ball date for you is so difficult that the very idea itself could actually be used to cut diamonds,” I added.
es_translation: —Getting a date for the dance is so tough that just thinking about it could cut diamonds —I added.

en: Radar tapped a locker twice with his fist to express his approval, and then came back with another. “Ben, getting you a date to prom is so hard that the American government believes the problem cannot be solved with diplomacy, but will instead require force.”
vi: Radar khẽ đấm hai cú vào ngăn tủ để bày tỏ sự tán thành, và tiếp tục đi đến kết luận. “Ben này, cua được một em chịu đi dạ hội với ông là chuyện gian nguy đến mức Chính phủ Hoa Kì tin rằng vấn đề không thể giải quyết được bằng đường ngoại giao, mà phải viện đến vũ lực.”
tr: Radar onayladığını göstermek için yumruğuyla dolaba iki kere hafifçe vurdu ve başka bir taneyle devam etti. “Ben, sana balo randevusu ayarlamak o kadar zor ki, Amerikan hükümeti sorunun diplomasiyle çözülemeyeceğine, bunun yerine kaba kuvvet gerektirdiğine inanıyor.
es: Radar dio un par de puñetazos a una taquilla para expresar que estaba de acuerdo y después soltó otra frase: —Ben, conseguirte pareja para el baile es tan duro que el gobierno de Estados Unidos cree que el problema no puede resolverse por la vía diplomática, sino que exigirá el uso de la fuerza.
vi_translation: Radar lightly punched the locker twice to show his approval and continued to the conclusion. "Ben, getting a girl to agree to go to the prom with you is so challenging that the United States government believes the issue cannot be resolved through diplomacy and must resort to force."
tr_translation: Radar lightly tapped the cabinet twice with his fist to show he agreed and continued with another one. "I tell you, getting you a prom date is so difficult that the American government believes the problem can't be solved with diplomacy and instead requires brute force."
es_translation: Radar gave a couple of punches to a locker to show he agreed and then released another phrase: —Ben, getting you a date for the dance is so tough that the United States government believes the problem cannot be resolved through diplomatic means, but will require the use of force.

en: I was trying to think of another one when we all three simultaneously saw the human-shaped container of anabolic steroids known as Chuck Parson walking toward us with some intent. Chuck Parson did not participate in organized sports, because to do so would distract from the larger goal of his life: to one day be convicted of homicide. “Hey, faggots,” he called.
vi: Tôi đang nghĩ dở vế tiếp theo thì cả ba thằng cùng trông thấy cái bình đựng hoóc-môn tăng cơ có hình dạng con người tên là Chuck Parson đang hằm hằm tiến lại phía chúng tôi. Chuck Parson không chơi trong đội thể thao nào cả vì như thế sẽ làm xao nhãng mục tiêu to tát của đời nó: một ngày nào đó được kết tội giết người. “Này, mấy thằng ái kia,” nó gọi.
tr: Başka bir tane düşünmeye çalışıyordum ki hepimiz o anda, bize doğru bir amaçla yürüyen ve Chuck Parson olarak tanınan insan şeklindeki anabolik steroit kabım gördük. Chuck Parson sporlara katılmazdı çünkü bu, dikkatini hayatının en büyük amacından başka yöne çekerdi: bir gün cinayetten mahkûm edilmek. “Hey, ibneler,” diye seslendi.
es: Estaba pensando en otra ocurrencia cuando los tres a la vez vimos al bote de esteroides anabólicos con forma humana conocido como Chuck Parson acercándose a nosotros con algún propósito. Chuck Parson no participaba en deportes de grupo porque eso lo distraería de su principal objetivo en la vida: que algún día lo condenaran por homicidio. —Hola, maricas —dijo.
vi_translation: I was still thinking about the next part when all three of us saw the muscle-building hormone container shaped like a human named Chuck Parson angrily approaching us. Chuck Parson didn't play on any sports team because it would distract him from his life's grand goal: to one day be convicted of murder. "Hey, you fags," he called.
tr_translation: I was trying to think of another one when we all saw, at that moment, the human-shaped anabolic steroid container known as Chuck Parson walking towards us with a purpose. Chuck Parson did not participate in sports because it would distract him from the greatest goal of his life: to one day be convicted of murder. "Hey, faggots," he called out.
es_translation: I was thinking about another occurrence when the three of us simultaneously saw the human-shaped bottle of anabolic steroids known as Chuck Parson approaching us with some purpose. Chuck Parson didn't participate in team sports because that would distract him from his main goal in life: to one day be convicted of homicide. —Hello, faggots —he said.

en: “Chuck,” I answered, as friendly as I could muster. Chuck hadn’t given us any serious trouble in a couple years—someone in cool kid land laid down the edict that we were to be left alone. So it was a little unusual for him even to talk to us.
vi: “Chào Chuck,” tôi đáp, dàn hòa cầu thân hết mức có thể. Mấy năm nay Chuck không xích mích gì nghiêm trọng với bọn tôi–có đứa trong đám có máu mặt đã phán rằng như thế là bọn tôi được yên thân. Thế nên khi chính Chuck bắt chuyện với bọn tôi thì điều này có vẻ kì kì.
tr: Rol yapabileceğim kadar arkadaşça, “Chuck,” diye karşılık verdim. Chuck birkaç yıldır bize ciddi bir sorun yaratmıyordu... havalı çocuklar ülkesinden biri, rahat bırakılmamız gerektiğiyle ilgili bir ferman çıkarmıştı. Yani bizimle konuşması bile biraz tuhaftı.
es: —Chuck —le contesté lo más amigablemente que pude. Chuck no nos había causado ningún problema grave en los dos últimos años, porque alguien del bando de los guays había dado la orden de que nos dejaran en paz, así que Chuck ni siquiera nos dirigía la palabra.
vi_translation: "Hello Chuck," I replied, trying to be as conciliatory as possible. In recent years, Chuck hasn't had any serious conflicts with us—some of the more influential members had declared that this meant we were safe. So when Chuck himself started a conversation with us, it seemed a bit strange.
tr_translation: As friendly as I could manage, I replied, "Chuck." Chuck hadn't caused us any serious problems for a few years... someone from the land of the cool kids had issued a decree that we should be left alone. So it was a bit strange for him to even talk to us.
es_translation: —Chuck —I responded as amicably as I could. Chuck hadn't caused us any serious problems in the last two years, because someone from the cool kids' side had given the order to leave us alone, so Chuck didn't even speak to us.

en: Maybe because I spoke and maybe not, he slammed his hands against the lockers on either side of me and then leaned in close enough for me to contemplate his toothpaste brand. “What do you know about Margo and Jase?”
vi: Có thể tại tôi đã mở miệng, hoặc cũng có thể không phải vậy, nhưng Chuck đã đấm uỳnh hai nắm tay lên cánh cửa tủ đựng đồ, găm tôi ở giữa, gí mặt sát lại đến mức tôi có thể tha hồ suy đoán xem nó đã dùng loại thuốc đánh răng nào. “Mày biết gì về Margo và Jase?”
tr: Belki konuştuğum için belki başka sebepten, ellerini iki yanımdan dolaplara çarparak koydu ve diş macunu markasmı tahmin edebileceğim kadar yakınıma eğildi. “Margo ve Jase hakkında ne biliyorsun?
es: Quizá porque fui yo el que le había contestado, o quizá no, apoyó las dos manos en la taquilla, conmigo en medio, y se acercó lo suficiente para que considerara qué marca de dentífrico utilizaba. —¿Qué sabes de Margo y Jase?
vi_translation: Maybe it was because I opened my mouth, or maybe not, but Chuck slammed both fists onto the locker doors, pinning me in between, his face so close that I could easily guess which toothpaste he used. "What do you know about Margo and Jase?"
tr_translation: Maybe because I was talking or maybe for another reason, he placed his hands on the cupboards on either side of me and leaned in so close that I could guess the brand of his toothpaste. "What do you know about Margo and Jase?"
