I chatted online with Ben, and after a while Radar also came online. During the conversation, he mentioned "the world's largest collection of black Santas" four times, each time making me chuckle. I told him that I was very happy he had a girlfriend. He said this summer would be fun. I agreed. Today is the fifth of May, but it doesn't really matter. My days are pleasantly similar. I always liked it that way: a regular routine. I liked the feeling of slight boredom. I didn't want to like it, but I did. And so the fifth of May could be any day—until just before midnight that night, when Margo Roth Spiegelman slid open the screenless window of my room, for the first time since she told me to close it nine years ago.
tr_translation: I went home. Before dinner, I ate two peanut butter and jelly sandwiches. I watched poker on TV. At six, my parents came home, hugged each other first, then hugged me. We ate baked pasta as a proper dinner. They asked questions about school. They asked questions about the prom. They marveled at what a great job they did raising me. They talked about their days spent dealing with people who weren't raised as skillfully as I was. They went to watch TV. I went to my room to check my emails. I wrote something about The Great Gatsby for English class. I read some of The Federalist Papers in preparation for my political science exam. I messaged with Ben online, then Radar came online. Radar used the phrase "the world's largest collection of black Santas" four times during our conversation, and I laughed each time. I told him I was happy for him because he had a girlfriend. He said it was going to be a great summer. I agreed. It was the fifth of May, but it didn't have to be. My days were passing in a happy monotony. I had always loved this: I loved the routine. I loved being bored. I didn't want to, but I loved it. So the fifth of May could have been any day... until just before midnight; until Margo Roth Spiegelman, for the first time since she told me to close it nine years ago, pushed open my bedroom window, which no longer had a screen.
es_translation: I returned home. I ate two peanut butter and jelly sandwiches for a snack. I watched poker on TV. My parents arrived at six, they hugged each other and then hugged me. We had macaroni for dinner. They asked me about school. Then they asked me about the prom. They marveled at how well they had raised me. They told me that in their time they had to deal with people who weren't raised as well. They went to watch TV. I went to my room to check the mail. I wrote for a while about The Great Gatsby for literature class. I read The Federalist for a while to prepare in advance for the final politics exam. I chatted with Ben and then Radar logged on too. In our conversation, he used the phrase "the world's largest collection of black Santas" four times and I laughed each time. I told him I was glad he had a girlfriend. He said that summer would be great. I agreed. It was May 5th, but it could have been any other day. My days were peacefully identical to each other. I had always liked it. I liked the routine. I liked being bored. I didn't want to, but I liked it. And that's why that May 5th could have been any other day... until just before midnight, when Margo Roth Spiegelman opened my bedroom window, without a screen, for the first time since that night she had asked me to close it, nine years ago.

en: I swiveled around when I heard the window open, and Margo’s blue eyes were staring back at me. Her eyes were all I could see at first, but as my vision adjusted, I realized she was wearing black face paint and a black hoodie. “Are you having cybersex?” she asked.
vi: Tôi quay lại khi nghe thấy tiếng cửa mở, và đôi mắt xanh của Margo đang chăm chú nhìn tôi. Thoạt đầu đôi mắt cô ấy là tất cả những gì tôi thấy được, nhưng khi thị giác đã điều chỉnh, tôi nhận ra Margo bôi đen mặt và mặc áo khoác có mũ màu đen. “Cậu đang gạ tình qua mạng đấy à?” cô ấy hỏi tôi.
tr: Pencerenin açıldığım duyunca bir anda döndüm; Margo’nun mavi gözleri bana bakıyordu. Önce tek görebildiğim şey gözleriydi ama odaklanabildikten sonra, yüzünün siyaha boyalı olduğunu ve siyah kapüşonlu bir ceket giydiğini fark ettim. “Sanal seks mi yapıyorsun?” diye sordu.
es: Al oír que la ventana se abría, me giré y vi que los ojos azules de Margo me miraban fijamente. Al principio solo vi sus ojos, pero en cuanto se me adaptó la vista me di cuenta de que tenía la cara pintada de negro y de que llevaba una sudadera negra. —¿Estás practicando cibersexo? —me preguntó.
vi_translation: I turned around when I heard the door open, and Margo's blue eyes were intently looking at me. At first, her eyes were all I could see, but as my vision adjusted, I realized Margo had blackened her face and was wearing a black hooded coat. "Are you flirting online?" she asked me.
tr_translation: When I heard the window open, I turned around instantly; Margo's blue eyes were looking at me. At first, the only thing I could see were her eyes, but after focusing, I noticed that her face was painted black and she was wearing a black hooded jacket. "Are you having virtual sex?" she asked.
es_translation: Upon hearing the window open, I turned around and saw Margo's blue eyes staring intently at me. At first, I only saw her eyes, but as soon as my vision adjusted, I realized that her face was painted black and she was wearing a black hoodie. —Are you practicing cybersex? —he asked me.

en: “I’m IM’ing with Ben Starling.”
vi: “Tớ đang chát chíu với Ben Starling.”
tr: “Ben Starling’le mesajlaşıyorum.
es: —Estoy chateando con Ben Starling.
vi_translation: “I'm chatting with Ben Starling.”
tr_translation: “I am texting with Ben Starling.”
es_translation: —I'm chatting with Ben Starling.

en: “That doesn’t answer my question, perv.”
vi: “Điều đó không trả lời câu hỏi của tớ, đồ dê cụ.”
tr: “Bu benim sorumu cevaplamıyor, sapık.
es: —Eso no responde a mi pregunta, pervertido.
vi_translation: “That doesn't answer my question, you old goat.”
tr_translation: “This doesn't answer my question, pervert.”
es_translation: —That doesn't answer my question, pervert.

en: I laughed awkwardly, then walked over and knelt by the window, my face inches from hers. I couldn’t imagine why she was here, in my window, like this. “To what do I owe the pleasure?” I asked. Margo and I were still friendly, I guess, but we weren’t meet-in-the-dead-of-night-wearing-black-face-paint friendly. She had friends for that, I’m sure. I just wasn’t among them.
vi: Tôi cười như mếu, rồi đi đến cửa sổ và quì xuống, mặt tôi chỉ cách mặt cô ấy vài phân. Tôi không thể hiểu được sao cô ấy lại ở đây, bên cửa sổ phòng tôi, như thế này. “Sao tớ lại có vinh hạnh này đây?” tôi hỏi. Margo và tôi vẫn là bạn bè, tôi nghĩ thế, nhưng không phải kiểu bạn gặp-nhau-lúc-nửa-đêm-với-bộ-mặt-bôi-đen. Tôi dám chắc cô ấy có bạn bè cho kiểu hoàn cảnh này. Và tôi không nằm trong số bạn đó.
tr: Tuhaf bir şekilde, güldüm, sonra oraya doğru yürüdüm, pencerenin kenarına diz çöküp oturdum, yüzüm onunkine çok yalandı. Neden burada, penceremde, bu şekilde olduğunu tahmin edemedim. “Bu şerefi neye borçluyum?” diye sordum. Margo’yla hâlâ samimiydik, sanırım ama “gecenin köründe siyah boyalı bir yüzle buluşma” ayarlayacak kadar değil. Bunun için de arkadaşları olduğuna «minim. Sadece ben onların arasında değildim.
es: Me reí con torpeza y luego me acerqué a la ventana, me arrodillé y me coloqué a solo unos centímetros de su cara. No podía imaginarme por qué estaba allí, en mi ventana, y con la cara pintada. —¿A qué debo el placer? —le pregunté. Margo y yo seguíamos teniendo buen rollo, supongo, pero no hasta el punto de quedar en plena noche con la cara pintada de negro. Para eso ya tenía a sus amigos, seguro. Yo no estaba entre ellos.
vi_translation: I smiled wryly, then walked to the window and knelt down, my face just a few inches from hers. I couldn't understand why she was here, by my window, like this. "Why do I have this honor?" I asked. Margo and I were still friends, I thought, but not the kind of friends who meet-in-the-middle-of-the-night-with-blackened-faces. I was sure she had friends for this kind of situation. And I was not one of those friends.
tr_translation: Strangely, I laughed, then walked over there, knelt by the window, and sat down, my face very close to hers. I couldn't guess why she was here, at my window, in this manner. “To what do I owe this honor?” I asked. I was still close with Margo, I think, but not close enough to arrange a “meeting in the dead of night with a face painted black.” She had friends for that. I just wasn't among them.
es_translation: I laughed awkwardly and then approached the window, knelt down, and positioned myself just a few centimeters from his face. I couldn't imagine why he was there, at my window, with his face painted. —To what do I owe the pleasure? —I asked him. Margo and I still had a good vibe, I suppose, but not to the point of meeting in the middle of the night with our faces painted black. For that, she already had her friends, surely. I was not among them.

en: “I need your car,” she explained.
vi: “Tớ cần xe của cậu,” Margo giải thích.
tr: “Arabana ihtiyacım var,” diye açıkladı.
es: —Necesito tu coche —me explicó.
vi_translation: “I need your car,” Margo explained.
tr_translation: “I need your car,” she explained.
es_translation: —I need your car —he explained to me.

en: “I don’t have a car,” I said, which was something of a sore point for me.
vi: “Tớ không có xe,” tôi nói, một thú nhận hơi có phần nhức nhối trong tôi.
tr: “Arabam yok,” dedim ki bu benim için hassas bir noktaydı.
es: —No tengo coche —le contesté, y era un tema del que prefería no hablar.
vi_translation: “I don't have a car,” I said, a confession that was somewhat painful for me.
tr_translation: “I don't have a car,” I said, which was a sensitive point for me.
es_translation: —I don't have a car —I replied, and it was a topic I preferred not to discuss.

en: “Well, I need your mom’s car.”
vi: “Chậc, tớ cần xe của mẹ cậu.”
tr: “Yani annenin arabasına ihtiyacım var.
es: —Bueno, pues el de tu madre.
vi_translation: "Well, I need your mom's car."
tr_translation: “So I need your mother's car.”
es_translation: —Well, then your mother's.

en: “You have your own car,” I pointed out.
vi: “Cậu có xe riêng mà,” tôi nói lại.
tr: “Kendi araban var,” diye hatırlattım.
es: —Tú tienes coche —le comenté.
vi_translation: “You have your own car,” I repeated.
tr_translation: “You have your own car,” I reminded.
es_translation: —You have a car —I commented to him.

en: Margo puffed out her cheeks and sighed. “Right, but the thing is that my parents have taken the keys to my car and locked them inside a safe, which they put under their bed, and Myrna Mount-weazel”— who was her dog—“is sleeping inside their room. And Myrna Mountweazel has a freaking aneurysm whenever she catches sight of me. I mean, I could totally sneak in there and steal the safe and crack it and get my keys out and drive away, but the thing is that it’s not even worth trying because Myrna Mountweazel is just going to bark like crazy if I so much as crack open the door. So like I said, I need a car. Also, I need you to drive it, because I have to do eleven things tonight, and at least five of them involve a getaway man.”
vi: Margo bụng má thở dài. “Đúng, nhưng vấn đề là bố mẹ giữ chìa khóa xe tớ và cất chìa trong một cái két, dưới gầm giường, và Myrna Mountweazel”–con chó của Margo– “ngủ trong phòng bố mẹ. Mà Myrna Mountweazel lên cơn phình mạch máu mỗi khi trông thấy tớ. Ý là, tớ hoàn toàn có thể lẻn vào phòng, nẫng két, cạy ra lấy chìa khóa xe và phóng đi, nhưng vấn đề ở chỗ chẳng cần phải thử vì tớ chỉ cần mở cửa phòng thôi là Myrna Mountweazel sẽ sủa loạn xà ngầu. Thế nên tớ nói rồi đấy, tớ cần một cái xe. Tớ cũng cần cậu lái xe nữa, vì đêm nay tớ có mười một việc cần làm, và ít nhất năm đầu việc cần đến đồng bọn đánh tháo.”
tr: Margo yanaklarını şişirdi ve iç çekti. “Doğru ama mesele şu ki annemle babam arabamın anahtarlarını alıp yataklarının altına koydukları bir kasanın içine kilitlediler ve Myma Mountweazel,” Margo’nun köpeği, “onların odasında uyuyor ve beni gördüğü anda Myma Mountweazel’ın kahrolası anevrizması ortaya çıkıyor. Yani aslında odaya sessizce girip kasayı çalabilir, kırıp anahtarlarımı çıkarabilir ve arabayla uzaklaşabilirdim ama sorun şu ki, denememe bile değmez çünkü kapıyı aralasam bile Myrna Mountweazel deli gibi havlayacak. Yani dediğim gibi, arabaya ihtiyacım var. Ayrıca senin sürmen lazım çünkü bu gece on bir şey yapmalıyım ve en azmdan beşi kaçmak için birini gerektiriyor, dostum.
es: Margo infló las mejillas y suspiró. —Cierto, pero resulta que mis padres me han quitado las llaves del coche y las han metido en una caja fuerte, que han dejado debajo de su cama, y Myrna Mountweazel, la perra, está durmiendo en su habitación. Y a Myrna Mountweazel le da un puto derrame cerebral cada vez que me ve. Vaya, que perfectamente podría colarme en la habitación, robar la caja fuerte, forzarla, coger las llaves y largarme, pero el caso es que no merece la pena intentarlo, porque Myrna Mountweazel se pondrá a ladrar como una loca en cuanto asome por la puerta. Así que, como te decía, necesito un coche. Y también necesito que conduzcas tú, porque esta noche tengo que hacer once cosas, y al menos cinco exigen que alguien esté esperándome para salir corriendo.
vi_translation: Margo sighed deeply. "Yes, but the problem is that my parents keep my car keys in a safe, under the bed, and Myrna Mountweazel"—Margo's dog—"sleeps in their room. And Myrna Mountweazel has a fit every time she sees me. I mean, I could totally sneak into the room, grab the safe, break it open to get the car keys, and drive away, but the problem is that there's no point in trying because as soon as I open the door, Myrna Mountweazel will start barking like crazy. So, like I said, I need a car. I also need you to drive because tonight I have eleven things to do, and at least the first five require an accomplice to break me out."
tr_translation: Margo puffed out her cheeks and sighed. “True, but the thing is, my mom and dad took my car keys and locked them in a safe under their bed, and Myma Mountweazel,” Margo’s dog, “is sleeping in their room and the moment she sees me, Myma Mountweazel’s damn aneurysm acts up. So actually, I could quietly enter the room, steal the safe, break it open to get my keys, and drive away, but the problem is, it's not even worth trying because even if I just crack the door open, Myrna Mountweazel will bark like crazy. So, as I said, I need the car. Also, you need to drive because I have to do eleven things tonight and at least five of them require someone to help me escape, buddy.”
es_translation: Margo puffed out her cheeks and sighed. —True, but it turns out that my parents have taken the car keys from me and put them in a safe, which they left under their bed, and Myrna Mountweazel, the dog, is sleeping in their room. And Myrna Mountweazel has a damn stroke every time she sees me. So, I could perfectly sneak into the room, steal the safe, break it open, grab the keys, and take off, but the thing is, it's not worth trying because Myrna Mountweazel will start barking like crazy as soon as I peek through the door. So, as I was saying, I need a car. And I also need you to drive, because tonight I have to do eleven things, and at least five require someone to be waiting for me to make a quick getaway.

en: When I let my sight unfocus, she became nothing but eyes, floating in the ether. And then I locked back on her, and I could see the outline of her face, the paint still wet against her skin. Her cheekbones triangulating into her chin, her pitch-black lips barely turned to a smile. “Any felonies?” I asked.
vi: Khi tôi không tập trung điểm nhìn vào đâu, Margo như tan biến bồng bềnh trong không khí, chỉ còn lại đôi mắt. Còn khi tập trung nhìn cô ấy, tôi có thể thấy đường viền khuôn mặt, thứ màu đen vẫn còn ướt trên da Margo. Hai gò má và cái cằm tạo thành một hình tam giác, và bờ môi đen thẫm mơ hồ cong một nụ cười. “Có cướp giết hiếp gì không đấy?” tôi hỏi.
tr: Bakışlarımı odaklamayı bıraktığımda Margo’nun görüntüsü sadece havada yüzen gözler haline dönüştü. Sonra tekrar ona kilitlendim ve yüzünün ana hatlarını görebildim, cildindeki boya hâlâ ıslaktı. Elmacık kemikleri çenesine doğru bir üçgen oluşturuyordu, simsiyah dudaklarında zar zor bir gülümseme oluştu. “Herhangi bir suç içerecek mi?” diye sordum.
es: Cuando yo no enfocaba la mirada, Margo era toda ojos flotando en el espacio. Luego volvía a fijar la mirada y veía el contorno de su cara, la pintura todavía húmeda en su piel. Sus pómulos se triangulaban hacia la barbilla, y sus labios, negros como el carbón, esbozaban apenas una sonrisa. —¿Algún delito? —le pregunté.
vi_translation: When I didn't focus my gaze anywhere, Margo seemed to dissolve and float in the air, leaving only her eyes. But when I focused on her, I could see the outline of her face, the black color still wet on Margo's skin. Her cheekbones and chin formed a triangle, and her dark lips faintly curved into a smile. "Is there any robbery, murder, or rape?" I asked.
tr_translation: When I stopped focusing my gaze, Margo's image turned into just eyes floating in the air. Then I locked onto her again and could see the contours of her face, the paint on her skin was still wet. Her cheekbones formed a triangle down to her chin, a barely noticeable smile appeared on her pitch-black lips. "Will it involve any crime?" I asked.
es_translation: When I didn't focus my gaze, Margo was all eyes floating in space. Then I would refocus and see the outline of her face, the paint still wet on her skin. Her cheekbones triangulated towards her chin, and her lips, black as coal, barely formed a smile. —Any crime? —I asked him.

en: “Hmm,” said Margo. “Remind me if breaking and entering is a felony.”
vi: “Hừm,” Margo đáp. “Hãy nhắc tớ nếu đột nhập bị coi là cướp giết hiếp.
tr: “Hımm,” dedi Margo. “Haneye tecavüz suç muydu, hatırlatsana.” Kararlı bir şekilde, “Hayır,” diye cevap verdim.
es: —Hum —me contestó Margo—. Recuérdame si el allanamiento de morada es un delito.
vi_translation: "Hmm," Margo replied. "Remind me if breaking and entering is considered robbery, murder, or rape."
tr_translation: “Hmm,” said Margo. “Remind me, was breaking and entering a crime?” I answered firmly, “No.”
es_translation: —Hmm —Margo replied to me—. Remind me if breaking and entering is a crime.

en: “No I won’t help. Can’t you enlist some of your underlings to drive you around?” Lacey and/or Becca were always doing her bidding.
vi: “Không tớ không giúp được đâu. Cậu không tuyển được đứa đàn em nào đưa cậu đi sao?” Lacey và/hoặc Becca luôn ngoan ngoãn theo Margo đấy thôi.
tr: “Hayır, yardım etmeyeceğim. Seni etrafta arabayla dolaştırması için emir kullarından birinin yardımım isteyemez misin?” Lacey ve/veya Becca her zaman onun emirlerini yerine getiriyordu.
es: —No voy a ayudarte. ¿No puedes reclutar a alguna de tus subordinadas para que te lleve? Lacey y/o Becca hacían siempre lo que ella decía.
vi_translation: “No, I can't help you. Can't you find a junior to take you?” Lacey and/or Becca always obediently followed Margo.
tr_translation: “No, I will not help. Can't you ask one of your minions to drive you around?” Lacey and/or Becca always followed his orders.
es_translation: —I'm not going to help you. Can't you recruit one of your subordinates to take you? Lacey and/or Becca always did what she said.

en: “They’re part of the problem, actually,” Margo said.
vi: “Thực ra tụi nó là một phần của vấn đề,” Margo nói.
tr: “Onlar sorunun bir parçası aslında,” dedi Margo.
es: —La verdad es que son parte del problema —me dijo Margo.
vi_translation: “Actually, they are part of the problem,” Margo said.
tr_translation: “They are actually part of the problem,” said Margo.
es_translation: —The truth is that they are part of the problem —Margo told me.

en: “What’s the problem?” I asked.
vi: “Vấn đề gì?” tôi hỏi.
tr: “Sorun ne?” diye sordum.
es: —¿Qué problema? —le pregunté.
vi_translation: “What’s the matter?” I asked.
tr_translation: “What’s the problem?” I asked.
es_translation: —What problem? —I asked him.

en: “There are eleven problems,” she said somewhat impatiently.
vi: “Có mười một vấn đề tất cả,” cô ấy nói, vẻ sốt ruột.
tr: “On bir sorun var,” dedi sabırsızlıkla.
es: —Hay once problemas —me contestó con cierta impaciencia.
vi_translation: “There are eleven issues in total,” she said, looking impatient.
tr_translation: “There are eleven problems,” he said impatiently.
es_translation: —There are eleven problems —he answered me with some impatience.

en: “I swear to God that you will not be asked to commit a felony.”
vi: “Tớ thề có Chúa chứng giám rằng cậu sẽ không phạm phải trọng tội như vậy đâu.”
tr: ‘Yemin ederim ki suç işlemen gerekmeyecek.
es: —Te juro por Dios que no te pediré que cometas ningún delito.
vi_translation: “I swear to God that you will not commit such a grave sin.”
tr_translation: “I swear you won't need to commit a crime.”
es_translation: —I swear to God that I will not ask you to commit any crime.

en: And right then, the floodlights came on all around Margo’s house. In one swift motion, she somersaulted through my window, into my room, and then rolled beneath my bed. Within seconds, her dad was standing on the patio outside. “Margo!” he shouted. “I saw you!”
vi: Và đúng lúc ấy, nhà Margo bỗng sáng bừng lên. Nhanh như cắt, cô ấy lộn cù mèo qua cửa sổ vào phòng tôi, lăn vào gậm giường. Chỉ tích tắc sau, bố Margo đứng ở hiên sau nhà réo. “Margo! Bố thấy mày rồi đấy!”
tr: Ve tam o anda Margo’nun evinin her tarafında ışıklar yandı. Margo tek bir seri hareketle pencereden geçerek odama doğru takla attı ve yatağımın altına yuvarlandı. Saniyeler içinde babası dışarıdaki terasta duruyordu. “Margo!” diye bağırdı. “Seni gördüm!” Yatağımın altmdan boğuk bir ses duydum.
es: Y en aquel preciso instante se encendieron todos los focos que rodeaban la casa de Margo. En un rápido movimiento, saltó por mi ventana, se metió en mi habitación y se tiró debajo de mi cama. En cuestión de segundos, su padre salió al patio. —¡Margo! —gritó—. ¡Te he visto!
vi_translation: And at that very moment, Margo's house suddenly lit up brightly. Quick as a flash, she somersaulted through the window into my room, rolling under the bed. A split second later, Margo's dad was yelling from the back porch. "Margo! I see you!"
tr_translation: And at that very moment, lights came on all over Margo's house. In a single swift motion, Margo tumbled through the window into my room and rolled under my bed. Within seconds, her father was standing on the terrace outside. “Margo!” he shouted. “I saw you!” I heard a muffled voice from under my bed.
es_translation: And at that precise moment, all the lights surrounding Margo's house turned on. In a quick movement, she jumped through my window, got into my room, and threw herself under my bed. In a matter of seconds, his father came out into the yard. —Margo! —he shouted—. I saw you!

en: From beneath my bed, I heard a muffled, “Oh, Christ.” Margo scooted out from under the bed, stood up, walked to the window, and said, “Come on, Dad. I’m just trying to have a chat with Quentin. You’re always telling me what a fantastic influence he could be on me and everything.”
vi: Tôi nghe thấy tiếng rên rẩm trong gậm giường, “Ôi trời ơi!” Margo bò khỏi gậm giường, đứng dậy đi đến bên cửa sổ và nói: “Bố ơi bố, con chỉ đang nói chuyện với Quentin thôi ạ. Bố luôn bảo là cậu ấy có tác động tích cực đến con còn gì.”
tr: “Seni gördüm!” Yatağımın altmdan boğuk bir ses duydum. “Ah, Tanrım.” Margo yatağın altmdan hızla çıktı, ayağa kalktı ve pencereye doğru yürüdü. “Haydi ama baba. Sadece Quentin’le sohbet etmeye çahşıyorum. Quentin’in benim üzerimde ne kadar olağanüstü bir etkisi olabileceğini filan hep söylersin.
es: Desde debajo de la cama me llegó un ahogado «Ay, joder». Margo salió rápidamente, se levantó, se acercó a la ventana y dijo: —Vamos, papá. Solo intento charlar con Quentin. Te pasas el día diciéndome que sería una influencia fantástica y todo eso.
vi_translation: I heard a groaning sound from under the bed, "Oh my God!" Margo crawled out from under the bed, stood up, went to the window, and said, "Dad, I was just talking to Quentin." "You always say he has a positive influence on me."
tr_translation: “I saw you!” I heard a muffled voice from under my bed. “Oh, God.” Margo quickly emerged from under the bed, stood up, and walked towards the window. “Come on, Dad. I'm just trying to chat with Quentin. You always say how extraordinary Quentin's influence on me can be and all that.”
es_translation: From under the bed came a muffled "Oh, damn." Margo quickly got out, stood up, approached the window, and said: —Let's go, Dad. I'm just trying to chat with Quentin. You spend the whole day telling me that he would be a fantastic influence and all that.

en: “Just chatting with Quentin?”
vi: “Chỉ nói chuyện với Quentin thôi sao?”
tr: “Sadece Quentin’le sohbet mi ediyorsun?
es: —¿Solo estás charlando con Quentin?
vi_translation: "Just talking to Quentin?"
tr_translation: “Are you just chatting with Quentin?”
es_translation: "Are you just chatting with Quentin?"

en: “Yes.”
vi: “Vâng.”
tr: “Evet.
es: —Sí.
vi_translation: “Yes.”
tr_translation: “Yes.”
es_translation: —Yes.

en: “Then why are you wearing black face paint?”
vi: “Thế sao phải bôi mặt đen sì thế kia?”
tr: “O zaman neden yüzünde siyah boya var?
es: —Y entonces ¿por qué te has pintado la cara de negro?
vi_translation: “Why do you have to paint your face so black like that?”
tr_translation: “Then why is there black paint on your face?”
es_translation: —And then why did you paint your face black?

en: Margo faltered for only the briefest moment. “Dad, to answer that question would take hours of backstory, and I know that you’re probably very tired, so just go back t—”
vi: Margo thoáng hoảng hồn trong một tích tắc vô cùng ngắn. “Giải thích đầu đuôi dài dòng lắm ạ, bây giờ chắc bố mệt rồi thì đi ng...
tr: Margo çok kısa bir an bocaladı. “Baba, bu soruya cevap vermek saatler boyu hikâye anlatmamı gerektirir ve biliyorum ki muhtemelen çok yorgunsun, yani sadece geri dö...
es: Margo dudó solo un instante. —Papá, responderte a esa pregunta exigiría horas y sé que seguramente estás muy cansado, así que vuelve a…
vi_translation: Margo was momentarily startled for a very brief second. “Explaining everything in detail would take a long time, you must be tired now, so go to sl...”
tr_translation: Margo hesitated for a very brief moment. “Dad, answering this question would require me to tell stories for hours, and I know you're probably very tired, so just go back...”
es_translation: Margo hesitated for just a moment. —Dad, answering that question would take hours and I know you're probably very tired, so go back to...

en: “In the house,” he thundered. “This minute!”
vi: “Về nhà ngay,” bố Margo gầm lên. “Tức khắc!”
tr: “Eve,” diye gürledi babası. “Hemen!”
es: —¡A casa! —gritó—. ¡Ahora mismo!
vi_translation: “Go home immediately,” Margo's dad roared. “Right now!”
tr_translation: “Eve,” roared her father. “Immediately!”
es_translation: —Home! —he shouted—. Right now!

en: Margo grabbed hold of my shirt, whispered, “Back in a minute,” in my ear, and then climbed out the window.
vi: Margo níu áo tôi, thì thầm “Một phút nữa tớ quay lại” vào tai tôi, rồi trèo qua cửa sổ.
tr: Margo gömleğimi tuttu. “Bir dakika içinde geri döneceğim.” diye fısıldadı ve pencereden dışan tırmandı.
es: Margo me agarró de la camisa, me susurró al oído «Vuelvo en un minuto» y salió por la ventana.
vi_translation: Margo tugged at my sleeve, whispered "I'll be back in a minute" into my ear, then climbed out the window.
tr_translation: Margo grabbed my shirt. “I will be back in a minute,” she whispered and climbed out the window.
es_translation: Margo grabbed me by the shirt, whispered in my ear "I'll be back in a minute," and went out the window.

en: As soon as she left, I grabbed my car keys from my desk. The keys are mine; the car, tragically, is not. On my sixteenth birthday, my parents gave me a very small gift, and I knew the moment they handed it to me that it was a car key, and I about peed myself, because they’d said over and over again that they couldn’t afford to give me a car. But when they handed me the tiny wrapped box, I knew they’d been tricking me, that I was getting a car after all. I tore off the wrapping paper and popped open the little box. Indeed, it contained a key.
vi: Ngay khi Margo rời đi, tôi vớ lấy chìa khóa xe trên bàn. Chìa khóa là của tôi, còn chiếc xe, éo le thay, thì không. Vào ngày sinh nhật thứ mười sáu của tôi, bố mẹ tặng một món quà rất nhỏ, tôi lập tức hiểu ra bố mẹ cho tôi một chiếc chìa khóa ô-tô. Tôi mừng suýt phát tiểu vì bố mẹ vẫn nói đi nói lại là không đủ tiền mua xe cho tôi. Nhưng khi bố mẹ trao cho tôi hộp quà bé xíu, tôi biết ngay hóa ra lúc trước bố mẹ chỉ trêu thôi, và rằng cuối cùng thì tôi cũng sắp có xe rồi. Tôi xé ngay giấy bọc, mở cái hộp con con. Đúng thật, ở trong là cái chìa khóa.
tr: Margo gider gitmez çalışma masamdan anahtarlarımı kaptım. Anahtarlar benim, trajik bir biçimde, araba değil. On altıncı yaş günümde, annemle babam bana çok küçük bir hediye vermişti ve hediyeyi bana uzattıkları anda bir araba anahtarı olduğunu biliyordum, heyecandan neredeyse altıma işeyecektim çünkü araba almaya güçlerinin yetmeyeceğini bana tekrar tekrar söylemişlerdi. Ama o paketlenmiş, ufacık kutuyu bana verdikleri zaman, beni kandırdıklarını ve nihayet bir arabam olduğunu düşünmüştüm. Paketi yırttım ve küçük kutuyu çabucak açtım. Hakikaten de içinde bir anahtar vardı.
es: En cuanto hubo salido, cogí las llaves del coche de encima de la mesa. Las llaves son mías, aunque lo trágico es que el coche no. Cuando cumplí dieciséis años, mis padres me hicieron un regalo muy pequeño. Supe en cuanto me lo dieron que eran las llaves de un coche, y casi me meo encima, porque me habían repetido una y mil veces que no podían comprarme un coche. Pero cuando me entregaron la cajita envuelta, pensé que me habían tomado el pelo y que al final tendría un coche. Quité el envoltorio y abrí la cajita, que efectivamente contenía una llave.
vi_translation: As soon as Margo left, I grabbed the car keys from the table. The keys were mine, but the car, ironically, was not. On my sixteenth birthday, my parents gave me a very small gift, and I immediately understood that they were giving me a car key. I was so happy I almost peed myself because my parents had always said they couldn't afford to buy me a car. But when they handed me the tiny gift box, I knew right away that they had just been teasing before, and that I was finally getting a car. I tore off the wrapping paper and opened the little box. Sure enough, inside was a key.
tr_translation: As soon as Margo left, I grabbed my keys from my desk. The keys are mine, tragically, not the car. On my sixteenth birthday, my mom and dad gave me a very small gift, and the moment they handed it to me, I knew it was a car key; I was almost going to pee my pants with excitement because they had repeatedly told me they couldn't afford a car. But when they gave me that tiny, wrapped box, I thought they had tricked me and that I finally had a car. I tore open the package and quickly opened the small box. Indeed, there was a key inside.
es_translation: As soon as he left, I grabbed the car keys from the table. The keys are mine, although the tragic part is that the car isn't. When I turned sixteen, my parents gave me a very small gift. I knew as soon as they gave it to me that it was car keys, and I almost peed myself, because they had told me a thousand times that they couldn't buy me a car. But when they handed me the wrapped little box, I thought they had been joking and that I would finally have a car. I took off the wrapping and opened the little box, which indeed contained a key.

en: Upon close inspection, it contained a Chrysler key. A key for a Chrysler minivan. The one and the same Chrysler minivan owned by my mother.
vi: Nhìn kĩ thì đó là chìa khóa xe Chrysler. Chìa khóa một chiếc minivan Chrysler. Chính là con minivan Chrysler của mẹ.
tr: Daha yakın bir inceleme yaptığımda gördüm ki içinde bir Chrysler anahtarı vardı. Chrysler minivan anahtarı. Annemin sahip olduğu Chrysler minivanın aynısı ve ta kendisi.
es: La observé y descubrí que era la llave de un Chrysler. La llave de un monovolumen Chrysler. Exactamente del monovolumen Chrysler de mi madre.
vi_translation: Upon closer inspection, it was a Chrysler car key. The key to a Chrysler minivan. It was indeed mom's Chrysler minivan.
tr_translation: When I took a closer look, I saw that there was a Chrysler key inside. A Chrysler minivan key. The exact same Chrysler minivan that my mother owned.
es_translation: I observed it and discovered that it was the key to a Chrysler. The key to a Chrysler minivan. Exactly to my mother's Chrysler minivan.

en: “My present is a key to your car?” I asked my mom.
vi: “Quà cho con là chìa khóa xe của mẹ ạ?” tôi hỏi mẹ.
tr: Anneme, “Hediyem senin arabamn anahtarı mı?” diye sordum. “Tom,” dedi babama, “umutlanacağını söylemiştim.
es: —¿Me regaláis una llave de tu coche? —le pregunté a mi madre.
vi_translation: "Is the gift for me your car keys, Mom?" I asked her.
tr_translation: I asked my mother, "Is my gift the key to your car?" "Tom," she said to my father, "I told you he would get his hopes up."
es_translation: —Will you give me a key to your car? —I asked my mother.

en: “Tom,” she said to my dad, “I told you he would get his hopes up.”
vi: “Anh Tom à,” mẹ quay sang bảo bố, “em đã nói với anh là thằng bé sẽ đặt kì vọng cao mà.”
tr: “Tom,” dedi babama, “umutlanacağını söylemiştim.
es: —Tom —le dijo a mi padre—, te dije que le daría falsas esperanzas.
vi_translation: “Tom,” Mom turned to Dad and said, “I told you that the boy would have high expectations.”
tr_translation: I asked my mother, "Is my gift the key to your car?" "Tom," she said to my father, "I told you he would get his hopes up."
es_translation: —Tom —he said to my father—, I told you I would give him false hopes.

en: “Oh, don’t blame me,” my dad said. “You’re just sublimating your own frustration with my income.”
vi: “Ơ kìa, đừng trách anh,” bố nói. “Em đang đá sự căng thẳng của em vào tiền lương của anh đấy.”
tr: Babam, “Ah, beni suçlama,” dedi. “Sadece kendi hüsranından benim kazancımla arınıyorsun.
es: —No me eches la culpa a mí —le respondió mi padre—. Estás sublimando tus propias frustraciones por mi sueldo.
vi_translation: “Hey, don't blame me,” Dad said. “You're kicking your stress into my paycheck.”
tr_translation: My father said, "Ah, don't blame me." "You are only cleansing your own frustration with my gain."
es_translation: —Don't blame me —my father replied to him—. You are sublimating your own frustrations about my salary.

en: “Isn’t that snap analysis a tad passive-aggressive?” my mother asked.
vi: “Đấy chẳng phải một phân tích vội vàng có phần thụ động-hung hăng sao?” mẹ hỏi lại.
tr: Annem, “Bu çabuk analizin biraz pasifagresif değil mi?” diye sordu.
es: —¿Este análisis que me sueltas no tiene algo de agresión pasiva? —le preguntó mi madre.
vi_translation: “Isn't that a somewhat passive-aggressive hasty analysis?” Mom asked back.
tr_translation: My mother asked, "Isn't this quick analysis a bit passive-aggressive?"
es_translation: —Doesn't this analysis you're giving me have a bit of passive aggression? —my mother asked him.

en: “Aren’t rhetorical accusations of passive aggression inherently passive-aggressive?” my dad responded, and they went on like that for a while.
vi: “Khi buộc tội một cách đầy hùng biện về lối hung hăng thụ động, chẳng phải chính những buộc tội ấy đã có bản chất thụ động-hung hăng rồi không?” bố đáp trả, và bố mẹ cứ liên tu bất tận như thế một lúc lâu.
tr: “Pasifagresyon hakkında tumturaklı suçlamalar özünde pasifagresif değil midir?” diye cevap verdi babam ve bir süre böyle devam ettiler.
es: —¿Y las acusaciones de agresión pasiva no son agresiones pasivas por naturaleza? —le contestó mi padre. Y siguieron así un rato.
vi_translation: “When making a rhetorical accusation of passive-aggressive behavior, isn't it true that those very accusations are inherently passive-aggressive themselves?” Dad retorted, and Mom and Dad continued like that for quite a while.
tr_translation: “Aren't grandiose accusations about passive aggression essentially passive-aggressive themselves?” replied my father, and they continued like this for a while.
es_translation: —And aren't accusations of passive aggression passive aggressions by nature? —my father replied. And they continued like that for a while.

en: The long and short of it was this: I had access to the vehicular awesomeness that is a late-model Chrysler minivan, except for when my mom was driving it. And since she drove to work every morning, I could only use the car on weekends. Well, weekends and the middle of the goddamned night.
vi: Nhưng lâu hay chóng thì tóm lại cũng là thế này: tôi được thụ hưởng sự vận tải tuyệt vời của chiếc minivan Chrysler đời cũ, trừ những lúc mẹ lái xe. Và vì sáng nào mẹ cũng lái xe đi làm, tôi chỉ có thể dùng vào dịp cuối tuần. Ờ, cuối tuần và giờ giấc quái quỉ lúc nửa đêm.
tr: Uzun lafın kısası şuydu: Son model bir Chrysler minivan olan taşıtsal muhteşemliğe binme imkânım vardı, annemin kullandığı zamanlar hariç. Ve annem her gün işe arabayla gittiği için arabayı yalnızca hafta sonlan kullanabiliyordum. Hafta sonları ve tabii gecenin köründe.
es: La cuestión era la siguiente: tendría acceso a ese fenómeno vehicular que es el monovolumen Chrysler último modelo, menos cuando mi madre lo utilizara. Y como mi madre iba al trabajo en coche cada mañana, yo solo podría utilizarlo los fines de semana. Bueno, los fines de semana y en mitad de la puta noche.
vi_translation: But sooner or later, it all comes down to this: I get to enjoy the wonderful transportation of the old Chrysler minivan, except when my mom is driving. And since my mom drives to work every morning, I can only use it on weekends. Well, weekends and the odd hours around midnight.
tr_translation: Long story short: I had the opportunity to ride in a vehicular marvel, a brand-new Chrysler minivan, except when my mom was using it. And since my mom drove to work every day, I could only use the car on weekends. On weekends and, of course, in the dead of night.
es_translation: The issue was the following: I would have access to that vehicular phenomenon that is the latest model Chrysler minivan, except when my mother used it. And since my mother drove to work every morning, I could only use it on weekends. Well, on weekends and in the middle of the damn night.

en: It took Margo more than the promised minute to return to my window, but not much more. But in the time she was gone, I’d started to waffle again. “I’ve got school tomorrow,” I told her.
vi: Margo mất hơn một phút như đã hứa mới quay lại bên cửa sổ phòng tôi, nhưng không quá lâu. Đúng lúc sắp sửa lên đường hành sự, tôi lại thấy đầu óc lung bung. “Mai tớ phải đi học đấy,” tôi nói với Margo.
tr: Margo’nun pencereme geri dönmesi, söz verdiği bir dakikadan daha uzun sürdü ama çok da değil. Fakat gittiği süre boyunca kendi kendime saçmalamıştım. “Yarın okulum var,” dedim.
es: Margo tardó más del prometido minuto en volver a mi ventana, aunque no mucho más. Pero durante su ausencia empecé a cambiar de opinión. —Tengo clase mañana —le dije.
vi_translation: Margo took more than a minute as promised to return to my window, but not too long. Just as we were about to set off, my mind started to feel cluttered. "I have to go to school tomorrow," I said to Margo.
tr_translation: It took Margo longer than the promised minute to return to my window, but not by much. However, during the time she was gone, I had been rambling to myself. "I have school tomorrow," I said.
es_translation: Margo took longer than the promised minute to return to my window, though not much longer. But during her absence, I began to change my mind. —I have class tomorrow —I told him.

en: “Yeah, I know,” Margo answered. “There’s school tomorrow and the day after that, and thinking about that too long could make a girl bonkers. So, yeah. It’s a school night. That’s why we’ve got to get going, because we’ve got to be back by morning.”
vi: “Ừa, tớ biết chứ,” Margo đáp. “Mai phải đi học, ngày kia cũng thế, cơ mà con trai suy đi tính lại lâu la có thể khiến con gái cáu điên lên đấy. Rồi, coi như đây là trường học ban đêm đi. Thế nên bây giờ chúng ta đi, vì phải trở về trước khi trời sáng.
tr: Margo, “Evet, biliyorum,” diye karşılık verdi. ‘Yarın okul var ve ondan sonraki gün de, bunun üzerine çok uzun süre düşünmek bir kıza keçileri kaçırtabüir. Yani evet, yann okul var. Başlamak zorunda olmamızın nedeni de bu, çünkü sabah geri dönmüş olmalıyız.
es: —Sí, lo sé —me contestó Margo—. Mañana tenemos clase, y pasado mañana, y si lo pienso demasiado, acabaré zumbada. Así que sí, es una noche antes de clase. Por eso tenemos que irnos ya, porque tenemos que estar de vuelta por la mañana.
vi_translation: “Yeah, I know,” Margo replied. “We have to go to school tomorrow, and the day after too, but boys taking a long time to think things through can drive girls crazy. Alright, let's consider this night school. So now we go, because we have to be back before dawn.”
tr_translation: Margo replied, "Yes, I know." 'There is school tomorrow and the day after that, thinking about this for too long can drive a girl crazy. So yes, there is school tomorrow. That's why we have to start, because we need to be back by morning."
es_translation: —Yes, I know —Margo replied to me—. We have class tomorrow, and the day after tomorrow, and if I think about it too much, I'll end up going crazy. So yes, it is a night before class. That's why we have to leave now, because we need to be back by morning.

en: “Q,” she said. “Q. Darling. How long have we been dear friends?”
vi: “Q này,” cô ấy nói. “Q ơi. Bạn tốt ơi. Chúng ta là bạn bè thân thiết được bao lâu rồi?”
tr: “Q,” Dedi. “Q. Hayatım. Ne zamandır iyi arkadaşız?
es: —Q —me dijo—. Q. Cariño. ¿Cuánto hace que somos muy amigos?
vi_translation: “Q,” she said. “Q. My good friend. How long have we been close friends?”
tr_translation: “Q,” said Dedi. “Q. My dear. How long have we been good friends?”
es_translation: —Q —he told me—. Q. Darling. How long have we been very good friends?

en: “We’re not friends. We’re neighbors.”
vi: “Chúng ta không phải bạn bè. Chúng ta là hàng xóm.”
tr: “Biz arkadaş değiliz, komşuyuz.
es: —No somos amigos. Somos vecinos.
vi_translation: "We are not friends. We are neighbors."
tr_translation: “We are not friends, we are neighbors.”
es_translation: —We are not friends. We are neighbors.

en: “Oh, Christ, Q. Am I not nice to you? Do I not order my various and sundry minions to be kind to you at school?”
vi: “Ôi trời ơi, Q ơi là Q. Tớ có gì tệ với cậu ư? Tớ không bảo ban đám đàn em nhan nhản của tớ ở trường phải tử tế với cậu sao?”
tr: “Ah, Tanrım, Q. Sana iyi davranmıyor muyum? Türlü türlü emir kullanma, okulda sana kibar davranmalarım emretmedim mi?
es: —Joder, Q. ¿No soy amable contigo? ¿No ordeno a mis compinches que se porten bien con vosotros en el instituto?
vi_translation: “Oh my God, Q, oh Q. Have I done anything bad to you?” “Didn't I tell my countless juniors at school to be nice to you?”
tr_translation: “Ah, my God, Q. Am I not treating you well? Didn't I order them to be polite to you at school, to use all kinds of commands?’
es_translation: —Damn, Q. Am I not nice to you? Don't I tell my buddies to treat you well at school?

en: “Uh-huh,” I answered dubiously, although in point of fact I’d always figured it was Margo who had stopped Chuck Parson and his ilk from screwing with us.
vi: “Ưm hừm,” tôi ậm ừ, dù đúng là tôi vẫn luôn ngờ ngợ rằng chính Margo đã ngăn Chuck Parson và đồng đảng của nó chơi xỏ bọn tôi.
tr: “Hı hı,” diye cevap verdim şüpheli bir şekilde, Chuck Parson ve türevlerinin bize bulaşmasını engelleyenin Margo olduğundan asbnda her zaman şüphelenmiştim.
es: —Uf —le contesté con recelo, aunque lo cierto era que siempre había supuesto que había sido Margo la que había impedido que Chuck Parson y los de su calaña nos putearan.
vi_translation: "Hmm," I mumbled, although I had always suspected that it was Margo who had stopped Chuck Parson and his gang from messing with us.
tr_translation: “Uh-huh,” I replied suspiciously, I had always suspected that it was actually Margo who prevented Chuck Parson and his ilk from bothering us.
es_translation: —Ugh —I replied warily, although the truth was that I had always assumed it was Margo who had prevented Chuck Parson and his ilk from messing with us.

en: She blinked. She’d even painted her eyelids. “Q,” she said, “we have to go.”
vi: Cô ấy nháy mắt, cả hàng mi cũng được bôi đen. “Q ơi,” Margo nói, “chúng ta phải đi.”
tr: Göz kırptı. Göz kapaklarım bile boyamıştı. “Q,” dedi, “gitmeliyiz.
es: Parpadeó. Se había pintado de negro hasta los párpados. —Q —me dijo—, tenemos que irnos.
vi_translation: She blinked, her entire row of lashes also darkened. "Q," Margo said, "we have to go."
tr_translation: He winked. He had even painted my eyelids. “Q,” he said, “we must go.”
es_translation: Blinked. She had painted her eyelids black. —Q —he told me—, we have to go.

en: And so I went. I slid out the window, and we ran along the side of my house, heads down, until we opened the doors of the minivan. Margo whispered not to close the doors—too much noise—so with the doors open, I put it in neutral, pushed off the cement with my foot, and then let the minivan roll down the driveway. We rolled slowly past a couple houses before I turned on the engine and the headlights. We closed the doors, and then I drove through the serpentine streets of Jefferson Park’s endlessness, the houses all still new-looking and plastic, like a toy village housing tens of thousands of real people.
vi: Và thế là tôi đi. Tôi lặng lẽ nhảy qua cửa sổ, và chúng tôi khom người chạy dọc hông nhà, cho đến khi mở được cửa chiếc minivan. Margo thì thầm bảo đừng đóng cửa xe–như vậy gây tiếng động quá lớn–thế là với cửa xe để mở, tôi không khởi động xe mà thò chân ra đẩy xuống nền xi-măng, để xe từ từ lăn xuống đường. Chúng tôi chầm chậm qua mấy ngôi nhà rồi tôi mới khởi động máy và bật đèn. Chúng tôi đóng cửa xe, và tôi bắt đầu lái qua những con phố ngoằn ngoèo tưởng như vô tận của khu Jefferson Park, những căn nhà còn mới và bằng chất dẻo, trông như một ngôi làng đồ chơi với hàng chục ngàn con người bằng xương bằng thịt.
tr: Ben de gittim. Pencereden dışarı doğru kaydım ve arabanın kapılarım açana kadar, evimin yan tarafı boyunca başımız aşağıda koştuk. Margo kapılan kapatmamam için fısıldadı çok ses yapacaktıve öylece açık kapılarla, arabayı boşa alıp ayağımla ittim ve garaj ile cadde arasındaki yoldan kaydırdım. Ben motoru ve farları açma dan önce, birkaç evin önünden yavaşça geçtik. Kapıları kapattık ve sonra Jefferson Park’m sonsuzluğunun kıvrımlı sokaklarında arabayı sürdüm, evlerin hepsi hâlâ yeni görünümlü ve plastikti, on binlerce gerçek insanın barındığı oyuncak bir köy gibi.
es: Y fui. Salté por la ventana y corrimos por la pared lateral de mi casa con la cabeza agachada hasta que abrimos las puertas del monovolumen. Margo me susurró que no cerrara las puertas —demasiado ruido—, así que, con las puertas abiertas, puse el coche en punto muerto, empujé con el pie en el asfalto, y el monovolumen rodó por el camino. Avanzamos despacio hasta dejar atrás un par de casas y luego encendí el motor y las luces. Cerramos las puertas y conduje por las sinuosas calles de la interminable Jefferson Park, con sus casas que todavía parecían nuevas y de plástico, como un pueblo de juguete que albergara decenas de miles de personas reales.
vi_translation: And so I went. I quietly jumped through the window, and we crouched and ran along the side of the house until we could open the door of the minivan. Margo whispered not to close the car door—it would make too much noise—so with the door left open, I didn't start the car but pushed my foot against the cement, letting the car slowly roll down the road. We slowly passed a few houses before I started the engine and turned on the lights. We closed the car door, and I began driving through the seemingly endless winding streets of Jefferson Park, the houses still new and made of plastic, looking like a toy village with tens of thousands of real people.
tr_translation: I went too. I slid out through the window and ran along the side of my house, heads down, until I opened the car doors. Margo whispered not to close the doors because it would make too much noise, so with the doors left open, I put the car in neutral, pushed it with my foot, and slid it down the path between the garage and the street. I didn't turn on the engine or the headlights Before that, we slowly passed in front of a few houses. We closed the doors and then I drove the car through the winding streets of Jefferson Park's infinity, with all the houses still looking new and plastic, like a toy village housing tens of thousands of real people.
es_translation: And I went. I jumped out the window and we ran along the side wall of my house with our heads down until we opened the doors of the minivan. Margo whispered to me not to close the doors —too much noise—, so, with the doors open, I put the car in neutral, pushed off with my foot on the asphalt, and the minivan rolled down the driveway. We moved slowly past a couple of houses and then I turned on the engine and the lights. We closed the doors and I drove through the winding streets of the endless Jefferson Park, with its houses that still looked new and plastic, like a toy town that housed tens of thousands of real people.

en: Margo started talking. “The thing is they don’t even really care; they just feel like my exploits make them look bad. Just now, do you know what he said? He said, ‘I don’t care if you screw up your life, but don’t embarrass us in front of the Jacobsens—they’re our friends.’ Ridiculous. And you have no idea how hard they’ve made it to get out of that goddamned house. You know how in prison-escape movies they put bundled-up clothes under the blankets to make it look like there’s a person in there?” I nodded. “Yeah, well, Mom put a goddamned baby monitor in my room so she could hear my sleep-breathing all night. So I just had to pay Ruthie five bucks to sleep in my room, and then I put bundled-up clothes in her room.” Ruthie is Margo’s little sister. “It’s Mission: Impossible shit now. Used to be I could just sneak out like a regular goddamned American—just climb out the window and jump off the roof. But God, these days, it’s like living in a fascist dictatorship.”
vi: Margo bắt đầu kể. “Vấn đề là bố mẹ chẳng thực sự quan tâm, bao nhiêu kì tích hay ho của tớ, họ chỉ thấy như vậy là làm hỏng thể diện của họ. Như lúc nãy, cậu có biết bố tớ nói gì không? ‘Bố không cần biết mày bày đặt trò gì với cuộc đời mày, nhưng đừng có mà làm bố mẹ mất mặt với nhà Jacobsen–cô chú ấy là bạn của bố mẹ.’ Buồn cười thật. Và cậu không biết bố mẹ tớ đã sảy vảy đến mức nào để có được cái nhà khủng ấy đâu. Cậu biết trong mấy bộ phim về vượt ngục, người ta nhét quần áo lùng bùng dưới chăn, giả bộ có người đang nằm chứ?” Tôi gật. “Ừ, đấy, mẹ tớ bày đặt xài một cái thiết bị giám sát bé chết giẫm trong phòng tớ để đêm nào cũng chực nghe tiếng tớ thở trong khi ngủ. Thế là tớ phải trả cho Ruthie năm đồng để nó ngủ trong phòng tớ, còn tớ nhét một đống quần áo lùng bùng lên giường nó.” Ruthie là em gái Margo. “Thế là thành một mớ Nhiệm vụ bất khả thi rồi đấy. Tớ đã từng chỉ việc lẻn khỏi nhà, như bất cứ người Mĩ bình thường chết tiệt nào–chỉ việc trèo qua cửa sổ và nhảy từ mái nhà xuống. Nhưng trời đất quỉ thần ơi, bây giờ không khác gì sống trong chế độ độc tài phát-xít mà.”
tr: Margo konuşmaya başladı. “Mesele şu ki gerçekten umursamıyorlar bile, sadece benim serüvenlerim onları kötü gösteriyormuş gibi hissediyorlar. Daha demin babam ne dedi biliyor musun? Dedi ki: ‘Hayatının içine etmen umurumda değil ama bizi Jacobsen’larm önünde utandırma... onlar bizim arkadaşımız.’ Saçmalık. Ve o lanet olası evden çıkmayı ne kadar zorlaştırdıklarını bilemezsin. Hani hapisten firar filmlerinde, içinde biri varmış gibi göstermek için sarmalanmış giysileri örtünün altına koyarlar ya?’ Başımı salladım. “İşte, annem de bütün gece uykumda nefes alışımı duyabilmek için odama lanet olası bir bebek telsizi koydu. Bu yüzden Ruthie’ye odamda uyuması için beş dolar ödemek zorunda kaldım ve sarmalanmış kıyafetleri onun odasına koydum.” Ruthie, Margo’nun kız kardeşi. “Şimdi olay lanet Görevimiz Tehlike gibi. Eskiden kahrolası, sıradan bir Amerikalı gibi gizlice sıvışabiliyordum... pencereden dışarı tırmanman ve çatıdan atlaman yetiyordu. Ama Tanrım, bugünlerde olay faşist bir diktatörlükte yaşamak gibi.
es: Margo empezó a hablar. —El caso es que ni siquiera les importa, solo creen que mis hazañas les hacen quedar mal. ¿Sabes lo que acaba de decirme mi padre? Me ha dicho: «No me importa que te jodas la vida, pero no nos avergüences delante de los Jacobsen. Son nuestros amigos». Ridículo. Y no te imaginas lo que me ha costado salir de esa puta casa. ¿Has visto esas películas en las que se escapan de la cárcel y meten ropa debajo de las sábanas para que parezca que hay alguien en la cama? —Asentí—. Sí, bueno, mi madre ha puesto en mi habitación una mierda de monitor de bebés para oír toda la noche mi respiración mientras duermo. Así que he tenido que darle a Ruthie cinco pavos para que durmiera en mi habitación y luego me he vestido en la suya. —Ruthie es la hermana menor de Margo—. Ahora es una mierda de Misión imposible. Hasta ahora se trataba de escabullirse como en cualquier puta casa normal, subir a la ventana y saltar, pero, joder, últimamente es como vivir en una dictadura fascista.
vi_translation: Margo began to tell. "The problem is that my parents don't really care, no matter how many cool feats I achieve, they just see it as ruining their reputation. Like just now, do you know what my dad said? 'I don't care what you do with your life, but don't embarrass us in front of the Jacobsens—they're friends of ours.' It's really funny. And you have no idea how much my parents have scraped to get that huge house. You know in those prison break movies, where they stuff clothes under the blanket to pretend someone's lying there?" I nodded. "Yeah, well, my mom set up this stupid baby monitor in my room to listen to me breathe while I sleep every night. So I had to pay Ruthie five bucks to sleep in my room, while I stuffed a bunch of clothes on her bed." Ruthie is Margo's younger sister. "So it turned into a whole Mission Impossible thing. I used to just sneak out of the house, like any normal damn American—just climb out the window and jump off the roof. But my god, now it's like living under a fascist dictatorship."
tr_translation: Margo started talking. “The thing is, they don't even care, they just feel like my adventures make them look bad. Do you know what my dad just said? He said: ‘I don't care if you mess up your life, but don't embarrass us in front of the Jacobsens... they are our friends.’ Ridiculous. And you can't even imagine how hard they make it to get out of that damn house. You know in prison break movies, they put bundled clothes under the blanket to make it look like someone is there?’ I nodded. “Well, my mom put a damn baby monitor in my room so she could hear me breathing all night. So I had to pay Ruthie five dollars to sleep in my room and put the bundled clothes in her room.” Ruthie is Margo’s sister. “Now it’s like damn Mission Impossible. I used to be able to sneak out like a regular, damn American... just climbing out the window and jumping off the roof was enough. But God, these days it’s like living in a fascist dictatorship.”
es_translation: Margo began to speak. —The thing is, they don't even care, they just think my exploits make them look bad. Do you know what my father just told me? He said: "I don't care if you screw up your life, but don't embarrass us in front of the Jacobsens. They are our friends." Ridiculous. And you can't imagine how hard it was for me to get out of that damn house. Have you seen those movies where they escape from jail and put clothes under the sheets to make it look like there's someone in the bed? —I nodded—. Yeah, well, my mother put a crappy baby monitor in my room to hear my breathing all night while I sleep. So I had to give Ruthie five bucks to sleep in my room, and then I got dressed in hers. —Ruthie is Margo's younger sister—. Now it's a damn Mission Impossible. It used to be about sneaking out like in any normal damn house, climbing out the window and jumping, but, damn, lately it's like living in a fascist dictatorship.

en: “Are you going to tell me where we’re going?”
vi: “Cậu có cho tớ biết là chúng ta sẽ đi đâu không?”
tr: “Nereye gittiğimizi söyleyecek misin?
es: —¿Vas a decirme adónde vamos?
vi_translation: “Can you tell me where we are going?”
tr_translation: “Are you going to tell me where we are going?”
es_translation: —Are you going to tell me where we are going?

en: “Well, first we’re going to Publix. Because for reasons I’ll explain later, I need you to go grocery shopping for me. And then to Wal-Mart.”
vi: “Ờ, đầu tiên đến siêu thị Publix. Vì những lí do tớ sẽ giải thích sau, tớ cần cậu vào mua đồ cho tớ. Sau đó sẽ đến cửa hàng Wal-Mart.”
tr: “Şey, önce Publix’e gidiyoruz. Çünkü daha sonra açıklayacağım nedenlerden ötürü. Benim için market alışverişi yapman gerekiyor. Ondan sonra Walmart’a.
es: —Bueno, primero iremos al Publix. Porque, por razones que te explicaré después, necesito que me compres unas cosas en el supermercado. Y luego iremos al Walmart.
vi_translation: “Well, first go to Publix supermarket. For reasons I will explain later, I need you to go in and buy things for me. Then we will go to the Wal-Mart store.”
tr_translation: “Well, first we are going to Publix. Because of reasons I will explain later. You need to do grocery shopping for me. Then to Walmart.”
es_translation: —Well, first we will go to Publix. Because, for reasons that I will explain to you later, I need you to buy me some things at the supermarket. And then we will go to Walmart.

en: “What, we’re just gonna go on a grand tour of every commercial establishment in Central Florida?” I asked.
vi: “Sao cơ, chúng ta sẽ lượn một vòng hoành tráng qua các tụ điểm mua sắm ở Trung Florida sao?” tôi hỏi.
tr: “Ne yani, Orta Florida’daki bütün ticari işletmeleri içeren büyük bir tur mu yapacağız?” diye sordum.
es: —¿Cómo? ¿Vamos a ir de gira por todas las tiendas de Florida? —le pregunté.
vi_translation: “What, are we going to take a grand tour through the shopping spots in Central Florida?” I asked.
tr_translation: "So what, are we going to take a big tour that includes all the commercial businesses in Central Florida?" I asked.
es_translation: —What? Are we going to tour all the stores in Florida? —I asked him.

en: “Tonight, darling, we are going to right a lot of wrongs. And we are going to wrong some rights. The first shall be last; the last shall be first; the meek shall do some earth-inheriting. But before we can radically reshape the world, we need to shop.” I pulled into the Publix then, the parking lot almost entirely empty, and parked.
vi: “Đêm nay, bạn thân mến ạ, chúng ta sẽ chấn chỉnh lại rất nhiều những sai trái. Và chúng ta sẽ làm trái một số điều phải. Kẻ đầu sẽ nên rốt và kẻ rốt sẽ nên đầu, người nhu mì sẽ hưởng được đất cho mà xem. Nhưng trước khi có thể tái định hình thế giới một cách căn bản, chúng ta phải đi mua sắm cái đã.” Thế là tôi lái xe đến Publix, bãi xe gần như không có ai, chúng tôi đỗ lại.
tr: “Canım, bu gece birçok yanlışı doğru yapacağız. Ve bazı doğruları da yanlış yapacağız. Birinciler sonuncu, sonuncular birinci olacak ve alçakgönüllüler yeryüzünü miras alacak. 4 Ama dünyayı köklü bir biçimde yeniden şekillendirmeden önce alışveriş yapma 4 Incil’e gönderme yapılmaktadır, (ç. n. lıyız.” Bu sırada Publix’e girdim, park alanı neredeyse tamamen boştu, park ettim.
es: —Cariño, esta noche tú y yo vamos a corregir un montón de errores. Y vamos a introducir errores en algunas cosas que están bien. Los primeros serán los últimos, los últimos serán los primeros, y los mansos heredarán la tierra. Pero antes de que podamos reorganizar totalmente el mundo, tenemos que comprar varias cosas. Así que me metí en el aparcamiento del Publix, casi vacío, y aparqué.
vi_translation: “Tonight, my dear friend, we will correct many wrongs. And we will do some wrongs to the right things. The first will be last and the last will be first, the meek will inherit the earth, just you wait and see. But before we can fundamentally reshape the world, we need to go shopping first.” So I drove to Publix, the parking lot was almost empty, and we parked.
tr_translation: “Darling, tonight we will make many wrongs right. And we will make some rights wrong. The first will be last, the last will be first, and the humble will inherit the earth. 4 But before radically reshaping the world, go shopping There is a reference to the 4 Gospels, (cf. n.) we are.” At this moment, I entered Publix, the parking lot was almost completely empty, I parked.
es_translation: —Honey, tonight you and I are going to correct a bunch of mistakes. And we are going to introduce mistakes into some things that are right. The first will be last, the last will be first, and the meek shall inherit the earth. But before we can totally reorganize the world, we have to buy several things. So I pulled into the Publix parking lot, almost empty, and parked.

en: “Listen,” she said, “how much money do you have on you right now?”
vi: “Này,” Margo nói, “hiện giờ cậu có bao nhiêu tiền?”
tr: “Dinle,” dedi, “şu anda üstünde ne kadar para var?
es: —Oye, ¿cuánto dinero llevas encima? —me preguntó.
vi_translation: “Hey,” Margo said, “how much money do you have right now?”
tr_translation: “Listen,” he said, “how much money do you have on you right now?”
es_translation: —Hey, how much money do you have on you? —he asked me.

en: “Zero dollars and zero cents,” I answered. I turned off the ignition and looked over at her. She wriggled a hand into a pocket of her tight, dark jeans and pulled out several hundred-dollar bills. “Fortunately, the good Lord has provided,” she said.
vi: “Không đồng và không xu,” tôi đáp. Tôi tắt động cơ và quay sang nhìn cô ấy. Margo lùa tay vào túi quần jeans sẫm màu, kéo ra mấy tờ một trăm đô-la. “Ơn trời may quá đã có đây rồi,” cô ấy nói.
tr: “Sıfır dolar, sıfır sent,” diye cevap verdim. Kontağı kapattım ve Margo’yu süzdüm. Dar, siyah kot pantolonunun cebine elini soktu ve birkaç tane yüz dolarlık banknot çıkardı. “Neyse ki yüce Tanrı yardım etti,” dedi.
es: —Cero dólares y cero céntimos —le contesté. Apagué el motor y la miré. Metió una mano en un bolsillo de sus vaqueros oscuros y ajustados, y sacó varios billetes de cien dólares. —Por suerte, Dios ha provisto —me contestó.
vi_translation: “Not a penny or a cent,” I replied. I turned off the engine and looked at her. Margo reached into the pocket of her dark jeans and pulled out a few hundred-dollar bills. “Thank goodness, here they are,” she said.
tr_translation: “Zero dollars, zero cents,” I replied. I turned off the ignition and looked at Margo. She reached into the pocket of her tight black jeans and pulled out a few hundred-dollar bills. “Luckily, the Almighty God helped,” she said.
es_translation: —Zero dollars and zero cents —I replied to him. I turned off the engine and looked at her. She put a hand into a pocket of her dark, tight jeans and pulled out several hundred-dollar bills. —Luckily, God has provided —he answered me.

en: “What the hell?” I asked.
vi: “Tiền này là sao?” tôi hỏi.
tr: “Nereden çıktı bu?” diye sordum.
es: —¿Qué mierda es esto? —le pregunté.
vi_translation: “What is this money for?” I asked.
tr_translation: "Where did this come from?" I asked.
es_translation: —What the hell is this? —I asked him.

en: “Bat mitzvah money, bitch. I’m not allowed to access the account, but I know my parents’ password because they use ‘myrnamountw3az3l’ for everything. So I made a withdrawal.” I tried to blink away the awe, but she saw the way I was looking at her and smirked at me. “Basically,” she said, “this is going to be the best night of your life.”
vi: “Tiền từ lễ Trưởng Thành Bat mitzvah đấy, ngốc ạ. Tớ không được động đến tài khoản, nhưng tớ biết thừa mật khẩu của bố mẹ vì họ dùng ‘myrnamountw3az3l’ cho tất cả mọi thứ. Thế là tớ rút thôi.” Tôi cố gắng chớp mắt cho bớt vẻ ngây thộn, nhưng Margo đã thấy cách tôi nhìn cô ấy và nhếch mép cười với tôi. “Nói đơn giản,” cô ấy bảo, “đây sẽ là đêm tuyệt nhất đời cậu.” 3.
tr: “Bat mitzva5 parası, dostum. Hesaba girmeye iznim yok ama annemle babamın şifresini biliyorum çünkü her şeye ‘myrnamountw3az31’ şifresini koyuyorlar. Ben de para çektim.” Gözlerimi kırpıştırarak hissettiğim huşu hissini uzaklaştırmaya çalıştım ama Margo ona bakış şeklimi gördü ve bana sırıttı. “Esasen,” dedi, “bu, hayatının en güzel gecesi olacak.
es: —Dinero del bat mitzvah, capullo. No tengo permiso para acceder a la cuenta, pero me sé la contraseña de mis padres porque utilizan «myrnamountw3az3l» para todo. Así que he sacado dinero. Intenté disimular mi sorpresa, pero se dio cuenta de cómo la miraba y me sonrió con suficiencia. —Será básicamente la mejor noche de tu vida. 3
vi_translation: “The money is from my Bat Mitzvah coming-of-age ceremony, you idiot. I'm not supposed to touch the account, but I totally know my parents' password because they use ‘myrnamountw3az3l’ for everything. So I just withdrew it.” I tried to blink away my dumbfounded look, but Margo had already seen the way I was looking at her and smirked at me. “Simply put,” she said, “this is going to be the best night of your life.”
tr_translation: “Bat mitzvah money, my friend. I'm not allowed to access the account, but I know my parents' password because they use 'myrnamountw3az31' for everything. So I withdrew some money.” I tried to blink away the awe I felt, but Margo saw the way I was looking at her and grinned at me. “Essentially,” she said, “this is going to be the best night of your life.”
es_translation: —Bat mitzvah money, idiot. I don't have permission to access the account, but I know my parents' password because they use "myrnamountw3az3l" for everything. So I withdrew money. I tried to hide my surprise, but she noticed how I was looking at her and smiled at me smugly. —It will basically be the best night of your life.

en: The thing about Margo Roth Spiegelman is that really all I could ever do was let her talk, and then when she stopped talking encourage her to go on, due to the facts that 1. I was incontestably in love with her, and 2. She was absolutely unprecedented in every way, and 3. She never really asked me any questions, so the only way to avoid silence was to keep her talking.
vi: 3. Về Margo Roth Spiegelman, tất cả những gì tôi có thể làm là để cô ấy nói, và khi cô ấy ngừng lời thì tôi sẽ khích lệ cô ấy hãy cứ nói tiếp đi, vì sự thật là 1. Không thể phủ nhận rằng tôi mến cô ấy, 2. Ở mọi góc độ, hoàn toàn không thể dự đoán được cô ấy sẽ làm gì, và 3. Cô ấy không bao giờ thực sự hỏi tôi điều gì, cho nên cách duy nhất để tránh sự im lặng là khuyến khích cô ấy cứ tiếp tục câu chuyện.
tr: n. Margo Roth Spiegelman’la durum şuydu: Benim tek yapabildiğim, onun konuşmasına izin vermek ve konuşmayı bıraktığında onu devam etmeye teşvik etmekti çünkü 1. Tartışmasız olarak ona âşıktım ve 2. Margo kesinlikle her bakımdan emsalsizdi ve 3. Bana hiçbir zaman gerçekten soru sormuyordu, yani sessizlikten kaçınmanın tek yolu onu konuşturmaya devam etmekti.
es: El problema con Margo Roth Spiegelman era que realmente lo único que podía hacer era dejarla hablar, y cuando se callaba, animarla a seguir hablando, por la sencilla razón de que: 1) estaba indiscutiblemente enamorado de ella; 2) era una chica sin precedentes se mirara por donde se mirase, y 3) la verdad es que ella nunca me preguntaba nada, así que la única manera de evitar el silencio era que siguiera hablando.
vi_translation: About Margo Roth Spiegelman, all I could do was let her talk, and when she stopped, I would encourage her to keep going, because the truth is 1. It cannot be denied that I liked her, 2. From every angle, it was completely unpredictable what she would do, and 3. She never really asked me anything, so the only way to avoid silence was to encourage her to keep the story going.
tr_translation: The thing about Margo Roth Spiegelman was this: All I could do was let her talk and encourage her to continue when she stopped because 1. Undoubtedly, I was in love with her and 2. Margo was absolutely unparalleled in every way and 3. She never really asked me any questions, so the only way to avoid silence was to keep her talking.
es_translation: The problem with Margo Roth Spiegelman was that the only thing I could really do was let her talk, and when she stopped, encourage her to keep talking, for the simple reason that: 1) I was indisputably in love with her; 2) she was an unprecedented girl no matter how you looked at it, and 3) the truth is that she never asked me anything, so the only way to avoid silence was for her to keep talking.

en: And so in the parking lot of Publix she said, “So, right. I made you a list. If you have any questions, just call my cell. Listen, that reminds me, I took the liberty of putting some supplies in the back of the van earlier.”
vi: Ở bãi đỗ xe vào siêu thị Publix, cô ấy nói, “Rồi, đây. Tớ đã lập danh sách cho cậu. Nếu cần hỏi gì cậu cứ gọi vào điện thoại di động của tớ. Mà này, nói mới nhớ, tớ đã tự giành lấy chút tự do xếp một ít đồ ở phía sau xe rồi nhé.”
tr: Sonuçta Publix’in park alanında Margo, “Evet, tamam. Sana bir liste yaptım. Eğer bir sorun olursa cebimi ara. Bak, bu bana önceden arabanın arkasına sana sormadan birkaç malzeme koyduğumu hatırlattı,” dedi.
es: Ya en el aparcamiento del Publix me dijo: —Bueno, veamos. Te he hecho una lista. Si tienes alguna duda, llámame al móvil. Ah, ahora que lo pienso, antes me he tomado la libertad de meter algunas provisiones en la parte de atrás del coche.
vi_translation: In the parking lot of the Publix supermarket, she said, "Alright, here you go. I've made a list for you. If you have any questions, just call my cell phone. Oh, by the way, speaking of which, I took the liberty of putting some stuff in the back of the car."
tr_translation: In the end, in the Publix parking lot, Margo said, "Yes, okay. I made you a list. If there's a problem, call my cell. Look, this reminded me that I put some supplies in the back of the car without asking you beforehand," she said.
es_translation: Already in the Publix parking lot, he told me: —Well, let's see. I've made a list for you. If you have any questions, call me on my mobile. Oh, now that I think about it, earlier I took the liberty of putting some provisions in the back of the car.

en: “What, like, before I agreed to all this?”
vi: “Hả, sao cơ, kể cả khi tớ chưa đồng ý ấy hả?”
tr: “Ne, ben bütün bunları kabul etmeden önce mi?
es: —¿Cómo? ¿Antes de que aceptara implicarme?
vi_translation: “Huh, what, even when I haven't agreed yet?”
tr_translation: “So, before I accept all this?”
es_translation: —What? Before I agreed to get involved?

en: “Well, yes. Technically yes. Anyway, just call me if you have any questions, but with the Vaseline, you want the one that’s bigger than your fist. There’s like a Baby Vaseline, and then there’s a Mommy Vaseline, and then there’s a big fat Daddy of a Vaseline, and that’s the one you want. If they don’t have that, then get, like, three of the Mommies.” She handed me the list and a hundred-dollar bill and said, “That should cover it.”
vi: “Ờ, ừ. Thực tế như vậy đấy. Dù sao, nếu có gì thắc mắc thì cứ gọi điện cho tớ. Riêng về Vaseline, cậu cần lấy loại to hơn nắm tay cậu một chút. Như là có loại Vaseline Bé Cưng này, loại Vaseline Mẹ Bé này, rồi Vaseline Bố Bé béo ú, đấy là loại cần mua. Nếu không thấy loại đó thì lấy, xem nào, ba lọ Vaseline Mẹ Bé.” Margo đưa tôi tờ danh mục và một trăm đô-la, nói.
tr: “Şey, evet. Teknik olarak evet. Her neyse, eğer bir sorun olursa sadece beni ara ama Vazelin konusunda yumruğundan daha büyük olanı alacaksın. Yani bir Bebek Vazelin var, bir de Anne Vazelin var ve bir de kocaman bir Baba Vazelin var, işte ondan alacaksın. Eğer ondan yoksa o zaman üç tane falan annelerden al.” Listeyi ve yüz dolarlık banknotu uzatıp, “Bu yetecektir,” dedi.
es: —Bueno, sí. Técnicamente sí. En fin, llámame si tienes alguna pregunta, pero coge el bote de vaselina que es más grande que tu puño. Hay vaselina pequeña, vaselina mediana y una vaselina enorme, que es la que tienes que coger. Si no la tienen, coge tres de las medianas.
vi_translation: “Uh, yeah. That's actually the case. Anyway, if you have any questions, just give me a call. As for Vaseline, you need to get a size slightly bigger than your fist. There's this Baby Vaseline, then there's Mommy Vaseline, and then there's Daddy Vaseline, which is the one you need to buy. If you can't find that, then get, let's see, three jars of Mommy Vaseline.” Margo handed me the list and a hundred dollars, saying. “This should be enough.”
tr_translation: “Well, yes. Technically yes. Anyway, if there's a problem, just call me, but you'll get the one that's bigger than your fist when it comes to Vaseline. So there's a Baby Vaseline, a Mother Vaseline, and a huge Father Vaseline, you'll get that one. If they don't have that, then get about three of the mothers.” Handing over the list and the hundred-dollar bill, “This will be enough,” he said.
es_translation: —Well, yes. Technically, yes. Anyway, call me if you have any questions, but grab the jar of Vaseline that's bigger than your fist. There's small Vaseline, medium Vaseline, and a huge Vaseline, which is the one you need to get. If they don't have it, get three of the medium ones. —He handed me the list and a hundred-dollar bill, and said—:
