tr: “Ama Lacey sürekli böyle küçük yorumlar yaptı,” diye devam etti Margo. ‘“Sana bu şortu ödünç verirdim ama sana tam olacağını sanmıyorum.’ Ya da, ‘Çok cesursun. Erkekleri kişiliğine âşık etmene bayılıyorum.’ Daima bana zarar vermeye çalıştı. Bana zarar vericiliği olmayan tek bir söz söylediğini bile sanmıyorum.”
es: —Pues siempre hace ese tipo de comentarios —siguió diciendo Margo—. «Te prestaría estos pantalones cortos, pero no creo que te queden bien», o «Eres muy valiente. Me encanta cómo consigues que los chicos se enamoren de tu personalidad». Todo el tiempo menoscabándome. Creo que nunca ha dicho nada que en realidad no fuera un intento de menoscabación.
vi_translation: “But that girl is always blabbering about things like that,” Margo continued. “‘I’ll lend you my pants, but I doubt they’ll fit you.’ And then ‘You’re so strong. I love the way you make the boys go crazy because of your personality. You're always mocking me. It seems like she never says anything without intentionally trying to put me down.”
tr_translation: “But Lacey kept making these little comments,” Margo continued. ‘“I would lend you these shorts, but I don't think they would fit you.’ Or, ‘You're so brave. I love how you make guys fall in love with your personality.’ She always tried to hurt me. I don't think she ever said a single word that wasn't hurtful.”
es_translation: —Well, she always makes those kinds of comments —Margo continued saying—. «I would lend you these shorts, but I don't think they would fit you well», or «You are very brave. I love how you get guys to fall in love with your personality». All the time undermining me. I think she has never said anything that wasn't actually an attempt to undermine me.

en: “Undermining.”
vi: “Dìm.”
tr: “Zarar verme olasılığı.
es: —Menoscabo.
vi_translation: "Dim."
tr_translation: “The possibility of harm.”
es_translation: —I diminish.

en: “Thank you, Annoying McMasterGrammician.”
vi: “Cảm ơn ngài Xành Ngữ Pháp Đến Phát Phiền.”
tr: “Teşekkür ederim, Bay Sıkıcı DilbilgiUzmanıoğlu.” “Dilbilgisi,” dedim.
es: —Gracias, señor plasta gramatical.
vi_translation: "Thank you, Mr. Grammar to the Point of Annoyance."
tr_translation: • “Thank you, Mr. Boring GrammarExpert.” “Grammar,” I said.
es_translation: —Thank you, Mr. Grammar Stickler.

en: “Oh my God I’m going to kill you!” But she was laughing.
vi: “Giời ạ, tớ sẽ giết cậu cho coi!” Nhưng Margo bật cười khi nói vậy.
tr: “Ah Tannm, seni öldüreceğim!” Ama gülüyordu.
es: —¡Te mataré! —exclamó sonriendo.
vi_translation: “Oh my God, I will kill you, just watch!” But Margo laughed as she said that.
tr_translation: "Ah Tannm, I will kill you!" But he was laughing.
es_translation: —I will kill you! —he exclaimed, smiling.

en: I drove around the perimeter of Jefferson Park so we could avoid driving past our houses, just in case our parents had woken up and discovered us missing. We drove in along the lake (Lake Jefferson), and then turned onto Jefferson Court and drove into Jefferson Park’s little faux downtown, which felt eerily deserted and quiet. We found Lacey’s black SUV parked in front of the sushi restaurant. We stopped a block away in the first parking spot we could find not beneath a streetlight.
vi: Tôi lái xe men theo Công viên Jefferson để tránh đi qua nhà tôi và Margo, phòng trường hợp bố mẹ hai đứa thức giấc và phát hiện ra chúng tôi trốn nhà. Chúng tôi đi men hồ (Hồ Jefferson), rẽ ở Jefferson Court, vào phố mua sắm trung tâm của cả khu Jefferson Park, lúc này vắng vẻ và yên tĩnh một cách đầy ma mị. Chúng tôi thấy chiếc SUV màu đen của Lacey đỗ trước một hiệu sushi. Tôi đỗ xe cách đó một tòa nhà, nơi đầu tiên có thể đỗ được mà không có đèn đường chiếu sáng.
tr: Arabayı Jefferson Park’ın etrafında sürdüm, böylece evlerimizin yanından geçmekten kaçınabildik, ebeveynlerimizin uyanıp evde olmadığımızı fark etmiş olmalan ihtimaline karşı. Göl (Jefferson Gölü) boyunca gittik, sonra Jefferson Adliyesi’ne döndük ve ürkütücü bir şekilde ıssız ve sessiz görünen Jefferson Park’m küçük, yapay merkezine gittik. Lacey’nin siyah arazi aracını suşi restoranının önüne park edilmiş halde bulduk. Bir blok uzakta, sokak ışığı altında olmayan bulduğumuz ilk park yerinde durduk.
es: Di un rodeo por Jefferson Park para evitar pasar por nuestras casas, por si acaso nuestros padres se habían despertado y habían descubierto que no estábamos. Bordeamos el lago (el lago Jefferson), giramos por Jefferson Court y nos dirigimos hacia el pequeño y artificial centro de Jefferson Park, que parecía siniestramente desierto y tranquilo. Encontramos el todoterreno negro de Lacey aparcado frente al restaurante de sushi. Aparcamos a una manzana de distancia, en el primer sitio que encontramos que no estaba debajo de una farola.
vi_translation: I drove along Jefferson Park to avoid passing by my house and Margo's, in case our parents woke up and discovered we had snuck out. We followed the lake (Jefferson Lake), turned at Jefferson Court, into the central shopping street of the entire Jefferson Park area, which was eerily quiet and deserted at this hour. We saw Lacey's black SUV parked in front of a sushi restaurant. I parked the car a building away, the first available spot without streetlights.
tr_translation: I drove the car around Jefferson Park, so we could avoid passing by our houses, in case our parents had woken up and noticed we weren't home. We went along the lake (Jefferson Lake), then turned towards Jefferson Courthouse. we went to the small, artificial center of Jefferson Park, which looked eerily deserted and silent. We found Lacey's black SUV parked in front of the sushi restaurant. We stopped a block away, in the first parking spot we found that wasn't under a streetlight.
es_translation: I took a detour through Jefferson Park to avoid passing by our houses, just in case our parents had woken up and discovered that we weren't there. We skirted the lake (Jefferson Lake), turned onto Jefferson Court, and headed towards the small, artificial center of Jefferson Park, which seemed eerily deserted and quiet. We found Lacey's black SUV parked in front of the sushi restaurant. We parked a block away, in the first spot we found that wasn't under a streetlight.

en: “Would you please hand me the last fish?” Margo asked me. I was glad to get rid of the fish because it was already starting to smell. And then Margo wrote on the paper wrapper in her lettering: your Friendship with ms Sleeps with The fishes We wove our way around the circular glow of the streetlights, walking as casually as two people can when one of them (Margo) is holding a sizable fish wrapped in paper and the other one (me) is holding a can of blue spray paint. A dog barked, and we both froze, but then it was quiet again, and soon we were at Lacey’s car.
vi: “Cậu làm ơn đưa tớ con cá cuối cùng được không?” Margo hỏi. Tôi mừng rơn thoát được con cá đó vì nó bắt đầu bốc mùi. Và Margo viết lên giấy bọc theo kiểu của cô ấy: tình Bạn của mi với ms đã Ngủ với Lũ cá rồi Chúng tôi tránh những chùm sáng từ đèn đường, bước đi tự nhiên hết mức có thể dù một người (Margo) đang cầm một con cá to gói trong giấy bọc, và người kia (tôi) đang lăm lăm bình xịt sơn trong tay. Một con chó nhăng nhẳng sủa, hai đứa tôi đều bất động, nhưng rồi lại yên tĩnh, và chúng tôi đã đến được chỗ xe của Lacey.
tr: “Son balığı bana uzatır mısın?” diye sordu Margo. Balıktan kurtulduğuma memnundum çünkü çoktan kokmaya başlamıştı. Sonra Margo ambalaj kâğıdına kendi yazım şekliyle yazdı: ms’yle olan Arkadaşlığın Balıklarla Uyuyor Sokak lambalarının dairesel ışıltıları etrafında zikzaklar çizerek ilerledik, biri (Margo) kâğıda sarılmış büyükçe bir balık ve diğeri (ben) bir kutu mavi sprey boya tutan iki insanın yürüyebileceği kadar sıradan bir şekilde yürüyorduk. Bir köpek havladı ve ikimiz de donakaldık ama sonra ortalık tekrar sessizleşti ve çok geçmeden Lacey’nin arabasına vardık.
es: —¿Me pasas el último pescado, por favor? —me preguntó Margo. Me alegraba de que nos quitáramos de encima el pescado, porque ya empezaba a oler. Y entonces Margo escribió con su letra en el papel que lo envolvía: «Tu Amistad con ms Duerme con Los peces». Serpenteamos entre los haces de luz circulares de las farolas, paseando lo más disimuladamente que pueden pasear dos personas cuando una de ellas (Margo) lleva un pescado de considerable tamaño envuelto en papel, y la otra (yo) lleva un espray de pintura azul. Un perro ladró, y los dos nos quedamos inmóviles, pero enseguida se calló y no tardamos en llegar al coche de Lacey.
vi_translation: “Could you please give me the last fish?” Margo asked. I was relieved to get rid of that fish because it was starting to smell. And Margo wrote on the wrapping paper in her style: your FriendShip with ms has Slept with the Fishes We avoided the beams of streetlights, walking as naturally as possible even though one person (Margo) was holding a large fish wrapped in paper, and the other (me) was clutching a spray paint can. A dog barked incessantly, and the two of us froze, but then it quieted down, and we reached Lacey's car.
tr_translation: “Can you pass me the last fish?” Margo asked. I was glad to be rid of the fish because it had already started to smell. Then Margo wrote on the wrapping paper in her own handwriting: Friendship with ms is Sleeping with Fish We moved forward in zigzags around the circular glows of the street lamps, walking as ordinarily as two people could, one (Margo) holding a large fish wrapped in paper and the other (me) holding a can of blue spray paint. A dog barked and we both froze, but then it got quiet again and soon we arrived at Lacey's car.
es_translation: —Can you pass me the last fish, please? —Margo asked me. I was glad that we got rid of the fish, because it was already starting to smell. And then Margo wrote in her handwriting on the paper that wrapped it: "Your Friendship with ms Sleeps with The fishes". We weaved between the circular beams of light from the streetlights, walking as inconspicuously as two people can when one of them (Margo) is carrying a considerable-sized fish wrapped in paper, and the other (me) is carrying a can of blue spray paint. A dog barked, and we both froze, but it quickly quieted down and we soon reached Lacey's car.

en: “Well, that makes it harder,” Margo said, seeing it was locked. She reached into her pocket and pulled out a length of wire that had once been a coat hanger. It took her less than a minute to jimmy the lock open. I was duly awed.
vi: “Chà, thế này sẽ khó hơn đây,” Margo nói khi thấy xe được khóa. Cô ấy tìm trong túi và lấy ra một đoạn dây kim loại từng là cái mắc áo. Chưa đầy một phút Margo đã mở được cửa xe. Tôi chỉ biết ngây ra thán phục.
tr: “Şey, bu durumu daha da zorlaştırıyor,” dedi Margo arabanın kilitli olduğunu görünce. Cebine uzandı ve bir zamanlar elbise askısı olan bir parça tel çıkardı. Kilidi açması bir dakikadan daha az zamanını aldı. Hayran kaldım tabii ki.
es: —Bueno, esto complica las cosas —dijo Margo al ver que estaba cerrado. Se metió una mano en el bolsillo y sacó un trozo de alambre que alguna vez había sido una percha. Tardó menos de un minuto en desbloquear la cerradura. Me quedé sorprendido, por supuesto.
vi_translation: “Well, this is going to be harder,” Margo said when she saw the car was locked. She searched in her bag and took out a piece of wire that used to be a coat hanger. In less than a minute, Margo had the car door open. I could only stand there in awe.
tr_translation: “Well, this makes things even more difficult,” said Margo when she saw that the car was locked. She reached into her pocket and pulled out a piece of wire that was once a clothes hanger. It took her less than a minute to unlock the car. Of course, I was impressed.
es_translation: —Well, this complicates things —said Margo upon seeing that it was closed. He put a hand in his pocket and took out a piece of wire that had once been a hanger. It took him less than a minute to unlock the lock. I was surprised, of course.

en: Once she had the driver’s-side door open, she reached over and opened my side. “Hey, help me get the seat up,” she whispered. Together we pulled the backseat up. Margo slipped the fish underneath it, and then she counted to three, and in one motion we slammed the seat down on the fish. I heard the disgusting sound of catfish guts exploding. I let myself imagine the way Lacey’s SUV would smell after just one day of roasting in the sun, and I’ll admit that a kind of serenity washed over me. And then Margo said, “Put an M on the roof for me.”
vi: Mở được cửa bên ghế lái xe, Margo nhoài người mở cánh cửa bên kia cho tôi. “Này, giúp tớ dựng ghế ngồi lên,” cô ấy thì thầm. Chúng tôi cùng dựng ghế sau lên. Margo nhét con cá xuống dưới rồi đếm đến ba, và chỉ bằng một động tác, chúng tôi thả tấm ghế xuống, đè lên con cá. Tôi nghe thấy âm thanh gớm ghiếc khi lòng phèo nội tạng cá bị dẹp lép. Tôi cho phép mình tưởng tượng chiếc SUV của Lacey sẽ đượm mùi thế nào sau một ngày như rang như quay trong ánh mặt trời, và phải thừa nhận rằng một cảm giác thư thái mãn nguyện đã trào dâng trong tôi. Rồi Margo nói, “Ịn một chữ M lên nóc xe cho tớ.”
tr: Sürücü kapısını açar açmaz uzanıp benim tarafımdakini de açtı. “Hey, koltuğu yukarı kaldırmama yardım et,” diye fısıldadı. Arka koltuğu beraberce yukarı çektik. Margo balığı koltuğun altına itekledi, sonra üçe kadar saydı ve tek bir hareketle koltuğu balığın üzerine indirdik. Kedi balığının iç organları patlayınca çıkan iğrenç sesi duydum. Sadece bir gün güneşin altında kavrulduktan sonra Lacey’nin arabasının nasıl kokacağını hayal etmeye çalıştım ve itiraf ediyorum ki üstümden bir tür huzur akıp gitti. Sonra Margo, “Benim için tavana M yaz,” dedi.
es: En cuanto hubo abierto la puerta del conductor, extendió el brazo y abrió la de mi lado. —Hey, ayúdame a levantar el asiento —me susurró. Levantamos el asiento entre los dos. Margo metió el pescado debajo, contó hasta tres y en un solo movimiento volvimos a colocar el asiento en su sitio. Oí el asqueroso sonido de las tripas del pez gato reventando. Imaginé cómo olería el todoterreno de Lacey después de un día asándose al sol y admito que me invadió una especie de serenidad. —Haz una M en el techo —me pidió Margo.
vi_translation: Opening the door on the driver's side, Margo leaned over to open the other door for me. "Hey, help me lift the seat up," she whispered. We lifted the back seat together. Margo shoved the fish underneath and counted to three, and with a single motion, we dropped the seat down, crushing the fish. I heard the disgusting sound of the fish's guts being squished flat. I allowed myself to imagine how Lacey's SUV would smell after a day roasting in the sunlight, and I had to admit that a feeling of serene satisfaction welled up inside me. Then Margo said, "Spray an M on the roof for me."
tr_translation: As soon as the driver opened his door, he reached over and opened mine too. "Hey, help me lift the seat up," he whispered. Together, we lifted the back seat up. Margo shoved the fish under the seat, then counted to three, and in one swift motion, we lowered the seat onto the fish. I heard the disgusting sound of the catfish's internal organs bursting. I tried to imagine how Lacey's car would smell after just one day baking in the sun, and I confess, a kind of peace washed over me. Then Margo said, "Write an M on the ceiling for me."
es_translation: As soon as he had opened the driver's door, he extended his arm and opened the one on my side. —Hey, help me lift the seat —he whispered to me. We lifted the seat between the two of us. Margo put the fish underneath, counted to three, and in one swift motion, we put the seat back in place. I heard the disgusting sound of the catfish's guts bursting. I imagined how Lacey's SUV would smell after a day baking in the sun, and I admit a kind of serenity washed over me. —Make an M on the ceiling —Margo asked me.

en: I didn’t even have to think about it for a full second before I nodded, scrambled up onto the back bumper, and then leaned over, quickly spraying a gigantic M all across the roof. Generally, I am opposed to vandalism. But I am also generally opposed to Lacey Pemberton—and in the end, that proved to be the more deeply held conviction. I jumped off the car. I ran through the darkness—my breath coming fast and short—for the block back to the minivan. As I put my hand on the steering wheel, I noticed my pointer finger was blue. I held it up for Margo to see. She smiled, and held out her own blue finger, and then they touched, and her blue finger was pushing against mine softly and my pulse failed to slow. And then after a long time, she said, “Part Nine— downtown.”
vi: Chẳng nghĩ hết một giây tôi đã gật đầu tắp lự, trèo lên thanh hãm xung ở phía sau, rướn về phía trước và nhanh gọn phun một chữ M khổng lồ lên nóc xe. Nhìn chung, tôi chống lại mọi hình thức phá hoại. Nhưng nhìn chung tôi cũng chống lại Lacey Pemberton–và rút cục, đó chính là lời tuyên án sâu xa và sâu sắc hơn. Tôi nhảy khỏi chiếc xe, chạy vội trong bóng tối–bắt đầu thở dốc và gấp gáp hơn–về phía chiếc minivan ở cách đó một khối nhà. Khi đặt tay lên tay lái, tôi nhận ra ngón trỏ của mình có màu xanh da trời. Tôi giơ lên cho Margo xem. Cô ấy cười, cũng giơ ngón tay xanh của mình ra, và những ngón tay chạm nhau, ngón tay xanh của Margo mềm mại chạm vào tôi, mạch máu trong người tôi không tài nào chậm lại nổi. Mãi một lúc lâu sau, Margo mới nói: “Phần Chín–trung tâm thành phố.”
tr: Başımı sallamadan önce bir saniye bile düşünmeme gerek yoktu, arka tampona tırmandım, sonra eğilip sprey boyayla hızlıca tavan boyunca kocaman bir M yazdım. Normalde vandalizme karşıydım. Ama normalde Lacey Pemberton’a da karşıydım... ve sonuçta bunun daha derinden savunulan bir inanç olduğu kanıt landı. Arabadan atladım. Karanlığa doğruhızlı ve kısa nefesler alarakminivana giden blok boyunca koştum. Elimi direksiyona koyarken işaret parmağımın mavi olduğunu fark ettim. Margo görsün diye parmağımı yukarı kaldırdım. Gülümsedi ve kendi mavi parmağını uzattı, sonra parmaklarımız birbirine değdi, onun mavi parmağı yumuşakça benimkini itiyordu ve nabzım yavaşlamayı başaramadı. Uzun bir süre sonra Margo, “Dokuzuncu Bölüm... şehir merkezi,” dedi.
es: No me lo pensé ni un segundo. Asentí, me subí en el parachoques trasero, me incliné hacia delante y rápidamente pinté con el espray una M gigante en el techo. Normalmente estoy en contra del vandalismo, pero también normalmente estoy en contra de Lacey Pemberton, y al final esta última resultó ser mi convicción más arraigada. Salté del coche y corrí en la oscuridad —mi respiración era cada vez más acelerada y más breve— hacia el monovolumen. Al poner la mano en el volante, vi que tenía el dedo índice azul. Lo levanté para que Margo lo viera. Sonrió, levantó su dedo azul, y ambos se tocaron, su dedo azul empujaba suavemente el mío, y mi pulso no conseguía desacelerarse.
vi_translation: Without thinking for even a second, I nodded immediately, climbed onto the rear bumper, leaned forward, and quickly sprayed a giant letter M on the roof of the car. In general, I am against all forms of vandalism. But in general, I am also against Lacey Pemberton–and ultimately, that is a deeper and more profound verdict. I jumped off the car, ran quickly in the dark–starting to breathe more heavily and rapidly–towards the minivan a block away. When I placed my hand on the steering wheel, I realized my index finger was blue. I held it up for Margo to see. She laughed, held up her own blue finger, and our fingers touched, Margo's soft blue finger touching mine, and the blood in my veins couldn't slow down. After a long moment, Margo finally said: “Part Nine–downtown.”
tr_translation: I didn't need to think for even a second before nodding my head, I climbed onto the rear bumper, then bent down and quickly spray-painted a huge M across the roof. Normally, I was against vandalism. But normally, I was also against Lacey Pemberton... and after all, this proved to be a more deeply held belief. It landed. I jumped out of the car. I ran along the block towards the minivan, taking quick and short breaths into the darkness. As I put my hand on the steering wheel, I noticed that my index finger was blue. I raised my finger for Margo to see. She smiled and extended her own blue finger, then our fingers touched, her blue finger softly pushing mine, and my pulse couldn't slow down. After a long while, Margo said, “Section Nine... downtown.”
es_translation: I didn't think about it for even a second. I nodded, climbed onto the rear bumper, leaned forward, and quickly sprayed a giant M on the roof. Normally, I'm against vandalism, but I'm also normally against Lacey Pemberton, and in the end, the latter turned out to be my most deeply held conviction. I jumped off the car and ran in the darkness —my breathing becoming more rapid and shorter— towards the minivan. As I put my hand on the steering wheel, I saw that my index finger was blue. I lifted it so Margo could see it. She smiled, lifted her blue finger, and we touched, her blue finger gently pushing mine, and my pulse couldn't slow down. —Ninth part —he said after a good while—:

en: It was 2:49 in the morning. I had never, in my entire life, felt less tired.
vi: Lúc ấy là 2:49 sáng. Chưa bao giờ, trong cả cuộc đời mình, tôi thấy rã rời đến vậy.
tr: Saat sabahın 02:49’uydu. Hayatım boyunca hiçbir zaman daha az yorgun hissetmemiştim.
es: —Novena parte —dijo un buen rato después—: Al centro. Eran las 2:49 de la madrugada. Nunca en toda mi vida había estado menos cansado.
vi_translation: It was 2:49 AM. Never in my entire life had I felt so exhausted.
tr_translation: It was 2:49 in the morning. I had never felt less tired in my entire life.
es_translation: To the center. It was 2:49 in the morning. Never in my entire life had I been less tired.

en: Tourists never go to downtown Orlando, because there’s nothing there but a few skyscrapers owned by banks and insurance companies. It’s the kind of downtown that becomes absolutely deserted at night and on the weekends, except for a few nightclubs half-filled with the desperate and the desperately lame. As I followed Margo’s directions through the maze of one-way streets, we saw a few people sleeping on the sidewalk or sitting on benches, but nobody was moving. Margo rolled down the window, and I felt the thick air blow across my face, warmer than night ought to be. I glanced over and saw strands of hair blowing all around her face. Even though I could see her there, I felt entirely alone among these big and empty buildings, like I’d survived the apocalypse and the world had been given to me, this whole and amazing and endless world, mine for the exploring.
vi: Khách du lịch không bao giờ đến trung tâm Orlando vì ở đó chẳng có gì ngoài vài tòa cao ốc của các ngân hàng và hãng bảo hiểm. Khu trung tâm hoàn toàn vắng vẻ về đêm và cuối tuần, trừ mấy hộp đêm lẻ tẻ, phân nửa trong số khách là những người thảm hại hoặc dặt dẹo một cách thảm hại. Trong khi tôi lái xe, Margo chỉ đường cho tôi đi qua mê cung những con phố một chiều, chúng tôi thấy lác đác có người ngủ trên vỉa hè hoặc vạ vật trên ghế băng, nhưng không có ai cử động cả. Margo hạ cửa kính xe xuống, không khí căng tràn từ bên ngoài phả lên mặt tôi, ấm áp hơn tiết trời đêm thông thường. Tôi liếc sang thấy mấy lọn tóc lòa xòa bay ngang mặt cô ấy. Dù Margo ở ngay đây, tôi vẫn cảm thấy hoàn toàn cô đơn giữa những cao ốc đồ sộ trống trải này, như thể tôi là kẻ sống sót sau ngày tận thế và thế giới đã được ủy thác cho tôi, toàn bộ thế gian vô tận và ẩn giấu đầy bất ngờ này, tất cả là của tôi, để tôi mặc sức khám phá.
tr: Turistler asla Orlando’nun şehir merkezine gitmezler çünkü orada bankalara ve sigorta şirketlerine ait birkaç gökdelenden başka bir şey yoktur. Burası geceleri ve hafta sonlan tamamen ıssız olan türde bir şehir merkezidir, umutsuzlar ve umutsuzca sıkıcı olanlarla yan yarıya dolan birkaç gece kulübü dışında. Ben tekyönlü sokaklar labirentinde Margo’nun tarifine göre yol alırken, kaldıranda uyuyan ya da bankta oturan birkaç insan gördük ama hiç kimse hareket etmiyordu. Margo camı aşağı indirdi, yüzüme doğru esen boğuk havayı hissettim, geceleri olması gerekenden daha ılıktı. Margo’ya bir bakınca yüzünün her tarafında uçuşan saç tellerini gördüm. Margo’nun orada olduğunu görmeme rağmen, bu büyük ve boş binaların arasında kendimi tamamen yalnız hissettim; sanki kıyametten sonra hayatta kalmışım ve dünya bana bahşedilmiş gibi, bütün bu hayret verici ve sonsuz dünya keşfedilmek üzere benimmiş gibi.
es: Los turistas nunca van al centro de Orlando, porque no tiene nada, aparte de varios rascacielos de bancos y compañías de seguros. Es uno de esos centros que se quedan absolutamente desiertos por la noche y los fines de semana, excepto por un par de clubes nocturnos medio vacíos para los desesperados y los desesperadamente aburridos. Mientras seguía las indicaciones de Margo por el laberinto de calles de un solo sentido, vimos a varias personas durmiendo en las aceras o sentadas en bancos, pero nadie se movía. Margo bajó la ventanilla y sentí en la cara una densa ráfaga de aire, más cálido de lo habitual por las noches. Miré a Margo y vi mechones de pelo volando alrededor de su cara. Aunque estaba viéndola, me sentí totalmente solo en medio de aquellos edificios altos y vacíos, como si hubiera sobrevivido al apocalipsis, y el mundo, todo aquel mundo sorprendente e infinito, se abriera ante mí para que lo explorara.
vi_translation: Tourists never come to downtown Orlando because there's nothing there except a few skyscrapers belonging to banks and insurance companies. The downtown area is completely deserted at night and on weekends, except for a few scattered nightclubs, half of whose patrons are either miserable or miserably staggering. As I drove, Margo directed me through the maze of one-way streets, and we saw a few people sleeping on the sidewalks or sprawled on benches, but none of them were moving. Margo rolled down the car window, and the air from outside rushed onto my face, warmer than the usual night weather. I glanced over and saw a few strands of her hair blowing across her face. Even though Margo was right there, I still felt completely alone among these massive, empty skyscrapers, as if I were the sole survivor of an apocalypse and the world had been entrusted to me, this entire endless and hidden world full of surprises, all for me to explore to my heart's content.
tr_translation: Tourists never go to downtown Orlando because there is nothing there except for a few skyscrapers belonging to banks and insurance companies. This is the kind of downtown that is completely deserted at night and on weekends, except for a few nightclubs half-filled with the desperate and the desperately boring. As I navigated through the labyrinth of one-way streets according to Margo's directions, we saw a few people sleeping on the sidewalk or sitting on benches, but no one was moving. Margo rolled down the window, and I felt the stale air blowing against my face, warmer than it should have been at night. When I looked at Margo, I saw strands of hair flying all over her face. Even though I could see Margo there, I felt completely alone among these big and empty buildings; as if I had survived the apocalypse and the world had been granted to me, as if this amazing and endless world was mine to explore.
es_translation: Tourists never go to downtown Orlando because it has nothing, aside from several skyscrapers of banks and insurance companies. It is one of those downtowns that become absolutely deserted at night and on weekends, except for a couple of half-empty nightclubs for the desperate and the desperately bored. While following Margo's directions through the maze of one-way streets, we saw several people sleeping on the sidewalks or sitting on benches, but no one was moving. Margo rolled down the window and I felt a dense gust of air on my face, warmer than usual at night. I looked at Margo and saw strands of hair flying around her face. Even though I was looking at her, I felt completely alone amidst those tall and empty buildings, as if I had survived the apocalypse, and the world, that whole surprising and infinite world, opened up before me for exploration.

en: “You just giving me the tour?” I asked.
vi: “Cậu dẫn tớ đi vòng vòng thế này thôi sao?” tôi hỏi.
tr: “Bana sadece tur mu attırıyorsun?” diye sordum.
es: —¿Estás llevándome de gira turística? —le pregunté.
vi_translation: “Are you just going to lead me around in circles like this?” I asked.
tr_translation: “Are you just taking me for a ride?” I asked.
es_translation: —Are you taking me on a sightseeing tour? —I asked him.

en: “No,” she said. “I’m trying to get to the SunTrust Building. It’s right next to the Asparagus.”
vi: “Không,” Margo đáp. “Tớ đang chỉ đường đến tòa nhà SunTrust, ở ngay cạnh Cây Măng Tây.”
tr: “Hayır,” dedi. “SunTrust binasına ulaşmaya çalışıyorum. Kuşkonmaz’ın tam yanında.
es: —No —me contestó—. Intento llegar al SunTrust Building. Está justo al lado del Espárrago.
vi_translation: “No,” Margo replied. “I’m giving directions to the SunTrust building, right next to the Asparagus Tree.”
tr_translation: “No,” he said. “I am trying to reach the SunTrust building. Right next to Kuşkonmaz.”
es_translation: —No —he answered me—. I'm trying to get to the SunTrust Building. It's right next to the Asparagus.

en: “Oh,” I said, because for once on this night I had useful information. “That’s on South.” I drove down a few blocks and then turned. Margo pointed happily, and yes, there, before us, was the Asparagus.
vi: “Ồ,” tôi thốt lên, vì lần đầu tiên trong đêm nay tôi biết chút thông tin hữu ích. “Chỗ đó ở hướng nam.” Tôi lái xe qua vài khối nhà rồi rẽ. Margo vui vẻ chỉ, đúng, kia rồi, trước mặt chúng tôi, là Cây Măng Tây.
tr: “Ya,” dedim, çünkü bu gece ilk defa faydalı bir bilgi almıştım. “Orası güneyde.” Birkaç blok daha ilerleyip döndüm. Margo mutlu bir şekilde eliyle işaret etti ve evet, Kuşkonmaz işte orada, tam önümüzdeydi.
es: —Ah —dije, porque por primera vez aquella noche disponía de información útil—. Está al sur. Dejé atrás varias manzanas y giré. Margo señaló muy contenta, y sí, ante nosotros estaba el Espárrago.
vi_translation: “Oh,” I exclaimed, for the first time tonight I knew some useful information. “That place is to the south.” I drove through a few blocks and then turned. Margo cheerfully pointed, yes, there it was, in front of us, the Asparagus Tree.
tr_translation: “Yes,” I said, because tonight I had received useful information for the first time. “It’s down south.” I drove a few more blocks and turned. Margo pointed happily with her hand and yes, Asparagus was right there, directly in front of us.
es_translation: —Ah —I said, because for the first time that night I had useful information—. It's to the south. I left several blocks behind and turned. Margo pointed very happily, and yes, in front of us was the Asparagus.

en: The Asparagus is not, technically, an asparagus spear, nor is it derived from asparagus parts. It is just a sculpture that bears an uncanny resemblance to a thirty-foot-tall piece of asparagus— although I’ve also heard it likened to:
vi: Cây Măng Tây thực ra không phải là đọt măng tây mọc từ dưới đất lên, cũng không dính dáng gì đến bộ phận nào của măng tây. Đó chỉ là khối điêu khắc tương đồng một cách kì dị với hình thù một cây măng tây cao cỡ chục mét, cơ mà tôi cũng thấy nhiều người bảo rằng nó giống:
tr: Kuşkonmaz teknik olarak ne bir kuşkonmaz filizi ne de kuşkonmaz parçalarından oluşuyor. Sadece yaklaşık dokuz metrelik bir kuşkonmaz parçasına esrarengiz bir benzerlik taşıyan bir heykel... Bununla birlikte şunlara benzediğini de duymuştum:
es: Técnicamente, el Espárrago no es un espárrago ni un derivado del espárrago. Es una escultura rara de diez metros que parece un espárrago, aunque también he oído compararla con:
vi_translation: The Asparagus Tree is actually not the asparagus shoot growing from the ground, nor is it related to any part of the asparagus. It is merely a sculpture that bizarrely resembles an asparagus tree about ten meters tall, though I have also heard many people say that it looks like:
tr_translation: Technically, the asparagus is neither an asparagus shoot nor made up of asparagus parts. It's just a sculpture that bears a mysterious resemblance to a roughly nine-meter piece of asparagus... However, I had also heard that it resembles the following:
es_translation: Technically, the Asparagus is neither an asparagus nor a derivative of asparagus. It is a rare ten-meter sculpture that looks like an asparagus, although I have also heard it compared to:

en: 1. A green-glass beanstalk
vi: 1. Một cây đậu leo bằng thủy tinh xanh
tr: 1. Yeşil camdan fasulye sapı
es: 1. Un tallo de judías de vidrio.
vi_translation: 1. A bean plant climbing on green glass
tr_translation: 1. Beanstalk made of green glass
es_translation: 1. A glass bean stalk.

en: 2. An abstract representation of a tree
vi: 2. Mô phỏng trừu tượng về một cái cây
tr: 2. Soyut bir ağaç temsil
es: 2. Una representación abstracta de un árbol.
vi_translation: 2. An abstract simulation of a tree
tr_translation: 2. An abstract representation of a tree
es_translation: 2. An abstract representation of a tree.

en: 3. A greener, glassier, uglier Washington Monument
vi: 3. Tượng đài Washington phiên bản xanh hơn, có vẻ ve chai và xấu xí hơn
tr: 3. Daha yeşil, daha camsı, daha çirkin bir Washington Anıtı
es: 3. Un monumento a Washington, pero verde, de vidrio y feo.
vi_translation: 3. The Washington Monument, a greener version, seems more like scrap and uglier
tr_translation: 3. A greener, more glassy, uglier Washington Monument
es_translation: 3. A monument to Washington, but green, made of glass, and ugly.

en: 4. The Jolly Green Giant’s gigantic jolly green phallus
vi: 4. Tượng sinh thực khí khổng lồ màu xanh lục của Người Khổng Lồ Xanh Vui Vẻ
tr: 4. Neşeli Yeşil Dev’in neşeli yeşil devasa penisi
es: 4. El alegre y gigantesco falo verde del gigante de la marca Gigante Verde.
vi_translation: 4. The giant green phallic statue of the Jolly Green Giant
tr_translation: 4. The cheerful green giant's cheerful green gigantic penis
es_translation: 4. The cheerful and gigantic green phallus of the giant from the Green Giant brand.

en: At any rate, it certainly does not look like a Tower of Light, which is the actual name of the sculpture. I pulled in front of a parking meter and looked over at Margo. I caught her staring into the middle distance just for a moment, her eyes blank, looking not at the Asparagus, but past it. It was the first time I thought something might be wrong—not my-boyfriend-is-an-ass wrong, but really wrong. And I should have said something. Of course. I should have said thing after thing after thing after thing. But I only said, “May I ask why you have taken me to the Asparagus?”
vi: Ở mọi góc độ, khối điêu khắc chẳng có gì từa tựa Tháp Ánh Sáng, tên thật của nó cả. Tôi dừng trước một cột đồng hồ ở bãi đỗ xe và nhìn sang Margo, thấy cô ấy đang đăm đăm nhìn ra vô định, ánh mắt trống rỗng, không nhìn Cây Măng Tây mà đưa mắt đi xa hơn. Lần đầu tiên tôi cảm thấy có gì đó không ổn–không phải chuyện bạn-trai-tớ-là-đồ-bốc-mùi, mà là chuyện gì đó thực sự không ổn. Lẽ ra tôi nên nói gì đó. Hẳn là vậy. Tôi nên nói chuyện này chuyện kia chuyện đây chuyện đó. Nhưng tôi đã chỉ nói rằng, “Cho tớ hỏi này, sao lại đưa tớ đến Cây Măng Tây thế?”
tr: Her halükârda, heykelin gerçek ismi olan Işık Kulesi gibi görünmüyordu. Bir parkometrenin önüne çektim ve Margo’ya baktım. Onu bir anlığına ortalama bir mesafeye gözü dalmış halde yakaladım, boş gözlerle Kuşkonmaz’a değil, onun ötesine bakıyordu. Bu bir şeylerin ters olabileceğini düşündüğüm ilk andı “erkek arkadaşım bir pislik” tersliği değil, gerçek bir terslik. Bir şeyler söylemeliydim. Şüphesiz, bir şeyin ardına bir şey ve bir şey daha söylemeliydim ama yalnızca, “Neden beni Kuşkonmaz’a getirdiğini sorabilir miyim?” dedim.
es: En cualquier caso, de lo que no cabe la menor duda es de que no parece una Torre de Luz, que es como realmente se llama la escultura. Aparqué delante de un parquímetro y miré a Margo. La pillé mirando fijamente al frente con ojos inexpresivos, pero no miraba el Espárrago, sino más allá. Por primera vez pensé que quizá algo iba mal, no del tipo «mi novio es gilipollas», sino algo malo de verdad. Y yo debería haber dicho algo. Por supuesto. Debería haber dicho un millón de cosas. Pero me limité a decir: —¿Puedo preguntarte por qué me has traído al Espárrago?
vi_translation: From every angle, the sculpture didn't resemble the Tower of Light, its real name, at all. I stopped in front of a clock post in the parking lot and looked over at Margo, seeing her staring blankly into the distance, her eyes empty, not looking at the Asparagus Tree but gazing far beyond it. For the first time, I felt that something was wrong—not the my-boyfriend-is-a-jerk kind of wrong, but something truly amiss. I should have said something. Probably. I should have talked about this, that, here, there. But I only said, "Let me ask you, why did you bring me to the Asparagus Tree?"
tr_translation: In any case, it didn't look like the real name of the statue, which was Light Tower. I parked in front of a parking meter and looked at Margo. I caught her for a moment staring into the distance with blank eyes, not at Asparagus, but beyond it. This was the first moment I thought something might be wrong—not the "my boyfriend is a jerk" kind of wrong, but a real wrong. I should have said something. Undoubtedly, I should have said one thing after another and another, but I only said, "Can I ask why you brought me to Asparagus?"
es_translation: In any case, what is beyond the slightest doubt is that it does not seem like a Tower of Light, which is what the sculpture is actually called. I parked in front of a parking meter and looked at Margo. I caught her staring straight ahead with expressionless eyes, but she wasn't looking at the Asparagus, she was looking beyond it. For the first time, I thought that maybe something was wrong, not the kind of "my boyfriend is an asshole" wrong, but something truly bad. And I should have said something. Of course. I should have said a million things. But I just said: —Can I ask you why you have brought me to the Asparagus?

en: She turned her head to me and shot me a smile. Margo was so beautiful that even her fake smiles were convincing. “We gotta check on our progress. And the best place to do that is from the top of the SunTrust Building.”
vi: Cô ấy quay lại và mỉm cười với tôi. Margo đẹp đến mức thậm chí những nụ cười giả dối của cô ấy cũng thành đáng tin. “Chúng ta sẽ kiểm tra tiến độ công việc. Và nơi lí tưởng để làm việc đó là từ nóc tòa nhà SunTrust.”
tr: Başını bana çevirdi ve gülümsedi. Margo o kadar güzeldi ki sahte gülümsemeleri bile inandırıcıydı. “İlerlememizi kontrol etmeliyiz. Ve bunu yapmak için en iyi yer SunTrust binasının tepesi.
es: Se giró hacia mí y me regaló una sonrisa. Margo era tan guapa que incluso sus falsas sonrisas resultaban convincentes. —Vamos a valorar nuestros avances. Y el mejor sitio para hacerlo es en lo alto del SunTrust Building.
vi_translation: She turned around and smiled at me. Margo was so beautiful that even her fake smiles were believable. "We will check the progress of the work. And the ideal place to do that is from the roof of the SunTrust building."
tr_translation: She turned her head to me and smiled. Margo was so beautiful that even her fake smiles were convincing. "We need to check our progress. And the best place to do that is the top of the SunTrust building."
es_translation: She turned towards me and gave me a smile. Margo was so beautiful that even her fake smiles were convincing. —Let's evaluate our progress. And the best place to do it is at the top of the SunTrust Building.

en: I rolled my eyes. “Nope. No. No way. You said no breaking and entering.”
vi: Tôi trợn tròn mắt. “Không. Không đâu. Không đời nào. Cậu đã bảo không có đột nhập lén lút và tự tiện ra vào rồi cơ mà.”
tr: Gözlerimi devirdim. “Hayır. Kesinlikle olmaz. Haneye tecavüz yok demiştin.
es: Miré al cielo. —No. No. Imposible. Has dicho que no habría allanamientos de morada.
vi_translation: I widened my eyes. "No. No way. Not a chance. You said there would be no sneaking in and out without permission."
tr_translation: I rolled my eyes. “No. Absolutely not. You said no breaking and entering.”
es_translation: I looked at the sky. —No. No. Impossible. You said there would be no breaking and entering.

en: “This isn’t breaking and entering. It’s just entering, because there’s an unlocked door.”
vi: “Đây không phải là đột nhập lén lút. Chỉ việc đi vào thôi, vì có một cửa không khóa.
tr: “Bu haneye tecavüz değil. Sadece içeri gireceğiz çünkü kilitlenmemiş bir kapı söz konusu.
es: —No es un allanamiento de morada. Basta con entrar, porque hay una puerta que no está cerrada con llave.
vi_translation: “This is not a stealthy break-in. Just go in, because there is an unlocked door.”
tr_translation: "This is not a home invasion. We are just going to enter because it is an unlocked door."
es_translation: —It is not a breaking and entering. Just go in, because there is a door that is not locked.

en: “Margo, that’s ridiculous. Of c—”
vi: “Margo, như vậy nực cười quá. Tất...”
tr: “Margo, bu çok saçma. Tabii ki...
es: —Margo, es ridículo. Te asegu…
vi_translation: “Margo, that's so ridiculous. All...”
tr_translation: “Margo, this is so ridiculous. Of course...”
es_translation: —Margo, it's ridiculous. I assu…

en: “I will acknowledge that over the course of the evening there has been both breaking and entering. There was entering at Becca’s house. There was breaking at Jase’s house. And there will be entering here. But there has never been simultaneous breaking and entering. Theoretically, the cops could charge us with breaking, and they could charge us with entering, but they could not charge us with breaking and entering. So I’ve kept my promise.”
vi: “Tớ điểm lại cho cậu hay, đêm nay mình đã nhúng tay vào cả mớ đột nhập lén lút và tự tiện ra vào rồi đó. Xông vào nhà Becca. Lẻn vào nhà Jase. Bây giờ chúng ta sẽ đàng hoàng vào đây. Nhưng không thể vừa đột nhập lén lút vừa tùy tiện ra vào được. Về lí thuyết, cảnh sát có thể bắt chúng ta vì tội đột nhập lén lút hoặc tùy tiện ra vào, nhưng họ không thể bắt chúng ta vì tội đột nhập lén lút và tự tiện ra vào. Tức là tớ vẫn giữ lời hứa mà.”
tr: “Kabul ediyorum, gece boyunca farklı hanelere izinsizce girdik. Becca’nın evine izinsiz girdik. Jase’in evine izinsiz girdik. Burada ise sadece içeri gireceğiz. Hiçbiri tam anlamıyla haneye tecavüz sayılmaz. Teoride polisler bizi haneye izinsiz girmekle suçlayabilirler ama bizi haneye tecavüzle suçlayamazlar. Yani sözümü tuttum.
es: —Estoy dispuesta a admitir que esta noche ha habido allanamiento de morada. Hemos allanado la morada de Becca y la de Jase. Pero en este caso la poli no podrá acusarnos de allanamiento de morada, puesto que no vamos a entrar en una morada. —Seguro que el SunTrust Building tiene guardia de seguridad o lo que sea —le dije.
vi_translation: “Let me recap for you, tonight we've been involved in a bunch of sneaky break-ins and unauthorized entries. Breaking into Becca's house. Slipping into Jase's house. Now we're going to enter here properly. But we can't both sneak in and enter at will. Technically, the police could arrest us for sneaky break-ins or unauthorized entries, but they can't arrest us for both sneaky break-ins and unauthorized entries. So I'm still keeping my promise.”
tr_translation: “I admit, throughout the night we entered different households without permission. We entered Becca's house without permission. We entered Jase's house without permission. Here, we will just enter. None of these fully count as trespassing. In theory, the police could charge us with unauthorized entry. They can accuse us, but they cannot charge us with trespassing. So, I kept my word.”
es_translation: —I am willing to admit that tonight there has been a break-in. We have broken into Becca's place and Jase's place. But in this case, the police won't be able to accuse us of breaking and entering, since we are not going to enter a dwelling. —I'm sure the SunTrust Building has a security guard or something —I told him.

en: “Surely the SunTrust Building has, like, a security guard or whatever,” I said.
vi: “Tòa SunTrust chắc phải có nhân viên an ninh bảo vệ gì đó chứ,” tôi nói.
tr: “Mutlaka, SunTrust binasının bir güvenlik görevlisi falan vardır,” dedim.
es: —Seguro que el SunTrust Building tiene guardia de seguridad o lo que sea —le dije.
vi_translation: “The SunTrust building must have some security personnel or something,” I said.
tr_translation: “Surely, there must be a security guard or something at the SunTrust building,” I said.
es_translation: —I'm sure the SunTrust Building has a security guard or something —I told him.

en: “They do,” she said, unbuckling her seat belt. “Of course they do. His name is Gus.”
vi: “Có,” cô ấy đáp, tháo đai an toàn. “Tất nhiên họ có bảo vệ. Anh ấy tên là Gus.”
tr: “Var,” dedi, emniyet kemerini açarken. “Tabii ki var. Adı Gus.”
es: —Sí, tiene guardia de seguridad —me contestó desabrochándose el cinturón de seguridad—. Por supuesto. Se llama Gus.
vi_translation: “Yes,” she replied, unbuckling her seatbelt. “Of course they have security. His name is Gus.”
tr_translation: “Yes,” he said, unbuckling his seatbelt. “Of course there is. His name is Gus.”
es_translation: —Yes, it has a security guard —he answered me as he unbuckled his seatbelt—. Of course. His name is Gus.

en: We walked in through the front door. Sitting behind a broad, semicircular desk sat a young guy with a struggling goatee wearing a Regents Security uniform. “What’s up, Margo?” he said.
vi: Chúng tôi đi vào qua cổng chính. Ngồi sau một bàn rộng hình bán nguyệt là một anh tre trẻ, cằm râu dê lún phún, mặc đồng phục công ty An ninh Regents. “Gì thế, Margo?” anh ta hỏi.
tr: On kapıdan içeri girdik. Geniş, yanın daire şeklinde bir masanın arkasında, ince bir keçisakalı olan ve Regents Güvenlik üniforması giyen genç bir adam oturuyordu. “Nasılsın, Margo?” dedi.
es: Cruzamos la puerta principal. Al otro lado de un mostrador semicircular estaba sentado un chico con una incipiente perilla y vestido con uniforme de vigilante de seguridad.
vi_translation: We entered through the main gate. Sitting behind a wide semicircular desk was a young man with a faint goatee, wearing a Regents Security company uniform. "What's up, Margo?" he asked.
tr_translation: We walked in through the door. Behind a wide, circular table, a young man with a thin goatee, wearing a Regents Security uniform, was sitting. "How are you, Margo?" he said.
es_translation: We crossed the main door. On the other side of a semicircular counter sat a young man with an incipient goatee, dressed in a security guard uniform. —How are you, Margo?

en: “Hey, Gus,” she answered.
vi: “Chào anh Gus,” cô ấy đáp.
tr: “Selam Gus,” diye cevap verdi Margo.
es: —¿Qué tal, Margo? —le preguntó. —Hola, Gus —le contestó Margo.
vi_translation: “Hello, Gus,” she replied.
tr_translation: “Hi Gus,” Margo replied.
es_translation: —he asked her. —Hi, Gus —Margo replied.

en: “Who’s the kid?”
vi: “Nhóc nào đấy?”
tr: “Çocuk kim?
es: —¿Quién es este crío?
vi_translation: "Which kid is that?"
tr_translation: "Who is the child?""
es_translation: —Who is this kid?

en: WE ARE THE SAME AGE! I wanted to shout, but I let Margo talk for me. “This is my colleague, Q. Q, this is Gus.”
vi: CHÚNG TÔI BẰNG TUỔI NHAU ĐÓ! Tôi muốn gào lên, nhưng đã để Margo lên tiếng thay: “Bạn học của em, tên là Q ạ. Q ơi, đây là anh Gus.”
tr: AYNI YAŞTAYIZ! diye bağırmak istedim ama Margo’nun benim yerime konuşmasına izin verdim. “Bu benim iş arkadaşım, Q. Q, bu Gus.
es: «¡SOMOS DE LA MISMA EDAD!», quise gritar, pero dejé que Margo hablara por mí. —Es mi amigo Q. Q, este es Gus.
vi_translation: WE ARE THE SAME AGE! I wanted to scream, but let Margo speak instead: "My classmate, his name is Q. Q, this is Gus."
tr_translation: I wanted to shout, "WE'RE THE SAME AGE!" but I let Margo speak for me. “This is my coworker, Q. Q, this is Gus.”
es_translation: “WE ARE THE SAME AGE!” I wanted to shout, but I let Margo speak for me. —This is my friend Q. Q, this is Gus.

en: “What’s up, Q?” asked Gus.
vi: “Có chuyện gì thế Q?” Gus hỏi.
tr: “Nasılsın, Q?” diye sordu Gus.
es: —¿Qué te cuentas, Q? —me preguntó Gus.
vi_translation: “What’s going on, Q?” Gus asked.
tr_translation: "How are you, Q?" asked Gus.
es_translation: —What’s up, Q? —Gus asked me.

en: Oh, we’re just scattering some dead fish about town, breaking some windows, photographing naked guys, hanging out in skyscraper lobbies at three-fifteen in the morning, that kind of thing. “Not much,” I answered.
vi: Ồ, chúng tôi vừa rải cá chết trong thành phố, đập vỡ mấy cái cửa sổ, chụp ảnh giai lõa thể, bây giờ sẽ bày trò vui ở hành lang một tòa nhà chọc trời vào lúc ba giờ mười lăm phút sáng, đại loại thế. “Không đáng kể,” tôi đáp.
tr: Ah, sadece şehirde dolaşıp ölü balık dağıtıyoruz, pencere kırıyoruz, çıplak adamların fotoğrafını çekiyoruz, sabah saat üç buçukta gökdelen lobilerinde takılıyoruz, böyle şeyler işte. “Pek bir şey yok,” diye cevap verdim.
es: «Pues nada, estamos repartiendo unos cuantos peces muertos por la ciudad, rompiendo algunas ventanas, haciendo fotos a tipos desnudos, dando una vuelta por rascacielos privados a las tres y cuarto de la madrugada…, esas cosas». —No demasiado —le contesté.
vi_translation: Oh, we just scattered dead fish around the city, smashed a few windows, took photos of naked guys, and now we're going to have some fun in the hallway of a skyscraper at three fifteen in the morning, something like that. "Nothing significant," I replied.
tr_translation: Ah, we're just wandering around the city distributing dead fish, breaking windows, taking photos of naked men, hanging out in skyscraper lobbies at three-thirty in the morning, things like that. "Not much," I replied.
es_translation: "Well, nothing much, we're distributing a few dead fish around the city, breaking some windows, taking photos of naked guys, wandering around private skyscrapers at a quarter past three in the morning... you know, those kinds of things." —Not too much —I replied to him.

en: “Elevators are down for the night,” Gus said. “Had to shut ’em off at three. You’re welcome to take the stairs, though.”
vi: “Đêm thang máy không lên đâu,” Gus nói. “Phải tắt đi lúc ba giờ. Hai đứa cứ tự nhiên đi cầu thang bộ.”
tr: “Asansörler bu gece çalışmıyor,” dedi Gus. “Saat üçte kapatmak zorunda kaldım.
es: —Los ascensores no funcionan por la noche —dijo Gus—. Tengo que apagarlos a las tres. Pero podéis subir por la escalera.
vi_translation: "The elevator doesn't go up at night," Gus said. "It has to be turned off at three o'clock. You two can just use the stairs."
tr_translation: “The elevators are not working tonight,” said Gus. “I had to shut them down at three o'clock. Still, please go ahead and use the stairs.”
es_translation: —The elevators don't work at night —said Gus—. I have to turn them off at three. But you can use the stairs.

en: “See ya, Margo.”
vi: “Ừ, Margo.”
tr: “Görüşürüz, Margo.
es: —Hasta luego, Margo.
vi_translation: "Yes, Margo."
tr_translation: "See you, Margo.""
es_translation: —See you later, Margo.

en: “How the hell do you know the security guard at the SunTrust Building?” I asked once we were safely in the stairwell.
vi: “Thế quái nào mà cậu lại quen nhân viên bảo vệ tòa nhà SunTrust vậy?” tôi hỏi khi cả hai đã yên ổn leo thang bộ.
tr: “Tanrı aşkına, SunTrust binasındaki güvenlik görevlisini nereden tanıyorsun?” diye sordum merdivenlere gelir gelmez.
es: —¿Cómo cojones conoces al vigilante de seguridad del SunTrust Building? —le pregunté en cuanto estábamos a salvo en la escalera.
vi_translation: “How on earth do you know the security guard at the SunTrust building?” I asked as we both safely climbed the stairs.
tr_translation: “For God's sake, how do you know the security guard at the SunTrust building?” I asked as soon as we reached the stairs.
es_translation: —How the hell do you know the security guard at the SunTrust Building? —I asked him as soon as we were safe on the stairs.

en: “He was a senior when we were freshmen,” she answered. “We gotta hustle, okay? Time’s a-wastin’.” Margo started taking the stairs two at a time, flying up, one arm on the rail, and I tried to keep pace with her, but couldn’t. Margo didn’t play any sports, but she liked to run—I sometimes saw her running by herself listening to music in Jefferson Park. I, however, did not like to run. Or, for that matter, engage in any kind of physical exertion. But now I tried to keep up a steady pace, wiping the sweat off my forehead and ignoring the burning in my legs. When I got to the twenty-fifth floor, Margo was standing on the landing, waiting for me.
vi: “Hồi chúng ta vào phổ thông thì anh ấy học năm cuối,” Margo đáp. “Phải nhanh lên mới được. Thời gian hao mòn lãng phí.” Cô ấy bắt đầu bước hai bậc một, lao người lên, một tay bám tay vịn cầu thang, tôi cố sức theo mà không kịp. Margo không chơi môn thể thao nào nhưng thích chạy bộ–thỉnh thoảng tôi vẫn thấy cô ấy vừa chạy một mình vừa nghe nhạc trong Công viên Jefferson. Cơ mà tôi lại không thích chạy. Hoặc vì thế mà không tham gia bất cứ loại vận động lao lực nào. Giờ tôi cố gắng giữ tốc độ ổn định, quệt mồ hôi túa ra trán và phớt lờ cơn đau thốn trong bắp chân. Khi tôi lên đến tầng hai mươi lăm, Margo đã đứng ở chiếu nghỉ đợi tôi.
tr: “Biz birinci sınıftayken o son sınıftaydı,” diye cevap verdi. “Acele etmeliyiz, tamam mı? Vakit geçiyor.” Margo merdivenleri ikişer ikişer çıkmaya başladı, bir kolu tırabzanda yukarı doğru uçuyordu, ben de ona ayak uydurmaya çalıştım ama yapamadım. Margo herhangi bir spor yapmıyordu ama koşmayı severdi... Onu tek başına müzik dinleyerek Jefferson Park’ta koşarken birkaç kez görmüştüm. Ne var ki ben koşmayı ve hatta herhangi bir fiziksel eforla meşgul olmayı sevmiyordum. Ama şimdi, istikrarlı bir şekilde ona ayak uydurmaya çalışıyordum, almmdaki teri silerek ve bacaklarımdaki yanmayı görmezden gelerek. Yirmi beşinci kata ulaştığımda, Margo sahanlıkta durmuş beni bekliyordu.
es: —Estaba en el último curso del instituto cuando nosotros íbamos a primero —me contestó—. Tenemos que darnos prisa, ¿vale? Se nos acaba el tiempo. Margo empezó a subir los escalones de dos en dos, a toda velocidad y con una mano en la barandilla, y yo intenté seguirle el paso, pero no podía. Margo no hacía deporte, pero le gustaba correr. De vez en cuando la veía en Jefferson Park corriendo sola con los cascos puestos. Pero a mí no me gustaba correr. Es más, no me gustaba hacer el más mínimo esfuerzo físico. Pero intenté mantener el paso firme, secarme el sudor de la frente e ignorar que me ardían las piernas. Cuando llegué a la planta veinticinco, Margo estaba esperándome en el descansillo.
vi_translation: “When we entered high school, he was in his final year,” Margo replied. “We need to hurry up.” “Time is wasting away.” She started taking the stairs two at a time, rushing up, one hand gripping the stair railing, and I struggled to keep up. Margo didn’t play any sports but liked to jog–I occasionally saw her running alone while listening to music in Jefferson Park. But I didn’t like running. Or maybe that’s why I didn’t participate in any strenuous physical activities. Now I tried to maintain a steady pace, wiping the sweat pouring down my forehead and ignoring the throbbing pain in my calves. When I reached the twenty-fifth floor, Margo was already standing at the landing, waiting for me.
tr_translation: “When we were in the first grade, he was in the final grade,” she replied. “We need to hurry, okay? Time is passing.” Margo started climbing the stairs two at a time, one arm flying up the banister, and I tried to keep up with her but couldn't. Margo didn't do any sports, but she loved to run... Her I had seen him a few times running in Jefferson Park, listening to music alone. However, I did not like running or even engaging in any physical effort. But now, I was trying to keep up with him steadily, wiping the sweat from my forehead and ignoring the burning in my legs. When I reached the twenty-fifth floor, Margo was standing on the landing, waiting for me.
es_translation: —He was in the last year of high school when we were in the first year —he answered me—. We have to hurry up, okay? We're running out of time. Margo started climbing the steps two at a time, at full speed and with one hand on the railing, and I tried to keep up with her, but I couldn't. Margo didn't play sports, but she liked to run. From time to time, I saw her in Jefferson Park running alone with her headphones on. But I didn't like running. In fact, I didn't like making the slightest physical effort. But I tried to keep a steady pace, wipe the sweat from my forehead, and ignore the burning in my legs. When I reached the twenty-fifth floor, Margo was waiting for me on the landing.

en: “Check it out,” she said. She opened the stairwell door and we were inside a huge room with an oak table as long as two cars, and a long bank of floor-to-ceiling windows. “Conference room,” she said. “It’s got the best view in the whole building.” I followed her as she walked along the windows. “Okay, so there,” she said pointing, “is Jefferson Park. See our houses? Lights still off, so that’s good.” She moved over a few panes. “Jase’s house. Lights off, no more cop cars. Excellent, although it might mean he’s made it home, which is unfortunate.” Becca’s house was too far away to see, even from up here.
vi: “Xem này,” cô ấy nói, mở cánh cửa cạnh cầu thang và chúng tôi đi vào một căn phòng thênh thang với cái bàn gỗ sồi dài bằng hai chiếc ô-tô và mảng tường với những ô cửa sổ trổ từ sàn lên đến trần. “Phòng hội thảo,” Margo nói. “Trong cả tòa nhà đây là nơi có tầm nhìn đẹp nhất.” Tôi theo sau khi cô ấy đi dọc dãy cửa sổ. “Đây rồi, chỗ đó,” cô ấy vừa nói vừa chỉ, “là Công viên Jefferson. Thấy nhà tụi mình không? Đèn vẫn tắt, vậy là tốt.” Cô ấy tiến thêm vài ô cửa. “Nhà Jase này. Tắt đèn, không còn xe cảnh sát nữa. Tuyệt, dù như vậy có thể là hắn đã mò về nhà, hơi bị chán.” Nhà Becca ở xa quá nên không thấy được, dù nhìn từ tận đây.
tr: “Şuna bir bak,” dedi. Merdivenin yanındaki kapıyı açtı ve içinde iki araba uzunluğunda meşe bir masa ve tabandan tavana pencerelerle çevrili uzun bir cephesi olan kocaman bir odaya girdik. “Konferans salonu,” dedi. “Bütün binadaki en iyi manzaraya sahip.” Pencerelerin yanmda yürürken onu takip ettim. “Tamam, işte şurada,” dedi eliyle işaret ederek. “Jefferson Park. Evlerimizi görüyor musun? Işıklar hâlâ kapalı, bu iyi.” Birkaç adım yana gitti. “Jase’in evi. Işıklar kapalı, artık polis arabaları yok. Mükemmel, ancak bu, Jase’in eve vardığını da gösteriyor olabilir maalesef.” Becca’nın evi görülmeyecek kadar uzaktaydı, buradan bile.
es: —Echa un vistazo —me dijo. Abrió la puerta de la escalera y entramos en una sala enorme con una mesa de roble del tamaño de dos coches y unos ventanales que iban desde el suelo hasta el techo. —La sala de conferencias —me explicó—. Tiene las mejores vistas de todo el edificio. —La seguí mientras recorría la sala—. Bien, pues ahí está Jefferson Park —dijo señalando—. ¿Ves nuestras casas? Las luces siguen apagadas, así que perfecto. —Avanzó un par de ventanas—. La casa de Jase. Las luces apagadas y sin coches de policía. Excelente, aunque eso podría significar que ya ha llegado a casa. Mala suerte. La casa de Becca estaba demasiado lejos, incluso desde aquella altura.
vi_translation: “Look at this,” she said, opening the door next to the stairs, and we walked into a spacious room with an oak table as long as two cars and walls with windows stretching from floor to ceiling. “Conference room,” Margo said. “In the whole building, this is the place with the best view.” I followed her as she walked along the row of windows. “There, that spot,” she said, pointing, “is Jefferson Park. Can you see our house? The lights are still off, so that's good.” She moved a few more windows down. “That's Jase's house. The lights are off, no more police cars. Great, although that could mean he's already sneaked back home, which is a bit boring.” Becca's house is too far away to see, even from here.
tr_translation: “Take a look at this,” he said. He opened the door next to the stairs and we entered a huge room with an oak table as long as two cars and a long side surrounded by floor-to-ceiling windows. “Conference room,” he said. “It has the best view in the entire building.” I followed him as he walked by the windows. “Alright, there it is,” he said, pointing with his hand. “Jefferson Park. Do you see our houses? The lights are still off, that's good.” He took a few steps to the side. “Jase’s house. The lights are off, no more police cars. Perfect, but unfortunately, this might also mean that Jase has arrived home.” Becca’s house was too far to be seen, even from here.
es_translation: —Take a look —he told me. He opened the stairway door and we entered a huge room with an oak table the size of two cars and some large windows that went from the floor to the ceiling. —The conference room —he explained to me—. It has the best views in the entire building. —I followed her as she walked through the room—. Well, there's Jefferson Park —she said, pointing—. Do you see our houses? The lights are still off, so that's perfect. —She moved forward a couple of windows—. Jase's house. The lights are off and no police cars. Excellent, although that could mean he's already home. Bad luck. Becca's house was too far away, even from that height.

en: She was quiet for a moment, and then she walked right up to the glass and leaned her forehead against it. I hung back, but then she grabbed my T-shirt and pulled me forward. I didn’t want our collective weight against a single pane of glass, but she kept pulling me forward, and I could feel her balled fist in my side, and finally I put my head against the glass as gently as possible and looked around.
vi: Margo yên lặng chốc lát, rồi đi về phía cửa kính và áp trán lên đó. Tôi lần chần ở phía sau, nhưng cô ấy giật giật áo phông của tôi và kéo tôi về phía trước. Tôi không muốn dồn sức nặng của cả hai lên một ô kính duy nhất, nhưng Margo cứ kéo tôi lại, tôi cảm thấy nắm tay cô ấy ngay bên cạnh mình. Thế là rút cục tôi dựa đầu vào kính, rón rén hết mức có thể, và nhìn ra ngoài.
tr: Margo kısa bir süre sessiz kaldı, sonra camın tam kenarına yaklaşıp alnını yasladı. Ben geride kaldım ama tişörtümü tuttu ve beni ileri doğru çekti. Tek bir cama ortak ağırlımızı vermek istemiyordum ama beni çekmeye devam etti, yanımda sıkılmış yumruğunu hissedebiliyordum ve sonunda başımı mümkün olduğu kadar yavaşça cama koyup etrafa baktım.
es: Se quedó un momento callada y luego se dirigió al ventanal y apoyó la frente contra el cristal. Yo me quedé atrás, pero me agarró de la camiseta y tiró de mí. No quería que el cristal tuviera que aguantar el peso de los dos, pero siguió tirando de mí, sentía su puño en el costado, así que al final yo también apoyé la cabeza contra el cristal lo más suavemente posible y eché un vistazo.
vi_translation: Margo was silent for a moment, then walked towards the glass door and pressed her forehead against it. I lingered behind, but she tugged at my t-shirt and pulled me forward. I didn't want to put the weight of both of us on a single pane of glass, but Margo kept pulling me, and I could feel her hand right next to mine. So, in the end, I rested my head against the glass, as cautiously as possible, and looked outside.
tr_translation: Margo remained silent for a short while, then approached the very edge of the window and rested her forehead against it. I stayed behind, but she grabbed my t-shirt and pulled me forward. I didn't want to put our combined weight on a single window, but she kept pulling me, and I could feel her clenched fist beside me. Finally, I slowly placed my head against the window and looked around.
es_translation: She stayed silent for a moment and then went to the window and pressed her forehead against the glass. I stayed behind, but she grabbed me by the shirt and pulled me. I didn't want the glass to have to bear the weight of both of us, but she kept pulling me, I felt her fist at my side, so in the end, I also pressed my head against the glass as gently as possible and took a look.

en: From above, Orlando was pretty well lit. Beneath us I could see the flashing DON’T WALK signs at intersections, and the streetlights running up and down the city in a perfect grid until downtown ended and the winding streets and cul-de-sacs of Orlando’s infinite suburb started.
vi: Từ trên cao, Orlando sáng rực rỡ. Phía bên dưới, tôi có thể thấy bảng hiệu CẤM ĐI BỘ nhấp nháy chỗ vòng xuyến giao thông, đèn đường lô xô một mạng lưới hoàn hảo, lan ra đến mép khu trung tâm, nơi khởi đầu những phố ngõ ngoằn ngoèo vùng ngoại ô vô tận của Orlando.
tr: Yukarıdan bakınca Orlando oldukça iyi aydınlatılmış görünüyordu. Altımızda, kavşaklarda yanıp sönen GEÇMEYİN işaretlerini görebiliyordum, sokak lambaları şehrin her yerini kusursuz bir örgü gibi kuşatıyordu, şehir merkezi bitip Orlando’nun uçsuz bucaksız banliyölerinin dolambaçlı ve çıkmaz sokakları başlayana kadar.
es: Desde arriba, Orlando parecía bastante iluminada. Veía los semáforos parpadeantes en los cruces y las farolas alineadas por toda la ciudad, como una cuadrícula perfecta, hasta que el centro terminaba y empezaban las serpenteantes calles y los callejones de la infinita periferia de Orlando.
vi_translation: From above, Orlando shines brightly. Below, I can see the NO PEDESTRIAN sign flashing at the traffic roundabout, the streetlights forming a perfect network, spreading out to the edge of the downtown area, where the winding streets of Orlando's endless suburbs begin.
tr_translation: From above, Orlando appeared to be quite well-lit. Below us, I could see the flashing DO NOT CROSS signs at the intersections, the streetlights enveloping the entire city like a perfect mesh, until the city center ended and the winding and dead-end streets of Orlando's vast suburbs began.
es_translation: From above, Orlando seemed quite illuminated. I could see the blinking traffic lights at the intersections and the streetlights lined up throughout the city, like a perfect grid, until the center ended and the winding streets and alleys of Orlando's endless outskirts began.

en: “It’s beautiful,” I said.
vi: “Đẹp thật,” tôi nói.
tr: “Çok güzel,” dedim.
es: —Qué bonito —dije.
vi_translation: “Beautiful,” I said.
tr_translation: "Very beautiful," I said.
es_translation: —How beautiful —I said.

en: Margo scoffed. “Really? You seriously think so?”
vi: Margo khụt khịt. “Thật ư? Cậu thực sự nghĩ vậy ư?”
tr: Margo dudak büktü. “Gerçekten mi? Cidden böyle mi düşünüyorsun?
es: —Qué bonito —dije. —¿De verdad? —se burló Margo—. ¿Lo dices en serio?
vi_translation: Margo sniffled. "Really? Do you really think so?"
tr_translation: Margo pursed her lips. "Really? Do you seriously think that way?"
es_translation: —How beautiful —I said. —Really? —Margo mocked—. Are you serious?

en: “I mean, well, maybe not,” I said, although it was. When I saw Orlando from an airplane, it looked like a LEGO set sunk into an ocean of green. Here, at night, it looked like a real place—but for the first time a place I could see. As I walked around the conference room, and then through the other offices on the floor, I could see it all: there was school. There was Jefferson Park. There, in the distance, Disney World. There was Wet ’n Wild. There, the 7-Eleven where Margo painted her nails and I fought for breath. It was all here—my whole world, and I could see it just by walking around a building. “It’s more impressive,” I said out loud. “From a distance, I mean. You can’t see the wear on things, you know? You can’t see the rust or the weeds or the paint cracking. You see the place as someone once imagined it.”
vi: “Ờ, có lẽ cũng không đẹp mấy,” tôi đáp, dù quả thực tôi có thấy đẹp. Khi tôi nhìn Orlando từ máy bay, trông thành phố như khối lắp ráp đồ chơi LEGO được thả xuống một đại dương xanh lục. Còn đây, vào ban đêm, thành phố là một địa danh có thực–nhưng lần đầu tiên, là nơi tôi có thể nhìn thấy được. Khi đi quanh phòng hội thảo, rồi sang những văn phòng khác ở cùng tầng, tôi có thể thấy được tất cả: một tổng thể. Trường học. Kia là Công viên Jefferson. Xa xa là Disney World. Công viên nước Wet ’n Wild. Kia là cửa hàng 7-Eleven nơi Margo đã sơn móng tay trong khi tôi chật vật điều hòa nhịp thở. Tất cả ở đây–toàn bộ thế giới của tôi, và tôi thấy được trọn vẹn, chỉ việc thong dong đi lại trong một tòa nhà. “Ấn tượng thật,” tôi nói lớn. “Ý tớ là nhìn từ xa ấy mà. Chẳng thấy khiếm khuyết nào, cậu hiểu ý tớ chứ? Cậu không thể thấy được những hoen gỉ tàn tạ, cỏ dại um tùm hay sơn bong tróc lở. Cậu nhìn thấy thành phố đúng như ai đó đã từng tưởng tượng ra nó vậy.”
tr: ‘Yani, peki, belki de öyle değil,” dedim, aslında öyle olmasına rağmen. Orlando’yu bir uçaktan gördüğümde, bana yeşil bir okya nusa batmış bir LEGO seti gibi görünmüştü. Buradan, geceleyin, gerçek fakat ilk defa görebildiğim bir yermiş gibi görünüyordu. Konferans salonunda ve o kattaki diğer ofislerde yürürken her şeyi görebildim. Okul oradaydı. Jefferson Park oradaydı. Uzakta Disney World vardı. Wet ’n Wild oradaydı. Margo’nun tırnaklarını boyadığı, benim nefes almak için uğraştığım 7Eleven oradaydı. İşte hepsi buradaydı... bütün dünyam. Ve onu sadece bir binanın içinde yürüyerek görebiliyordum. “Daha etkileyici,” dedim yüksek sesle. “Uzaktan yani. Üstlerindeki aşınmaları göremiyorsun, anlatabiliyor muyum bilmiyorum. Pası, yabani otları ya da boyanın çatladığını göremiyorsun. Bu yeri, birinin bir zamanlar hayal ettiği gibi görüyorsun.
es: —Bueno, no sé, quizá no —le contesté, aunque me parecía bonito. Cuando vi Orlando desde un avión, me pareció una pieza de Lego hundida en un mar verde. Allí, por la noche, parecía una ciudad real, pero una ciudad real que veía por primera vez. Recorrí la sala de conferencias, y después los demás despachos de la planta. Se veía toda la ciudad. Allí estaba el instituto. Allí, Jefferson Park. Allí, en la distancia, Disney World. Allí, el parque acuático Wet’n Wild. Allí, el 7-Eleven en el que Margo se había pintado las uñas y yo hacía esfuerzos por respirar. Allí estaba todo mi mundo, y podía verlo con solo andar por un edificio. —Es más impresionante —dije en voz alta—. Desde la distancia, quiero decir. No se ve el desgaste de las cosas, ¿sabes? No se ve el óxido, las malas hierbas y la pintura cayéndose. Ves los sitios como alguien los imaginó alguna vez.
vi_translation: “Well, maybe it's not that beautiful,” I replied, even though I actually found it beautiful. When I looked at Orlando from the plane, the city looked like a LEGO toy set dropped into a green ocean. But here, at night, the city was a real place–for the first time, a place I could see. As I walked around the conference room, then to other offices on the same floor, I could see it all: a whole picture. The school. There was Jefferson Park. In the distance was Disney World. Wet ’n Wild water park. There was the 7-Eleven store where Margo painted her nails while I struggled to catch my breath. It was all here–my entire world, and I could see it completely, just by leisurely walking around a building. “Impressive,” I said aloud. “I mean, from a distance. You don't see any flaws, you know what I mean? You can't see the rust, the overgrown weeds, or the peeling paint. You see the city just as someone once imagined it.”
tr_translation: "Well, okay, maybe it's not like that," I said, even though it actually was. When I saw Orlando from a plane, it looked like a green ocean to me. It looked like a sunken LEGO set. From here, at night, it looked like a real place but one I was seeing for the first time. While walking in the conference room and the other offices on that floor, I could see everything. The school was there. Jefferson Park was there. Disney World was in the distance. Wet ’n Wild was there. The 7Eleven where Margo painted her nails and I struggled to breathe was there. Here they all were... my whole world. And I could see it just by walking inside a building. “More impressive,” I said out loud. “From a distance, I mean. You can't see the wear and tear on them, if you know what I mean. You can't see the rust, the weeds, or the paint cracking. You see this place as someone once imagined it.”
es_translation: —Well, I don't know, maybe not —I replied, although it seemed nice to me. When I saw Orlando from a plane, it looked like a Lego piece submerged in a green sea. There, at night, it seemed like a real city, but a real city that I was seeing for the first time. I walked through the conference room, and then the other offices on the floor. The whole city could be seen. There was the institute. There, Jefferson Park. There, in the distance, Disney World. There, the Wet’n Wild water park. There, the 7-Eleven where Margo had painted her nails and I struggled to breathe. There was my entire world, and I could see it just by walking through a building. —It's more impressive —I said out loud—. From a distance, I mean. You don't see the wear and tear of things, you know? You don't see the rust, the weeds, and the peeling paint. You see places as someone once imagined them.

en: “Everything’s uglier close up,” she said.
vi: “Gần lại thì cái gì cũng xấu đi mà,” Margo nói.
tr: “Yakından her şey daha çirkin,” dedi.
es: —Todo es más feo de cerca —explicó Margo.
vi_translation: “Everything looks worse up close,” Margo said.
tr_translation: “Everything is uglier up close,” he said.
es_translation: —Everything is uglier up close —explained Margo.

en: “Not you,” I answered before thinking better of it.
vi: “Trừ cậu,” tôi đáp mà chẳng kịp nghĩ ra điều gì hay ho hơn.
tr: “Sen değilsin,” dedim, doğru düzgün düşünemeden.
es: —Tú no —le contesté sin pensármelo dos veces.
vi_translation: "Except for you," I replied without having time to think of anything better.
tr_translation: "It's not you," I said, without thinking properly.
es_translation: —Not you —I replied without thinking twice.

en: Her forehead still against the glass, she turned to me and smiled. “Here’s a tip: you’re cute when you’re confident. And less when you’re not.” Before I had a chance to say anything, her eyes went back to the view and she started talking. “Here’s what’s not beautiful about it: from here, you can’t see the rust or the cracked paint or whatever, but you can tell what the place really is. You see how fake it all is. It’s not even hard enough to be made out of plastic. It’s a paper town. I mean look at it, Q: look at all those cul-de-sacs, those streets that turn in on themselves, all the houses that were built to fall apart. All those paper people living in their paper houses, burning the future to stay warm. All the paper kids drinking beer some bum bought for them at the paper convenience store. Everyone demented with the mania of owning things. All the things paper-thin and paper-frail. And all the people, too. I’ve lived here for eighteen years and I have never once in my life come across anyone who cares about anything that matters.”
vi: Margo vẫn áp trán trên cửa kính, cô ấy quay lại và mỉm cười với tôi. “Bắt bài nhé: cậu đáng yêu khi cậu tự tin. Và bớt đáng yêu đi khi thiếu tự tin.” Tôi chưa kịp phản ứng gì, cô ấy đã lại hướng tầm mắt ra ngoài và bắt đầu nói. “Phần không đẹp là thế này: từ đây, cậu không thấy được những hoen gỉ tróc lở, nhưng cậu có thể nói lên được nơi này đích thực là gì. Cậu thấy tất cả chỉ là đồ hàng mã. Thậm chí còn chẳng đủ chắc chắn để nói rằng nó được làm từ nhựa hay chất dẻo. Đây là một thành phố giấy. Cậu nhìn mà xem, Q: hãy nhìn tất cả những phố cụt ấy, những con phố rẽ vòng vào chính mình, tất cả những ngôi nhà được xây lên để rồi sẽ bị kéo sập. Tất cả những con người giấy sống trong những ngôi nhà giấy đó, đốt tương lai để sưởi ấm. Tất cả những đứa trẻ giấy đó, uống thứ bia một gã lang thang vô công rồi nghề nào đó đã mua cho chúng trong một cửa hàng tiện lợi giấy. Ai cũng như phát điên trong cơn cuồng sở hữu tài sản. Tất cả những tài sản mỏng manh như giấy và dễ rách như giấy. Và tất cả những con người đó cũng như giấy vậy. Tớ đã sống ở đây mười tám năm, và tớ chưa từng một lần trong đời gặp được ai đó quan tâm đến những điều thực sự có ý nghĩa.”
tr: Alnı hâlâ cama dayalıyken bana döndü ve gülümsedi. “Sana bir tavsiye: Kendine güvendiğin zaman sevimlisin. Güvenmediğinde ise daha az sevimlisin.” Ben bir şey söylemeye fırsat bulamadan manzaraya geri döndü ve konuşmaya başladı: “Burada güzel olmayan şey işte şu: Buradan pası, çatlak boyaları filan göremiyorsun ama bu yerin gerçekte ne olduğunu anhyorsun. Hepsinin nasü da sahte olduğunu görüyorsun. Plastikten yapılmış kadar bile sağlam değil. Kâğıttan bir kent. Yani şuna bir bak, Q, bütün şu çıkmaz sokaklara, aynı yere dönen caddelere, parçalanması için inşa edilmiş bütün şu evlere bak. Kâğıttan evlerinde yaşayan bütün şu kâğıttan insanlar, kendilerini ısıtmak için geleceği yakıyorlar. Bütün kâğıttan çocuklar, bir serserinin kâğıttan büfeden onlar için aldığı birayı içiyor. Herkes bir şeylere sahip olma çılgınlığıyla kendini kaybetmiş. Bütün bu şeyler kâğıt inceliğinde ve kâğıt kırılganlığında. Ve bütün insanlar da. On sekiz yıldır burada yaşıyorum ve hayatımda bir kez olsun gerçekten önemli bir şeyle ilgilenen tek bir insanla karşılaşmadım.
es: Se giró, sin despegar la frente del cristal, y me sonrió. —Te doy tu recompensa: eres mono cuando confías en ti mismo. Y menos mono cuando no. Antes de que hubiera tenido tiempo de decir algo, volvió los ojos a la ciudad y siguió hablando. —Te cuento lo que no me gusta: desde aquí no se ve el óxido, la pintura cayéndose y todo eso, pero ves lo que es realmente. Ves lo falso que es todo. Ni siquiera es duro como el plástico. Es una ciudad de papel. Mírala, Q, mira todos esos callejones, esas calles que giran sobre sí mismas, todas las casas que construyeron para que acaben desmoronándose. Toda esa gente de papel que vive en sus casas de papel y queman el futuro para calentarse. Todos los chicos de papel bebiendo cerveza que algún imbécil les ha comprado en la tienda de papel. Todo el mundo enloquecido por la manía de poseer cosas. Todas las cosas débiles y frágiles como el papel. Y todas las personas también. He vivido aquí dieciocho años y ni una sola vez en la vida me he encontrado con alguien que se preocupe de lo que de verdad importa.
vi_translation: Margo still had her forehead pressed against the glass door, she turned back and smiled at me. "Here's the thing: you're adorable when you're confident. And less adorable when you're not." Before I could react, she had already turned her gaze back outside and started talking. "The ugly part is this: from here, you can't see the rust and decay, but you can tell what this place really is. You see that everything is just a facade. It's not even sturdy enough to say it's made of plastic or some synthetic material. This is a paper town. Look at it, Q: look at all those dead-end streets, those roads that loop back onto themselves, all those houses built just to be torn down. All those paper people living in those paper houses, burning their futures to keep warm. All those paper kids, drinking the beer some jobless bum bought for them at a paper convenience store. Everyone is going crazy in this frenzy of property ownership. All that fragile, paper-thin property. And all those people are just like paper. I've lived here for eighteen years, and I've never once in my life met anyone who cared about the things that really matter."
