tr_translation: With her forehead still pressed against the window, she turned to me and smiled. "Here's a piece of advice: You're charming when you're confident. When you're not confident, you're less charming." Before I could say anything, she turned back to the view and started talking: "The thing that's not beautiful here is this: You can't see the rust, the cracked paint from here, but you understand what this place really is. You see how everything is fake. It's not even as sturdy as something made of plastic. A city made of paper. So look at this, Q, look at all these dead-end streets, the roads that lead to the same place, all these houses built to fall apart. All these paper people living in their paper houses, burning the future to keep themselves warm. All the paper children drinking the beer that some thug got for them from a paper kiosk. Everyone is losing themselves in the madness of owning things. All these things are paper-thin and paper-fragile. And so are all the people. I've been living here for eighteen years and I've never once met a single person who cared about something truly important in my life."
es_translation: She turned, without lifting her forehead from the glass, and smiled at me. —I give you your reward: you are cute when you trust yourself. And less cute when you don't. Before he had time to say anything, he turned his eyes to the city and continued speaking. —I'll tell you what I don't like: from here you can't see the rust, the peeling paint, and all that, but you see what it really is. You see how fake everything is. It's not even as tough as plastic. It's a paper town. Look at it, Q, look at all those alleys, those streets that turn back on themselves, all the houses they built just to fall apart. All those paper people living in their paper houses and burning the future to keep warm. All the paper kids drinking beer that some idiot bought for them at the paper store. Everyone going crazy with the obsession of owning things. All the things weak and fragile like paper. And all the people too. I've lived here for eighteen years and not once in my life have I met someone who cares about what really matters.

en: “I’ll try not to take that personally,” I said. We were both staring into the inky distance, the cul-de-sacs and quarter-acre lots. But her shoulder was against my arm, and the backs of our hands were touching, and although I was not looking at Margo, pressing myself against the glass felt almost like pressing myself against her.
vi: “Tớ sẽ cố gắng không nghĩ rằng cậu đang nói đến cá nhân cụ thể nào,” tôi nói. Chúng tôi cùng nhìn khoảng không hút mắt màu mực, những phố cụt và những lô đất làm nhà. Nhưng bờ vai cô ấy tì vào cánh tay tôi, mu bàn tay chúng tôi chạm nhau, và dù tôi không nhìn Margo, nhưng áp mặt vào cửa kính cũng khiến tôi cảm thấy gần như đang áp mặt vào cô ấy.
tr: “Bunu kişisel algılamamaya çalışacağım,” dedim, ikimiz de gözlerimizi dikmiş mürekkep gibi karanlığa, çıkmaz sokaklara ve çeyrek dönümlük bahçelere bakıyorduk. Ama Margo’nun omzu benim koluma dayalıydı ve ellerimizin üst kısımları birbirine değiyordu, Margo’ya bakmamama rağmen, cama yaslanmak neredeyse ona yaslanmakmış gibi hissettiriyordu.
es: —Intentaré no tomármelo como algo personal —le dije. Nos quedamos los dos observando la oscura distancia, las calles sin salida y los terrenos de mil metros cuadrados. Pero Margo tenía el hombro pegado a mi brazo, los dorsos de nuestras manos se tocaban y, aunque no estaba mirándola, pegarme al cristal era casi como pegarme a ella.
vi_translation: “I'll try not to think that you're talking about any specific person,” I said. We both looked at the ink-colored void, the dead-end streets, and the plots of land for houses. But her shoulder pressed against my arm, the backs of our hands touched, and even though I wasn't looking at Margo, pressing my face against the glass made me feel almost as if I were pressing my face against hers.
tr_translation: “I will try not to take it personally,” I said, as we both stared into the ink-like darkness, dead-end streets, and quarter-acre gardens. But Margo's shoulder was leaning against my arm, and the tops of our hands were touching; even though I wasn't looking at Margo, leaning against the window felt almost like leaning against her.
es_translation: —I will try not to take it personally —I said to him. We both stayed watching the dark distance, the dead-end streets, and the thousand-square-meter plots. But Margo had her shoulder pressed against my arm, the backs of our hands touched, and although I wasn't looking at her, pressing against the glass was almost like pressing against her.

en: “Sorry,” she said. “Maybe things would have been different for me if I’d been hanging out with you the whole time instead of—ugh. Just, God. I just hate myself so much for even caring about my, quote, friends. I mean, just so you know, it’s not that I am oh-so-upset about Jason. Or Becca. Or even Lacey, although I actually liked her. But it was the last string. It was a lame string, for sure, but it was the one I had left, and every paper girl needs at least one string, right?”
vi: “Xin lỗi nhé,” Margo nói. “Có thể mọi thứ đối với tớ đã rất khác nếu bấy lâu nay tớ chơi với cậu chứ không... ừ... Chỉ là, trời ạ, tớ chỉ thấy ghét bản thân quá, vì vẫn còn bận tâm đến những người bạn trong ngoặc kép của tớ. Nói thật với cậu, không phải là tớ ôi-quá-đau-khổ vì Jason. Hay Becca. Hoặc thậm chí cả Lacey, dù tớ thực sự thích cậu ấy. Nhưng đó là sợi dây nối cuối cùng. Một dây nối yếu ớt, hẳn là thế rồi, nhưng đó là sợi dây tớ để lại, và cô gái giấy nào cũng cần ít nhất một dây nối, phải không?”
tr: “Üzgünüm,” dedi. “Bunca zamandır seninle takılıyor olsaydım belki benim için her şey farklı olurdu... Of, Tanrım. Tırnak içinde arkadaşlarımı önemsediğim için bile kendimden nefret ediyorum. Yani olay ‘ah Jason yüzünden çok üzülüyorum’ filan değil. Ya da Becca yüzünden. Hatta Lacey yüzünden bile değil... gerçi onu seviyordum. Ama bu geriye kalan son ipti. Kesinlikle önemsiz bir ipti ama son ipti ve her kâğıttan kızın en azından bir tane ipe ihtiyacı vardır, değil mi?
es: —Lo siento —se disculpó—. Quizá las cosas habrían sido distintas para mí si hubiera salido contigo en lugar de… uf. Mierda. Me odio a mí misma porque me importen mis supuestos amigos. Mira, para que lo sepas, no es que me afecte tanto lo de Jason. O Becca. O incluso Lacey, aunque de verdad me caía bien. Pero fue el último hilo. Era un hilo débil, por supuesto, pero era el único que me quedaba, y toda chica de papel necesita al menos un hilo, ¿no?
vi_translation: “Sorry,” Margo said. “Maybe everything would have been very different for me if I had been hanging out with you all this time instead of... well...” It's just that, gosh, I just hate myself so much, because I still care about my so-called friends. To be honest with you, it's not that I'm oh-so-heartbroken over Jason. Or Becca. Or even Lacey, though I really did like her. But that was the last connection. A weak connection, surely, but it was the one I had left, and every paper girl needs at least one connection, right?”
tr_translation: “I'm sorry,” he said. “If I had been hanging out with you all this time, maybe everything would have been different for me... Oh, God. I even hate myself for caring about my so-called friends. So it's not like ‘oh, I'm so upset because of Jason’ or anything. Or because of Becca. Not even because of Lacey... though I did love her. But this was the last remaining thread. It was definitely an insignificant thread, but it was the last thread, and every paper girl needs at least one thread, right?”
es_translation: —I'm sorry —she apologized—. Maybe things would have been different for me if I had gone out with you instead of... ugh. Shit. I hate myself for caring about my supposed friends. Look, just so you know, it's not that Jason affects me that much. Or Becca. Or even Lacey, although I really liked her. But it was the last thread. It was a weak thread, of course, but it was the only one I had left, and every paper girl needs at least one thread, right?

en: And here is what I said. I said, “You would be welcome at our lunch table tomorrow.”
vi: Và đây là những gì tôi đã nói. “Mai cứ tự nhiên ngồi ăn trưa cùng bọn tớ đi.
tr: Ve ben de şunu dedim. Dedim ki: ‘Yann öğlen yemeğinde bizim masamızda hoş karşılanırsın.
es: Y lo que le contesté fue lo siguiente: —Puedes sentarte a comer con nosotros mañana.
vi_translation: And this is what I said. “Mai, feel free to join us for lunch.”
tr_translation: And I said this. I said: 'Yann, you are welcome to join us at our table for lunch.'"
es_translation: And what I replied was the following: —You can sit and eat with us tomorrow.

en: “That’s sweet,” she answered, her voice trailing off. She turned to me and nodded softly. I smiled. She smiled. I believed the smile. We walked to the stairs and then ran down them. At the bottom of each flight, I jumped off the bottom step and clicked my heels to make her laugh, and she laughed. I thought I was cheering her up. I thought she was cheerable. I thought maybe if I could be confident, something might happen between us.
vi: “Tốt với tớ thế,” cô ấy đáp, tiếng nói nhỏ dần. Margo quay lại và khẽ gật đầu. Tôi mỉm cười. Cô ấy mỉm cười. Tôi tin nụ cười ấy. Chúng tôi ra cầu thang rồi theo các bậc thang chạy xuống. Hết mỗi tầng, tôi nhảy cách bậc cuối và đá gót chân để làm Margo cười, và cô ấy đã bật cười. Tôi nghĩ mình đang làm cô ấy vui lên. Tôi nghĩ cô ấy dễ vui vẻ phấn khích. Tôi nghĩ nếu tôi tự tin được, biết đâu điều gì đó có thể xảy ra giữa hai đứa.
tr: “Çok tatlısın,” diye karşılık verdi sesi giderek kısılırken. Bana döndü ve yavaşça başım salladı. Gülümsedim. Gülümsedi. Gülümsemesine inandım. Merdivenlere yürüdük ve sonra koşarak aşağı indik. Her katın sonunda, onu güldürmek için son basamaktan atlayıp topuklarımı tıkırdattım, o da güldü. Onu neşelendirdiğimi düşündüm. Neşelendirilebileceğini düşündüm. Eğer kendime güvenirsem belki aramızda bir şeyler olur diye düşündüm.
es: —Muy amable —me dijo con un tono cada vez más apagado. Se giró hacia mí y asintió suavemente. Sonreí. Sonrió. Me creí su sonrisa. Nos dirigimos a la escalera y bajamos corriendo. Al final de cada tramo, saltaba desde el último escalón y chocaba los talones para hacerla reír, y Margo se reía. Pensaba que estaba animándola. Pensaba que quizá si conseguía confiar en mí mismo, podría haber algo entre nosotros.
vi_translation: “So nice to me,” she replied, her voice fading. Margo turned back and nodded slightly. I smiled. She smiled. I believed that smile. We went to the stairs and then ran down the steps. At the end of each floor, I jumped over the last step and kicked my heels to make Margo laugh, and she did laugh. I thought I was making her happy. I thought she was easily cheerful and excited. I thought if I could be confident, maybe something could happen between us.
tr_translation: “You are very sweet,” he replied as his voice gradually faded. He turned to me and slowly nodded his head. I smiled. He smiled. I believed in his smile. We walked to the stairs and then ran down. At the end of each floor, I jumped off the last step and clicked my heels to make him laugh, and he laughed. I thought I was cheering him up. I thought he could be cheered up. I thought that if I had confidence in myself, maybe something could happen between us.
es_translation: —Very kind —he said to me in an increasingly subdued tone. He turned towards me and nodded softly. I smiled. She smiled. I believed her smile. We headed to the stairs and ran down. At the end of each flight, I would jump from the last step and click my heels to make her laugh, and Margo laughed. I thought I was cheering her up. I thought that maybe if I managed to trust myself, there could be something between us.

en: I was wrong.
vi: Tôi đã nhầm.
tr: Yanılıyordum.
es: Me equivocaba.
vi_translation: I was mistaken.
tr_translation: I was mistaken.
es_translation: I was wrong.

en: Sitting in the minivan with the keys in the ignition but the engine not yet started, she asked, “What time do your parents get up, by the way?”
vi: Ngồi trong chiếc minivan khi chìa khóa đã cắm trong ổ nhưng chưa khởi động động cơ, Margo hỏi tôi, “Mà này, bố mẹ cậu dậy lúc mấy giờ vậy?”
tr: Anahtarlar kontakta ama motor henüz çalışmazken minivanda otururken Margo, “Ebeveynlerin saat kaçta kalkar bu arada?” diye sordu.
es: Sentados en el coche, con las llaves en el contacto, aunque sin haber encendido el motor, Margo me preguntó: —Por cierto, ¿a qué hora se levantan tus padres?
vi_translation: Sitting in the minivan with the key in the ignition but the engine not yet started, Margo asked me, "By the way, what time do your parents wake up?"
tr_translation: While sitting in the minivan with the keys in the ignition but the engine not yet running, Margo asked, "By the way, what time do your parents get up?"
es_translation: Sitting in the car, with the keys in the ignition, although without having started the engine, Margo asked me: —By the way, what time do your parents get up?

en: “I don’t know, like, six-fifteen?” It was 3:51. “I mean, we have two-plus hours and we’re through with nine parts.”
vi: “Tớ chẳng biết, khoảng sáu giờ mười lăm chăng?” Đang là 3:51. “Tức là chúng ta có hơn hai tiếng và đã qua truông được chín phần.
tr: “Bilmem, altı çeyrek falan.” Saat 03:51’di. “Yani, iki ya da daha fazla saatimiz var ve dokuz bölümü bitirdik.
es: —No sé, hacia las seis y cuarto, quizá. —Eran las 3:51—. Bueno, así que nos quedan dos horas y ya hemos acabado nueve partes.
vi_translation: “I don't know, maybe around six fifteen?” It's 3:51. “That means we have more than two hours and have already covered nine-tenths of the way.”
tr_translation: “I don't know, around a quarter past six.” It was 03:51. “So, we have two or more hours and we have finished nine sections.”
es_translation: —I don't know, around a quarter past six, maybe. —It was 3:51—. Well, so we have two hours left and we've already finished nine parts.

en: “I know, but I saved the most laborious one for last. Anyway, we’ll get it all done. Part Ten—Q’s turn to pick a victim.”
vi: “Ừ, nhưng tớ đã để dành phần nhọc sức nhất đến cuối cùng. Dù gì cũng sẽ xong thôi. Phần Mười–đến lượt Q chọn nạn nhân.
tr: “Biliyorum ama en zahmetli olanı sona sakladım. Her neyse, hepsini tamamlayacağız. Onuncu Bölüm... Bir kurban seçmek için Q’nun sırası.
es: —Lo sé, pero he dejado las más difíciles para el final. En fin, las terminaremos todas. Décima parte: te toca elegir a una víctima.
vi_translation: “Yes, but I saved the hardest part for last. Anyway, it will be done soon. Part Ten—it's Q's turn to choose the victim.”
tr_translation: “I know, but I saved the most difficult one for last. Anyway, we will complete them all. Chapter Ten... It's Q's turn to choose a victim.”
es_translation: —I know, but I have left the hardest ones for last. Anyway, we will finish them all. Tenth part: it's your turn to choose a victim.

en: “What?”
vi: “Hả?”
tr: “Ne?
es: —¿Qué?
vi_translation: "Huh?"
tr_translation: “What?”
es_translation: —What?

en: “I already picked a punishment. Now you just pick who we’re going to rain our mighty wrath down on.”
vi: “Tớ chọn sẵn hình phạt rồi. Cậu chỉ việc chọn người bị chịu hứng cơn bão tố cuồng nộ mà chúng ta sẽ trút xuống thôi.
tr: “Ben bir ceza seçtim bile. Şimdi sen sadece kim üstüne kudretli öfkemizi yağdıracağımızı seç.
es: —Ya tengo decidido el castigo. Ahora te toca a ti elegir sobre qué va a caer nuestra terrible ira.
vi_translation: “I've already chosen the punishment. You just need to choose the person who will bear the storm of fury that we will unleash.”
tr_translation: “I have already chosen a punishment. Now you just choose upon whom we shall unleash our mighty wrath.”
es_translation: —I have already decided the punishment. Now it's your turn to choose upon whom our terrible wrath will fall.

en: “Upon whom we are going to rain our mighty wrath,” I corrected her, and she shook her head in disgust. “And I don’t really have anyone upon whom I want to rain down my wrath,” I said, because in truth I didn’t. I always felt like you had to be important to have enemies. Example: Historically, Germany has had more enemies than Luxembourg. Margo Roth Spiegelman was Germany. And Great Britain. And the United States. And czarist Russia. Me, I’m Luxembourg. Just sitting around, tending sheep, and yodeling.
vi: “Người phải hứng chịu cơn bão tố cuồng nộ mà chúng ta sẽ trút xuống,” tôi sửa lỗi diễn đạt của cô ấy và Margo ngao ngán lắc đầu. “Tớ không thực sự muốn trút cáu giận của mình xuống đầu ai cả,” tôi nói, vì đúng là như vậy. Tôi luôn có cảm giác rằng phải là người quan trọng thì mới có kẻ thù. Chẳng hạn: Xét về lịch sử, nước Đức có nhiều kẻ thù hơn nước Luxembourg. Margo Roth Spiegelman là nước Đức. Là nước Anh. Nước Mỹ. Là nước Nga trong triều đại các Sa Hoàng. Còn tôi, tôi là Luxembourg. Chỉ nhẩn nha ngồi loanh quanh, chăn cừu và hát dân ca thôi.
tr: “Kudretli öfkemizi kimin üstüne yağdıracağımızı,” diye düzelttim, yüzünü buruşturarak başını salladı. ‘Ye gerçekten öfkemi üstüne yağdıracağım kimse yok,” dedim çünkü hakikaten yoktu. Bana her zaman, düşmanlara sahip olmak için önemli biri olmak gerekir gibi gelmişti. Örnek: Tarihsel olarak, Almanya Lüksemburg’dan daha fazla düşmana sahip olmuştu. Margo Roth Spiegelman Almanya’ydı. Ve Büyük Britanya. Ve Birleşik Devletler. Ve Çarlık Rusyası. Bense Lüksemburg’um. Sadece boş boş oturuyor, koyunlara göz kulak oluyor ve halk şarkdan söylüyordum.
es: —Sobre quién va a caer nuestra terrible ira —la corregí, y movió la cabeza con cara de fastidio—. La verdad es que no hay nadie sobre quien quiera dejar caer mi ira. Y era cierto. Siempre había creído que había que ser importante para tener enemigos. Por ejemplo: históricamente, Alemania ha tenido más enemigos que Luxemburgo. Margo Roth Spiegelman era Alemania. Y Gran Bretaña. Y Estados Unidos. Y la Rusia de los zares. Yo soy Luxemburgo. Me siento por ahí, vigilo las ovejas y canto canciones tirolesas.
vi_translation: “The person must endure the raging storm that we will unleash,” I corrected her phrasing, and Margo shook her head in exasperation. “I don't really want to unleash my anger on anyone,” I said, because that was true. I always had the feeling that one had to be important to have enemies. For example: Historically, Germany has had more enemies than Luxembourg. Margo Roth Spiegelman is Germany. Is England. Is America. Is Russia during the Tsarist era. And me, I am Luxembourg. Just idly sitting around, herding sheep and singing folk songs.
tr_translation: “Whom we shall rain our mighty wrath upon,” I corrected, as she shook her head with a grimace. “There really isn’t anyone upon whom I shall rain my wrath,” I said, because there truly wasn’t. It always seemed to me that to have enemies, one must be someone important. For example: Historically, Germany had more enemies than Luxembourg. Margo Roth Spiegelman was Germany. And Great Britain. And the United States. And Tsarist Russia. And I was Luxembourg. Just sitting idly, keeping an eye on the sheep and singing folk songs.
es_translation: —On whom our terrible wrath will fall —I corrected her, and she shook her head with an annoyed expression—. The truth is, there is no one upon whom I want to unleash my wrath. And it was true. I had always believed that you had to be important to have enemies. For example: historically, Germany has had more enemies than Luxembourg. Margo Roth Spiegelman was Germany. And Great Britain. And the United States. And Tsarist Russia. I am Luxembourg. I sit around, watch the sheep, and sing Tyrolean songs.

en: “What about Chuck?” she asked.
vi: “Chuck thì sao?” Margo hỏi.
tr: “Chuck’a ne dersin?” diye sordu.
es: —¿Qué me dices de Chuck? —me preguntó.
vi_translation: “What about Chuck?” Margo asked.
tr_translation: “What do you say to Chuck?” he asked.
es_translation: —What do you tell me about Chuck? —he asked me.

en: “Hmm,” I said. Chuck Parson was pretty horrible in all those years before he’d been reined in. Aside from the cafeteria conveyor belt debacle, he once grabbed me outside school while I waited for the bus and twisted my arm and kept saying, “Call yourself a faggot.” That was his all-purpose, I-have-a-vocabulary-of-twelve-words-so-don’t-expect-a-wide-variety-of-insults insult. And even though it was ridiculously childish, in the end I had to call myself a faggot, which really annoyed me, because 1. I don’t think that word should ever be used by anyone, let alone me, and 2. As it happens, I am not gay, and furthermore, 3. Chuck Parson made it out like calling yourself a faggot was the ultimate humiliation, even though there’s nothing at all embarrassing about being gay, which I was trying to say while he twisted my arm farther and farther toward my shoulder blade, but he just kept saying, “If you’re so proud of being a faggot, why don’t you admit that you’re a faggot, faggot?”
vi: “Hừm,” tôi đáp. Chuck Parson đã cực kì kinh khủng khiếp trong nhiều năm liền rồi mới được kìm bớt lại. Ngoài vụ vứt tôi lên băng chuyền trong căng-tin, một lần nó đã tóm lấy tôi ở ngoài cổng trường khi tôi đang đợi xe buýt, bẻ giật tay tôi ra sau và ra lệnh, “Tự nhận mình là ái đi.” Đó là kiểu sỉ nhục trong-mọi-hoàn-cảnh, vì-từ-vựng-của-tao-chỉ-có-mười-hai-từ-thôi-nên-đừng-mong-tao-sỉ-nhục-mày-theo-kiểu-khác của Chuck. Dù trò này trẻ con đến nực cười, rút cục tôi vẫn phải tự nhận mình là ái, chuyện thực sự khiến tôi cáu tiết vì 1. Tôi không nghĩ rằng bất cứ ai, huống chi là tôi, nên nói ra từ đó, 2. Dù chuyện đã xảy ra, nhưng tôi không ái, hơn nữa 3. Đối với Chuck, bắt ai đó tự nhận mình ái là cách phỉ báng thậm tệ nhất, dù thực ra đồng tính hoàn toàn không phải là điều đáng xấu hổ. Tôi cố gắng nói vậy với Chuck khi nó xoắn cánh tay tôi như muốn long khỏi bả vai, nhưng nó một mực: “Nếu mày tự hào rằng mình ái đến thế, sao không thừa nhận phắt là mình ái đi, hả đồ ái?”
tr: “Hımm,” dedim. Chuck Parson dizginlenmeden önce, bütün o yıllar boyunca oldukça korkunçtu. Kafeteryadaki taşıma bandı faciası bir yana, bir keresinde beni okulun dışında otobüs beklerken yakalamış ve kolumu çevirip, ‘İbne olduğunu söyle,” deyip durmuştu. Bütün amacı buydu, “on iki kelimelik bir sözcük dağarcığım var, bu yüzden geniş çeşitliliği olan hakaretler bekleme” tipi bir hakaret. Ve korkunç derecede çocukça olmasına rağmen sonunda ibne olduğumu söylemek zorunda kalmıştım ve bu gerçekten canımı sıkmıştı çünkü 1. Beni bırak, bu sözcüğün kimse tarafından kesinlikle kullanılmaması gerektiğini düşünüyorum, 2. Görüldüğü üzere, eşcinsel değilim ve dahası 3. Eşcinsel olmakta yanlış olan hiçbir şey olmamasına rağmen, Chuck Parson sanki ibne olduğunu söylemek dünyadaki en büyük hakaretmiş gibi davranıyordu ki kolumu kürekkemiğime doğru gittikçe daha fazla çevirirken bunu söylemeye çalışmıştım ve o sadece, “Eğer ibne olmakla bu kadar gurur duyuyorsan, neden ibne olduğunu itiraf etmiyorsun, ibne?” deyip durmuştu.
es: —Hum —le contesté. Chuck Parson había sido una pesadilla durante años, antes de que le pusieran las riendas. Además del desastre de la cinta transportadora de la cafetería, una vez me arrastró fuera del colegio y, mientras esperaba el autobús, me retorció el brazo y se dedicó a repetir: «Di que eres maricón». Era su insulto para todo, porque, como tenía un vocabulario de doce palabras, no cabía esperar una amplia variedad de insultos. Y aunque era ridículamente infantil, al final tuve que decir que era maricón, y me fastidió, porque: 1) Creo que nadie debería emplear esa palabra, mucho menos yo; 2) Resulta que no soy gay, y además, 3) Que Chuck Parson consiguiera que te llamaras a ti mismo maricón era la máxima humillación, pese a que ser gay no tiene nada de vergonzoso, cosa que intentaba explicarle mientras me retorcía el brazo y me lo levantaba cada vez más hacia el omóplato, pero él no dejaba de decir: «Si estás tan orgulloso de ser maricón, ¿por qué no reconoces que eres maricón, eres maricón?».
vi_translation: "Hmm," I replied. Chuck Parson had been extremely terrible for many years before he was finally restrained. Besides the incident of throwing me onto the conveyor belt in the cafeteria, once he grabbed me at the school gate while I was waiting for the bus, twisted my arm behind my back, and ordered, "Admit that you're gay." It was the kind of insult-in-any-situation, because-my-vocabulary-only-has-twelve-words-so-don't-expect-me-to-insult-you-in-any-other-way kind of insult from Chuck. Even though this game was ridiculously childish, in the end, I still had to admit that I was gay, which really pissed me off because 1. I don't think anyone, let alone me, should say that word, 2. Even though it happened, I'm not gay, moreover 3. To Chuck, making someone admit they're gay was the worst form of slander, even though being gay is absolutely nothing to be ashamed of. I tried to tell Chuck that while he twisted my arm like he wanted to rip it out of its socket, but he insisted: "If you're so proud of being gay, why don't you just admit that you're gay, huh, you gay?"
tr_translation: “Hmm,” I said. Chuck Parson was quite terrifying all those years before he was reined in. The conveyor belt in the cafeteria Aside from the disaster, one time he caught me waiting for the bus outside of school, twisted my arm, and kept saying, "Say you're a fag." That was his whole purpose, a "I have a twelve-word vocabulary, so don't expect a wide variety of insults" type of insult. And even though it was terribly childish, I eventually had to say that I was a fag, and it really bothered me because 1. Leaving me aside, I think that word should absolutely not be used by anyone, 2. As can be seen, I am not gay, and furthermore 3. Even though there's nothing wrong with being gay, Chuck Parson acted as if saying you're a fag was the biggest insult in the world, and while he was twisting my arm more and more towards my shoulder blade, I tried to say this, and he just kept saying, "If you're so proud of being a fag, why don't you admit you're a fag, fag?"
es_translation: —Hmm —I replied. Chuck Parson had been a nightmare for years before they put a leash on him. Besides the disaster with the cafeteria conveyor belt, he once dragged me out of school and, while waiting for the bus, twisted my arm and kept repeating: "Say you're a faggot." It was his insult for everything because, with a twelve-word vocabulary, one couldn't expect a wide variety of insults. And although it was ridiculously childish, in the end, I had to say I was a faggot, and it pissed me off because: 1) I believe no one should use that word, least of all me; 2) It turns out I'm not gay, and besides, 3) That Chuck Parson getting you to call yourself a faggot was the ultimate humiliation, even though there's nothing shameful about being gay, which I tried to explain to him while he twisted my arm and lifted it higher towards my shoulder blade, but he kept saying: "If you're so proud of being a faggot, why don't you admit you're a faggot, you're a faggot?"

en: Clearly, Chuck Parson was no Aristotle when it came to logic. But he was six three, and 270 pounds, which counts for something.
vi: Rõ như ban ngày, động đến lô-gíc thì Chuck không phải là Aristotle. Nhưng khi nó cao gần hai mét, nặng trên trăm kí, thì điều đó cũng đáng dè chừng lắm.
tr: Olay mantığa geldiğinde Chuck Parson’m Aristo sayılmadığı şüphe götürmezdi. Ama yaklaşık iki metre boyunda ve yüz yirmi kiloydu ki bu kayda değer bir özellikti.
es: Es evidente que Chuck Parson no era Aristóteles cuando de lógica se trataba. Pero medía un metro noventa y pesaba ciento veinte kilos, que no es poco.
vi_translation: As clear as day, when it comes to logic, Chuck is no Aristotle. But when he's nearly two meters tall and weighs over a hundred kilograms, that's something to be wary of.
tr_translation: When it came to logic, there was no doubt that Chuck Parson was no Aristotle. But he was about two meters tall and weighed one hundred and twenty kilos, which was a noteworthy feature.
es_translation: It is evident that Chuck Parson was not Aristotle when it came to logic. But he was one meter ninety and weighed one hundred and twenty kilos, which is not insignificant.

en: “You could make a case for Chuck,” I acknowledged. And then I turned on the car and started to make my way back toward the interstate. I didn’t know where we were going, but we sure as hell weren’t staying downtown.
vi: “Làm một vụ cho Chuck cũng được,” tôi ghi nhận. Thế là tôi quay xe, lái trở lại cao tốc liên bang. Tôi không biết sẽ đi đâu, nhưng chắc như ăn bắp là không ở khu trung tâm.
tr: “Chuck aleyhinde gerçekten iyi sebepler bulmak mümkün,” diye kabul ettim. Sonra arabayı çalıştırdım ve tekrar eyaletler arası yola doğru koyuldum. Nereye gittiğimizi bilmiyordum ama lanet olası şehir merkezinde kalmıyorduk.
es: —Chuck estaría justificado —admití. Arranqué el coche y me dirigí a la autopista. No sabía adónde íbamos, pero tenía clarísimo que no íbamos a quedarnos en el centro.
vi_translation: “Doing a job for Chuck is fine,” I noted. So I turned the car around and drove back to the interstate. I didn't know where I was going, but it was definitely not downtown.
tr_translation: “It is possible to find really good reasons against Chuck,” I admitted. Then I started the car and set off again towards the interstate road. I didn't know where we were going, but we weren't staying in the damn city center.
es_translation: —Chuck would be justified —I admitted. I started the car and headed for the highway. I didn't know where we were going, but I was very sure that we were not going to stay downtown.

en: “Remember at the Crown School of Dance?” she asked. “I was just thinking about that tonight.”
vi: “Cậu có nhớ hồi ở trường vũ đạo Crown không?” Margo hỏi. “Đêm nay tự dưng tớ chợt nhớ lại.
tr: “Crown Dans Okulu’nu hatırlıyor musun?” diye sordu. “Bu gece bunu düşünüyordum.
es: —¿Recuerdas lo de la Escuela de Baile Crown? —me preguntó Margo—. Estaba pensándolo esta noche.
vi_translation: "Do you remember the time at Crown Dance School?" Margo asked. "Tonight, I suddenly remembered it."
tr_translation: "Do you remember the Crown Dance School?" he asked. "I was thinking about it tonight."
es_translation: —Do you remember the Crown Dance School thing? —Margo asked me—. I was thinking about it tonight.

en: “Ugh. Yeah.”
vi: “Ừa, nhớ.”
tr: “Ah. Evet.
es: —Uf, sí.
vi_translation: “Yeah, I remember.”
tr_translation: “Ah. Yes.”
es_translation: —Ugh, yes.

en: “I’m sorry about that, by the way. I have no idea why I went along with him.”
vi: “Mà nhân thể tớ xin lỗi nhé. Chẳng hiểu sao hồi đó tớ lại nghe nó dụ khị.”
tr: “Bunun için üzgünüm bu arada. Neden ona eşlik ettiğim hakkında hiçbir fikrim yok.
es: —Lo siento, por cierto. No sé por qué se lo consentí.
vi_translation: “By the way, I apologize. I don't understand why I was persuaded by it back then.”
tr_translation: “I am sorry about this, by the way. I have no idea why I accompanied him.”
es_translation: —I'm sorry, by the way. I don't know why I allowed it.

en: “Yeah. It’s all good,” I said, but remembering the godforsaken Crown School of Dance pissed me off, and I said, “Yeah. Chuck Parson. You know where he lives?”
vi: “Ờ, không sao đâu,” tôi nói, nhưng thực ra trong bụng vẫn ôm cái vố nhớ đời ở trường vũ đạo Crown. “Được. Chuck Parson. Cậu biết nhà nó không?”
tr: “Evet. Hiç önemli değil,” dedim ama kahrolası Crown Dans Okulu’nu hatırlamak beni kızdırdı. “Evet. Chuck Parson. Nerede oturduğunu biliyor musun?” diye sordum.
es: —Bueno, no pasa nada —le dije, pero recordar la dichosa Escuela de Baile Crown me tocó las narices, así que añadí—: Sí. Chuck Parson. ¿Sabes dónde vive?
vi_translation: "Oh, it's okay," I said, but in reality, I was still holding onto the unforgettable incident at Crown Dance School. "Alright. Chuck Parson. Do you know where he lives?"
tr_translation: “Yes. It's not important at all,” I said, but remembering the damn Crown Dance School made me angry. “Yes. Chuck Parson. Do you know where he lives?” I asked.
es_translation: —Well, it's no big deal —I said to him, but remembering the darn Crown Dance School got on my nerves, so I added—: Yes. Chuck Parson. Do you know where he lives?

en: “I knew I could bring out your vengeful side. He’s in College Park. Get off at Princeton.” I turned onto the interstate entrance ramp and floored it. “Whoa there,” Margo said. “Don’t break the Chrysler.”
vi: “Tớ biết tớ có thể lôi ra ánh sáng bộ mặt trả thù của cậu mà. Chuck ở College Park. Rẽ ở Princeton ấy.” Tôi rẽ sang phần dốc ở vai đường, khiến gầm xe hơi cà xuống đất. “Ái dà,” Margo nói. “Đừng làm tan tành em Chrysler này chứ.”
tr: “Kindar tarafını ortaya çıkarabileceğimi biliyordum. College Park’ta. Princeton’dan çık.” Eyaletler arası yolun girişindeki yokuşa döndüm ve gazı kökleyerek çıktım. “Hop,” dedi Margo. “Chrysler’ı bozma.
es: —Sabía que podría sacar tu lado vengativo. Está en College Park. Sal en Princeton. Giré hacia la entrada de la autopista y pisé el acelerador. —¡No corras tanto! —exclamó Margo—. No vayas a romper el Chrysler.
vi_translation: “I knew I could expose your vengeful side.” “Chuck is at College Park. Turn at Princeton.” I turned onto the slope at the shoulder of the road, causing the car's undercarriage to scrape the ground. “Ouch,” Margo said. “Don't wreck this Chrysler.”
tr_translation: “I knew I could bring out your kinder side. In College Park. Leave Princeton.” I turned onto the ramp at the interstate entrance and floored the gas pedal. “Whoa,” said Margo. “Don’t break the Chrysler.”
es_translation: —I knew I could bring out your vengeful side. It's in College Park. Get off at Princeton. I turned towards the highway entrance and stepped on the accelerator. —Don't drive so fast! —exclaimed Margo—. Don't go and break the Chrysler.

en: In sixth grade, a bunch of kids including Margo and Chuck and me were forced by our parents to take ballroom dancing lessons at the Crown School of Humiliation, Degradation, and Dance. And how it worked was the boys would stand on one side and the girls would stand on the other and then when the teacher told us to, the boys would walk over to the girls and the boy would say, “May I have this dance?” and the girl would say, “You may.” Girls were not allowed to say no. But then one day—we were doing the fox-trot—Chuck Parson convinced every single girl to say no to me. Not anyone else. Just me. So I walked across to Mary Beth Shortz and I said, “May I have this dance?” and she said no. And then I asked another girl, and then another, and then Margo, who also said no, and then another, and then I started to cry.
vi: Hồi lớp sáu, đám nhóc tì có cả Margo, Chuck và tôi bị bố mẹ bắt đi học khiêu vũ ở trường Crown chuyên bồi dưỡng nhân cách và vũ đạo. Trong giờ học, con trai đứng một bên, con gái đứng bên kia, khi nào cô giáo bảo thì con trai sẽ tiến đến trước con gái, hỏi, “Cho phép tớ mời cậu nhảy điệu này được không?”, và con gái trả lời, “Được chứ.” Con gái không được phép từ chối. Nhưng một hôm–lớp học điệu fox-trot–Chuck Parson đã thuyết phục được từng đứa con gái hãy từ chối tôi. Không ai khác nữa. Chỉ mỗi tôi. Thế là khi tôi đến trước Mary Beth Shortz và nói, “Cho phép tớ mời cậu nhảy điệu này được không?”, con bé đáp không. Tôi hỏi một đứa con gái khác, một đứa khác nữa, và Margo, cô ấy cũng đáp không, và một đứa khác nữa nữa, rồi tôi khóc.
tr: Altıncı sınıfta Margo, Chuck ve ben dâhil bir grup çocuk, ebeveynlerimiz tarafından Crown Küçük Düşürülme, Aşağılanma ve Dans Okulu’nda salon dansı eğitimi almaya zorlanmıştık. İşler şu şekilde yürüyordu: Erkekler bir tarafta, kızlar diğer tarafta duruyordu, sonra öğretmen bize söylediğinde erkekler kızların yanma gidip, “Bu dansı bana lütfeder misiniz?’ diye soruyordu ve kızlar da ‘Tabii,” diyordu. Kızların hayır demesine izin verilmiyordu,. Fakat bir günfokstrot yapıyordukChuck Parson bütün kızları bana hayır demeye ikna etti. Başka birine değil. Sadece bana. Böylece karşıya geçip Mary Beth Shortz’a doğru yürüdüm ve “Bu dansı bana lütfeder misiniz?’ dedim, o da hayır dedi. Sonra başka bir kıza sordum, sonra başka birine, sonra yine hayır diyen Margo’ya, sonra başka birine ve sonra da ağlamaya başladım.
es: En sexto, a un grupo de críos, incluidos Margo, Chuck y yo, nuestros padres nos obligaron a hacer clases de baile en la Escuela de Humillación, Degradación y Baile Crown. Los chicos tenían que colocarse a un lado, las chicas al otro, y cuando la profesora nos lo decía, los chicos se acercaban a las chicas y les decían: «¿Me concedes este baile?», y las chicas les respondían: «Te lo concedo». Así funcionaba. Las chicas no podían decir que no. Pero un día, bailando el foxtrot, Chuck Parson convenció a todas y cada una de las chicas de que me dijeran que no. A nadie más. Solo a mí. Me acerqué a Mary Beth Shortz y le dije: «¿Me concedes este baile?», y me contestó que no. Entonces se lo pedí a otra chica, y a otra, y a Margo, que también me dijo que no, y luego a otra, y al final me puse a llorar.
vi_translation: Back in sixth grade, the group of kids including Margo, Chuck, and me were forced by our parents to attend dance classes at Crown School, which specialized in character building and dance. During the lessons, the boys stood on one side, the girls on the other, and when the teacher instructed, the boys would step up to the girls and ask, "May I have this dance?" and the girls would reply, "Of course." The girls were not allowed to refuse. But one day–during the fox-trot lesson–Chuck Parson convinced every girl to refuse to dance with me. No one else. Just me. So when I approached Mary Beth Shortz and asked, "May I have this dance?" she said no. I asked another girl, then another, and even Margo, and she also said no, and another girl again, until I cried.
tr_translation: In sixth grade, a group of kids including Margo, Chuck, and me were forced by our parents to take ballroom dance lessons at the Crown School of Humiliation, Degradation, and Dance. This is how it worked: The boys stood on one side, the girls on the other, and then when the teacher told us, the boys would go over to the girls and ask, 'Would you do me the honor of this dance?' and the girls would say, 'Of course.' The girls were not allowed to say no. But one day, while we were doing the foxtrot, Chuck Parson convinced all the girls to say no to me. Not to anyone else. Just to me. So I walked over to Mary Beth Shortz and asked, 'Would you do me the honor of this dance?' and she said no. Then I asked another girl, then another, then Margo who also said no, then another, and then I started to cry.
es_translation: In sixth grade, a group of kids, including Margo, Chuck, and me, were forced by our parents to take dance classes at the School of Humiliation, Degradation, and Dance Crown. The boys had to stand on one side, the girls on the other, and when the teacher told us to, the boys would approach the girls and say, "May I have this dance?" and the girls would respond, "I grant you this dance." That's how it worked. The girls couldn't say no. But one day, while dancing the foxtrot, Chuck Parson convinced each and every girl to say no to me. To no one else. Just to me. I approached Mary Beth Shortz and said, "May I have this dance?" and she answered no. Then I asked another girl, and another, and Margo, who also said no, and then another, and in the end, I started to cry.

en: The only thing worse than getting rejected at dance school is crying about getting rejected at dance school, and the only thing worse than that is going to the dance teacher and saying through your tears, “The girls are saying no to me and they’re not supposedtuh.” So of course I went weeping to the teacher, and I spent the majority of middle school trying to live down that one embarrassing event. So, long story short, Chuck Parson kept me from ever dancing the fox-trot, which doesn’t seem like a particularly horrible thing to do to a sixth-grader. And I wasn’t really pissed about it anymore, or about everything else he’d done to me over the years. But I certainly wasn’t going to lament his suffering.
vi: Điều duy nhất tệ hại hơn bị từ chối trong lớp khiêu vũ là khóc lóc vì bị từ chối trong lớp khiêu vũ, và điều duy nhất tệ hại hơn thế là tèm lem nước mắt đi kiếm cô giáo mách, “Bọn con gái không chịu nhảy với con và bọn nó hông được làm càn như vậy.” Hồi đó tất nhiên tôi đã thút thít mách cô, và phần lớn những năm tháng còn lại ở trường phổ thông cơ sở, tôi phải vật vã chung sống với sự kiện mất mặt đó. Nói ngắn gọn, Chuck Parson khiến tôi không bao giờ nhảy fox-trot nữa. Đối với một thằng lớp sáu thì cũng không phải đại họa khủng khiếp gì. Tôi không còn thực sự cố chấp nghĩ ngợi chuyện đó nữa, cũng như những chuyện khác Chuck đã gây ra cho tôi mấy năm qua. Nhưng chắc chắn tôi sẽ không nhỏ nước mắt thương cảm nếu nó phải lãnh chịu điều gì.
tr: Dans okulunda reddedilmekten daha kötü olan tek şey, dans okulunda reddedildiğiniz için ağlamaktır ve bundan da daha kötü olan tek şey, dans hocasına gidip gözyaşlarımzm arasında, “Kızlar bana hayır diyor ama öyle yapmamaları gerekiyooor,” demektir. Dolayısıyla tabii ki ağlayarak öğretmenin yanma gittim ve ortaokulun çoğunu, bu utanç verici olayı unutmaya çalışarak harcadım. Yani uzun lafın kısası, Chuck Parson bir altıncı sınıf öğrencisine, özellikle korkunç bir şeymiş gibi görünmeyen fokstrotu yapmamı sonsuza kadar engellemişti. Artık bu olay yüzünden gerçekten kızgın değildim... ya da bunca yıldır bana yaptığı diğer her şeye. Ama kesinlikle Chuck acı çektiği için hayıflanmayacaktım.
es: Lo único peor a que te rechacen en la escuela de baile es llorar porque te rechazan en la escuela de baile, y lo único peor que eso es ir a la profesora de baile y decirle llorando: «Las chicas me han dicho que no, y se supone que no deberían». Así que, cómo no, fui llorando a la profesora, y me pasé casi todos los años siguientes intentando superar aquel vergonzoso episodio. En fin, resumiendo, Chuck Parson me impidió bailar el foxtrot, lo que no parece un castigo tan horrible para alguien de sexto. Y la verdad es que ya no estaba cabreado por aquello, ni por nada de lo que me había hecho durante años. Pero estaba claro que tampoco iba a lamentar que sufriera.
vi_translation: The only thing worse than being rejected in dance class is crying because you were rejected in dance class, and the only thing worse than that is tearfully running to the teacher to tattle, "The girls won't dance with me and they shouldn't be allowed to do that." Of course, back then I did tattle to the teacher, and for most of the remaining years in middle school, I had to live with that embarrassing incident. In short, Chuck Parson made sure I never fox-trotted again. For a sixth grader, it wasn't exactly a huge catastrophe. I no longer really dwell on it, just like I don't dwell on the other things Chuck did to me over the years. But I certainly wouldn't shed a tear if something bad happened to him.
tr_translation: The only thing worse than being rejected at dance school is crying because you were rejected at dance school, and the only thing worse than that is going to the dance teacher and, through your tears, saying, "The girls are saying no to me but they shouldn't beee," So of course, I went to the teacher crying and spent most of middle school trying to forget this embarrassing incident. In short, Chuck Parson had forever prevented me, a sixth grader, from doing the foxtrot, which didn't even seem particularly terrible. I wasn't really angry about this incident anymore... or about everything else he had done to me over the years. But I definitely wasn't going to feel sorry for Chuck's suffering.
es_translation: The only thing worse than being rejected by the dance school is crying because you were rejected by the dance school, and the only thing worse than that is going to the dance teacher and telling her while crying: "The girls have said no to me, and they’re not supposed to." So, of course, I went crying to the teacher, and I spent almost all the following years trying to get over that embarrassing episode. In short, Chuck Parson prevented me from dancing the foxtrot, which doesn’t seem like such a horrible punishment for a sixth grader. And the truth is, I was no longer angry about that, nor about anything he had done to me over the years. But it was clear that I wasn’t going to regret if he suffered either.

en: “Wait, he won’t know it’s me, will he?”
vi: “Hượm đã, nó sẽ không phát hiện ra tớ chứ?”
tr: “Bekle, benim olduğumu bilmeyecek, değil mi?
es: —Espera. No se enterará de que he sido yo, ¿verdad?
vi_translation: "Wait, it won't find out about me, right?"
tr_translation: “Wait, they won't know it's me, right?”
es_translation: —Wait. They won't find out it was me, right?

en: “Nope. Why?”
vi: “Ừ, không đâu. Sao thế?”
tr: ‘Yo. Neden?
es: —No. ¿Por qué?
vi_translation: "Yes, not at all." "Why?"
tr_translation: 'Hey. Why?"
es_translation: —No. Why?

en: “I don’t want him to think I give enough of a shit about him to hurt him.” I put a hand down on the center console and Margo patted it. “Don’t worry,” she said. “He’ll never know what depilatated him.”
vi: “Tớ không muốn Chuck tưởng bở rằng tớ vẫn còn đủ bận tâm vì nó đến mức muốn trả miếng nó.” Một tay tôi đặt xuống bảng điều khiển xe và Margo vỗ nhẹ nhẹ lên đó. “Đừng lo,” cô ấy nói. “Chuck sẽ không bao giờ biết được ai đã ra tay triệt mao nó đâu.”
tr: “Onu incitecek kadar bile umursadığımı düşünmesini istemiyorum.” Bir elimi orta konsolun üzerine koydum ve Margo elime hafifçe vurdu. “Endişelenme,” dedi. “Kimin tüylerini söktürdüğünü asla bilmeyecek.
es: —No quiero que piense que me importa tanto como para hacerle una putada. Apoyé una mano en la guantera situada entre los asientos y Margo me dio unas palmaditas. —No te preocupes —me dijo—. Nunca sabrá qué lo ha depiladado.
vi_translation: “I don't want Chuck to get the wrong idea that I still care enough about him to want to get back at him.” I placed one hand on the car's dashboard and Margo gently patted it. “Don't worry,” she said. “Chuck will never know who shaved him bald.”
tr_translation: “I don't want him to think I care enough to hurt him.” I placed one hand on the center console and Margo lightly tapped it. “Don't worry,” she said. “He'll never know who plucked his feathers.”
es_translation: —I don't want him to think that I care enough to screw him over. I rested a hand on the glove compartment located between the seats, and Margo patted me. —Don't worry —he told me—. He will never know what shaved him.

en: “I think you just misused a word, but I don’t know what it means.”
vi: “Hình như cậu vừa dùng từ sai rồi, nhưng tớ không biết từ đấy nghĩa là gì.
tr: “Sanırım az önce bir tanımı yanlış kullandın ama ne anlama geldiğini de bilmiyorum.
es: —Creo que te has inventado una palabra, porque no sé lo que significa.
vi_translation: "It seems like you just used the wrong word, but I don't know what that word means."
tr_translation: "I think you just used a term incorrectly, but I don't know what it means either."
es_translation: —I think you made up a word, because I don't know what it means.

en: “I know a word you don’t know,” Margo chanted. “I’M THE NEW QUEEN OF VOCABULARY! I’VE USURPED YOU!”
vi: “Tớ biết một từ mà cậu không biết,” Margo reo lên. “TỚ LÀ NỮ HOÀNG TỪ VỰNG MỚI ĐĂNG QUANG! TỚ TIẾM NGÔI CỦA CẬU RỒI NHÉ!”
tr: “Senin bilmediğin bir sözcük biliyorum,” dedi Margo melodik bir sesle. “KELİME HÂZİNESİNİN YENİ KRALİÇESİYİM! SENİN YERİNİ GASBETTİM!
es: —Sé una palabra que tú no sabes —canturreó Margo—. ¡SOY LA NUEVA REINA DE LAS PALABRAS! ¡TE HE SUPLANTADO!
vi_translation: "I know a word that you don't know," Margo exclaimed. “I AM THE NEWLY CROWNED VOCABULARY QUEEN! I HAVE TAKEN YOUR THRONE!”
tr_translation: "I know a word you don't know," said Margo in a melodious voice. "I AM THE NEW QUEEN OF VOCABULARY! I HAVE USURPED YOUR PLACE!"
es_translation: —I know a word that you don't know —Margo sang—. I AM THE NEW QUEEN OF WORDS! I HAVE REPLACED YOU!

en: “Spell usurped,” I told her.
vi: “Có giỏi thì đánh vần từ tiếm ngôi đi,” tôi bảo Margo.
tr: “Gasbetmek kelimesini hecele,” dedim.
es: —Deletrea «Suplantado» —le dije.
vi_translation: “If you're so smart, spell the word 'usurpation',” I told Margo.
tr_translation: “Spell out the word 'gasbetmek',” I said.
es_translation: —Spell "Suplantado" —I said to him.

en: “No,” she answered, laughing. “I’m not giving up my crown over usurped. You’ll have to do better.”
vi: “Không đời nào,” cô ấy cười giòn tan. “Tớ sẽ không bị mất ngai vàng vì từ tiếm ngôi đâu. Cậu phải thể hiện được oách hơn.”
tr: “Hayır,” diye cevapladı gülerek. “Gasbetmek karşılığında tacımdan vazgeçmeyeceğim. Daha iyisini yapmalısın.
es: —No —me contestó riendo—. No voy a renunciar a mi corona por un «Suplantado». Tendrás que pensar en algo mejor.
vi_translation: "No way," she laughed heartily. "I won't lose my throne because of a usurper. You have to show off better."
tr_translation: “No,” she replied, laughing. “I will not give up my crown in exchange for being robbed. You must do better.”
es_translation: —No —he answered me, laughing—. I'm not going to give up my crown for an "Imposter." You'll have to come up with something better.

en: “Fine.” I smiled.
vi: “Được thôi,” tôi mỉm cười.
tr: “Peki.” Gülümsedim.
es: —Perfecto —le dije sonriendo.
vi_translation: “Alright,” I smiled.
tr_translation: “Okay.” I smiled.
es_translation: —Perfect —I said, smiling.

en: We drove through College Park, a neighborhood that passes for Orlando’s historic district on account of how the houses were mostly built thirty whole years ago. Margo couldn’t remember Chuck’s exact address, or what his house looked like, or even for sure what street it was on (“I’m almost like ninety-five percent positive it’s on Vassar.”). Finally, after the Chrysler had prowled three blocks of Vassar Street, Margo pointed to her left and said, “That one.”
vi: Chúng tôi lái xe vào College Park, một khu ghi dấu lịch sử của Orlando, xét ở góc độ phần lớn nhà ở đây được xây từ khoảng ba chục năm trước. Margo không nhớ chính xác địa chỉ nhà Chuck, cũng không nhớ căn nhà trông như thế nào, thậm chí còn không chắc nó ở phố nào. (“Tớ nghĩ chín mươi lăm phần trăm là nó ở Vassar.”). Cuối cùng, sau khi chiếc Chrysler rề rề lướt qua ba khối nhà trên Phố Vassar, Margo chỉ bên tay trái, nói, “Nhà kia.”
tr: Evlerin çoğu otuz yıl önce inşa edildiği için, Orlando’nun tarihî bölgesi olarak görülen semte, College Park’a doğru ilerledik. Margo, Chuckîn tam adresini ya da evinin nasıl göründüğünü ya da kesin olarak hangi sokakta yaşadığım bile hatırlayamadı (“Vassar’da olduğundan neredeyse yüzde doksan beş falan eminim.”) Nihayet Chrysler, Vassar Sokağı’nda üç blok dolaştıktan sonra, Margo sol tarafı işaret etti ve “Şuradaki,” dedi.
es: Atravesamos College Park, un barrio considerado del distrito histórico de Orlando porque la mayoría de las casas fueron construidas hace más de treinta años. Margo no recordaba la dirección exacta de Chuck, ni cómo era su casa, ni siquiera en qué calle estaba exactamente («Noventa y cinco por ciento de posibilidades de que esté en Vassar»). Al final, cuando el Chrysler había patrullado por tres manzanas de la calle Vassar, Margo señaló a la izquierda y dijo:
vi_translation: We drove into College Park, a historic district of Orlando, considering that most of the houses here were built about thirty years ago. Margo didn't remember Chuck's exact address, nor did she remember what the house looked like, and she wasn't even sure which street it was on. ("I think there's a ninety-five percent chance it's on Vassar."). Finally, after the Chrysler slowly glided past three blocks on Vassar Street, Margo pointed to the left and said, "That house."
tr_translation: Since most of the houses were built thirty years ago, we proceeded towards College Park, the neighborhood considered Orlando's historic district. Margo couldn't remember Chuck's exact address, what his house looked like, or even exactly which street he lived on ("I'm almost ninety-five percent sure it's on Vassar."). Finally, after the Chrysler circled three blocks on Vassar Street, Margo pointed to the left and said, "There it is."
es_translation: We passed through College Park, a neighborhood considered part of the historic district of Orlando because most of the houses were built more than thirty years ago. Margo didn't remember Chuck's exact address, nor what his house looked like, nor even exactly which street it was on ("Ninety-five percent chance it's on Vassar"). In the end, when the Chrysler had patrolled three blocks of Vassar Street, Margo pointed to the left and said:

en: “Are you sure?” I asked.
vi: “Cậu chắc không?” tôi hỏi.
tr: “Emin misin?” diye sordum.
es: —Aquella. —¿Estás segura? —le pregunté.
vi_translation: “Are you sure?” I asked.
tr_translation: "Are you sure?" I asked.
es_translation: —That one. —Are you sure? —I asked her.

en: “I’m like ninety-seven-point-two percent sure. I mean, I’m pretty sure his bedroom is right there,” she said, pointing. “One time he had a party, and when the cops came I shimmied out his window. I’m pretty sure it’s the same window.”
vi: “Tớ chắc khoảng chín-mươi-bảy-phảy-hai phần trăm. Ý là tớ khá chắc phòng ngủ của Chuck ở ngay kia,” cô ấy chỉ. “Một lần nó mở tiệc, và khi cảnh sát đến tớ đã vọt qua cửa sổ phòng nó. Tớ khá chắc chính là cửa sổ kia.”
tr: ‘Yüzde doksan yedi nokta iki falan eminim. Yani yatak odasının tam şurada olduğundan oldukça eminim,” dedi eliyle işaret ederek. “Bir keresinde bir parti vermişti ve polisler geldiğinde penceresinden kaçmıştım.
es: —Noventa y siete coma dos por ciento de posibilidades. Vaya, estoy casi segura de que su habitación es aquella —me dijo señalando—. Una vez hizo una fiesta, y cuando vino la poli, me escabullí por aquella ventana. Estoy casi segura de que es la misma.
vi_translation: “I'm about ninety-seven-point-two percent sure. Meaning, I'm quite sure Chuck's bedroom is right there,” she pointed. “Once he had a party, and when the police came, I jumped out of his bedroom window. I'm pretty sure it's that window.”
tr_translation: “I am like ninety-seven point two percent sure. I mean, I am quite sure that the bedroom is right here,” he said, gesturing with his hand. “Once, he threw a party and when the police came, I escaped through his window. I am quite sure this is the same window.”
es_translation: —Ninety-seven point two percent chance. Wow, I'm almost sure that his room is that one —she told me, pointing—. Once he had a party, and when the cops came, I slipped out through that window. I'm almost sure it's the same one.

en: “This seems like we could get in trouble.”
vi: “Dự là sẽ dính rắc rối đây.”
tr: Bunun aynı pencere olduğundan oldukça eminim.” “Başımız belaya girebilirmiş gibi görünüyor.
es: —Podemos meternos en problemas.
vi_translation: "It looks like there will be trouble."
tr_translation: “It looks like we might be getting into trouble.”
es_translation: —We could get into trouble.

en: “But if the window is open, there’s no breaking involved. Only entering. And we just did entering at the SunTrust, and it wasn’t that big of a deal, right?”
vi: “Nhưng nếu cửa sổ để mở thì có phải là lén lút đột nhập đâu. Chỉ là đi vào nhà người ta thôi mà. Chúng ta vừa đi vào SunTrust đấy thôi, mà cũng có gì to tát ghê gớm đâu, đúng chứ?”
tr: “Ama pencere açıksa işin içinde haneye tecavüz olmayacak. Sadece eve gireceğiz. Ve az önce SunTrust’ta içeri girme eylemi gerçekleştirdik ve çok büyük bir mesele yoktu ortada, değil mi?” Güldüm.
es: —Si la ventana está abierta, no haremos destrozos. Solo entraremos. Ya hemos entrado en el SunTrust y no ha sido para tanto, ¿verdad?
vi_translation: “But if the window is left open, then it's not really sneaking in. It's just entering someone's house. We just entered SunTrust, and it wasn't that big of a deal, right?”
tr_translation: “But if the window is open, there won't be any trespassing involved. We'll just enter the house. And we just performed an entry action at SunTrust a moment ago, and it wasn't a big deal, right?” I laughed.
es_translation: —If the window is open, we won't cause any damage. We'll just go in. We've already gotten into the SunTrust and it wasn't that bad, right?

en: I laughed. “It’s like you’re turning me into a badass.”
vi: Tôi bật cười. “Cậu sắp cảm hóa tớ thành một gã bất kham rồi đấy.”
tr: Güldüm. “Beni sert bir çocuğa dönüştürüyorsun sanırım.
es: Me reí. —Estás convirtiéndome en un cabrón.
vi_translation: I burst out laughing. "You're about to turn me into a reckless guy."
tr_translation: And we just performed an entry action at SunTrust a moment ago, and it wasn't a big deal, right?” I laughed. “I think you're turning me into a tough kid.”
es_translation: I laughed. —You are turning me into an asshole.

en: “That’s the idea. Okay, supplies: get the Veet, the spray paint, and the Vaseline.”
vi: “Tham vọng lớn của tớ đấy. Được rồi, tác chiến cần có: Veet, bình sơn và Vaseline.”
tr: “Maksat bu. Tamam, malzemeler: Veet’i, sprey boyayı ve vazelini al.
es: —De eso se trata. Venga, las herramientas. Coge la Veet, el espray de pintura y la vaselina.
vi_translation: “That's my big ambition.” “Alright, for the mission we need: Veet, a spray can, and Vaseline.”
tr_translation: “That's the goal. Alright, the materials: Get the Veet, spray paint, and Vaseline.”
es_translation: —That's what it's about. Come on, the tools. Grab the Veet, the spray paint, and the Vaseline.

en: “Okay.” I grabbed them.
vi: “Xong,” tôi vớ mấy món đó.
tr: “Tamam.” Dediklerini aldım.
es: —De acuerdo. Los cogí.
vi_translation: "Done," I grabbed those items.
tr_translation: "Okay." I got what they said.
es_translation: —Agreed. I caught them.

en: “Now don’t freak out on me, Q. The good news is that Chuck sleeps like a hibernating bear—I know because I had English with him last year and he wouldn’t wake up even when Ms. Johnston swatted him with Jane Eyre. So we’re going to go up to his bedroom window, we’re gonna open it, we’re gonna take off our shoes, and then very quietly go inside, and I’m going to screw with Chuck. Then you and I are going to fan out to opposite sides of the house, and we’re going to cover every door handle in Vaseline, so even if someone wakes up, they’ll have a hella hard time getting out of the house in time to catch us. Then we’ll screw with Chuck some more, paint his house a little, and we’re out of there. And no talking.”
vi: “Đừng làm tớ choáng thế chứ Q. Tin tốt là Chuck ngủ như một con gấu ú ngủ đông–tớ biết vì năm ngoái tớ học Quốc ngữ với nó và nó vẫn say giấc điệp kể cả khi cô Johnston tẩn nó bằng cuốn Jane Eyre. Thế nên chúng ta sẽ trèo lên cửa sổ phòng nó, mở cửa, tháo giày, khe khẽ vào trong, tớ sẽ xử Chuck. Rồi cậu và tớ sẽ tỏa đi hai hướng ngược nhau trong nhà, chúng ta sẽ bôi Vaseline lên từng tay nắm cửa, phòng trường hợp có ai thức giấc thì cũng phải mất chán vạn thời gian mới ra được khỏi nhà và đuổi theo mình. Tụi mình sẽ xử nốt đoạn cuối với Chuck, sơn vẽ nhà nó tí chơi, rồi biến. Mà không nói gì trong khi hành động nhé.”
tr: “Şimdi kendini kaybetme, Q. iyi haber şu ki, Chuck kış uykusuna yatan bir ayı gibi uyuyor... Biliyorum çünkü geçen sene onunla edebiyat dersi aldım ve Bayan Johnston ona Jane Eyre’le vurduğunda bile uyanmadı. Bu yüzden yatak odasının penceresine çıkacağız, pencereyi açacağız, ayakkabılarımızı çıkaracağız, sonra çok sessiz bir şekilde içeri gireceğiz ve ben Chuck’la eğleneceğim. Sonra seninle evin farklı taraflarına gideceğiz ve tüm kapı kollarını vazelinle kaplayacağız, böylece birileri uyansa bile bizi yakalamak için evden çıkarken felaket zor anlar yaşayacaklar. Sonra Chuck’la biraz daha eğlenip evini biraz boyayacağız ve oradan çıkacağız. Ve konuşmak yok.
es: —Ahora no te me pongas histérico, Q. La buena noticia es que Chuck duerme como un oso hibernando… Lo sé porque el año pasado fui a clase de literatura con él y ni siquiera se despertaba cuando la señorita Johnston le daba un golpe con Jane Eyre. Así que subiremos hasta la ventana de su habitación, la abriremos, nos quitaremos los zapatos, entraremos sin hacer ruido y yo me encargaré de joder a Chuck. Luego los dos nos dispersaremos por la casa y cubriremos todos los pomos de las puertas con vaselina para que si alguien se levanta, le cueste un huevo salir de la casa a tiempo para pillarnos. Luego joderemos un poco más a Chuck, pintaremos un poco la casa y saldremos. Y ni una palabra.
vi_translation: “Don't overwhelm me like that, Q. The good news is that Chuck sleeps like a hibernating bear—I know because last year I took National Language with him and he was still sound asleep even when Ms. Johnston whacked him with a copy of Jane Eyre. So we will climb through his window, open the door, take off our shoes, quietly go inside, and I'll handle Chuck. Then you and I will go in opposite directions in the house, we'll smear Vaseline on every doorknob, in case anyone wakes up, it will take them forever to get out of the house and chase us. We'll finish up with Chuck, do some painting on his house for fun, and then get out of there. And no talking while we're at it.”
tr_translation: “Now don't lose yourself, Q. The good news is that Chuck is sleeping like a bear in hibernation... I know because I took a literature class with him last year and even when Ms. Johnston hit him with Jane Eyre, he didn't wake up. So we’re going to climb up to his bedroom window, open the window, take off our shoes, then very quietly go inside and I’m going to have some fun with Chuck. Then we’ll go to different parts of the house and cover all the doorknobs with Vaseline, so even if someone wakes up, they’ll have a terribly hard time catching us while trying to get out of the house. Then we’ll have some more fun with Chuck, paint his house a bit, and get out of there. And no talking.”
es_translation: —Now don’t get hysterical on me, Q. The good news is that Chuck sleeps like a hibernating bear… I know because last year I had literature class with him and he didn’t even wake up when Miss Johnston hit him with Jane Eyre. So we’ll climb up to his room’s window, open it, take off our shoes, enter quietly, and I’ll take care of messing with Chuck. Then the two of us will spread out through the house and cover all the doorknobs with Vaseline so that if someone gets up, it’ll be really hard for them to get out of the house in time to catch us. Then we’ll mess with Chuck a bit more, paint the house a little, and leave. And not a word.

en: I put my hand to my jugular, but I was smiling.
vi: Tôi đặt tay mình lên tĩnh mạch cổ, nhưng tôi mỉm cười.
tr: Elimi şah damarıma koydum ama gülümsüyordum.
es: Me llevé la mano a la yugular, pero sonreí.
vi_translation: I placed my hand on my neck vein, but I smiled.
tr_translation: I placed my hand on my jugular vein, but I was smiling.
es_translation: I put my hand to my jugular, but I smiled.

en: We were walking away from the car together when Margo reached down for my hand, laced her fingers in mine, and squeezed. I squeezed back and then glanced at her. She nodded her head solemnly, and I nodded back, and then she let go of my hand. We scampered up to the window. I gently pushed the wooden casing up. It squeaked ever so quietly but opened in one motion. I looked in. It was dark, but I could see a body in a bed.
vi: Chúng tôi ra khỏi xe và đi bộ cạnh nhau, Margo đưa tay ra nắm tay tôi, đan những ngón tay cô ấy vào các ngón tay tôi, và siết chặt. Tôi cũng siết tay mình và liếc nhìn cô ấy. Margo lặng lẽ gật đầu, tôi gật đầu đáp lại, và cô ấy thả tay tôi ra. Chúng tôi lẹ làng đến trước cửa sổ. Tôi khẽ đẩy khung gỗ lên. Hơi khẽ phát ra tiếng động, nhưng mở được ngay. Tôi nhìn vào trong. Tối quá, nhưng tôi thấy một người nằm trên giường.
tr: Margo elime uzanıp parmaklarım benimkilere geçirerek sıktığında, birlikte arabadan uzaklaşıyorduk. Ben de onunkileri sıkıp ona baktım. Ciddiyetle başını salladı, ben de ona salladım ve sonra elimi bıraktı. Çabucak pencereye çıktık. Tahta çerçeveyi usulca yukarı ittim. Çok az gıcırdadı ama tek bir hareketle açıldı. İçeri baktım. Karanlıktı fakat yatakta birinin olduğunu görebiliyordum.
es: Nos alejábamos del coche cuando Margo me cogió de la mano, entrelazó sus dedos con los míos y los apretó. Le devolví el apretón y la miré. Movió la cabeza solemnemente, volví a apretar y me soltó la mano. Corrimos hasta la ventana. Empujé hacia arriba despacio el marco de madera. Chirrió un poco, pero se abrió a la primera. Eché un vistazo. Aunque estaba oscuro, vi a alguien en una cama.
vi_translation: We got out of the car and walked side by side, Margo reached out and held my hand, intertwining her fingers with mine, and squeezed tightly. I also squeezed my hand and glanced at her. Margo quietly nodded, I nodded back, and she released my hand. We quickly approached the window. I gently pushed the wooden frame up. It made a slight noise, but it opened right away. I looked inside. It was too dark, but I saw someone lying on the bed.
tr_translation: When Margo reached out and intertwined her fingers with mine, we were walking away from the car together. I squeezed hers and looked at her. She nodded seriously, I nodded back, and then she let go of my hand. We quickly climbed out the window. I gently pushed the wooden frame up. It creaked very little but opened in one motion. I looked inside. It was dark, but I could see someone in the bed.
es_translation: We were walking away from the car when Margo took my hand, intertwined her fingers with mine, and squeezed. I squeezed back and looked at her. She nodded solemnly, I squeezed again, and she let go of my hand. We ran to the window. I slowly pushed the wooden frame up. It creaked a little, but it opened on the first try. I took a look inside. Although it was dark, I saw someone on a bed.

en: The window was a little high for Margo, so I put my hands together and she stepped a socked foot onto my hand and I boosted her up. Her silent entrance into the house would have made a ninja jealous. I proceeded to jump up, get my head and shoulders into the window, and then attempt, via a complicated torso undulation, to dance the caterpillar into the house. That might have worked fine except I racked my balls against the windowsill, which hurt so bad that I groaned, which was a pretty sizable mistake.
vi: Cửa sổ hơi cao so với Margo, nên tôi chắp tay để cô ấy dận một chân đi bít tất lên, và tôi đẩy Margo lên. Cô ấy vào trong êm ái đến mức ninja thứ thiệt chắc cũng phải ghen tị. Tôi nhảy lên, chui được đầu và vai qua cửa sổ, rồi với nỗ lực xoắn vặn cơ thể, tôi uốn éo như sâu lùn chùn bò vào trong. Sự thể lẽ ra đã suôn sẻ, nếu tôi không lỡ cọ hai quả trứng cò vào bậu cửa sổ, đau tê tái đến mức tôi không nén nổi rên rẩm, gây ra một sai lầm vô cùng tệ hại.
tr: Pencere Margo için biraz yüksekti, bu yüzden ellerimi birleştirdim, Margo çoraplı ayağıyla elimin üstüne bastı ve onu yukarı doğru ittim. Sessizce eve girişi bir ninjayı kıskandınrdı. Bense yukan zıplayıp başımı ve omuzlarımı pencereye ulaştırmaya, karmaşık bir vücut dalgalanması yoluyla, tırtıl gibi dans ederek evin içine girmeye çalıştım. Her şey iyi gitmiş olabilirdi, yalnız hayalarım pencere eşiğine takıldı ve acıdan inledim ki bu oldukça büyük bir hataydı.
es: Como la ventana estaba un poco alta para Margo, junté las manos, puso un pie encima y la impulsé. Su silenciosa entrada en la casa habría sido la envidia de un ninja. Me dispuse a subir, metí la cabeza y los hombros por la ventana, y pretendía, mediante una complicada contorsión, entrar en la casa en plan oruga. Podría haber funcionado perfectamente de no haberme aplastado los huevos contra la repisa, y me dolió tanto que solté un quejido, lo cual suponía un error nada desdeñable.
vi_translation: The window was a bit high for Margo, so I clasped my hands for her to step on with one socked foot, and I pushed Margo up. She got in so smoothly that even a real ninja would be envious. I jumped up, got my head and shoulders through the window, and with a twisting effort, I wriggled like a worm to get inside. Things would have gone smoothly if I hadn't accidentally brushed my two eggs against the window sill, causing such excruciating pain that I couldn't help but groan, leading to a terribly bad mistake.
tr_translation: The window was a bit high for Margo, so I clasped my hands together, Margo stepped on my hand with her socked foot, and I pushed her up. Her silent entry into the house would make a ninja envious. As for me, I tried to jump up and get my head and shoulders to the window, attempting to enter the house by performing a complex body undulation, dancing like a caterpillar. Everything might have gone well, except my groin got caught on the window sill and I groaned in pain, which was quite a big mistake.
es_translation: Since the window was a bit high for Margo, I cupped my hands, she put a foot on them, and I boosted her up. Her silent entry into the house would have been the envy of a ninja. I prepared to climb up, stuck my head and shoulders through the window, and intended, through a complicated contortion, to enter the house caterpillar-style. It could have worked perfectly if I hadn't crushed my balls against the ledge, and it hurt so much that I let out a groan, which was no small mistake.

en: A bedside light came on. And there, lying in bed, was some old guy—decidedly not Chuck Parson. His eyes were wide with terror; he didn’t say a thing.
vi: Đèn ở đầu giường bật sáng. Người nằm trên giường là một bác trai có tuổi–rõ ràng không phải Chuck Parson. Bác ta tròn mắt kinh hãi và không nói nổi lời nào.
tr: Bir başucu lambası yandı. Ve orada, yatakta yatan, yaşlı bir adamdı... açık bir şekilde Chuck Parson değildi. Gözleri dehşetle açılmıştı; hiçbir şey söylemedi.
es: Se encendió la luz de la mesita. Y resultó que el que estaba en la cama era un viejo, sin duda no era Chuck Parson. Abrió los ojos como platos, aterrorizado. No dijo una palabra.
vi_translation: The bedside lamp turned on. The person lying on the bed was an elderly man—clearly not Chuck Parson. He widened his eyes in horror and couldn't utter a word.
tr_translation: A bedside lamp turned on. And there, lying in bed, was an old man... it was clearly not Chuck Parson. His eyes were wide with terror; he said nothing.
es_translation: The light on the bedside table turned on. And it turned out that the one in the bed was an old man, certainly not Chuck Parson. He opened his eyes wide, terrified. He didn't say a word.

en: “Um,” said Margo. I thought about shoving off and running back to the car, but for Margo’s sake I stayed there, the top half of me in the house, parallel to the floor. “Um, I think we have the wrong house.” She turned around then and looked at me urgently, and only then did I realize I was blocking Margo’s exit. So I pushed myself back out the window, grabbed my shoes, and took off.
vi: “Ơ,” Margo lên tiếng. Tôi toan té và phóng thẳng ra xe, nhưng vì Margo mà tôi nán lại, nửa thân trên ở trong nhà theo phương song song với sàn. “Dạ, chắc tụi cháu đi lộn nhà rồi bác.” Cô ấy quay lại và nhìn tôi đầy khẩn thiết. Lúc ấy tôi mới nhận ra rằng mình đang chặn đường thoát của cô ấy. Thế là tôi lẳng người khỏi cửa sổ, vớ vội đôi giày và chạy thẳng.
tr: “Hımm,” dedi Margo. Kaçıp gitmeyi ve arabaya koşmayı düşündüm ama Margo’nun hatırına orada kaldım, gövdemin üst kısmı evin içinde yere paralel bir halde. “Hımm, sanırım yanlış evdeyiz.” Geri döndü ve ısrarcı bir şekilde bana baktı, ancak o zaman Margo’nun çıkışını engellediğimi fark ettim. Bu nedenle kendimi pencerenin dışına ittim, ayakkabılarımı kaptım ve tabanları yağladım.
es: —Hum —murmuró Margo. Pensé en largarme corriendo al coche, pero me quedé por Margo, con la mitad del cuerpo dentro de la casa, paralelo al suelo. —Hum, creo que nos hemos equivocado de casa —dijo Margo. Se giró, me miró con insistencia y solo entonces me di cuenta de que estaba bloqueándole la salida. Así que salté de la ventana, cogí mis zapatos y eché a correr.
vi_translation: “Oh,” Margo spoke up. I was about to fall and dash straight to the car, but because of Margo, I stayed back, with my upper body inside the house parallel to the floor. “Sorry, we must have come to the wrong house,” she turned back and looked at me urgently. It was then that I realized I was blocking her escape route. So I slipped out of the window, grabbed my shoes, and ran straight away.
tr_translation: “Hmm,” said Margo. I thought about running away and dashing to the car, but I stayed there for Margo's sake, with the upper part of my body parallel to the ground inside the house. “Hmm, I think we’re in the wrong house.” She turned back and looked at me insistently, and only then did I realize I was blocking Margo's exit. So I pushed myself out of the window, grabbed my shoes, and made a run for it.
es_translation: —Hmm —murmured Margo. I thought about running to the car, but I stayed for Margo, with half of my body inside the house, parallel to the ground. —Hmm, I think we've come to the wrong house —said Margo. He turned, looked at me insistently, and only then did I realize that I was blocking his way out. So I jumped out of the window, grabbed my shoes, and started running.

en: We drove to the other side of College Park to regroup.
vi: Chúng tôi lái xe đến đầu kia của College Park để hoàn hồn trở lại.
tr: Her şeyi yeniden planlamak için arabayla College Park’m diğer tarafına gittik.
es: Nos dirigimos al otro extremo de College Park para reorganizarnos.
vi_translation: We drove to the other end of College Park to recover our composure.
tr_translation: We drove to the other side of College Park to plan everything again.
es_translation: We headed to the other end of College Park to regroup.

en: “I think we share the blame on that one,” Margo said.
vi: “Vụ vừa rồi cả hai đứa mình đều ấm ớ,” Margo nói.
tr: “Bence bu seferki suçu paylaşıyoruz,” dedi Margo.
es: —Creo que esta vez la culpa es de los dos —dijo Margo.
vi_translation: "We both messed up last time," Margo said.
tr_translation: "I think we're sharing the blame this time," said Margo.
es_translation: —I think this time it's both of our faults —said Margo.

en: “Um, you picked the wrong house,” I said.
vi: “Ờ, là cậu chỉ nhầm nhà đấy nhá,” tôi nói.
tr: “Hımm, yanlış evi sen seçtin,” dedim.
es: —Vaya, la que se ha equivocado de casa has sido tú —le contesté.
vi_translation: “Uh, you just got the wrong house,” I said.
tr_translation: “Hmm, you chose the wrong house,” I said.
es_translation: —Well, the one who got the wrong house is you —I replied.

en: “Right, but you were the one who made noise.” It was quiet for a minute, and we were just driving in circles, and then finally I said, “We could probably get his address off the Internet. Radar has a log-in to the school directory.”
vi: “Đúng, nhưng cậu là đứa manh động đấy nhá.” Yên lặng một phút, rồi bọn tôi chỉ biết lái xe vòng vòng. Cuối cùng tôi nói, “Mình có thể mò được địa chỉ nhà Chuck trên Internet. Radar đăng nhập được vào danh bạ của trường.”
tr: ‘T)oğru ama ses çıkaran şendin.” Bir dakikalığına sessiz kaldık, arabayla daireler çiziyorduk, sonra nihayet konuştum: ‘Muhtemelen Chuckin adresini internetten bulabiliriz. Radar okulun sistemine bağlanabiliyor.
es: —Sí, pero el que ha hecho ruido has sido tú. Nos quedamos callados un minuto. Yo conducía haciendo círculos. —Seguramente podemos conseguir su dirección en internet —dije por fin—. Radar está registrado en la página del instituto.
vi_translation: “Right, but you're quite impulsive.” A minute of silence, then we just drove around. Finally, I said, “We can find Chuck's home address on the Internet. Radar can log into the school's directory.”
tr_translation: ‘True, but you are the one making noise.” We stayed silent for a minute, driving in circles, then I finally spoke: ‘We can probably find Chuck's address on the internet. Radar can connect to the school's system.”
es_translation: —Yes, but the one who made noise was you. We stayed silent for a minute. I was driving in circles. —Surely we can get his address on the internet —I said finally—. Radar is registered on the school's website.

en: “Brilliant,” Margo said.
vi: “Giải pháp xuất sắc,” Margo nói.
tr: “Harika,” dedi Margo.
es: —Genial —añadió Margo.
vi_translation: “Excellent solution,” Margo said.
tr_translation: “Great,” said Margo.
es_translation: —Great —added Margo.

en: So I called Radar, but his phone went straight to voice mail. I contemplated calling his house, but his parents were friends with my parents, so that wouldn’t work. Finally, it occurred to me to call Ben. He wasn’t Radar, but he did know all of Radar’s passwords. I called. It went to voice mail, but only after ringing. So I called again. Voice mail. I called again. Voice mail. Margo said, “He’s obviously not answering,” and as I dialed again, I said, “Oh, he’ll answer.” And after just four more calls, he did.
vi: Thế là tôi gọi cho Radar, nhưng điện thoại của nó nhảy ngay sang hộp thư thoại. Tôi tính gọi vào điện thoại cố định nhà nó, nhưng bố mẹ nó cũng biết bố mẹ tôi, thế thì hỏng việc mất. Rút cục, tôi thình lình nảy ra ý gọi cho Ben. Ben không phải là Radar, nhưng nó biết hết tất cả các mật khẩu của Radar. Tôi gọi. Điện thoại nhảy sang hộp thư thoại sau vài hồi chuông. Thế là tôi gọi lại. Thư thoại. Gọi lại. Thư thoại. Margo nói, “Chắc cậu ấy không nhấc máy đâu,” tôi vừa gọi lại vừa nói, “Ồ, cậu ta sẽ trả lời cho coi.” Gọi thêm bốn cuộc nữa thì Ben nhấc máy thật.
tr: Bunun üstüne Radar’ı aradım ama telefon beni sesli mesaja yönlendirdi. Evini aramaya niyetlendim ama ebeveynleri benimkilerle arkadaştı, yani bu işe yaramazdı. Sonunda Ben’i aramak aklıma geldi. Radar değildi ama Radar’m bütün şifrelerini biliyordu. Aradım. Sesli mesaja yönlendirildim ama telefon çaldıktan sonra. Bu yüzden tekrar aradım. Sesli mesaj. Tekrar aradım. Sesli mesaj. Margo, “Belli ki açmayacak,” dedi, ben numarayı tekrar girerken. “Ah, açacak,” dedim. Ve sadece dört defa daha aradıktan sonra açtı.
es: Así que llamé a Radar, pero saltó directamente el buzón de voz. Me planteé llamar a su casa, pero sus padres eran amigos de los míos, de modo que no funcionaría. Al final se me ocurrió llamar a Ben. No era Radar, pero se sabía todas sus contraseñas. Lo llamé. Saltó el buzón de voz después de haber sonado varias veces. Volví a llamar. Buzón de voz. Llamé otra vez. Buzón de voz. —Está claro que no contesta —observó Margo. —Bueno, contestará —le dije volviendo a marcar. Y después de un par de llamadas más, contestó.
vi_translation: So I called Radar, but his phone went straight to voicemail. I thought about calling his home phone, but his parents knew my parents, which would ruin everything. In the end, I suddenly had the idea to call Ben. Ben wasn't Radar, but he knew all of Radar's passwords. I called. The phone went to voicemail after a few rings. So I called again. Voicemail. Called again. Voicemail. Margo said, "He probably won't pick up," and as I called again, I said, "Oh, he'll answer." After four more calls, Ben finally picked up.
tr_translation: Then I called Radar, but the phone directed me to voicemail. I intended to call his house, but his parents were friends with mine, so that wouldn’t work. Finally, I thought of calling Ben. He wasn’t Radar, but he knew all of Radar’s passwords. I called. I was directed to voicemail, but only after the phone rang. So I called again. Voicemail. I called again. Voicemail. Margo said, “Clearly, he’s not going to answer,” as I dialed the number again. “Oh, he will,” I said. And he answered after just four more calls.
es_translation: So I called Radar, but it went straight to voicemail. I considered calling his house, but his parents were friends with mine, so that wouldn't work.
