en: The detective looked up from his notebook. “We’ll get the word out, of course, but she can’t be compelled to come home; you shouldn’t necessarily expect her back under your roof in the near future.”
vi: Thám tử ngước khỏi trang sổ tay, nhìn lên nói. “Tất nhiên chúng tôi sẽ tìm cho ra đầu ra cuối, nhưng không thể bắt ép Margo về ngay được. Trước mắt anh chị không nhất thiết phải trông đợi con bé về nhà.
tr: Dedektif başmı defterinden kaldırdı. “Haberi yayacağız elbette ama eve gelmeye zorlanamaz, yakın gelecekte onun tekrar çatınızın altında olmasını beklememelisiniz.
es: El detective levantó los ojos de la carpeta. —Haremos correr la voz, por supuesto, pero de ningún modo podemos obligarla a volver a casa. No deben contar necesariamente con que regresará bajo su techo en un futuro inmediato.
vi_translation: The detective looked up from his notebook and spoke. “Of course, we will get to the bottom of this, but we can't force Margo to come back right away. For now, you shouldn't expect her to return home.”
tr_translation: The detective lifted his head from his notebook. "We will spread the news, of course, but he cannot be forced to come home; you should not expect him to be under your roof again in the near future."
es_translation: The detective lifted his eyes from the folder. —We will spread the word, of course, but we cannot force her to return home in any way. You should not necessarily count on her coming back under your roof in the immediate future.

en: “I don’t want her under our roof.” Mrs. Spiegelman raised a tissue to her eyes, although I heard no crying in her voice. “I know that’s terrible, but it’s true.”
vi: “Tôi không muốn thấy mặt nó ở nhà nữa.” Cô Spiegelman nâng khăn giấy lên chấm chấm mắt, nhưng tôi không nghe thấy chút thổn thức nào trong giọng nói của cô ấy. “Tôi biết như vậy thực khủng khiếp, nhưng đúng thế đấy.”
tr: “Onu çatımızın altında istemiyorum.” Bayan Spiegelman gözüne bir mendil götürdü, buna rağmen sesi hiç de ağlıyormuş gibi gelmiyordu. “Korkunç olduğunu biliyorum ama gerçek bu.
es: —No la quiero bajo nuestro techo. —La señora Spiegelman se llevó un pañuelo a los ojos, aunque no parecía estar llorando—. Sé que es terrible, pero es la verdad.
vi_translation: “I don't want to see her face at home anymore.” Ms. Spiegelman lifted a tissue to dab at her eyes, but I didn't hear any sobbing in her voice. “I know it's terrible, but it's true.”
tr_translation: “I don't want him under our roof.” Mrs. Spiegelman brought a handkerchief to her eye, yet her voice didn't sound like she was crying at all. “I know it's terrible, but it's the truth.”
es_translation: —I don't want her under our roof. —Mrs. Spiegelman brought a handkerchief to her eyes, although she didn't seem to be crying—. I know it's terrible, but it's the truth.

en: “Deb,” my mom said in her therapist voice.
vi: “Chị Deb,” mẹ tôi nói bằng giọng chuyên gia trị liệu.
tr: “Deb,” dedi annem terapist sesiyle.
es: —Deb —dijo mi madre con su tono de psicóloga.
vi_translation: "Sister Deb," my mother said in a therapist's voice.
tr_translation: “Deb,” said my mom in a therapist's voice.
es_translation: —Deb —said my mother in her psychologist tone.

en: Mrs. Spiegelman just shook her head—the smallest shake. “What can we do? We told the detective. We filed a report. She’s an adult, Connie.”
vi: Cô Spiegelman chỉ lắc đầu–cái lắc đầu khẽ nhất. “Vợ chồng tôi biết làm gì được chứ? Chúng tôi đã báo thám tử. Chúng tôi đã làm tường trình. Nó lớn rồi, Connie ạ.
tr: Bayan Spiegelman sadece başını salladı... Çok küçük bir sallama. “Ne yapabiliriz? Dedektife anlattık. Kayıp bildiriminde bulunduk. O bir yetişkin, Connie.
es: La señora Spiegelman se limitó a mover ligeramente la cabeza. —¿Qué podemos hacer? Se lo hemos dicho al detective. Hemos presentado una denuncia. Es una adulta, Connie.
vi_translation: Ms. Spiegelman just shook her head—the slightest shake. "What could my husband and I do? We reported it to the detective. We made a report. She's grown up now, Connie."
tr_translation: Bayan Spiegelman just nodded... A very small nod. “What can we do? We told the detective. We filed a missing person report. She's an adult, Connie.”
es_translation: Mrs. Spiegelman merely nodded slightly. —What can we do? We have told the detective. We have filed a report. She is an adult, Connie.

en: “She’s your adult,” my mom said, still calm.
vi: “Nó là đứa con lớn của chị,” mẹ tôi nói, vẫn giữ giọng bình tĩnh.
tr: “O sizin yetişkininiz,” dedi annem, hâlâ sakin bir şekilde.
es: —Es tu hija adulta —dijo mi madre, todavía calmada.
vi_translation: “It is your eldest child,” my mother said, still keeping a calm voice.
tr_translation: "He is your grown-up," said my mother, still calmly.
es_translation: —She is your adult daughter —said my mother, still calm.

en: “Oh, come on, Connie. Look, is it sick that it’s a blessing to have her out of the house? Of course it’s sick. But she was a sickness in this family! How do you look for someone who announces she won’t be found, who always leaves clues that lead nowhere, who runs away constantly? You can’t!”
vi: “Ôi, thôi nào Connie. Cô xem, nếu coi chuyện Margo đi khỏi nhà là một cái phước, như vậy có tệ không? Tất nhiên là tệ. Nhưng Margo là một chứng bệnh trong nhà tôi! Sao có thể tìm được một đứa tuyên bố rằng sẽ không có ai tìm ra mình, một đứa luôn để lại những manh mối chẳng dẫn đến đâu, một đứa cứ động một tí là bỏ nhà đi? Không tìm được đâu!”
tr: “Ah, yapma, Connie. Onu evin dışmda bırakmanın bir lütuf olması hastalıkb mı? Elbette, hastalıklı. Ama o bu ailedeki bir hastalık! Bulunmayacağım ilan eden, daima hiçbir yere varmayan ipuçları bırakan, sürekli evden kaçan birini nasıl ararsın? Arayamazsın!”
es: —Vamos, Connie. ¿Acaso no es de locos que estemos encantados de que se haya ido de casa? Pues claro que es de locos. Pero estaba volviendo loca a toda la familia. ¿Cómo buscar a una persona que asegura que no van a encontrarla, que siempre deja pistas que no llevan a ninguna parte, que se escapa cada dos por tres? ¡Es imposible!
vi_translation: “Oh, come on Connie. You see, if we consider Margo leaving home a blessing, is that so bad? Of course, it's bad. But Margo is a disease in my house! How can you find someone who declares that no one will find them, someone who always leaves clues that lead nowhere, someone who runs away from home at the slightest provocation? You can't find that!”
tr_translation: “Oh, don't do it, Connie. Is it a disease to consider leaving him outside the house a favor? Of course, it's diseased. But he is a disease in this family! How do you search for someone who declares they won't be found, always leaves clues that lead nowhere, and constantly runs away from home? You can't search!”
es_translation: —Let's go, Connie. Isn't it crazy that we're delighted she left home? Of course it's crazy. But she was driving the whole family crazy. How do you look for someone who insists they won't be found, who always leaves clues that lead nowhere, who escapes every now and then? It's impossible!

en: My mom and dad shared a glance, and then the detective spoke to me. “Son, I’m wondering if we can chat privately?” I nodded. We ended up in my parents’ bedroom, he in an easy chair and me sitting on the corner of their bed.
vi: Bố mẹ tôi cùng liếc nhau, rồi viên thám tử nói với tôi. “Con trai, chúng ta nói chuyện riêng với nhau chút được không?” Tôi gật đầu. Tôi và bác ấy vào phòng bố mẹ tôi, bác ấy ngồi trên ghế gấp còn tôi ngồi ở mép giường.
tr: Annemle babam bakıştılar, sonra dedektif bana doğru konuştu. “Evlat, acaba özel olarak konuşabilir miyiz?” Başımla onayladım. Kendimizi annemle babamın odasında bulduk, o rahat bir koltuğa yerleşti, ben yatağın köşesine oturdum.
es: Mi madre y mi padre se miraron, y luego el detective se dirigió a mí. —Hijo, me pregunto si podríamos charlar en privado. Asentí. Nos metimos en la habitación de mis padres. Él se sentó en un sillón y yo, en el borde de la cama.
vi_translation: My parents glanced at each other, then the detective spoke to me. “Son, can we talk privately for a bit?” I nodded. The detective and I went into my parents' room, he sat on a folding chair while I sat on the edge of the bed.
tr_translation: My mom and dad exchanged glances, then the detective spoke to me. "Kid, can we talk in private?" I nodded in agreement. We found ourselves in my parents' room, he settled into a comfortable chair, and I sat on the edge of the bed.
es_translation: My mother and my father looked at each other, and then the detective turned to me. —Son, I wonder if we could talk in private. I nodded. We went into my parents' room. He sat in an armchair and I sat on the edge of the bed.

en: “Kid,” he said once he’d settled into the chair, “let me give you some advice: never work for the government. Because when you work for the government, you work for the people. And when you work for the people, you have to interact with the people, even the Spiegelmans.” I laughed a little.
vi: “Con ạ,” bác ấy nói khi đã ngồi thoải mái trên ghế, “để bác khuyên con điều này: đừng bao giờ làm việc cho nhà nước. Vì khi là người nhà nước, con phải làm việc cho nhân dân. Và khi làm việc cho nhân dân, con phải giao tiếp với người khác, thậm chí những người như vợ chồng nhà Spiegelman.” Tôi khẽ nhe răng cười.
tr: “Evlat,” dedi koltuğa oturur oturmaz, “izninle sana biraz tavsiye vereyim: Asla devlet için çalışma. Çünkü devlet için çalıştığında, insanlar için çalışırsın. Ve insanlar için çalıştığında, insanlarla etkileşime girmek zorunda kalırsın, Spiegelman’larla bile.” Biraz güldüm.
es: —Muchacho —me dijo cuando se hubo acomodado en el sillón—, permíteme que te dé un consejo: nunca trabajes para el gobierno. Porque cuando trabajas para el gobierno, trabajas para la gente. Y cuando trabajas para la gente, tienes que relacionarte con ella, incluso con los Spiegelman. Solté una risita.
vi_translation: "My child," he said as he sat comfortably in the chair, "let me give you this advice: never work for the government. Because when you work for the government, you have to serve the people. And when you serve the people, you have to interact with others, even people like the Spiegelman couple." I smiled slightly.
tr_translation: “Child,” he said as soon as he sat down, “let me give you some advice: Never work for the government. Because when you work for the government, you work for the people. And when you work for the people, you have to interact with people, even with the Spiegelmans.” I laughed a little.
es_translation: —Boy —he said to me once he had settled into the armchair—, allow me to give you some advice: never work for the government. Because when you work for the government, you work for the people. And when you work for the people, you have to interact with them, even with the Spiegelmans. I let out a giggle.

en: “Let me be frank with you, kid. Those people know how to parent like I know how to diet. I’ve worked with them before, and I don’t like them. I don’t care if you tell her parents where she is, but I’d appreciate it if you told me.”
vi: “Để bác nói thẳng với con nhé. Vợ chồng đó biết cách làm cha mẹ thế nào cũng giống như bác biết cách phải ăn kiêng ra sao. Bác đã từng giải quyết công việc với họ, và bác không ưa cả hai vợ chồng. Bác không quan tâm con có nói với bố mẹ của Margo rằng con bé đi đâu không, nhưng bác sẽ rất cảm kích nếu con cho bác biết.
tr: “Sana karşı dürüst olayım, evlat. Bu insanlar nasıl ebeveyn olunacağını benim nasıl diyet yapılacağım bildiğim kadar biliyorlar. Onlarla daha önce de çalıştım ve onlardan hoşlanmadım. Annesiyle babasına Margo’nun nerede olduğunu söyleyip söylememen umurumda değil ama bana söylersen minnettar olurum.
es: —Permíteme que sea sincero contigo, muchacho —siguió diciéndome—. Esta gente sabe tanto de ser padres como yo de hacer dieta. He trabajado con ellos otras veces y no me gustan. Me da igual que no les digas a los padres de Margo dónde está, pero te agradecería que me lo dijeras a mí.
vi_translation: “Let me be frank with you. That couple knows how to be parents just as much as I know how to diet. I've dealt with them before, and I don't like either of them. I don't care if you tell Margo's parents where she went or not, but I would appreciate it if you let me know.”
tr_translation: “Let me be honest with you, kid. These people know how to be parents as much as I know how to diet. I’ve worked with them before and I didn’t like them. I don’t care if you tell Margo’s parents where she is, but I’d be grateful if you tell me.”
es_translation: —Allow me to be honest with you, kid —he continued saying to me—. These people know as much about being parents as I do about dieting. I've worked with them before and I don't like them. I don't care if you don't tell Margo's parents where she is, but I would appreciate it if you told me.

en: “I don’t know,” I said. “I really don’t.”
vi: “Con không biết ạ,” tôi đáp. “Con không biết thật mà bác.”
tr: “Bilmiyorum,” dedim. “Gerçekten.
es: —No lo sé —le contesté—. De verdad que no lo sé.
vi_translation: "I don't know," I replied. "I really don't know, sir."
tr_translation: "I don't know," I said. "Really."
es_translation: —I don't know —I replied—. Honestly, I don't know.

en: “Kid, I’ve been thinking about this girl. This stuff she does— she breaks into Disney World, for instance, right? She goes to Mississippi and leaves alphabet soup clues. She organizes a huge campaign to toilet paper houses.”
vi: “Con trai ạ, bác đã nghĩ nhiều đến cô bé Margo này. Những việc nó làm–đột nhập vào Disney World chẳng hạn, nhỉ? Nó đi Mississippi và để lại manh mối trong bát súp. Nó tổ chức một chiến dịch qui mô lớn phủ giấy vệ sinh lên các căn nhà.”
tr: “Evlat, bu kız hakkında düşünüyordum. Yaptığı bu şeyleri... Disney World’e izinsiz giriyor mesela, değil mi? Mississippi’ye gidiyor ve çorbasına harflerden ipucu bırakıyor. Evlere tuvalet kâğıdı saldırısı yapmak için büyük bir kampanya düzenliyor.
es: —Muchacho, he estado pensando en la chica. Lo que hace… Se mete en Disney World, por ejemplo, ¿verdad? Se va a Mississippi y deja pistas con sopa de letras. Organiza una gran campaña para empapelar casas con papel higiénico.
vi_translation: "Son, I've been thinking a lot about this girl Margo." "The things she does—like breaking into Disney World, right? She goes to Mississippi and leaves clues in a bowl of soup." "She organizes a large-scale campaign to cover houses with toilet paper."
tr_translation: “Son, I was thinking about this girl. The things she does... She sneaks into Disney World, for example, right? She goes to Mississippi and leaves clues in her soup with letters. She organizes a big campaign to toilet paper houses.”
es_translation: —Boy, I've been thinking about the girl. What she does... She sneaks into Disney World, for example, right? She goes to Mississippi and leaves clues with alphabet soup. She organizes a big campaign to toilet paper houses.

en: “How do you know about that?” Two years before, Margo had led the TP-ing of two hundred houses in a single night. Needless to say, I wasn’t invited on that adventure.
vi: “Sao bác biết chuyện đó ạ?” Hai năm trước, Margo đã chỉ huy tác chiến phủ giấy vệ sinh lên hai trăm căn nhà trong đúng một đêm. Khỏi nói cũng biết, tất nhiên tôi không được mời tham gia cuộc vui ấy.
tr: “Bunu nereden biliyorsunuz?” iki yıl önce Margo bir gecede iki yüz eve tuvalet kâğıdı saldırısı yapılmasına öncülük etmişti. Söylememe gerek yok, bu maceraya davet edilmemiştim.
es: —¿Cómo lo sabe? Hacía dos años, Margo había liderado el empapelado de doscientas casas en una sola noche. No será necesario que diga que no me invitó a participar en aquella aventura.
vi_translation: "How did you know about that?" Two years ago, Margo had orchestrated a mission to cover two hundred houses with toilet paper in just one night. Needless to say, I wasn't invited to join in on the fun.
tr_translation: "How do you know this?" Two years ago, Margo had led an overnight toilet paper attack on two hundred houses. Needless to say, I had not been invited to this adventure.
es_translation: —How do you know? Two years ago, Margo had led the wallpapering of two hundred houses in a single night. It goes without saying that she didn't invite me to participate in that adventure.

en: “I worked this case before. So, kid, here’s where I need your help: who plans this stuff? These crazy schemes? She’s the mouthpiece for it all, the one crazy enough to do everything. But who plans it? Who’s sitting around with notebooks full of diagrams figuring out how much toilet paper you need to toilet paper a ton of houses?”
vi: “Bác đã theo vụ đó mà. Vậy nên con trai ạ, đây là chỗ bác cần con giúp: ai đã vạch kế hoạch tất cả? Những hiệp đồng tác chiến điên rồ này? Con bé Margo là phát ngôn viên cho tất cả, là đứa đủ điên rồ làm tất cả. Nhưng ai đã tính toán kế hoạch? Ai ngồi giữa đống sổ nhằng nhịt sơ đồ, tính xem cần bao nhiêu giấy vệ sinh để phủ lên cả tấn nhà như vậy?”
tr: “Önceden bu olayda görev almıştım. Yani evlat, yardımına ihtiyacım olan nokta şu: Bu şeyleri kim planlıyor? Bu çılgın projeleri. Margo bunların hepsinin sözcüsü, her şeyi yapabilecek kadar çılgın olan kişi. Ama kim planbyor? Bir ton eve saldırmak için ne kadar tuvalet kâğıdı gerektiğini gösteren diyagramlarla dolu defterleri kim dolduruyor?
es: —He trabajado en este caso antes. Así que, muchacho, necesito que me ayudes. ¿Quién planifica estas cosas? ¿Estos proyectos de locos? Ella es la portavoz de todo esto, la única lo bastante loca para hacerlo. Pero ¿quién lo planifica? ¿Quién se sienta con libretas llenas de diagramas para calcular cuánto papel higiénico se necesita para empapelar un montón de casas?
vi_translation: “I have been following that case.” “So, my boy, this is where I need your help: who planned all of this?” “These crazy coordinated attacks?” “That girl Margo is the spokesperson for all of it, the one crazy enough to do it all.” “But who calculated the plan?” “Who sat amidst the messy diagrams, figuring out how much toilet paper was needed to cover so many houses?”
tr_translation: “I had previously been involved in this event. So, kid, the point where I need your help is this: Who is planning these things? These crazy projects. Margo is the spokesperson for all of them, capable of doing everything The person who is crazy. But who is planning? Who is filling notebooks with diagrams showing how much toilet paper is needed to attack a ton of houses?”
es_translation: —I have worked on this case before. So, kid, I need you to help me. Who plans these things? These crazy projects? She is the spokesperson for all of this, the only one crazy enough to do it. But who plans it? Who sits with notebooks full of diagrams to calculate how much toilet paper is needed to wallpaper a bunch of houses?

en: “It’s all her, I assume.”
vi: “Con đoán đều là Margo cả thôi.”
tr: “Hepsi Margo’nun işi sanırım.
es: —Supongo que ella.
vi_translation: "I guess they are all Margo."
tr_translation: “I think it's all Margo's doing.”
es_translation: —I suppose her.

en: “But she might have a partner, somebody helpin’ her do all these big and brilliant things, and maybe the person who’s in on her secret isn’t the obvious person, isn’t her best friend or her boyfriend. Maybe it’s somebody you wouldn’t think of right off,” he said. He took a breath and was about to say something more when I cut him off.
vi: “Nhưng hẳn là con bé phải có trợ thủ, ai đó giúp nó thực thi tất cả những thứ to tát táo bạo này, và có thể cái người giấu mặt đó không phải là một người mà ai cũng biết, không phải bạn thân nhất hay bạn trai của Margo. Có thể là ai đó con không nghĩ ngay đến.” Bác ấy lấy hơi toan nói tiếp thì tôi cắt ngang.
tr: “Ama bir ortağı olabilir, bütün bu büyük ve zekice şeyleri yapmasına yardım eden ve belki de sırnna ortak olan kişi; apaçık ortada olan biri değil, en iyi arkadaşı ya da erkek arkadaşı değil. Belki hemen aklına gelmeyecek birisi,” dedi. Nefes aldı, sözünü kestiğimde bir şeyler daha söylemek üzereydi.
es: —Pero debe de tener un socio, alguien que la ayude a hacer todas estas cosas desaforadas y geniales. Y quizá la persona que comparte su secreto no es la más obvia, no es su mejor amiga ni su novio. Quizá es alguien en quien nunca pensarías —me dijo. El detective respiró y estaba a punto de decir algo más cuando lo interrumpí.
vi_translation: “But surely the girl must have an accomplice, someone helping her carry out all these grand and daring things, and maybe that hidden person is not someone everyone knows, not Margo's best friend or boyfriend. It could be someone you wouldn't immediately think of.” He took a breath, about to continue, when I interrupted him.
tr_translation: “But he might have a partner, someone who helps him do all these great and clever things and maybe shares his secret; someone who is not obviously in the picture, not his best friend or boyfriend. Maybe someone who wouldn't immediately come to mind,” he said. He took a breath, he was about to say something more when I interrupted him.
es_translation: —But she must have a partner, someone who helps her do all these outrageous and brilliant things. And maybe the person who shares her secret is not the most obvious one, not her best friend or her boyfriend. Maybe it's someone you would never think of —he told me. The detective took a breath and was about to say something else when I interrupted him.

en: “I don’t know where she is,” I said. “I swear to God.”
vi: “Con không biết Margo đang ở đâu,” tôi nói. “Con thề có Chúa chứng giám.
tr: “Nerede olduğunu bilmiyorum,” dedim. “Yemin ederim.” “Sadece kontrol ediyorum, evlat.
es: —No sé dónde está. Se lo juro por Dios.
vi_translation: "I don't know where Margo is," I said. "I swear to God."
tr_translation: “I don't know where she is,” I said. “I swear.” “I'm just checking, kid.
es_translation: —I don't know where it is. I swear to God.

en: “Just checking, kid. Anyway, you know something, don’t you? So let’s start there.” I told him everything. I trusted the guy. He took a few notes while I talked, but nothing very detailed. And something about telling him, and his scribbling in the notebook, and her parents being so lame—something about all of it made the possibility of her being lastingly missing well up in me for the first time. I felt the worry start to snatch at my breath when I finished talking. The detective didn’t say anything for a while. He just leaned forward in the chair and stared past me until he’d seen whatever he was waiting to see, and then he started talking.
vi: “Con cứ cân nhắc xem. Dù sao, con cũng biết điều gì đó, phải không? Vậy hãy bắt đầu từ đó.” Thế là tôi kể với bác ấy tất cả. Tôi tin người đàn ông này. Bác ấy ghi chép chút ít trong khi tôi nói, nhưng không có gì quá chi tiết. Và có gì đó trong việc kể lại với bác ấy, trong những ghi chú vắn tắt trên trang sổ, trong vẻ bạc nhược của bố mẹ Margo–có điều gì đó trong tất cả khiến lần đầu tiên trong tôi quặn lên cảm giác nhộn nhạo rằng có thể Margo sẽ còn mất tích trong một thời gian dài nữa. Sự lo lắng bất an như chặn lấy hơi thở của tôi khi tôi ngừng kể. Viên thám tử yên lặng một lúc. Bác ấy chỉ nhoài khỏi ghế, nhìn chăm chú qua vai tôi cho đến khi thấy điều gì đó bác ấy đã chờ để thấy, rồi bắt đầu nói.
tr: “Sadece kontrol ediyorum, evlat. Her halükârda, bir şeyler biliyorsun, değil mi? O zaman haydi oradan başlayalım.” Ona her şeyi anlattım. Adama güvenmiştim. Ben konuşurken birkaç not aldı ama hiçbiri çok detaylı değildi. Ve adama anlatmam, onun deftere karalaması, ebeveynlerinin kötü olması... Margo’nun gerçekten kaybolmuş olabileceği ihtimaliyle ilgili bir duygunun ilk kez içimi doldurmasına sebep oldu. Konuşmayı bitirdiğimde, endişeden nefesimin kesilmeye başladığını hissettim. Dedektif bir süre hiçbir şey demedi. Sadece koltukta öne doğru eğilip ne görmeyi bekliyorsa onu görene kadar benden öteye doğru baktı, sonra konuşmaya başladı.
es: —Solo quería asegurarme, muchacho. De todas formas, sabes algo, ¿verdad? Empecemos por ahí. Se lo conté todo. Confiaba en aquel tipo. Tomó algunas notas mientras yo hablaba, aunque sin demasiados detalles. Pero al contárselo, y al verlo garabateando en la libreta, y al haberme dado cuenta de la estupidez de los padres de Margo…, por primera vez me planteé la posibilidad de que hubiera desaparecido por mucho tiempo. Cuando acabé de hablar, estaba tan preocupado que empezaba a faltarme el aire. El detective no dijo nada durante un rato. Se inclinó hacia delante y miró a la lejanía hasta encontrar lo que estaba buscando, y entonces empezó a hablar.
vi_translation: "Just consider it carefully." "Anyway, you know something, don't you?" "So let's start from there." So I told him everything. I trusted this man. He took a few notes while I spoke, but nothing too detailed. And there was something in telling him, in the brief notes on the page, in the weariness of Margo's parents—something in all of it made me feel for the first time a gnawing sensation that Margo might be missing for a long time. Anxiety seemed to choke my breath as I stopped speaking. The detective was silent for a moment. He just leaned out of his chair, staring intently over my shoulder until he saw something he had been waiting to see, then he began to speak.
tr_translation: “I swear.” “I'm just checking, kid. Anyway, you know something, don't you? Then let's start from there.” I told him everything. I had trusted the man. He took a few notes while I was talking, but none of them were very detailed. And telling the man, his scribbling in the notebook, the badness of her parents... Made me feel, for the first time, the possibility that Margo might really be missing. When I finished talking, I felt my breath starting to catch from worry. The detective didn't say anything for a while. He just leaned forward in the chair and looked past me until he saw whatever he was expecting to see, then he started to speak.
es_translation: —I just wanted to make sure, boy. Anyway, you know something, right? Let's start from there. I told him everything. I trusted that guy. He took some notes while I talked, though without too many details. But in telling him, and seeing him scribbling in the notebook, and realizing the stupidity of Margo's parents... for the first time, I considered the possibility that she might have disappeared for a long time. When I finished talking, I was so worried that I started to run out of breath. The detective didn't say anything for a while. He leaned forward and looked into the distance until he found what he was looking for, and then he started to speak.

en: “Listen, kid. This is what happens: somebody—girl usually— got a free spirit, doesn’t get on too good with her parents. These kids, they’re like tied-down helium balloons. They strain against the string and strain against it, and then something happens, and that string gets cut, and they just float away. And maybe you never see the balloon again. It lands in Canada or somethin’, gets work at a restaurant, and before the balloon even notices, it’s been pouring coffee in that same diner to the same sad bastards for thirty years. Or maybe three or four years from now, or three or four days from now, the prevailing winds take the balloon back home, because it needs money, or it sobered up, or it misses its kid brother. But listen, kid, that string gets cut all the time.”
vi: “Nghe này, con trai. Chuyện xảy ra thế này: một người nào đó–thường là con gái–có một tâm hồn tự do, và không thực sự hòa hợp với bố mẹ. Những đứa trẻ ấy, chúng như quả bóng bay chứa đầy khí hê-li bị buộc lại. Chúng vươn lên và muốn bứt khỏi dây buộc, và rồi chuyện gì đó xảy ra, dây bị đứt lìa, thế là chúng trôi đi. Có thể con sẽ không bao giờ thấy lại quả bóng bay nữa. Nó đáp xuống Canada hay nơi nào đó, có công ăn việc làm trong một nhà hàng. Và trước khi quả bóng kịp nhận ra, nó đã phục vụ cà phê trong cái quán quèn đó, cho những thực khách nhàm chán đó suốt ba mươi năm. Hoặc cũng có thể dăm ba năm nữa, hay dăm ba ngày nữa, những luồng gió mạnh đưa quả bóng về nhà, vì nó cần tiền, hoặc vì nó thổn thức, nó nhớ thằng em trai ở nhà. Nhưng con nghe này, sợi dây nối cứ bị đứt lìa suốt thôi.”
tr: “Dinle, evlat. Genelde şöyle olur: Birigenellikle bir kızözgür ruhludur, ebeveynleriyle fazla iyi geçinemez. Bu çocuklar bağlanmış helyum dolu balonlar gibidir. İpe karşı çabalarlar, çabalarlar, sonra bir şey olur, ip kopar ve o anda uçup giderler. Belki de balonu bir daha göremezsin. Kanada’ya falan iner, bir restoranda iş bulur ve balon daha fark etmeden otuz yıldır aynı lokantada, aynı kasvetli serserilere kahve servis ediyordur. Ya da belki bundan üçdört yıl sonra veya üçdört gün sonra, rüzgâr balonu eve geri getirir çünkü ya paraya ihtiyacı vardır ya aklı başına gelmiştir ya da erkek kardeşini özlemiştir. Ama dinle evlat, o ip sürekli kopar.”
es: —Mira, muchacho. Pasa lo siguiente: alguien con espíritu libre, normalmente una chica, no se lleva demasiado bien con sus padres. Estos chicos son como globos de helio atados. Tiran del hilo una y otra vez, hasta que al final el hilo se rompe y salen volando. Y quizá no vuelvas a ver ese globo, porque aterriza en Canadá o donde sea, encuentra trabajo en un restaurante y antes de que el globo se dé cuenta, lleva treinta años en la misma cafetería sirviendo café a los mismos hijos de puta. O quizá dentro de tres o cuatro años, o dentro de tres o cuatro días, los vientos predominantes devuelven el globo a casa, porque necesita dinero, o porque se lo ha pensado mejor, o porque echa de menos a su hermanito. Pero, mira, muchacho, el hilo no deja de romperse.
vi_translation: “Listen, son. This is how it goes: someone—usually a girl—has a free spirit and doesn't really get along with her parents. Those kids, they're like helium-filled balloons tied down. They rise up and want to break free from the string, and then something happens, the string snaps, and they drift away. You might never see that balloon again. It lands in Canada or somewhere, gets a job in a restaurant. And before the balloon realizes it, it's been serving coffee in that dingy café to those boring customers for thirty years. Or maybe in a few years, or a few days, strong winds bring the balloon back home because it needs money, or because it aches, it misses its little brother at home. But listen, the string keeps snapping all the time.”
tr_translation: “Listen, kid. It usually goes like this: Typically, a girl is a free spirit and doesn't get along too well with her parents. These kids are like helium-filled balloons tied down. They struggle against the string, struggle and struggle, then something happens, the string breaks, and at that moment, they fly away. Maybe you'll never see the balloon again. It might land in Canada or somewhere, find a job in a restaurant, and before the balloon even realizes it, it's been serving coffee to the same gloomy drifters in the same diner for thirty years. Or maybe three or four years later, or three or four days later, the wind brings the balloon back home because either it needs money, has come to its senses, or misses its brother. But listen, kid, that string always breaks.”
es_translation: —Look, kid. Here's the thing: someone with a free spirit, usually a girl, doesn't get along too well with her parents. These kids are like helium balloons tied down. They pull on the string over and over again, until finally the string breaks and they fly away. And maybe you'll never see that balloon again, because it lands in Canada or wherever, finds a job in a restaurant, and before the balloon realizes it, it's been thirty years in the same café serving coffee to the same sons of bitches. Or maybe in three or four years, or in three or four days, the prevailing winds bring the balloon back home, because it needs money, or because it has changed its mind, or because it misses its little brother. But, look, kid, the string keeps breaking.

en: “Yeah, bu—”
vi: “Vâng, như–”
tr: “Evet ama...
es: —Sí, pe…
vi_translation: “Yes, like–”
tr_translation: “Yes, but...”
es_translation: —Yes, bu…

en: “I’m not finished, kid. The thing about these balloons is that there are so goddamned many of them. The sky is choked full of them, rubbing up against one another as they float to here or from there, and every one of those damned balloons ends up on my desk one way or another, and after a while a man can get discouraged. Everywhere the balloons, and each of them with a mother or a father, or God forbid both, and after a while, you can’t even see ’em individually. You look up at all the balloons in the sky and you can see all of the balloons, but you cannot see any one balloon.” He paused then, and inhaled sharply, as if he was realizing something. “But then every now and again you talk to some big-eyed kid with too much hair for his head and you want to lie to him because he seems like a good kid. And you feel bad for this kid, because the only thing worse than the skyful of balloons you see is what he sees: a clear blue day interrupted by just the one balloon. But once that string gets cut, kid, you can’t uncut it. Do you get what I’m saying?”
vi: “Bác chưa nói hết, con trai ạ. Vấn đề về bóng bay là ở chỗ có quá nhiều những quả bóng như vậy. Bầu trời chật ních những bóng bay, chúng cọ vào nhau khi trôi từ nơi này sang nơi khác, và từng quả trong đám bóng quái quỉ ấy bằng cách này hay cách khác sẽ đến với bàn làm việc của bác, cứ hoài như vậy thì một người đàn ông cũng có thể thấy nản. Chỗ nào cũng là bóng bay, từng quả với một bà mẹ hoặc một ông bố, hoặc trời thương cho có cả hai, và cứ hoài như vậy, đến khi không thể thấy từng quả được nữa. Con nhìn lên bóng bay trên bầu trời, con thấy tất cả những quả bóng ấy, nhưng không thể nhìn rõ từng quả.” Bác ấy dừng lại, thở vào thật sâu, như thể đang nhận ra điều gì đó. “Nhưng rồi từ đấy, bất cứ khi nào, khi nói chuyện với một cậu nhóc mắt tròn xoe, đầu tóc bù xù nào đó, con không muốn nói thật với nó vì trông nó có vẻ là một đứa trẻ ngoan. Và con chợt thương thằng bé, vì điều duy nhất tệ hơn vòm trời đầy bóng mà con thấy chính là những gì thằng bé thấy: một ngày trong xanh bị gãy bởi một quả bóng duy nhất. Nhưng con trai ạ, một khi dây nối đã đứt lìa, con không thể đảo ngược điều đó được. Con có hiểu những điều bác vừa nói không?”
tr: “Daha bitirmedim, evlat. Bu balonlarla ilgili olay şu ki onlardan gerçekten çok fazla var. Gökyüzü tıka basa onlarla dolu, oradan oraya dolaşırken birbirleriyle rastlaşıyorlar ve bu lanet balonların her biri öyle ya da böyle benim masamı boyluyor ve bir süre sonra insan beziyor. Her yerde balonlar, hepsinin bir annesi veya babası ya da Tanrı korusun, ikisi birden var ve bir süre sonra onları tek tek göremiyorsun. Gökyüzündeki bütün balonlara bakıyorsun ve bütün balonları görebiliyorsun ama tek bir balon asla göremiyorsun.” O sırada ara verip sert bir nefes aldı, sanki bir şeyin farkına varmış gibiydi. “Ama sonra, arada bir, kafasına oranla fazla saçı olan kocaman gözlü bir çocukla konuşur ve ona yalan söylemek istersin, çünkü iyi bir çocuğa benziyordur. Sonra o çocuk için kendini kötü hissedersin çünkü senin gördüğün balon dolu gökyüzünden daha kötü olan tek şey onun gördüğü şeydir: Sadece tek bir balon tarafından sekteye uğrayan açık, mavi bir gökyüzü. Ama ip bir kere koptuğunda bunu geri alamazsın, evlat. Ne dediğimi anlıyor musun?
es: —No he terminado, muchacho. El problema de estos putos globos es que hay muchísimos. El cielo está lleno de globos que vuelan de un lado a otro y chocan entre sí, y todos y cada uno de estos putos globos acaban en la mesa de mi despacho por una razón u otra, y con el tiempo uno se desanima. Globos por todas partes, cada uno de ellos con un padre o una madre, o con un poco de suerte con los dos, y al final ni siquiera puedes verlos individualmente. Levantas la mirada hacia los globos del cielo y los ves en su totalidad, pero ya no los ves de uno en uno. —Se calló y respiró profundamente, como si acabara de darse cuenta de algo—. Pero de vez en cuando hablas con un chico de ojos grandes y con demasiado pelo en la cabeza y quieres mentirle porque parece un buen chico. Y lo sientes por él, porque lo único peor que el cielo lleno de globos que ves es lo que ve él: un día azul y despejado con un único globo. Pero cuando el hilo se rompe, muchacho, no puedes volver a pegarlo. ¿Entiendes lo que te quiero decir?
vi_translation: "I haven't finished speaking yet, son. The problem with balloons is that there are too many of them. The sky is crowded with balloons, they rub against each other as they drift from place to place, and each one of those damn balloons somehow ends up on my desk, and if this keeps happening, a man can get discouraged. Balloons everywhere, each with a mother or a father, or heaven forbid, both, and it keeps happening until you can't see each one anymore. You look up at the balloons in the sky, you see all those balloons, but you can't see each one clearly." He paused, taking a deep breath, as if realizing something. "But then, from there, anytime, when talking to some wide-eyed, tousle-haired kid, you don't want to tell him the truth because he looks like a good kid. And you suddenly feel sorry for the boy, because the only thing worse than the sky full of balloons you see is what the boy sees: a clear day broken by a single balloon. But son, once the string is cut, you can't reverse that. Do you understand what I've just said?"
tr_translation: “I'm not done yet, kid. The thing about these balloons is that there are really a lot of them. The sky is crammed full of them, they bump into each other as they float around, and every single one of these damn balloons somehow ends up on my desk, and after a while, you get tired of it. Balloons everywhere, each one has a mother or a father or, God forbid, both, and after a while, you can't see them individually anymore. You look at all the balloons in the sky and you can see all of them, but you can never see just one balloon.” He paused then and took a deep breath, as if he had realized something. “But then, once in a while, you talk to a kid with too much hair for his head and big eyes, and you want to lie to him, because he looks like a good kid. Then you feel bad for that kid because the only thing worse than the balloon-filled sky you see is what he sees: A clear, blue sky interrupted by just one balloon. But once the string is broken, you can't take it back, kid. Do you understand what I'm saying?”
es_translation: —I'm not finished, kid. The problem with these damn balloons is that there are so many of them. The sky is full of balloons flying from one side to the other and colliding with each other, and each and every one of these damn balloons ends up on my desk for one reason or another, and over time you get discouraged. Balloons everywhere, each one with a father or a mother, or if you're lucky, with both, and in the end, you can't even see them individually. You look up at the balloons in the sky and see them as a whole, but you no longer see them one by one. —He fell silent and took a deep breath, as if he had just realized something—. But every now and then you talk to a kid with big eyes and too much hair on his head, and you want to lie to him because he seems like a good kid. And you feel sorry for him, because the only thing worse than the sky full of balloons you see is what he sees: a clear blue day with a single balloon. But when the string breaks, kid, you can't glue it back together. Do you understand what I'm trying to tell you?

en: I nodded, although I wasn’t sure I did understand. He stood up. “I do think she’ll be back soon, kid. If that helps.”
vi: Tôi gật đầu, dù không dám chắc tôi đã hiểu. Bác ấy đứng lên. “Bác nghĩ cô bé sẽ sớm về thôi, con trai. Nếu nói ra như vậy khiến con thấy khá hơn.”
tr: Başımı aşağı yukarı salladım, anladığımdan pek emin olmasam da. Ayağa kalktı. “Ben yakında döneceğini düşünüyorum, evlat. Eğer yardımı olacaksa.
es: Asentí, aunque no estaba seguro de haberlo entendido. Se levantó. —Creo que volverá pronto, muchacho. Por si sirve de algo.
vi_translation: I nodded, though I wasn't sure I understood. He stood up. “I think the girl will be back soon, son. If saying it like that makes you feel better.”
tr_translation: I nodded my head up and down, though I wasn't quite sure I understood. He stood up. "I think he'll be back soon, son. If it will help.""
es_translation: I nodded, although I wasn't sure I had understood. He stood up. —I think he will return soon, boy. For what it's worth.

en: I liked the image of Margo as a balloon, but I figured that in his urge for the poetic, the detective had seen more worry in me than the pang I’d actually felt. I knew she’d be back. She’d deflate and float back to Jefferson Park. She always had.
vi: Tôi thích hình dung Margo như quả bóng bay, nhưng dường như trong cơn trào dâng đầy chất thơ vừa rồi, vị thám tử đã nhìn thấu có rất nhiều lo lắng ở trong tôi, còn hơn cả những xung động tôi đang thực sự cảm nhận. Tôi biết Margo sẽ về. Cô ấy sẽ xẹp lại và trôi trở về Jefferson Park. Cô ấy luôn như vậy.
tr: Margo’nun balon halini hayal etmek hoşuma gitmişti ama dedektif konuya şiirsel yaklaşırken bende, aslında hissettiğim ani sancıdan ziyade endişe gördüğünü düşündüm. Margo’nun geri döneceğini biliyordum. Sönecek ve tekrar Jefiferson Park’a doğru süzülecekti. Her zaman öyle yapmıştı.
es: Me gustó la imagen de Margo como un globo, pero pensé que, en su deseo de ser poético, el detective me había visto mucho más preocupado de lo que realmente estaba. Sabía que volvería. Se desinflaría y volvería volando a Jefferson Park. Siempre había vuelto.
vi_translation: I like to imagine Margo as a balloon, but it seems that in the midst of the poetic surge just now, the detective saw through to a lot of worries within me, even more than the impulses I was actually feeling. I know Margo will come back. She will deflate and drift back to Jefferson Park. She always does.
tr_translation: I liked imagining Margo as a balloon, but while the detective approached the matter poetically, I thought he saw worry in me rather than the sudden pang I actually felt. I knew Margo would come back. She would deflate and float back towards Jefferson Park. She had always done so.
es_translation: I liked the image of Margo as a balloon, but I thought that, in his desire to be poetic, the detective had seen me as much more worried than I actually was. I knew she would come back. She would deflate and fly back to Jefferson Park. She had always come back.

en: I followed the detective back to the dining room, and then he said he wanted to go back over to the Spiegelmans’ house and pick through her room a little. Mrs. Spiegelman gave me a hug and said, “You’ve always been such a good boy; I’m sorry she ever got you caught up in this ridiculousness.” Mr. Spiegelman shook my hand, and they left. As soon as the door closed, my dad said, “Wow.”
vi: Tôi theo bác thám tử quay lại phòng ăn, rồi bác ấy nói muốn sang nhà Spiegelman và xem qua phòng Margo. Cô Spiegelman ôm tôi và nói, “Con luôn là một chàng trai nghiêm chỉnh, cô xin lỗi vì con bé Margo đã lôi con vào trò nực cười này.” Chú Spiegelman bắt tay tôi, rồi họ ra về. Cửa vừa đóng, bố tôi đã thốt lên: “Ồ!”
tr: Dedektifi tekrar yemek odasma doğru takip ettim, sonra Spiegelman’Iann evine dönüp biraz Margo’nun odasını incelemek istediğini söyledi. Bayan Spiegelman bana sarıldı ve “Sen her zaman çok iyi bir çocuk oldun; seni de bu maskaralığın içine çektiyse üzgünüm,” dedi. Bay Spiegelman elimi sıktı ve gittiler. Kapı kapanır kapanmaz babam, “Vay canına,” dedi.
es: Regresé al comedor con el detective, que dijo que quería volver a la casa de los Spiegelman para echar un vistazo en la habitación de Margo. La señora Spiegelman me abrazó. —Siempre has sido un buen chico —me dijo—. Siento que tengas que verte mezclado en estas ridiculeces. El señor Spiegelman me estrechó la mano y se marcharon. En cuanto se hubo cerrado la puerta, mi padre dijo:
vi_translation: I followed the detective back to the dining room, then he said he wanted to go to the Spiegelman house and take a look at Margo's room. Ms. Spiegelman hugged me and said, "You've always been a serious young man, I'm sorry that Margo dragged you into this ridiculous game." Mr. Spiegelman shook my hand, then they left. As soon as the door closed, my dad exclaimed, "Oh!"
tr_translation: I followed the detective back to the dining room, then he said he wanted to return to the Spiegelmans' house and examine Margo's room a bit. Mrs. Spiegelman hugged me and said, "You have always been a very good child; I'm sorry if he dragged you into this nonsense." Mr. Spiegelman shook my hand and they left. As soon as the door closed, my father said, "Wow."
es_translation: I returned to the dining room with the detective, who said he wanted to go back to the Spiegelman house to take a look in Margo's room. Mrs. Spiegelman hugged me. "You have always been a good boy," he told me. "I'm sorry that you have to get mixed up in these ridiculous things." Mr. Spiegelman shook my hand and they left. As soon as the door was closed, my father said:

en: My dad put his arm around me. “Those are some very troubling dynamics, eh, bud?”
vi: Bố khoác vai tôi. “Vừa rồi là những xung lực rất phiền toái phải không con giai bố?”
tr: Babam kolunu bana doladı. “Bunlar çok rahatsız edici hareketler, değil mi ahbap?
es: Mi padre me pasó el brazo por los hombros. —Han optado por una dinámica que solo crea problemas, ¿verdad?
vi_translation: Dad put his arm around my shoulder. "Those were some very troublesome impulses just now, weren't they, my boy?"
tr_translation: My father wrapped his arm around me. “These are very disturbing actions, aren't they buddy?”
es_translation: My father put his arm around my shoulders. —They have opted for a dynamic that only creates problems, haven't they?

en: “They’re kind of assholes,” I said. My parents always liked it when I cursed in front of them. I could see the pleasure of it in their faces. It signified that I trusted them, that I was myself in front of them. But even so, they seemed sad.
vi: “Vợ chồng họ thúi hoăng hoắc,” tôi nói. Bố mẹ luôn lấy làm thú vị khi tôi làu bàu rủa sả trước mặt họ. Tôi thấy ngay vẻ mãn nguyện trên mặt hai đấng sinh thành ra mình. Công khai rủa sả như vậy là tín hiệu cho thấy tôi tin tưởng bố mẹ, rằng tôi bộc lộ bản thân trước mặt họ. Dù quả là như vậy, nhưng trông bố mẹ vẫn buồn buồn.
tr: “Göte benziyorlar,” dedim. Ebeveynlerim onların önünde küfretmemden hoşlanırdı. ifadelerinden bundan memnun olduklarım görürdüm. Bu benim onlara güvendiğimi, onların önünde kendim olduğumu gösteriyordu. Ama buna rağmen üzgün görünüyorlardı.
es: —Son gilipollas —le dije yo. A mis padres les gustaba que dijera tacos delante de ellos. Veía el placer en sus caras. Significaba que confiaba en ellos, que era yo mismo delante de ellos. Pero, aun así, parecían tristes.
vi_translation: "That couple stinks to high heaven," I said. My parents always found it amusing when I grumbled and cursed in front of them. I immediately saw the look of satisfaction on the faces of my creators. Openly cursing like that was a signal that I trusted my parents, that I was revealing myself in front of them. Even though that was indeed the case, my parents still looked somewhat sad.
tr_translation: “They look like idiots,” I said. My parents liked it when I swore in front of them. I could see from their expressions that they were pleased by this. This showed that I trusted them, that I was being myself in front of them. But despite this, they looked sad.
es_translation: —They are idiots —I told him. My parents liked it when I said swear words in front of them. I saw the pleasure on their faces. It meant that I trusted them, that I was myself in front of them. But, even so, they seemed sad.

en: “Margo’s parents suffer a severe narcissistic injury whenever she acts out,” Dad said to me.
vi: “Bố mẹ Margo hẳn là bị tổn thương lòng tự tôn nghiêm trọng khi con bé cư xử như vậy,” bố bảo tôi.
tr: “Margo ne zaman bir yaramazlık yapsa, annesiyle babası ciddi bir narsistik yaranın acısını çekiyor,” dedi babam.
es: —Los padres de Margo sufren una lesión grave en su narcisismo cada vez que su hija se porta mal —me dijo mi padre.
vi_translation: "Margo's parents must have been deeply hurt in their pride when she behaved like that," Dad told me.
tr_translation: “Whenever Margo does something mischievous, her mother and father suffer the pain of a serious narcissistic wound,” said my father.
es_translation: —Margo's parents suffer a serious blow to their narcissism every time their daughter misbehaves —my father told me.

en: “It prevents them from parenting effectively,” my mom added.
vi: “Điều đó khiến họ không làm cha làm mẹ một cách hữu hiệu được,” mẹ tôi nói thêm.
tr: “Bu da onları etkili bir biçimde ebeveynlik yapmaktan alıkoyuyor,” diye ekledi annem.
es: —Y eso les impide comportarse como padres de forma eficaz —añadió mi madre.
vi_translation: "That makes them unable to be effective parents," my mother added.
tr_translation: “This also prevents them from parenting effectively,” my mother added.
es_translation: —And that prevents them from behaving as effective parents —added my mother.

en: “They’re assholes,” I repeated.
vi: “Họ thúi hoắc à,” tôi nhắc lại.
tr: “Gerçekten götler,” diye tekrar ettim.
es: —Son gilipollas —repetí.
vi_translation: “They stink,” I repeated.
tr_translation: “They are really assholes,” I repeated.
es_translation: —They are idiots —I repeated.

en: “Honestly,” my dad said, “they’re probably right. She probably is in need of attention. And God knows, I would need attention, too, if I had those two for parents.”
vi: “Thành thật mà nói,” bố tiếp, “có thể họ có lí. Có thể Margo cần mọi người chú ý đến mình. Và có Chúa biết, bố cũng cần mọi người chú ý đến mình nếu hai vị đó là phụ huynh của bố.”
tr: “Aslına bakarsan,” dedi babam, “muhtemelen haklılar. Margo büyük ihtimalle ilgiye muhtaç. Ve Tanrı biliyor, bu ikisi benim ebeveynlerim olsaydı benim de ilgiye ihtiyacım olurdu.
es: —Para ser sincero —dijo mi padre—, seguramente tienen razón. Seguramente Margo necesita atención. Y Dios sabe que también yo necesitaría atención si esos dos fueran mis padres.
vi_translation: “To be honest,” Dad continued, “maybe they have a point. Maybe Margo needs everyone to pay attention to her. And God knows, I would need everyone to pay attention to me if those two were my parents.”
tr_translation: “If you ask me,” said my father, “they're probably right. Margo is most likely in need of attention. And God knows, if these two were my parents, I would need attention too.”
es_translation: —To be honest —said my father—, they are probably right. Margo probably needs attention. And God knows I would need attention too if those two were my parents.

en: “When she comes back,” my mom said, “she’s going to be devastated. To be abandoned like that! Shut out when you most need to be loved.”
vi: “Khi nào Margo về,” mẹ nói, “cô bé sẽ thấy kiệt quệ lắm. Bị bỏ mặc như vậy! Bị đẩy đi trong khi cần được yêu thương nhất.”
tr: “Margo döndüğünde,” dedi annem, “harap olacak. Bu şekilde terk edilmek!.. En çok sevilmeye ihtiyacm olduğunda dışarıda bırakılmak...
es: —Cuando vuelva se quedará destrozada —comentó mi madre—. Que te abandonen así… Rechazada cuando más cariño necesitas.
vi_translation: “When Margo comes back,” mother said, “she will be exhausted. Being abandoned like that! Being pushed away when she needed love the most.”
tr_translation: “When Margo returns,” said my mother, “she will be devastated. To be abandoned like this!.. To be left out when she needs to be loved the most...”
es_translation: —When she comes back, she will be devastated —commented my mother—. To be abandoned like that… Rejected when you need affection the most.

en: “Maybe she could live here when she comes back,” I said, and in saying it I realized what a fantastically great idea it was. My mom’s eyes lit up, too, but then she saw something in my dad’s expression and answered me in her usual measured way.
vi: “Khi nào về, có khi Margo cứ ở luôn đây,” tôi nói, và khi thốt ra những lời ấy, tôi thấy đó quả là một ý tưởng vĩ đại tuyệt vời. Mẹ tôi hơi nhướn mắt, nhưng ngay lập tức mẹ đọc được gì đó trên nét mặt bố, nên mẹ trả lời tôi bằng giọng chừng mực thường ngày.
tr: “Belki geldiğinde burada yaşayabilir,” dedim ve söylerken bunun ne kadar şahane bir fikir olduğunu fark ettim. Annemin de gözleri aydınlandı ama sonra babamın ifadesinde bir şey gördü ve bana her zamanki ölçülü tavrıyla cevap verdi.
es: —Quizá podría vivir aquí cuando vuelva —dije. Y al decirlo me di cuenta de que era una idea absolutamente genial. A mi madre también le brillaron los ojos, pero luego vio algo en la expresión de mi padre y me contestó con su habitual moderación.
vi_translation: "When you come back, maybe Margo should just stay here," I said, and as I uttered those words, I realized it was indeed a brilliant idea. My mother raised her eyebrows slightly, but she immediately read something on my father's face, so she responded to me in her usual measured tone.
tr_translation: “Maybe she can live here when she arrives,” I said, and as I spoke, I realized what a wonderful idea it was. My mother's eyes lit up too, but then she saw something in my father's expression and responded to me with her usual measured demeanor.
es_translation: —Maybe I could live here when I come back —I said. And when I said it, I realized that it was an absolutely brilliant idea. My mother's eyes also sparkled, but then she saw something in my father's expression and replied to me with her usual restraint.

en: “Well, she’d certainly be welcome, although that would come with its own challenges—being next door to the Spiegelmans. But when she returns to school, please do tell her that she’s welcome here, and that if she doesn’t want to stay with us, there are many resources available to her that we’re happy to discuss.”
vi: “Ừm, chắc chắn là chúng ta chào đón Margo, dù như vậy cũng có phần khó xử–chúng ta là hàng xóm với nhà Spiegelman. Nhưng khi nào Margo quay lại trường, con hãy bảo bạn ấy là chúng ta hoan nghênh Margo đến đây. Nếu Margo không muốn ở nhà mình, thì vẫn có rất nhiều nơi khác thích hợp để chúng ta thoải mái tính đến.”
tr: “Şey, isterse gelebilir ancak bu durumun da bazı sıkıntıları var... Spiegelman’larm bitişiğinde olmak gibi. Ama okula döndüğünde, lütfen ona onu buraya davet ettiğimizi ve bizimle kalmak istemezse üstünde konuşmaktan mutlu olacağımız birçok seçeneği olduğunu söyle.
es: —Bueno, sin duda sería bienvenida, aunque tendría sus inconvenientes…: vivir al lado de los Spiegelman. Pero cuando vuelva al instituto, dile que aquí es bienvenida, por favor, y si no quiere quedarse con nosotros, hay muchas otras soluciones que nos encantaría comentar con ella.
vi_translation: “Um, we certainly welcome Margo, though it is somewhat awkward—we are neighbors with the Spiegelmans. But when Margo returns to school, tell her that we welcome her to come here. If Margo doesn't want to stay at our house, there are still plenty of other suitable places we can comfortably consider.”
tr_translation: “Well, she can come if she wants, but there are some issues with this situation... Like being next to the Spiegelmans. But when she returns to school, please tell her that we invited her here and that if she doesn't want to stay with us, we would be happy to discuss many other options.”
es_translation: —Well, it would certainly be welcome, although it would have its inconveniences…: living next to the Spiegelmans. But when she returns to the institute, please tell her that she is welcome here, and if she doesn't want to stay with us, there are many other solutions we would love to discuss with her.

en: Ben came out then, his bedhead seeming to challenge our basic understanding of the force gravity exerts upon matter. “Mr. and Mrs. Jacobsen—always a pleasure.”
vi: Lúc đó Ben đi ra, cái đầu tổ quạ của nó như thách thức mọi hiểu biết cơ bản về tác động của trọng lực lên vật chất. “Cháu chào cô chú Jacobsen–luôn hân hạnh được gặp cô chú ạ.”
tr: O sırada Ben geldi, saçlarının yataktan yeni kalkmışkenki hali yer çekimi kuvveti anlayışımıza meydan okur gibiydi. “Bay ve Bayan Jacobsen... sizi görmek ne güzel.
es: En aquel momento apareció Ben con el pelo tan enmarañado que parecía desafiar nuestros conocimientos básicos sobre el efecto de la fuerza de gravedad sobre la materia. —Señor y señora Jacobsen, encantado de verlos, como siempre.
vi_translation: At that moment, Ben walked out, his messy hair defying all basic understanding of gravity's effect on matter. "Hello Mr. and Mrs. Jacobsen—always a pleasure to see you."
tr_translation: At that moment, Ben arrived, his hair in a state that seemed to defy our understanding of gravity, as if he had just gotten out of bed. “Mr. and Mrs. Jacobsen... it's so nice to see you.”
es_translation: At that moment, Ben appeared with his hair so tangled that it seemed to defy our basic understanding of the effect of gravity on matter. —Mr. and Mrs. Jacobsen, delighted to see you, as always.

en: “Good morning, Ben. I wasn’t aware you were staying the night.”
vi: “Chào cháu, Ben. Cô chú không biết là cháu ở lại qua đêm đấy.”
tr: “Günaydın, Ben. Gece kaldığının farkında değildim.
es: —Buenos días, Ben. No sabía que te habías quedado a dormir.
vi_translation: "Hello, Ben. We didn't know you were staying overnight."
tr_translation: "Good morning, Ben. I didn't realize you stayed the night."
es_translation: —Good morning, Ben. I didn't know you had stayed the night.

en: “Neither was I, actually,” he said. “What’s wrong?”
vi: “Thực ra chính cháu cũng không biết sao lại như vậy,” Ben nói. “Vừa có chuyện gì thế ạ?”
tr: “Ben de değildim aslında,” dedi. “Bir sorun mu var?
es: —La verdad es que yo tampoco —dijo Ben—. ¿Sucede algo?
vi_translation: "Actually, I don't know why either," Ben said. "What just happened?"
tr_translation: "I wasn't either, actually," he said. "Is there a problem?"
es_translation: —The truth is that I don't either —said Ben—. Is something wrong?

en: I told Ben about the detective and the Spiegelmans and Margo being technically a missing adult. And when I had finished, he nodded and said, “We should probably discuss this over a piping hot plate of Resurrection.” I smiled and followed him back to my room. Radar came over shortly thereafter, and as soon as he arrived, I was kicked off the team, because we were facing a difficult mission and despite being the only one of us who actually owned the game, I wasn’t very good at Resurrection. As I watched them tramp through a ghoul-infested space station, Ben said, “Goblin, Radar, goblin.”
vi: Tôi kể cho Ben nghe về bác thám tử và vợ chồng Spiegelman, và rằng về lí mà nói, Margo là một người trưởng thành bị mất tích. Khi tôi kết thúc, Ben gật đầu nói, “Ta nên bàn chuyện này bên một đĩa Hồi Sinh nóng sốt.” Tôi cười và theo nó quay lại phòng tôi. Không lâu sau Radar đến, ngay khi ấy tôi bị đá khỏi đội, vì tụi tôi đang chơi đến đoạn khó, và bất chấp thực tế rằng tôi là đứa duy nhất trong cả ba sở hữu trò chơi này, trình độ chơi Hồi Sinh của tôi chỉ ở hạng làng nhàng thôi. Tôi theo dõi hai thằng uỳnh uỳnh lao qua một trạm không gian nhung nhúc những gã ăn thịt người gớm ghiếc. Ben choe chóe, “Quỉ lùn kìa, Radar, quỉ lùn.”
tr: Ben’e dedektifi, Spiegelman’ları ve Margo’nun teknik olarak kayıp bir yetişkin olmasını anlattım. Bitirdiğimde başını salladı ve “Bunu muhtemelen dumanı üstünde bir tabak Diriliş sırasında tartışmalıyız,” dedi. Gülümseyip onu tekrar odama kadar takip ettim. Kısa süre sonra Radar geldi ve o gelir gelmez takımdan atıldım, çünkü zor bir görevle karşı karşıyaydık ve aslında aramızda oyuna sahip tek kişi olmama rağmen, Diriliş’te pek iyi değildim. Ben onların hortlaklar tarafından istila edilmiş bir uzay istasyonunda gezinmelerini izlerken, Ben, “Goblin, Radar, goblin,” dedi. “Görüyorum.
es: Le conté a Ben lo del detective, los Spiegelman y Margo, que técnicamente era una persona adulta desaparecida. Cuando terminé, asintió y dijo: —Seguramente tendríamos que hablarlo ante un plato bien caliente de Resurrection. Sonreí y volví con él a mi habitación. Radar se pasó por mi casa poco después, y en cuanto llegó, me echaron del equipo, porque nos enfrentábamos a una misión difícil y, aunque era el único de los tres que tenía el juego, no era demasiado bueno en el Resurrection. Estaba observándolos avanzar por una estación espacial atestada de demonios cuando Ben dijo: —Un duende, Radar, un duende.
vi_translation: I told Ben about the detective and the Spiegelman couple, and that technically, Margo was a missing adult. When I finished, Ben nodded and said, “We should discuss this over a hot plate of Resurrection.” I laughed and followed him back to my room. Not long after, Radar arrived, and right then I was kicked off the team, because we were playing a difficult part, and despite the fact that I was the only one among the three of us who owned the game, my Resurrection skills were just average. I watched the two of them crash through a space station swarming with hideous cannibals. Ben yelled, “Dwarves, Radar, dwarves.”
tr_translation: I told Ben about the detective, the Spiegelmans, and how Margo was technically a missing adult. When I finished, he nodded and said, "We should probably discuss this over a hot plate of Resurrection." I smiled and followed him back to my room. Shortly after, Radar arrived, and as soon as he did, I was kicked off the team because we were facing a tough mission, and even though I was actually the only one among us who owned the game, I wasn't very good at Resurrection. As I watched them navigate a zombie-infested space station, Ben said, "Goblin, Radar, goblin." "I see."
es_translation: I told Ben about the detective, the Spiegelmans, and Margo, who was technically a missing adult. When I finished, he nodded and said: —Surely we would have to discuss it over a steaming plate of Resurrection. I smiled and went back with him to my room. Radar came by my house shortly after, and as soon as he arrived, they kicked me off the team because we were facing a difficult mission and, although I was the only one of the three who had the game, I wasn't very good at Resurrection. I was watching them advance through a space station crowded with demons when Ben said: —A goblin, Radar, a goblin.

en: “Come here, you little bastard,” Ben said, the controller twisting in his hand. “Daddy’s gonna put you on a sailboat across the River Styx.”
vi: “Lại đây nào đồ thấp bé nhẹ cân,” Ben xoay bảng điều khiển trong tay. “Bố sẽ bứng mày lên thuyền cho chu du trên sông Styx.”
tr: “Gel buraya seni küçük serseri,” dedi Ben, elinde gamepad’i çevirirken. “Babacık seni Styks Nehrinde7 bir yelkenliye koyacak.”
es: —Ven aquí, hijo de puta —dijo Ben girando los mandos—. Papá va a meterte en un barco para que cruces el río Estigia.
vi_translation: “Come here, you little lightweight,” Ben turned the control panel in his hand. “Daddy will lift you onto the boat for a trip on the River Styx.”
tr_translation: "Come here, you little rascal," said Ben, twirling the gamepad in his hand. "Daddy is going to put you on a sailboat on the River Styx."
es_translation: —Come here, son of a bitch —said Ben, turning the controls—. Daddy is going to put you on a boat to cross the River Styx.

en: “Did you just use Greek mythology to talk trash?” I asked.
vi: “Ông chỉ trích dẫn thần thoại Hi Lạp cho những trò bông phèng thế này thôi à?” tôi hỏi.
tr: “Az önce tahrik edici konuşmanda Yunan mitolojisini mi kullandın?
es: —¿Acabas de recurrir a la mitología griega para fanfarronear? —le pregunté.
vi_translation: “You only cite Greek mythology for such trivial matters?” I asked.
tr_translation: "Did you just use Greek mythology in your provocative speech?"
es_translation: —Did you just resort to Greek mythology to show off? —I asked him.

en: Radar laughed. Ben started pummeling buttons, shouting, “Eat it, goblin! Eat it like Zeus ate Metis!”
vi: Radar cười khoái chí. Ben bắt đầu cuồng đấm nút điều khiển, la lối tùm lum, “Xực nó đi, quỉ lùn! Như thần Zeus xực Metis đó!”
tr: Radar güldü. Ben düğmelere vurmaya ve bağırmaya başladı: ‘Ye bunu, goblin! Zeus’un Metis’i yediği gibi ye bunu!
es: Radar se rió. Ben empezó a aporrear botones y a gritar. —¡Cómete esa, duende! ¡Cómetela como Zeus se comió a Metis!
vi_translation: Radar laughed with delight. Ben started frantically punching the control buttons, shouting all over the place, "Smash it, you little devil! Like Zeus smashed Metis!"
tr_translation: Radar laughed. I started hitting the buttons and shouting: 'Eat this, goblin! Eat this like Zeus ate Metis!'"
es_translation: Radar laughed. Ben started pounding buttons and shouting. —Eat that, elf! Eat it like Zeus ate Metis!

en: “I would think that she’d be back by Monday,” I said. “You don’t want to miss too much school, even if you’re Margo Roth Spiegelman. Maybe she can stay here till graduation.”
vi: “Tôi nghĩ có lẽ đến thứ Hai Margo sẽ về,” tôi nói. “Có ai muốn nghỉ học vô độ đâu, dù là Margo Roth Spiegelman đi nữa. Có lẽ cậu ấy có thể ở đây cho đến lúc tốt nghiệp.”
tr: “Pazartesiye kadar dönmüş olacağını düşünüyorum,” dedim. “Dersleri fazla ekmek istemezsin, Margo Roth Spiegelman olsan bile. Belki mezuniyete kadar burada kalabilir.
es: —Diría que volverá el lunes —comenté—. Ni siquiera a Margo Roth Spiegelman le interesa perder muchas clases. Quizá se quede aquí hasta la graduación.
vi_translation: “I think maybe Margo will be back by Monday,” I said. “No one wants to skip school indefinitely, not even Margo Roth Spiegelman. Maybe she can stay here until graduation.”
tr_translation: “I think you will have returned by Monday,” I said. “You wouldn't want to skip too many classes, even if you were Margo Roth Spiegelman. Maybe you could stay here until graduation.”
es_translation: —I would say she will be back on Monday —I commented—. Not even Margo Roth Spiegelman is interested in missing too many classes. Maybe she will stay here until graduation.

en: Radar answered me in the disjointed way of someone playing Resurrection. “I don’t even get why she left, was it just imp six o’clock no dude use the ray gun like because of lost love? I would have figured her to be where is the crypt is it to the left immune to that kind of stuff.”
vi: Radar trả lời tôi một cách khá phân tâm vì vẫn đang chơi Hồi Sinh. “Tôi thậm chí không hiểu sao Margo lại bỏ đi, có phải chỉ yêu tinh ở hướng sáu giờ không dùng súng ánh sáng đi ông vì thiếu thốn tình cảm thôi không? Tôi cứ tưởng Margo đã hầm mộ ở đâu có phải bên trái không miễn dịch với những thứ đại loại thế rồi chứ?”
tr: Radar, Diriliş oynayan birinin hayattan kopmuş haliyle bana cevap verdi. “Neden gittiğini bile anlamıyorum, sebebi sadece cüce saat altı yönünde dostum ışın tabancanı kullan, kaybettiği aşkı yüzünden falan mı? Onun bu tür şeylere mahzen nerede solda mı duyarsız olduğunu düşünürdüm.
es: Radar me contestó como contestaría cualquiera que estuviera jugando al Resurrection, de forma inconexa. —Todavía no entiendo por qué se ha marchado, ¿solo porque demonio delante no tío con la pistola de rayos se ha quedado sin novio? Pensaba que era más dónde está la cueva a la izquierda inmune a estas cosas.
vi_translation: Radar answered me somewhat distractedly because he was still playing Resurrection. "I don't even understand why Margo left, is it just that the goblin at six o'clock doesn't use the light gun because of a lack of affection?" "I thought Margo had already entombed somewhere, isn't it to the left, immune to things like that?"
tr_translation: Radar, someone playing Resurrection, responded to me in a way that seemed disconnected from life. “I don't even understand why he left, is the reason just because of the dwarf at six o'clock, buddy use your ray gun, because of the love he lost or something? I used to think he was indifferent to these kinds of things, where's the cellar, on the left?”
es_translation: Radar answered me as anyone would who was playing Resurrection, incoherently. —I still don't understand why she left, just because demon in front not uncle with the ray gun has been left without a boyfriend? I thought she was more where is the cave to the left immune to these things.

en: “No,” I said. “It wasn’t that, I don’t think. Not just that, anyway. She kind of hates Orlando; she called it a paper town. Like, you know, everything so fake and flimsy. I think she just wanted a vacation from that.”
vi: “Không,” tôi nói. “Không phải như vậy, tôi không nghĩ như ông. Dù gì cũng không chỉ có vậy. Hình như Margo ghét Orlando; cậu ấy gọi nơi này là một thành phố giấy. Kiểu như, ông biết đấy, cái gì cũng hàng mã, rởm đời và oặt ẹo. Tôi nghĩ cậu ấy chỉ muốn một kì nghỉ để tránh xa tất cả.”
tr: “Hayır,” dedim. “O yüzden olduğunu sanmıyorum. Sadece o yüzden değildi en azından. Orlando’dan nefret ediyor, buraya kâğıttan kent dedi. Yani hani her şey çok sahte ve dayanıksız diye. Sanırım sadece bu durumdan kurtulup bir tatil yapmak istedi. 7 Yunan mitolojisinde ölülerin ruhlarını yer altına taşıyan nehir, (ç. n)
es: —No —le dije—, no ha sido eso, no creo. O no solo eso. Odia Orlando. Dijo que es una ciudad de papel. Ya sabes, todo tan falso y poco sólido. Creo que sencillamente quería tomarse unas vacaciones.
vi_translation: "No," I said. "It's not like that, I don't think like you." Anyway, it's not just that. It seems like Margo hates Orlando; she calls this place a paper town. Like, you know, everything is fake, shoddy, and flimsy. I think she just wants a vacation to get away from it all."
tr_translation: “No,” I said. “I don't think that's the reason. At least, it wasn't just because of that. He hates Orlando, he called this place a paper town. Meaning, like, everything is very fake and flimsy. I think he just wanted to escape this situation and take a vacation.” 7 In Greek mythology, the river that carries the souls of the dead to the underworld, (abbr. n)
es_translation: —No —I said to him—, it wasn't that, I don't think. Or not just that. He hates Orlando. He said it's a paper town. You know, everything so fake and insubstantial. I think he simply wanted to take a vacation.

en: I happened to glance out my window, and I saw immediately that someone—the detective, I guessed—had lowered the shade in Margo’s room. But I wasn’t seeing the shade. Instead, I was seeing a black-and-white poster, taped to the back of the shade. In the photograph, a man stands, his shoulders slightly slumped, staring ahead. A cigarette dangles out of his mouth. A guitar is slung over his shoulder, and the guitar is painted with the words THIS MACHINE KILLS FASCISTS.
vi: Bất chợt tôi liếc ra cửa sổ, và lập tức tôi nhận thấy ai đó–có thể là bác thám tử–đã hạ rèm cửa sổ phòng Margo xuống. Nhưng tôi không nhìn tấm rèm. Thay vào đó, tôi đang nhìn vào một tấm áp-phích đen trắng, đính trên mặt sau tấm rèm. Trong hình, một người đàn ông đứng, vai hơi so, mắt nhìn thẳng phía trước, môi cắn hờ điếu thuốc lá. Cây guitar khoác qua vai, và trên đàn có dòng chữ CHIẾC MÁY NÀY DIỆT PHÁT-XÍT.
tr: n) Pencereden dışarı baktım ve o anda birinindedektif olduğunu tahmin ediyordumMargo’nun odasındaki jaluziyi indirmiş olduğunu gördüm. Ama jaluziyi görmüyordum. Onun yerine jaluzinin arkasına bantlanmış siyahbeyaz bir poster görüyordum. Fotoğrafta, omuzları hafifçe düşük, dosdoğru karşıya bakan bir adam vardı. Ağzından bir sigara sarkıyordu. Omzuna bir gitar asılmıştı ve gitara şu kelimeler çizilmişti: BU MAKİNA FAŞİSTLERİ ÖLDÜRÜR.
es: Entonces eché un vistazo por la ventana e inmediatamente vi que alguien —supuse que el detective— había bajado la persiana de la habitación de Margo. Pero no se veía la persiana. Lo que se veía era un póster en blanco y negro pegado a la parte exterior de la persiana. Era la fotografía de un hombre, con los hombros ligeramente caídos, mirando al frente. Tenía un cigarrillo entre los labios y llevaba colgada del hombro una guitarra con una frase pintada: ESTA MÁQUINA MATA FASCISTAS.
vi_translation: Suddenly, I glanced out the window, and immediately I noticed that someone—possibly the detective—had lowered the curtain in Margo's room. But I wasn't looking at the curtain. Instead, I was looking at a black-and-white poster, pinned to the back of the curtain. In the picture, a man stood, shoulders slightly hunched, eyes looking straight ahead, lips gently holding a cigarette. The guitar slung over the shoulder, and on the instrument, there was the phrase THIS MACHINE KILLS FASCISTS.
tr_translation: I looked out the window and at that moment I was guessing someone was a detective, I saw that Margo had lowered the blinds in her room. But I couldn't see the blinds. Instead, I saw a black and white poster taped behind the blinds. In the photo, there was a man with slightly slumped shoulders, looking straight ahead. A cigarette was hanging from his mouth. A guitar was slung over his shoulder and the words "THIS MACHINE KILLS FASCISTS" were written on the guitar.
es_translation: Then I glanced out the window and immediately saw that someone —I assumed it was the detective— had lowered the blind in Margo's room. But the blind was not visible. What was visible was a black and white poster stuck to the outside of the blind. It was a photograph of a man, with slightly slumped shoulders, looking straight ahead. He had a cigarette between his lips and a guitar hanging from his shoulder with a phrase painted on it: THIS MACHINE KILLS FASCISTS.

en: “There’s something in Margo’s window.” The game music stopped, and Radar and Ben knelt down on either side of me. “That’s new?” asked Radar.
vi: “Có gì trên cửa sổ phòng Margo kìa.” Nhạc trò chơi dừng lại, Radar và Ben lổm ngổm ở hai bên cạnh tôi. “Cái đó mới hả?” Radar hỏi.
tr: “Margo’nun penceresinde bir şey var.” Oyunun müziği durdu ve Radar ile Ben yanımda diz çöktüler. ‘Yeni mi?” diye sordu Radar.
es: —Hay algo en la ventana de Margo. La música del juego se paró, y Radar y Ben se acercaron a mí y se arrodillaron uno a cada lado. —¿Es nuevo? —me preguntó Radar.
vi_translation: “There’s something on Margo’s window.” The game music stopped, and Radar and Ben crawled up on either side of me. “Is that new?” Radar asked.
tr_translation: "There is something at Margo's window." The game's music stopped, and Radar and Ben knelt down beside me. "Is it new?" asked Radar.
es_translation: —There is something at Margo's window. The game's music stopped, and Radar and Ben approached me and knelt down on either side. —Is it new? —Radar asked me.

en: “I’ve seen the back of that shade a million times,” I answered, “but I’ve never seen that poster before.”
vi: “Tôi đã thấy mặt sau tấm rèm đó cả triệu lần,” tôi đáp, “nhưng chưa từng thấy tấm áp-phích đó.”
tr: “O jaluziyi milyonlarca kez görmüşümdür,” diye cevapladım, “ama o posteri daha önce hiç görmedim.
es: —He visto esa persiana por fuera millones de veces, pero nunca había visto ese póster —le contesté.
vi_translation: “I have seen the back of that curtain a million times,” I replied, “but I have never seen that poster.”
tr_translation: “I have seen those blinds millions of times,” I replied, “but I have never seen that poster before.”
es_translation: —I have seen that shutter from the outside millions of times, but I had never seen that poster —I replied.

en: “Weird,” Ben said.
vi: “Lạ nhỉ,” Ben nói.
tr: ‘Tuhaf,” dedi Ben.
es: —Qué raro —dijo Ben.
vi_translation: “Strange, isn't it,” Ben said.
tr_translation: “Strange,” said Ben.
es_translation: —How strange —said Ben.

en: “Margo’s parents just said this morning that she sometimes leaves clues,” I said. “But never anything, like, concrete enough to find her before she comes home.”
vi: “Sáng nay bố mẹ Margo vừa nói rằng cậu ấy thường để lại những manh mối,” tôi nói. “Nhưng chưa bao giờ có manh mối nào đủ chắc chắn để tìm được Margo trước khi cậu ấy tự về.”
tr: ‘Margo’nun annesiyle babası daha bu sabah onun bazen ipuçları bıraktığım söyledi,” dedim. “Ama asla eve dönmesinden önce onu bulabilecekleri kadar, ne bileyim, somut bir şey değilmiş.
es: —Los padres de Margo han dicho esta mañana que a veces deja pistas —dije yo—. Pero nunca algo lo bastante concreto como para encontrarla antes de que vuelva a casa.
vi_translation: "This morning Margo's parents just said that she often leaves clues," I said. "But there has never been a clue solid enough to find Margo before she comes back on her own."
tr_translation: “Margo's parents said just this morning that sometimes she leaves clues,” I said. “But never anything, I don't know, concrete enough for them to find her before she comes home.”
es_translation: —Margo's parents said this morning that sometimes she leaves clues —I said—. But never anything concrete enough to find her before she comes back home.

en: Radar already had his handheld out; he was searching Omnictionary for the phrase. “The picture’s of Woody Guthrie,” he said. “A folksinger, 1912 to 1967. Sang about the working class. ‘This Land Is Your Land.’ Bit of a Communist. Um, inspired Bob Dylan.” Radar played a snippet of one of his songs—a high-pitched scratchy voice sang about unions.
vi: Radar rút ngay máy tính cầm tay ra, nó vào Toàn Thư Đủ Thứ tra cụm từ trên cây đàn. “Bức hình đó là Woody Guthrie,” nó nói. “Ca sĩ dòng nhạc đồng quê, sinh năm 1912, mất năm 1967. Hát về tầng lớp lao động, ‘Đất này là đất của anh.’ Hơi mang tư tưởng cộng sản chủ nghĩa. Ừm, là nguồn cảm hứng của Bob Dylan.” Radar bật trích đoạn một trong các bài hát của ông ấy–một giọng găn gắt tông cao, hát về các hội đoàn.
tr: Radar çoktan cep bilgisayarını çıkarmış, Omnictionary’de o cümleyi araştırıyordu. “Fotoğraftaki Woody Guthrie,” dedi. “Folk müzik şarkıcısı, 19121967 yıllarında yaşamış. İşçi sınıfıyla ilgili şarkılar söylemiş. This Land Is Your Land. Biraz Komünist. Hımm, Bob Dylan’a ilham vermiş.” Radar şarkılarından birinin bir kısmını çaldı... çok tiz, cızırtılı bir ses sendikalarla ilgili bir şarkı söylüyordu.
es: Radar ya había sacado su ordenador de bolsillo y estaba buscando la frase en el Omnictionary. —La foto es de Woody Guthrie —comentó—. Cantante de folk, 1912-1967. Todas sus letras hablaban de la clase obrera. «This Land Is Your Land». Tirando a comunista. Inspiró a Bob Dylan. Radar reprodujo un trozo de una canción suya, una voz aguda y chirriante cantando sobre sindicatos.
vi_translation: Radar immediately took out his handheld computer and looked up the phrase on the guitar in the Encyclopedia of Everything. “That picture is of Woody Guthrie,” he said. “A country music singer, born in 1912, died in 1967. Sang about the working class, ‘This Land Is Your Land.’ Somewhat communist-leaning. Yeah, he was an inspiration to Bob Dylan.” Radar played a snippet of one of his songs—a high-pitched, gritty voice singing about unions.
tr_translation: Radar had already taken out his pocket computer and was researching that sentence on Omnictionary. “The guy in the photo is Woody Guthrie,” he said. “A folk music singer, lived from 1912 to 1967. He sang songs about the working class. This Land Is Your Land. A bit of a Communist. Hmm, he inspired Bob Dylan.” Radar played a part of one of his songs... a very high-pitched, crackling voice was singing a song about unions.
es_translation: Radar had already taken out his pocket computer and was looking up the phrase in the Omnictionary. —The photo is of Woody Guthrie —he commented—. Folk singer, 1912-1967. All his lyrics spoke about the working class. «This Land Is Your Land». Leaning towards communist. Inspired Bob Dylan. Radar reproduced a snippet of one of his songs, a high-pitched and squeaky voice singing about unions.

en: “I’ll email the guy who wrote most of this page and see if there are any obvious connections between Woody Guthrie and Margo,” Radar said.
