vi: “Tôi sẽ e-mail cho người viết phần lớn trang này để xem có liên quan cụ thể gì giữa Woody Guthrie và Margo không,” Radar nói.
tr: “Bu sayfanın çoğunu yazan çocuğa bir eposta atıp Margo ile Woody Guthrie arasında belirgin bir bağlantı olup olmadığına bakacağım,” dedi Radar.
es: Radar reprodujo un trozo de una canción suya, una voz aguda y chirriante cantando sobre sindicatos. —Mandaré un correo al tipo que ha escrito casi toda esta página para ver si hay alguna relación entre Woody Guthrie y Margo —dijo Radar.
vi_translation: “I will email the person who wrote most of this page to see if there is any specific connection between Woody Guthrie and Margo,” Radar said.
tr_translation: "I will send an email to the kid who wrote most of this page and see if there is a clear connection between Margo and Woody Guthrie," said Radar.
es_translation: —I will send an email to the guy who has written almost all of this page to see if there is any connection between Woody Guthrie and Margo —said Radar.

en: “I can’t imagine she likes his songs,” I said.
vi: “Không thể tưởng tượng được là Margo lại thích những bài hát của ông ấy,” tôi nói.
tr: “Onun şarkılarını sevdiğini hayal bile edemiyorum,” dedim.
es: —Me cuesta imaginar que le gusten sus canciones —añadí.
vi_translation: “I can't imagine that Margo likes his songs,” I said.
tr_translation: "I can't even imagine that you like his songs," I said.
es_translation: —I find it hard to imagine that he likes his songs —I added.

en: “Seriously,” Ben said. “This guy sounds like an alcoholic Kermit the Frog with throat cancer.”
vi: “Nói nghiêm túc chứ,” Ben nhận định, “ông ấy hát nghe như Ếch Kermit đang chìm trong men say và bị ung thư họng.
tr: “Cidden,” dedi Ben. “Bu adamın sesi gırtlak kanserine yakalanmış, alkolik Kurbağa Kermit gibi geliyor.
es: —Cierto —admitió Ben—. Este tipo parece la rana Gustavo alcohólica y con cáncer de garganta.
vi_translation: “Seriously,” Ben remarked, “he sings like Kermit the Frog drowning in booze and suffering from throat cancer.”
tr_translation: “Seriously,” said Ben. “This guy's voice sounds like an alcoholic Kermit the Frog who has throat cancer.”
es_translation: —True —admitted Ben—. This guy looks like an alcoholic Kermit the Frog with throat cancer.

en: Radar opened the window and stuck his head out, swiveling it around. “It sure seems she left this for you, though, Q. I mean, does she know anyone else who could see this window?” I shook my head no.
vi: Radar mở cửa sổ, thò đầu ra ngoài, quay qua quay lại. “Nhưng chắc như ăn bắp là Margo để ám hiệu lại cho ông đấy Q. Thì đó, Margo có biết ai khác có thể nhìn thấy góc cửa sổ ấy không?” Tôi lắc đầu.
tr: Radar pencereyi açıp başım dışarı uzattı. “Kesinlikle bunu senin için bırakmış gibi görünüyor, Q. Yani, bu pencereyi görebilecek başka birini tanıyor mu?” Hayır anlamında başımı salladım.
es: Radar abrió la ventana, asomó la cabeza y miró en todas direcciones. —Pues parece que ha dejado la pista para ti, Q. Vaya, ¿conoce a alguien más que pueda ver esa ventana? Negué con la cabeza.
vi_translation: Radar opened the window, stuck his head out, and looked around. "But it's as sure as corn that Margo left a signal for you, Q." "Well, does Margo know anyone else who could see that corner of the window?" I shook my head.
tr_translation: Radar opened the window and stuck his head out. “It definitely looks like he left this for you, Q. I mean, does he know anyone else who can see this window?” I shook my head to mean no.
es_translation: Radar opened the window, stuck his head out, and looked in all directions. —Well, it looks like he left the clue for you, Q. Wow, do you know anyone else who can see that window? I shook my head.

en: After a moment, Ben added, “The way he’s staring at us—it’s like, ‘pay attention to me.’ And his head like that, you know? It’s not like he’s standing on a stage; it’s like he’s standing in a doorway or something.”
vi: Chốc sau, Ben nói thêm, “Cái cách ông ấy chằm chằm nhìn tụi mình–như kiểu ‘hãy chú ý đến tôi’. Và cái đầu của ông ấy như vậy, các ông thấy chứ? Không giống như ca sĩ đứng trên sân khấu, mà như ông ấy đang đứng trước ngưỡng cửa nào đó vậy.”
tr: Bir an sonra Ben ekledi: “Adamın bize bakış şekli... şey gibi, ‘dikkatinizi bana verin.’ Kafası şey gibi hani... Sahnede duruyormuş gibi değil de bir kapı eşiğinde falan duruyormuş gibi.
es: Al rato Ben añadió: —Nos mira de una manera… Como si dijera: «Prestadme atención». Y la cabeza así… No parece estar en un escenario. Parece estar en una puerta o algo así.
vi_translation: A moment later, Ben added, "The way he stared at us–like 'pay attention to me.' And his head like that, did you see? Not like a singer on stage, but as if he were standing at some kind of threshold."
tr_translation: A moment later Ben added: "The way the man looks at us... like, 'give me your attention.' His head is like, you know... Not like he's standing on stage but like he's standing in a doorway or something."
es_translation: After a while, Ben added: —He looks at us in a way... As if saying: "Pay attention to me." And his head like this... It doesn't seem like he's on a stage. It seems like he's at a door or something like that.

en: “I think he wants us to come inside,” I said.
vi: “Tôi nghĩ ông ấy muốn tụi mình vào trong,” tôi nói.
tr: “Sanırım, içeri girmemizi istiyor,” dedim.
es: —Creo que quiere que entremos —dije.
vi_translation: “I think he wants us to go inside,” I said.
tr_translation: “I think he wants us to go inside,” I said.
es_translation: —I think he wants us to go in —I said.

en: We didn’t have a view of the front door or the garage from my bedroom: for that, we needed to sit in the family room. So while Ben continued playing Resurrection, Radar and I went out to the family room and pretended to watch TV while keeping watch on the Spiegelmans’ front door through a picture window, waiting for Margo’s mom and dad to leave. Detective Warren’s black Crown Victoria was still in the driveway.
vi: Từ phòng tôi đều không nhìn được ra hướng cửa chính hoặc ga-ra, do vậy chúng tôi cần ngồi trong phòng khách. Ben vẫn tiếp tục cày Hồi Sinh, Radar và tôi ra phòng khách giả vờ xem ti-vi trong khi không ngừng phóng mắt qua cửa sổ, theo sát tình hình cửa chính nhà Spiegelman, phục thời điểm bố mẹ Margo ra ngoài. Chiếc Crown Victoria màu đen của thám tử Warren vẫn đỗ ở lối đi.
tr: Odamdan ön kapıyı ya da garajı göremediğimiz için salonda oturmamız gerekiyordu. Böylece Ben, Diriliş oynamaya devam ederken Radar’la çıkıp salona gittik ve büyük pencereden Spiegelman’lann ön kapışım izlemeye devam ederek Margo’nun annesiyle babasının evi terk etmelerini bekleyerek televizyon izliyormuş gibi yaptık. Dedektif Warren’ın siyah Ford Crown Victoria’sı hâlâ garaj yolundaydı.
es: Desde mi habitación no se veía la puerta de la calle ni el garaje. Para verlos teníamos que ir a la sala de estar. De modo que, mientras Ben seguía jugando al Resurrection, Radar y yo fuimos a la sala y fingimos ver la tele mientras vigilábamos la puerta de los Spiegelman a través de un ventanal, esperando a que los padres de Margo salieran. El Crown Victoria negro del detective Warren todavía estaba frente a la casa.
vi_translation: From my room, I couldn't see the front door or the garage, so we needed to sit in the living room. Ben continued grinding Resurrection, while Radar and I went to the living room pretending to watch TV, constantly glancing out the window, keeping an eye on the Spiegelmans' front door, waiting for the moment Margo's parents went out. Detective Warren's black Crown Victoria was still parked in the driveway.
tr_translation: Since we couldn't see the front door or the garage from my room, we had to sit in the living room. So Ben, while continuing to play Resurrection, and I went out with Radar to the living room and pretended to watch TV, watching the Spiegelmans' front door through the big window, waiting for Margo's parents to leave the house. Detective Warren's black Ford Crown Victoria was still in the driveway.
es_translation: From my room, you couldn't see the front door or the garage. To see them, we had to go to the living room. So, while Ben kept playing Resurrection, Radar and I went to the living room and pretended to watch TV while keeping an eye on the Spiegelmans' door through a large window, waiting for Margo's parents to leave. Detective Warren's black Crown Victoria was still parked in front of the house.

en: He left after about fifteen minutes, but neither the garage door nor the front door opened again for an hour. Radar and I were watching some half-funny stoner comedy on HBO, and I had started to get into the story when Radar said, “Garage door.” I jumped off the couch and got close to the window so that I could see clearly who was in the car. Both Mr. and Mrs. Spiegelman. Ruthie was still at home. “Ben!” I shouted. He was out in a flash, and as the Spiegelmans turned off Jefferson Way and onto Jefferson Road, we raced outside into the muggy morning.
vi: Được khoảng mười lăm phút, bác thám tử rời đi, nhưng suốt một tiếng sau cả cửa ga-ra lẫn cửa chính đều đóng im ỉm. Radar và tôi đang xem một phim hài khá vui trên kênh HBO, tôi bắt đầu khoái mạch phim thì Radar nói, “Cửa ga-ra.” Tôi bật khỏi xô-pha, đến sát cửa sổ xem ai ở trong xe. Cả cô và chú Spiegelman. Ruthie vẫn ở nhà. “Ben ơi!” tôi gọi lớn. Nó lập tức xẹt ra như một tia chớp. Khi cô chú Spiegelman rẽ khỏi Jefferson Way vào Jefferson Road, chúng tôi rời nhà, lao vào bầu không khí nóng ẩm bên ngoài.
tr: Yaklaşık on beş dakika sonra dedektif gitti ama ne garaj kapısı ne de ön kapı bir saat boyunca tekrar açıldı. Radar’la HBO’da yarıeğlenceli bir esrar konulu komedi izliyorduk, Radar, “Garaj kapısı,” dediğinde hikâyeye kaptırmaya başlamıştım. Koltuktan atlayıp arabada kim olduğunu görmek için pencereye yaklaştım. Bay ve Bayan Spiegelman oradaydı. Ruthie hâlâ evdeydi. “Ben!” diye bağırdım. Kaşla göz arasında Ben dışarıdaydı, Spiegelman’lar Jefferson Yolu’ndan dönüp Jefferson Caddesi’ne yönelirken koşarak dışarı, sıcak ve nemli sabaha doğru çıktık.
es: Se marchó unos quince minutos después, pero durante la hora siguiente no volvió a abrirse ni la puerta de la calle ni la del garaje. Radar y yo veíamos una comedia medio graciosa de porreros en el canal HBO, y había empezado a meterme en la historia cuando Radar dijo: —La puerta del garaje. Salté del sofá y me acerqué a la ventana para ver quién iba en el coche. El señor y la señora Spiegelman. Ruthie se había quedado en casa. —¡Ben! —grité. Salió como una flecha. Mientras los Spiegelman giraban Jefferson Way para meterse en Jefferson Road, salimos corriendo a la húmeda mañana.
vi_translation: After about fifteen minutes, the detective left, but for an hour afterward, both the garage door and the front door remained tightly closed. Radar and I were watching a pretty funny comedy on HBO, I was starting to get into the movie when Radar said, "Garage door." I jumped off the sofa, went close to the window to see who was in the car. Both Mr. and Mrs. Spiegelman. Ruthie was still at home. "Ben!" I called out loudly. He immediately dashed out like a lightning bolt. When Mr. and Mrs. Spiegelman turned off Jefferson Way onto Jefferson Road, we left the house, rushing into the hot and humid outside air.
tr_translation: About fifteen minutes later, the detective left, but neither the garage door nor the front door opened again for an hour. We were watching a semi-entertaining marijuana-themed comedy on HBO with Radar when I started getting into the story, and Radar said, "Garage door." I jumped off the couch and approached the window to see who was in the car. Mr. and Mrs. Spiegelman were there. Ruthie was still at home. "Ben!" I shouted. In the blink of an eye, Ben was outside, and as the Spiegelmans turned from Jefferson Road onto Jefferson Street, we ran outside into the hot and humid morning.
es_translation: He left about fifteen minutes later, but during the next hour, neither the front door nor the garage door opened again. Radar and I were watching a somewhat funny stoner comedy on HBO, and I had started to get into the story when Radar said: —The garage door. I jumped off the couch and approached the window to see who was in the car. Mr. and Mrs. Spiegelman. Ruthie had stayed at home. —Ben! —I shouted. He shot out like an arrow. While the Spiegelmans turned onto Jefferson Way to get onto Jefferson Road, we ran out into the damp morning.

en: We walked through the Spiegelmans’ lawn to their front door. I rang the doorbell and heard Myrna Mountweazel’s paws scurrying on the hardwood floors, and then she was barking like crazy, staring at us through the sidelight glass. Ruthie opened the door. She was a sweet girl, maybe eleven.
vi: Tụi tôi qua thảm cỏ đến cửa trước nhà Spiegelman. Tôi bấm chuông và nghe thấy tiếng móng vuốt của Myrna Mountweazel cào rột rột trên sàn gỗ, rồi nó bắt đầu sủa như điên, chằm chằm nhìn tụi tôi qua dải cửa kính. Ruthie ra mở cửa. Nó là một con bé ngoan, khoảng mười một tuổi.
tr: Spiegelman’larm çimenliğinden geçerek ön kapılarına doğru yürüdük. Kapı zilini çaldım ve Myrna Mountweazel’in patilerinin parkede çıkardığı sesleri duydum, sonra deli gibi havlamaya, yan camdan gözünü dikmiş bize bakmaya başladı. Ruthie kapıyı açtı. Tatlı bir kızdı, herhalde on bir yaşındaydı.
es: Atravesamos el césped de los Spiegelman hasta la puerta. Llamé al timbre, oí las patas de Myrna Mountweazel corriendo por el suelo de madera y luego se puso a ladrar como una loca, mirándonos por el cristal lateral. Ruthie abrió la puerta. Era una niña muy dulce de unos once años.
vi_translation: We walked across the lawn to the front door of the Spiegelman house. I rang the doorbell and heard the scratching of Myrna Mountweazel's claws on the wooden floor, then it started barking like crazy, staring at us through the glass strip. Ruthie came to open the door. She was a good girl, about eleven years old.
tr_translation: We walked across Spiegelman's lawn towards their front door. I rang the doorbell and heard the sound of Myrna Mountweazel's paws on the parquet floor, then she started barking like crazy, staring at us from the side window. Ruthie opened the door. She was a sweet girl, probably around eleven years old.
es_translation: We crossed the Spiegelmans' lawn to the door. I rang the doorbell, heard Myrna Mountweazel's paws running on the wooden floor, and then she started barking like crazy, looking at us through the side glass. Ruthie opened the door. She was a very sweet girl of about eleven years old.

en: “Hey, Ruthie.”
vi: “Chào em, Ruthie.”
tr: “Hey, Ruthie.
es: —Hola, Ruthie.
vi_translation: "Hello, Ruthie."
tr_translation: "Hey, Ruthie."
es_translation: —Hello, Ruthie.

en: “Hi, Quentin,” she said.
vi: “Em chào anh Quentin,” Ruthie nói.
tr: “Selam Quentin,” dedi.
es: —Hola, Quentin —me contestó.
vi_translation: "Hello, Mr. Quentin," Ruthie said.
tr_translation: "Hello Quentin," he said.
es_translation: —Hello, Quentin —he/she replied to me.

en: “Hey, are your parents here?”
vi: “Bố mẹ có nhà không em?”
tr: “Hey, annenle baban burada mı?
es: —¿Están tus padres en casa?
vi_translation: "Are your parents home?"
tr_translation: “Hey, are your mom and dad here?”
es_translation: —Are your parents at home?

en: “They just left,” she said, “to go to Target.” She had Margo’s big eyes, but hers were hazel. She looked up at me, her lips pursed with worry. “Did you meet the policeman?”
vi: “Bố mẹ em vừa đi rồi,” nó đáp, “đến Target ạ.” Ruthie cũng có cặp mắt to như Margo, nhưng mang màu nâu ấm. Nó nhìn tôi, bặm bặm môi lo lắng. “Anh có gặp ông cảnh sát không?”
tr: “Az önce çıktılar,” dedi, “Target’a gitmek için.” Margo’nun büyük gözleri onda da vardı ama onunkiler elaydı. Başını kaldırıp bana baktı, dudakları endişeyle büzüldü. “Polis memuruyla tanıştın mı?
es: —Acaban de marcharse —me dijo—. Al Target. —Tenía los grandes ojos de Margo, pero castaños. Me miró y frunció los labios preocupada—. ¿Has visto al policía?
vi_translation: “My parents just left,” she replied, “they went to Target.” Ruthie also had big eyes like Margo, but they were a warm brown color. She looked at me, biting her lips anxiously. “Did you meet the police officer?”
tr_translation: “They just left,” he said, “to go to Target.” Margo's big eyes were in him too, but his were hazel. He lifted his head and looked at me, his lips pursed with worry. “Did you meet the police officer?”
es_translation: —They just left —he told me—. To Target. —She had Margo's big eyes, but brown. She looked at me and pursed her lips worriedly—. Have you seen the police officer?

en: “Yeah,” I said. “He seemed nice.”
vi: “Ừ, có,” tôi đáp. “Bác ấy có vẻ dễ mến.
tr: “Evet,” dedim. “İyi birine benziyordu.
es: —Sí —le contesté—. Parecía amable.
vi_translation: “Yes, there is,” I replied. “He seems nice.”
tr_translation: “Yes,” I said. “He seemed like a good person.”
es_translation: —Yes —I replied—. He seemed kind.

en: “Mom says that it’s like if Margo went to college early.”
vi: “Mẹ em bảo cứ coi như chị Margo đã đi học đại học sớm rồi.”
tr: “Annem, Margo üniversiteye erken gitmiş gibi diyor.
es: —Mi madre dice que es como si Margo hubiera ido a la universidad antes.
vi_translation: “My mom said to just consider that Margo went to college early.”
tr_translation: “My mom says it feels like Margo went to university early.”
es_translation: —My mother says it's as if Margo had gone to college earlier.

en: “Yeah,” I said, thinking that the easiest way to solve a mystery is to decide that there is no mystery to solve. But it seemed clear to me now that she had left the clues to a mystery behind.
vi: “Ừ,” tôi đáp, thầm nghĩ cách đơn giản nhất để tháo gỡ một bí ẩn là quyết định rằng không có bí ẩn nào cần tháo gỡ cả. Nhưng có lẽ đã rõ ràng rằng Margo đã để lại những manh mối dẫn đến một bí ẩn.
tr: “Evet,” dedim, bir gizemi çözmenin en kolay yolunun çözülecek bir gizem olmadığına karar vermek olduğunu düşünerek. Ama Margo’nun bir gizeme giden ipuçları bırakmış olduğu, şimdi bana net bir şekilde görünüyordu.
es: —Sí —le dije. Pensé que la mejor manera de resolver un misterio era llegar a la conclusión de que no había misterio que resolver. Pero a esas alturas tenía claro que Margo había dejado tras de sí las pistas de un misterio.
vi_translation: “Yes,” I replied, silently thinking that the simplest way to unravel a mystery is to decide that there is no mystery to unravel at all. But perhaps it was already clear that Margo had left clues leading to a mystery.
tr_translation: “Yes,” I said, thinking that the easiest way to solve a mystery is to decide that there is no mystery to solve. But it was now clear to me that Margo had left clues leading to a mystery.
es_translation: —Yes —I told him. I thought that the best way to solve a mystery was to conclude that there was no mystery to solve. But by that point, it was clear to me that Margo had left behind the clues of a mystery.

en: “Listen, Ruthie, we need to look in Margo’s room,” I said. “But the thing is—it’s like when Margo would ask you to do top-secret stuff. We’re in the same situation here.”
vi: “Anh bảo này nhé, Ruthie, bọn anh cần xem phòng Margo một chút,” tôi nói. “Nhưng vấn đề là–giống như khi Margo ủy thác nhiệm vụ tối mật cho em ấy. Bọn anh cũng ở trong tình cảnh tương tự.”
tr: “Dinle Ruthie, Margo’nun odasına bakmamız gerekiyor,” dedim. “Ama sorun şu ki... bu olay, tıpkı Margo’nun senden çok gizli şeyler yapmanı istediği zamanlar olduğu gibi. Burada biz de aynı durumdayız.
es: —Oye, Ruthie, tenemos que echar un vistazo a la habitación de Margo —le dije—. Pero el caso es… Es como cuando Margo te pedía hacer algo en secreto. La situación es la misma.
vi_translation: “Listen, Ruthie, we need to take a look at Margo's room for a bit,” I said. “But the problem is—it's like when Margo entrusted you with a top-secret mission. We're in a similar situation.”
tr_translation: “Listen Ruthie, we need to check Margo's room,” I said. “But the problem is... this situation is just like when Margo wanted you to do very secret things. We are in the same situation here.”
es_translation: —Hey, Ruthie, we need to take a look at Margo's room —I said—. But the thing is… It's like when Margo asked you to do something in secret. The situation is the same.

en: “Margo doesn’t like people in her room,” Ruthie said. “’Cept me. And sometimes Mommy.”
vi: “Chị Margo không thích người khác vào phòng chị ấy,” Ruthie nói. “Trừ em ra. Thỉnh thoảng mẹ em nữa ạ.”
tr: “Margo odasmda insanlar olmasından hoşlanmaz,” dedi Ruthie. “Ben hariç. Bazen de annem.
es: —A Margo no le gusta que entren en su habitación —me contestó Ruthie—. Menos yo. Y a veces mi madre.
vi_translation: “Sister Margo doesn't like others entering her room,” Ruthie said. "Except for me." "Sometimes my mom too."
tr_translation: “Margo doesn't like having people in her room,” said Ruthie. “Except me. Sometimes my mom too.”
es_translation: —Margo doesn't like people entering her room —Ruthie answered me—. Except for me. And sometimes my mother.

en: “But we’re her friends.”
vi: “Nhưng bọn anh là bạn của Margo mà.”
tr: “Ama biz onun arkadaşlarıyız.
es: —Pero somos amigos suyos.
vi_translation: “But we are Margo's friends.”
tr_translation: “But we are his friends.”
es_translation: —But we are his friends.

en: “She doesn’t like her friends in her room,” Ruthie said.
vi: “Chị ấy không thích cho bạn vào phòng,” Ruthie khăng khăng.
tr: “Arkadaşlarının da odasında olmasından hoşlanmaz,” dedi Ruthie.
es: —No le gusta que sus amigos entren en su habitación —insistió Ruthie.
vi_translation: “She doesn't like letting you into the room,” Ruthie insisted.
tr_translation: “She doesn't like having her friends in her room either,” said Ruthie.
es_translation: —He doesn't like his friends entering his room —insisted Ruthie.

en: I leaned down toward her. “Ruthie, please.”
vi: Tôi cúi thấp xuống gần nó. “Năn nỉ em đó.”
tr: Ona doğru eğildim. “Ruthie, lütfen.
es: Me incliné hacia ella. —Ruthie, por favor.
vi_translation: I bent down close to it. "I'm begging you."
tr_translation: I leaned towards her. “Ruthie, please.”
es_translation: I leaned towards her. —Ruthie, please.

en: “And you don’t want me to tell Mommy and Dad,” she said.
vi: “Và các anh không muốn em kể lại với bố mẹ,” con bé nói.
tr: “Ve annemle babama söylememi de istemiyorsun,” dedi.
es: —Y no quieres que se lo diga a mis padres.
vi_translation: “And you guys don't want me to tell Mom and Dad,” the little girl said.
tr_translation: “And you don't want me to tell my mom and dad either,” she said.
es_translation: —And you don't want me to tell my parents.

en: “Correct.”
vi: “Chính xác.”
tr: “Doğru.
es: —Exacto.
vi_translation: “Exactly.”
tr_translation: “Correct.”
es_translation: —Exactly.

en: “Five dollars,” she said. I was about to bargain with her, but then Radar produced a five-dollar bill and handed it to her. “If I see the car in the driveway, I’ll let you know,” she said conspiratorially.
vi: “Năm đô-la ạ,” Ruthie chốt. Tôi định mặc cả nhưng Radar đã rút một tờ năm đô-la ra đưa cho nó. “Nếu thấy có xe về, em sẽ báo với các anh,” Ruthie nói với một tinh thần thông đồng đầy cao cả.
tr: “Beş dolar,” dedi. Onunla pazarlık etmek üzereydim ama Radar beş dolarlık bir banknot çıkarıp ona uzattı. “Eğer garaj yolunda arabayı görürsem size haber veririm,” dedi Ruthie komplo kurarmış gibi.
es: —Cinco dólares —me dijo. Estuve a punto de regatear el precio, pero Radar sacó un billete de cinco dólares y se lo dio. —Si veo el coche en el camino de entrada, os avisaré —nos dijo con un tono cómplice.
vi_translation: “Five dollars,” Ruthie concluded. I was about to bargain, but Radar had already pulled out a five-dollar bill and handed it to her. “If I see any cars coming back, I'll let you know,” Ruthie said with a spirit of noble collusion.
tr_translation: “Five dollars,” he said. I was about to bargain with him, but Radar pulled out a five-dollar bill and handed it to him. “If I see the car on the driveway, I’ll let you know,” Ruthie said as if she were plotting.
es_translation: —Five dollars —he told me. I was about to haggle over the price, but Radar took out a five-dollar bill and gave it to him. —If I see the car in the driveway, I will let you know —he told us with a conspiratorial tone.

en: I knelt down to give the aging-but-always-enthusiastic Myrna Mountweazel a good petting, and then we raced upstairs to Margo’s room. As I put my hand on the doorknob, it occurred to me that I had not seen Margo’s entire room since I was about ten years old.
vi: Tôi cúi xuống vỗ nựng con Myrna Mountweazel tuổi-cao-sung-sức, rồi cả lũ kéo nhau lên gác vào phòng Margo. Khi đặt tay lên tay nắm cửa, tôi chợt nhận ra mình chưa từng vào phòng cô ấy kể từ hồi mười tuổi.
tr: Yaşlanan ama her zaman coşkulu olan Myrna Mountweazel’ı okşamak için dizlerimin üstüne çöktüm, sonra koşarak üst kata, Margo’nun odasına çıktık. Elimi kapı koluna koyarken, neredeyse on yaşından beri Margo’nun odasının tamamını görmediğim aklıma geldi.
es: Me arrodillé para acariciar a la vieja pero siempre entusiasta Myrna Mountweazel y luego subimos corriendo a la habitación de Margo. Al apoyar la mano en el pomo de la puerta se me pasó por la cabeza que no había visto la habitación de Margo desde que tenía unos diez años.
vi_translation: I bent down to gently pat the elderly yet vigorous Myrna Mountweazel, and then we all went upstairs to Margo's room. As I placed my hand on the doorknob, I suddenly realized that I hadn't been in her room since I was ten years old.
tr_translation: I knelt down to pet the aging but always enthusiastic Myrna Mountweazel, then we ran upstairs to Margo's room. As I placed my hand on the doorknob, it occurred to me that I hadn't seen the entirety of Margo's room since I was almost ten years old.
es_translation: I knelt down to pet the old but always enthusiastic Myrna Mountweazel and then we ran up to Margo's room. As I placed my hand on the doorknob, it crossed my mind that I hadn't seen Margo's room since I was about ten years old.

en: I walked in. Much neater than you’d expect Margo to be, but maybe her mom had just picked everything up. To my right, a closet packed-to-bursting with clothes. On the back of the door, a shoe rack with a couple dozen pairs of shoes, from Mary Janes to prom heels. It didn’t seem like much could be missing from that closet.
vi: Tôi đi vào. Ngăn nắp hơn tôi hình dung, nhưng có thể do mẹ Margo vừa dọn dẹp lại. Ở bên phải, một tủ ních đầy quần áo đến mức như sắp banh ra đến nơi. Trên mặt sau cánh cửa, một cái giá với khoảng vài chục đôi giày, từ giày búp bê Mary Janes đến giày cao gót. Trông có vẻ tủ quần áo không bị thiếu đi gì nhiều.
tr: İçeri girdim. Margo’dan beklenebileceğinden çok daha tertipliydi ama herhalde annesi az önce her şeyi düzenlemişti. Sağımda, elbiselerle tıka basa dolu bir dolap vardı. Kapının arkasmda, tokalı düz ayakkabılardan yüksek topuklulara kadar birkaç düzine ayakkabı dizili bir ayakkabı rafı duruyordu. O dolaptan çok fazla şey kayıp olabilirmiş gibi görünmüyordu.
es: Entré. Estaba más limpia de lo que cabría esperar de Margo, pero quizá su madre lo había recogido todo. A mi derecha, un armario lleno a rebosar de ropa. Detrás de la puerta, un zapatero con un par de docenas de pares de zapatos, desde merceditas hasta taconazos. No parecía que faltaran demasiadas cosas.
vi_translation: I walked in. It was tidier than I imagined, but maybe that's because Margo's mom had just cleaned up. On the right, a closet was so stuffed with clothes that it looked like it was about to burst open. On the back of the door, there was a rack with about a dozen pairs of shoes, ranging from Mary Janes to high heels. It seemed like the closet wasn't missing much.
tr_translation: I entered. It was much more orderly than one would expect from Margo, but her mother had probably just organized everything. To my right, there was a closet stuffed full of clothes. Behind the door, there was a shoe rack lined with several dozen shoes, ranging from flat buckle shoes to high heels. It didn't seem like too many things could be missing from that closet.
es_translation: I entered. It was cleaner than one would expect from Margo, but perhaps her mother had picked everything up. To my right, a closet overflowing with clothes. Behind the door, a shoe rack with a couple dozen pairs of shoes, ranging from Mary Janes to high heels. It didn't seem like too many things were missing.

en: “I’m on the computer,” Radar said. Ben was fiddling with the shade. “The poster is taped on,” he said. “Just Scotch tape. Nothing strong.”
vi: “Tôi mò máy tính coi,” Radar nói. Ben kéo kéo tấm rèm. “Bức áp-phích được dính lên,” nó nói. “Chỉ là băng dính bình thường. Không phải là dính không gỡ nổi.”
tr: “Ben bilgisayardayım,” dedi Radar. Ben panjuru kurcalıyordu. “Poster bantlanmış,” dedi. “Sadece selobant. Güçlü bir şey değil.
es: —Me pongo con el ordenador —dijo Radar. Ben toqueteaba la persiana. —El póster está pegado —observó—. Solo con cinta adhesiva. Nada fuerte.
vi_translation: "I'll check the computer," Radar said. Ben tugged at the curtain. "The poster is stuck up," he said. "It's just regular tape. It's not like it's unremovable."
tr_translation: "I'm on the computer," said Radar. I was fiddling with the shutter. "The poster is taped," he said. "Just scotch tape. It's not something strong."
es_translation: —I'll get on the computer —said Radar. Ben was fiddling with the blind. —The poster is stuck —he observed—. Only with adhesive tape. Nothing strong.

en: The great surprise was on the wall next to the computer desk: bookcases as tall as me and twice as long, filled with vinyl records. Hundreds of them. “John Coltrane’s A Love Supreme is in the record player,” Ben said.
vi: Bất ngờ lớn chính là mảng tường cạnh bàn máy tính: giá sách cao bằng tôi và rộng gấp đôi, xếp đầy các đĩa than. Hàng trăm đĩa như vậy. “Tình yêu tối thượng của John Coltrane nằm trong máy quay đĩa,” Ben nói.
tr: Büyük sürpriz bilgisayar masasının yanındaki duvardaydı: plaklarla dolu, benim boyumda ve iki katı uzunlukta kitaplıklar. Yüzlerce plak. “John Coltrane’in A Love Supreme’i pikapta,” dedi Ben.
es: La gran sorpresa estaba en la pared de al lado de la mesa del ordenador: estanterías de mi altura y el doble de anchas llenas de discos de vinilo. Cientos de discos. —En el tocadiscos está A Love Supreme, de John Coltrane —dijo Ben.
vi_translation: The big surprise was the wall next to the computer desk: a bookshelf as tall as me and twice as wide, filled with vinyl records. Hundreds of such records. "John Coltrane's ultimate love is in the record player," Ben said.
tr_translation: The big surprise was on the wall next to the computer desk: bookshelves filled with records, as tall as me and twice as long. Hundreds of records. “John Coltrane’s A Love Supreme is on the turntable,” said Ben.
es_translation: The big surprise was on the wall next to the computer desk: shelves as tall as me and twice as wide, filled with vinyl records. Hundreds of records. —On the turntable is A Love Supreme by John Coltrane —said Ben.

en: “God, that is a brilliant album,” Radar said without looking away from the computer. “Girl’s got taste.” I looked at Ben, confused, and then Ben said, “He was a sax player.” I nodded.
vi: “Chà, đó là một album xuất sắc,” Radar nói, mắt vẫn không rời máy vi tính. “Margo cũng có gu ra phết.” Tôi không hiểu, nhìn sang Ben thì nó giải thích, “John Coltrane là nghệ sĩ thổi kèn saxophone.” Tôi gật, đã hiểu.
tr: “Tanrım, o harika bir albüm,” dedi Radar bilgisayardan başını kaldırmadan. “Kız ağzmın tadını biliyor.” Kafam karışmış bir halde Ben’e baktım, sonra Ben, “Saksafon çalıyordu,” dedi. Başımı salladım.
es: —Joder, es un álbum genial —dijo Radar sin apartar los ojos del ordenador—. La chica tiene buen gusto. Miré confundido a Ben. —Era un saxofonista —comentó Ben. Asentí.
vi_translation: “Well, that's an excellent album,” Radar said, his eyes still glued to the computer. “Margo has quite the taste.” I didn't understand, so I looked at Ben, who explained, “John Coltrane is a saxophone player.” I nodded, now understanding.
tr_translation: “God, it's an amazing album,” said Radar without lifting his head from the computer. “The girl knows my taste.” Confused, I looked at Ben, then Ben said, “She was playing the saxophone.” I nodded.
es_translation: —Damn, it's an awesome album —said Radar without taking his eyes off the computer—. The girl has good taste. I looked at Ben in confusion. —He was a saxophonist —commented Ben. I nodded.

en: Still typing, Radar said, “I can’t believe Q has never heard of Coltrane. Trane’s playing is literally the most convincing proof of God’s existence I’ve ever come across.”
vi: Vừa gõ lên bàn phím, Radar vừa nói, “Không tin được là Q chưa từng nghe Coltrane. Theo nghĩa đen, tiếng kèn của Trane là minh chứng xác tín nhất mà tôi từng biết, cho thấy Chúa trời thực sự tồn tại.”
tr: Hâlâ bilgisayara bir şeyler yazan Radar, “Q’nun Coltrane’i hiç duymamış olmasına inanamıyorum. Trane’in çalışı Tann’nın varlığına dair karşılaştığım en ikna edici kanıt,” dedi.
es: —No me puedo creer que Q nunca haya oído hablar de Coltrane —dijo Radar sin dejar de teclear—. Su música es literalmente la prueba más convincente de la existencia de Dios que he encontrado jamás.
vi_translation: While typing on the keyboard, Radar said, "I can't believe Q has never heard of Coltrane. Literally, Trane's saxophone is the most convincing proof I've ever known that God truly exists."
tr_translation: Radar, who was still typing something on the computer, said, "I can't believe Q has never heard of Coltrane. Trane's playing is the most convincing evidence I've encountered of the existence of God," he said.
es_translation: —I can't believe that Q has never heard of Coltrane —said Radar without stopping typing—. His music is literally the most convincing proof of the existence of God that I have ever found.

Multiple_ents: ['dizzy gillespie', 'woody guthrie', 'jimmie dale gilmore', 'green day', 'george harrison', 'margo']
en: I began to look through the records. They were organized alphabetically by artist, so I scanned through, looking for the G’s. Dizzy Gillespie, Jimmie Dale Gilmore, Green Day, Guided by Voices, George Harrison. “She has, like, every musician in the world except Woody Guthrie,” I said. And then I went back and started from the A’s.
vi: Tôi bắt đầu nhìn qua dãy đĩa. Tất cả đều được sắp xếp theo bảng chữ cái và theo tên nghệ sĩ, tôi bèn dò tìm phần chữ G. Dizzy Gillespie, Jimmie Dale Gilmore, Green Day, Guided by Voices, George Harrison. “Hình như Margo có tất cả các nhạc sĩ ca sĩ trên thế giới, trừ Woody Guthrie,” tôi nói. Rồi tôi quay lại và bắt đầu từ phần chữ A.
tr: Plakları incelemeye başladım. Şarkıcılara göre alfabetik olarak dizilmişlerdi, bu yüzden G’leri aramak için gözlerimle taradım. Dizzy Gillespie, Jimmie Dale Gilmore, Green Day, Guided by Voices, George Harrison. “Woody Guthrie hariç dünyadaki her müzisyen var gibi,” dedim. Sonra geri dönüp A’lardan başladım.
es: Empecé a mirar los discos. Estaban ordenados alfabéticamente por artistas, así que los recorrí buscando la G: Dizzy Gillespie, Jimmie Dale Gilmore, Green Day, Guided by Voices, George Harrison. —Tiene a todos los músicos del mundo menos a Woody Guthrie —dije. Volví atrás y empecé por la A.
vi_translation: I started looking through the row of discs. All were arranged alphabetically and by artist name, so I searched the G section. Dizzy Gillespie, Jimmie Dale Gilmore, Green Day, Guided by Voices, George Harrison. "It seems like Margo has every musician and singer in the world except Woody Guthrie," I said. Then I turned back and started from the A section.
tr_translation: I started examining the records. They were arranged alphabetically by singers, so I scanned with my eyes to look for the G’s. Dizzy Gillespie, Jimmie Dale Gilmore, Green Day, Guided by Voices, George Harrison. “It seems like every musician in the world is here except Woody Guthrie,” I said. Then I went back and started from the A’s.
es_translation: I started looking at the records. They were arranged alphabetically by artists, so I went through them looking for G: Dizzy Gillespie, Jimmie Dale Gilmore, Green Day, Guided by Voices, George Harrison. —He has all the musicians in the world except for Woody Guthrie —I said. I went back and started with A.

en: “All her schoolbooks are still here,” I heard Ben say. “Plus some other books by her bedside table. No journal.”
vi: “Tất cả sách giáo khoa của Margo còn ở đây,” tôi nghe thấy Ben nói. “Có thêm vài cuốn ở trên bàn cạnh giường. Không có báo chí gì.”
tr: Ben’in, “Bütün okul kitapları hâlâ burada,” dediğini duydum. “Bir de komodininde bazı başka kitaplar var. Gazete yok.
es: —Todos sus libros de texto están aquí —oí decir a Ben—. Más algunos otros en la mesita de noche. Ningún diario.
vi_translation: “All of Margo's textbooks are still here,” I heard Ben say. “There are a few more on the table next to the bed. No newspapers.”
tr_translation: I heard Ben say, "All the school books are still here." "And there are some other books on the nightstand. No newspapers."
es_translation: —All his textbooks are here —I heard Ben say—. Plus some others on the nightstand. No diary.

en: But I was distracted by Margo’s music collection. She liked everything. I could never have imagined her listening to all these old records. I’d seen her listening to music while running, but I’d never suspected this kind of obsession. I’d never heard of most of the bands, and I was surprised to learn that vinyl records were even being produced for the newer ones.
vi: Nhưng bộ sưu tập nhạc của Margo thu hút tôi hơn. Cô ấy thích mọi thứ. Tôi chưa từng tưởng tượng được Margo đã nghe hết tất cả những đĩa nhạc cũ kĩ kia. Tôi đã thấy cô ấy vừa nghe nhạc vừa chạy, nhưng chưa bao giờ ngờ đến niềm say mê lớn thế này. Phần lớn các ban nhạc tôi chưa từng nghe tên, và tôi lấy làm lạ là đĩa than vẫn còn được sản xuất cho những đĩa nhạc mới.
tr: Ama Margo’nun müzik koleksiyonu nedeniyle dikkatim dağılmıştı. Her şeyi seviyordu, bütün bu eski plakları dinlediğini hayal bile edemezdim. Koşarken müzik dinlediğini görmüştüm ama bu tür bir saplantıdan hiç şiiphelenmemiştim. Grupların çoğunu hiç duymamıştım ve yeni olanlar için plak üretilmesine şaşırmıştım.
es: Pero yo estaba distraído con la colección de discos de Margo. Le gustaba todo. Nunca me la habría imaginado escuchando todos aquellos viejos discos. La había visto escuchando música mientras corría, pero nunca había sospechado aquella especie de obsesión. Yo no había oído hablar de la mayoría de los grupos y me sorprendió descubrir que incluso los grupos nuevos seguían sacando discos en vinilo.
vi_translation: But Margo's music collection attracted me more. She liked everything. I had never imagined that Margo had listened to all those old records. I had seen her listening to music while running, but I never suspected such a great passion. Most of the bands I had never heard of, and I found it strange that vinyl records were still being produced for new music.
tr_translation: I was distracted by Aunt Margo's music collection. She loved everything, I couldn't even imagine her listening to all these old records. I had seen her listening to music while running, but I had never suspected this kind of obsession. I had never heard of most of the bands and was surprised that records were still being produced for the new ones.
es_translation: But I was distracted by Margo's record collection. She liked everything. I never would have imagined her listening to all those old records. I had seen her listening to music while running, but I had never suspected that kind of obsession. I hadn't heard of most of the bands, and I was surprised to discover that even new bands were still releasing records on vinyl.

en: I kept going through the A’s and then the B’s—making my way through the Beatles and the Blind Boys of Alabama and Blondie—and I started to rifle through them more quickly, so quickly that I didn’t even see the back cover of Billy Bragg’s Mermaid Avenue until I was looking at the Buzzcocks. I stopped, went back, and pulled out the Billy Bragg record. The front was a photograph of urban row houses. But on the back, Woody Guthrie was staring at me, a cigarette hanging out of his lips, holding a guitar that said THIS MACHINE KILLS FASCISTS.
vi: Tôi đi dọc từ A đến B–qua Beatles, Blind Boys of Alabama và Blondie–tôi bắt đầu lướt nhanh hơn, nhanh đến mức hình như tôi không xem bìa sau Đại lộ Mĩ Nhân Ngư của Billy Bragg cho đến khi nhìn sang Buzzcocks. Tôi dừng lại, quay ngược, kéo đĩa Billy Bragg ra. Mặt trước là ảnh mấy tòa nhà mặt phố đều tăm tắp. Nhưng ở mặt sau, Woody Guthrie đăm đăm nhìn tôi, điếu xì gà bập hờ trên môi, cùng cây guitar có dòng chữ CHIẾC MÁY NÀY DIỆT PHÁT-XÍT.
tr: A’ları gözden geçirmeye devam ettim, sonra B’lere geçtim, Beatles, Blind Boys of Alabama ve Blondie’yi geçtikten sonra daha hızlı göz gezdirmeye başladım, Billy Bragg’in Mermaid Avenue’sunun arka kapağını, Buzzcocks’a bakana dek göremeyecek kadar hızlı. Durdum, geri döndüm ve Billy Bragg plağını çekip çıkardım. Önde bir kentteki sıra sıra evlerin bir fotoğrafı vardı. Ama arkada Woody Guthrie bana bakıyordu, dudaklarından bir sigara sarkıyor, BU MAKİNA FAŞİSTLERİ ÖLDÜRÜR yazan bir gitar tutuyordu.
es: Seguí avanzando por la A, luego por la B —abriéndome camino entre los Beatles, los Blind Boys of Alabama y Blondie—, y empecé a ojearlos más deprisa, tan deprisa que ni siquiera me fijé en la contraportada del Mermaid Avenue, de Billy Bragg, hasta que estaba mirando el de los Buzzcocks. Me detuve, volví atrás y saqué el disco de Billy Bragg. La portada era una fotografía de casas adosadas de una ciudad. Pero en la cara contraria Woody Guthrie me miraba fijamente, con un cigarrillo entre los labios y con una guitarra en la que ponía: ESTA MÁQUINA MATA FASCISTAS.
vi_translation: I walked from A to B–through the Beatles, Blind Boys of Alabama, and Blondie–I started to skim faster, so fast that it seemed I didn't look at the back cover of Billy Bragg's Mermaid Avenue until I glanced at the Buzzcocks. I stopped, turned back, and pulled out the Billy Bragg record. The front cover showed a row of identical storefront buildings. But on the back, Woody Guthrie stared at me, a cigar dangling from his lips, with a guitar that had the words THIS MACHINE KILLS FASCISTS.
tr_translation: I continued to review the A’s, then moved on to the B’s. After passing by the Beatles, Blind Boys of Alabama, and Blondie, I started to skim faster, too fast to see the back cover of Billy Bragg’s Mermaid Avenue until I got to the Buzzcocks. I stopped, went back, and pulled out the Billy Bragg record. There was a photo of rows of houses in a city on the front. But on the back, Woody Guthrie was looking at me, a cigarette dangling from his lips, holding a guitar that said THIS MACHINE KILLS FASCISTS.
es_translation: I kept moving through A, then through B —making my way between the Beatles, the Blind Boys of Alabama, and Blondie—, and I started to browse them faster, so fast that I didn't even notice the back cover of Mermaid Avenue by Billy Bragg until I was looking at the Buzzcocks. I stopped, went back, and took out the Billy Bragg record. The cover was a photograph of terraced houses in a city. But on the other side, Woody Guthrie was staring at me, with a cigarette between his lips and a guitar that said: THIS MACHINE KILLS FASCISTS.

en: “Hey,” I said. Ben looked over.
vi: “Xem này,” tôi nói. Ben nhìn sang.
tr: “Hey,” dedim. Ben bana baktı.
es: —¡Eh! —exclamé. Ben se acercó a mirar.
vi_translation: “Look,” I said. Ben looked over.
tr_translation: "Hey," I said. Ben looked at me.
es_translation: —Hey! —I exclaimed. Ben approached to look.

en: “Holy shitstickers,” he said. “Nice find.” Radar spun around the chair and said, “Impressive. Wonder what’s inside.”
vi: “Chèn đét ơi,” nó thốt lên. “Mát tay tìm kiếm đấy.” Radar xoay ghế lại và nói, “Rất ấn tượng. Có gì ở trong vậy ta?”
tr: “Vay anasını,” dedi. “İyi buldun.” Radar sandalyeyle etrafında döndü ve “Etkileyici. İçinde ne var acaba?” dedi.
es: —De puta madre —dijo—. Buen trabajo. Radar giró la silla. —Impresionante. Me pregunto qué hay dentro —dijo.
vi_translation: “Oh my goodness,” he exclaimed. “You have a knack for finding things.” Radar turned his chair around and said, “Very impressive. What's inside, I wonder?”
tr_translation: “Holy crap,” he said. “You found it well.” Radar spun around in his chair and said, “Impressive. I wonder what's inside?”
es_translation: —Fucking awesome —he said—. Good job. Radar turned the chair. —Impressive. I wonder what's inside —he said.

en: Unfortunately, only a record was inside. The record looked exactly like a record. I put it on Margo’s record player and eventually figured out how to turn it on and put down the needle. It was some guy singing Woody Guthrie songs. He sang better than Woody Guthrie.
vi: Nhưng rủi là chỉ có một đĩa than bên trong. Cái đĩa trông đúng là một cái đĩa than. Tôi đặt nó vào máy quay đĩa của Margo, rút cục cũng mò được cách bật và đặt kim xuống đĩa. Giọng một ca sĩ khác hát các ca khúc của Woody Guthrie, nghe hay hơn chính Woody Guthrie hát.
tr: Ne yazık ki içinde sadece bir plak vardı. Plak tamamen bir plak gibi görünüyordu. Plağı Margo’nun plakçalarma koydum, en sonunda nasıl çalıştıracağımı çözdüm ve iğneyi indirdim. Ses, Woody Guthrie şarkıları söyleyen bir adama aitti. Woody Guthrie’den daha iyi söylüyordu.
es: Por desgracia, lo que había dentro era solo un disco. Y el disco parecía exactamente un disco. Lo puse en el tocadiscos de Margo y al final descubrí cómo encenderlo y colocar la aguja. Era un tipo cantando canciones de Woody Guthrie. Cantaba mejor que él.
vi_translation: But unfortunately, there was only one record inside. The record looked exactly like a vinyl record. I placed it into Margo's record player, eventually figuring out how to turn it on and set the needle on the record. The voice of another singer sang Woody Guthrie's songs, sounding better than Woody Guthrie himself.
tr_translation: Unfortunately, there was only one record inside. The record looked exactly like a record. I placed the record on Margo's record player, finally figured out how to operate it, and lowered the needle. The voice belonged to a man singing Woody Guthrie songs. He sang better than Woody Guthrie.
es_translation: Unfortunately, what was inside was just a record. And the record looked exactly like a record. I put it on Margo's turntable and eventually figured out how to turn it on and place the needle. It was a guy singing Woody Guthrie songs. He sang better than him.

en: “What is it, just a crazy coincidence?”
vi: “Thế là thế nào, chẳng lẽ chỉ là trùng hợp dẩm dớ thôi sao?”
tr: “Nedir bu, sadece çılgın bir tesadüf mü?
es: —¿Qué es esto? ¿Una simple coincidencia?
vi_translation: “What is this, could it just be a silly coincidence?”
tr_translation: “What is this, just a crazy coincidence?”
es_translation: —What is this? A mere coincidence?

en: Ben was holding the album cover. “Look,” he said. He was pointing at the song list. In thin black pen, the song title “Walt Whitman’s Niece” had been circled.
vi: Ben đang cầm bìa album. “Nhìn này,” nó nói, chỉ vào danh mục bài hát. Tên bài “Cháu gái của Walt Whitman” được khoanh tròn bằng nét mực đen mảnh.
tr: Ben albüm kapağını tutuyordu. “Bak,” dedi. Şarkı listesini işaret ediyordu. İnce uçlu siyah kalemle, Walt Whitman’s Niece adlı şarkı daire içine alınmıştı.
es: Ben tenía en las manos la cubierta. —Mira —dijo. Estaba señalando el listado de canciones. El título «Walt Whitman’s Niece» estaba rodeado con un círculo trazado con boli negro.
vi_translation: Ben is holding the album cover. "Look," he says, pointing to the song list. The title "Walt Whitman's Niece" is circled with a thin black line.
tr_translation: I was holding the album cover. “Look,” he said. He was pointing at the song list. With a fine-tipped black pen, the song titled Walt Whitman’s Niece was circled.
es_translation: Ben had the cover in his hands. —Look —he said. He was pointing at the list of songs. The title "Walt Whitman’s Niece" was circled with a black pen.

en: “Interesting,” I said. Margo’s mom had said that Margo’s clues never led anywhere, but I knew now that Margo had created a chain of clues—and she had seemingly made them for me. I immediately thought of her in the SunTrust Building, telling me I was better when I showed confidence. I turned the record over and played it. “Walt Whitman’s Niece” was the first song on side two. Not bad, actually.
vi: “Thú vị đấy,” tôi nói. Mẹ Margo bảo rằng những manh mối của Margo chẳng bao giờ dẫn đến đâu, nhưng giờ tôi biết cô ấy đã tạo ra cả chuỗi manh mối–và hình như cô ấy đã để lại chúng cho tôi. Lập tức tôi nhớ lại lúc ở trong tòa nhà SunTrust, Margo đã nói rằng tôi ổn hơn khi tôi thể hiện tự tin. Tôi lật mặt đĩa và bật lên. “Cháu gái của Walt Whitman” là bài đầu tiên ở mặt hai. Thực ra nghe không tệ.
tr: “İlginç,” dedim. Margo’nun annesi Margo’nun ipuçlarının asla hiçbir yere çıkmadığım söylemişti ama artık Margo’nun ipuçlarından bir zincir yaratmış olduğunu biliyordum... ve görünüşe göre bunu benim için yapmıştı. Hemen sonra onun SunTrust binasındaki halini, kendime güvendiğimde daha iyi olduğumu söyleyişini düşündüm. Plağı çevirip çaldım. Walt Whitmans Niece ikinci yüzdeki ilk şarkıydı. Fena değildi aslında.
es: —Interesante —murmuré. La madre de Margo había dicho que las pistas de Margo nunca llevaban a ninguna parte, pero ahora sabía que Margo había dejado una cadena de pistas, y todo parecía indicar que la había dejado para mí. Inmediatamente pensé en ella diciéndome en el SunTrust Building que yo era mejor cuando confiaba en mí mismo. Di la vuelta al disco y puse la canción. «Walt Whitman’s Niece» era la primera de la cara B. No estaba mal, la verdad.
vi_translation: “Interesting,” I said. Margo's mom said that Margo's clues never led anywhere, but now I know she had created a whole chain of clues–and it seems she left them for me. Immediately, I recalled the moment in the SunTrust building when Margo said I was better when I showed confidence. I flipped the record and turned it on. “Walt Whitman's Niece” was the first track on side two. It actually didn't sound bad.
tr_translation: “Interesting,” I said. Margo's mother had said that Margo's clues never led anywhere, but now I knew that Margo had created a chain of clues... and apparently, she had done it for me. Right after, I thought about her in the SunTrust building, telling me that I was better when I was confident. I flipped the record and played it. Walt Whitman's Niece was the first song on the second side. It wasn't actually bad.
es_translation: —Interesting —I murmured. Margo's mother had said that Margo's clues never led anywhere, but now I knew that Margo had left a chain of clues, and everything seemed to indicate that she had left them for me. Immediately, I thought of her telling me in the SunTrust Building that I was better when I trusted myself. I turned the record over and played the song. "Walt Whitman’s Niece" was the first on side B. It wasn't bad, actually.

en: I saw Ruthie in the doorway then. She looked at me. “Got any clues for us, Ruthie?” She shook her head. “I already looked,” she said glumly. Radar looked at me and gestured his head toward Ruthie.
vi: Đúng lúc đó tôi thấy Ruthie trên ngưỡng cửa. Con bé nhìn tôi. “Có manh mối gì cho bọn anh hả Ruthie?” Con bé lắc đầu. “Em đã tìm rồi,” giọng nó nghe buồn buồn. Radar nhìn tôi và hất đầu về phía Ruthie để ra hiệu.
tr: O sırada kapı eşiğinde Ruthie’yi gördüm. Bana baktı. “Bizim için herhangi bir ipucun var mı, Ruthie?” Başını salladı. “Çoktan baktım,” dedi asık suratla. Radar bana bakıp başıyla Ruthie’yi işaret etti.
es: Entonces vi a Ruthie en la puerta. Me miró. —¿Puedes darnos alguna pista, Ruthie? Negó con la cabeza. —Yo también he buscado —me contestó con tono triste. Radar me miró y luego giró la cabeza hacia Ruthie.
vi_translation: Just then I saw Ruthie at the doorway. She looked at me. "Any clues for us, Ruthie?" She shook her head. "I've already looked," she said sadly. Radar looked at me and nodded towards Ruthie to signal.
tr_translation: At that moment, I saw Ruthie at the doorway. She looked at me. “Do you have any clues for us, Ruthie?” She shook her head. “I already looked,” she said with a sullen face. Radar looked at me and gestured towards Ruthie with his head.
es_translation: Then I saw Ruthie at the door. She looked at me. —Can you give us a hint, Ruthie? He shook his head. —I have also searched —he replied to me with a sad tone. Radar looked at me and then turned his head towards Ruthie.

en: “Can you please keep watch for your mom for us?” I asked. She nodded and left. I closed the door.
vi: “Em trông chừng bố mẹ em hộ bọn anh được không?” tôi hỏi. Con bé gật đầu rồi đi. Tôi đóng cửa lại.
tr: “Lütfen anneni bizim için beklemeye devam edebilir misin?” diye sordum. Başını salladı ve gitti. Kapıyı kapattım.
es: —¿Puedes vigilar que no llegue tu madre, por favor? —le pregunté. Asintió y se marchó. Cerré la puerta.
vi_translation: "Can you look after your parents for us?" I asked. The little girl nodded and left. I closed the door.
tr_translation: “Can you please keep waiting for your mother for us?” I asked. He nodded and left. I closed the door.
es_translation: —Can you watch out so your mother doesn't arrive, please? —I asked him. He nodded and left. I closed the door.

en: “What’s up?” I asked Radar. He motioned us over to the computer. “In the week before she left, Margo was on Omnictionary a bunch. I can tell from minutes logged by her username, which she stored in her passwords. But she erased her browsing history, so I can’t tell what she was looking at.”
vi: “Có gì thế?” tôi hỏi Radar. Nó vẫy bọn tôi lại phía máy vi tính. “Trong tuần trước khi bỏ đi, Margo đã sục kha khá vào Toàn Thư Đủ Thứ. Tôi biết vì dựa vào số phút đăng nhập bằng tên của Margo, và cậu ấy đã lưu mật khẩu lại máy. Nhưng Margo đã xóa toàn bộ lịch sử tìm kiếm, do vậy không thể biết được cậu ấy đã tìm thông tin gì.”
tr: “Ne var?” diye sordum Radar’a. Bizi bilgisayarın başına çağırdı. “Gitmeden önceki hafta, Margo Omnictionary’ye girmiş. Kullanıcı adıyla oturum açtığı dakikalardan bunu anlayabiliyorum.
es: —¿Qué pasa? —le pregunté a Radar, que nos indicó con un gesto que nos acercáramos al ordenador. —Una semana antes de marcharse, Margo entró un montón de veces en el Omnictionary. Lo sé por los minutos que estuvo conectada con su nombre de usuario, que ha quedado guardado en sus contraseñas. Pero borró su historial de navegación, así que no sé qué buscaba.
vi_translation: “What is it?” I asked Radar. He waved us over to the computer. “In the week before she left, Margo spent quite a bit of time on Omnictionary. I know because of the number of minutes logged in under Margo's name, and she had saved the password on the computer. But Margo deleted all her search history, so we can't know what information she was looking for.”
tr_translation: “What is it?” I asked Radar. He called us over to the computer. “The week before she left, Margo logged into Omnictionary. I can tell from the minutes she was logged in with her username. But she cleared her browsing history, so I can’t tell what she looked at.”
es_translation: —What's going on? —I asked Radar, who gestured for us to come closer to the computer. —A week before leaving, Margo logged into Omnictionary a bunch of times. I know this from the minutes she was connected with her username, which has been saved in her passwords. But she deleted her browsing history, so I don't know what she was looking for.

en: “Hey, Radar, look up who Walt Whitman was,” Ben said.
vi: “Này, Radar, tra xem Walt Whitman là ai,” Ben nói.
tr: Ama tarama geçmişini silmiş, bu yüzden neye baktığını söylemem.” “Hey Radar, Walt Whitman’m kim olduğuna bak,” dedi Ben.
es: —Oye, Radar, busca quién era Walt Whitman —dijo Ben.
vi_translation: "Hey, Radar, look up who Walt Whitman is," Ben said.
tr_translation: “Hey Radar, look up who Walt Whitman is,” said Ben.
es_translation: "Hey, Radar, look up who Walt Whitman was," said Ben.

en: “He was a poet,” I answered. “Nineteenth century.”
vi: “Đó là một nhà thơ,” tôi đáp. “Thế kỉ mười chín.
tr: “Şairdi,” diye cevap verdim. “On dokuzuncu yüzyılda.” “Harika,” dedi Ben gözlerini devirerek.
es: —Era un poeta —le contesté—. Del siglo diecinueve.
vi_translation: “That is a poet,” I replied. “Nineteenth century.”
tr_translation: “He was a poet,” I answered. “In the nineteenth century.” “Great,” said Ben, rolling his eyes.
es_translation: —He was a poet —I replied—. From the nineteenth century.

en: “Great,” Ben said, rolling his eyes. “Poetry.”
vi: “Tuyệt,” Ben thốt lên, mắt đảo tròn. “Thi ca.”
tr: “On dokuzuncu yüzyılda.” “Harika,” dedi Ben gözlerini devirerek. “Şiir.
es: —Genial —dijo Ben mirando al techo—. Poesía.
vi_translation: "Amazing," Ben exclaimed, eyes wide. "Poetry."
tr_translation: “In the nineteenth century.” “Great,” said Ben, rolling his eyes. “Poetry.”
es_translation: —Great —said Ben, looking at the ceiling—. Poetry.

en: “What’s wrong with that?” I asked.
vi: “Có gì không ổn sao?” tôi hỏi.
tr: “Bunda ne sorun var?” diye sordum.
es: —¿Qué tiene de malo? —le pregunté.
vi_translation: “Is something wrong?” I asked.
tr_translation: "What's the problem with this?" I asked.
es_translation: —What's wrong with it? —I asked him.

en: “Poetry is just so emo,” he said. “Oh, the pain. The pain. It always rains. In my soul.”
vi: “Thi ca chỉ tổ nát cõi lòng,” Ben đáp. “Ôi, đau đớn. Đau đớn. Rơi hoài rơn rớn. Mảnh hồn tôi.”
tr: “Şiir fazla emo,” dedi. “Ah, acı. Acı. Sürekli yağmur yağıyor. Ruhumda.
es: —La poesía es tan emo —me dijo—. Ay, el dolor. El dolor. Siempre llueve. En mi corazón.
vi_translation: "Poetry only shatters the heart," Ben replied. "Oh, the pain. The pain. Falling endlessly, trembling. A fragment of my soul."
tr_translation: “The poem is too emo,” he said. “Oh, the pain. The pain. It’s constantly raining. In my soul.”
es_translation: —Poetry is so emo —he told me—. Oh, the pain. The pain. It always rains. In my heart.

en: “Yeah, I believe that’s Shakespeare,” I said dismissively. “Did Whitman have any nieces?” I asked Radar. He was already on Whitman’s Omnictionary page. A burly guy with this huge beard. I’d never read him, but he looked like a good poet.
vi: “Ờ, tôi chắc chắn đó là thơ Shakespeare,” tôi nói, không chấp nó. “Whitman có cô cháu gái nào không?” tôi quay sang hỏi Radar. Nó đã vào trang viết về Whitman trong Toàn Thư Đủ Thứ. Một người đàn ông vạm vỡ với hàm râu khổng lồ. Tôi chưa từng đọc Whitman, nhưng trông ông ta cũng có vẻ ra dáng nhà thơ.
tr: “Evet, sanıyorum bu Shakespeare,” dedim onu duymazlıktan gelip. “Walt Whitman’ın yeğeni var mıymış?” diye sordum Radar’a. Zaten Whitman’ın Omnictionary sayfasmdaydı. İri yarı, koca sakallı bir adamdı. Hiç okumamıştım ama iyi bir şair gibi görünüyordu.
es: —Sí, creo que eso es de Shakespeare —le contesté despectivamente—. ¿Walt Whitman tenía alguna sobrina? —le pregunté a Radar. Radar había entrado ya en la página de Walt Whitman del Omnictionary. Un tipo corpulento con una enorme barba. Nunca lo había leído, pero tenía pinta de ser buen poeta.
vi_translation: "Well, I'm sure that's Shakespeare's poetry," I said, not bothering with it. "Does Whitman have any nieces?" I turned to ask Radar. He was on the page about Whitman in the Encyclopedia of Everything. A burly man with a huge beard. I had never read Whitman, but he certainly looked the part of a poet.
tr_translation: “Yes, I think this is Shakespeare,” I said, pretending not to hear him. “Does Walt Whitman have a nephew?” I asked Radar. He was already on Whitman’s Omnictionary page. He was a large, big-bearded man. I had never read him, but he looked like a good poet.
es_translation: —Yes, I think that's from Shakespeare —I replied disdainfully—. Did Walt Whitman have any nieces? —I asked Radar. Radar had already entered the Walt Whitman page of the Omnictionary. A burly guy with a huge beard. He had never read him, but he looked like a good poet.

en: “Uh, no one famous. Says he had a couple brothers, but no mention of whether they had kids. I can probably find out if you want.” I shook my head. That didn’t seem right. I went back to looking around the room. The bottom shelf of her record collection included some books—middle school yearbooks, a beat-up copy of The Outsiders—and some back issues of teen magazines. Nothing relating to Walt Whitman’s niece, certainly.
vi: “Ờ, không có ai nổi tiếng. Trong này nói ông ta có mấy người anh em trai, nhưng không nói họ có con hay không. Có thể tôi sẽ tra được thông tin này nếu ông muốn.” Tôi lắc đầu. Có vẻ không phải hướng này. Tôi lùi lại nhìn quanh căn phòng. Hàng dưới cùng của giá đĩa có mấy cuốn sách–các kiểu kỉ yếu trường phổ thông cơ sở, cuốn Những kẻ ngoài vòng đã sờn cũ–và vài ấn bản in lại các tạp chí thanh thiếu niên. Không có gì liên quan đến cháu gái của Walt Whitman, chắc chắn vậy.
tr: “Ah, ünlü biri değil. İki erkek kardeşi olduğu yazıyor ama çocukları olup olmadığından bahsedilmiyor. Büyük ihtimalle bulabilirim, istersen.” Başımı salladım. Bu doğru gibi gelmiyordu. Odayı araştırmaya geri döndüm. Plak koleksiyonunun alt rafında bazı kitaplar vardıortaokul yıllıkları, eskimiş bir The Outsiders— ve bazı gençlik dergilerinin eski sayıları. Walt Whitman’m yeğeniyle alakalı hiçbir şey yoktu.
es: —Uf, ninguna famosa. Pone que tenía un par de hermanos, pero no si alguno de ellos tuvo hijos. Creo que puedo encontrarlo si quieres. Negué con la cabeza. No parecía el camino correcto. Volví a buscar por la habitación. En el último estante de la colección de discos había unos libros —anuarios escolares de años anteriores, un ejemplar destrozado de Rebeldes— y varios números atrasados de revistas juveniles. Sin duda nada que tuviera que ver con la sobrina de Walt Whitman.
vi_translation: “Well, no one famous. This says he had a few brothers, but it doesn't mention if they had children or not. I might be able to find this information if you want.” I shook my head. It doesn't seem like this is the direction. I stepped back and looked around the room. The bottom shelf of the record rack had a few books—various middle school yearbooks, a worn-out copy of The Outsiders—and some reprinted editions of teen magazines. Nothing related to Walt Whitman's niece, that's for sure.
tr_translation: “Ah, not a famous person. It says he has two brothers, but it doesn't mention whether he has children. I can probably find out, if you want.” I nodded. This didn't feel right. I went back to searching the room. On the bottom shelf of the record collection, there were some books—middle school yearbooks, a worn-out copy of The Outsiders—and some old issues of youth magazines. There was nothing about Walt Whitman's nephew.
es_translation: —Ugh, no famous ones. It says he had a couple of siblings, but not if any of them had children. I think I can find it if you want. I shook my head. It didn't seem like the right path. I went back to searching the room. On the last shelf of the record collection, there were some books —school yearbooks from previous years, a battered copy of The Outsiders— and several back issues of youth magazines. Clearly nothing that had to do with Walt Whitman's niece.

en: I looked through the books by her bedside table. Nothing of interest. “It would make sense if she had a book of his poetry,” I said. “But she doesn’t seem to.”
vi: Tôi nhìn lại những cuốn sách trên bàn cạnh giường. Không có gì đáng chú ý. “Chắc Margo phải có cuốn thơ nào của ông ấy chứ nhỉ,” tôi nói. “Nhưng hình như không thấy.”
tr: Komodinindeki kitaplara göz gezdirdim. İlgi çekici bir şey yoktu. “Eğer Whitman’m bir şiir kitabı olsaydı, mantıklı olurdu,” dedim. “Ama varmış gibi görünmüyor.
es: Eché un vistazo a los libros de su mesita de noche. Nada interesante. —Lo lógico sería que tuviera un libro de poemas de Whitman —dije—. Pero parece que no es así.
vi_translation: I looked back at the books on the bedside table. Nothing noteworthy. "Margo must have one of his poetry books," I said. "But it seems like I can't find it."
tr_translation: I glanced through the books in the nightstand. There was nothing interesting. “If there were a book of Whitman's poetry, it would make sense,” I said. “But it doesn't seem like there is one.”
es_translation: I glanced at the books on her nightstand. Nothing interesting. —The logical thing would be for him to have a book of Whitman's poems —I said—. But it seems that is not the case.

en: “She does!” Ben said excitedly. I went over to where he had knelt by the bookshelves, and saw it now. I’d looked right past the slim volume on the bottom shelf, wedged between two yearbooks. Walt Whitman. Leaves of Grass. I pulled out the book. There was a photograph of Whitman on the cover, his light eyes staring back at me.
vi: “Có đấy!” Ben reo lên. Tôi đến chỗ nó đang quì bên giá sách, và thấy cuốn sách. Tôi đã bỏ qua một cuốn mỏng ở tầng dưới cùng, nằm kẹp giữa hai tập kỉ yếu. Walt Whitman. Những cánh cỏ. Tôi kéo cuốn sách ra. Có một bức ảnh Whitman trên bìa sách, đôi mắt sáng của ông ấy đăm đăm nhìn tôi.
tr: “Var!” dedi Ben heyecanla. Kitaplıkta diz çöktüğü yere gidince gördüm. Alt rafta, iki yıllık arasında sıkışıp kalmış ince cildi gözden kaçırmıştım. Walt Whitman. Çimen Yapraklan. Kitabı çekip çıkardım. Kapakta Whitman’m bir fotoğrafı vardı, parlak gözleri bana bakıyordu.
es: —¡Sí que lo tiene! —exclamó Ben entusiasmado. Me acerqué a él, que se había arrodillado frente a las estanterías, y lo vi. Había pasado por alto el delgado volumen del último estante, metido entre dos anuarios. Walt Whitman. Hojas de hierba. Saqué el libro. En la cubierta había una foto del poeta, cuyos ojos brillantes me miraron fijamente.
vi_translation: "There is!" Ben exclaimed. I went to where he was kneeling by the bookshelf and saw the book. I had overlooked a thin volume on the bottom shelf, wedged between two yearbooks. Walt Whitman. Leaves of Grass. I pulled the book out. There was a photo of Whitman on the cover, his bright eyes staring intently at me.
tr_translation: “There is!” Ben said excitedly. I saw it when I went to the spot where he was kneeling in front of the bookshelf. I had missed the thin volume wedged between the two-year-old books on the bottom shelf. Walt Whitman. Leaves of Grass. I pulled the book out. There was a photo of Whitman on the cover, his bright eyes looking at me.
es_translation: —He sure does! —exclaimed Ben enthusiastically. I approached him, who had knelt in front of the shelves, and I saw him. I had overlooked the thin volume on the last shelf, tucked between two yearbooks. Walt Whitman. Leaves of Grass. I took out the book. On the cover was a photo of the poet, whose bright eyes stared at me intently.

en: “Not bad,” I told Ben.
vi: “Khá đấy,” tôi nói với Ben.
tr: “Fena değil,” dedim Ben’e.
es: —No ha estado mal —le dije a Ben.
vi_translation: "Not bad," I said to Ben.
tr_translation: "Not bad," I said to Ben.
es_translation: —It wasn't bad —I said to Ben.

en: He nodded. “Yeah, now can we get out of here? Call me old-fashioned, but I’d rather not be here when Margo’s parents get back.”
vi: Nó gật. “Ừa, bây giờ ra khỏi đây được chưa? Cứ cho là tôi bảo thủ đi, nhưng tôi không muốn lúc bố mẹ Margo về vẫn thấy bọn mình lởn vởn ở đây đâu.”
tr: Başını salladı. “Evet, şimdi buradan çıkabilir miyiz? Bana eskikafalı diyebilirsiniz ama Margo’nun annesiyle babası döndüğünde burada olmamayı tercih ederim.
es: Asintió. —Sí. ¿Podemos largarnos ya? Puedes llamarme chapado a la antigua, pero preferiría no estar aquí cuando volvieran los padres de Margo.
vi_translation: It nodded. “Okay, can we get out of here now? Call me conservative, but I don't want Margo's parents to come back and find us hanging around here.”
tr_translation: He nodded. “Yes, can we leave now? You can call me old-fashioned, but I would prefer not to be here when Margo's parents return.”
es_translation: He nodded. —Yes. Can we get out of here already? You can call me old-fashioned, but I would prefer not to be here when Margo's parents come back.

en: “Is there anything we’re missing?”
vi: “Liệu có sót gì không nhỉ?”
tr: “Atladığımız bir şey var mı?
es: —¿Nos dejamos algo?
vi_translation: "Is there anything missing?"
tr_translation: “Is there something we missed?”
es_translation: —Did we leave something behind?

en: Radar stood up. “It really seems like she’s drawing a pretty straight line; there’s gotta be something in that book. It’s weird, though—I mean, no offense, but if she always left clues for her parents, why would she leave them for you this time?”
vi: Radar đứng lên. “Có vẻ rõ ràng là Margo đã đi một đường khá mạch lạc, ắt sẽ tìm thấy gì đó trong cuốn sách. Kể ra cũng lạ–tôi nói không có ý gì đâu, nhưng nếu Margo luôn để lại manh mối cho bố mẹ, sao lần này cậu ấy lại để lại cho ông?”
tr: Radar ayağa kalktı. “Gerçekten oldukça düz bir çizgi çiziyormuş gibi görünüyor; o kitabın içinde bir şeyler olmalı. Tuhaf, gerçi... yani kusura bakma ama eğer hep ebeveynleri için ipuçları bıraktıysa, neden bu sefer senin için bıraksın?
es: Radar se levantó. —La verdad es que parece que ha trazado una línea perfectamente recta. En ese libro tiene que haber algo. Pero me parece raro… Bueno, sin ofender, pero si siempre ha dejado pistas para sus padres, ¿por qué esta vez iba a dejártelas a ti?
vi_translation: Radar stood up. "It seems clear that Margo has taken a rather coherent path, surely she will find something in the book." "It's strange," I said, "I don't mean anything by it, but if Margo always left clues for her parents, why did she leave them for you this time?"
tr_translation: Radar stood up. “It really seems to be drawing quite a straight line; there must be something in that book. Strange, though... I mean, sorry, but if she always left clues for her parents, why would she leave one for you this time?”
es_translation: Radar stood up. —The truth is that it seems he has drawn a perfectly straight line. There must be something in that book. But it seems strange to me… Well, no offense, but if he has always left clues for his parents, why would he leave them for you this time?

en: I shrugged my shoulders. I didn’t know the answer, but of course I had my hopes: maybe Margo needed to see my confidence. Maybe this time she wanted to be found, and to be found by me. Maybe—just as she had chosen me on the longest night, she had chosen me again. And maybe untold riches awaited he who found her.
vi: Tôi nhún vai. Tôi không có câu trả lời, nhưng tất nhiên tôi nuôi hi vọng: có lẽ Margo muốn thấy sự tự tin của tôi. Có thể lần này cô ấy muốn được tìm thấy, và được tôi tìm thấy. Có thể–cũng giống như cô ấy đã chọn tôi trong cái đêm dài nhất ấy, lần này cô ấy lại chọn tôi. Và có thể kho báu bí mật đang chờ người tìm ra cô ấy.
tr: Omzumu silktim. Cevabı bilmiyordum ama elbette umutlarım vardı: Belki Margo’nun benim güvenimi görmesi gerekiyordu. Belki bu sefer benim tarafımdan bulunmak istiyordu. Belki... tam da o uzun gecede beni seçtiği gibi, yine beni seçmişti. Ve belki onu bulan kişiyi bilinmeyen hazineler bekliyordu.
es: Me encogí de hombros. No podía responderle, aunque por supuesto albergaba esperanzas: quizá Margo quería ver que confiaba en mí mismo. Quizá esa vez quería que la encontraran, que la encontrara yo. Quizá… igual que me había elegido a mí para la noche más larga, había vuelto a elegirme a mí. Y quizá al que la encontrara le esperasen incalculables riquezas.
vi_translation: I shrugged. I didn't have an answer, but of course, I held onto hope: maybe Margo wanted to see my confidence. Maybe this time she wanted to be found, and found by me. Maybe—just like she chose me on that longest night, this time she chose me again. And maybe the secret treasure is waiting for someone to find her.
tr_translation: I shrugged. I didn't know the answer, but of course, I had hopes: Maybe Margo needed to see my trust. Maybe this time she wanted to be found by me. Maybe... just as she chose me on that long night, she had chosen me again. And maybe unknown treasures awaited the person who found her.
es_translation: I shrugged. I couldn't answer him, although of course I harbored hopes: maybe Margo wanted to see that I trusted myself. Maybe this time she wanted to be found, for me to find her. Maybe... just as she had chosen me for the longest night, she had chosen me again. And maybe incalculable riches awaited the one who found her.

en: Ben and Radar left soon after we got back to my house, after they’d each looked through the book and not found any obvious clues. I grabbed some cold lasagna from the fridge for lunch and went to my room with Walt. It was the Penguin Classics version of the first edition of Leaves of Grass. I read a little from the introduction and then paged through the book. There were several quotes highlighted in blue, all from the epically long poem known as “Song of Myself.” And there were two lines from the poem that were highlighted in green:
vi: Không lâu sau khi quay lại nhà tôi, xem một lượt qua cuốn sách và không tìm thấy manh mối rõ rệt nào, Ben và Radar cũng về. Tôi lấy suất lasagna trong tủ lạnh ra ăn trưa và mang Walt về phòng. Cuốn Những cánh cỏ đó là bản in lần đầu của nhà xuất bản Penguin Classics. Tôi đọc một ít từ lời giới thiệu rồi lật tiếp từng trang. Có một số câu được đánh dấu màu xanh da trời, tất cả đều nằm trong một bài thơ dài dằng dặc như sử thi tên là “Tự khúc.” Hai dòng trong bài thơ đó được đánh dấu màu xanh lá cây:
tr: Ben ile Radar bizim eve döndükten kısa süre sonra gittiler, ikisi de kitaba göz gezdirip herhangi belirgin bir ipucu bulamamıştı. Öğle yemeği için buzdolabından biraz soğuk lazanya alıp Walt’la birlikte odama gittim. Çimen Yaprakları’mn Penguin Classics edisyonunun ilk baskısıydı. Girişten bir parça okudum, sonra kitabın sayfalarını çevirip göz gezdirdim. Mavi renkle altı çizilmiş bir sürü mısra vardı, hepsi destan gibi uzun Kendi Şarkım isimli şiirdendi. Ve şiirde yeşil renkle altı çizilmiş iki dize vardı:
es: Ben y Radar se marcharon poco después de que volviéramos a mi casa, tras haber echado un vistazo al libro y no haber encontrado ninguna pista evidente. Cogí un trozo de lasaña del frigorífico y subí a mi habitación con Walt. Era la edición de Penguin Classics de la primera edición de Hojas de hierba. Leí parte de la introducción y después hojeé el libro. Había varios versos marcados en fluorescente azul, todos ellos del épicamente largo poema titulado «Canto de mí mismo». Y dos versos marcados en verde:
vi_translation: Not long after I returned home, having looked through the book without finding any clear clues, Ben and Radar also came back. I took a serving of lasagna from the fridge for lunch and brought Walt back to my room. The book Leaves of Grass was a first edition published by Penguin Classics. I read a bit from the introduction and then continued flipping through the pages. There were some lines marked in blue, all of which were in a long, epic-like poem called "Song of Myself." Two lines in that poem were marked in green:
tr_translation: Ben and Radar left shortly after we returned home; neither of them had found any obvious clues while skimming through the book. I grabbed some cold lasagna from the fridge for lunch and went to my room with Walt. It was the first edition of the Penguin Classics version of Leaves of Grass. I read a piece from the introduction, then flipped through the pages of the book. There were many lines underlined in blue, all from the epic-length poem called Song of Myself. And there were two lines underlined in green in the poem:
es_translation: Ben and Radar left shortly after we returned to my house, having looked through the book and found no obvious clues. I grabbed a piece of lasagna from the fridge and went up to my room with Walt. It was the Penguin Classics edition of the first edition of Leaves of Grass. I read part of the introduction and then skimmed through the book. There were several verses highlighted in blue fluorescent, all of them from the epically long poem titled "Song of Myself." And two verses highlighted in green:

en: Unscrew the locks from the doors!
vi: Tháo mở ổ khóa khỏi cánh cửa!
tr: Sökün kilitleri kapılardan!
es: ¡Arrancad los cerrojos de las puertas!
vi_translation: Unlock the lock from the door!
tr_translation: Remove the locks from the doors!
es_translation: Rip the locks off the doors!

en: Unscrew the doors themselves from their jambs!
vi: Tháo mở chính cánh cửa khỏi khung!
tr: Sökün kapıları kasalarından!
es: ¡Arrancad las puertas de los goznes[1]!
vi_translation: He removed the door from its frame!
tr_translation: Remove the doors from their frames!
es_translation: Rip the doors off their hinges[1]!

en: I spent most of my afternoon trying to make sense of that quote, thinking maybe it was Margo’s way of telling me to become more of a badass or something. But I also read and reread everything highlighted in blue:
vi: Tôi dành gần hết buổi chiều cố hiểu hàm ý câu đó, thầm nghĩ có lẽ đó là cách Margo bảo tôi hãy mạnh mẽ táo bạo hơn hay đại loại thế. Nhưng tôi cũng đọc đi đọc lại từng dòng thơ được đánh dấu xanh da trời:
tr: Öğleden sonramın çoğunu bu sözü anlamlandırmaya çalışarak geçirdim, bunun belki de Margo’nun bana daha sert bir çocuk falan haline gelmemi söyleme şekli olduğunu düşünerek. Ama mavi renkle altı çizili her şeyi de tekrar tekrar okudum:
es: Pasé buena parte de la tarde intentando desentrañar el sentido de la cita, pensando que quizá Margo intentaba decirme que me volviera un cabrón o algo así. Pero leí y releí también lo que estaba marcado en azul:
vi_translation: I spent nearly the entire afternoon trying to understand the implication of that sentence, thinking to myself that perhaps it was Margo's way of telling me to be bolder or something like that. But I also read and reread each line of the poem marked in sky blue:
tr_translation: I spent most of my afternoon trying to make sense of this phrase, thinking that maybe it was Margo's way of telling me to become a tougher kid or something. But I also read everything underlined in blue over and over again:
es_translation: I spent a good part of the afternoon trying to unravel the meaning of the quote, thinking that maybe Margo was trying to tell me to become a jerk or something like that. But I also read and reread what was marked in blue:

en: You shall no longer take things at second or third hand . . . .
vi: Ngươi sẽ không nhận từ bàn tay thứ hai hay thứ ba nữa... không nhìn qua đôi mắt của người chết nữa... không ăn những bóng ma ám ảnh trong những trang sách nữa.
tr: Artık olayları ne ikinci ne üçüncü elden almalısın...
es: Ya no recibirás de segunda o de tercera mano las cosas, ni
vi_translation: You will no longer receive from the second or third hand... no longer see through the eyes of the dead... no longer consume the haunting phantoms within the pages of books.
tr_translation: You should no longer get events secondhand or thirdhand...
es_translation: You will no longer receive things second or third hand, nor

en: nor look through the eyes of the dead . . . . nor feed on
vi: Ngươi sẽ không nhận từ bàn tay thứ hai hay thứ ba nữa... không nhìn qua đôi mắt của người chết nữa... không ăn những bóng ma ám ảnh trong những trang sách nữa.
tr: ne ölünün gözlerinden bakmalısın... ne de kitaplardaki vesveselerle beslenmelisin.
es: mirarás por los ojos de los muertos, ni te alimentarás de los espectros de los libros.
vi_translation: You will no longer receive from the second or third hand... no longer see through the eyes of the dead... no longer consume the haunting phantoms within the pages of books.
