Tôi đọc Những văn bản Liên bang để chuẩn bị cho bài kiểm tra ngày mai trong môn nhà nước, nhưng đầu óc tôi cứ lởn vởn liên hồi giữa Guthrie, Whitman, New York và Margo. Có phải Margo đến New York theo đuổi nhạc đồng quê không? Có phải có một Margo bí mật đam mê âm nhạc đồng quê mà tôi chưa từng biết không? Có phải cô ấy sống trong một căn hộ mà một trong số họ từng sống không? Và tại sao cô ấy muốn nói với tôi tất cả những điều đó?
tr: Ben ile Radar bandodayken, kapıları açık halde SESIB’da oturdum; hafif, serin bir meltem esiyordu. Ertesi günkü siyaset bilimi sınavıma hazırlanmak için Federalist Yazılar'dan bir şeyler okudum ama aklım bitmeyen döngüsüne takılıp durdu: Guthrie, Whitman, New York ve Margo. Kendini folk müziğe gömmek için New York’a mı gitmişti? Benim bilmediğim folk müziksever bir Margo mu vardı? Belki onların bir zamanlar yaşadığı bir evde mi kalıyordu? Ve neden bunu bana anlatmak istiyordu?
es: Mientras Ben y Radar ensayaban, me senté en el Chuco con las puertas abiertas. Soplaba una ligera brisa esquimal. Leí el Federalista para preparar un examen de política que tenía al día siguiente, pero mi mente había entrado en un bucle: Guthrie, Whitman, Nueva York y Margo. ¿Había ido a Nueva York para meterse de lleno en la música folk? ¿Había allí algún músico folk secreto al que yo no conocía? ¿Estaba quizá en un piso en el que uno de ellos había vivido alguna vez? ¿Y por qué quería que yo lo supiera?
vi_translation: While Ben and Radar were practicing music, I sat in RHAPAW with the car door open, a gentle breeze slowly caressing through. I was reading The Federalist Papers to prepare for tomorrow's government class test, but my mind kept wandering between Guthrie, Whitman, New York, and Margo. Did Margo go to New York to pursue country music? Is there a secret Margo passionate about country music that I never knew about? Is she living in an apartment that one of them once lived in? And why did she want to tell me all of that?
tr_translation: While I was in the band with Radar, I sat in SESIB with the doors open; a light, cool breeze was blowing. To prepare for my political science exam the next day, I read some of the Federalist Papers. I read it, but my mind kept getting stuck in its endless loop: Guthrie, Whitman, New York, and Margo. Had he gone to New York to bury himself in folk music? Was there a Margo who loved folk music that I didn't know about? Maybe he was staying in a house where they once lived? And why did he want to tell me this?
es_translation: While Ben and Radar were rehearsing, I sat in the Chuco with the doors open. A light Eskimo breeze was blowing. I read the Federalist to prepare for a politics exam I had the next day, but my mind had entered a loop: Guthrie, Whitman, New York, and Margo. Had she gone to New York to dive into folk music? Was there some secret folk musician there that I didn't know about? Was she perhaps in an apartment where one of them had once lived? And why did she want me to know?

en: I saw Ben and Radar approaching in the sideview mirror, Radar swinging his sax case as he walked quickly toward RHAPAW. They hustled in through the already-open door, and Ben turned the key and RHAPAW sputtered, and then we hoped, and then she sputtered again, and then we hoped some more, and finally she gurgled to life. Ben raced out of the parking lot and turned off campus before saying to me, “CAN YOU BELIEVE THIS SHIT!” He could hardly contain his glee.
vi: Nhìn qua gương cạnh, tôi thấy Ben và Radar đang tiến lại. Radar vung vẩy hộp đựng cây kèn saxophone khi rảo bước đến RHAPAW. Hai thằng ào vào qua cửa mở sẵn, Ben tra khóa vào ổ và RHAPAW bắt đầu lục bục. Bọn tôi hi vọng, ẻm lại lục bục, bọn tôi hi vọng thêm chút nữa, và rút cục ẻm cũng khục lên tỉnh giấc. Ben đã kịp vọt qua bãi đỗ xe, rẽ ra khỏi trường trước khi gào lên với tôi, “CÁC ÔNG CÓ TIN NỔI KHÔNG?” Nó hầu như không thể hoãn nổi sung sướng.
tr: Yan aynadan Ben ile Radar’ın yaklaştığını gördüm, Radar hızlıca SESIB’a doğru yürürken saksafon çantasını sallıyordu. Halihazırda açık olan kapıdan aceleyle arabaya bindiler, Ben kontağı çevirdi ve SESIB tekledi, biz umut ettik, o yine tekledi, biz biraz daha umut ettik ve nihayet öksürerek hayata aktı. Ben önce hızla park alanının dışına çıkıp okuldan uzaklaştı ve ardından bana doğru haykırdı: “BU SAÇMALIĞA İNANABİLİYOR MUSUN!” Sevincini zapt edemiyordu.
es: Vi por el retrovisor lateral a Ben y a Radar acercándose, Radar balanceando el estuche de su saxo mientras avanzaba deprisa hacia el Chuco. Entraron, Ben giró la llave y el Chuco escupió. Esperamos un momento y el coche volvió a escupir. Seguimos esperando y al final reaccionó. Ben salió del aparcamiento y del campus. —¿PUEDES CREERTE ESTA MIERDA? —gritó sin poder contener su alegría.
vi_translation: Looking through the side mirror, I saw Ben and Radar approaching. Radar was swinging the saxophone case as he walked briskly to RHAPAW. The two of them rushed in through the open door, Ben inserted the key into the ignition, and RHAPAW started to sputter. We hoped, it sputtered again, we hoped a little more, and finally, it coughed to life. Ben managed to speed through the parking lot, turning out of the school before shouting at me, “CAN YOU BELIEVE IT?” He could hardly contain his excitement.
tr_translation: I saw Ben and Radar approaching from the window, Radar was swinging his saxophone case as he walked quickly towards SESIB. They hurriedly got into the car through the already open door, Ben turned the ignition and SESIB sputtered, we hoped, it sputtered again, we hoped a bit more, and finally it coughed to life. Ben first quickly drove out of the parking lot and away from the school, then he shouted at me: "CAN YOU BELIEVE THIS NONSENSE!" He couldn't contain his joy.
es_translation: I saw Ben and Radar approaching through the side mirror, Radar swinging his sax case as he hurried towards the RHAPAW. They got in, Ben turned the key, and the RHAPAW sputtered. We waited a moment and the car sputtered again. We kept waiting and finally it responded. Ben drove out of the parking lot and off the campus. —CAN YOU BELIEVE THIS SHIT? —he shouted, unable to contain his joy.

en: He started hitting the car’s horn, but of course the horn didn’t work, so every time he hit it, he just yelled, “BEEP! BEEP! BEEP! HONK IF YOU’RE GOING TO PROM WITH TRUE-BLUE HONEYBUNNY LACEY PEMBERTON! HONK, BABY, HONK!”
vi: Ben bắt đầu bấm còi, nhưng tất nhiên còi không hoạt động, thế nên mỗi lần bấm còi, Ben lại rống lên, “BÍP! BÍP! BÍP! CÒI LÊN ĐI NẾU ĐI DẠ HỘI CÙNG SIÊU THỎ LACEY PEMBERTON! CÒI LÊN, CÒI LÊN ĐI!”
tr: Arabanın kornasına vurmaya başladı ama elbette korna çalışmadı, bu yüzden her vurduğunda haykırdı: “BİP! BİP! BİP! EĞER SADIK TAVŞANCIK LACEY PEMBERTON’LA BALOYA GİDİYORSAN ÖT! ÖT, TATLIM, ÖT!
es: Empezó a tocar el claxon, pero por supuesto no funcionó, así que cada vez que lo tocaba, gritaba: ¡PIII! ¡PIII! ¡PIII! ¡PITA SI VAS A IR AL BAILE CON UNA PAVA, CON LACEY PEMBERTON! ¡PITA, NENE, PITA!
vi_translation: Ben started honking the horn, but of course, the horn didn't work, so every time he honked, Ben would shout, "BEEP! BEEP! BEEP! HONK IF YOU'RE GOING TO PROM WITH SUPER BUNNY LACEY PEMBERTON! HONK, HONK!"
tr_translation: He started hitting the car horn, but of course, the horn didn't work, so he shouted every time he hit it: "BEEP! BEEP! BEEP! IF LOYAL BUNNY LACEY PEMBERTON IS GOING TO THE PROM WITH YOU, HONK! HONK, SWEETIE, HONK!"
es_translation: He started honking the horn, but of course it didn't work, so every time he honked, he shouted: BEEP! BEEP! BEEP! HONK IF YOU'RE GOING TO THE DANCE WITH A TURKEY, WITH LACEY PEMBERTON! HONK, BABY, HONK!

Multiple_ents: ['becca', 'ben', 'becca arrington', 'lacey', 'ben el sangriento', 'margo', 'ben bỉ bựa', 'bloody ben']
en: Ben could hardly shut up the whole way home. “You know what did it? Aside from desperation? I guess she and Becca Arrington are fighting because Becca’s, you know, a cheater, and I think she started to feel bad about the whole Bloody Ben thing. She didn’t say that, but she sort of acted it. So in the end, Bloody Ben is going to get me some puh-lay-hey.” I was happy for him and everything, but I wanted to focus on the game of getting to Margo.
vi: Ben hầu như không tắt loa trên suốt đường về nhà. “Các ông có biết điều gì đã nên chuyện không? Ngoài cảm giác tuyệt vọng ra nhé? Tôi đoán là Lacey và Becca Arrington đang chiến nhau vì các ông cũng biết rồi đấy, Becca là một nàng lừa đảo lắm chiêu. Tôi cũng nghĩ chắc Lacey bắt đầu ăn năn về vụ dựng chuyện Ben Bỉ Bựa. Cậu ấy không nói hẳn ra, nhưng có cư xử đại loại như thế. Thế là rút cục, Ben Bỉ Bựa sẽ giành lại cho tôi chút tò-te-tí-toét.” Tôi rất mừng cho Ben và tất cả, nhưng tôi muốn tập trung cho cuộc chơi dẫn đến Margo.
tr: Eve dönüş yolu boyunca Ben hemen hemen hiç çenesini kapatamadı. “Bunun sebebi ne biliyor musun? Çaresizliğin yanında yani. Sanırım Becca Arrington’la, Becca’mn dalavereci olması yüzünden filan kavga ediyorlar ve bütün o Kanlı Ben meselesi yüzünden kendisini kötü hissetmeye başladığını düşünüyorum. Bunu söylemedi ama bir nevi öyle davrandı. Yani sonuçta, Kanlı Ben bana biraz oyuncuk getirecek.” Tamam, Ben adına seviniyordum ama Margo’ya ulaşma oyununa odaklanmak istiyordum.
es: Apenas pudo mantener la boca cerrada de camino a casa. —¿Sabéis por qué ha aceptado? ¿Aparte de porque estuviera desesperada? Creo que se ha peleado con Becca Arrington, porque ya sabéis, Becca la engañó, y creo que empezaba a sentirse mal por el tema de Ben el Sangriento. No me lo ha dicho, pero lo parecía. Así que al final tendré temita gracias a Ben el Sangriento. Me alegraba por él, por supuesto, pero quería centrarme en cómo llegar a Margo.
vi_translation: Ben hardly turned off the speaker the entire way home. “Do you guys know what has really happened? Besides the feeling of despair? I guess Lacey and Becca Arrington are fighting because, as you all know, Becca is quite the cunning trickster. I also think Lacey is starting to feel remorseful about the whole Ben Bullshit thing. He didn’t say it outright, but he behaved somewhat like that. So in the end, Ben Bullshit will get me some attention.” I was very happy for Ben and all, but I wanted to focus on the game leading to Margo.
tr_translation: On the way home, Ben almost couldn't shut his mouth. "Do you know why that is? Besides the desperation, I mean. I think he's fighting with Becca Arrington because Becca is being sneaky and all that Bloody Ben stuff is making him feel bad. He didn't say it, but he kind of acted that way. So in the end, Bloody Ben is going to bring me some toys." Okay, I was happy for Ben, but I wanted to focus on the game of reaching Margo.
es_translation: He could barely keep his mouth shut on the way home. —Do you know why she accepted? Apart from being desperate? I think she had a fight with Becca Arrington, because you know, Becca deceived her, and I think she was starting to feel bad about the whole Bloody Ben thing. She didn't tell me, but it seemed like it. So in the end, I'll have some drama thanks to Bloody Ben. I was happy for him, of course, but I wanted to focus on how to reach Margo.

en: “Do you guys have any ideas at all?”
vi: “Các ông có thêm ý tưởng gì chưa?”
tr: “Çocuklar, sizin bir fikriniz var mı?
es: —Chicos, ¿se os ha ocurrido alguna idea?
vi_translation: "Do you have any more ideas?"
tr_translation: "Children, do you have any ideas?""
es_translation: —Guys, has any idea occurred to you?

en: It was quiet for a moment, and then Radar looked at me through the rearview mirror and said, “That doors thing is the only one marked different from the others, and it’s also the most random; I really think that’s the one with the clue. What is it again?”
vi: Cả bọn lặng đi chốc lát, rồi Radar nhìn tôi qua gương chiếu hậu và nói, “Câu thơ về cánh cửa là chỗ duy nhất đánh dấu khác những câu còn lại, và nó cũng ngẫu nhiên nhất, tôi thực sự cho rằng câu đó găm một manh mối. Cả câu là gì ấy nhỉ?”
tr: Kasa bir süre sessizlik oldu, sonra Radar dikiz aynasından bana baktı. “O kapı şeyi diğerlerinden farklı işaretlenmiş tek şey ve ayrıca en rastgele olam; içinde ipucu olanın gerçekten o olduğunu düşünüyorum. Neydi bu arada?
es: Por un momento no hubo respuesta, pero luego Radar me miró por el retrovisor y dijo: —Lo de las puertas es lo único marcado de diferente color que lo demás, y es además lo más inesperado. Creo que la pista está ahí. ¿Cómo decía?
vi_translation: The whole group fell silent for a moment, then Radar looked at me through the rearview mirror and said, "The line about the door is the only one that stands out from the rest, and it's also the most random. I really think that line holds a clue." "What is the whole line again?"
tr_translation: There was a moment of silence, then Radar looked at me through the rearview mirror. "That door thing is the only one marked differently from the others, and also the most random one; I really think the one with the clue is that one." By the way, what was it?"
es_translation: For a moment there was no response, but then Radar looked at me through the rearview mirror and said: —The thing about the doors is the only thing marked in a different color from the rest, and it's also the most unexpected. I think the clue is there. What did it say?

en: “‘Unscrew the locks from the doors! / Unscrew the doors themselves from their jambs!’” I replied.
vi: “Tháo mở ổ khóa khỏi cánh cửa!/ Tháo mở chính cánh cửa khỏi khung!” tôi nhắc lại.
tr: “Sökün kilitleri kapılardan! / Sökün kapılan kasalanndan!” diye cevapladım.
es: —«¡Arrancad los cerrojos de las puertas! / ¡Arrancad las puertas de los goznes!», le respondí.
vi_translation: “Remove the lock from the door! / Remove the door itself from the frame!” I repeated.
tr_translation: "Remove the locks from the doors! / Remove the doors from their frames!" I replied.
es_translation: —"Tear the bolts from the doors! / Tear the doors from their hinges!" I replied.

en: “Admittedly, Jefferson Park is not really the best place to unscrew the doors of closed-mindedness from their jambs,” Radar allowed. “Maybe that’s what she’s saying. Like the paper town thing she said about Orlando? Maybe she’s saying that’s why she left.”
vi: “Phải thừa nhận rằng, Jefferson Park không thực sự là nơi lí tưởng để tháo mở những cánh cửa của đầu-óc-hạn-hẹp khỏi khung cửa,” Radar xác thực. “Có lẽ đó là điều Margo muốn nói. Như cậu ấy đã nói Orlando là thành phố giấy nhỉ? Có thể Margo đang giải thích tại sao cậu ấy bỏ đi.”
tr: Radar, “Kuşkusuz, Jefferson Park, dar görüşlülüğün kapılarını kasalarından sökmek için en iyi yer değil,” diye kabullendi. “Belki Margo’nun söylediği budur. Orlando’yla ilgili dediği şu kâğıttan kent şeyi gibi? Belki gitme nedeninin bu olduğunu söylüyordur.”
es: —Hay que admitir que Jefferson Park no es el mejor sitio para arrancar de sus goznes las puertas de los estrechos de mente —dijo Radar—. Quizá es lo que quiere decir. Como aquello que dijo de que Orlando es una ciudad de papel. Quizá lo que quiere decir es que por eso se ha marchado.
vi_translation: “I must admit, Jefferson Park isn't really the ideal place to unlock the doors of narrow-mindedness from their frames,” Radar confirmed. “Maybe that's what Margo meant. As she said, Orlando is a paper town, right? Maybe Margo is explaining why she left.”
tr_translation: Radar said, "Undoubtedly, Jefferson Park is not the best place to pry open the doors of narrow-mindedness." "Maybe that's what Margo meant. Like that paper town thing she said about Orlando? Maybe she's saying that's why she left."
es_translation: —You have to admit that Jefferson Park is not the best place to unhinge the doors of the narrow-minded —said Radar—. Maybe that's what he means. Like what he said about Orlando being a paper town. Maybe what he means is that's why he left.

en: Ben slowed for a stoplight and then turned around to look at Radar. “Bro,” he said, “I think you guys are giving Margo Honey-bunny way too much credit.”
vi: Ben giảm tốc độ để dừng trước đèn giao thông, rồi quay sang nhìn Radar. “Này bồ tèo,” Ben nói, “tôi nghĩ các ông đang phức tạp hóa nàng thỏ Margo đấy.”
tr: Ben dur ışığı yüzünden yavaşladı, sonra Radar’a bakmak için arkasını döndü. “Kardeşim,” dedi, “siz çocukların Margo tavşancılına çok fazla itibar ettiğinizi düşünüyorum.
es: Ben frenó en un semáforo y se giró para mirar a Radar. —Colega —dijo—, creo que estáis dando a esa pava demasiado crédito.
vi_translation: Ben slowed down to stop at the traffic light, then turned to look at Radar. "Hey buddy," Ben said, "I think you guys are overcomplicating the Margo rabbit."
tr_translation: I slowed down because of the red light, then turned around to look at Radar. "Brother," he said, "I think you kids are giving too much credit to Margo's rabbit trails."
es_translation: Ben stopped at a traffic light and turned to look at Radar. —Colleague —he said—, I think you are giving that girl too much credit.

en: “How’s that?” I asked.
vi: “Tức là sao?” tôi hỏi.
tr: “Nasıl yani?” diye sordum.
es: —¿Qué quieres decir? —le pregunté.
vi_translation: "What do you mean?" I asked.
tr_translation: “What do you mean?” I asked.
es_translation: —What do you mean? —I asked him.

en: “Unscrew the locks from the doors,” he said. “Unscrew the doors themselves from their jambs.”
vi: “Tháo mở ổ khóa khỏi cánh cửa!” Ben nói. “Tháo mở chính cánh cửa khỏi khung
tr: “Sökün kilitleri kapılardan,” dedi.
es: —«Arrancad los cerrojos de las puertas» —comentó—. «Arrancad las puertas de los goznes».
vi_translation: "Remove the lock from the door!" Ben said. "Remove the door itself from the frame!"
tr_translation: “Remove the locks from the doors,” he said. “Remove the doors from their frames.”
es_translation: —"Tear the bolts off the doors," he commented—. "Tear the doors off the hinges."

en: “Yeah,” I said. The light turned green and Ben hit the gas. RHAPAW shuddered like she might disintegrate but then began to move.
vi: “Ừ nhỉ,” tôi thốt lên. Đèn chuyển sang xanh và Ben nhấn ga. RHAPAW rung bần bật như thể ẻm sắp long rời từng bộ phận, nhưng rồi lại tiếp tục lăn bánh.
tr: “Sökün kapılan kasalarından.” “Evet,” dedim. Işık yeşile döndü ve Ben gaza bastı. SESIB parçalara ayrılacakmış gibi zangırdadı ama sonra hareket etmeye başladı.
es: —Sí —dije yo. El semáforo se puso en verde y Ben pisó el acelerador. El Chuco tembló como si fuera a desintegrarse, pero empezó a moverse.
vi_translation: "Oh right," I exclaimed. The light turned green and Ben stepped on the gas. RHAPAW shook violently as if it was about to fall apart, but then it continued to roll on.
tr_translation: “Yes,” I said. The light turned green and Ben stepped on the gas. SESIB rattled as if it was going to fall apart, but then it started to move.
es_translation: —Yes —I said. The traffic light turned green and Ben stepped on the accelerator. The Chuco trembled as if it were about to disintegrate, but it started to move.

en: “It’s not poetry. It’s not metaphor. It’s instructions. We are supposed to go to Margo’s room and unscrew the lock from the door and unscrew the door itself from its jamb.”
vi: “Đó không phải là thơ. Cũng không phải ẩn dụ. Đó là những hướng dẫn. Chúng ta sẽ phải vào phòng Margo, tháo ổ khóa khỏi cánh cửa phòng và tháo chính cánh cửa khỏi khung bao quanh.”
tr: “Bu şiir değil. Metafor değil. Bunlar talimat. Margo’nun odasma gidip kilidi kapıdan ve kapıyı da kasasından sökmemiz gerekiyor.”
es: —No es poesía. No es una metáfora. Son instrucciones. Se supone que tenemos que ir a la habitación de Margo, arrancar la cerradura de la puerta y arrancar la puerta de sus goznes.
vi_translation: "That is not poetry. Nor is it a metaphor. Those are instructions. We will have to enter Margo's room, remove the lock from the door, and take the door itself off its frame."
tr_translation: “This is not a poem. It is not a metaphor. These are instructions. We need to go to Margo's room, remove the lock from the door, and take the door off its hinges.”
es_translation: —It is not poetry. It is not a metaphor. They are instructions. We are supposed to go to Margo's room, break the lock off the door, and take the door off its hinges.

en: Radar looked at me in the rearview mirror, and I looked back at him. “Sometimes,” Radar said to me, “he’s so retarded that he becomes kind of brilliant.”
vi: Radar nhìn tôi qua gương chiếu hậu, và tôi nhìn lại nó. “Thỉnh thoảng,” Radar nói với tôi, “thằng bạn mình chậm tiêu đến mức trở thành siêu luôn.
tr: Radar dikiz aynasından bana baktı, ben de ona baktım. “Bazen,” dedi Radar bana, “o kadar embesil oluyor ki pırlantaya dönüşüyor.
es: Radar me miró por el retrovisor y le devolví la mirada. —Está tan tarado que a veces acaba siendo un genio —me dijo Radar.
vi_translation: Radar looked at me through the rearview mirror, and I looked back at him. “Sometimes,” Radar said to me, “my friend is so slow that it becomes superhuman.”
tr_translation: Radar looked at me through the rearview mirror, and I looked back at him. “Sometimes,” Radar said to me, “she is so idiotic that she turns into a diamond.”
es_translation: Radar looked at me through the rearview mirror and I returned his gaze. —He's so crazy that sometimes he ends up being a genius —Radar told me.

en: After parking in my driveway, we walked across the strip of grass that separated Margo’s house from mine, just as we had Saturday. Ruthie answered the door and said her parents wouldn’t be home until six; Myrna Mountweazel ran excited circles around us; we went upstairs. Ruthie brought us a toolbox from the garage, and then we all stared at the door leading to Margo’s bedroom for a while. We were not handy people.
vi: Sau khi đỗ xe ở lối đi nhà tôi, tụi tôi đi bộ qua vạt cỏ ngăn nhà Margo và nhà tôi, như đã đi hôm thứ Bảy. Ruthie ra mở cửa và nói bố mẹ nó sáu giờ mới về; Myrna Mountweazel lăng xăng chạy mòng mòng quanh tụi tôi; cả đám lên gác. Ruthie mang cho bọn tôi một hộp dụng cụ từ trong ga-ra, rồi tất cả đứng ngây ra nhìn cửa phòng Margo một lúc. Có đứa nào khéo tay biết xoay xở việc này đâu.
tr: Bizim garaj yoluna park ettikten sonra, Margo’nun evini benimkinden ayıran çimenlikten karşıya geçtik, tıpkı cumartesi yaptığımız gibi. Kapıyı Ruthie açtı ve annesiyle babasının saat altıya kadar evde olmayacaklarını söyledi; Myrna Mountvveazel etrafımızda heyecanla koşarak daireler çizdi; üst kata çıktık. Ruthie garajdan bize bir alet çantası getirdi, sonra hepimiz bir süre Margo’nun odasına giden kapıya baktık. Becerikli insanlar değildik.
es: Aparcamos delante de mi casa y atravesamos la franja de césped que separa la casa de Margo de la mía, como habíamos hecho el sábado. Ruthie abrió la puerta y nos dijo que sus padres no volverían a casa hasta las seis. Myrna Mountweazel, nerviosa, dio vueltas a nuestro alrededor. Subimos al piso de arriba. Ruthie nos llevó una caja de herramientas del garaje, y por un momento nos quedamos todos mirando la puerta de la habitación de Margo. No éramos demasiado mañosos.
vi_translation: After parking in my driveway, we walked across the strip of grass separating Margo's house from mine, just like we did on Saturday. Ruthie opened the door and said her parents wouldn't be home until six; Myrna Mountweazel was bustling around us; we all went upstairs. Ruthie brought us a toolbox from the garage, and then we all stood there staring at Margo's bedroom door for a moment. None of us were handy enough to handle this task.
tr_translation: After parking on our driveway, we crossed the lawn that separated Margo's house from mine, just like we did on Saturday. Ruthie opened the door and said that her parents wouldn't be home until six; Myrna Mountweazel ran around us excitedly in circles; we went upstairs. Ruthie brought us a toolbox from the garage, then we all stared at the door leading to Margo's room for a while. We were not handy people.
es_translation: We parked in front of my house and crossed the strip of grass that separates Margo's house from mine, just as we had done on Saturday. Ruthie opened the door and told us that her parents wouldn't be home until six. Myrna Mountweazel, nervous, circled around us. We went upstairs. Ruthie brought us a toolbox from the garage, and for a moment we all stood staring at the door to Margo's room. We weren't very handy.

en: “What the hell are you supposed to do?” asked Ben.
vi: “Bây giờ chúng ta làm thế quỉ nào được đây?” Ben hỏi.
tr: “Hay lanet, cehennem gibi iş,” dedi Ben.
es: —¿Qué demonios se supone que vais a hacer? —preguntó Ben.
vi_translation: “What the hell are we going to do now?” Ben asked.
tr_translation: “Damn, it's a hellish job,” said Ben.
es_translation: —What the hell are you supposed to do? —asked Ben.

en: “Don’t curse in front of Ruthie,” I said.
vi: “Đừng rủa sả trước mặt Ruthie thế,” tôi nhắc nó.
tr: “Ruthie’nin önünde küfretme,” dedim.
es: —No hables así delante de Ruthie —le dije.
vi_translation: "Don't curse in front of Ruthie," I reminded him.
tr_translation: "Don't swear in front of Ruthie," I said.
es_translation: —Don't talk like that in front of Ruthie —I told him.

en: “Ruthie, do you mind if I say hell?”
vi: “Ruthie, em có phiền khi nghe anh nói đến quỉ không?”
tr: “Ruthie, cehennem desem senin için sakıncası olur mu?
es: —Ruthie, ¿te importa que diga demonios?
vi_translation: "Ruthie, do you mind when I talk about demons?"
tr_translation: “Ruthie, would it be a problem for you if I said hell?”
es_translation: —Ruthie, do you mind if I say damn?

en: “We don’t believe in hell,” she said, by way of answering.
vi: “Quỉ không có thật ạ,” Ruthie nói thay cho câu trả lời.
tr: “Biz cehenneme inanmıyoruz,” diye yanıtladı.
es: —No creemos en el demonio —le contestó la niña.
vi_translation: “Ghosts aren't real,” Ruthie said in response.
tr_translation: “We don't believe in hell,” he replied.
es_translation: —We don't believe in the devil —the girl replied to him.

en: Radar interrupted. “People,” he said. “People. The door.” Radar dug out a Phillips-head screwdriver from the mess of a toolbox and knelt down, unscrewing the locking doorknob. I grabbed a bigger screwdriver and tried to unscrew the hinges, but there didn’t seem to be any screws involved. I looked at the door some more. Eventually, Ruthie got bored and went downstairs to watch TV.
vi: Radar chen vào. “Nào,” nó dõng dạc, “tập trung vào nào. Cánh cửa.” Radar bới một cây tua-vít đầu có cạnh từ đám dụng cụ ra và cúi xuống, tháo tay nắm cửa. Tôi vớ một cái tua-vít to hơn và cố tháo bản lề, nhưng có vẻ không có đinh vít nào. Tôi săm soi cánh cửa thêm chút nữa. Rút cục, Ruthie chán, bỏ xuống nhà xem ti-vi.
tr: Radar araya girdi. “Millet,” dedi. “Millet. Kapı.” Darmadağınık alet çantasını kurcalayıp bir yıldız tornavida çıkardı ve diz çöktü, kilidin olduğu kapı kolunu söküyordu. Daha büyük bir tornavida alıp menteşeleri sökmeye çalıştım ama hiçbir vida yok gibi görünüyordu. Kapıya biraz daha baktım. En sonunda Ruthie sıkıldı ve televizyon izlemek için aşağı indi.
es: Radar interrumpió. —Tíos —dijo—. Tíos, la puerta. Radar sacó un destornillador del montón de herramientas, se arrodilló y desatornilló el pomo de la puerta. Yo cogí un destornillador más grande e intenté desatornillar las bisagras, pero no parecía que hubiera tornillos, así que me dediqué a buscarlos. Al final Ruthie se aburrió y se fue a ver la tele.
vi_translation: Radar interrupted. "Now," he said firmly, "let's focus. The door." Radar pulled out a flathead screwdriver from the pile of tools and bent down to remove the door handle. I grabbed a larger screwdriver and tried to remove the hinges, but there didn't seem to be any screws. I examined the door a bit more. Eventually, Ruthie got bored and went downstairs to watch TV.
tr_translation: Radar intervened. "Folks," he said. "Folks. The door." He rummaged through the messy toolbox, pulled out a Phillips screwdriver, and knelt down, removing the door handle where the lock was. I tried to take a larger screwdriver to remove the hinges, but there didn't seem to be any screws. I looked at the door a bit more. Finally, Ruthie got bored and went downstairs to watch TV.
es_translation: Radar interrupted. —Uncles —he said—. Uncles, the door. Radar took a screwdriver from the pile of tools, knelt down, and unscrewed the door handle. I grabbed a larger screwdriver and tried to unscrew the hinges, but there didn't seem to be any screws, so I set about looking for them. In the end, Ruthie got bored and went to watch TV.

en: Radar got the doorknob loose, and we each, in turn, peered inside at the unpainted, unfinished wood around the knob. No message. No note. Nothing. Annoyed, I moved onto the hinges, wondering how to open them. I swung the door open and shut, trying to understand its mechanics. “That poem is so damned long,” I said. “You’d think old Walt could have taken a line or two to tell us how to unscrew the door itself from its jamb.”
vi: Radar đã nới lỏng được tay nắm cửa, và chúng tôi lần lượt ghé mắt quan sát phía trong phần gỗ thô, không sơn quanh tay nắm. Không có lời nhắn nào. Không một mảnh ghi chú nào. Không gì cả. Bực mình, tôi quay lại với bản lề, loay hoay không biết phải tháo ra thế nào. Tôi mở cửa ra rồi đóng lại, cố tìm hiểu nguyên lí của thanh bản lề. “Cái bài thơ ấy dài lê thê đến gớm,” tôi nói. “Các ông có nghĩ cụ nhà thơ Walt đã viết đâu đó một hai dòng hướng dẫn tháo mở cánh cửa khỏi khung như thế nào không?”
tr: Radar kapı kolunu gevşetti ve her birimiz, sırayla, kolun etrafındaki boyasız, cilasız tahtamn içine dikkatle baktık. Mesaj yoktu. Not yoktu. Sıkılmış bir halde, nasıl açacağımı merak ederek menteşeler üzerinde çalışmaya devam ettim, işleyişini anlamaya çalışarak kapıyı açıp kapattım. “Şu şiir o kadar uzun ki,” dedim, “yaşlı Walt en azından bir iki dizeyi bize kapıyı kasasından nasıl sökeceğimizi anlatmak için ayırır diye düşünüyor insan.
es: Radar sacó el pomo, y uno a uno echamos un vistazo al agujero sin pintar y sin pulir. Ningún mensaje. Ninguna nota. Nada. Enfadado, volví a mirar las bisagras preguntándome cómo abrirlas. Abrí y cerré la puerta intentando entender el mecanismo. —El poema es jodidamente largo —dije—. ¿Creéis que el viejo Walt recurrió a un verso o dos para contarnos cómo arrancar la puerta de sus goznes?
vi_translation: Radar managed to loosen the door handle, and we took turns peeking inside the rough, unpainted wood around the handle. There was no message. Not a single note. Nothing at all. Annoyed, I turned back to the hinge, fumbling with how to remove it. I opened and closed the door, trying to understand the principle of the hinge bar. “That poem is disgustingly long,” I said. “Do you think old poet Walt wrote a line or two somewhere on how to remove the door from the frame?”
tr_translation: Radar loosened the door handle and each of us, in turn, carefully looked inside the unpainted, unpolished wood around the handle. There was no message. There was no note. Feeling frustrated, I continued to work on the hinges, wondering how to open it, opening and closing the door to understand its mechanism. "That poem is so long," I said, "One thinks that old Walt would at least spare a line or two to tell us how to remove the door from its frame.""
es_translation: Radar took out the knob, and one by one we took a look at the unpainted and unpolished hole. No message. No note. Nothing. Angry, I looked again at the hinges, wondering how to open them. I opened and closed the door, trying to understand the mechanism. —The poem is fucking long —I said—. Do you think old Walt resorted to a verse or two to tell us how to rip the door off its hinges?

en: Only when he responded did I realize Radar was sitting at Margo’s computer. “According to Omnictionary,” he said, “we’re looking at a butt hinge. And you just use the screwdriver as a lever to pop out the pin. Incidentally, some vandal has added that butt hinges function well because they are powered by farts. Oh, Omnictionary. Wilt thou ever be accurate?”
vi: Chỉ khi Radar lên tiếng tôi mới nhận ra nó đang ngồi trước máy tính của Margo. “Theo Toàn Thư Đủ Thứ,” nó nói, “chúng ta phải tìm bản lề lá trước. Chỉ cần dùng tua-vít để nậy chốt lên thôi. Nhân tiện, gã nỡm nào đó còn chua thêm rằng bản lề lá hoạt động trơn tru khi bị bể làn. Ôi, Toàn Thư Đủ Thứ. Liệu ngài có giỡn không đây?”
tr: Radar’m Margo’nun bilgisayarında oturduğunu, ancak bana cevap verdiğinde fark ettim. “Omnictionary’ye göre,” dedi, “bir kapı menteşesine bakıyoruz. Ve tornavidayı menteşeyi yerinden çıkarmak için bir kaldıraç olarak kullanıyormuşsun. Şans eseri bir vandalın kapı menteşelerinin osuruklarla güçlendirildikleri için sağlam olduklarını yazdığını keşfettim. Ah, Omnictionary. Hiç eksiksiz bilgi verecek misin acaba?
es: No me di cuenta de que Radar estaba sentado frente al ordenador de Margo hasta que me contestó. —Según el Omnictionary, estamos buscando un pernio. Y el destornillador se utiliza como palanca para levantar el clavo. Por cierto, algún gamberro ha colgado que los pernios funcionan bien porque se propulsan a pedos. Ay, Omnictionary, ¿llegarás algún día a ser exacto?
vi_translation: Only when Radar spoke did I realize he was sitting in front of Margo's computer. "According to the Complete Encyclopedia of Everything," he said, "we need to find the leaf hinge first. Just use a screwdriver to pry the pin up. By the way, some idiot also added that the leaf hinge works smoothly when the lane is broken. Oh, Complete Encyclopedia of Everything. Are you kidding me?”
tr_translation: I only realized Radar was sitting at Margo's computer when he responded to me. “According to Omnictionary,” he said, “we are looking at a door hinge. And you are using the screwdriver as a lever to remove the hinge. By chance, I discovered that a vandal wrote that the door hinges are strong because they are reinforced with farts. Ah, Omnictionary. Will you ever provide complete information?”
es_translation: I didn't realize that Radar was sitting in front of Margo's computer until he answered me. —According to the Omnictionary, we are looking for a hinge. And the screwdriver is used as a lever to lift the nail. By the way, some prankster has posted that hinges work well because they are propelled by farts. Oh, Omnictionary, will you ever be accurate?

en: Once Omnictionary had told us what to do, doing it proved surprisingly easy. I got the pin off each of the three hinges and then Ben pulled the door away. I examined the hinges, and the unfinished wood of the doorway. Nothing.
vi: Một lần nữa Toàn Thư Đủ Thứ đã cho chúng tôi biết phải làm gì, và thực hành thì dễ không ngờ. Tôi tháo được chốt khỏi ba bản lề và Ben nhấc cánh cửa ra. Tôi xem xét kĩ lưỡng bản lề, và phần gỗ thô trên khung cửa. Không có gì.
tr: Omnictionary bize ne yapacağımızı söyler söylemez, yapmanın şaşırtıcı derecede kolay olduğu ortaya çıktı. Kapıyı üç menteşeden çıkardım, sonra Ben kapıyı ayırdı. Menteşeleri ve kapı aralığının cilasız tahtasını inceledim. Hiçbir şey yoktu.
es: Una vez que el Omnictionary nos había explicado lo que hacer, resultó sorprendentemente fácil. Saqué el clavo de cada una de las tres bisagras, y Ben retiró la puerta. Inspeccioné las bisagras y los trozos de madera sin pulir del marco. Nada.
vi_translation: Once again, the Complete Book of Everything has shown us what to do, and the practice was unexpectedly easy. I removed the pins from the three hinges, and Ben lifted the door out. I carefully examined the hinges and the rough wood on the door frame. Nothing.
tr_translation: As soon as Omnictionary told us what to do, it turned out to be surprisingly easy to do. I removed the door from its three hinges, then Ben separated the door. I examined the hinges and the unfinished wood of the door frame. There was nothing.
es_translation: Once the Omnictionary had explained to us what to do, it turned out to be surprisingly easy. I took the nail out of each of the three hinges, and Ben removed the door. I inspected the hinges and the rough pieces of wood from the frame. Nothing.

en: “Nothing on the door,” Ben said. Ben and I placed the door back in place, and Radar pounded in the pins with the screwdriver’s handle.
vi: “Cánh cửa chẳng có gì,” Ben nói. Ben và tôi cùng lắp cánh cửa lại như cũ, và Radar đóng lại đinh bằng phần tay cầm của tua-vít.
tr: “Kapıda hiçbir şey yok,” dedi Ben. Ben’le kapıyı yerine yerleştirdik ve Radar tornavidanın arkasıyla menteşeleri yerine oturttu.
es: —En la puerta no hay nada —dijo Ben. Volvimos a colocar la puerta y Ben empujó los clavos con el mango del destornillador.
vi_translation: "The door has nothing," Ben said. Ben and I reassembled the door as it was, and Radar hammered the nails back in with the handle of a screwdriver.
tr_translation: "There's nothing at the door," said Ben. Ben and I put the door back in place and Radar secured the hinges with the back of the screwdriver.
es_translation: —There is nothing at the door —said Ben. We put the door back in place and Ben pushed the nails in with the handle of the screwdriver.

en: Radar and I went over to Ben’s house, which was architecturally identical to mine, to play a game called Arctic Fury. We were playing this game-within-a-game where you shoot each other with paintballs on a glacier. You received extra points for shooting your opponents in the balls. It was very sophisticated. “Bro, she’s definitely in New York City,” Ben said. I saw the muzzle of his rifle around a corner, but before I could move, he shot me between the legs. “Shit,” I mumbled.
vi: Radar và tôi sang nhà Ben, ngôi nhà có kiến trúc giống hệt nhà tôi, và chơi một trò gọi là Bắc Cực Nổi Giận. Đây là một kiểu trò-chơi-ở-trong-trò-chơi, các đấu thủ bắn nhau bằng bom sơn lên băng. Nếu bắn trúng tờ-rym của đối phương thì sẽ được điểm thưởng. Tóm lại là một trò khá tinh vi phức tạp. “Các ông ạ, nhất định Margo đang ở New York,” Ben nói. Tôi thấy nòng súng của nó thấp thoáng ở một góc, nhưng tôi chưa kịp nhúc nhích gì thì nó đã bắn trúng phóc giữa hai chân tôi. “Đồ khỉ,” tôi lầm bầm.
tr: Radarla Kutup Hiddeti adh bir oyun oynamak için Ben’in mimari olarak benimkiyle aynı olan evine gittik. Bir buzulun üstünde oyuncuların birbirini boya toplarıyla vurduğu “oyun içinde oyun” tarzındaydı. Rakibi hayalarından vurunca fazladan puan almıyordu. Çok karmaşıktı gerçekten. “Kardeşim, Margo kesinlikle New York’ta,” dedi Ben. Bir köşeden çıkan tüfeğinin ucunu gördüm ama ben hareket edemeden bacaklarımın arasından beni vurdu. “Kahretsin,” diye homurdandım.
es: Radar y yo fuimos a casa de Ben, que era arquitectónicamente idéntica a la mía, a jugar a un videojuego llamado Arctic Fury. Jugamos a ese juego dentro del juego en el que disparabas a los demás con balas de pintura en un glaciar. Recibías puntos extra por disparar a tus enemigos en los huevos. Era muy sofisticado. —Colega, está en Nueva York, seguro —dijo Ben. Vi la boca de su rifle detrás de una esquina, pero, antes de que pudiera moverme, me disparó entre las piernas. —Mierda —murmuré.
vi_translation: Radar and I went to Ben's house, which had the exact same architecture as mine, and played a game called Angry Arctic. This is a kind of game-within-a-game, where players shoot each other with paint bombs on ice. If you hit the opponent's crotch, you get bonus points. In short, it's a pretty sophisticated and complex game. "Guys, Margo must be in New York," Ben said. I saw the barrel of his gun peeking from a corner, but before I could move, he shot me right between the legs. "Damn it," I muttered.
tr_translation: We went to Ben's house, which had the same architecture as mine, to play a game called Polar Fury with radar. It was in the style of a "game within a game" where players hit each other with paintballs on top of a glacier. You didn't get extra points for hitting the opponent in the groin. It was really very complicated. "Dude, Margo is definitely in New York," said Ben. I saw the tip of his gun coming from around a corner, but before I could move, he hit me between my legs. "Damn it," I grumbled.
es_translation: Radar and I went to Ben's house, which was architecturally identical to mine, to play a video game called Arctic Fury. We played that game within the game where you shot others with paintballs on a glacier. You got extra points for shooting your enemies in the balls. It was very sophisticated. —Colleague, he is in New York, for sure —said Ben. I saw the muzzle of his rifle behind a corner, but before I could move, he shot me between the legs. —Shit —I murmured.

en: Radar said, “In the past, it seems like her clues have pointed to a place. She tells Jase; she leaves us clues involving two people who both lived in New York City most of their lives. It does make sense.”
vi: Radar nói, “Nhìn lại, có vẻ như các manh mối của Margo dẫn đến một nơi. Cậu ấy nói với Jase; và để lại cho chúng ta gợi ý gắn với hai người hầu như cả đời chỉ sống ở New York. Rất hợp lô-gíc.
tr: Radar, “Geçmişte, ipuçları bir yeri göstermiş gibi görünüyor. Jase’e söylüyor; bize her ikisi de hayatlarının çoğunu New York’ta geçirmiş iki kişiyle ilgili ipuçları bırakıyor. Kulağa mantıklı geliyor,” dedi.
es: —Parece que otras veces sus pistas apuntaban a un lugar. Se lo dice a Jase y nos deja pistas de dos personas que vivieron en Nueva York la mayor parte de su vida —dijo Radar—. Tiene sentido.
vi_translation: Radar said, "Looking back, it seems like Margo's clues lead to one place. She told Jase; and left us hints tied to two people who have spent almost their entire lives in New York. Very logical."
tr_translation: Radar, "In the past, clues seemed to point to a place. He tells Jase; they leave us clues about two people who have spent most of their lives in New York. It sounds logical," he said.
es_translation: —It seems that other times her clues pointed to a place. She tells Jase and leaves us clues about two people who lived in New York for most of their lives —said Radar—. It makes sense.

en: Ben said, “Dude, that’s what she wants.” Just as I was creeping up on Ben, he paused the game. “She wants you to go to New York. What if she arranged to make that the only way to find her? To actually go?”
vi: Ben nói, “Đó là những gì Margo muốn, các bồ ạ.” Tôi vừa mon men lại gần Ben thì nó lại tạm dừng trò chơi. “Cậu ấy muốn ông đi đến New York. Giả sử Margo sắp xếp để đó là cách duy nhất tìm ra cậu ấy thì sao? Thực sự đi đến nơi ấy?”
tr: Ben, “Dostum, istediği bu,” dedi. Tam Ben’e doğru sürünürken oyunu durdurdu. “Senden New York’a gitmeni istiyor. Ya bunu, onu bulmanın tek yolu olarak ayarlamışsa? Sahiden gitmeyi.
es: —Colega, eso es lo que quiere —observó Ben. Justo cuando estaba acercándome sigilosamente a Ben, paró el juego. —Quiere que vayas a Nueva York —siguió diciendo Ben—. ¿Qué pasa si lo ha organizado todo para que sea la única manera de encontrarla? Que vayas.
vi_translation: Ben said, "That's what Margo wants, guys." As I was inching closer to Ben, he paused the game again. "She wants you to go to New York. What if Margo arranged it so that was the only way to find her?" "Actually go to that place?"
tr_translation: Ben said, "Buddy, that's what he wants." He stopped the game just as he was crawling towards Ben. "He wants you to go to New York. What if he set this up as the only way to find him? To actually go."
es_translation: —Colleague, that's what he wants —observed Ben. Just as I was stealthily approaching Ben, he stopped the game. —He wants you to go to New York —Ben continued saying—. What if he has arranged everything so that it's the only way to find her? That you go.

en: “What? It’s a city of like twelve million people.”
vi: “Sao cơ? Đó là một thành phố với mười hai triệu dân mà.”
tr: “Ne? Orası on İM milyon falan nüfuslu bir şehir.
es: —¿Que qué pasa? Es una ciudad de doce millones de personas.
vi_translation: “What? That is a city with twelve million people.”
tr_translation: “What? That place is a city with a population of about ten million.”
es_translation: —What do you mean, what's happening? It's a city of twelve million people.

en: “She could have a mole here,” Radar said. “Who will tell her if you go.”
vi: “Biết đâu Margo có một con chuột chũi gián điệp ở đây,” Radar nói. “Kẻ đó sẽ bắn tin cho Margo nếu ông lên đường.
tr: “Burada bir köstebeği olabilir,” dedi Radar. “Eğer gidersen ona bunu söyleyecek biri.
es: —Podría tener aquí a un espía —dijo Radar—. Si vas, ¿quién se lo dirá?
vi_translation: “Who knows, maybe Margo has a mole spy here,” Radar said. “That person will inform Margo if you hit the road.”
tr_translation: “There might be a mole here,” said Radar. “If you go, there will be someone to tell him this.”
es_translation: —I might have a spy here —said Radar—. If you go, who will tell him?

en: “Lacey!” Ben said. “It’s totally Lacey. Yes! You gotta get on a plane and go to New York City right now. And when Lacey finds out, Margo will pick you up at the airport. Yes. Bro, I am going to take you to your house, and you’re gonna pack, and then I’m driving your ass to the airport, and you’re gonna put a plane ticket on your emergencies-only credit card, and then when Margo finds out what a badass you are, the kind of badass Jase Worthington only dreams about being, all three of us will be taking hotties to prom.”
vi: “Lacey rồi!” Ben thốt lên. “Chắc chắn là Lacey. Đúng vậy! Ông sẽ lên máy bay tới New York ngay bây giờ. Và khi Lacey phát hiện ra, Margo sẽ ra sân bay đón ông. Quá chính xác. Nào, tôi sẽ đưa ông về nhà, ông sẽ chuẩn bị hành lí, rồi tôi sẽ lái xe đưa cái bàn tọa của ông ra sân bay, và ông sẽ mua vé máy bay bằng thẻ tín dụng chỉ-dùng-khi-cần-kíp của ông. Và khi Margo nhận ra ông cứng cựa đến mức nào, hạng cứng cựa mà Jase Worthington nằm mơ cũng không nổi, cả ba chúng ta sẽ cùng đưa các cô nàng nóng bỏng tới dạ hội tốt nghiệp.”
tr: “Lacey!” dedi Ben. “Bu kesinlikle Lacey. Evet! Bir uçağa binip hemen New York’a gitmelisin. Ve Lacey bunu öğrendiğinde, Margo seni havaalanından alacak. Evet. Kardeşim, seni evine götüreceğim, eşyalarını toplayacaksın, sonra arabayla kıçım havaalanına götüreceğim ve sen de sadece acil durumlar için kenarda tuttuğun kredi kartınla bir uçak bileti alacaksın ve sonra Margo senin ne sert bir çocuk, Jase Worthington’ın olmayı ancak hayal edebileceği türde sert bir çocuk olduğunu anladığında, üçümüz de baloya seksi kızları götürüyor olacağız.
es: —¡Lacey! —exclamó Ben—. Seguro que es Lacey. ¡Sí! Tienes que meterte en un avión y volar a Nueva York ahora mismo. Y cuando Lacey se entere, Margo irá al aeropuerto a buscarte. Sí. Colega, voy a llevarte a tu casa, harás la maleta, te llevaré al aeropuerto, comprarás un billete con tu tarjeta de crédito solo para emergencias, y entonces, cuando Margo descubra lo de puta madre que eres, tan de puta madre que Jase Worthington no podría ni soñar con compararse contigo, los tres iremos al baile con tías buenas.
vi_translation: “It's Lacey!” Ben exclaimed. “It must be Lacey. That's right! You will get on a plane to New York right now. And when Lacey finds out, Margo will pick you up at the airport. Exactly. Now, I'll take you home, you'll pack your bags, then I'll drive your butt to the airport, and you'll buy a plane ticket with your emergency-only credit card. And when Margo realizes how tough you are, the kind of toughness that Jase Worthington couldn't even dream of, the three of us will take the hot girls to the prom together.”
tr_translation: “Lacey!” said Ben. “This is definitely Lacey. Yes! You should get on a plane and go to New York immediately. And when Lacey finds out, Margo will pick you up from the airport. Yes. Brother, I will take you to your house, you will pack your things, then I will drive your ass to the airport and you will buy a plane ticket with the credit card you keep on the side just for emergencies, and then when Margo realizes what a tough kid you are, the kind of tough kid Jase Worthington can only dream of being, the three of us will be taking sexy girls to the prom.”
es_translation: —Lacey! —exclaimed Ben—. It's definitely Lacey. Yes! You have to get on a plane and fly to New York right now. And when Lacey finds out, Margo will go to the airport to pick you up. Yes. Buddy, I'm going to take you to your house, you'll pack your bag, I'll drive you to the airport, you'll buy a ticket with your emergency-only credit card, and then, when Margo finds out how freaking awesome you are, so awesome that Jase Worthington couldn't even dream of comparing to you, the three of us will go to the dance with hot chicks.

en: I didn’t doubt there was a flight to New York City leaving shortly. From Orlando, there’s a flight to everywhere leaving shortly. But I doubted everything else. “If you call Lacey . . . ” I said.
vi: Tôi không nghi ngờ gì rằng chẳng phải đợi lâu sẽ có chuyến bay tới New York. Từ Orlando, máy bay đi bất cứ nơi nào đều sẽ sớm cất cánh. Nhưng tôi nghi ngờ tất cả các yếu tố khác. “Nếu ông báo với Lacey...,” tôi nói.
tr: Kısa sürede New York’a giden bir uçak olduğundan şüphem yoktu. Orlando’dan, kısa sürede her yere giden bir uçak vardır. Ama geriye kalan her şeyden şüphem vardı. “Eğer Lacey’yi ararsan...” dedim.
es: No tenía la menor duda de que en las próximas horas habría algún vuelo a Nueva York. Desde Orlando hay vuelos a todas partes a todas horas. Pero dudaba de todo lo demás. —¿Y si llamas a Lacey? —le pregunté.
vi_translation: I have no doubt that it won't be long before there is a flight to New York. From Orlando, planes to anywhere will soon take off. But I doubt all the other factors. "If you inform Lacey...," I said.
tr_translation: I had no doubt that there was a plane going to New York in a short time. From Orlando, there is a plane going everywhere in a short time. But I had doubts about everything else. “If you call Lacey...” I said.
es_translation: He had no doubt that in the next few hours there would be a flight to New York. From Orlando, there are flights everywhere at all hours. But he doubted everything else. —What if you call Lacey? —I asked her.

en: “She’s not going to confess!” Ben said. “Think of all the misdirection they used—they probably only acted like they were fighting so you wouldn’t suspect she was the mole.”
vi: “Lacey sẽ không thú nhận đâu!” Ben nói. “Cứ nghĩ tất cả những trò đánh lạc hướng của họ xem–có khi hai nàng chỉ giả vờ uýnh nhau để ông không nghi ngờ rằng Lacey là chuột chũi.
tr: “İtiraf etmeyecektir!” dedi Ben. ‘Yaptıkları bütün yanlış yönlendirmeleri düşün... Muhtemelen onun köstebek olduğundan şüphelenme diye yalmzca kavga ediyormuş gibi davrandılar.
es: —¡No va a confesar! —me contestó Ben—. Piensa en todo lo que han hecho para despistar. Seguramente fingieron haberse peleado para que no sospecharas que Lacey era la espía.
vi_translation: "Lacey won't confess!" Ben said. "Just think about all their distractions—maybe the two of them are just pretending to fight so you won't suspect that Lacey is the mole."
tr_translation: “He will not confess!” said Ben. ‘Think about all the misdirections they made... They probably just pretended to be fighting so you wouldn't suspect he was the mole.”
es_translation: —He won't confess! —Ben replied to me—. Think about everything they've done to mislead. They probably pretended to have fought so you wouldn't suspect that Lacey was the spy.

en: Radar said, “I don’t know, that doesn’t really add up.” He kept talking, but I was only half listening. Staring at the paused screen, I thought it over. If Margo and Lacey were fake-fighting, did Lacey fake-break-up with her boyfriend? Had she faked her concern? Lacey had been fielding dozens of emails—none with real information—from the flyers her cousin had put in record stores in New York. She was no mole, and Ben’s plan was idiotic. Still, the mere idea of a plan appealed to me. But there were only two and a half weeks left of school, and I’d miss at least two days if I went to New York—not to mention my parents would kill me for putting a plane ticket on my credit card. The more I thought about it, the dumber it was. Still, if I could see her tomorrow. . . . But no. “I can’t miss school,” I finally said. I unpaused the game.
vi: Radar nói, “Tôi không biết nữa, điều đó không thực sự sáng tỏ được gì.” Nó tiếp tục nói, nhưng tôi chỉ nghe nửa chừng. Nhìn trân trối vào màn hình bất động trước mặt, tôi nghĩ mãi về sự việc. Nếu Margo và Lacey chỉ giả vờ giận nhau, liệu Lacey có giả vờ chia tay bạn trai không? Có giả vờ lo lắng không? Lacey đã tự tay xử lí hàng chục e-mail–chẳng cái nào có thông tin thực sự–từ những tờ rơi chị họ cô ấy đã để lại trong các cửa hàng đĩa ghi âm ở New York. Lacey không hề là chuột chũi gián điệp, và kế hoạch của Ben ngớ ngẩn quá. Nhưng, chỉ riêng ý tưởng về một kế hoạch đã lôi cuốn tôi. Cơ mà chỉ còn hai tuần rưỡi nữa là kết thúc năm học, nếu đi New York tôi sẽ phải nghỉ ít nhất hai ngày–chưa kể bố mẹ sẽ giết tôi vì mua vé máy bay bằng thẻ tín dụng. Càng nghĩ tôi càng thấy kế hoạch này xuẩn quá. Nhưng, giá mà mai có thể nhìn thấy cô ấy... Nhưng không. “Tôi không nghỉ học được,” rút cục tôi chốt hạ, rồi tiếp tục trò chơi.
tr: Radar, “Bilmiyorum, gerçekten makul gelmiyor,” dedi. Konuşmaya devam etti ama onu tam dinlemiyordum. Dondurulmuş ekrana bakarak düşünüp taşındım. Eğer Margo ile Lacey yalandan kavga ediyorlarsa, Lacey erkek arkadaşmdan yalandan mı ayrılmıştı? Endişesi de mi yalandı? Lacey kuzeninin New York’taki müzik mağazalarma koyduğu el ilanlarına karşılık olarak gönderilenhiçbirinde gerçek bir bilgi olmayan— düzinelerce eposta cevaplıyordu. Köstebek falan değildi ve Ben’in planı aptalcaydı. Yine de en azından bir plan olması bile hoşuma gitmişti. Fakat okulun bitmesine iki buçuk hafta kalmıştı ve New York’a gidersem en az iki günü kaçıracaktım... Kredi kartımla uçak bileti aldığım için annemle babanım beni Öldüreceğinden bahsetmeme gerek bile yoktu. Hakkında ne kadar çok düşünürsem o kadar aptalca geli yordu. Yine de eğer Margo’yu yarın görebilseydim... Ama hayır. “Okulu aşamam,” dedim sonunda. Oyunu tekrar başlattım.
es: —No lo sé —dijo Radar—, la verdad es que no parece congruente. Siguió hablando, pero solo lo escuché a medias. Miraba la pantalla detenida y pensaba. Si Margo y Lacey habían fingido pelearse. ¿Lacey había fingido romper con su novio? ¿Había fingido estar preocupada? Lacey había respondido a decenas de e-mails —ninguno con información real— de los carteles que su prima había colgado en tiendas de discos de Nueva York. No era una espía. El plan de Ben era una idiotez. Sin embargo, me atraía la mera idea de tener un plan, aunque faltaban solo dos semanas y media para que acabaran las clases, y si iba a Nueva York, perdería al menos dos días, por no decir que mis padres me matarían por comprar un billete de avión con la tarjeta de crédito. Cuanto más lo pensaba, más absurdo me parecía. Aunque si pudiera verla mañana… Pero no. —No puedo faltar a clase —dije por fin. Quité la pausa al juego—.
vi_translation: Radar said, "I don't know, it doesn't really clarify anything." He continued talking, but I only half-listened. Staring at the motionless screen in front of me, I kept thinking about the situation. If Margo and Lacey were just pretending to be mad at each other, would Lacey pretend to break up with her boyfriend? Pretend to be worried? Lacey had personally handled dozens of emails—none of which had any real information—from the flyers her cousin had left in record stores in New York. Lacey was not a spy mole, and Ben's plan was too ridiculous. But, the very idea of a plan intrigued me. However, with only two and a half weeks left until the end of the school year, if I went to New York, I would have to miss at least two days—not to mention my parents would kill me for buying a plane ticket with a credit card. The more I thought about it, the more absurd this plan seemed. But, if only I could see her tomorrow... But no. "I can't skip school," I finally concluded, then continued the game.
tr_translation: Radar said, "I don't know, it really doesn't seem reasonable." He continued talking, but I wasn't really listening to him. I pondered while staring at the frozen screen. If Margo and Lacey were pretending to fight, had Lacey also pretended to break up with her boyfriend? Was her concern also fake? Lacey was responding to dozens of emails—none of which contained any real information—in response to the flyers her cousin had put up in music stores in New York. She wasn't a mole or anything, and Ben's plan was stupid. Still, I liked that there was at least a plan. But there were only two and a half weeks left until school ended, and if I went to New York, I would miss at least two days... Not to mention that my mom and dad would kill me for buying a plane ticket with my credit card. The more I thought about it, the more foolish it seemed. was tiring. Still, if I could see Margo tomorrow... But no. "I can't skip school," I said finally. I restarted the game.
es_translation: —I don't know —said Radar—, the truth is that it doesn't seem consistent. He kept talking, but I only half-listened. I was staring at the frozen screen and thinking. If Margo and Lacey had pretended to fight. Had Lacey pretended to break up with her boyfriend? Had she pretended to be worried? Lacey had responded to dozens of emails —none with real information— from the posters her cousin had put up in record stores in New York. She wasn't a spy. Ben's plan was idiotic. However, I was attracted to the mere idea of having a plan, even though there were only two and a half weeks left until classes ended, and if I went to New York, I would lose at least two days, not to mention that my parents would kill me for buying a plane ticket with the credit card. The more I thought about it, the more absurd it seemed to me. Although if I could see her tomorrow... But no. —I can't miss class —I finally said. I unpaused the game—.

en: “I have a French quiz tomorrow.”
vi: “Mai tôi phải làm bài kiểm tra tiếng Pháp.”
tr: “Yarın Fransızca sınavım var.
es: Mañana tengo un examen de francés.
vi_translation: "I have a French test tomorrow."
tr_translation: "I have a French exam tomorrow."
es_translation: Tomorrow I have a French exam.

en: “You know,” Ben said, “your romanticism is a real inspiration.”
vi: “Ông biết không,” Ben nói. “Trào lưu lãng mạn chủ nghĩa của ông là một nguồn cảm hứng thực sự.
tr: “Romantizmin gerçekten ilham verici,” dedi Ben.
es: —¿Sabes? —preguntó Ben—. Tu romanticismo es toda una inspiración.
vi_translation: "You know," Ben said. "Your romanticism is a true source of inspiration."
tr_translation: "Your romanticism is truly inspiring," said Ben.
es_translation: —You know? —asked Ben—. Your romanticism is quite an inspiration.

en: I played for a few more minutes and then walked across Jefferson Park back home.
vi: Tôi chơi thêm mấy phút nữa rồi đi bộ qua Công viên Jefferson về nhà.
tr: Birkaç dakika daha oynadım, sonra Jefferson Park’tan karşıya geçerek eve yürüdüm.
es: Jugué un rato más y luego crucé Jefferson Park de vuelta a casa.
vi_translation: I played for a few more minutes and then walked home through Jefferson Park.
tr_translation: I played for a few more minutes, then walked home by crossing Jefferson Park.
es_translation: I played for a while longer and then crossed Jefferson Park back home.

en: My mom told me once about this crazy kid she worked with. He was a completely normal kid until he was nine, when his dad died. And even though obviously a lot of nine-year-olds have had a lot of dead fathers and most of the time the kids don’t go crazy, I guess this kid was an exception.
vi: Có lần mẹ kể với tôi về một đứa bé tâm thần mà mẹ đã chăm sóc. Thằng bé hoàn toàn bình thường cho đến năm lên chín, khi bố nó qua đời. Dù rõ ràng có rất nhiều trẻ chín tuổi bị mất cha, và trong phần lớn các trường hợp không có đứa nào phát điên cả, nhưng có lẽ thằng bé này là ngoại lệ.
tr: Bir keresinde annem, kendisiyle çalışmak zorunda kaldığı deli bir çocuğu anlatmıştı. Dokuz yaşında, babası ölene kadar tamamen normal bir çocukmuş. Bir sürü dokuz yaşında çocuğun bir sürü ölmüş babası olmuştu muhtemelen ve çoğu zaman çocuklar delirmiyorlardı ama tahminimce bu çocuk bir istisnaydı.
es: Mi madre me habló una vez de un niño loco con el que trabajaba. Había sido un niño completamente normal hasta los nueve años, cuando murió su padre. Y aunque es evidente que a un montón de niños de nueve años se les muere el padre, y la mayoría no se vuelven locos, supongo que aquel niño fue una excepción.
vi_translation: There was a time when my mother told me about a mentally ill child she had taken care of. The boy was completely normal until he was nine years old, when his father passed away. Although clearly many nine-year-old children lose their fathers, and in most cases, none of them go insane, perhaps this boy was an exception.
tr_translation: Once, my mother told me about a crazy child she had to work with. He was a completely normal child until the age of nine, when his father died. Probably, many nine-year-old children had many deceased fathers, and most of the time, the children did not go crazy, but I guess this child was an exception.
es_translation: My mother once told me about a crazy boy she worked with. He had been a completely normal boy until he was nine years old, when his father died. And although it is evident that a lot of nine-year-old children lose their fathers, and most do not go crazy, I suppose that boy was an exception.

en: So what he did was he took a pencil and one of those steel compass things, and he started drawing circles onto a piece of paper. All the circles exactly two inches in diameter. And he would draw the circles until the entire piece of paper was completely black, and then he would get another piece of paper and draw more circles, and he did this every day, all day, and didn’t pay attention in school and drew circles all over all of his tests and shit, and my mom said that this kid’s problem was that he had created a routine to cope with his loss, only the routine became destructive. So anyway, then my mom made him cry about his dad or whatever and the kid stopped drawing circles and presumably lived happily ever after. But I think about the circles kid sometimes, because I can sort of understand him. I always liked routine. I suppose I never found boredom very boring. I doubted I could explain it to someone like Margo, but drawing circles through life struck me as a kind of reasonable insanity.
vi: Và thằng bé đã làm thế này, nó lấy cái bút chì và một trong những thứ như com-pa sắt, bắt đầu vẽ những vòng tròn lên giấy. Tất cả các vòng tròn đều có bán kính chính xác năm phân. Thằng bé cứ vẽ mãi những vòng tròn cho đến khi tờ giấy đen kịt, nó sẽ lấy một tờ khác và vẽ tiếp những vòng tròn. Ngày nào nó cũng làm thế, suốt ngày, chẳng chú ý đến học hành, vẽ cả vòng tròn lên kín các bài kiểm tra và bài vở ở trường. Mẹ tôi bảo vấn đề của thằng bé là ở chỗ nó đã tạo ra một thói quen đều đặn để đương đầu với mất mát, chỉ có điều chính thói quen ấy lại hủy hoại nó. Thế là khi mẹ tôi tìm cách khiến thằng bé bật khóc vì người cha đã mất, nó thôi không vẽ vòng tròn nữa, và được cho là từ đó sẽ sống hạnh phúc mãi mãi. Nhưng thỉnh thoảng tôi lại nghĩ đến thằng bé vẽ vòng tròn ấy, vì hình như tôi hiểu được nó. Tôi luôn thích những thói quen đều đặn. Tôi còn nghĩ chắc tôi không bao giờ thấy sự nhàm chán có gì đáng chán lắm. Có lẽ tôi không giải thích nổi điều này cho ai đó như Margo, nhưng vẽ những vòng tròn đi hết đời mình mang lại cho tôi chút cảm giác điên rồ có nghĩa lí.
tr: Sonuçta şöyle bir şey yapmış: Bir kalem ile şu çelik pergellerden almış ve bir kâğıdın üzerine çemberler çizmeye başlamış. Bütün çemberler tam olarak iki santimetre çapındaymış. Çemberleri, kâğıdın tamamı siyah olana kadar çiziyor, sonra başka bir kâğıt alıp daha fazla çember çiziyormuş ve bunu her gün sürekli yapıyormuş. Derslere dikkatini vermeyip sınav kâğıtlarının filan her yerine çember çiziyormuş ve annem çocuğun sorununun, kaybıyla başa çıkmak için yarattığı rutinin yıkıcı hale gelmesi olduğunu söylemişti. Yani her neyse, sonra annem babası için falan ağlamasını sağlamış ve çocuk çember çizmeyi bırakıp galiba sonsuza kadar mutlu yaşamış. Ama bazen çember çocuğu düşünürüm çünkü onu bir nevi anlıyorum. Her zaman rutini sevdim. Sanırım hiçbir zaman can sıkıntısını sıkıcı bulmadım. Margo gibi birine bunu açıklayabileceğimden emin değildim ama hayatta çemberler çizmek bende makul bir tür delilik izlenimi bırakıyordu.
es: Lo que hizo el niño fue coger un lápiz y un compás, y empezar a dibujar circunferencias en una hoja de papel. Todas las circunferencias de exactamente cinco centímetros de diámetro. Y dibujaba circunferencias hasta que toda la hoja de papel quedaba totalmente negra. Entonces cogía otra hoja y dibujaba más circunferencias. Y lo hacía todos los días, a todas horas. No prestaba atención en clase, dibujaba circunferencias en todos los exámenes, y mi madre me dijo que el problema del niño era que había generado una rutina para sobrellevar su pérdida, pero que la rutina se había vuelto destructiva. El caso es que mi madre consiguió que llorara por su padre, y el niño dejó de dibujar circunferencias y al parecer desde entonces vivió feliz. Pero de vez en cuando pienso en el niño de las circunferencias, porque de alguna manera lo entiendo. Siempre me han gustado las rutinas. Supongo que aburrirme nunca me había aburrido demasiado. Suponía que no podría explicárselo a alguien como Margo, pero pasarte la vida dibujando circunferencias me parecía una locura hasta cierto punto razonable.
vi_translation: And the boy did this, he took a pencil and one of those things like a metal compass, and started drawing circles on paper. All the circles had an exact radius of five centimeters. The boy kept drawing circles until the paper was completely black, then he would take another sheet and continue drawing circles. He did this every day, all day long, not paying attention to his studies, drawing circles all over his tests and schoolwork. My mother said the boy's problem was that he had created a regular habit to cope with loss, but it was this very habit that was destroying him. So when my mother tried to make the boy cry for his lost father, he stopped drawing circles, and was said to live happily ever after from then on. But sometimes I think about that boy drawing circles, because it seems like I understand him. I've always liked regular habits. I even think that I never found boredom to be all that boring. Maybe I can't explain this to someone like Margo, but drawing circles for the rest of my life gives me a bit of a crazy sense of meaning.
tr_translation: In the end, he did something like this: He took one of those steel compasses with a pencil and started drawing circles on a piece of paper. All the circles were exactly two centimeters in diameter. He would draw circles until the entire paper was black, then take another paper and draw more circles, and he did this continuously every day. He wasn't paying attention in classes and was drawing circles all over his exam papers and such, and my mom said that the child's problem was that the routine he created to cope with his loss had become destructive. So anyway, then my mom made him cry for his father or something, and the kid stopped drawing circles and apparently lived happily ever after. But sometimes I think about the circle kid because I kind of understand him. I've always liked routine. I guess I've never found boredom boring. I wasn't sure if I could explain this to someone like Margo, but in life, drawing circles left me with the impression of a reasonable kind of madness.
es_translation: What the boy did was take a pencil and a compass, and start drawing circles on a sheet of paper. All the circles were exactly five centimeters in diameter. And he drew circles until the entire sheet of paper was completely black. Then he would take another sheet and draw more circles. And he did this every day, all the time. He didn't pay attention in class, he drew circles on all the exams, and my mother told me that the boy's problem was that he had created a routine to cope with his loss, but the routine had become destructive. The fact is that my mother managed to make him cry for his father, and the boy stopped drawing circles and apparently lived happily ever since. But every now and then I think about the boy with the circles, because in some way I understand him. I've always liked routines. I suppose that being bored never really bored me too much. I figured I couldn't explain it to someone like Margo, but spending your life drawing circles seemed like a somewhat reasonable madness to me.

en: So I should have felt fine about not going to New York—it was a dumb idea, anyway. But as I went about my routine that night and the next day at school, it ate away at me, as if the routine itself was taking me farther from reuniting with her.
vi: Cho nên tôi cần phải thấy ổn vì quyết định không đi New York–dù sao đó cũng là một ý tưởng dở ẹc. Nhưng khi trôi theo nhịp đều đặn đêm đó và ngày tiếp theo ở trường, nó dần gặm nhấm tôi, như thể chính những lẽ thường tình ấy đang kéo doãng tôi xa khỏi lúc gặp lại cô ấy.
tr: Bu yüzden New York’a gitmeme konusunda kendimi iyi hissetmeliydim... Nasılsa aptalca bir fikirdi. Ama o gece ve sonraki gün kendi rutinimde yol alırken beni yiyip bitirdi, sanki rutinin kendisi beni ona kavuşmaktan daha da uzaklaştırıyor gibiydi.
es: Así que debería haberme sentido bien por no ir a Nueva York. En cualquier caso, era una idiotez. Pero aquella noche, cuando volví a mi rutina, y al día siguiente, en clase, sentía que me corroía por dentro, como si la propia rutina estuviera impidiendo que me reuniera con Margo.
vi_translation: So I need to feel okay about the decision not to go to New York—even though it was a terrible idea anyway. But as the steady rhythm of that night and the next day at school went by, it gradually gnawed at me, as if those very common sense reasons were pulling me away from the moment I would see her again.
tr_translation: That's why I should have felt good about not going to New York... After all, it was a foolish idea. But that night and the next day, as I moved through my own routine, it ate me up, as if the routine itself was pulling me further away from reaching it.
es_translation: So I should have felt good about not going to New York. In any case, it was idiotic. But that night, when I returned to my routine, and the next day, in class, I felt like it was eating me up inside, as if the routine itself was preventing me from meeting Margo.

en: Tuesday evening, when she had been gone six days, I talked to my parents. It wasn’t a big decision or anything; I just did. I was sitting at the kitchen counter while Dad chopped vegetables and Mom browned some beef in a skillet. Dad was razzing me about how much time I’d spent reading such a short book, and I said, “Actually, it’s not for English; it seems like maybe Margo left it for me to find.” They got quiet, and then I told them about Woody Guthrie and the Whitman.
vi: Tối thứ Ba, Margo đã bỏ đi được sáu ngày, tôi nói chuyện với bố mẹ. Đó không phải là một quyết định trọng đại hay gì đó tương tự; tôi chỉ kể thôi. Tôi ngồi bên quầy bếp trong khi bố thái rau và mẹ bỏ thịt bò vào áp chảo. Bố chọc tôi, hỏi tôi đã vùi bao nhiêu thời gian vào cuốn sách ngắn tủn ấy, và tôi đáp, “Thực ra không phải vì môn Quốc ngữ, mà hình như Margo đã chủ ý để lại cuốn sách cho con tìm hiểu ạ.” Bố mẹ lặng đi, tôi bèn kể lại những gì liên quan đến Woody Guthrie và Whitman.
tr: Salı akşamı, gitmesinin üzerinden altı gün geçmişken ebeveynlerimle konuştum. Büyük bir karar falan değildi; sadece konuştum. Babam sebzeleri doğrayıp annem tavada biftek kızartırken mutfak tezgâhında oturuyordum. Babam o kadar kısa bir kitabı okumak için ne kadar fazla zaman harcadığımla ilgili beni ağır bir şekilde eleştiriyordu ve ben, “Aslında edebiyat için değil; galiba Margo onu bulmam için bırakmış gibi,” dedim. Sessizleştiler, sonra onlara Woody Guthrie ve Whitmani anlattım.
es: El martes por la tarde, cuando hacía seis días que Margo se había marchado, hablé con mis padres. No se trataba de haber tomado una gran decisión ni nada de eso. Sencillamente hablé. Estaba sentado en la barra de la cocina mientras mi padre picaba verduras y mi madre salteaba carne en una sartén. Mi padre me tomaba el pelo preguntándome cuánto iba a tardar en leer un libro tan breve. —La verdad es que no es para literatura —le dije—. Parece que Margo lo dejó para que lo encontrara. Se quedaron los dos en silencio, y entonces les conté lo de Woody Guthrie y lo de Whitman.
vi_translation: On Tuesday night, Margo had been gone for six days, and I talked to my parents. It wasn't a major decision or anything like that; I just told them. I sat by the kitchen counter while Dad chopped vegetables and Mom put beef in the skillet. Dad teased me, asking how much time I had buried into that short book, and I replied, "Actually, it's not for Literature class, but it seems like Margo intentionally left the book for me to figure out." My parents went silent, so I recounted everything related to Woody Guthrie and Whitman.
tr_translation: On Tuesday evening, six days after she had left, I talked to my parents. It wasn't a big decision or anything; I just talked. While my dad was chopping vegetables and my mom was frying steak in the pan, I was sitting on the kitchen counter. My dad was heavily criticizing me for taking so much time to read such a short book, and I said, "Actually, it's not for literature; I think Margo left it for me to find her." They fell silent, then I told them about Woody Guthrie and Whitman.
es_translation: On Tuesday afternoon, when it had been six days since Margo had left, I talked to my parents. It wasn't about having made a big decision or anything like that. I simply talked. I was sitting at the kitchen counter while my father chopped vegetables and my mother sautéed meat in a pan. My father was teasing me, asking how long it was going to take me to read such a short book. —The truth is that it's not for literature —I told him—. It seems that Margo left it for him to find. They both remained silent, and then I told them about Woody Guthrie and Whitman.

en: “She clearly likes to play these games of incomplete information,” my dad said.
vi: “Con bé rõ là thích chơi trò rắc những mảnh vụn thông tin này,” bố nói.
tr: “Eksik bilgilerle böyle oyunlar oynamayı sevdiği açık,” dedi babam.
es: —Está claro que le gusta jugar a estos juegos de no dar toda la información —observó mi padre.
vi_translation: "The girl clearly likes to play the game of scattering these bits of information," Dad said.
tr_translation: “It's clear that he enjoys playing such games with incomplete information,” said my father.
es_translation: —It's clear that he likes to play these games of not giving all the information —observed my father.

en: “I don’t blame her for wanting attention,” my mom said, and then to me added, “but that doesn’t make her well-being your responsibility.”
vi: “Em không trách Margo khi con bé muốn được quan tâm,” mẹ nói, rồi quay sang tôi nói tiếp, “nhưng như thế không có nghĩa là con phải chịu trách nhiệm về tình trạng của Margo đâu nhé.
tr: “İlgi istediği için onu suçlayamam,” dedi annem, sonra bana bakarak ekledi: “Ama bu onun esenliğini senin sorumluluğun yapmaz.
es: —No la culpo por querer llamar la atención —dijo mi madre, y luego añadió dirigiéndose a mí—: Pero eso no te hace responsable de su bienestar.
vi_translation: “I don't blame Margo for wanting attention,” Mom said, then turned to me and continued, “but that doesn't mean you have to be responsible for Margo's situation.”
tr_translation: “I can't blame her for wanting attention,” said my mother, then added, looking at me: “But that doesn't make her well-being your responsibility.”
es_translation: —I don't blame her for wanting attention —said my mother, and then added, addressing me—: But that doesn't make you responsible for her well-being.

en: Dad scraped the carrots and onions into the skillet. “Yeah, true. Not that either of us could diagnose her without seeing her, but I suspect she’ll be home soon.”
vi: Bố thả cà rốt và hành vào chảo. “Ừm, đúng vậy. Không phải do không gặp trực tiếp thì bố mẹ không tiên lượng, chẩn đoán được về Margo, nhưng bố nghĩ bạn con sẽ sớm về nhà thôi.
tr: Babam havuçları ve soğanları tavaya sıyırdı. “Evet, doğru, ikimiz de onu görmeden teşhis koyamayız belki ama yakında eve döneceğini düşünüyorum.
es: Mi padre echó las zanahorias y las cebollas a la sartén. —Sí, es verdad. Ninguno de los dos podemos diagnosticarla sin haberla visto, aunque sospecho que pronto estará en casa.
vi_translation: Dad dropped the carrots and onions into the pan. "Hmm, that's right. It's not that we can't anticipate or diagnose about Margo just because we haven't met in person, but I think your friend will come home soon."
tr_translation: My father scraped the carrots and onions into the pan. "Yes, it's true, maybe neither of us can diagnose without seeing him, but I think he'll be home soon."
es_translation: My father threw the carrots and onions into the pan. —Yes, it's true. Neither of us can diagnose her without having seen her, although I suspect she will be home soon.

en: “We shouldn’t speculate,” my mom said to him quietly, as if I couldn’t hear or something. Dad was about to respond but I interrupted.
vi: “Ta không nên tiên lượng liều,” mẹ khẽ nói với bố, như thể tôi không nghe được hay đại khái thế. Bố định nói gì đó nhưng tôi đã chen ngang.
tr: “Tahminde bulunmamalıyız,” dedi annem sessizce, sanki onları duyamıyormuşum gibi. Babam karşılık vermek üzereydi ama araya girdim.
es: —No deberíamos especular —le dijo mi madre en voz baja, como si yo no estuviera escuchando. Mi padre iba a contestar, pero lo interrumpí.
vi_translation: "We shouldn't predict the dosage," Mom whispered to Dad, as if I couldn't hear or something like that. Dad was about to say something, but I interrupted.
tr_translation: “We shouldn't make assumptions,” my mother said quietly, as if I couldn't hear them. My father was about to respond, but I intervened.
es_translation: —We shouldn't speculate —my mother said to him in a low voice, as if I weren't listening. My father was about to reply, but I interrupted him.

en: “What should I do?”
vi: “Con nên làm gì ạ?”
tr: “Ben ne yapmalıyım?
es: —¿Qué debo hacer?
vi_translation: "What should I do?"
tr_translation: “What should I do?”
es_translation: —What should I do?

en: “Graduate,” my mom said. “And trust that Margo can take of herself, for which she has shown a great talent.”
vi: “Tốt nghiệp con ạ,” mẹ đáp. “Và tin tưởng rằng Margo có thể tự lo liệu được, con bé vẫn có tài xoay xở đấy thôi.
tr: “Mezun ol,” dedi annem. “Ve Margo’nun kendine bakabileceğine inan, bu konuda harika bir yetenek sergiliyor.
es: —Graduarte —me contestó mi madre—. Y confiar en que Margo puede cuidar de sí misma. Ya ha mostrado un gran talento.
vi_translation: "Graduation, dear," mother replied. "And trust that Margo can handle it herself, she has always been resourceful.""
tr_translation: “Graduate,” said my mother. “And believe that Margo can take care of herself, she shows a remarkable talent in this regard.”
es_translation: —Graduate —my mother answered me—. And trust that Margo can take care of herself. She has already shown great talent.

en: “Agreed,” my dad said, but after dinner, when I went back to my room and played Resurrection on mute, I could hear them talking quietly back and forth. I could not hear the words, but I could hear the worry.
vi: “Bố đồng tình với mẹ,” bố khẳng định. Nhưng sau bữa tối, khi về phòng và chơi Hồi Sinh ở chế độ tắt tiếng, tôi nghe được bố mẹ khẽ trao đổi qua lại với nhau. Không nghe được từng lời cụ thể, nhưng tôi thấy có tiếng nói của sự lo lắng.
