Pseudovisions had been pointed out to me a couple times before on drives with my parents, but I’d never seen one so desolate.
vi: Đi tiếp, chúng tôi chạy xe qua một bảng hiệu gỗ cũ kĩ đề GROVEPOINT ACRES. Một dải đường đen nứt nẻ, chỉ kéo dài vài trăm mét rồi cụt vào một bãi đất xám, chớm báo hiệu rằng Grovepoint Acres là một thứ như mẹ tôi vẫn gọi là “khu đô thị ma”–một tiểu khu bị bỏ hoang trước khi hoàn thành thi công xây dựng. Trước đây mấy lần đi trên đường bố mẹ đã chỉ cho tôi thấy những khu đô thị ma kiểu này, nhưng tôi chưa từng thấy nơi nào hoang vắng tiêu điều đến thế.
tr: Daha uzakta, GROVEPOINT ACRES yazan çürümüş, tahta bir tabela gördük. Çatlak asfalt yol yalmzca altmış metre uzunluktaydı ve ucu, gri görünen geniş bir toprak alanda son buluyor, Grovepoint Acresin, annemin deyimiyle bir semtimsi yani t amamlanamadan önce terk edilmiş bir semt olduğunu gösteriyordu. Semtimsiler daha önce arabayla gezerken annemle babam tarafından birkaç defa bana gösterilmişti ama hiç bu kadar ıssızım görmemiştim.
es: Algo más adelante pasamos por una señal de madera roída que decía GROVEPOINT ACRES. Una carretera con el asfalto agrietado de menos de cien metros iba a parar a una gran extensión de tierra gris que señalaba que Grovepoint Acres era lo que mi madre llamaba una pseudovisión, una urbanización abandonada antes de haberla terminado. Mis padres me habían señalado pseudovisiones un par de veces yendo con ellos en coche, pero nunca había visto ninguna tan desolada.
vi_translation: Continuing on, we drove past an old wooden sign that read GROVEPOINT ACRES. A cracked black road stretched only a few hundred meters before ending in a gray patch of land, hinting that Grovepoint Acres was what my mother used to call a “ghost town”–a subdivision abandoned before construction was completed. On previous trips, my parents had pointed out ghost towns like this to me, but I had never seen one as desolate and barren as this.
tr_translation: Further away, we saw a decayed wooden sign that read GROVEPOINT ACRES. The cracked asphalt road was only sixty meters long and ended in a wide, gray-looking dirt area, indicating that Grovepoint Acres was, as my mother put it, a semi-neighborhood, abandoned before it could be completed. Semi-neighborhoods had been shown to me a few times by my parents while driving around, but I had never seen one this desolate.
es_translation: A little further on, we passed a worn wooden sign that said GROVEPOINT ACRES. A road with cracked asphalt less than a hundred meters long led to a large expanse of gray land, indicating that Grovepoint Acres was what my mother called a pseudovision, an abandoned development before it was completed. My parents had pointed out pseudovisions to me a couple of times while driving with them, but I had never seen one so desolate.

en: We were about five miles past Grovepoint Acres when Radar turned down the music and said, “Should be in about a mile.”
vi: Chúng tôi đi quá Grovepoint Acres khoảng năm dặm thì Radar vặn nhỏ nhạc lại và thông báo, “Tầm một dặm nữa thì đến nhé.
tr: Radar müziği kapatıp, “Yaklaşık bir buçuk kilometre sonra olmalı,” dediğinde Grovepoint Acres’ı yaklaşık sekiz kilometre geçmiştik.
es: Habíamos recorrido poco más de cinco kilómetros desde Grovepoint Acres cuando Radar apagó la música. —Debe de estar a un kilómetro —dijo.
vi_translation: We drove about five miles past Grovepoint Acres when Radar turned down the music and announced, "About one more mile to go.""
tr_translation: Turning off the music on the radar, "It should be in about one and a half kilometers," he said, as we had passed Grovepoint Acres by about eight kilometers.
es_translation: We had traveled a little over five kilometers from Grovepoint Acres when Radar turned off the music. —It must be about a kilometer away —he said.

en: I took a long breath. The excitement of being somewhere other than school had started to wane. This didn’t seem like a place where Margo would hide, or even visit. It was a far cry from New York City. This was the Florida you fly over, wondering why people ever thought to inhabit this peninsula. I stared at the empty asphalt, the heat distorting my vision. Ahead, I saw a strip mall wavering in the bright distance.
vi: Tôi hít một hơi thật sâu. Cơn hứng khởi trốn học đi chơi đã xẹp dần. Nơi này chẳng có vẻ gì là chỗ Margo sẽ trú ẩn, hoặc thậm chí ghé qua. Khác một trời một vực thành phố New York. Đây là phần Florida mà người ta chỉ bay qua, tự hỏi sao có thể tá túc ở mảnh bán đảo này. Tôi chăm chăm nhìn mặt đường nhựa trống trơn, cái nóng như kéo nhòe thị giác. Phía trước, một vệt cửa hàng trông như khu mua sắm dập dờn trong ánh nắng xa xa.
tr: Derin bir nefes aldım. Okuldan başka bir yerde olmanın heyecanı azalmaya başlamıştı. Burası Margo’nun saklanacağı ya da ziyaret edeceği bir yer gibi görünmüyordu. New York’tan bambaşka bir yerdi. Bu, insanlarm bu yarımadaya neden yerleşmeyi düşündüklerini merak ederek üstünden uçup gittiği Florida’ydı işte. Boş asfalta baktım, sıcaklık görüşümü bozuyordu. İleride, parlak alanda titreyen fabrika satış mağazası tipinde bir alışveriş merkezi gördüm.
es: Respiré hondo. La emoción de no estar en el instituto había empezado a disminuir. No parecía un sitio en el que Margo se escondería, ni siquiera al que querría ir. Nada que ver con Nueva York. Era la Florida que ves desde un avión y te preguntas por qué a alguien se le ocurrió un día poblar esta península. Miré el asfalto vacío. El calor me distorsionaba la visión. Frente a nosotros vi un pequeño centro comercial temblando en la distancia.
vi_translation: I took a deep breath. The excitement of skipping school to go out had gradually faded. This place didn't seem like somewhere Margo would hide, or even visit. A world apart from New York City. This is the part of Florida that people just fly over, wondering how anyone could live on this peninsula. I stared at the empty asphalt road, the heat blurring my vision. Ahead, a strip of stores looked like a wavering shopping area in the distant sunlight.
tr_translation: I took a deep breath. The excitement of being somewhere other than school had started to wane. This place didn’t look like somewhere Margo would hide or visit. It was a place completely different from New York. This was Florida, the place people flew over, wondering why anyone would think of settling on this peninsula. I looked at the empty asphalt, the heat was distorting my vision. In the distance, I saw a shopping center shimmering in the bright area, resembling a factory outlet store.
es_translation: I took a deep breath. The excitement of not being at school had started to wane. It didn't seem like a place where Margo would hide, or even want to go. Nothing like New York. It was the Florida you see from a plane and wonder why anyone ever thought to populate this peninsula. I looked at the empty asphalt. The heat distorted my vision. In front of us, I saw a small shopping center shimmering in the distance.

en: “Is that it?” I asked, leaning forward and pointing.
vi: “Đằng kia phải không?” tôi hỏi, rướn lên chỉ.
tr: “Şu mu?” diye sordum öne eğilip işaret ederek.
es: —¿Es aquello? —pregunté inclinándome hacia delante y señalándolo.
vi_translation: "Over there, right?" I asked, leaning forward to point.
tr_translation: "This one?" I asked, leaning forward and pointing.
es_translation: —Is that it? —I asked, leaning forward and pointing at it.

en: “Must be,” Radar said.
vi: “Hẳn rồi,” Radar đáp.
tr: “Öyle olmalı,” dedi Radar.
es: —Debe de serlo —me contestó Radar.
vi_translation: “Of course,” Radar replied.
tr_translation: "It should be so," said Radar.
es_translation: —It must be —Radar answered me.

en: Ben pushed the power button on the stereo, and we all got very quiet as Ben pulled into a parking lot long since reclaimed by the gray sandy dirt. There had once been a sign for these four storefronts. A rusted pole stood about eight feet high by the side of the road. But the sign was long gone, snapped off by a hurricane or an accumulation of decay. The stores themselves had fared little better: it was a single-story building with a flat roof, and bare cinder block was visible in places. Strips of cracked paint wrinkled away from the walls, like insects clinging to a nest. Water stains formed brown abstract paintings between the store windows. The windows were boarded up with warped sheets of particleboard. I was struck by an awful thought, the kind that cannot be taken back once it escapes into the open air of consciousness: it seemed to me that this was not a place you go to live. It was a place you go to die.
vi: Ben ấn nút điều khiển dàn âm thanh, và chúng tôi chìm trong yên lặng khi Ben tấp xe vào bãi đỗ từ lâu đã bị lớp đất cát xám ngoét chiếm dụng. Đã từng có biển hiệu cho bốn cửa hàng ở mặt tiền này. Một cây cột gỉ sét, cao chừng hai mét rưỡi, được cắm bên vệ đường. Nhưng biển hiệu đã tiêu đời từ lâu, bị trận bão nào đó cuốn đi hoặc do cũ kĩ tích tụ. Dãy cửa hàng trụ được khá khẩm hơn: khu nhà một tầng, mái bằng, lác đác trơ ra những khối bê-tông thô. Những dải sơn bong tróc nhăn nhúm bám trên tường, như đám côn trùng ráng bám vào tổ. Cặn nước vẽ những bức tranh trừu tượng màu nâu lên các ô cửa sổ. Cửa sổ được ráp lại từ những tấm gỗ ép. Một ý nghĩ khủng khiếp bung lên trong đầu tôi, thứ suy nghĩ không thể nhốt lại được một khi nó đã len vào bầu khí quyển nhận thức: dường như đây không phải nơi người ta đến để sống. Đây là nơi người ta đến để chết.
tr: Ben radyonun düğmesine basıp arabayı uzun zamandan beri gri kumlu toprağın ele geçirdiği park alanına çekerken hepimiz sessizleştik. Bir zamanlar buradaki dört mağaza için tabelalar konmuştu. Yolun kenarında yaklaşık iki buçuk metre yüksekliğinde paslanmış bir direk duruyordu. Ama tabela uzun zaman Önce gitmişti, bir kasırga yüzünden ya da zaman içinde çürüyerek kopmuştu. Mağazalar biraz daha iyi dayanmıştı: tek katlı, düz çatısı olan bir binaydı ve bazı yerlerde yalın beton sütunlar görülebiliyordu. Çatlak boyalar bir yuvaya yapışmış böcekler gibi büzülmüştü. Su lekeleri, vitrinlerin arasında kahverengi soyut resimler oluşturmuştu. Camlara çarpık sunta levhalar çakılmıştı. Korkunç bir düşünceyle çarpıldım; bilincin semalarına bir kez girdiği zaman geri almamayacak türden bir düşünceydi: Burası bana yaşanılacak türde bir yer gibi görünmüyordu. Burası ölünecek türde bir yerdi.
es: Ben pulsó el botón del equipo de música y nos quedamos los tres callados mientras se metía en un aparcamiento invadido desde hacía tiempo por la arena gris. En su momento había habido un cartel que anunciaba la presencia de cuatro tiendas, porque a un lado de la carretera había un poste raído de más de dos metros, pero el cartel había desaparecido hacía tiempo. Lo habría arrancado un huracán o se habría podrido de viejo. A las tiendas no les había ido mucho mejor. Era un edificio de una sola planta con techo plano, y por algunos sitios se veían los bloques de hormigón al descubierto. Las capas de pintura se desprendían de las paredes como insectos pegados a un nido. Las manchas de humedad formaban dibujos abstractos de color marrón entre los escaparates de las tiendas. Los escaparates estaban sellados con láminas torcidas de aglomerado. De pronto se me pasó por la cabeza una idea horrible, una de esas ideas de las que no puedes librarte en cuanto han cruzado el umbral de la conciencia: me parecía que no era un lugar al que va uno a vivir. Era un lugar al que se va a morir.
vi_translation: Ben pressed the sound system control button, and we were enveloped in silence as Ben pulled the car into a parking lot long claimed by a layer of gray sand. There used to be signs for four stores on this frontage. A rusty pole, about two and a half meters high, was planted by the roadside. But the signs had long since vanished, either blown away by some storm or due to accumulated decay. The row of stores fared slightly better: a single-story building with a flat roof, sparsely dotted with exposed concrete blocks. Strips of peeling paint clung to the walls, like insects desperately holding onto their nests. Water stains painted abstract brown patterns on the window panes. The windows were patched together with plywood sheets. A terrible thought burst into my mind, a thought that couldn't be contained once it had seeped into the atmosphere of awareness: it seemed this was not a place where people came to live. This was a place where people came to die.
tr_translation: When I pressed the radio button and pulled the car into the parking lot that had long been overtaken by gray sandy soil, we all fell silent. Once, signs had been put up for the four stores here. A rusted pole about two and a half meters high stood by the side of the road. But the sign had long gone, either blown away by a hurricane or rotted away over time. The stores had held up a bit better: it was a single-story building with a flat roof, and in some places, bare concrete columns could be seen. The cracked paints had shriveled up like insects clinging to a nest. Water stains had formed brown abstract paintings between the display windows. Crooked plywood boards were nailed to the windows. I was struck by a horrifying thought; the kind of thought that, once it entered the skies of consciousness, would not be taken back: This place did not look like the kind of place to live. This was the kind of place to die.
es_translation: Ben pressed the button on the music system and the three of us fell silent as he drove into a parking lot that had long been overtaken by gray sand. At one time, there had been a sign announcing the presence of four stores, because on one side of the road there was a worn-out post over two meters high, but the sign had long since disappeared. A hurricane might have torn it down or it might have rotted away with age. The stores hadn't fared much better. It was a single-story building with a flat roof, and in some places, the concrete blocks were exposed. The layers of paint were peeling off the walls like insects stuck to a nest. Damp stains formed abstract brown patterns between the shop windows. The shop windows were sealed with crooked sheets of chipboard. Suddenly, a horrible idea crossed my mind, one of those ideas you can't shake off once it crosses the threshold of consciousness: it seemed to me that this wasn't a place where one goes to live. It was a place where one goes to die.

en: As soon as the car stopped, my nose and mouth were flooded with the rancid smell of death. I had to swallow back a rush of puke that rose up into the raw soreness in the back of my throat. Only now, after all this lost time, did I realize how terribly I had misunderstood both her game and the prize for winning it.
vi: Xe vừa dừng lại, mũi và miệng tôi đã ngập trong thứ mùi khăn khẳn của chết chóc. Tôi phải nuốt ngược cơn ói đang dâng lên lờm lợm và đau nhói nơi cuống họng. Chỉ đến lúc này, sau tất cả những thời gian đã mất, tôi mới nhận ra mình đã nhầm tai hại đến thế nào về trò chơi của Margo và phần thưởng cho người chiến thắng.
tr: Araba durur durmaz, burnum ve ağzım ölümün iğrenç kokusuyla kaplandı. Genzime çiğ acılıkla yükselen kusmuğu yutmak zorunda kaldım. Ancak şimdi, bütün bu kaybedilmiş zamandan sonra, hem Margo’nun oyununu hem de kazanmanın ödülünü ne kadar korkunç bir şekilde yanlış anladığımı fark ediyordum.
es: En cuanto el coche se detuvo, el olor a rancio de la muerte me invadió la nariz y la boca. Tuve que tragarme la bocanada de vómito que me subió dolorosamente por la garganta. Solo entonces, tras haber perdido tanto tiempo, entendí lo mal que había interpretado tanto el juego de Margo como el premio por ganarlo.
vi_translation: As soon as the car stopped, my nose and mouth were filled with the pungent smell of death. I had to swallow back the rising nausea that was burning and painful at the back of my throat. Only now, after all the lost time, did I realize how terribly wrong I had been about Margo's game and the reward for the winner.
tr_translation: As soon as the car stopped, my nose and mouth were filled with the disgusting smell of death. I had to swallow the vomit that rose to my throat with raw bitterness. But now, after all this lost time, I realized how terribly I had misunderstood both Margo's game and the reward of winning.
es_translation: As soon as the car stopped, the rancid smell of death invaded my nose and mouth. I had to swallow the mouthful of vomit that painfully rose up my throat. Only then, after having wasted so much time, did I understand how badly I had misinterpreted both Margo's game and the prize for winning it.

en: I get out of the car and Ben is standing next to me, and Radar next to him. And I know all at once that this isn’t funny, that this hasn’t been prove-to-me-you’re-good-enough-to-hang-out-with-me. I can hear Margo that night as we drove around Orlando. I can hear her saying to me, “I don’t want some kids to find me swarmed with flies on a Saturday morning in Jefferson Park.” Not wanting to be found by some kids in Jefferson Park isn’t the same thing as not wanting to die.
vi: Tôi ra khỏi xe, Ben đứng cạnh tôi và Radar cạnh nó. Tôi lập tức hiểu rằng chuyện này không vui chút nào, rằng tất cả không phải là hãy-chứng-minh-rằng-cậu-đủ-bản-lĩnh-chơi-với-tớ. Tôi nghe được tiếng Margo đêm đó khi chúng tôi lái xe lòng vòng Orlando. Tôi nghe được cô ấy nói với tôi, “Tớ không muốn đứa trẻ con nào tìm thấy tớ trong cảnh ruồi bâu kiến đậu vào một sáng thứ Bảy ở Công viên Jefferson đâu.” Không muốn bị trẻ con tìm thấy trong Công viên Jefferson không đồng nghĩa với không muốn chết.
tr: Arabadan çıkıyorum, Ben yanımda duruyor ve Radar da onun yanında. Birden bunun eğlenceli olmadığını, “benimle takılmak için yeterince iyi olduğunu kanıtla” tarzı bir şey olmadığım anlıyorum. O gece Orlando’da gezinirken Margo’yu duyabiliyorum. Bana, “Birkaç çocuğun beni bir cumartesi sabahı üstüme sinekler üşüşmüş halde Jefferson Park’ta bulmasını istemem,” deyişini duyabiliyorum. Birkaç çocuk tarafından Jefferson Park’ta bulunmayı istememek, ölmeyi istememekle aynı şey değil.
es: Salgo del coche. Ben se coloca a mi lado y Radar al lado de Ben. Y de repente sé que esto no tiene gracia, que no se trata de demostrarle que merezco salir con ella. Puedo oír las palabras de Margo la noche en que recorrimos Orlando. La oigo diciéndome: «No quiero que unos críos me encuentren cubierta de moscas un sábado por la mañana en Jefferson Park». No querer que unos críos te encuentren en Jefferson Park no es lo mismo que no querer morir.
vi_translation: I got out of the car, Ben stood next to me, and Radar next to him. I immediately understood that this was not fun at all, that it was not about proving-you-have-the-guts-to-hang-out-with-me. I heard Margo's voice that night when we drove around Orlando. I heard her say to me, "I don't want some kid to find me all covered in flies and ants on a Saturday morning in Jefferson Park." Not wanting to be found by kids in Jefferson Park does not mean not wanting to die.
tr_translation: I am getting out of the car, Ben is standing next to me, and Radar is next to him. Suddenly, I realize that this isn't fun, "hanging out with me I understand that I am not something like "prove that you are good enough." I can hear Margo while wandering around Orlando that night. I can hear her saying to me, “I don’t want a few kids to find me in Jefferson Park on a Saturday morning with flies swarming over me.” Not wanting to be found in Jefferson Park by a few kids is not the same as not wanting to die.
es_translation: I get out of the car. Ben stands next to me and Radar next to Ben. And suddenly I know that this isn't funny, that it's not about proving that I deserve to go out with her. I can hear Margo's words the night we roamed around Orlando. I hear her telling me: "I don't want some kids to find me covered in flies on a Saturday morning in Jefferson Park." Not wanting some kids to find you in Jefferson Park is not the same as not wanting to die.

en: There is no evidence that anyone has been here in a long time except for the smell, that sickly sour stench designed to keep the living from the dead. I tell myself she can’t smell like that, but of course she can. We all can. I hold my forearm up to my nose so I can smell sweat and skin and anything but death.
vi: Chẳng có gì cho thấy lâu nay còn có người ở đây, trừ cái mùi, thứ mùi chua chua nồng nồng bệnh bệnh bốc lên để giữ người sống tránh xa người chết. Tôi tự nhủ Margo không thể nào có mùi như thế, nhưng tất nhiên là có thể rồi. Tất cả chúng ta đều có thể bốc mùi như vậy. Tôi giơ cánh tay chặn ngang mũi để ngửi mùi mồ hôi và da mình, bất kể mùi gì trừ cái chết.
tr: Koku dışında, canlıları ölüden uzak tutmak için tasarlanmış bu hastalıklı derecede keskin olan pis koku dışında, burada uzun zamandır herhangi birinin olduğuna dair hiç kanıt yok. Kendime Margo’nun böyle kokamayacağım söylüyorum ama elbette kokabilir. Hepimiz kokabiliriz. Terin ve derinin yani ölümden başka bir şeylerin kokusunu almak için kolumu burnuma doğru kaldırıyorum.
es: No parece que haya pasado nadie por aquí desde hace tiempo, excepto por el olor, ese tufo rancio y dulzón que diferencia a los muertos de los vivos. Me digo a mí mismo que Margo no puede oler así, pero claro que puede. Todos podemos. Me llevo el brazo a la nariz para oler el sudor, la piel y cualquier cosa menos la muerte.
vi_translation: There was nothing to indicate that anyone had been here for a long time, except for the smell, that sour, pungent, sickly smell that kept the living away from the dead. I told myself that Margo couldn't possibly smell like that, but of course she could. All of us could smell like that. I raised my arm to my nose to smell my sweat and skin, anything but the smell of death.
tr_translation: Aside from the smell, this morbidly sharp stench designed to keep the living away from the dead, there is no evidence that anyone has been here for a long time. I tell myself that Margo couldn't smell like this, but of course, she could. We all could. I lift my arm to my nose to catch the scent of sweat and skin, anything other than death.
es_translation: It doesn't seem like anyone has been here for a long time, except for the smell, that rancid and sweetish stench that distinguishes the dead from the living. I tell myself that Margo can't smell like that, but of course she can. We all can. I bring my arm to my nose to smell the sweat, the skin, and anything but death.

en: “MARGO?” Radar calls. A mockingbird perched on the rusted gutter of the building spits out two syllables in response. “MARGO!” he shouts again. Nothing. He digs a parabola into the sand with his foot and sighs. “Shit.”
vi: “MARGO ƠI?” Radar gọi. Một con chim nhại đậu trên ống máng hoen gỉ của tòa nhà, phun ra hai âm tiết đáp trả. “MARGO!” Radar lại gọi lớn. Không có gì. Radar đá sục một cú vào cát, ngao ngán rủa, “Chết tiệt.
tr: Radar, “MARGO?” diye sesleniyor. Binanın paslanmış mazgalına tünemiş bir alaycı kuş cevap olarak iki hecelik bir çığlık atıyor. Radar tekrar, “MARGO!” diye bağırıyor. Hiçbir şey yok. Ayağıyla kuma bir parabol kazıyor ve iç çekiyor. “Kahretsin.
es: —¿MARGO? —grita Radar. Un pájaro posado en el oxidado canalón del edificio suelta dos sílabas a modo de respuesta. —¡MARGO! —vuelve a gritar Radar. Nada. Pega una patada en la arena y suspira. —Mierda.
vi_translation: “MARGO?” Radar called. A mockingbird perched on the rusty gutter of the building, chirping back two syllables. “MARGO!” Radar called out again. Nothing. Radar kicked at the sand in frustration, cursing, “Damn it.”
tr_translation: Radar calls out, "MARGO?" A mockingbird perched on the building's rusty grate responds with a two-syllable scream. Radar shouts again, "MARGO!" Nothing. He digs a parabola in the sand with his foot and sighs. "Damn it."
es_translation: —MARGO? —shouts Radar. A bird perched on the rusty gutter of the building releases two syllables as a response. —MARGO! —Radar shouts again. Nothing. He kicks the sand and sighs. —Shit.

en: Standing before this building, I learn something about fear. I learn that it is not the idle fantasies of someone who maybe wants something important to happen to him, even if the important thing is horrible. It is not the disgust of seeing a dead stranger, and not the breathlessness of hearing a shotgun pumped outside of Becca Arrington’s house. This cannot be addressed by breathing exercises. This fear bears no analogy to any fear I knew before. This is the basest of all possible emotions, the feeling that was with us before we existed, before this building existed, before the earth existed. This is the fear that made fish crawl out onto dry land and evolve lungs, the fear that teaches us to run, the fear that makes us bury our dead.
vi: Đứng trước tòa nhà này, tôi hiểu được chút gì đó về nỗi sợ hãi. Tôi hiểu rằng đó không phải là ảo giác đờ đẫn của người có lẽ muốn chuyện gì đó trọng đại xảy ra với mình, dù điều trọng đại đó thực khủng khiếp. Đó không phải là cảm giác ghê sợ khi thấy một người xa lạ bị chết, cũng không phải khoảnh khắc nghẹt thở khi nghe thấy tiếng súng rít lên từ nhà Becca Arrington. Không thể điều hòa bình ổn nó bằng bài tập thở. Nỗi sợ hãi này không có chút nào tương đồng với những sợ hãi tôi từng biết trước đó. Nó nằm ở nơi sâu nhất của mọi cảm xúc có thể có, thứ cảm giác theo chúng ta từ trước khi chúng ta tồn tại, trước khi khối nhà này tồn tại, trước cả khi trái đất tồn tại. Đó là nỗi sợ hãi đã đẩy cá khỏi đất khô mà tiến hóa buồng phổi, nỗi sợ hãi đã dạy chúng ta phải chạy, nỗi sợ hãi khiến chúng ta chôn cất những người đã qua đời.
tr: Bu binanın önünde dururken, korku hakkında bir şey öğreniyorum. Korkunun, başına önemli bir şeybu önemli şey korkunç bile olsagelmesini isteyen birinin boş fantezileri olmadığım öğreniyorum. Korku, yabancı birinin ölüsünü görmekten iğrenmek ve Becca Arrington’ın evinin dışında bir tüfeğin ateşlendiğim duymanın nefes kesiciliği değil. Bu, nefes egzersizleriyle idare edilemez. Bu korku daha önce tanıdığım korkularla mukayese edilemez. Bu, bütün olası duyguların en temeli, var oluşumuzdan önce bizimle olan, bu bina var olmadan, dünya var olmadan önce olan bir his. Bu, balıklan karaya süründüren ve akciğer geliştirmelerine neden olan korku, bize koşmayı öğreten korku, bize ölülerimizi gömdüren korku.
es: Aquí, frente a este edificio, aprendo algo sobre el miedo. Aprendo que no son las banales fantasías de alguien que quizá quiere que le pase algo importante, aunque lo importante sea terrible. No es el asco de ver a un extraño muerto, ni la falta de aliento cuando oyes cargarse una escopeta delante de la casa de Becca Arrington. Este miedo no se soluciona con ejercicios de respiración. Este no es comparable con ningún miedo que haya sentido antes. Es la más baja de todas las emociones posibles, sientes que estaba con nosotros antes de que existieras, antes de que existiera este edificio, antes de que existiera la Tierra. Es el miedo que hizo que los peces salieran del agua y desarrollaran pulmones, el miedo que nos enseña a correr, el miedo que hace que enterremos a nuestros muertos.
vi_translation: Standing in front of this building, I understand something about fear. I understand that it is not the dull hallucination of someone who perhaps wants something significant to happen to them, even if that significant thing is truly terrifying. It is not the feeling of horror when seeing a stranger die, nor the breathless moment when hearing the sound of gunfire from Becca Arrington's house. It cannot be calmed by breathing exercises. This fear bears no resemblance to the fears I have known before. It lies in the deepest place of all possible emotions, a feeling that follows us from before we existed, before this building existed, even before the earth existed. It is the fear that pushed fish from dry land to evolve lungs, the fear that taught us to run, the fear that makes us bury the deceased.
tr_translation: While standing in front of this building, I am learning something about fear. I am learning that fear is not the empty fantasies of someone who wants something significant to happen to them, even if that significant thing is terrifying. Fear is not the disgust of seeing a stranger's corpse or the breathtaking sound of a gunshot outside Becca Arrington's house. This cannot be managed with breathing exercises. This fear is incomparable to the fears I have known before. This is the most fundamental of all possible emotions, a feeling that was with us before our existence, before this building existed, before the world existed. This is the fear that drove fish to crawl onto land and develop lungs, the fear that taught us to run, the fear that made us bury our dead.
es_translation: Here, in front of this building, I learn something about fear. I learn that it is not the banal fantasies of someone who might want something important to happen to them, even if that important thing is terrible. It is not the disgust of seeing a stranger dead, nor the shortness of breath when you hear a shotgun being loaded in front of Becca Arrington's house. This fear is not resolved with breathing exercises. This is not comparable to any fear I have felt before. It is the lowest of all possible emotions, you feel that it was with us before you existed, before this building existed, before the Earth existed. It is the fear that made fish come out of the water and develop lungs, the fear that teaches us to run, the fear that makes us bury our dead.

en: The smell leaves me seized by desperate panic—panic not like my lungs are out of air, but like the atmosphere itself is out of air. I think maybe the reason I have spent most of my life being afraid is that I have been trying to prepare myself, to train my body for the real fear when it comes. But I am not prepared.
vi: Cái mùi ấy thít lấy tôi trong cơn hoảng loạn tuyệt vọng– hoảng loạn không phải như trong phổi tôi đã cạn sinh khí, mà như chính sinh quyển đã cạn khí. Tôi nghĩ có thể lí do tôi lo lắng hết phần lớn thời gian đời mình là vì tôi cố gắng tự chuẩn bị cho bản thân, rèn luyện cơ thể sẵn sàng chống lại nỗi sợ hãi đích thực khi nó tràn tới. Nhưng tôi không sẵn sàng.
tr: Koku beni çaresizlikle dolu bir panik tarafından ele geçirilmiş halde bırakıyor... ciğerlerimin havasız kalması gibi bir panik değil, atmosferin kendisinin havasız kalması gibi bir panik. Sanırım hayatımın çoğunu korkarak geçirdim çünkü gerçek korku geldiğinde kendimi onun için hazırlamaya, vücudumu eğitmeye çalışıyordum. Ama hazır değilim.
es: El olor hace que un desesperado pánico se apodere de mí. No como cuando mis pulmones se quedan sin aire, sino como cuando lo que se queda sin aire es la propia atmósfera. Creo que la razón por la que he pasado la mayor parte de mi vida asustado es quizá porque intentaba prepararme y entrenar mi cuerpo para cuando llegara el miedo de verdad. Pero no estoy preparado.
vi_translation: That smell gripped me in a panic of despair—not panic as if my lungs had run out of air, but as if the entire biosphere had run out of air. I think the reason I worry most of the time is that I try to prepare myself, training my body to be ready to fight against the true fear when it comes. But I am not ready.
tr_translation: Despair leaves me seized by a panic filled with helplessness... not a panic like my lungs running out of air, but a panic as if the atmosphere itself is running out of air. I think I spent most of my life in fear because when real fear came I was trying to prepare myself for him, to train my body. But I'm not ready.
es_translation: The smell causes a desperate panic to take hold of me. Not like when my lungs run out of air, but like when the very atmosphere runs out of air. I think the reason I've spent most of my life scared is perhaps because I was trying to prepare and train my body for when real fear arrived. But I am not prepared.

en: “Bro, we should leave,” Ben says. “We should call the cops or something.” We have not looked at each other yet. We are all still looking at this building, this long-abandoned building that cannot possibly hold anything but corpses.
vi: “Nên đi thôi mấy bồ,” Ben lên tiếng. “Nên gọi cảnh sát hay làm gì đại khái thế.” Chúng tôi vẫn chưa nhìn nhau. Cả ba thằng vẫn chăm chăm nhìn tòa nhà, cái nơi bị bỏ hoang từ bao nhiêu lâu nay không có khả năng cất giấu bất cứ thứ gì trừ những xác chết.
tr: “Kardeşim, gitmeliyiz,” diyor Ben. “Polisleri falan aramalıyız.” Henüz birbirimize bakmadık. Hâlâ binaya bakıyoruz, bu uzun zamandır terk edilmiş, cesetlerden başka hiçbir şey barındırma ihtimali olmayan binaya.
es: —Colega, deberíamos marcharnos —dice Ben—. Deberíamos llamar a la poli o a quien sea. Todavía no nos hemos mirado. Los tres seguimos mirando el edificio, un edificio abandonado desde hace mucho tiempo que solo puede albergar cadáveres.
vi_translation: “We should go, guys,” Ben spoke up. “We should call the police or something like that.” We still hadn't looked at each other. The three of us kept staring at the building, the place that had been abandoned for so long it couldn't hide anything except corpses.
tr_translation: “Brother, we must go,” says Ben. “We should call the police or something.” We haven't looked at each other yet. We are still looking at the building, this building that has been abandoned for a long time, likely harboring nothing but corpses.
es_translation: —Colleague, we should leave —says Ben—. We should call the cops or whoever. We still haven't looked at each other. The three of us continue looking at the building, an abandoned building that has been vacant for a long time and can only house corpses.

en: “No,” Radar says. “No no no no no. We call if there’s something to call about. She left the address for Q. Not for the cops. We have to find a way in there.”
vi: “Không,” Radar kêu lên. “Không không không không không. Bọn mình sẽ gọi khi có gì đó để trình báo. Margo để lại địa chỉ này cho Q. Không phải cho cảnh sát. Chúng ta phải tìm cách vào trong đó.”
tr: “Hayır,” diyor Radar. “Yo yo yo. Eğer aranacak bir şey olursa ararız. Adresi Q için bıraktı. Polisler için değil, içeriye girmek için bir yol bulmak zorundayız.
es: —No —dice Radar—. No no no no no. Los llamaremos si hay razones para llamarlos. Dejó la dirección a Q, no a la poli. Tenemos que buscar la manera de entrar.
vi_translation: "No," Radar shouted. "No no no no no. We'll call when we have something to report. Margo left this address for Q. Not for the police. We have to find a way to get in there."
tr_translation: “No,” says Radar. “No no no. If there’s something to search for, we’ll search. He left the address for Q. Not for the police, we have to find a way to get inside.”
es_translation: —No —says Radar—. No no no no no. We'll call them if there's a reason to call them. She left the address to Q, not to the cops. We need to find a way to get in.

en: “In there?” Ben says dubiously.
vi: “Vào trong đó?” Ben ngờ vực hỏi.
tr: “İçeriye mi?” diyor Ben kuşkulu bir şekilde.
es: —¿Entrar? —pregunta Ben dubitativo.
vi_translation: "In there?" Ben asked suspiciously.
tr_translation: "Inside?" says Ben skeptically.
es_translation: —Enter? —asks Ben doubtfully.

en: I clap Ben on the back, and for the first time all day, the three of us are looking not forward but at one another. That makes it bearable. Something about seeing them makes me feel as if she is not dead until we find her. “Yeah, in there,” I say.
vi: Tôi vỗ vỗ lên lưng Ben, và lần đầu tiên trong suốt cả ngày, ba đứa chúng tôi không nhìn về phía trước mà quay sang nhìn nhau. Như vậy còn có thể chịu đựng được. Khi tôi nhìn hai thằng bạn, có điều gì đó như mách bảo tôi rằng Margo không chết cho đến khi nào chúng tôi tìm ra cô ấy. “Đúng vậy, vào trong đó,” tôi nói.
tr: Ben’in sırtını sıvazlıyorum ve bütün gün boyunca ilk defa üçümüz önümüze değil, birbirimize bakıyoruz. Bu, durumu katlanılabilir hale getiriyor. Onları görmekle ilgili bir şey bana sanki biz onu bulana kadar Margo ölmeyecekmiş gibi hissettiriyor. “Evet, içeriye,” diyorum.
es: Le doy una palmada en la espalda a Ben, y por primera vez en todo el día no miramos al frente, sino que nos miramos entre nosotros. Lo hace más llevadero. Al mirarlos, algo me hace sentir que Margo no está muerta si no la hemos encontrado. —Sí, entrar —digo.
vi_translation: I patted Ben on the back, and for the first time all day, the three of us didn't look forward but turned to look at each other. That made it bearable. When I looked at my two friends, something told me that Margo wouldn't be dead until we found her. "Yes, let's go in there," I said.
tr_translation: I pat Ben on the back and for the first time all day, the three of us look at each other instead of ahead. This makes the situation bearable. Something about seeing them makes me feel like Margo won't die until we find her. "Yes, inside," I say.
es_translation: I give Ben a pat on the back, and for the first time all day, we don't look ahead, but instead, we look at each other. It makes it more bearable. When I look at them, something makes me feel that Margo isn't dead if we haven't found her. —Yes, come in —I say.

en: I don’t know who she is anymore, or who she was, but I need to find her.
vi: Tôi không còn biết Margo là ai nữa, hay từng là ai, nhưng tôi cần tìm cô ấy.
tr: Artık Margo kim ya da kimdi bilmiyorum ama onu bulmam gerekiyor.
es: Ya no sé quién es Margo, o quién era, pero tengo que encontrarla.
vi_translation: I no longer know who Margo is, or who she ever was, but I need to find her.
tr_translation: I no longer know who Margo is or was, but I need to find her.
es_translation: I no longer know who Margo is, or who she was, but I have to find her.

en: We walk around the back of the building and find four locked steel doors and nothing but ranch land, patches of palmettos dotting an expanse of gold-green grass. The stench is worse here, and I feel afraid to keep walking. Ben and Radar are just behind me, to my right and left. We form a triangle together, walking slowly, our eyes scanning the area.
vi: Chúng tôi đi ra phía sau tòa nhà và thấy bốn cánh cửa sắt bị khóa. Không có gì ngoài đất hoang, vài đám cọ mọc lác đác trên mênh mông cỏ nửa vàng nửa xanh. Cái mùi khăn khẳn ở đây còn nồng nặc hơn, tôi chờn chợn không muốn đi tiếp. Ben và Radar ở ngay phía sau, bên phải và bên trái tôi. Ba thằng làm thành đội hình tam giác, bước đi chầm chậm, căng mắt quan sát xung quanh.
tr: Binanın arkasından dolaşıyoruz ve dört çelik kapı ile altmyeşil otluk alanı benek benek kaplayan cüce palmiyelerden başka bir şey bulamıyoruz. Pis koku burada daha kötü ve yürümeye devam etmekten korktuğumu hissediyorum. Ben ile Radar benim tam arkamda, sağımda ve solumdalar. Birlikte bir üçgen oluşturuyoruz, yavaşça yürüyoruz, gözlerimiz etrafı tarıyor.
es: Rodeamos el edificio hasta la parte de atrás y encontramos cuatro puertas de acero cerradas, y nada más aparte de terreno con palmeras enanas esparcidas en una extensión de hierba verde con matices dorados. Aquí todavía hace más peste y me da más miedo seguir andando. Ben y Radar están justo detrás de mí, a mi derecha y a mi izquierda, formando un triángulo. Avanzamos despacio mientras recorremos la zona con los ojos.
vi_translation: We went to the back of the building and saw four locked iron doors. There was nothing but wasteland, with a few clumps of palm trees scattered across the vast half-yellow, half-green grass. The musty smell here was even stronger, making me hesitant to go further. Ben and Radar were right behind me, to my left and right. The three of us formed a triangular formation, walking slowly, eyes straining to observe our surroundings.
tr_translation: We walk around the back of the building and find nothing but four steel doors and dwarf palms dotting the sixty-green grassy area. The foul smell is worse here, and I feel afraid to keep walking. Ben and Radar are right behind me, to my right and left. We form a triangle together, walking slowly, our eyes scanning the surroundings.
es_translation: We circled the building to the back and found four closed steel doors, and nothing else except for land with dwarf palm trees scattered across an expanse of green grass with golden hues. It still smells worse here and I'm more scared to keep walking. Ben and Radar are right behind me, to my right and left, forming a triangle. We move slowly as we scan the area with our eyes.

en: “It’s a raccoon!” Ben shouts. “Oh, thank God. It’s a raccoon. Jesus.” Radar and I walk away from the building to join him near a shallow drainage ditch. A huge, bloated raccoon with matted hair lies dead, no visible trauma, its fur falling off, one of its ribs exposed. Radar turns away and heaves, but nothing comes out. I lean down next to him and put my arm between his shoulder blades, and when he gets his breath back, he says, “I am so fucking glad to see that dead fucking raccoon.”
vi: “Một con ra-cun!” Ben hét toáng lên. “Ôi, đội ơn Chúa, một con ra-cun, trời đất quỉ thần ơi!” Radar và tôi liền đi xa khỏi tòa nhà, lại chỗ Ben đang đứng bên một rãnh thoát nước nông. Một con ra-cun to đùng, lông dày bết, nằm chết trương phềnh, không có vết thương nào rõ rệt, lớp lông nó đang rã ra, lộ một dẻ xương sườn. Radar quay đi và hộc lên, nhưng không ói. Tôi cúi xuống, vòng tay giữ hai bả vai nó. Khi nhịp thở trở lại bình thường, Radar nói, “Tôi mừng kinh khủng khiếp vì đó là xác một con ra-cun kinh khủng khiếp.
tr: “Bu bir rakun!” diye bağırıyor Ben. “Ah, Tanrı’ya şükür. Bir rakun. Tanrım.” Radar’la, sığ bir drenaj çukurunun yanındaki Ben’e katılmak için binadan uzaklaşıyoruz. Kocaman, şişmiş bir rakun keçeleşmiş tüyleriyle ölü yatıyor, gözle görülür bir travma yok, kürkü dökülüyor, kaburgalarından biri ortaya çıkmış. Radar arkasını dönüp öğürüyor ama dışarı hiçbir şey çıkmıyor. Radar’m yanında eğilip kürek kemiklerinin arasına elimi koyuyorum ve nefeslendiğinde, “Kahretsin, şu lanet ölü rakunu gördüğüme o kadar sevindim ki,” diyor.
es: —¡Un mapache! —grita Ben—. Gracias, Dios mío. Es un mapache. Joder. Radar y yo nos alejamos del edificio y vamos hacia el animal, que está junto a una zanja de drenaje poco profunda. Un enorme mapache hinchado y con el pelo apelmazado yace muerto, sin heridas visibles. Se le ha desprendido el pelo, que deja al descubierto una costilla. Radar se aparta con arcadas, pero no llega a vomitar. Me inclino a su lado y apoyo la mano entre sus omóplatos. —Me alegro tanto de ver a ese puto mapache muerto —me dice cuando recupera la respiración.
vi_translation: “A raccoon!” Ben shouted. “Oh, thank God, a raccoon, heavens and earth!” Radar and I immediately moved away from the building, towards where Ben was standing by a shallow drainage ditch. A huge raccoon, with thick matted fur, lay dead and bloated, with no obvious wounds, its fur decomposing, revealing a rib bone. Radar turned away and gagged, but didn't vomit. I bent down, wrapping my arms around its shoulders. When its breathing returned to normal, Radar said, “I’m terribly relieved that it’s the corpse of a terribly disgusting raccoon.”
tr_translation: “It's a raccoon!” Ben shouts. “Oh, thank God. A raccoon. My God.” We move away from the building to join Ben by a shallow drainage ditch with Radar. A huge, swollen raccoon lies dead with matted fur, no visible trauma, its fur falling out, one of its ribs exposed. Radar turns around and retches, but nothing comes out. I lean down next to Radar and place my hand between his shoulder blades, and as he breathes, he says, “Damn, I'm so glad to see that damn dead raccoon.”
es_translation: —A raccoon! —shouts Ben—. Thank you, my God. It's a raccoon. Shit. Radar and I move away from the building and head towards the animal, which is next to a shallow drainage ditch. A huge, swollen raccoon with matted fur lies dead, with no visible wounds. Its fur has fallen off, exposing a rib. Radar steps back gagging, but doesn't actually vomit. I lean down next to him and place my hand between his shoulder blades. —I'm so glad to see that damn raccoon dead —he tells me when he catches his breath.

en: But even so, I cannot picture her here alive. It occurs to me that the Whitman could be a suicide note. I think about things she highlighted: “To die is different from what any one supposed, and luckier.” “I bequeath myself to the dirt to grow from the grass I love, / If you want me again look for me under your bootsoles.” For a moment, I feel a flash of hope when I think about the last line of the poem: “I stop some where waiting for you.” But then I think that the I does not need to be a person. The I can also be a body.
vi: Dẫu vậy, tôi vẫn không thể hình dung Margo còn sống ở đây. Tôi chợt nhận ra rằng những câu thơ của Whitman có thể là lời nhắn tuyệt mệnh. Tôi nghĩ đến những dòng cô ấy đã đánh dấu: “Và chết chẳng giống những gì người ta huyễn tưởng, và thêm phước phận. “Ta trả mình về đất, nuôi những thân cỏ ta yêu, / Nếu ngươi muốn ta, hãy tìm ta dưới đế ủng.” Trong tích tắc, tôi thấy lóe lên chút hi vọng khi nghĩ đến câu cuối bài thơ: “Ở đâu đó, ta dừng lại đợi ngươi.” Nhưng rồi tôi nghĩ ta không nhất thiết phải là một con người. Ta cũng có thể là một cái xác.
tr: Ama her şeye rağmen, burada Margo’yu canlı olarak hayal edemiyorum. Whitman’ın bir intihar mektubu olabileceği aklıma geliyor. Altını çizdiği şeyleri düşünüyorum: “Ölmek herkesin varsaydığından daha farklı ve talihli.” “Toprağa, sevdiğim çimenle büyümeye bırakıyorum kendimi, / Eğer tekrar istiyorsan, tabanlarının altında ara beni.” Şiirin son dizesini düşününce, bir anlığına bir umut dalgası hissediyorum: “Ben bir yerde duruyorum bekleyerek seni.” Ama sonra ben kelimesinin bir insan olması gerekmediğini düşünüyorum. Ben, bir ceset de olabilir.
es: Pero, aun así, no me la puedo imaginar viva aquí. Se me ocurre que el Whitman podría ser una nota de suicidio. Pienso en versos que había marcado: «Y morir es algo distinto de lo que muchos supusieron, y de mejor augurio». «Que el lodo sea mi heredero, quiero crecer del pasto que amo; / Si quieres encontrarte conmigo, búscame bajo la suela de tus zapatos». Por un momento siento un destello de esperanza al pensar en el último verso del poema: «En alguna parte te espero». Pero luego pienso que esa primera persona no tiene por qué ser una persona. También puede ser un cuerpo.
vi_translation: Even so, I still can't imagine Margo living here. I suddenly realized that Whitman's verses might be a suicide note. I thought of the lines she had marked: "And death is not what people imagine, and it is a blessing." “I return myself to the earth, nurturing the grasses I love, / If you want me, look for me under the soles of your boots.” In an instant, I saw a glimmer of hope when thinking about the last line of the poem: “Somewhere, I stop and wait for you.” But then I thought that I don't necessarily have to be a human being. I could also be a corpse.
tr_translation: But despite everything, I can't imagine Margo alive here. The thought that Whitman's poem might be a suicide note crosses my mind. I think about the things she underlined: "To die is different from what anyone supposed, and luckier." "I bequeath myself to the dirt to grow from the grass I love, / If you want me again, look for me under your boot-soles." Thinking about the last line of the poem, I feel a wave of hope for a moment: "I stop somewhere waiting for you "you." But then I think that the word "I" does not have to be a person. "I" could also be a corpse.
es_translation: But, even so, I can't imagine her alive here. It occurs to me that the Whitman could be a suicide note. I think of verses she had marked: "And to die is different from what anyone supposed, and luckier." "Let the mud be my inheritance, I want to grow from the grass I love; / If you want to find me, look for me under the soles of your shoes." For a moment I feel a flash of hope thinking about the last verse of the poem: "I stop somewhere waiting for you." But then I think that this first person doesn't have to be a person. It could also be a body.

en: Radar has walked away from the raccoon and is tugging on the handle of one of the four locked steel doors. I feel like praying for the dead—saying Kaddish for this raccoon—but I don’t even know how. I’m so sorry for him, and so sorry for how happy I am to see him like this.
vi: Radar đã tránh xa khỏi con ra-cun, đang giật giật tay nắm của một trong bốn cánh cửa sắt bị khóa. Tôi cảm thấy muốn cầu nguyện cho những gì đã khuất–tụng một khúc Kaddish cho con ra-cun này–nhưng thậm chí tôi còn không biết phải làm thế nào. Tôi thương tiếc con vật ấy, và lấy làm tiếc vì đã thầm mừng khi thấy nó như vậy.
tr: Radar rakundan uzaklaşıp dört çelik kapıdan birinin koluna asılıyor. Ölüye dua etmek istiyorum aslındabu rakun için Kadiş okumam gerekiyormuş gibiama nasıl yapacağımı bile bilmiyorum. Onun için çok üzülüyorum ve onu bu şekilde görmekten bu kadar mutlu olduğum için çok üzülüyorum,
es: Radar se ha apartado del mapache y tira del pomo de una de las cuatro puertas de acero. Siento deseos de rezar por el muerto, de rezar el Kadish por este mapache, pero ni siquiera me lo sé. Lo siento mucho por él y siento mucho alegrarme tanto de verlo así.
vi_translation: Radar stayed away from the raccoon, tugging at the handle of one of the four locked iron doors. I felt like praying for the departed—reciting a Kaddish for this raccoon—but I didn't even know how to do it. I mourned the animal and regretted feeling a silent joy at seeing it like that.
tr_translation: Radar moves away from the raccoon and hangs onto the handle of one of the four steel doors. I actually want to pray for the dead, as if I should recite Kaddish for this raccoon, but I don't even know how to do it. I feel very sorry for it and I feel very sorry for being so happy to see it this way,
es_translation: Radar has moved away from the raccoon and pulls the handle of one of the four steel doors. I feel the urge to pray for the dead, to recite the Kaddish for this raccoon, but I don't even know it. I feel very sorry for him and I feel very sorry for being so glad to see him like this.

en: “It’s giving a little,” Radar shouts to us. “Come help.”
vi: “Cần lực mạnh hơn,” Radar gọi. “Lại giúp tôi đi.”
tr: “Biraz açılıyor,” diye bağırıyor Radar bize doğru. “Gelip yardım edin.
es: —Está cediendo un poco —nos grita Radar—. Venid a ayudarme.
vi_translation: "We need more force," Radar called. "Help me again."
tr_translation: “It's opening a bit,” Radar shouts towards us. “Come and help.”
es_translation: —It's giving way a little —Radar shouts to us—. Come and help me.

en: Ben and I both put our arms around Radar’s waist and pull back. He puts his foot up against the wall to give himself extra leverage as he pulls, and then all at once they collapse onto me, Radar’s sweat-soaked T-shirt pressed up against my face. For a moment, I’m excited, thinking we’re in. But then I see Radar holding the door handle. I scramble up and look at the door. Still locked.
vi: Ben và tôi cùng vòng tay qua hông Radar và kéo về phía sau. Nó chống chân lên tường để có thêm điểm tựa khi kéo, rồi thì cả hai thằng ngã huỵch xuống tôi. Lưng áo đẫm mồ hôi của Radar đè lên mặt tôi. Trong thoáng chốc tôi mừng rơn, tưởng đã vào được rồi. Nhưng rồi tôi thấy Radar cầm cái tay nắm cửa. Tôi vội nhổm dậy nhìn cánh cửa. Vẫn đóng im ỉm.
tr: Radar’m beline kollarımızı dolayıp kapıyı Ben’le geriye doğru çekiyoruz. Radar çekerken kendine fazladan güç sağlamak için ayağım duvara dayıyor, sonra birdenbire üstüme yığılıyorlar, Radar’m terden ıslanmış tişörtü yüzüme yapışıyor. Bir anlığına heyecanlanıyorum, içeri girdiğimizi düşünüyorum. Ama sonra Radar’m kapı kolunu tuttuğunu görüyorum. Güçlükle kalkıp kapıya bakıyorum. Hâlâ kilitli.
es: Ben y yo sujetamos a Radar por la cintura y tiramos de él. Radar apoya un pie en la pared para darse más impulso y de repente los dos caen encima de mí y me encuentro con la camiseta empapada de sudor de Radar en la cara. Por un momento me entusiasmo, creo que lo hemos conseguido, pero entonces me doy cuenta de que Radar tiene el mango de la puerta en la mano. Me levanto y echo un vistazo a la puerta: sigue cerrada.
vi_translation: Ben and I wrapped our arms around Radar's waist and pulled him back. He braced his feet against the wall for extra leverage, and then both of us fell heavily onto me. Radar's sweat-soaked back pressed against my face. For a moment, I was thrilled, thinking we had made it in. But then I saw Radar holding the door handle. I quickly got up to look at the door. Still firmly closed.
tr_translation: We wrap our arms around Radar's waist and pull the door back with Ben. Radar braces his foot against the wall to give himself extra strength while pulling, then suddenly they collapse on top of me, Radar's sweat-soaked shirt sticking to my face. For a moment, I get excited, thinking we've made it inside. But then I see Radar holding the doorknob. With difficulty, I get up and look at the door. It's still locked.
es_translation: Ben and I grabbed Radar by the waist and pulled him. Radar placed a foot on the wall to give himself more momentum, and suddenly the two of them fell on top of me, and I found myself with Radar's sweat-soaked shirt in my face. For a moment I got excited, thinking we had done it, but then I realized that Radar had the door handle in his hand. I got up and took a look at the door: it was still closed.

en: “Piece of shit forty-year-old goddamned doorknob,” Radar says. I’ve never heard him talk like this before.
vi: “Cái thứ tay nắm cửa bốn chục năm tuổi thọ đáng nguyền rủa này!” Radar rủa. Tôi chưa từng thấy nó nói năng kiểu đó bao giờ.
tr: “Boktan, kırk yıllık lanet olasıca kapı kolu,” diyor Radar. Onun bu şekilde konuştuğunu daha önce hiç duymamıştım.
es: —Puto pomo de mierda del año de la pera —gruñe Radar. Nunca lo había oído hablar así.
vi_translation: “This damn forty-year-old door handle!” Radar cursed. I had never heard it speak like that before.
tr_translation: “Damn, you forty-year-old cursed door handle,” says Radar. I had never heard him talk like that before.
es_translation: —Damn shitty apple from the year of the pear —grumbles Radar. I've never heard him speak like that.

en: “It’s okay,” I say. “There’s a way. There has to be.”
vi: “Được rồi mà,” tôi nói. “Có cách. Phải có cách chứ.”
tr: “Sorun değil,” diyorum. “Bir yol var. Olmalı.
es: —Tranquilo —le digo—. Alguna manera habrá. Tiene que haberla.
vi_translation: "It's okay," I said. "There's a way. There has to be a way."
tr_translation: “No problem,” I say. “There is a way. There must be.”
es_translation: —Calm down —I tell him—. There must be a way. There has to be one.

en: We walk all the way around to the front of the building. No doors, no holes, no visible tunnels. But I need in. Ben and Radar try to peel the slabs of particleboard from the windows, but they’re all nailed shut. Radar kicks at the board, but it doesn’t give. Ben turns back to me. “There’s no glass behind one of these boards,” he says, and then he starts jogging away from the building, his sneakers splashing sand as he goes.
vi: Chúng tôi vòng lại mặt trước tòa nhà. Không cửa ra vào, không lỗ hổng, không có vẻ gì là có đường ngầm. Nhưng tôi cần vào trong. Ben và Radar cố gắng nạy những mảng gỗ ép khỏi cửa sổ, nhưng tất cả đều đã được đóng đinh cố định. Radar đá tấm gỗ mà không ăn thua. Ben quay lại nói với tôi, “Không có kính sau lớp gỗ ép,” và nó bắt đầu giật lùi, đôi giày thể thao đá vung cát lên theo mỗi bước chân.
tr: Binanın önüne doğru bütün yolu tekrar yürüyoruz. Kapı yok, delik yok, gözle görülür bir tünel yok. Ama içeri girmem gerek. Ben ile Radar pencereden suntaları çıkarmaya çalışıyorlar ama hepsi çivilenmiş. Radar suntayı tekmeliyor ama sunta yol vermiyor. Ben bana dönüyor. “Bu levhaların hiçbirinin arkasında cam yok,” diyor, sonra koşarak binadan uzaklaşmaya başlıyor, o giderken spor ayakkabıları kumları sıçratıyor.
es: Damos la vuelta hasta la parte delantera del edificio. No vemos puertas, ni agujeros, ni túneles. Pero tengo que entrar. Ben y Radar intentan arrancar las planchas de conglomerado de los escaparates, pero están clavadas. Radar les da patadas, pero no ceden. Ben vuelve a mi lado. —Detrás de una de esas planchas no hay cristal —me dice. Y sale corriendo. Mientras corre, sus zapatillas esparcen la arena.
vi_translation: We circled back to the front of the building. No doors, no openings, no sign of an underground passage. But I needed to get inside. Ben and Radar tried to pry the plywood off the windows, but everything was nailed down tight. Radar kicked the plywood to no avail. Ben turned back to me and said, "There's no glass behind the plywood," and he started to back up, his sneakers kicking up sand with each step.
tr_translation: We walk the entire way back towards the front of the building. There is no door, no hole, no visible tunnel. But I need to get inside. Ben and Radar are trying to remove the boards from the window, but they are all nailed down. Radar kicks the board, but it doesn't give way. Ben turns to me. "There is no glass behind any of these panels," he says, then starts running away from the building, his sneakers kicking up sand as he goes.
es_translation: We go around to the front of the building. We don't see doors, holes, or tunnels. But I have to get in. Ben and Radar try to pull the plywood sheets off the storefronts, but they are nailed down. Radar kicks them, but they don't budge. Ben comes back to my side. —Behind one of those panels, there is no glass —he tells me. And he runs off. As he runs, his shoes scatter the sand.

en: I give him a confused look. “I’m going to bust through the particleboard,” he explains.
vi: Tôi chưa hiểu gì, nhìn Ben dò hỏi. “Tôi sẽ công phá đám gỗ ép đó,” nó giải thích.
tr: Ona kafamın karıştığım gösteren bir bakış atıyorum. “Suntayı parçalayacağım,” diye açıklıyor.
es: Lo miro confundido. —Voy a atravesar las planchas —me explica.
vi_translation: I didn't understand anything, looking at Ben questioningly. "I will break through that plywood," he explained.
tr_translation: I give her a look that shows my confusion. “I will break the board,” she explains.
es_translation: I look at him confused. —I am going to cross the plates —he explains to me.

en: “You can’t do that.” He is the smallest of our light trio. If anyone tries to smash through the boarded-up windows, it should be me.
vi: “Ông không làm được đâu.” Ben thấp bé nhất trong ba đứa. Nếu cần người công phá những cửa sổ bịt bằng gỗ ép ấy, thì đó nên là tôi.
tr: ‘Yapamazsın.” Ben, hafif üçlümüzün en küçüğü. Eğer biri levhaları kırmayı deneyecekse, bu ben olmalıyım.
es: —No podrás. Es el menos corpulento de los tres, que ya es decir. Si alguno tiene que intentar atravesar las planchas de los escaparates, debería ser yo.
vi_translation: “You can't do it.” Ben was the smallest of the three. If someone was needed to break through those boarded-up windows, it should be me.
tr_translation: "You can't do it." I, the smallest of our light trio. If someone is going to try to break the boards, it should be me.
es_translation: —You won't be able to. He is the least corpulent of the three, which is saying something. If anyone has to try to get through the display window panels, it should be me.

en: He balls his hands into fists and then extends his fingers out. As I walk toward him, he starts talking to me. “When my mom was trying to keep me from getting beat up in third grade, she put me in tae kwon do. I only went to like three classes, and I only learned one thing, but the thing comes in handy sometimes: we watched this tae kwon do master punch through a thick wooden block, and we were all like, dude, how did he do that, and he told us that if you move as though your hand will go through the block, and if you believe that your hand will go through the block, then it will.”
vi: Ben nắm tay lại thành nắm đấm rồi duỗi các ngón ra. Khi tôi tiến lại, nó bắt đầu kể. “Hồi tôi học lớp ba, mẹ tìm cách để tôi không bị bắt nạt nên cho tôi học lớp võ taekwondo. Hình như tôi chỉ đến lớp có ba buổi, và chỉ học được mỗi một chiêu, nhưng thỉnh thoảng cũng hữu hiệu ra phết: bọn nhóc tì xem sư phụ taekwondo đấm xuyên một tấm gỗ dày, đứa nào cũng trầm trồ hỏi sao thầy làm được, và thầy đã nói với cả lớp rằng nếu ta di chuyển như thể tay ta sẽ xuyên qua súc gỗ, và nếu ta tin rằng tay ta sẽ xuyên qua được, thì ắt nó xuyên được.”
tr: Ellerim yumruk haline getiriyor, sonra parmaklarım uzatıyor. Ben ona doğru yürürken, benimle konuşmaya başlıyor. “Annem beni üçüncü sınıfta dövülmekten korumaya çalıştığı zaman, tekvandoya yazdırdı. Yalnızca üç ders falan gittim ve sadece tek bir şey öğrendim ama o şey bazen işe yarıyor: O tekvando ustasının kalın bir tahtayı yumruklamasını izlerdik ve hepimiz, dostum, bunu nasıl yaptı falan gibi bakardık ve usta bize eğer eliniz tahtanın içinden geçecekmiş gibi hareket ederseniz ve elinizin tahtadan geçeceğine inanırsanız o zaman öyle olur, dedi.
es: Aprieta los puños y luego extiende los dedos. Mientras voy hacia él empieza a decirme: —En tercero, mi madre intentó que dejaran de pegarme apuntándome a taekwondo. Solo fui a tres clases, y solo aprendí una cosa, pero de vez en cuando es útil. Vimos al maestro de taekwondo partir un bloque grueso de madera y todos pensamos, colega, cómo lo ha hecho, y él nos dijo que si actúas como si tu mano fuera a atravesar el bloque de madera, y si crees que tu mano va a atravesar ese bloque, entonces lo atraviesa.
vi_translation: Ben clenched his hand into a fist and then stretched out his fingers. As I approached, he began to tell. "When I was in third grade, my mom tried to prevent me from being bullied by enrolling me in a taekwondo class. I think I only attended three sessions and learned just one move, but it was occasionally quite effective: the kids watched the taekwondo master punch through a thick wooden board, and they all marveled, asking how he did it. The master told the class that if we moved as if our hand would go through the board, and if we believed that our hand would go through, then it surely would."
tr_translation: I clench my hands into fists, then extend my fingers. As I walk towards him, he starts talking to me. “When my mom tried to protect me from being beaten up in third grade, she enrolled me in taekwondo. I only went to about three lessons and learned just one thing, but sometimes that one thing works: We would watch the taekwondo master punch through a thick board, and we would all look like, dude, how did he do that, and the master told us if you move your hand as if it’s going through the board and believe that your hand will go through, then it will happen.”
es_translation: Clench your fists and then extend your fingers. As I walk towards him, he starts to say to me: —In third grade, my mother tried to stop them from hitting me by signing me up for taekwondo. I only went to three classes, and I only learned one thing, but every now and then it's useful. We saw the taekwondo master break a thick block of wood and we all thought, dude, how did he do that, and he told us that if you act as if your hand is going to go through the block of wood, and if you believe that your hand is going to go through that block, then it goes through.

en: I’m about to refute this idiotic logic when he takes off, running past me in a blur. His acceleration continues as he approaches the board, and then utterly without fear, he leaps up at the last possible second, twists his body sideways—his shoulder out to bear the brunt of the force—and slams into the wood. I half-expect him to burst through and leave a Ben-shaped cutout, like a cartoon. Instead, he bounces off the board and falls onto his ass in a patch of bright grass amid the sea of sandy dirt. Ben rolls onto his side, rubbing his shoulder. “It broke,” he announces.
vi: Tôi toan phản bác thứ lô-gíc ăn dỗ trẻ con ấy, thì Ben đã xuất phát, lao vù qua tôi như một vệt nhòe. Càng đến gần tấm gỗ nó càng tăng tốc, và cuối cùng không chút nao núng, nó nhảy lên trong giây cuối cùng, xoay nghiêng người–giơ vai ra hứng chịu va đập–rồi đâm sầm vào lớp gỗ. Tôi nửa mong nó sẽ phá tung tấm ván và để lại một lỗ hổng hình-Ben, như trong phim hoạt hình vậy. Nhưng nó bật khỏi lớp gỗ, ngã bệt xuống vạt cỏ sáng màu, trong một biển cát bụi tung bay. Ben lăn nghiêng người, xoa xoa bả vai. “Vỡ rồi,” nó tuyên bố.
tr: O harekete geçip bir bulanıklık halinde yanımdan koşup geçerken, ben onun aptalca mantığım reddetmek üzereyim. Levhaya yaklaşırken hızlanmaya devam ediyor ve sonra, tamamen korkusuzca, olabilecek son saniyede havaya sıçrayıp vücudunu yana doğru çeviriyoromzu gücün ağırlığını taşımak için dışarıdave tahtaya çarpıyor. Kısmen, Ben’in tahtayı parçalayıp içeri girmesini ve çizgi film karakteri gibi Ben şeklinde bir oyuk bırakmasını bekliyorum. Bunun yerine levhadan sekip kumlu toprak denizinin ortasındaki parlak bir çimen parçasına, kıçüstü düşüyor. Ben, omzunu ovuşturarak yana doğru yuvarlanıyor. “Kırıldı,” diye beyan ediyor.
es: Estoy a punto de rebatir esa lógica absurda cuando echa a correr y pasa por delante de mí como una flecha. Sigue acelerando mientras se acerca a la plancha y luego, sin miedo, en el último segundo, pega un salto, gira el cuerpo, saca el hombro para que cargue con la fuerza del impacto y cae en la madera. Casi espero que la atraviese y deje su silueta recortada, como en los dibujos animados. Pero rebota en la plancha y cae de culo en una zona de hierba situada en medio de la arena. Ben se gira hacia un lado frotándose el hombro. —Se ha roto —dice.
vi_translation: I was about to refute that childish logic, when Ben took off, zooming past me like a blur. The closer he got to the wooden plank, the faster he accelerated, and finally, without any hesitation, he jumped at the last second, twisting his body—shoulder first to absorb the impact—and crashed into the wood. I half-expected him to break through the plank and leave a Ben-shaped hole, just like in a cartoon. But he bounced off the wood, landing flat on the bright patch of grass, in a cloud of dust. Ben rolled over, rubbing his shoulder. "It's broken," he declared.
tr_translation: As he springs into action and runs past me in a blur, I am about to dismiss his foolish logic. He continues to accelerate as he approaches the board and then, completely fearlessly, at the very last possible second, he leaps into the air, twists his body sideways with his shoulder out to bear the brunt of the impact, and crashes into the board. Part of me expects Ben to smash through the board and leave a Ben-shaped hole in it like a cartoon character. Instead, he bounces off the board and lands on his backside on a bright patch of grass in the middle of the sandy soil sea. Ben rolls to the side, rubbing his shoulder. “It broke,” he declares.
es_translation: I am about to refute that absurd logic when he starts running and passes in front of me like an arrow. He keeps accelerating as he approaches the plank and then, fearlessly, at the last second, he jumps, twists his body, throws out his shoulder to bear the brunt of the impact, and lands on the wood. I almost expect him to go through it and leave his silhouette cut out, like in cartoons. But he bounces off the plank and lands on his butt in a grassy area in the middle of the sand. Ben turns to one side, rubbing his shoulder. —It has broken —he says.

en: I assume he means his shoulder as I race toward him, but then he stands up, and I’m looking at a Ben-high crack in the particle-board. I start kicking at it, and the crack spreads horizontally, and then Radar and I get our fingers inside the crack and start tugging. I squint to keep the sweat from burning my eyes, and pull with all my force back and forth until the crack starts to make a jagged opening. Radar and I urge it on with silent work, until eventually he has to take a break and Ben replaces him. Finally we are able to punch a big chunk of the board into the minimall. I climb in feetfirst, landing blindly onto what feels like a stack of papers.
vi: Tôi nghĩ Ben muốn nói vai nó vỡ rồi nên chạy vội lại, nhưng rồi nó đứng lên, và tôi thấy một vết nứt cao-bằng-Ben trên tấm gỗ ép. Tôi bắt đầu đá vào đó, vết nứt toác dọc ra, rồi Radar và tôi lách được ngón tay qua vết nứt và bắt đầu giật mạnh. Tôi nhíu mày để mồ hôi không chảy xuống làm cay mắt, ra sức kéo ra đẩy vào cho vết nứt đó loang rộng ra. Radar và tôi cùng nghiến răng làm, cho đến khi Radar phải nghỉ một lát lấy sức và Ben thế chỗ. Cuối cùng, ba thằng khoét được một lỗ kha khá trên tấm gỗ ép để vào được bên trong khu mua sắm mini này. Tôi trèo vào, tù mù đặt chân lên thứ gì đó như là một đống giấy tờ.
tr: Ona doğru koşarken omzunu kastettiğini farz ediyorum ama sonra ayağa kalkıyor ve sunta levhada Ben yüksekliğindeki çatlağa bakıyorum. Tekmelemeye başlıyorum ve çatlak yatay olarak genişliyor, sonra Radarla parmaklarımızı çatlağın içine geçirip asılmaya başlıyoruz. Terin gözlerimi yakmasını engellemek için gözlerimi kısarak bakıyorum ve çatlak girintili çıkıntılı bir açıklık yaratmaya başlayana kadar bütün gücümle ileri geri asılıyorum. Sessiz bir çalışmayla Radar’la, en sonunda ara vermesi gerekene kadar açıklığa baskı yapıyoruz, sonra Ben onun yerine geçiyor. Nihayet levhadan büyük, iri bir parçayı mağazanın içine doğru yumruklayabiliyoruz. Ayaklarım önde tırmanıyor, kâğıt yığını gibi gelen bir şeylerin üzerinde körlemesineyere iniyorum.
es: Doy por sentado que habla del hombro y corro hacia él, pero se levanta y veo una grieta en la plancha de conglomerado, a su altura. Empiezo a darle patadas y la grieta se expande horizontalmente. Entonces Radar y yo metemos los dedos en la grieta y tiramos. Entrecierro los ojos para evitar que me entre el sudor y tiro con todas mis fuerzas hasta que la grieta empieza a formar una abertura dentada. Seguimos en silencio hasta que Radar necesita descansar y lo sustituye Ben. Al final conseguimos lanzar un trozo grande de plancha dentro del local. Meto los pies y aterrizo a ciegas en lo que parece un montón de papeles.
vi_translation: I think Ben meant to say his shoulder was broken and rushed over, but then he stood up, and I saw a Ben-height crack on the plywood. I started kicking at it, the crack split open, then Radar and I managed to wedge our fingers into the crack and began pulling hard. I squinted to keep the sweat from running into my eyes and stinging them, pulling and pushing to widen the crack. Radar and I gritted our teeth and kept at it until Radar had to take a break to catch his breath and Ben took over. Finally, the three of us managed to make a sizable hole in the plywood to get inside this mini shopping area. I climbed in, blindly stepping onto something that felt like a pile of papers.
tr_translation: As I run towards her, I assume she means her shoulder, but then she stands up and I look at the crack in the particle board at Ben's height. I start kicking, and the crack widens horizontally, then Radar and I start pulling ourselves up by sticking our fingers into the crack. Squinting to prevent the sweat from stinging my eyes, I look and swing back and forth with all my strength until I start creating a jagged opening. With silent effort, Radar and I press against the opening until he finally needs a break, then Ben takes his place. At last, we manage to punch a large, hefty piece of the board into the store. My feet climb first, and I blindly land on something that feels like a pile of paper.
es_translation: I take for granted that he is talking about the shoulder and run towards him, but he gets up and I see a crack in the particle board at his height. I start kicking it and the crack expands horizontally. Then Radar and I stick our fingers into the crack and pull. I squint to avoid getting sweat in my eyes and pull with all my strength until the crack starts to form a jagged opening. We continue in silence until Radar needs to rest and Ben takes his place. In the end, we manage to throw a large piece of the board inside the place. I stick my feet in and land blindly on what seems to be a pile of papers.

en: The hole we’ve carved into this building gives a little light, but I can’t even make out the dimensions of the room, or whether there is a ceiling. The air in here is so stale and hot that inhaling and exhaling feel identical.
vi: Chút ánh sáng lọt được vào bên trong qua cái lỗ bọn tôi vừa khoét, nhưng tôi vẫn không thể hình dung được phương hướng, cũng không nhận biết được liệu phía trên có trần hay không. Không khí trong này ngột ngạt và bức bối đến mức hít vào hay thở ra cũng na ná như nhau.
tr: Binaya oyduğumuz delik içeri biraz ışık veriyor ama alanın boyutlarını ya da tavan olup olmadığım bile çıkaramıyorum. İçerideki hava o kadar bayat ve sıcak ki soluk almak ya da vermek farksız geliyor.
es: Por el agujero que hemos abierto entra algo de luz, pero no veo las dimensiones de la sala, ni si hay techo. El aire es tan cálido y está tan viciado que inspirar produce la misma sensación que espirar.
vi_translation: A bit of light seeped inside through the hole we had just made, but I still couldn't make out the direction, nor could I tell if there was a ceiling above. The air in here was so stifling and oppressive that inhaling and exhaling felt almost the same.
tr_translation: The hole we carved into the building lets in a bit of light, but I can't even make out the dimensions of the space or whether there is a ceiling. The air inside is so stale and hot that breathing in or out feels the same.
es_translation: Through the hole we have opened, some light enters, but I cannot see the dimensions of the room, nor if there is a ceiling. The air is so warm and stale that inhaling produces the same sensation as exhaling.

en: I turn around and my chin hits Ben’s forehead. I find myself whispering, even though there’s no reason to. “Do you have a—”
vi: Tôi quay lại và cằm tôi va phải trán Ben. Tôi thì thào, dù chẳng có lí do gì phải thì thào như vậy. “Ông có cái–”
tr: Arkamı dönüyorum ve çenem Ben’in alnına çarpıyor. Ortada bir neden olmamasına rağmen, kendimi fısıldarken buluyorum. “Şey var mı...
es: Me giro y me doy con la barbilla en la frente de Ben. Me descubro a mí mismo hablando en susurros, aunque no hay razón para ello. —¿Tienes una…?
vi_translation: I turned around and my chin hit Ben's forehead. I whispered, even though there was no reason to whisper like that. "You have a–"
tr_translation: I turn around and my chin hits Ben's forehead. Even though there is no reason, I find myself whispering. "Is there something..."
es_translation: I turn and bump my chin against Ben's forehead. I find myself speaking in whispers, even though there's no reason for it. —Do you have a…?

en: “No,” he whispers back before I can finish. “Radar, did you bring a flashlight?”
vi: “Không,” Ben thì thầm lại trước khi tôi nói hết câu. “Radar ơi, ông có mang đèn pin không?”
tr: Sözümü bitiremeden, “Hayır,” diye fısıldıyor Ben karşılık olarak. “Radar, el feneri getirdin mi?
es: —No —me contesta también en susurros antes de que haya terminado de decirlo—. Radar, ¿has traído una linterna?
vi_translation: "No," Ben whispered back before I finished my sentence. "Radar, do you have a flashlight?"
tr_translation: Before I can finish my sentence, Ben whispers in response, "No." "Radar, did you bring the flashlight?"
es_translation: —No —he also answers me in whispers before I have finished saying it—. Radar, did you bring a flashlight?

en: I hear Radar coming through the hole. “I have one on my key chain. It’s not much, though.”
vi: Tôi nghe thấy tiếng Radar trèo vào. “Có một cái trên dây đeo chìa khóa của tôi, nhưng không sáng lắm đâu.”
tr: Radar’ın delikten geçtiğini duyuyorum. “Anahtarlığımda bir tane var. Çok büyük bir şey değil gerçi.
es: Oigo a Radar entrando por el agujero. —Tengo una en el llavero, pero no es gran cosa. Enciende la luz.
vi_translation: I heard the sound of Radar climbing in. “There’s one on my keychain, but it’s not very bright.”
tr_translation: I hear Radar going through the hole. "I have one on my keychain. It's not a big deal, though."
es_translation: I hear Radar coming in through the hole. —I have one on the keychain, but it's not a big deal. Turn on the light.

en: The light comes on, and I still can’t see very well, but I can tell we’ve stepped into a big room filled with a labyrinth of metal shelves. The papers on the floor are pages from an old day-by-day calendar, the days scattered through the room, all of them yellowing and mouse-bit. I wonder if this might once have been a little bookstore, although it’s been decades since these shelves held anything but dust.
vi: Ánh sáng rọi đến, tôi vẫn chẳng thấy gì rõ rệt, nhưng có thể nói được rằng chúng tôi đang ở trong một căn phòng rộng, đầy một mê hồn trận những giá sắt. Đống giấy trên sàn là từ lịch xé hàng ngày, những tờ lịch rải rác rơi khắp phòng, tất cả đều đã ố vàng và bị chuột gặm. Tôi tự hỏi không biết nơi này có từng là một hiệu sách nhỏ hay không, dù hàng thập kỉ đã trôi qua và trên giá không có gì ngoài bụi.
tr: Işık yanıyor ve hâlâ çok iyi göremiyorum ama metal raflardan oluşan bir labirentle dolu büyük bir odaya adım attığımızı anlayabiliyorum. Yerdeki kâğıtlar eski bir takvimden yapraklar, günler odanın etrafına dağılmış, hepsi sararmış ve fareler tarafından kemirilmiş. Buranın bir zamanlar küçük bir kitapçı olup olmadığını merak ediyorum, bununla beraber bu raflar tozdan başka bir şey tutmayalı on yıllar olmuş.
es: Sigo sin ver muy bien, pero está claro que hemos entrado en una gran sala con un laberinto de estanterías metálicas. Los papeles del suelo son páginas de un viejo calendario. Los días están esparcidos por la sala, todos ellos amarillentos y mordidos por los ratones. Me pregunto si esto pudo ser una librería, aunque hace décadas que los estantes no albergan otra cosa que polvo.
vi_translation: The light shone in, I still couldn't see anything clearly, but it could be said that we were in a large room, filled with a labyrinth of iron shelves. The pile of papers on the floor was from a daily torn calendar, the scattered pages falling all over the room, all yellowed and gnawed by mice. I wondered if this place had ever been a small bookstore, though decades had passed and there was nothing on the shelves but dust.
tr_translation: The light is on and I still can't see very well, but I can understand that we have stepped into a large room filled with a labyrinth of metal shelves. The papers on the floor are pages from an old calendar, days scattered around the room, all yellowed and gnawed by mice. I wonder if this place was once a small bookstore, however, these shelves haven't held anything but dust for decades.
es_translation: I still can't see very well, but it's clear that we have entered a large room with a labyrinth of metal shelves. The papers on the floor are pages from an old calendar. The days are scattered around the room, all of them yellowed and gnawed by mice. I wonder if this could have been a bookstore, although the shelves have housed nothing but dust for decades.

en: We fall into line behind Radar. I hear something creak above us, and we all stop moving. I try to swallow the panic. I can hear each of Radar’s and Ben’s breaths, their shuffling footsteps. I want out of here, but that could be Margo creaking for all I know. It could also be crack addicts.
vi: Chúng tôi đi hàng một sau Radar. Tôi nghe thấy có tiếng cót két trên đầu, cả bọn liền dừng lại. Cố gắng nốt trôi cảm giác hoảng loạn, tôi nghe được từng nhịp thở của Radar và Ben, từng bước chân loạt soạt. Tôi muốn ra khỏi chỗ này, nhưng đó có thể là Margo ra hiệu cho tôi. Đó cũng có thể là những con nghiện đầy ranh ma.
tr: Radar’ın arkasında sıraya giriyoruz. Üstümüzde bir şeyin gıcırdadığını duyuyorum ve hepimiz hareket etmeyi bırakıyoruz. Paniğimi bastırmaya çalışıyorum.
