Radar ile Ben’in nefeslerini ve ayaklarım yere sürtmelerini duyabiliyorum. Buradan çıkmak istiyorum ama neticede gıcırdayanın Margo olması mümkün. Kokain bağımlıları da.
es: Nos ponemos en fila detrás de Radar. Oigo algo crujir encima de nosotros y nos quedamos los tres quietos. Intento tragarme el pánico. Oigo las respiraciones de Radar y de Ben, sus pasos arrastrando los pies. Quiero salir de aquí, pero el crujido podría ser Margo. También podrían ser adictos al crack.
vi_translation: We walked in single file behind Radar. I heard a creaking sound above, and we all stopped. Trying to swallow the feeling of panic, I could hear every breath of Radar and Ben, every rustling step. I wanted to get out of this place, but it could be Margo signaling to me. It could also be the cunning addicts.
tr_translation: We line up behind Radar. I hear something creaking above us and we all stop moving. I try to suppress my panic. I can hear Radar and Ben's breaths and my feet scraping the ground. I want to get out of here, but it could just be Margo who's creaking. Or cocaine addicts.
es_translation: We line up behind Radar. I hear something creak above us and the three of us stand still. I try to swallow my panic. I hear Radar and Ben's breathing, their shuffling footsteps. I want to get out of here, but the creaking could be Margo. It could also be crack addicts.

en: “Just the building settling,” Radar whispers, but he seems less sure than usual. I stand there unable to move. After a moment, I hear Ben’s voice. “The last time I was this scared, I peed myself.”
vi: “Chỉ là tòa nhà này tự lắng lại sau màn rung rinh vừa rồi thôi mà,” Radar thì thầm, nhưng nó có vẻ không quả quyết như thường lệ. Tôi đứng không nhúc nhích nổi. Lát sau, tôi nghe thấy tiếng Ben. “Lần cuối sợ đến mức này, tôi đã quẩn ra tiều.”
tr: “Döşemeler yerine oturuyor,” diye fısıldıyor Radar ama her zamankinden daha az emin görünüyor. Orada hareket edemez halde duruyorum. Bir dakika sonra Ben’in sesini duyuyorum. “En son bu kadar korktuğumda altıma işemiştim.
es: —Son los cimientos del edificio —susurra Radar, aunque parece menos seguro de lo habitual. Me quedo donde estoy, incapaz de moverme. Al momento oigo la voz de Ben. —La última vez que tuve tanto miedo me meé encima.
vi_translation: “It's just the building settling down after that little shake,” Radar whispered, but he didn't sound as confident as usual. I stood frozen. A moment later, I heard Ben's voice. “The last time I was this scared, I nearly peed my pants.”
tr_translation: “The floors are settling,” whispers Radar, but he seems less sure than usual. I stand there unable to move. A minute later, I hear Ben’s voice. “The last time I was this scared, I peed my pants.”
es_translation: —They are the foundations of the building —whispers Radar, although he seems less sure than usual. I stay where I am, unable to move. At that moment, I hear Ben's voice. —The last time I was this scared, I peed myself.

en: “The last time I was this scared,” Radar says, “I actually had to face a Dark Lord in order to make the world safe for wizards.”
vi: “Lần cuối sợ đến mức này,” Radar góp chuyện, “tôi thực sự đã phải đối mặt với Chúa Tể Hắc Ám vì an nguy của thế giới phù thủy.”
tr: “En son bu kadar korktuğumda,” diyor Radar, “dünyayı büyücüler için güvenli hale getirmek amacıyla Karanlık Lord’la yüzleşmek zorunda kalmıştım.
es: —La última vez que tuve tanto miedo —dijo Radar— tuve que enfrentarme a un Lord Oscuro para que los magos estuvieran seguros.
vi_translation: "The last time I was this scared," Radar chimed in, "I actually had to face the Dark Lord for the safety of the wizarding world."
tr_translation: “The last time I was this scared,” says Radar, “I had to face the Dark Lord to make the world safe for wizards.”
es_translation: —The last time I was this scared —said Radar— I had to face a Dark Lord to keep the wizards safe.

en: I made a feeble attempt. “The last time I was this scared I had to sleep in Mommy’s room.”
vi: Tôi nỗ lực một cách yếu ớt. “Lần cuối sợ đến mức này, tôi đã phải ngủ trong phòng mẹ.”
tr: Zayıf bir girişimde bulunuyorum. “En son bu kadar korktuğumda anneciğimin odasında uyumak zorunda kalmıştım.
es: Hice un débil intento: —La última vez que tuve tanto miedo tuve que dormir en la habitación de mi madre.
vi_translation: I made a feeble effort. "The last time I was this scared, I had to sleep in my mother's room."
tr_translation: I am making a weak attempt. "The last time I was this scared, I had to sleep in my mother's room."
es_translation: I made a feeble attempt: —The last time I was this scared, I had to sleep in my mother's room.

en: Ben chuckles. “Q, if I were you, I would get that scared Every. Single. Night.”
vi: Ben khúc khích. “Q này, nếu tôi là ông, tôi sẽ muốn sợ đến mức này Mỗi. Đêm.”
tr: Ben kıkırdıyor. “Q, eğer senin yerinde olsaydım, her zaman o kadar korkardım. Her. Gece.
es: Ben suelta una risita. —Q, si yo fuera tú, tendría tanto miedo todas las noches.
vi_translation: Ben chuckled. "Q, if I were you, I would want to be this scared Every. Night."
tr_translation: I'm giggling. "Q, if I were you, I would always be that scared. Every. Night."
es_translation: Ben lets out a chuckle. —Q, if I were you, I would be so scared every night.

en: I’m not up for laughing, but their laughter makes the room feel safer, and so we begin to explore. We walk through each row of shelves, finding nothing but a few copies of Reader’s Digest from the 1970s lying on the floor. After a while, I find my eyes adjusting to the darkness, and in the gray light we start walking in different directions at different speeds.
vi: Tôi chẳng có tâm trạng nào cười, nhưng tiếng cười của hai thằng khiến căn phòng có cảm giác an toàn hơn, và chúng tôi bắt đầu khám phá. Ba đứa đi qua từng dãy giá sắt, chẳng thấy gì ngoài vài số tạp chí Reader’s Digest từ những năm 1970 trên sàn. Một lúc sau, mắt bắt đầu quen với bóng tối, và trong ánh sáng mờ mờ, chúng tôi bắt đầu đi về những hướng khác nhau, nhanh chậm khác nhau.
tr: Gülme havamda değilim ama onların kahkahaları odayı daha güvenli hissettiriyor ve böylece araştırmaya başlıyoruz. Her raf sırasını inceliyoruz ve yerde duran 1970’lerden kalma birkaç Readers Digest sayısından başka bir şey bulamıyoruz. Bir süre sonra, gözlerim karanlığa alışıyor ve gri ışıkta farklı hızlarda, farklı yönlere doğru yürümeye başlıyoruz.
es: No estoy de humor para reírme, pero sus risas consiguen que la sala parezca segura, de modo que empezamos a explorarla. Pasamos entre las filas de estanterías, pero lo único que encontramos son algunas copias del Reader’s Digest de la década de los setenta tiradas en el suelo. Al rato mis ojos se han adaptado a la oscuridad y medio a oscuras empezamos a andar en diferentes direcciones y a diferentes velocidades.
vi_translation: I wasn't in the mood to laugh, but the laughter of the two made the room feel safer, and we began to explore. The three of us walked past each row of iron shelves, seeing nothing but a few issues of Reader’s Digest from the 1970s on the floor. After a while, our eyes adjusted to the darkness, and in the dim light, we began to move in different directions, at different paces.
tr_translation: I'm not in the mood to laugh, but their laughter makes the room feel safer, and so we begin to investigate. We examine each row of shelves and find nothing but a few issues of Readers Digest from the 1970s lying on the floor. After a while, my eyes adjust to the darkness, and in the gray light, we start walking in different directions at different speeds.
es_translation: I'm not in the mood to laugh, but their laughter makes the room seem safe, so we start to explore it. We pass between the rows of shelves, but the only thing we find are some copies of Reader's Digest from the seventies lying on the floor. After a while, my eyes have adjusted to the darkness and half in the dark we start to walk in different directions and at different speeds.

en: “No one leaves the room until everyone leaves the room,” I whisper, and they whisper okay’s back. I get to a side wall of the room and find the first evidence that someone has been here since everyone left. A jagged semicircular, waist-high tunnel has been cut out of the wall. The words TROLL HOLE have been spray-painted in orange above the hole, with a helpful arrow pointing down to the hole. “Guys,” Radar says, so loud that the spell breaks for just a moment. I follow his voice and find him standing by the opposite wall, his flashlight illuminating another Troll Hole. The graffiti doesn’t look particularly like Margo’s, but it’s hard to tell for sure. I’ve only seen her spray-paint a single letter.
vi: “Không ai rời phòng này cho đến khi tất cả cùng ra nhé,” tôi thì thầm giao hẹn, và hai thằng kia thì thầm đáp đồng ý. Tôi đến trước một vách tường ngăn căn phòng và phát hiện ra bằng chứng đầu tiên cho thấy có người đã vào đây sau khi tòa nhà bị bỏ hoang. Một lỗ bán nguyệt nham nhở, cao chừng ngang hông, được đục xuyên qua tường. Hai từ LỖ QUỈ được phun bằng sơn màu da cam ở phía trên, và một mũi tên tận tình chỉ xuống cái lỗ bên dưới. “Này,” Radar gọi, to đến mức tiếng như vỡ ra trong chốc lát. Tôi đi về phía tiếng nó và thấy Radar đang đứng trước một mảng tường, đèn pin rọi lên một Lỗ Quỉ nữa. Chữ graffiti không đặc biệt giống kiểu của Margo, nhưng khó mà nói chắc được. Tôi mới thấy cô ấy phun sơn viết mỗi một chữ cái.
tr: “Herkes odadan aynlana kadar, kimse odayı terk etmiyor,” diye fısıldıyorum ve karşılık olarak tamam diye fısıldıyorlar. Odanın duvarlarından birine yanaşıyorum ve burası terk edildikten sonra birinin burada bulunduğunu gösteren ilk delili buluyorum. Duvara yarım daire şeklinde, girintili çıkıntılı, bel hizasında bir tünel kazılmış. Yukarıya turuncu sprey boyayla, aşağıdaki deliği işaret eden yardımcı bir okla birlikte, CÜCE DELİĞİ kelimeleri yazılmış. “Çocuklar,” diyor Radar, o kadar yüksek sesle söylüyor ki, sadece bir anlığına büyü bozuluyor. Sesini takip edip onu karşı duvarda dururken buluyorum, el feneri başka bir Cüce Deliği’ni aydınlatıyor. Duvar yazısı bilhassa Margo’nunmuş gibi görünmüyor ama kesin bir şey söylemek zor. Ne de olsa sprey boyayla tek bir harf yazdığını görmüştüm.
es: —Que ninguno salga hasta que salgamos todos —susurro. Me susurran que de acuerdo. Voy hacia una pared lateral de la sala y encuentro la primera evidencia de que alguien ha estado aquí después de que todo el mundo se hubiera marchado. En la pared, a la altura de mi cintura, hay un túnel más o menos semicircular. Encima del agujero han escrito las palabras AGUJERO DE TROL con espray naranja, además de una útil flecha que apunta al agujero. —Chicos —dice Radar tan alto que por un momento se rompe el hechizo. Sigo su voz y lo encuentro en la pared del otro lado, iluminando con la linterna otro Agujero de Trol. El grafiti no se parece demasiado a los de Margo, pero no podría asegurarlo. Solo la he visto pintar una letra.
vi_translation: “No one leaves this room until we all leave together, okay?” I whispered the agreement, and the other two whispered their consent. I approached a partition wall in the room and discovered the first evidence that someone had entered here after the building was abandoned. A jagged semicircular hole, about waist-high, had been chiseled through the wall. The words DEMON HOLE were spray-painted in orange above it, with an arrow helpfully pointing down to the hole below. “Hey,” Radar called out, loud enough that it seemed to shatter for a moment. I walked towards the sound and saw Radar standing in front of another section of wall, flashlight illuminating another Demon Hole. The graffiti style didn’t particularly resemble Margo’s, but it was hard to be certain. I had only seen her spray-paint a single letter.
tr_translation: “No one leaves the room until everyone is mirrored,” I whisper, and they whisper back in agreement. I move towards one of the walls of the room and find the first evidence that someone has been here since it was abandoned. A semi-circular, indented, waist-high tunnel has been dug into the wall. Above, the words DWARF HOLE are written in orange spray paint, accompanied by an auxiliary arrow pointing to the hole below. “Kids,” says Radar, so loudly that the spell is broken for just a moment. I follow his voice and find him standing against the opposite wall, his flashlight illuminating another Dwarf Hole. The graffiti doesn't particularly look like it belongs to Margo, but it's hard to say for sure. After all, I had seen her write a single letter with spray paint.
es_translation: —Let no one leave until we all leave —I whisper. They whisper to me that they agree. I go towards a side wall of the room and find the first evidence that someone has been here after everyone else had left. On the wall, at waist height, there is a more or less semicircular tunnel. Above the hole, the words TROLL HOLE are written in orange spray, along with a helpful arrow pointing to the hole. —Guys —says Radar so loudly that for a moment the spell is broken. I follow his voice and find him on the other side of the wall, illuminating another Troll Hole with the flashlight. The graffiti doesn't look much like Margo's, but I couldn't be sure. I've only seen her paint one letter.

en: Radar shines the light through the hole as I duck down and lead the way through. This room is entirely empty except for a rolled carpet in one corner. As the flashlight scans the floor, I can see glue stains on the concrete from where the carpet had once been. Across the room, I can just make out another hole cut into the wall, this time without the graffiti.
vi: Radar chiếu đèn qua cái lỗ ấy trong khi tôi khom người chui qua đầu tiên. Căn phòng bên này hoàn toàn trống không, trừ tấm thảm cuộn lại trong góc. Khi đèn chiếu xuống sàn, tôi thấy những vệt keo còn trên nền bê-tông, chỗ trước ắt là có tấm thảm. Nhìn qua phòng, tôi thấy thêm một lỗ thông trên tường nữa, lần này không có chữ viết.
tr: Radar ışığı deliğin içine tutuyor, ben de çömelip içeri giriyorum. Bu oda bir köşedeki rulo yapılmış hah dışında tamamen boş. Fener yeri tararken, betonun üzerinde bir zamanlar halının olduğu yerdeki yapıştırıcı lekelerini görebiliyorum. Odanın karşısında, duvara kazılmış sadece başka bir delik daha görebiliyorum, bu sefer duvarda yazı yok.
es: Radar enfoca la linterna hacia el agujero, y yo me agacho y entro el primero. Lo único que hay en la sala es una moqueta enrollada en una esquina. La linterna recorre el suelo y veo manchas de cola en el hormigón, donde antes había estado la moqueta. Al fondo de la sala descubro otro agujero abierto en la pared, esa vez sin grafiti.
vi_translation: Radar shone the light through the hole while I bent down and crawled through first. The room on this side was completely empty, except for a rolled-up carpet in the corner. When the light shone on the floor, I saw glue streaks still on the concrete, where there must have been a carpet before. Looking across the room, I saw another vent hole on the wall, this time without any writing.
tr_translation: Radar shines the light into the hole, and I crouch down and go inside. This room is completely empty except for a rolled-up rug in one corner. As the flashlight scans the area, I can see adhesive stains on the concrete where a carpet once was. On the opposite side of the room, I can see just another hole dug into the wall, but this time there is no writing on the wall.
es_translation: Radar focuses the flashlight towards the hole, and I crouch down and enter first. The only thing in the room is a rolled-up carpet in a corner. The flashlight scans the floor and I see glue stains on the concrete, where the carpet used to be. At the back of the room, I discover another hole in the wall, this time without graffiti.

en: I crawl through that Troll Hole into a room lined with clothing racks, the stainless-steel poles still bolted into walls wine-stained with water damage. This room is better lit, and it takes me a moment to realize it’s because there are several holes in the roof—tar paper hangs down, and I can see places where the roof sags against exposed steel girders.
vi: Tôi chui qua Lỗ Quỉ đó vào một căn phòng có hàng dãy móc treo quần áo, các cọc thép không gỉ vẫn kiên cố giữa những mảng tường loang lổ ngấm nước dột. Phòng này sáng hơn, mất một lúc tôi mới nhận ra đó là do có vài lỗ thủng trên mái–giấy phết hắc ín rã xuống, và tôi thấy được những chỗ trần mái tì vào các rầm sắt giờ trơ ra.
tr: O Cüce Deliği’nden sürünerek elbise askıları dizili bir odaya geçiyorum, paslanmaz çelik direkler hâlâ üstünde su lekeleri olan duvarlara tutturulmuş halde duruyor. Bu oda daha iyi ışık alıyor, bunun çatıda bir sürü delik olmasından kaynaklandığını fark etmem kısa bir zamanımı alıyor... katranlı kâğıt aşağı doğru sallanıyor ve çatıda çelik kirişlerin ortaya çıktığı yerleri görebiliyorum.
es: Gateo por ese Agujero de Trol hasta una sala con filas de estantes de ropa. Las perchas de acero inoxidable siguen colgadas en las paredes con manchas de color vino y de humedad. Esta sala está más iluminada, y tardo un momento en darme cuenta de que es porque en el techo hay varios agujeros. La tela asfáltica está colgando y veo trozos en los que el techo se hunde sobre vigas de hierro descubiertas.
vi_translation: I crawled through that Devil's Hole into a room with rows of clothes hooks, the stainless steel posts still sturdy amidst the water-stained, patchy walls. This room was brighter; it took me a moment to realize it was because of several holes in the roof—the tarred paper had worn away, and I could see the spots where the roof pressed against the now-exposed iron beams.
tr_translation: I crawl through the Dwarf Hole into a room lined with clothes hangers, stainless steel poles still bearing water stains It remains attached to the walls. This room gets better light, and it doesn't take me long to realize that it's because there are a lot of holes in the roof... The tarred paper is hanging down, and I can see the places where the steel beams are exposed in the roof.
es_translation: I crawl through that Troll Hole into a room with rows of clothing racks. The stainless steel hangers are still hanging on the walls with wine-colored and damp stains. This room is more illuminated, and it takes me a moment to realize that it's because there are several holes in the ceiling. The asphalt fabric is hanging down, and I see parts where the ceiling is sagging over exposed iron beams.

en: “Souvenir store,” Ben whispers in front of me, and I know immediately he is right.
vi: “Cửa hàng lưu niệm,” Ben thì thào trước mặt tôi, và tôi lập tức nhận ra nó nhận xét đúng.
tr: Önümde Ben, “Hediyelik eşya dükkânı,” diye fısıldıyor ve hemen haklı olduğunu anlıyorum.
es: —Una tienda de souvenirs —susurra Ben delante de mí. Y al momento me doy cuenta de que tiene razón.
vi_translation: “Souvenir shop,” Ben whispered in front of me, and I immediately realized he was right.
tr_translation: In front of me, Ben whispers, "Gift shop," and I immediately realize he is right.
es_translation: —A souvenir shop —whispers Ben in front of me. And at that moment I realize that he is right.

en: In the middle of the room five display cases form a pentagon. The glass that once kept the tourists from their tourist crap has mostly been shattered and lies in shards around the cases. The gray paint peels off the wall in odd and beautiful patterns, each cracked polygon of paint a snowflake of decay.
vi: Ở giữa phòng có năm tủ trưng bày được kê thành một hình ngũ giác. Lớp kính từng ngăn cách khách du lịch và những món đồ lưu niệm vô bổ đã vỡ gần hết, những mảnh thủy tinh vương vãi quanh tủ. Lớp sơn xám bong khỏi tường thành những họa tiết ngộ ngộ vui mắt, từng đa giác sơn nứt nẻ tạc thành hình một bông tuyết tàn tạ.
tr: Odanın ortasındaki beş vitrin bir beşgen oluşturuyor. Bir zamanlar turistleri, turist ıvır zıvırlarından uzak tutan cam, çoğunlukla tuzla buz olmuş. Gri boya, garip ve güzel motiflerle duvardan soyuluyor, boyanın her çatlağı, çürümeden meydana gelen bir kar tanesi gibi.
es: En medio de la sala, cinco vitrinas forman un pentágono. El cristal que en su momento separaba a los turistas de sus mierdas para turistas está hecho añicos en el suelo, alrededor de las vitrinas. La pintura gris se desconcha de las paredes formando bonitos dibujos. Cada polígono de pintura desconchada es como un copo de nieve de la decadencia.
vi_translation: In the middle of the room, there were five display cabinets arranged in a pentagon shape. The glass that once separated tourists from the useless souvenirs was mostly shattered, with shards of glass scattered around the cabinets. The gray paint peeled off the walls into amusing patterns, each cracked polygon forming the shape of a withered snowflake.
tr_translation: The five display cases in the middle of the room form a pentagon. The glass that once kept tourists away from tourist knick-knacks is mostly shattered. Gray paint is peeling off the wall with strange and beautiful patterns, each crack in the paint resembling a snowflake formed by decay.
es_translation: In the middle of the room, five display cases form a pentagon. The glass that once separated tourists from their tourist trinkets is shattered on the floor, around the display cases. The gray paint peels off the walls, forming beautiful patterns. Each polygon of peeled paint is like a snowflake of decay.

en: Strangely, though, there’s still some merchandise: there’s a Mickey Mouse phone I recognize from some way back part of childhood. Moth-bit but still-folded SUNNY ORLANDO T-shirts are on display, splattered with broken glass. Beneath the glass cases, Radar finds a box filled with maps and old tourist brochures advertising Gator World and Crystal Gardens and fun houses that no longer exist. Ben waves me over and silently points out the green glass alligator tchotchke lying alone in the case, almost buried in the dust. This is the value of our souvenirs, I think: you can’t give this shit away.
vi: Nhưng kì lạ là vẫn có chút dấu tích của buôn bán: một cái điện thoại chuột Mickey, hồi bé tôi từng thấy kiểu như vậy. Mấy cái áo phông ORLANDO NGẬP NẮNG bị gián nhấm nhưng còn nếp gấp và vẫn được trưng bày, lẫn với mảnh thủy tinh vỡ. Phía dưới tủ kính, Radar thấy một hộp đầy bản đồ và sách lữ hành, quảng cáo Gator World, Crystal Gardens và những căn nhà cười giờ không còn hoạt động nữa. Ben vẫy tôi, lặng lẽ trỏ một món lưu niệm hình cá sấu bằng thủy tinh xanh, nằm đơn độc trong một tủ trưng bày, gần như đã chôn vùi trong bụi. Đây chính là giá trị của các món đồ lưu niệm, tôi trộm nghĩ: ta chẳng thể nào vứt chúng đi.
tr: Garip bir biçimde hâlâ biraz eşya var: Çocukluğumun geçmişteki bir bölümünden hatırladığım bir Mickey Mouse telefonu. Güveler tarafından yenmiş ama hâlâ katlı olan GÜNEŞLİ ORLANDO tişörtleri hâlâ vitrinde, üzerlerine kırık camlar saçılmış. Cam vitrinlerin altında Radar haritalar ile artık var olmayan Timsah Dünyası, Kristal Bahçeler ve eğlence parklarının reklamını yapan eski turist broşürleriyle dolu bir kutu buluyor. Ben beni yanma çağırıp sessizce vitrinde tek başına duran, yeşil camdan bir timsah biblosunu işaret ediyor, neredeyse toza gömülmüş. Hatıralarımızın değeri bu samnm: bu saçmalıkları verebilmeniz mümkün değil.
es: Pero lo raro es que quedan algunos artículos. Hay un teléfono de Mickey Mouse que me recuerda a mi infancia. En las vitrinas, salpicadas de cristales rotos, hay camisetas mordidas por las polillas, aunque todavía dobladas, en las que pone ORLANDO AL SOL. Debajo de las vitrinas, Radar encuentra una caja llena de mapas y viejos folletos turísticos que publicitan Gator World, Crystal Gardens y otras atracciones que ya no existen. Ben me hace un gesto con la mano y sin decir nada señala el caimán de vidrio verde metido en una caja, casi enterrado entre el polvo. Esto es lo que valen nuestros recuerdos, pienso. No puedes regalar esta mierda.
vi_translation: But strangely, there were still some traces of commerce: a Mickey Mouse phone, the kind I had seen when I was a kid. Some ORLANDO SUNSHINE t-shirts, nibbled by cockroaches but still folded and displayed, mixed with broken glass shards. Under the glass cabinet, Radar found a box full of maps and travel books, advertising Gator World, Crystal Gardens, and those now-defunct funhouses. Ben waved at me, silently pointing to a green glass alligator souvenir, lying alone in a display case, almost buried in dust. This is the value of souvenirs, I thought to myself: we can never throw them away.
tr_translation: Strangely, there are still some items left: A Mickey Mouse phone that I remember from a part of my childhood. The SUNSHINE ORLANDO t-shirts, which have been eaten by moths but are still folded, are still in the display, with broken glass scattered over them. Under the glass displays, they find a box full of old tourist brochures advertising now-defunct amusement parks like Alligator World, Crystal Gardens, and others, along with radar maps. He calls me over and silently points to a green glass alligator figurine standing alone in the display, almost buried in dust. This is the value of our memories: it's impossible to give away these absurdities.
es_translation: But the strange thing is that there are still some items left. There is a Mickey Mouse phone that reminds me of my childhood. In the display cases, sprinkled with broken glass, there are moth-eaten t-shirts, still folded, that say ORLANDO IN THE SUN. Under the display cases, Radar finds a box full of maps and old tourist brochures advertising Gator World, Crystal Gardens, and other attractions that no longer exist. Ben gestures with his hand and without saying anything points to the green glass alligator in a box, almost buried in the dust. This is what our memories are worth, I think. You can't give this crap away.

en: We make our way back through the empty room and the shelved room and crawl through the last Troll Hole. This room looks like an office only without computers, and it appears to have been abandoned in a great hurry, like its employees were beamed up to space or something. Twenty desks sit in four rows. There are still pens on some of the desks, and they all feature oversize paper calendars lying flat against the desks. On each calendar, it is perpetually February of 1986. Ben pushes a cloth desk chair and it spins, creaking rhythmically. Thousands of Post-it notes advertising The Martin-Gale Mortgage Corp. are piled beside one desk in a rickety pyramid. Open boxes contain stacks of paper from old dot matrix printers, detailing the expenses and income of the Martin-Gale Mortgage Corp. On one of the desks, someone has stacked brochures for subdivisions into a single-story house of cards. I spread the brochures out, thinking that they may hold a clue, but no.
vi: Chúng tôi đi ngược lại, qua căn phòng trống và phòng có nhiều giá sắt, chui qua Lỗ Quỉ cuối cùng. Gian này trông như một văn phòng, có điều không có máy vi tính, và dường như nó bị bỏ lại chóng vánh, như thể các nhân viên bị đột ngột bắt cóc vào vũ trụ hay đại loại thế. Hai mươi bàn làm việc kê thành bốn dãy. Đây đó còn mấy cái bút trên mặt bàn, và bàn nào cũng còn lại những tờ lịch tường to chảng. Các tờ lịch nhất nhất dừng lại ở tháng Hai năm 1986. Ben đẩy một cái ghế bọc vải, cái ghế quay tròn, nhịp nhàng kêu ken két. Hàng ngàn tập giấy ghi chú quảng cáo Công Ti Thế Chấp Martin-Gale được chất cạnh một bàn, làm thành một kim tự tháp xiêu vẹo. Những cái hộp không đậy nắp, đựng hàng tập giấy từ những máy in kim cổ lỗ sĩ, thống kê thu chi của Công Ti Thế Chấp MartinGale. Trên một bàn khác, ai đó đã xếp những cuốn quảng cáo các tiểu khu thành hình ngôi nhà một tầng. Tôi xô đổ các cuốn quảng cáo, thầm mong chúng giữ manh mối gì đó, nhưng không có.
tr: Önce boş odadan, sonra raflı odadan geçerek geri dönüyor ve son Cüce Deliği’nden sürünerek geçiyoruz. Bu oda bir ofise benziyor fakat bilgisayar yok ve büyük bir aceleyle terk edilmiş gibi görünüyor, sanki çalışanları uzaya falan ışınlanmış gibi. Dört sıra halinde yirmi masa duruyor. Bazı masaların üzerinde hâlâ kalemler var ve bütün masaların özelliği düz bir halde üstlerinde yatan aşın büyük takvimler olması. Her takvim Şubat 1986’yı gösteriyor. Ben kumaş kaplı bir sandalyeyi itiyor ve sandalye, ritmik bir gıcırdamayla dönüyor. Bir masanın yanma MartinGale Mortgage Şirketi’nin reklamını yapan binlerce yapışkanlı not piramit şeklinde yığılmış. Açık kutularda, eski nokta vuruşlu yazıcılardan çıkan, MartinGale Mortgage Şirketi’nin gelirgiderlerinin detaylarını gösteren kâğıt desteleri var. Masalardan birinin üstünde birisi, semtlerin broşürlerini tek katlı bir karttan ev oluşturacak şekilde dizmiş. İçlerinde bir ipucu olabilir diye düşünerek broşürleri yayıyorum ama yok.
es: Volvemos atrás pasando por la sala vacía y la sala de las estanterías, y gateamos por el último Agujero de Trol. Esta sala parece un despacho, solo que no tiene ordenadores, y da la impresión de que la abandonaron a toda prisa, como si hubieran teletransportado al espacio a los trabajadores o algo así. Veinte mesas colocadas en cuatro filas. En alguna mesa todavía hay bolis, y todas ellas están cubiertas de calendarios de papel gigantes. Todos los calendarios se han detenido en febrero de 1986. Ben empuja una silla de escritorio, que al girar chirría rítmicamente. Miles de post-it con publicidad de la empresa de hipotecas Martin-Gale están apilados en forma de pirámide inestable debajo de una mesa. Hay cajas abiertas con pilas de papel de viejas impresoras matriciales que detallan los gastos y los ingresos de la empresa Martin-Gale. En una de las mesas alguien ha apilado folletos de urbanizaciones formando una casa de una planta. Extiendo los folletos por si esconden alguna pista, pero no.
vi_translation: We went back, through the empty room and the room with many iron shelves, crawling through the last Devil's Hole. This area looked like an office, except there were no computers, and it seemed to have been abandoned hastily, as if the employees had been suddenly abducted into space or something like that. Twenty desks arranged in four rows. Here and there were some pens on the desks, and each desk still had large wall calendars. All the calendars stopped at February 1986. Ben pushed a fabric-covered chair, the swivel chair creaking rhythmically. Thousands of note pads advertising Martin-Gale Mortgage Company were piled next to a desk, forming a wobbly pyramid. Uncovered boxes, containing stacks of paper from ancient dot matrix printers, held the financial statistics of Martin-Gale Mortgage Company. On another desk, someone had arranged brochures of subdivisions into the shape of a one-story house. I knocked over the brochures, hoping they held some clue, but they didn't.
tr_translation: First, we go back through the empty room, then through the room with shelves, and finally crawl through the last Dwarf Hole. This room looks like an office, but there are no computers, and it seems to have been abandoned in a great hurry, as if its workers were teleported to space or something. There are twenty desks arranged in four rows. Some desks still have pens on them, and all the desks feature large calendars lying flat on top of them. Each calendar shows February 1986. I push a fabric-covered chair, and the chair spins with a rhythmic creak. Next to one desk, thousands of sticky notes advertising the MartinGale Mortgage Company are piled up in a pyramid shape. In open boxes, there are printouts from old dot matrix printers, MartinGale There are stacks of papers showing the details of the income and expenses of the Mortgage Company. On top of one of the desks, someone has arranged neighborhood brochures to form a single-story house out of a card. Thinking there might be a clue inside them, I spread out the brochures, but there isn't.
es_translation: We go back through the empty room and the room with the shelves, and we crawl through the last Troll Hole. This room looks like an office, only it doesn't have computers, and it gives the impression that it was abandoned in a hurry, as if the workers had been teleported into space or something like that. Twenty tables arranged in four rows. There are still pens on some tables, and all of them are covered with giant paper calendars. All the calendars stopped in February 1986. Ben pushes a desk chair, which squeaks rhythmically as it turns. Thousands of post-it notes with advertisements for the Martin-Gale mortgage company are piled in an unstable pyramid shape under a table. There are open boxes with stacks of paper from old dot matrix printers detailing the expenses and income of the Martin-Gale company. On one of the tables, someone has stacked brochures of housing developments to form a one-story house. I spread out the brochures to see if they hide any clues, but no.

en: Radar fingers through the papers, whispering, “Nothing after 1986.” I start to go through the desk drawers. I find Q-tips and stickpins. Pens and pencils packed a dozen each in flimsy cardboard packaging with retro fonts and design. Napkins. A pair of golf gloves.
vi: Radar đưa ngón tay qua đống giấy tờ, khẽ nói, “Không có gì sau năm 1986 cả.” Tôi bắt đầu xem các hộc bàn. Có tăm bông ngoáy tai và ghim cài cra-vát. Bút và bút chì từng tá trong hộp bìa ọp ẹp, chữ in và kiểu dáng cũ kĩ. Khăn ăn. Một đôi găng tay chơi golf.
tr: Radar, “1986’dan sonra hiçbir şey yok,” diye fısıldayarak parmaklarıyla kâğıtları karıştırıyor. Masa çekmecelerini gözden geçirmeye başlıyorum. Kulak çöpleri ile kravat iğneleri buluyorum. Düzineler halinde, eski tarz fontları ve tasarımları olan karton ambalajlarla paketlenmiş dolmakalemler ve kurşun kalemler. Kâğıt peçeteler. Bir çift golf eldiveni.
es: —Nada de después de 1986 —suspira Radar pasando los dedos por los papeles. Empiezo a revisar los cajones. Encuentro bastoncillos para los oídos y alfileres. Bolígrafos y lápices metidos de diez en diez en cajas de cartulina con letras y diseños retro. Servilletas de papel. Un par de guantes de golf.
vi_translation: Radar ran his finger through the pile of papers and said quietly, “Nothing after 1986.” I started looking through the desk drawers. There were cotton swabs and tie pins. Pens and pencils by the dozen in rickety cardboard boxes, printed and styled old look. Napkin. A pair of golf gloves.
tr_translation: Radar, "There is nothing after 1986," he whispers while shuffling the papers with his fingers. I start to inspect the desk drawers. I find cotton swabs and tie pins. Dozens of fountain pens and pencils, packaged in cardboard boxes with old-fashioned fonts and designs. Paper napkins. A pair of golf gloves.
es_translation: —Nothing after 1986 —sighs Radar, running his fingers over the papers. I start to check the drawers. I find cotton swabs and pins. Pens and pencils packed ten by ten in cardboard boxes with retro letters and designs. Paper napkins. A pair of golf gloves.

en: “Do you guys see anything,” I ask, “that gives any hint that anyone has been here in the last, say, twenty years?”
vi: “Hai ông có thấy gì chứng tỏ có người đã ở đây trong khoảng, xem nào, hai chục năm đổ lại không?” tôi hỏi.
tr: “Çocuklar, siz bir şey görüyor musunuz?” diye soruyorum. “Son yirmi yıl içinde herhangi birinin burada bulunduğuna dair bir ipucu?
es: —¿Veis el menor indicio de que alguien haya estado aquí en los últimos veinte años, por decir algo? —les pregunto.
vi_translation: "Have you two seen anything that indicates someone has been here in the last, let's see, twenty years or so?" I asked.
tr_translation: “Children, do you see anything?” I ask. “Any clue that someone has been here in the last twenty years?”
es_translation: —Do you see the slightest indication that anyone has been here in the last twenty years, for instance? —I ask them.

en: “Nothing but the Troll Holes,” Ben answers. It’s a tomb, everything wrapped in dust.
vi: “Không có gì trừ các Lỗ Quỉ,” Ben đáp. Nơi này là một hầm mộ, cái gì cũng nằm yên dưới bụi.
tr: “Cüce Delikleri’nden başka hiçbir şey yok,” diye cevaplıyor Ben. Burası bir mezar, her şey toza bürünmüş.
es: —Solo los Agujeros de Trol —me contesta Ben. Es una tumba, todo cubierto de polvo.
vi_translation: "Nothing except the Ghouls," Ben replied. This place is a tomb, everything lies still under the dust.
tr_translation: “There is nothing but Dwarf Holes,” Ben replies. This place is a tomb, everything is covered in dust.
es_translation: —Only the Troll Holes —Ben answers me. It is a tomb, all covered in dust.

en: “So why did she lead us here?” asks Radar. We are speaking now.
vi: “Vậy sao Margo lại dẫn chúng ta đến đây?” Radar hỏi. Bây giờ chúng tôi đã nói được bình thường, không còn thì thào nữa.
tr: “O zaman Margo neden bizi buraya yönlendirdi?” diye soruyor Radar. Artık konuşuyoruz.
es: —Y entonces ¿por qué nos ha traído aquí? —pregunta Radar. Por fin empezamos a hablar.
vi_translation: “So why did Margo bring us here?” Radar asked. We could speak normally now, no longer whispering.
tr_translation: “Then why did Margo direct us here?” asks Radar. We are talking now.
es_translation: —And then why did you bring us here? —asks Radar. We finally started talking.

en: “Dunno,” I say. She is clearly not here.
vi: “Không biết,” tôi đáp. Rõ ràng là Margo không ở đây.
tr: “Bilmem,” diyorum. Belli ki Margo burada değil.
es: —Ni idea —le contesto. No hay duda de que Margo no está.
vi_translation: "I don't know," I replied. Clearly, Margo is not here.
tr_translation: "I don't know," I say. Clearly, Margo is not here.
es_translation: —No idea —I answered. There is no doubt that Margo is not here.

en: “There are some spots,” Radar says, “with less dust. There’s a dustless rectangle in the empty room, like something was moved. But I don’t know.”
vi: “Có mấy chỗ ít bụi hơn,” Radar nói. “Một hình chữ nhật không chút bụi bặm trong căn phòng trống không, như thể cái gì đó đã được chuyển đi. Nhưng tôi không biết.”
tr: “Bazı yerler var,” diyor Radar, “daha az tozlu. Boş odada tozsuz bir dikdörtgen var, sanki bir şey kaldırılmış gibi. Ama bilemiyorum.
es: —Hay manchas con menos polvo —dice Radar—. En la sala vacía hay un rectángulo sin polvo, como si hubieran movido algo. Pero no sé.
vi_translation: “There are a few places with less dust,” Radar said. “A dust-free rectangle in an otherwise empty room, as if something had been moved. But I don't know.”
tr_translation: “There are some places,” says Radar, “that are less dusty. In the empty room, there is a dust-free rectangle, as if something has been removed. But I don't know.”
es_translation: —There are spots with less dust —says Radar—. In the empty room, there is a dust-free rectangle, as if something had been moved. But I don't know.

en: “And there’s that painted part,” Ben says. Ben points and Radar’s flashlight shows me that a piece of the far wall in this office has been brushed over with white primer, like someone got the idea to remodel the place but abandoned the project after half an hour. I walk over to the wall, and up close, I can see that there’s some red graffiti behind the white paint. But I can only see occasional hints of the red paint bleeding through—not nearly enough to make anything out. There’s a can of primer up against the wall, open. I kneel down and push my finger into the paint. There’s a hard surface, but it breaks easily, and my finger comes up drenched in white. As the paint drips off my finger, I don’t say anything, because we’ve all come to the same conclusion, that someone has been here recently after all, and then the building creaks again and Radar drops the flashlight and curses.
vi: “Và có mấy chỗ sơn,” Ben góp thêm. Ben chỉ, ánh đèn của Radar theo đó rọi lên một mảng ở góc xa trên tường văn phòng này. Mảng tường được phủ sơn lót, như thể ai đó nảy ra ý tưởng thiết kế lại nơi này, nhưng rồi bỏ dở dự án sau khoảng nửa tiếng đồng hồ. Tôi tiến tới mảng tường đó, và gần lại, tôi thấy có hình graffiti màu đỏ dưới lớp sơn trắng. Nhưng chỉ thấy được lấp ló màu đỏ như rỉ ra qua mảng trắng–gần như không hiểu được đó là gì. Một thùng sơn lót ở ngay sát tường, còn mở nắp. Tôi quì xuống và nhúng ngón tay vào sơn. Mặt sơn đã cứng lại, nhưng dễ dàng rạn ra, và khi rút lên ngón tay tôi đã được hoàn toàn phủ trắng. Khi những giọt sơn nhỏ từ ngón tay tôi xuống, tôi không nói gì vì chúng tôi đều có chung kết luận: rút cục gần đây đã có ai đó đến chỗ này. Tiếng cót két lại vang lên đâu đó trong tòa nhà, Radar đánh rơi đèn pin.
tr: “Ve şu boyanmış bölüm var,” diyor Ben. İşaret ediyor ve Radar’m feneri, ofisin karşı duvarının bir kısmının beyaz astar boyasıyla boyandığını gösteriyor, sanki biri odaya bir değişiklik yapma fikrine kapılmış ancak yarım saat sonra bu projeden vazgeçmiş gibi. Duvara doğru yürüyorum ve yakınlaşınca, beyaz boyanın altında kırmızı bir duvar yazısı olduğunu görebiliyorum. Ama kırmızı duvar yazısından yalnızca tek tük izler görebiliyorum... bir şeyler anlamak için kesinlikle yeterli değil. Duvarın tam karşısında açık bir boya kutusu var. Diz çöküp parmağımı boyanın içine bastırıyorum. Yüzeyi sert ama kolayca kırılıyor ve parmağım beyaza bulanmış halde dışarı çıkıyor. Boya parmağımdan damlarken hiçbir şey söylemiyorum çünkü hepimiz yakın zamanda birinin buraya geldiğine dair aynı sonuca varıyoruz, sonra bina tekrar gıcırdıyor ve Radar feneri düşürüp küfrediyor.
es: —Y está este trozo pintado —observa Ben señalando a una pared. La linterna de Radar me muestra que en la pared del fondo del despacho hay un trozo al que se ha dado una capa de pintura blanca, como si a alguien se le hubiera ocurrido remodelarlo, pero hubiera abandonado el proyecto a la media hora. Me acerco a la pared y veo que debajo de la pintura hay algo escrito de color rojo. Pero solo veo indicios de pintura roja que traspasa, no lo suficiente para saber lo que pone. Junto a la pared hay un bote abierto de pintura blanca. Me arrodillo y meto el dedo en la pintura. La superficie está dura, pero se rompe fácilmente, así que saco el dedo blanco. No digo nada mientras la pintura me gotea del dedo, porque todos hemos llegado a la misma conclusión: que alguien ha estado aquí hace poco. Y entonces el edificio vuelve a crujir, y a Radar se le cae la linterna y suelta un taco.
vi_translation: "And there are some painted spots," Ben added. Ben pointed, and Radar's light followed, illuminating a patch in the far corner of this office wall. The patch was covered with primer, as if someone had the idea to redesign this place but abandoned the project after about half an hour. I approached the patch, and up close, I saw red graffiti under the white paint. But I could only see glimpses of red seeping through the white—almost impossible to discern what it was. A can of primer was right next to the wall, still open. I knelt down and dipped my finger into the paint. The surface of the paint had hardened, but it easily cracked, and when I pulled my finger out, it was completely covered in white. As drops of paint fell from my finger, I said nothing because we all reached the same conclusion: someone had been here recently. The creaking sound echoed again somewhere in the building, and Radar dropped his flashlight.
tr_translation: “And there's this painted section,” says Ben. He points, and Radar's flashlight shows that part of the office's opposite wall is painted with white primer, as if someone had the idea to make a change to the room but abandoned the project half an hour later. I walk towards the wall and, upon getting closer, I can see that there is red graffiti under the white paint. But I can only see traces of the red graffiti... definitely not enough to make out anything. There is an open paint can directly opposite the wall. I kneel down and press my finger into the paint. The surface is hard but breaks easily, and my finger comes out covered in white. As the paint drips from my finger, nothing I'm not saying anything because we all come to the same conclusion that someone recently came here, then the building creaks again and Radar drops the flashlight and curses.
es_translation: —And this section is painted —observes Ben, pointing to a wall. Radar's flashlight shows me that on the back wall of the office there is a section that has been given a coat of white paint, as if someone had thought of remodeling it but abandoned the project after half an hour. I approach the wall and see that underneath the paint there is something written in red. But I only see traces of red paint seeping through, not enough to know what it says. Next to the wall, there is an open can of white paint. I kneel down and dip my finger into the paint. The surface is hard, but it breaks easily, so I pull out my white finger. I say nothing while the paint drips from my finger, because we have all come to the same conclusion: someone has been here recently. And then the building creaks again, and Radar drops the flashlight and lets out a curse.

en: “This is freaky,” he says.
vi: “Gớm quá,” nó lầm bầm rủa.
tr: “Bu çok ürkütücü,” diyor.
es: —Esto es muy raro —comenta.
vi_translation: "Disgusting," he muttered angrily.
tr_translation: "This is very scary," he says.
es_translation: —This is very strange —he comments.

en: “Guys,” Ben says. The flashlight is still on the ground, and I take a step back, to pick it up, but then I see Ben pointing. He is pointing at the wall. A trick of the indirect light has made the graffiti letters float up through the coat of primer, a ghost-gray print I recognize immediately as Margo’s.
vi: “Xem này,” Ben thốt lên. Đèn pin vẫn ở trên sàn, tôi lùi lại để nhặt nó lên, nhưng đúng lúc đó tôi thấy Ben đang chỉ. Nó chỉ vào mảng tường. Trò chơi của ánh sáng phản chiếu đã phô bày những con chữ graffiti, đẩy chúng nổi lên khỏi lớp sơn trắng phủ bên trên, những nét chữ rờn rợn tôi nhận ra ngay là của Margo.
tr: “Çocuklar,” diyor Ben. Fener hâlâ yerde, onu almak için geriye bir adım atıyorum ama sonra Ben’in bir yeri işaret ettiğini görüyorum. Duvarı işaret ediyor. Dolaylı ışık sayesinde, duvar yazısındaki harfler, astar boya tabakasının altından okunur hale geliyor, hemen Margo’nun olduğunu anladığım hayali grilikte bir yazı görüyorum.
es: —Chicos —dice Ben. Como la linterna sigue en el suelo, doy un paso atrás para cogerla, pero entonces veo a Ben señalando. Lo que señala es la pared. Al recibir la luz indirecta, las letras de la pintada han atravesado la capa de pintura. Al momento sé que esas fantasmagóricas letras grises son de Margo.
vi_translation: “Look,” Ben exclaimed. The flashlight was still on the floor, I stepped back to pick it up, but at that moment I saw what Ben was pointing at. He was pointing at a section of the wall. The play of reflected light had revealed some graffiti letters, making them stand out from the white paint covering them, the eerie handwriting I immediately recognized as Margo's.
tr_translation: “Kids,” says Ben. The flashlight is still on the ground, I take a step back to pick it up but then I see Ben pointing at something. He is pointing at the wall. Thanks to the indirect light, the letters on the wall writing become readable through the layer of primer paint, and I see a faint writing that I immediately understand is Margo’s.
es_translation: —Guys —says Ben. As the flashlight is still on the ground, I take a step back to pick it up, but then I see Ben pointing. What he's pointing at is the wall. With the indirect light, the letters of the graffiti have pierced through the layer of paint. In that moment, I know that those ghostly gray letters are from Margo.

en: YOU WILL GO TO THE PAPER TOWNS
vi: SẼ ĐẾN NHỮNG THÀNH PHỐ GIẤY
tr: KÂĞITTAN KENTLERE GİDECEKSİN VE ASLA GERİ DÖNMEYECEKSİN
es: IRÁS A LAS CIUDADES DE PAPEL
vi_translation: WILL COME TO PAPER CITIES
tr_translation: YOU WILL GO TO PAPER TOWNS AND NEVER COME BACK
es_translation: YOU WILL GO TO THE PAPER TOWNS

en: AND YOU WILL NEVER COME BACK
vi: VÀ SẼ KHÔNG BAO GIỜ TRỞ LẠI
tr: KÂĞITTAN KENTLERE GİDECEKSİN VE ASLA GERİ DÖNMEYECEKSİN
es: Y NUNCA VOLVERÁS
vi_translation: AND WILL NEVER RETURN
tr_translation: YOU WILL GO TO PAPER TOWNS AND NEVER COME BACK
es_translation: AND YOU WILL NEVER RETURN

en: I pick up the flashlight and shine it on the paint directly, and the message disappears. But when I shine it against a different part of the wall, I can read it again. “Shit,” Radar says under his breath.
vi: Tôi nhặt đèn pin lên và chiếu thẳng vào lớp sơn, thông điệp đó lập tức biến mất. Nhưng khi chiếu đèn lên những mảnh tường khác trong phòng, tôi lại đọc được những con chữ ấy. “Quái quỉ,” Radar nói trong hơi thở.
tr: Feneri yerden alıp doğrudan boyanın üstüne doğrultuyorum ve mesaj yok oluyor. Ama feneri duvarın başka bir bölümüne doğrulttuğum zaman yazıyı yine okuyabiliyorum. “Kahretsin,” diyor Radar alçak sesle.
es: Cojo la linterna, enfoco directamente a la pintura, y el mensaje desaparece. Pero cuando enfoco otra zona de la pared, vuelve a ser legible. —Mierda —dice Radar en voz baja.
vi_translation: I picked up the flashlight and shone it directly on the paint, the message immediately disappeared. But when I shone the light on other parts of the wall in the room, I could read those letters again. "What the hell," Radar said under his breath.
tr_translation: I pick up the flashlight from the ground and point it directly at the paint, and the message disappears. But when I point the flashlight at another part of the wall, I can read the writing again. "Damn," Radar says in a low voice.
es_translation: I grab the flashlight, shine it directly at the painting, and the message disappears. But when I focus on another area of the wall, it becomes readable again. —Shit —says Radar in a low voice.

en: And now Ben says, “Bro, can we go now? Because the last time I was this scared . . . screw it. I’m freaked out. There’s nothing funny about this shit.”
vi: Và giờ Ben lên tiếng, “Các bồ, chúng ta đi được chưa? Vì lần cuối sợ đến mức này... quỉ tha ma bắt, tôi sợ đứng tim gan rồi đây. Trò này chẳng vui vẻ gì sất.”
tr: Şimdi de Ben, “Kardeşim, artık gidebilir miyiz? Çünkü en son bu kadar korktuğumda... siktir et. Ödüm kopuyor. Bu boktan olayda komik bir durum yok,” diyor.
es: —Colega, ¿podemos irnos ya? —pregunta Ben—. Porque la última vez que tuve tanto miedo… A tomar por saco. Estoy acojonado. Esta mierda no tiene nada de divertido.
vi_translation: And now Ben spoke up, "Guys, can we go now? Because the last time I was this scared... damn it, I'm scared out of my wits here. This game is no fun at all."
tr_translation: Now I say, "Brother, can we leave now? Because the last time I was this scared... screw it. I'm terrified. There's nothing funny about this shitty situation," he says.
es_translation: —Colleague, can we leave now? —asks Ben—. Because the last time I was this scared... To hell with it. I'm terrified. This shit isn't fun at all.

en: There’s nothing funny about this shit is the closest Ben can come to the terror I feel, maybe. And it is close enough for me. I fast-walk toward the Troll Hole. I can feel the walls closing in on us.
vi: Trò này chẳng vui vẻ gì sất là cách gần nhất Ben có thể với tới nỗi kinh hoàng tôi đang cảm thấy, có lẽ vậy. Và đối với tôi như vậy là đủ gần rồi. Tôi bước nhanh về phía Lỗ Quỉ. Có cảm giác những bức tường đang đóng lại sau chúng tôi.
tr: Bu boktan olayda komik bir durum yok, belki de Ben’in, hissettiğim dehşete ulaşabildiği en yakın mesafe. Ve benim için bu yeterince yakın. Hızlıca Cüce Deliği’ne doğru yürüyorum. Duvarların üstümüze geldiğini hissedebiliyorum.
es: Esta mierda no tiene nada de divertido. Creo que «Esta mierda no tiene nada de divertido» es lo que más se acerca a mi propio terror. Y para mí está lo bastante cerca. Me dirijo a toda prisa al Agujero de Trol. Siento que las paredes se cierran sobre nosotros.
vi_translation: This game is not fun at all, it's the closest way Ben can reach the horror I'm feeling, perhaps. And for me, that's close enough. I quickly walked towards the Devil's Hole. It feels like the walls are closing in behind us.
tr_translation: There is nothing funny about this shitty situation, maybe the closest Ben can get to the horror I feel. And for me, that's close enough. I quickly walk towards the Dwarf Hole. I can feel the walls closing in on us.
es_translation: I think "This shit isn't fun at all" is what comes closest to my own terror. And for me, that's close enough. I hurry towards the Troll Hole. I feel the walls closing in on us.

en: Ben and Radar dropped me off at my house—even though they’d skipped school, they couldn’t afford to skip band practice. I sat alone with “Song of Myself” for a long time, and for about the tenth time I tried to read the entire poem starting at the beginning, but the problem was that it’s like eighty pages long and weird and repetitive, and although I could understand each word of it, I couldn’t understand anything about it as a whole. Even though I knew the highlighted parts were probably the only important parts, I wanted to know whether it was a suicide-note kind of poem. But I couldn’t make sense of it.
vi: Ben và Radar thả tôi về nhà–hai thằng chịu cúp cua nhưng nhất định không bỏ tập nhạc. Tôi ngồi một mình rất lâu với “Tự khúc”. Dễ đến lần thứ mười tôi cố gắng đọc toàn bộ bài thơ từ đầu đến cuối, nhưng vấn đề là bài thơ dài chừng tám chục trang, vòng vo khó hiểu và lặp ý. Dù hiểu được từng từ riêng lẻ, nhưng gộp thành tổng thể thì tôi chịu không hiểu nổi. Cả khi biết có lẽ chỉ những phần được đánh dấu là quan trọng, tôi vẫn muốn tìm hiểu xem liệu đây có phải là kiểu thơ tuyệt mệnh không. Nhưng tôi vẫn không tài nào luận ra được.
tr: Ben ile Radar beni eve bıraktılar... okulu asmalarına rağmen bando provasını asma. Uzun süre, Kendi Şarkım’la tek başıma oturdum ve aşağı yukarı onuncu kez bütün şiiri baştan sona dek okumaya çabştım ama mesele şuydu ki, şiir seksen sayfa falan uzunluğunda, tuhaf ve fazla tekrarlıydı ve her kelimesini anlayabilmeme rağmen, bütün olarak hiçbir şey anlayamıyordum. Altı çizili bölümlerin muhtemelen önemli olan tek bölümler olduğunu bilsem de, intihar mektubu tarzmda bir şiir olup olmadığını anlamak istiyordum. Fakat bir anlam çıkaramıyordum.
es: Ben y Radar me dejaron en casa. Aunque no habían ido a clase, no podían permitirse saltarse el ensayo. Me senté un buen rato con el «Canto de mí mismo», y por enésima vez intenté leer el poema entero, empezando por el principio, pero el problema era que son como ochenta páginas, es raro y repetitivo, y aunque entendía todas las palabras, no entendía lo que quería decir en sí. Pese a que sabía que seguramente lo único importante eran los versos marcados, quería saber si el poema era una especie de nota suicida. Pero no entendía nada.
vi_translation: Ben and Radar dropped me off at home—those two were willing to skip school but definitely wouldn't miss band practice. I sat alone for a long time with "Song of Myself." It must have been the tenth time I tried to read the entire poem from start to finish, but the problem was that the poem was about eighty pages long, convoluted, and repetitive. Even though I understood each individual word, when combined into a whole, I just couldn't make sense of it. Even knowing that perhaps only the marked parts were important, I still wanted to figure out whether this was a kind of suicide note poetry. But I still couldn't make any sense of it.
tr_translation: Ben and Radar dropped me off at home... despite skipping school, don't skip band practice. For a long time, I sat alone with My Song and tried to read the entire poem from start to finish for about the tenth time, but the thing was, the poem was about eighty pages long, strange, and overly repetitive, and although I could understand every word, I couldn't understand anything as a whole. Even though I knew that the underlined sections were probably the only important parts, I wanted to understand whether it was a poem in the style of a suicide note. But I couldn't make any sense of it.
es_translation: Ben and Radar dropped me off at home. Although they hadn't gone to class, they couldn't afford to skip rehearsal. I sat for a good while with "Song of Myself," and for the umpteenth time, I tried to read the entire poem, starting from the beginning, but the problem was that it's like eighty pages long, it's weird and repetitive, and even though I understood all the words, I didn't understand what it was trying to say. Even though I knew that probably the only important parts were the marked verses, I wanted to know if the poem was some kind of suicide note. But I didn't understand anything.

en: I was ten confusing pages into the poem when I got so freaked out that I decided to call the detective. I dug his business card out of a pair of shorts in the laundry hamper. He answered on the second ring.
vi: Đọc được chục trang sách loạn cào cào, tôi thấy hoang mang đến mức quyết định gọi điện cho bác thám tử. Tôi moi được danh thiếp của bác ấy từ túi quần soóc đã lẳng vào giỏ quần áo bẩn. Bác ấy nhấc máy ở hồi chuông thứ hai.
tr: Dedektifi aramaya karar verecek kadar korkuya kapıldığımda, şiirde on kafa karıştırıcı sayfa geçmiştim. Çamaşır sepetindeki şorttan dedektifin kartvizitini bulup çıkardım. İkinci çalışta cevap verdi.
es: Había leído ya diez confusas páginas cuando me puse tan histérico que decidí llamar al detective. Saqué su tarjeta de unos pantalones cortos del cesto de la ropa sucia. Contestó al segundo tono.
vi_translation: After reading a dozen pages of the book, feeling utterly confused, I decided to call the detective. I retrieved his business card from the pocket of my shorts, which I had tossed into the dirty laundry basket. He picked up on the second ring.
tr_translation: When I became frightened enough to decide to call the detective, I had gone through ten confusing pages of the poem. I found and pulled out the detective's business card from the shorts in the laundry basket. He answered on the second ring.
es_translation: I had already read ten confusing pages when I became so hysterical that I decided to call the detective. I took his card out of a pair of shorts from the dirty laundry basket. He answered on the second ring.

en: “Warren.”
vi: “Warren nghe đây.”
tr: “Warren.
es: —Warren.
vi_translation: "Warren, listen."
tr_translation: "Warren."
es_translation: —Warren.

Multiple_ents: ['margo roth spiegelman', 'quentin jacobse', 'quentin jacobsen', 'margo roth spiegelma']
en: “Hi, um, it’s Quentin Jacobsen. I’m a friend of Margo Roth Spiegelman?”
vi: “Hơ, dạ, con là Quentin Jacobsen, bạn của Margo Roth Spiegelman, bác nhớ con không ạ?”
tr: “Selam, eee, ben Quentin Jacobsen. Margo Roth Spiegelman’ın bir arkadaşıyım ama?
es: —Hola, hum, soy Quentin Jacobsen, un amigo de Margo Roth Spiegelman.
vi_translation: "Uh, yes, I am Quentin Jacobsen, a friend of Margo Roth Spiegelman, do you remember me?"
tr_translation: "Hello, um, I am Quentin Jacobsen. I am a friend of Margo Roth Spiegelman, but?"
es_translation: Hello, um, I am Quentin Jacobsen, a friend of Margo Roth Spiegelman.

en: “Sure, kid, I remember you. What’s up?”
vi: “Bác nhớ chứ con trai. Có chuyện gì thế?”
tr: “Tabii, evlat, seni hatırlıyorum. Nasılsın?
es: —Claro, muchacho, me acuerdo de ti. ¿Qué sucede?
vi_translation: “I remember, son. What's the matter?”
tr_translation: “Of course, child, I remember you. How are you?”
es_translation: —Of course, boy, I remember you. What’s happening?

en: I told him about the clues and the minimall and about paper towns, about how she had called Orlando a paper town from the top of the SunTrust Building, but she hadn’t used it in the plural, about her telling me that she wouldn’t want to be found, about finding her underneath our bootsoles. He didn’t even tell me not to break into abandoned buildings, or ask why I was at an abandoned building at 10 A.M. on a school day. He just waited until I stopped talking and said, “Jesus, kid, you’re almost a detective. All you need now is a gun, a gut, and three ex-wives. So what’s your theory?”
vi: Tôi kể với bác ấy về những manh mối, khu mua sắm mini, về những thành phố giấy và Margo đã gọi Orlando là một thành phố giấy khi chúng tôi nhìn từ tòa nhà SunTrust xuống như thế nào, nhưng cô ấy đã không dùng số nhiều. Tôi kể lại chuyện Margo đã nói với tôi rằng cô ấy không muốn bị tìm thấy, cả chuyện hãy tìm cô ấy dưới những đế ủng. Bác ấy thậm chí không lên giọng với tôi rằng không được vào những khu nhà hoang, không hỏi tại sao tôi lại ở trong một tòa nhà bị bỏ hoang vào lúc 10 giờ sáng một ngày phải đến trường. Bác ấy chỉ đợi cho đến khi tôi nói xong rồi mới lên tiếng, “Chúa ơi, chàng trai, con gần như là một thám tử rồi đấy. Giờ con chỉ cần có thêm khẩu súng, linh cảm nghề nghiệp và ba bà vợ cũ nữa thôi. Vậy giả thuyết của con là gì?”
tr: Ona küçük alışveriş merkezindeki ipuçlarını ve kâğıttan kentleri, SunTrust binasının tepesinden Orlando’ya nasıl kâğıttan kent dediğini ama çoğul olarak kullanmadığını, bana bulunmak istemediğini söyleyişini, onu ayakkabı tabanlarının altında bulma meselesini anlattım. Bana terk edilmiş binalara izinsiz girmememi söylemedi ya da neden bir okul gününde sabahın onunda terk edilmiş bir binada olduğumu bile sormadı. Sadece ben konuşmamı bitirene kadar bekledi ve “Tanrım, evlat, neredeyse bir dedektif olmuşsun. Şimdi tek ihtiyacın olan bir silah, cesaret ve üç eski eş. Yani teorin nedir?” dedi.
es: Le conté lo de las pistas, lo del centro comercial y lo de las ciudades de papel, le expliqué que desde lo alto del SunTrust Building me había dicho que Orlando era una ciudad de papel, pero no había hablado de ciudades en plural, que me había contado que no quería que la encontraran y lo de buscarla bajo la suela de nuestros zapatos. El detective ni siquiera me dijo que no debía entrar en edificios abandonados, ni me preguntó qué hacía allí a las diez de la mañana de un día de clase. Esperó a que hubiera terminado de hablar. —Por Dios, muchacho, eres casi un detective. Lo único que te falta es una pistola, una buena barriga y tres exmujeres. ¿Cuál es tu teoría?
vi_translation: I told him about the clues, the mini shopping mall, about the paper towns and how Margo called Orlando a paper town when we looked down from the SunTrust building, but she didn't use the plural form. I recounted how Margo told me that she didn't want to be found, and to look for her under the soles of boots. He didn't even raise his voice to tell me not to go into abandoned buildings, nor did he ask why I was in an abandoned building at 10 AM on a school day. He just waited until I finished speaking before saying, "Good Lord, boy, you're almost a detective already. Now you just need a gun, a detective's intuition, and three ex-wives. So what's your hypothesis?"
tr_translation: I told her about the clues in the small shopping center and the paper towns, how she called Orlando a paper town from the top of the SunTrust building but didn't use it in plural, how she told me she didn't want to be found, and the matter of finding her under the soles of my shoes. She didn't tell me not to trespass into abandoned buildings or even ask why I was in an abandoned building at ten in the morning on a school day. She just let me talk He waited until he finished and said, "My God, son, you're almost a detective. Now all you need is a gun, courage, and three ex-wives. So, what's your theory?"
es_translation: I told him about the clues, the mall, and the paper towns, I explained that from the top of the SunTrust Building she had told me that Orlando was a paper town, but she hadn't talked about towns in plural, that she had told me she didn't want to be found and about looking for her under the soles of our shoes. The detective didn't even tell me that I shouldn't enter abandoned buildings, nor did he ask me what I was doing there at ten in the morning on a school day. He waited until I had finished speaking. —For God's sake, boy, you're almost a detective. The only thing you're missing is a gun, a good belly, and three ex-wives. What's your theory?

en: “I’m worried that she might have, um, I guess killed herself.”
vi: “Con lo là có thể Margo đã, ừm, con sợ có khi bạn ấy đã tự vẫn rồi.”
tr: “Kendini, eee, öldürmüş olabileceğinden endişeleniyorum.
es: —Me preocupa que se haya… bueno, que se haya suicidado, supongo.
vi_translation: "It's possible that Margo, um, I'm afraid she might have committed suicide."
tr_translation: “I am worried that he might have, umm, killed himself.”
es_translation: —I'm worried that he might have... well, that he might have committed suicide, I suppose.

en: “It never crossed my mind this girl did anything but run off, kid. I can see your case, but you gotta remember she’s done this before. The clues, I mean. Adds drama to the whole enterprise. Honestly, kid, if she wanted you to find her—dead or alive—you already would have.”
vi: “Trong đầu bác luôn đinh ninh rằng cô bé chỉ bỏ đi thôi, con trai ạ. Bác hiểu suy luận của con, nhưng cũng nên nhớ rằng cô bé đã từng cư xử như vậy. Bác muốn nói đến những manh mối được để lại ấy mà. Tăng thêm kịch tính cho toàn bộ quá trình. Thật lòng mà nói, con trai ạ, nếu Margo muốn con tìm thấy nó–còn sống hay đã chết–thì rồi con sẽ tìm được thôi.”
tr: “Bu kızın kaçmaktan başka bir şey yaptığı aklımın ucundan bile geçmedi, evlat. Durumunu anlayabiliyorum ama bunu daha önce yaptığını hatırlamalısın. İpuçları... bütün bu girişime heyecan katıyor. Doğrusu, evlat, onu bulmanı isteseydiölü ya da diriçoktan bulmuş olurdun.
es: —Jamás se me ha pasado por la cabeza que esta chica hiciera otra cosa que escaparse, muchacho. Entiendo lo que me dices, pero recuerda que lo ha hecho otras veces. Me refiero a las pistas. Así le añade un poco de teatro. Sinceramente, si hubiera querido que la encontraras, viva o muerta, ya la habrías encontrado.
vi_translation: “In my mind, I always believed that the girl just ran away, son. I understand your reasoning, but you should also remember that the girl has behaved like this before. I mean the clues that were left behind. Adding more drama to the whole process. Honestly, son, if Margo wants you to find her—alive or dead—then you will find her.”
tr_translation: “The thought that this girl did anything other than run away never even crossed my mind, son. I can understand her situation, but you must remember that she has done this before. Clues... add excitement to this whole endeavor. Honestly, son, if she wanted you to find herdead or aliveyou would have found her by now.”
es_translation: —It has never crossed my mind that this girl did anything other than run away, boy. I understand what you're telling me, but remember that she has done it before. I'm referring to the clues. She adds a bit of drama that way. Honestly, if she had wanted you to find her, alive or dead, you would have found her by now.

en: “Kid, the unfortunate thing is that she’s a legal adult with free will, you know? Let me give you some advice: let her come home. I mean, at some point, you gotta stop looking up at the sky, or one of these days you’ll look back down and see that you floated away, too.”
vi: “Con trai, điều không may là Margo đã là một người trưởng thành được pháp luật công nhận, với một ý chí tự do, con hiểu chứ? Bác khuyên con thế này nhé: hãy để con bé tự về. Bác muốn nói là rồi đến lúc nào đó, con sẽ thôi không nhìn lên trời nữa, hoặc một trong những ngày đó, con sẽ nhìn xuống và thấy rằng chính con cũng đã trôi đi.”
tr: “Evlat, talihsiz olan şu ki, o yasal olarak özgür iradesi olan bir yetişkin. Sana biraz tavsiye vereyim: Bırak o eve gelsin. Yani bir noktada gökyüzüne bakmayı bırakmak zorunda kalacaksın ya da bir gün aşağı bakıp kendinin de uçup gittiğini göreceksin.
es: —Muchacho, tenemos la mala suerte de que legalmente es una persona adulta y libre, ¿sabes? Permíteme que te dé un consejo: espera a que vuelva. Bueno, en algún momento dejarás de mirar el cielo, o uno de estos días mirarás hacia abajo y verás que también tú has salido volando.
vi_translation: "Son, the unfortunate thing is that Margo is already a legally recognized adult, with a free will, you understand? My advice to you is this: let her come back on her own." "What I mean is that eventually, you will stop looking up at the sky, or one of these days, you will look down and realize that you yourself have drifted away."
tr_translation: “Child, the unfortunate thing is that he is legally an adult with free will. Let me give you some advice: Let him come home. At some point, you will have to stop looking at the sky, or one day you will look down and see that you have flown away too.”
es_translation: —Boy, we have the bad luck that legally she is an adult and free, you know? Allow me to give you some advice: wait for her to come back. Well, at some point you'll stop looking at the sky, or one of these days you'll look down and see that you too have flown away.

en: I hung up with a bad taste in my mouth—I realized it wasn’t Warren’s poetry that would take me to Margo. I kept thinking about those lines at the end Margo had underlined: “I bequeath myself to the dirt to grow from the grass I love, / If you want me again look for me under your bootsoles.” That grass, Whitman writes in the first few pages, is “the beautiful uncut hair of graves.” But where were the graves? Where were the paper towns?
vi: Tôi đặt máy xuống với một cảm giác khó chịu ở trong miệng–tôi nhận ra rằng chất thi sĩ của bác Warren sẽ không đưa tôi đến với Margo. Tôi miên man nghĩ đến những dòng cuối mà Margo đã gạch chân: “Ta trả mình về đất, nuôi những thân cỏ ta yêu, / Nếu ngươi muốn ta, hãy tìm ta dưới đế ủng.” Thứ cỏ ấy, Whitman đã viết trong những trang đầu tiên là “làn tóc mộ chí buông không buồn cắt.” Nhưng những ngôi mộ ở đâu? Những thành phố giấy ở đâu?
tr: Ağzımda kötü bir tatla telefonu kapattım... Beni Margo’ya götürecek şeyin Warren’ın şiiri olmadığını anlamıştım. Margo’nun sonda altını çizdiği satırları düşünmeye devam ettim: “Toprağa, sevdiğim çimenle büyümeye bırakıyorum kendimi, / Eğer tekrar istiyorsan, tabanlarının altında ara beni.” O çimen, Whitman’ın ilk birkaç sayfada yazdığına göre, “mezarların kesilmemiş güzel saçlan” idi. Ama mezarlar neredeydi? Kâğıttan kentler neredeydi?
es: Colgué con mal sabor de boca. Estaba claro que lo que me llevaría hasta Margo no sería la poesía de Warren. Seguí pensando en los versos del final que Margo había marcado: «Que el lodo sea mi heredero, quiero crecer del pasto que amo; / Si quieres encontrarte conmigo, búscame bajo la suela de tus zapatos». En las primeras páginas, Whitman escribe que ese pasto, esa hierba, es «la cabellera suelta y hermosa de las tumbas». Pero ¿dónde estaban las tumbas? ¿Dónde estaban las ciudades de papel?
vi_translation: I put the phone down with an uncomfortable feeling in my mouth—I realized that Dr. Warren's poetic substance would not lead me to Margo. I pondered over the last lines that Margo had underlined: "I give myself back to the earth, nourishing the grasses I love, / If you want me, look for me under your boot-soles." That grass, Whitman wrote in the first pages, is "the beautiful uncut hair of graves." But where are the graves? Where are the paper towns?
tr_translation: I hung up the phone with a bad taste in my mouth... I had realized that what would lead me to Margo was not Warren's poem. I kept thinking about the lines Margo had underlined at the end: “I bequeath myself to the dirt to grow from the grass I love, / If you want me again, look for me under your boot-soles.” According to what Whitman wrote in the first few pages, that grass was the “beautiful uncut hair of graves.” But where were the graves? Where were the paper towns?
es_translation: I hung up with a bad taste in my mouth. It was clear that what would lead me to Margo would not be Warren's poetry. I kept thinking about the final verses that Margo had marked: "Let the mud be my heir, I want to grow from the grass I love; / If you want to find me, look for me under the sole of your shoes." In the first pages, Whitman writes that this grass, this herb, is "the loose and beautiful hair of graves." But where were the graves? Where were the paper towns?

en: Looks like Madison Estates isn’t going to get built; my husband and I bought property there, but someone called this week to say they’re refunding us our deposit because they didn’t presell enough houses to finance the project. Another paper town for KS! —Marge in Cawker, KS
vi: Xem ra khu bất động sản Madison sẽ không bao giờ được hoàn thiện; vợ chồng tôi đặt mua nhà ở đó, nhưng trong tuần có người gọi điện cho chúng tôi, báo rằng tiền đặt cọc của chúng tôi sẽ được hoàn lại vì họ không bán trước được đủ nhà để rót vốn cho dự án. Thêm một thành phố giấy cho bang Kansas! –Marge ở Cawker, KS Một khu đô thị ma!
tr: Madison Evleri inşa edilmeyecekmiş gibi görünüyor; kocamla (ıradan bir ev aldık ama bu hafta birisi depozitomuzu bize geri ödeyeceklerini çünkü projeyi finanse edecek kadar ev satmadıklarını söylemek için aradı. Kansas için bir kâğıttan kent daha!Cawker, Kansas’tan Marge.
es: Parece que Madison Estates no va a construirse. Mi marido y yo compramos una casa, pero esta semana nos llamaron para decirnos que van a devolvernos la entrada porque no han vendido suficientes casas para financiar el proyecto. ¡Otra ciudad de papel para Kansas! - Marge, Cawker, Kansas.
vi_translation: It seems that the Madison real estate area will never be completed; my spouse and I placed an order for a house there, but during the week someone called us, informing that our deposit would be refunded because they couldn't sell enough houses in advance to fund the project. Another paper city for Kansas! –Marge in Cawker, KS A ghost town!
tr_translation: It looks like the Madison Homes won't be built; my husband and I bought an ordinary house, but this week someone called to tell us they would refund our deposit because they didn't sell enough homes to finance the project. Another paper town for Kansas! Marge from Cawker, Kansas.
es_translation: It seems that Madison Estates is not going to be built. My husband and I bought a house, but this week they called us to say that they are going to return our deposit because they have not sold enough houses to finance the project. Another paper city for Kansas! - Marge, Cawker, Kansas.

en: A pseudovision! You will go to the pseudovisions and you will never come back. I took a deep breath and stared at the screen for a while.
vi: –Marge ở Cawker, KS Một khu đô thị ma! Sẽ đến những khu đô thị ma và sẽ không bao giờ trở lại. Tôi thở thật sâu và nhìn chằm chằm màn hình máy tính một lúc.
tr: I lir semtimsi! Semtimsilere gideceksin ve asla geri dönmeyeceksin. I )erin bir nefes aldım ve bir süre gözümü dikip ekrana baktım.
es: ¡Una pseudovisión! Irás a las pseudovisiones y no volverás jamás. Respiré hondo y me quedé mirando la pantalla.
vi_translation: –Marge in Cawker, KS A ghost town! They will come to ghost towns and will never return. I took a deep breath and stared at the computer screen for a while.
tr_translation: I feel semtimsi! You will go to the semtimsis and never return. I took a deep breath and stared at the screen for a while.
es_translation: A pseudovision! You will go to the pseudovisions and you will never return. I took a deep breath and kept looking at the screen.

en: The conclusion seemed inescapable. Even with everything broken and decided inside her, she couldn’t quite allow herself to disappear for good. And she had decided to leave her body—to leave it for me—in a shadow version of our subdivision, where her first strings had broken. She had said she didn’t want her body found by random kids—and it made sense that out of everyone she knew, she would pick me to find her. She wouldn’t be hurting me in a new way. I’d done it before. I had experience in the field.
vi: Dường như không thể tránh được kết cục ấy. Dù bên trong cô ấy mọi thứ đã tan vỡ và đã đi đến phán quyết, Margo chừng như không cho phép bản thân biến mất vĩnh viễn. Và cô ấy đã quyết định để lại thân xác mình–để lại cho tôi–trong dáng dấp khu đô thị ma của chúng tôi, nơi những sợi dây đầu tiên của cô ấy đã đứt. Margo đã nói rằng cô ấy không muốn thân xác mình bị những đứa trẻ vu vơ tìm thấy–và có thể lí giải được rằng trong số những người quen biết, Margo sẽ chọn tôi là người tìm ra cô ấy. Cô ấy sẽ không làm tổn thương tôi bằng một cách mới. Tôi đã từng làm việc đó. Tôi có kinh nghiệm trong lĩnh vực này.
tr: Sonuç kaçınılmaz görünüyordu, içindeki kopmuş ve karar verilmiş her şeye rağmen Margo, sonsuza kadar ortadan yok olmayı kabullenmemişti. Ve ilk iplerinin koptuğu bizim semtimizin hayalî bir versiyonunda bedenini bırakmayabana bırakmayakarar vermişti. Bedeninin rastgele çocuklar tarafından bulunmasını istemediğini söylemişti... ve bütün tanıdıkları arasından onu bulmak için beni seçmiş olması mantıklıydı. Beni farklı bir şekilde incitmiş olmayacaktı. Bunu daha önce yapmıştım. Sahada deneyimim vardı.
es: La conclusión parecía irrefutable. Aunque todo se había roto en su interior y había tomado su decisión, no se permitió desaparecer para siempre, así que había decidido dejar su cuerpo —dejármelo a mí— en una sombría versión de nuestra urbanización, donde se le rompieron los primeros hilos. Había dicho que no quería que cualquier niño encontrara su cuerpo, y parecía lógico que, de todas las personas a las que conocía, me eligiera a mí para encontrarlo. No me haría tanto daño porque para mí no sería nuevo. Ya me había sucedido antes. Tenía experiencia en la materia.
vi_translation: It seemed impossible to avoid that outcome. Even though everything inside her had shattered and reached a verdict, Margo seemingly did not allow herself to disappear forever. And she decided to leave her body behind–leave it for me–in the guise of our ghost town, where her first threads had snapped. Margo had said that she didn't want her body to be found by random children–and it could be understood that among those who knew her, Margo would choose me to be the one to find her. She would not hurt me in a new way. I had done that before. I have experience in this field.
tr_translation: The outcome seemed inevitable; despite everything that had broken inside her and all the decisions she had made, Margo had not accepted disappearing forever. And she had decided not to leave her body in an imaginary version of our neighborhood where the first ties had broken. She had said she didn't want her body to be found by random children... and it made sense that she had chosen me to find her among all her acquaintances. She wouldn't have hurt me in a different way. I had done this before. I had experience in the field.
es_translation: The conclusion seemed irrefutable. Although everything inside her had broken and she had made her decision, she did not allow herself to disappear forever, so she had decided to leave her body —leave it to me— in a gloomy version of our neighborhood, where the first threads had broken. She had said that she didn't want any child to find her body, and it seemed logical that, of all the people she knew, she chose me to find it. It wouldn't hurt me as much because it wouldn't be new to me. It had already happened to me before. I had experience in the matter.

en: I saw that Radar was online and was clicking over to talk to him when an IM from him popped up on my screen.
vi: Tôi thấy Radar đang trực tuyến, định gọi nó nói chuyện thì thấy tin nhắn của nó hiện lên màn hình của tôi.
tr: Radar’m çevrimiçi olduğunu gördüm ve ekranımda bir mesajı çıkıverdiğinde, onunla konuşmak için üstüne tıkladım.
es: Vi que Radar estaba conectado, y estaba pinchando para hablar con él cuando en la pantalla me apareció un mensaje suyo.
vi_translation: I saw Radar was online, intended to call it to talk, then saw its message appear on my screen.
tr_translation: I saw that Radar was online and when a message popped up on my screen, I clicked on it to talk to him.
