es_translation: I saw that Radar was online, and I was about to click to talk to him when a message from him appeared on the screen.

en: OMNICTIONARIAN96: Hey.
vi: CÔNGDÂNCỦATOÀNTHƯ96: Êu.
tr: OMNICTIONARIAN96: Selam.
es: OMNICTIONARIAN96: Hola.
vi_translation: GLOBALCITIZENOFTHETOTALBOOK96: Êu.
tr_translation: OMNICTIONARIAN96: Hello.
es_translation: OMNICTIONARIAN96: Hello.

en: QTHERESURRECTION: Paper towns = pseudovisions.
vi: QKẺHỒISINH: Những thành phố giấy = những khu đô thị ma.
tr: DIRILIŞÇIQ: Kâğıttan kentler = semtimsiler.
es: QTHERESURRECTION: Ciudades de papel = pseudovisiones.
vi_translation: QKẺHỒISINH: Paper towns = ghost towns.
tr_translation: RESURRECTIONIST: Paper towns = neighborhood-like places.
es_translation: QTHERESURRECTION: Paper towns = pseudovisions.

en: I think she wants me to find her body. Because she thinks I can handle it. Because we found that dead guy when we were kids.
vi: Tôi nghĩ Margo muốn tôi tìm thấy xác cậu ấy. Vì cậu ấy nghĩ rằng tôi có thể xoay xở được. Vì hồi còn bé, bọn tôi đã phát hiện được một xác chết.
tr: Sanırım bedenini bulmamı istiyor. Çünkü bunu kaldırabileceğimi düşünüyor. Çünkü çocukken o ölü adamı bulduk.
es: Creo que quiere que encuentre su cuerpo. Porque piensa que podré soportarlo. Porque encontramos a un tipo muerto cuando éramos niños.
vi_translation: I think Margo wanted me to find her body. Because she thought I could handle it. Because when we were kids, we discovered a dead body.
tr_translation: I think your body wants me to find it. Because he thinks I can handle it. Because we found that dead man when we were children.
es_translation: I think she wants me to find her body. Because she thinks I will be able to handle it. Because we found a dead guy when we were kids.

en: I sent him the link.
vi: Tôi gửi đường dẫn cho Radar.
tr: Ona internet adresini gönderdim.
es: Le mandé el link.
vi_translation: I sent the link to Radar.
tr_translation: I sent her the internet address.
es_translation: I sent him the link.

en: OMNICTIONARIAN96: Slow down. Let me look at the link.
vi: CÔNGDÂNCỦATOÀNTHƯ96: Hượm để tôi đọc từ đường dẫn đã.
tr: OMNICTIONARIAN96: Yavaş ol. Bırak adrese bakayım.
es: OMNICTIONARIAN96: Cálmate. Espera a que vea el link.
vi_translation: CITIZENOFTHEUNIVERSE96: Hold on, let me read from the link first.
tr_translation: OMNICTIONARIAN96: Slow down. Let me check the address.
es_translation: OMNICTIONARIAN96: Calm down. Wait until they see the link.

en: QTHERESURRECTION: K.
vi: QKẺHỒISINH: Ừ.
tr: DİRİLİŞÇİQ: Tmm.
es: QTHERESURRECTION: OK.
vi_translation: QKẺHỒISINH: Yes.
tr_translation: DİRİLİŞÇİQ: Okay.
es_translation: QTHERESURRECTION: OK.

en: OMNICTIONARIAN96: Okay, don’t be so morbid. You don’t know anything for sure. I think she’s probably fine.
vi: CÔNGDÂNCỦATOÀNTHƯ96: Được rồi, đừng nghĩ quẩn. Ông vẫn chưa có gì chắc chắn cả mà. Tôi nghĩ chắc Margo ổn cả thôi.
tr: OMNICTIONARIAN96: Tamam, bu kadar hastalıklı olma. Hiçbir şeyi kesin olarak bilmiyorsun. Margo muhtemelen iyi.
es: OMNICTIONARIAN96: Vale, no seas tan macabro. No sabes nada seguro. Creo que seguramente está bien.
vi_translation: CITIZENOFTHEWORLD96: Alright, don't overthink it. You still don't have anything certain yet. I think Margo will be fine.
tr_translation: OMNICTIONARIAN96: Okay, don't be so morbid. You don't know anything for sure. Margo is probably fine.
es_translation: OMNICTIONARIAN96: Okay, don't be so macabre. You don't know anything for sure. I think it's probably fine.

en: QTHERESURRECTION: No you don’t.
vi: QKẺHỒISINH: Đừng lòe tôi.
tr: DİRİLİŞ ÇIQ: Hayır, düşünmüyorsun.
es: QTHERESURRECTION: No, no lo crees.
vi_translation: QKẺHỒISINH: Don't fool me.
tr_translation: RESURRECTION ÇIQ: No, you are not thinking.
es_translation: QTHERESURRECTION: No, you don't believe it.

en: OMNICTIONARIAN96: Okay, I don’t. But if anybody’s alive in the face of this evidence . . .
vi: CÔNGDÂNCỦATOÀNTHƯ96: Được rồi tôi không lòe ông. Nhưng nếu có ai đó còn sống bất luận bằng chứng này...
tr: OMNICTIONARIAN96: Tamam, düşünmüyorum. Ama bu delil karşılığında, eğer biri yaşıyorsa...
es: OMNICTIONARIAN96: Vale, no lo creo. Pero puede estar viva a pesar de los indicios…
vi_translation: CITIZENOFTHEWORLD96: Alright, I won't deceive you. But if there is someone still alive regardless of this evidence...
tr_translation: OMNICTIONARIAN96: Okay, I don't think so. But in response to this evidence, if someone is alive...
es_translation: OMNICTIONARIAN96: Okay, I don't believe it. But she might be alive despite the evidence...

en: QTHERESURRECTION: Yeah, I guess. I’m gonna go lie down. My parents get home soon.
vi: QKẺHỒISINH: Ừ, cho là vậy. Tôi đi nằm một lúc đây, bố mẹ tôi sắp về rồi.
tr: DIRILIŞÇIQ: Evet, sanının. Gidip uzanacağım. Annemle babam yakında eve gelir.
es: QTHERESURRECTION: Sí, supongo. Me voy a la cama. Mis padres no tardarán en llegar.
vi_translation: QKẺHỒISINH: Yeah, let's say so. I'm going to lie down for a bit, my parents are coming home soon.
tr_translation: DIRILIŞÇIQ: Yes, I think so. I will go and lie down. My mom and dad will come home soon.
es_translation: QTHERESURRECTION: Yes, I suppose. I'm going to bed. My parents will be here soon.

en: But I couldn’t calm down, so I called Ben from bed and told him my theory.
vi: Nhưng không sao bình tĩnh được, thế là tôi nằm trên giường gọi điện cho Ben, kể lại giả thuyết của mình.
tr: Ama sakinleşemedim, bu yüzden yataktan Ben’i arayıp ona teorimi anlattım.
es: Pero no conseguía calmarme, así que llamé a Ben desde la cama y le conté mi teoría.
vi_translation: But I couldn't stay calm, so I lay on the bed and called Ben, telling him my hypothesis.
tr_translation: But I couldn't calm down, so I called Ben from bed and told him my theory.
es_translation: But I couldn't calm down, so I called Ben from the bed and told him my theory.

en: “Pretty morbid shit, bro. But she’s fine. It’s all part of some game she’s playing.”
vi: “Ông nghĩ nhiều quá hóa quẩn đó. Nhưng Margo ổn mà. Tất cả đều là một phần của trò chơi nào đó mà cậu ấy đang tiêu khiển.
tr: “Oldukça hastalıklı bir saçmalık, kardeşim. Ama Margo iyidir. Hepsi oynadığı oyunun bir parçası.
es: —Qué mierda macabra, colega. Margo está bien. Solo está jugando.
vi_translation: "You're overthinking it, driving yourself crazy. But Margo is fine. It's all just part of some game she's playing."
tr_translation: “A rather sickly nonsense, my brother. But Margo is good. It's all part of the game she plays.”
es_translation: —What macabre shit, buddy. Margo is fine. She's just playing.

en: “You’re being kind of cavalier about it.”
vi: “Ông bắt đầu thờ ơ về chuyện này rồi đấy.”
tr: “Bu konu hakkında biraz düşüncesiz davranıyorsun.
es: —No parece preocuparte demasiado.
vi_translation: "You are starting to become indifferent about this."
tr_translation: “You are being a bit thoughtless about this matter.”
es_translation: —It doesn't seem to worry you too much.

en: He sighed. “Whatever, it’s a little lame of her to, like, hijack the last three weeks of high school, you know? She’s got you all worried, and she’s got Lacey all worried, and prom is in like three days, you know? Can’t we just have a fun prom?”
vi: Ben thở dài. “Dù sao thì Margo chơi, chà, hơi không đẹp. Ông thấy đấy, không dưng cậu ấy tung đòn đánh úp ba tuần cuối ở trường phổ thông. Ông cũng thấy rồi đấy, Margo làm cả lũ lo lắng, Lacey lo loạn lên, và dạ tiệc thì chỉ còn ba ngày nữa là đến. Chúng ta không thể có một dạ tiệc tốt nghiệp vui tới bến sao?”
tr: İç çekti. “Neyse ne, bu biraz da onun aptallığı, yani, okulun son üç haftasını çalmak filan... Seni endişelendirdi, Lacey’yi endişelendirdi ve balo üç gün içinde falan, biliyorsun. Sadece eğlenceli bir balo geçiremez miyiz?
es: Suspiró. —Bueno, es un mal rollo por su parte hacerte perder las tres últimas semanas de clase, ¿sabes? Te tiene muy preocupado, y tiene a Lacey muy preocupada, y faltan tres días para el baile, ¿sabes? ¿No podemos tener un baile tranquilo y divertirnos?
vi_translation: Ben sighed. "Anyway, Margo played, well, a bit unfairly. You see, out of nowhere, she launched a surprise attack in the last three weeks of high school. You also saw, Margo made everyone worried, Lacey freaked out, and the prom is only three days away. Can't we have a fun graduation prom?”
tr_translation: He sighed. “Whatever, it's partly his stupidity, I mean, stealing the last three weeks of school and all... It worried you, it worried Lacey, and the prom is in like three days, you know. Can't we just have a fun prom?”
es_translation: He sighed. —Well, it's a bummer on their part to make you miss the last three weeks of class, you know? You're very worried, and Lacey is very worried, and there are three days left until the dance, you know? Can't we just have a peaceful dance and have fun?

en: “Are you serious? She could be dead, Ben.”
vi: “Ông nói nghiêm túc không đấy? Có thể Margo đã chết đấy Ben ạ.
tr: “Sen ciddi misin? Margo ölmüş olabilir, Ben.
es: —¿Lo dices en serio? Ben, podría estar muerta.
vi_translation: “Are you serious?” “Margo might be dead, Ben.””
tr_translation: “Are you serious? Margo might be dead, Ben.”
es_translation: —Are you serious? Ben, she could be dead.

en: “She’s not dead. She’s a drama queen. Wants attention. I mean, I know her parents are assholes, but they know her better than we do, don’t they? And they think so, too.”
vi: “Cậu ấy không chết đâu. Margo là nữ hoàng dựng chuyện mà. Muốn được chú ý. Tôi biết phụ huynh của Margo là hai vị chẳng ra sao cả, nhưng họ hiểu Margo rõ hơn chúng ta, đúng chứ? Và họ cũng nghĩ như thế đấy.”
tr: “Ölmemiştir. İlgi istiyor. Yani, ebeveynlerinin boktan olduğunu biliyorum ama onu bizden daha iyi tanıyorlar, değil mi? Ve onlar da böyle düşünüyor.
es: —No está muerta. Es la reina del teatro. Quiere llamar la atención. Mira, ya sé que sus padres son unos gilipollas, pero la conocen mejor que nosotros, ¿verdad? Y sus padres piensan lo mismo.
vi_translation: “He won't die. Margo is the queen of making things up. She wants attention. I know Margo's parents aren't great, but they know Margo better than we do, right? And they think the same way.”
tr_translation: “He hasn't died. He wants attention. I mean, I know his parents are shitty, but they know him better than we do, right? And they think so too.”
es_translation: —She is not dead. She is the queen of drama. She wants to get attention. Look, I know her parents are assholes, but they know her better than we do, right? And her parents think the same.

en: “You can be such a tool,” I said.
vi: “Ông là đồ cùi bắp,” tôi rủa.
tr: “Öyle göt kafalı olabiliyorsun ki,” dedim.
es: —Cuando quieres eres un perfecto capullo.
vi_translation: “You are a loser,” I cursed.
tr_translation: "You can be such an ass-head," I said.
es_translation: —When you want to be, you are a perfect jerk.

en: “Whatever, bro. We both had a long day. Too much drama. I’ll TTYS.” I wanted to ridicule him for using chatspeak IRL, but I found myself lacking the energy.
vi: “Ông nói sao cũng được. Hai thằng mình đều vừa có một ngày dài. Quá nhiều kịch tính. Tôi sẽ NCSN.” Tôi định trêu nó là sao lại dùng ngôn ngữ mạng NĐ[8] thế này, nhưng chính tôi chẳng còn hơi sức nào đùa cợt nữa.
tr: “Her neyse, kardeşim. İkimiz de uzun bir gün geçirdik. Çok fazla heyecan yaşadık. KIB.” Gerçek hayatta internet dili kullandığı için onunla dalga geçmek istedim ama enerjim olmadığım hissettim.
es: —Lo que tú digas, colega. El día ha sido largo para los dos. Demasiado melodrama. TTYS. Quise reírme de él por utilizar siglas de chat IRL, pero no tuve fuerzas.
vi_translation: "You can say whatever you want." "Both of us just had a long day." "Too much drama." "I'm going to GTSY." I was about to tease him about using such internet slang, but I didn't have the energy to joke anymore.
tr_translation: "Anyway, my brother. We both had a long day. We experienced a lot of excitement. KIB." I wanted to make fun of him for using internet slang in real life, but I felt like I didn't have the energy.
es_translation: —Whatever you say, buddy. The day has been long for both of us. Too much melodrama. TTYS. I wanted to laugh at him for using chat acronyms IRL, but I didn't have the strength.

en: After I hung up with Ben, I went back online, looking for a list of pseudovisions in Florida. I couldn’t find a list anywhere, but after searching “abandoned subdivisions” and “Grovepoint Acres” and the like for a while, I managed to compile a list of five places within three hours of Jefferson Park. I printed out a map of Central Florida, tacked the map to the wall above my computer, and then added a tack for each of the five locations. Looking at the map, I could detect no pattern among them. They were randomly distributed among the far-flung suburbs, and it would take me at least a week to get to all of them. Why hadn’t she left me a specific place? All these scary-as-hell clues. All this intimation of tragedy. But no place. Nothing to hold on to. Like trying to climb a mountain of gravel.
vi: Sau khi ngắt máy với Ben, tôi lại vào mạng, tìm danh mục những khu đô thị ma ở bang Florida. Không thấy danh mục nào như vậy, nhưng sau khi tìm “những tiểu khu bị bỏ hoang” và “Grovepoint Acres”, na ná như vậy, tôi gom được danh sách năm địa điểm nằm trong khoảng ba tiếng đồng hồ chạy xe từ Jefferson Park. Tôi in bản đồ Trung Florida ra, đính lên khoảng tường phía trên máy tính, rồi lấy ghim mũ đánh dấu năm nơi đó. Quan sát bản đồ, tôi không thấy mối liên hệ nào. Những địa điểm đó nằm rải rác ở ngoại ô hẻo lánh, có lẽ phải mất ít nhất một tuần tôi mới đi được hết. Tại sao Margo không khoanh lại cho tôi một khu vực cụ thể? Tất cả những manh mối rùng-rợn-đến-phát-gớm này. Tất cả những cận kề thảm kịch này. Nhưng không một nơi chốn. Không có gì để bám víu. Như thể phải leo một đỉnh núi đầy sỏi đá vậy.
tr: Ben’le telefonu kapattıktan sonra Florida’daki semtimsilerin bir listesini aramak için tekrar internete girdim. Hiçbir yerde bir liste bulamadım ama bir süre “terk edilmiş semtler” ve “Grovepoint Acres” diye aradıktan sonra, Jefferson Park’a üç saatlik mesafede bulunan beş yer listelemeyi başardım. Orta Florida’nın bir haritasını yazıcıdan çıkarıp haritayı bilgisayarımın üzerindeki duvara raptiyeledim, sonra beş yerin her biri için bir raptiye ekledim. Haritaya bakarak aralarında hiçbir bağlantı bulamadım. Rastgele ücra kenar mahallelere dağılmışlardı ve hepsine ulaşmam en az lıir haftamı alırdı. Neden bana belirli bir yer belirtmemişti? Bütün bu cehennem gibi korkunç ipuçları. Bütün bu trajedi imaları. Ama hiçbir yer yoktu. Tutunacak hiçbir şey yoktu. Çakıl taşlarından bir dağa tırmanmaya çalışmak gibiydi.
es: Colgué y volví a la red en busca de un listado de pseudovisiones de Florida. No lo encontraba por ningún sitio, pero, después de teclear «urbanizaciones abandonadas», «Grovepoint Acres» y cosas por el estilo un buen rato, conseguí una lista de cinco lugares a menos de tres horas de Jefferson Park. Imprimí un mapa de Florida central, lo clavé con chinchetas en la pared, por encima del ordenador, y puse una chincheta en cada una de las cinco localizaciones. A simple vista no detecté la menor relación entre ellas. Estaban repartidas al azar entre las urbanizaciones más lejanas, así que necesitaría al menos una semana para ir a todas. ¿Por qué no me había dejado un lugar concreto? Varias pistas jodidamente siniestras, varios indicios de tragedia, pero ni un lugar. Nada a lo que agarrarse. Como intentar subir una montaña de gravilla.
vi_translation: After hanging up with Ben, I went back online, looking for a list of ghost towns in Florida. I didn't find any such list, but after searching for "abandoned subdivisions" and "Grovepoint Acres," something similar, I gathered a list of five locations within about a three-hour drive from Jefferson Park. I printed out a map of Central Florida, pinned it to the wall above my computer, and marked those five places with pushpins. Looking at the map, I didn't see any connection. Those locations were scattered in remote suburbs, and it would probably take at least a week to visit them all. Why didn't Margo narrow it down to a specific area for me? All these creepy-to-the-point-of-gross clues. All this proximity to disaster. But not a single place. Nothing to hold on to. Like having to climb a mountain full of loose rocks.
tr_translation: After hanging up the phone with Ben, I went back online to search for a list of neighborhoods in Florida. I couldn’t find a list anywhere, but after searching for a while with terms like “abandoned neighborhoods” and “Grovepoint Acres,” I managed to list five places located within a three-hour distance from Jefferson Park. I printed out a map of Central Florida and pinned it to the wall above my computer, then added a pin for each of the five places. Looking at the map, I couldn’t find any connection between them. They were randomly scattered across remote outskirts, and reaching each of them would take at least It would take my whole week. Why hadn't he specified a particular place for me? All these hellish, terrifying clues. All these implications of tragedy. But there was no place. There was nothing to hold on to. It was like trying to climb a mountain made of pebbles.
es_translation: I hung up and went back online in search of a list of Florida's pseudo-visions. I couldn't find it anywhere, but after typing "abandoned developments," "Grovepoint Acres," and things like that for a while, I managed to get a list of five places less than three hours from Jefferson Park. I printed a map of central Florida, pinned it to the wall above the computer, and put a pin in each of the five locations. At first glance, I didn't detect the slightest connection between them. They were randomly scattered among the farthest developments, so I would need at least a week to visit them all. Why hadn't he left me a specific place? Several damn sinister clues, several hints of tragedy, but not a single place. Nothing to hold on to. Like trying to climb a gravel mountain.

en: Ben gave me permission to borrow RHAPAW the next day, since he was going to be driving around, prom shopping with Lacey in her SUV. So for once I didn’t have to sit outside the band room—the seventh-period bell rang and I raced out to his car. I lacked Ben’s talent for getting RHAPAW to start, so I was one of the first people to arrive at the senior parking lot and one of the last to leave, but finally the engine caught, and I was off to Grovepoint Acres.
vi: Ngày hôm sau Ben cho tôi mượn ẻm RHAPAW vì nó sẽ lái chiếc SUV của Lacey đi lòng vòng mua sắm chuẩn bị cho dạ tiệc tốt nghiệp. Thế là lần này tôi không phải ngồi chờ ngoài phòng tập nhạc–chuông báo kết thúc tiết thứ bảy là tôi phóng đến bên chiếc xe. Nhưng không có tài khởi động RHAPAW được như Ben, nên dù là một trong những đứa đầu tiên có mặt tại bãi đỗ xe của học sinh năm cuối, tôi là một trong những kẻ cuối cùng ra được. Dù gì cuối cùng động cơ cũng chịu hoạt động, và tôi thẳng tiến đến Grovepoint Acres.
tr: Ertesi gün Ben, balo alışverişi için etrafta Lacey’nin cipiyle gezineceğinden bana SESIB’ı ödünç almam için izin verdi. Böylece ilk defa bando odasının dışında oturmak zorunda kalmadım... yedinci zil çaldı ve koşarak Ben’in arabasma gittim. Ben’in SESIB’ı çalıştırma yeteneğinden yoksun olduğumdan son sınıfların park alanına ilk ulaşanlardan ve oradan en son aynlanlardan biriydim ama sonunda motoru çalıştırdım ve Grovepoint Acres’a doğru hareket ettim.
es: Ben me dio permiso para llevarme el Chuco al día siguiente, porque iba a ir de compras con Lacey en su todoterreno. Así que por una vez no tenía que esperar a la puerta de la sala de ensayo. Sonó el timbre y corrí a su coche. Como no tenía el talento de Ben para arrancar el Chuco, fui uno de los primeros en llegar al aparcamiento de los alumnos de último curso y uno de los últimos en salir, pero al final el motor hizo contacto y me puse en camino hacia Grovepoint Acres.
vi_translation: The next day, Ben lent me RHAPAW because he would be driving Lacey's SUV around to shop for the graduation party. So this time I didn't have to wait outside the music room–as soon as the bell rang to end the seventh period, I dashed to the car. But I couldn't start RHAPAW as easily as Ben, so even though I was one of the first to arrive at the senior parking lot, I was one of the last to leave. Eventually, the engine did start, and I headed straight to Grovepoint Acres.
tr_translation: The next day, since Ben would be driving around in Lacey's jeep for prom shopping, he allowed me to borrow SESIB. So, for the first time, I didn't have to sit outside the band room... the seventh bell rang, and I ran to Ben's car. Since I lacked the ability to start Ben's SESIB, I was one of the first to reach the senior parking lot and one of the last to leave, but I finally got the engine running and headed towards Grovepoint Acres.
es_translation: Ben gave me permission to take the Chuco the next day, because he was going shopping with Lacey in his SUV. So for once, I didn't have to wait at the rehearsal room door. The bell rang and I ran to his car. Since I didn't have Ben's talent for starting the Chuco, I was one of the first to arrive at the senior parking lot and one of the last to leave, but in the end, the engine caught and I set off towards Grovepoint Acres.

en: I drove out of town on Colonial, driving slowly, watching for any other pseudovisions I might have missed online. A long line of cars trailed behind me, and I felt anxious about holding them up; I marveled at how I could still have room to worry about such petty, ridiculous crap as whether the guy in the SUV behind me thought I was an excessively cautious driver. I wanted Margo’s disappearance to change me; but it hadn’t, not really.
vi: Tôi lái xe dọc đường Colonial, chạy chầm chậm để quan sát xem có khu đô thị ma nào tôi lỡ bỏ sót khi tra trên mạng không. Một hàng dài ô-tô nối sau xe tôi. Tôi hơi bấn khi thấy cảnh ấy, rồi lập tức thán phục bản thân sao tôi vẫn còn sức lo đến những thứ trẻ con vụn vặt ngốc xít ấy: tự hỏi không biết gã trong chiếc SUV phía sau có đang nghĩ tôi là một tay lái quá ư thận trọng, chạy xe rù rì như rùa không. Tôi những muốn rằng sự biến mất của Margo sẽ thay đổi tôi; nhưng nó không thay đổi, không được là bao.
tr: Arabayla Colonial Bulvarı’nda şehir dışına doğru yavaşça sürerek, internette kaçırmış olabileceğim başka semtimsileri kollayarak ilerledim. Arkama uzun bir araba kuyruğu dizildi, onları geciktirdiğim için huzursuz hissettim; arkamdaki arazi aracındaki adamın benim haddinden fazla tedbirli bir sürücü olduğumu düşünüp düşünmediği gibi, bu kadar önemsiz, gülünç ıvır zıvırlara endişelenecek yerimin hâlâ var olabilmesine hayret ettim. Margo’nun ortadan kayboluşunun beni değiştirmesini isterdim ama değiştirmemişti, tam olarak değil.
es: Conduje despacio por la Colonial, buscando otras pseudovisiones que pudieran habérseme escapado en la red. Llevaba detrás una larga fila de coches y me angustiaba pensar que estaba creando un embotellamiento. Me sorprendía que todavía pudiera preocuparme de gilipolleces insignificantes y ridículas como si el tipo del coche que iba detrás de mí pensaba que conducía con excesiva precaución. Me habría gustado que la desaparición de Margo me hubiera cambiado, pero la verdad era que no.
vi_translation: I drove along Colonial Road, slowly driving to see if there was any ghost town I had missed when searching online. A long line of cars followed behind my car. I felt a bit flustered seeing that scene, then immediately admired myself for still having the energy to worry about such childish, trivial, and silly things: wondering if the guy in the SUV behind me thought I was an overly cautious driver, driving as slow as a turtle. I had hoped that Margo's disappearance would change me; but it didn't change much, not significantly.
tr_translation: Driving slowly out of the city on Colonial Boulevard, I kept an eye out for other neighborhoods I might have missed on the internet. A long line of cars formed behind me, and I felt uneasy for delaying them; I marveled at how I still had room to worry about such trivial, ridiculous things, like whether the man in the SUV behind me thought I was an overly cautious driver. I wished Margo's disappearance had changed me, but it hadn't, not exactly.
es_translation: I drove slowly through Colonial, looking for other pseudovisions that might have escaped me in the net. There was a long line of cars behind me, and I was anxious thinking that I was creating a traffic jam. I was surprised that I could still worry about insignificant and ridiculous bullshit like whether the guy in the car behind me thought I was driving too cautiously. I would have liked Margo's disappearance to have changed me, but the truth was that it hadn't.

en: As the line of cars snaked behind me like some kind of unwilling funeral procession, I found myself talking out loud to her. I will play out the string. I will not betray your trust. I will find you.
vi: Khi dòng xe phía sau cứ nối dài như một đám đưa tang bất đắc dĩ, tôi nhận ra mình đang nói to lên với cô ấy. Tớ sẽ lần theo dây nối. Tớ sẽ không phản bội niềm tin của cậu. Tớ sẽ tìm được cậu.
tr: Arabalardan oluşan kuyruk, gönülsüz bir cenaze alayı gibi arkamda kıvrıla kıvrıla giderken, kendimi yüksek sesle Margo’yla konuşurken buldum. Bütün ipleri çekeceğim. Güvenini sarsmayacağım. Seni bulacağım.
es: Mientras la fila de coches se arrastraba detrás de mí como un reticente cortejo fúnebre, me descubrí a mí mismo hablando con Margo en voz alta. «Seguiré el hilo. No traicionaré tu confianza. Te encontraré».
vi_translation: When the line of cars behind kept stretching out like an unwilling funeral procession, I realized I was speaking loudly to her. I will follow the connection. I will not betray your trust. I will find you.
tr_translation: As the line of cars snaked behind me like a reluctant funeral procession, I found myself talking out loud to Margo. I will pull all the strings. I will not break your trust. I will find you.
es_translation: While the line of cars crawled behind me like a reluctant funeral procession, I found myself talking to Margo out loud. «I will follow the thread. I will not betray your trust. I will find you».

en: Talking like this to her kept me calm, strangely. It kept me from imagining the possibilities. I came again to the sagging wooden sign for Grovepoint Acres. I could almost hear the sighs of relief from the bottleneck behind me as I turned left onto the dead-end asphalt road. It looked like a driveway without a house. I left RHAPAW running and got out. From close up, I could see that Grovepoint Acres was more finished than it initially appeared. Two dirt roads ending in cul-de-sacs had been cut into the dusty ground, although the roads had eroded so much I could barely see their outlines. As I walked up and down both streets, I could feel the heat in my nose with each breath. The scalding sun made it hard to move, but I knew the beautiful, if morbid, truth: heat made death reek, and Grovepoint Acres smelled like nothing except cooked air and car exhaust—our cumulative exhalations held close to the surface by the humidity.
vi: Kì lạ là nói to lên như vậy khiến tôi bình tĩnh hơn. Tôi không vẽ ra các giả thuyết nữa. Lại đi qua tấm bảng gỗ cũ kĩ đề Grovepoint Acres, tôi gần như nghe thấy tiếng thở phào nhẹ nhõm từ đám thắt cổ chai phía sau khi tôi rẽ trái vào con đường cụt trải nhựa. Trông như một lối đi không dẫn vào căn nhà nào. Tôi cứ để RHAPAW chạy hết dải đường ấy. Lại gần, Grovepoint Acres có vẻ hoàn thiện hơn là thoạt nhìn. Hai con đường đất dẫn vào một vòng cung cụt, giao cắt nhau thành những mảng trống bụi bặm. Dù đường đã bị xói lở nhiều, tôi vẫn hơi thấy được các mép đường. Đi đi lại lại trên hai con phố ấy, tôi cảm nhận được hơi nóng phả ra từ hai cánh mũi mình, theo từng nhịp thở. Mặt trời nóng như rang khiến đi lại khá mệt, nhưng tôi tự hiểu một sự thật đẹp đẽ, dù có thể hơi xuẩn ngốc: cái nóng sẽ khiến mùi chết chóc phải sộc lên, và Grovepoint Acres chỉ bốc lên mùi không khí bị hun nóng và mùi khói xe–những phát thải tích tụ, bị cái ẩm đẩy xuống gần mặt đất.
tr: Tuhaf bir biçimde, onunla bu şekilde konuşmak beni sakinleştirdi. Olasılıkları hayal etmemi engelledi. Tekrar yamuk duran, tahta Grovepoint Acres tabelasına geldim. Sola, çıkmaz asfalt yola dönerken arkamdakilerden gelen ferahlama iç çekişlerini neredeyse duyabiliyordum. Evsiz bir garaj yolu gibi görünüyordu. SESIB’ı çalışır halde bırakıp indim. Yakından, Grovepoint Acres’m başta göründüğünden daha fazla tamamlanmış olduğunu görebildim. Tozlu zemine çıkmazlarla sonlanan iki toprak yol kazılmıştı, yollar oldukça aşınmış olmasına rağmen, ana hatlarını zar zor görebiliyordum. İki yolda da ileri geri yürürken, her nefesimle birlikte burnumda sıcaklığı hissedebiliyordum. Yakıcı güneş hareket etmeyi zorlaştırıyordu ama ben biraz hastalıklı olmasına rağmen iyi hissettiren gerçeği biliyordum: Sıcaklık ölümü kokuturdu ve Grovepoint Acres pişmiş hava ve araba egzozu dışında bir şey kokmuyordu...
es: Por raro que parezca, dirigirme a ella en voz alta me tranquilizaba. Evitaba que imaginara las diversas posibilidades. Llegué al letrero de madera roída de Grovepoint Acres. Casi oí los suspiros de alivio de los que me seguían cuando giré a la izquierda hacia la carretera asfaltada sin salida. Parecía un camino de acceso a una casa pero sin casa. Dejé el Chuco en marcha y salí. Al acercarme, vi que Grovepoint Acres estaba más acabado de lo que en un primer momento parecía. Habían abierto en el suelo dos caminos de tierra sin salida, aunque se habían erosionado tanto que apenas se veían los contornos. Recorrí las dos calles arriba y abajo sintiendo el calor en la nariz cada vez que respiraba. El sol abrasador dificultaba el movimiento, pero sabía la bonita, aunque macabra, verdad: el calor hace que los muertos apesten, y Grovepoint Acres solo olía a aire caliente y tubos de escape. La humedad hacía que la acumulación de exhalaciones se mantuviera en el aire a mi alrededor.
vi_translation: Strangely, speaking out loud like that made me calmer. I no longer conjured up hypotheses. Passing the old wooden sign that read Grovepoint Acres again, I almost heard a sigh of relief from the bottleneck behind me as I turned left onto the paved dead-end road. It looked like a path that didn't lead to any house. I let RHAPAW run the entire length of that road. Up close, Grovepoint Acres seemed more complete than it initially appeared. Two dirt roads led into a cul-de-sac, intersecting each other into dusty patches. Although the roads were heavily eroded, I could still faintly see the edges. Walking back and forth on those two streets, I felt the heat emanating from my nostrils with each breath. The sun was scorching, making the walk quite tiring, but I understood a beautiful, albeit slightly foolish, truth: the heat would force the smell of death to rise, and Grovepoint Acres only emitted the scent of heated air and car exhaust—the accumulated emissions pushed down close to the ground by the humidity.
tr_translation: Strangely, talking to him this way calmed me down. It prevented me from imagining the possibilities. I arrived again at the crooked, wooden Grovepoint Acres sign. As I turned left onto the dead-end asphalt road, I could almost hear the sighs of relief from those behind me. It looked like a driveway without a house. I left the SESIB running and got out. Up close, the Grovepoint Acres’ initially I could see that it was more completed than it appeared. Two dirt roads that ended in dead ends were dug into the dusty ground; although the roads were quite worn, I could barely see their outlines. As I walked back and forth on both roads, I could feel the warmth in my nose with every breath. The scorching sun made it difficult to move, but I knew the truth that felt good despite being a bit sickly: The heat smelled of death, and Grovepoint Acres smelled of nothing but cooked air and car exhaust...
es_translation: As strange as it may seem, speaking to her out loud calmed me. It prevented me from imagining the various possibilities. I reached the worn wooden sign of Grovepoint Acres. I almost heard the sighs of relief from those following me when I turned left onto the dead-end paved road. It seemed like an access road to a house but without a house. I left the Chuco running and got out. As I approached, I saw that Grovepoint Acres was more rundown than it initially appeared. They had opened two dead-end dirt roads in the ground, although they had eroded so much that the outlines were barely visible. I walked up and down the two streets, feeling the heat in my nose with each breath. The scorching sun made movement difficult, but I knew the pretty, though macabre, truth: heat makes the dead stink, and Grovepoint Acres only smelled of hot air and exhaust fumes. The humidity caused the accumulation of exhalations to linger in the air around me.

en: I looked for evidence she had been there: footprints or something written in the dirt or some memento. But I seemed to be the first person to walk on these unnamed dirt streets in years. The ground was flat, and not much brush had grown back yet, so I could see for a ways in every direction. No tents. No campfires. No Margo.
vi: Tôi tìm kiếm bằng chứng cho thấy Margo đã ở đây: những dấu chân, điều gì đó được viết lên đất hoặc kỉ vật nào đó. Nhưng dường như sau nhiều năm trời, tôi là người đầu tiên đặt chân lên những con phố bụi bặm vô danh này. Mặt đất bằng phẳng, cây bụi còn chưa mọc nhiều, thế nên tôi có thể bao quát được mọi hướng. Không lều lán. Không dấu lửa. Không có Margo.
tr: Margo’nun orada bulunduğuna dair delil aradım: ayak izleri, toprağa yazılmış bir şey ya da bir hatıra. Ancak bu isimsiz toprak yollarda yıllardır yürüyen ilk kişi gibi görünüyordum. Zemin düzdü ve henüz pek fazla çalı büyümemişti, bu nedenle her yönde epey uzağı görebiliyordum. Çadır yoktu. Kamp ateşi yoktu. Margo yoktu.
es: Busqué pruebas de que Margo hubiera estado allí: huellas, algo escrito en la tierra o cualquier cosa que hubiera dejado, pero parecía que yo era la primera persona que andaba por aquellas calles sin nombre en años. El suelo era plano y todavía no había crecido mucha hierba, así que tenía la vista despejada en todas las direcciones. No vi tiendas de campaña, ni rastros de hogueras, ni a Margo.
vi_translation: I searched for evidence that Margo had been here: footprints, something written on the ground, or some kind of memento. But it seemed that after many years, I was the first person to set foot on these nameless dusty streets. The ground was flat, and the shrubs had not grown much, so I could see in all directions. No tents. No signs of fire. No Margo.
tr_translation: I searched for evidence that Margo had been there: footprints, something written in the dirt, or a keepsake. But I seemed to be the first person to walk these nameless dirt roads in years. The ground was flat and not many bushes had grown yet, so I could see quite far in every direction. There was no tent. There was no campfire. There was no Margo.
es_translation: I looked for evidence that Margo had been there: footprints, something written in the dirt, or anything she might have left behind, but it seemed like I was the first person to walk those nameless streets in years. The ground was flat and not much grass had grown yet, so I had a clear view in all directions. I saw no tents, no traces of campfires, and no Margo.

en: I got back in RHAPAW and drove to I-4 and then went northeast of town, up to a place called Holly Meadows. I drove past Holly Meadows three times before I finally found it—everything in the area was oak trees and ranch land, and Holly Meadows—lacking a sign at its entrance—didn’t stand out much. But once I drove a few feet down a dirt road through the initial roadside stand of oak and pine trees, it was every bit as desolate as Grovepoint Acres. The main dirt road just slowly evaporated into a field of dirt. There were no other roads that I could make out, but as I walked around, I did find a few spray-painted wooden stakes lying on the ground; I guessed that they had once been lot line markers. I couldn’t smell or see anything suspicious, but even so I felt a fear standing on my chest, and at first I couldn’t understand why, but then I saw it: when they’d clear-cut the area to build, they’d left a solitary live oak tree near the back of the field. And the gnarled tree with its thick-barked branches looked so much like the one where we’d found Robert Joyner in Jefferson Park that I felt sure she was there, on the other side of the tree.
vi: Tôi quay lại RHAPAW, lái sang cao tốc I-4 rồi theo hướng đông bắc thành phố, đến một nơi tên là Holly Meadows. Tôi lái qua Holly Meadows ba lần trước khi thực sự tìm thấy nó–toàn bộ khu vực chỉ có những cây sồi và đất lưu không, còn Holly Meadows–không có biển báo ở lối vào–không mấy nổi bật. Tôi lái xe đi vài mét theo con đường đất qua cụm những cây sồi và thông đầu tiên, xem ra nơi này cũng tiêu điều không kém Grovepoint Acres. Dải đường đất chính dần nhòe vào cánh đồng đất. Tôi không thấy con đường nào khác nữa, nhưng khi đi quanh, tôi có thấy vài cọc gỗ được phun sơn nằm vương trên đất; chắc từng đánh dấu địa giới. Tôi không ngửi hay phát hiện được gì khả nghi, dù vậy tôi vẫn thấy nỗi sợ hãi trồi lên trong lồng ngực. Ban đầu tôi không hiểu tại sao, nhưng rồi đã nhận ra: khi người ta giải phóng mặt bằng để xây dựng, họ đã để lại một cây sồi duy nhất ở phía cuối cánh đồng. Và thân cây xoắn vặn với lớp vỏ dày ấy trông rất giống cái cây ngày xưa ở Công viên Jefferson, nơi chúng tôi đã tìm thấy Robert Joyner, giống đến nỗi tôi gần như dám chắc Margo ở đó, phía sau thân cây.
tr: SESIB’a geri dönüp I4’e sürdüm, sonra şehrin kuzeydoğusuna, Holly Meadows denilen bir yere gittim. Sonunda bulana kadar, üç defa Holly Meadows’un yanından geçtim... etraftaki tek şey, meşe ağaçlan ve çiftlik arazileriydi ve girişinde bir işaret olmayan Holly Meadows fazla göze batmıyordu. Ama meşe ve çam ağaçlarının olduğu ilk yoldan ayrılan toprak yolda birkaç metre ilerler ilerlemez ortalık Grovepoint Acres kadar ıssızlaştı. Esas toprak yol yavaşça buharlaşıp toprak arazisine dönüştü. Görebildiğim başka yol yoktu ama etrafta yürürken, yerde duran birkaç sprey boyalı tahta kazık buldum; bir zamanlar arsaların sınır göstergeleri olduklanın tahmin ediyordum. Şüpheli hiçbir şey göremiyor ya da kokusunu alamıyordum ancak yine de göğsüme baskı yapan bir korku hissettim, başta nedenini anlayamadım ama sonra onu gördüm: inşaat için araziyi temizlediklerinde, arka sınınna yakın bir yerde kimsesiz bir meşe ağacı bırakmışlardı. Ve bu eğri büğrü ağaç, kalın kabuklu dallarıyla Jefferson Park’ta Robert Joyner’ı Inılduğumuz yerdekine o kadar benziyordu ki Margo’nun orada, ağacın öbür tarafında olduğuna emindim âdeta.
es: Volví al Chuco, me dirigí a la I-4 y giré al nordeste de la ciudad, hacia un lugar llamado Holly Meadows. Lo pasé de largo tres veces antes de encontrarlo por fin, porque toda la zona estaba rodeada de robles y ranchos, y como no había un cartel que indicara la entrada, Holly Meadows no se veía. Pero en cuanto avancé unos metros por una carretera sin asfaltar entre los robles y los pinos, apareció todo tan desolado como en Grovepoint Acres. El camino principal se diluía lentamente en un terreno de tierra. No vi otros caminos, pero andando descubrí en el suelo varios postes de madera pintados con espray. Supuse que los habían utilizado para delimitar el terreno. No olía ni veía nada sospechoso, pero aun así sentí que el miedo se apoderaba de mí, y al principio no entendía por qué, pero luego lo vi: al limpiar la zona para construir, habían dejado un roble solitario en la parte de atrás del campo. Y el árbol retorcido, con sus ramas cubiertas de gruesa corteza, se parecía tanto al árbol en el que habíamos encontrado a Robert Joyner, en Jefferson Park, que estuve seguro de que Margo estaba allí, al otro lado del árbol.
vi_translation: I turned back to RHAPAW, drove onto the I-4 highway, and then headed northeast of the city to a place called Holly Meadows. I drove past Holly Meadows three times before actually finding it—the entire area was just oak trees and vacant land, and Holly Meadows—with no sign at the entrance—wasn't very noticeable. I drove a few meters along the dirt road through the first cluster of oak and pine trees, and this place seemed no less desolate than Grovepoint Acres. The main dirt road gradually blurred into a field of soil. I didn't see any other roads, but as I went around, I did see some painted wooden stakes lying scattered on the ground; they probably once marked the boundaries. I didn't smell or detect anything suspicious, yet I still felt a fear rising in my chest. At first, I didn't understand why, but then I realized: when they cleared the land for construction, they left a single oak tree at the far end of the field. And the twisted trunk with its thick bark looked very much like the tree from long ago in Jefferson Park, where we had found Robert Joyner, so much so that I was almost certain Margo was there, behind the trunk.
tr_translation: I went back to SESIB and drove to I4, then went to a place called Holly Meadows in the northeast of the city. I passed by Holly Meadows three times until I finally found it... The only things around were oak trees and farmland, and Holly Meadows, which had no sign at its entrance, didn't stand out much. But as soon as I moved a few meters along the dirt road branching off from the first road with oak and pine trees, the place became as desolate as Grovepoint Acres. The main dirt road slowly evaporated and turned into a dirt field. I couldn't see any other road, but while walking around, I found a few spray-painted wooden stakes on the ground; I guessed they were once boundary markers for the plots. I couldn't see or smell anything suspicious, but I still felt a fear pressing on my chest. At first, I didn't understand why, but then I saw it: when they cleared the land for construction, they had left a solitary oak tree near the back boundary. And this crooked tree, with its thick-barked branches, reminded me of Robert Joyner in Jefferson Park. It looked so much like the place we were in that I was almost certain Margo was there, on the other side of the tree.
es_translation: I returned to Chuco, headed to I-4, and turned northeast of the city, towards a place called Holly Meadows. I passed it by three times before finally finding it, because the whole area was surrounded by oaks and ranches, and since there was no sign indicating the entrance, Holly Meadows was not visible. But as soon as I advanced a few meters on an unpaved road between the oaks and pines, everything appeared as desolate as in Grovepoint Acres. The main road slowly dissolved into a dirt terrain. I didn't see any other roads, but while walking I discovered several wooden posts on the ground painted with spray paint. I assumed they had been used to delineate the land. I didn't smell or see anything suspicious, but still, I felt fear taking hold of me, and at first, I didn't understand why, but then I saw it: when clearing the area to build, they had left a solitary oak at the back of the field. And the twisted tree, with its branches covered in thick bark, looked so much like the tree where we had found Robert Joyner, in Jefferson Park, that I was sure Margo was there, on the other side of the tree.

Multiple_ents: ['margo', 'margo roth spiegelma', 'margo roth spiegelman', 'margo itoth spiegelman']
en: And for the first time, I had to picture it: Margo Roth Spiegelman, slumped against the tree, her eyes silent, the black blood pouring out of her mouth, everything bloated and distorted because I had taken so long to find her. She had trusted me to find her sooner. She had trusted me with her last night. And I had failed her. And even though the air tasted like nothing but it-might-rain-later, I was sure I’d found her.
vi: Và lần đầu tiên, tôi phải mường tượng điều này: Margo Roth Spiegelman, gục vào thân cây, hai mắt đờ đẫn, máu đen trào từ miệng ra, tất cả đã trương lên và biến dạng vì tôi đã mất quá nhiều thời gian mới tìm được cô ấy. Margo đã tin tưởng rằng tôi sẽ tìm thấy cô ấy sớm hơn. Đêm hôm đó cô ấy đã đặt niềm tin vào tôi. Và tôi đã phụ niềm tin ấy. Và dù không khí chỉ nghe mùi trời-sắp-mưa, tôi chắc chắn rằng sẽ thấy Margo ở đó.
tr: O anı ilk defa gözümün önüne getirmek zorunda kaldım: Margo Itoth Spiegelman, ağacın gövdesine yaslanmış, gözleri donuk, siyah kan ağzından dışarı akıyor, her yeri şişmiş ve bozulmuş çünkü onu bulmam çok uzun sürmüş. Onu daha erken bulmam için bana güvenmişti. Son gecesinde bana güvenmişti. Ve ben onu yüzüstü bırakmıştım. Havada “daha sonra yağmur yağabilir’ tadından başka tat olmasa da Margo’yu bulduğuma emindim.
es: Y por primera vez tuve que imaginarlo: Margo Roth Spiegelman desplomada sobre el árbol, los ojos mudos, la sangre oscura saliéndole de la boca, toda hinchada y deformada porque había tardado mucho en encontrarla. Ella había confiado en que la encontraría antes. Me había confiado su última noche. Y le había fallado. Y aunque el olor del aire solo permitía deducir que se avecinaba lluvia, estaba seguro de que la había encontrado.
vi_translation: And for the first time, I had to imagine this: Margo Roth Spiegelman, slumped against a tree, her eyes vacant, black blood pouring from her mouth, everything swollen and deformed because I had taken too long to find her. Margo had believed that I would find her sooner. That night she had placed her trust in me. And I had betrayed that trust. And although the air only smelled of impending rain, I was certain that I would find Margo there.
tr_translation: I had to bring that moment to my mind for the first time: Margo Itoth Spiegelman, leaning against the trunk of the tree, her eyes dull, black blood flowing from her mouth, her whole body swollen and decomposed because it took me so long to find her. She had trusted me to find her sooner. She had trusted me on her last night. And I had let her down. Even though there was no other taste in the air except the taste of "it might rain later," I was sure I had found Margo.
es_translation: And for the first time, I had to imagine it: Margo Roth Spiegelman collapsed on the tree, her eyes silent, dark blood coming out of her mouth, all swollen and deformed because it had taken too long to find her. She had trusted that I would find her sooner. She had entrusted me with her last night. And I had failed her. And although the smell of the air only suggested that rain was coming, I was sure that I had found her.

en: But no. It was only a tree, alone in the empty silver dirt. I sat down against the tree and let my breath come back. I hated doing this alone. I hated it. If she thought Robert Joyner had prepared me for this, she was wrong. I didn’t know Robert Joyner. I didn’t love Robert Joyner.
vi: Nhưng không. Chỉ có cái cây, đơn côi trên nền đất xám bạc. Tôi ngồi thụp xuống tựa vào thân cây và cố lấy lại nhịp thở. Tôi ghét phải một mình trải qua chuyện này. Tôi căm ghét. Nếu Margo nghĩ rằng vụ Robert Joyner đã đặt tôi vào thế sẵn sàng, thì cô ấy đã nhầm rồi. Tôi không quen biết Robert Joyner. Tôi không đem lòng yêu mến Robert Joyner.
tr: Ama hayır. Bu sadece bir ağaçtı, boş gümüş rengi toprakta tek başına bir ağaç. Ağacm gövdesine dayanarak oturdum ve soluklandım. Bunu yalnız başıma yapmaktan nefret ediyordum. Nefret ediyordum. Eğer Robert Joyner’m beni buna hazırladığını düşündüyse yanılmıştı. Robert Joyner’ı tanımıyordum. Robert Joyner’ı sevmiyordum.
es: Pero no. Solo era un árbol solitario en la tierra gris. Me senté, me apoyé en el tronco y esperé a recuperar el aliento. Odiaba estar solo en aquellos momentos. Lo odiaba. Si Margo pensaba que Robert Joyner me había preparado para aquello, se equivocaba. Yo no conocía a Robert Joyner. Yo no amaba a Robert Joyner.
vi_translation: But no. There was only the tree, solitary on the silver-gray ground. I crouched down, leaning against the tree trunk and tried to catch my breath. I hated having to go through this alone. I hated it. If Margo thought that the Robert Joyner incident had prepared me, she was wrong. I didn't know Robert Joyner. I didn't have any affection for Robert Joyner.
tr_translation: But no. This was just a tree, a solitary tree in the empty silver-colored soil. I sat down leaning against the trunk of the tree and caught my breath. I hated doing this alone. I hated it. If Robert Joyner thought he was preparing me for this, he was wrong. I didn't know Robert Joyner. I didn't like Robert Joyner.
es_translation: But no. It was just a solitary tree in the gray land. I sat down, leaned against the trunk, and waited to catch my breath. I hated being alone in those moments. I hated it. If Margo thought that Robert Joyner had prepared me for this, she was wrong. I didn't know Robert Joyner. I didn't love Robert Joyner.

en: I hit at the dirt with the heels of my fists, and then pounded it again and again, the sand scattering around my hands until I was hitting the bare roots of the tree, and I kept it up, the pain shooting up through my palms and wrists. I had not cried for Margo until then, but now finally I did, pounding against the ground and shouting because there was no one to hear: I missed her I missed her I missed her I miss her.
vi: Tôi dận nắm tay mình xuống mặt đất, cứ thế đấm thình thịch, cát vẩn lên cho đến khi tôi đấm phải hàng rễ trần của cây. Tôi vẫn không dừng lại, cơn đau thốn chạy khắp bàn tay và cổ tay tôi. Tôi chưa từng bật khóc vì Margo, cho đến khi đó, giờ rút cục tôi không nén nổi nữa. Tôi vẫn nện xuống mặt đất và hét lên vì chẳng có ai ở đây nghe được cả: tôi nhớ Margo, nhớ cô ấy, nhớ, nhớ, nhớ.
tr: Toprağı yumrukladım, sonra tekrar tekrar yumrukladım, ben ağacın dışarı çıkmış köklerine vuruncaya kadar, kumlar ellerimin arasından etrafa saçılıyordu, devam ettim, acı hızla avuçlarımdan ve bileklerimden geçerek artıyordu. O zamana kadar Margo için ağlamamıştım ama sonunda o anda ağladım, yeri yumruklayarak ve duyacak kimse olmadığı için bağırarak: Onu özledim onu özledim onu özledim onu özledim onu özlüyorum.
es: Golpeé el suelo con los nudillos y volví a golpearlo una y otra vez. La arena cedía alrededor de mis manos hasta que llegué a las raíces del árbol, y seguí golpeando. El dolor me subía por las palmas y las muñecas. Hasta aquel momento no había llorado por Margo, pero por fin lo hice, di golpes en el suelo y grité porque nadie podía oírme. La echaba de menos la echaba de menos la echaba de menos la echo de menos.
vi_translation: I pounded my fist into the ground, punching repeatedly, sand swirling up until I hit the exposed roots of a tree. I still didn't stop, the sharp pain shooting through my hand and wrist. I had never cried because of Margo, until then, now I couldn't hold back anymore. I kept pounding the ground and screaming because there was no one here to hear: I miss Margo, miss her, miss, miss, miss.
tr_translation: I punched the ground, then punched it again and again, until I hit the tree's exposed roots, sand scattering around from between my hands, I continued, the pain rapidly increasing as it passed through my palms and wrists. Until then, I hadn't cried for Margo, but finally, at that moment, I cried, punching the ground and shouting because there was no one to hear: I miss her I miss her I miss her I miss her I miss her.
es_translation: I pounded the ground with my knuckles and kept hitting it over and over again. The sand gave way around my hands until I reached the tree roots, and I kept hitting. Pain shot up through my palms and wrists. Until that moment, I hadn't cried for Margo, but I finally did, pounding the ground and screaming because no one could hear me. I missed her I missed her I missed her I miss her.

en: I stayed there even after my arms got tired and my eyes dried up, sitting there and thinking about her until the light got gray.
vi: Tôi cứ ở đó cho đến khi cánh tay bã ra và hai mắt khô lại, cứ ngồi đó và nghĩ về cô ấy, cho đến khi ánh ngày đổ tối.
tr: Kollarım yorulup gözlerim kuruduktan sonra bile oturdum ve ışık grileşene kadar onu düşünerek orada kaldım.
es: Me quedé allí, aunque se me habían agotado los brazos y se me habían secado los ojos. Me quedé sentado pensando en ella hasta que la luz se volvió gris.
vi_translation: I stayed there until my arms went numb and my eyes dried out, just sitting there thinking about her, until day turned to night.
tr_translation: Even after my arms grew tired and my eyes dried up, I sat there and stayed, thinking about it until the light turned gray.
es_translation: I stayed there, even though my arms were exhausted and my eyes had dried up. I sat thinking about her until the light turned gray.

en: The next morning at school, I found Ben standing beside the band door talking to Lacey, Radar, and Angela in the shade of a tree with low-hanging branches. It was hard for me to listen as they talked about prom, and about how Lacey was feuding with Becca or whatever. I was waiting for a chance to tell them what I’d seen, but then when I had the chance, when I finally said, “I took a pretty long look at the two pseudovisions but didn’t find much,” I realized that there was nothing new to say, really.
vi: Sáng hôm sau ở trường, tôi thấy Ben đứng cạnh phòng tập nhạc, đang nói chuyện với Lacey, Radar và Angela dưới một vòm cây xòa tán thấp. Tôi chẳng có lòng dạ nào nghe chúng nó bàn về dạ tiệc tốt nghiệp, và những chuyện đại loại như Lacey đã nổi cơn tá hỏa tam tinh với Becca như thế nào. Tôi chờ đến lúc có thể kể với chúng nó những gì tôi đã thấy, nhưng rồi khi thời điểm ấy đến, rút cục tôi chỉ nói vỏn vẹn, “Hôm qua tôi đã xem rất kĩ hai khu đô thị ma nhưng không có gì đáng chú ý.” Thực ra tôi cũng thấy chẳng có gì mới để nói với chúng nó.
tr: Ertesi gün okulda, Ben’i bando odasının kapısının yanında alçak dallı bir ağacın gölgesinde Lacey, Radar ve Angela’yla konuşurken buldum. Onlar balo ve Lacey’nin Becca’ya nasıl düşmanlık beslediği falan hakkında konuşurken benim için dinlemek zor oldu. Onlara ne gördüğümü anlatmak için fırsat kolluyordum ama sonra fırsat bulduğumda ve sonunda, “İki semtimsiye oldukça uzun süre baktım ama pek bir şey bulamadım,” dediğimde gerçekten de söylenecek yeni bir şey olmadığını fark ettim.
es: Al día siguiente encontré a Ben junto a la puerta de la sala de ensayo, charlando con Lacey, Radar y Angela a la sombra de un árbol de ramas bajas. Me resultaba difícil oírlos hablar del baile, de que Lacey se había peleado con Becca o de lo que fuera. Estaba esperando la oportunidad de contarles lo que había visto, pero cuando por fin la tuve me di cuenta de que en realidad no tenía nada nuevo que contar. —Revisé a fondo dos pseudovisiones, pero no encontré nada.
vi_translation: The next morning at school, I saw Ben standing next to the music room, talking to Lacey, Radar, and Angela under a low-hanging tree canopy. I had no interest in listening to them discuss the prom, or things like how Lacey had a huge fight with Becca. I waited for the moment to tell them what I had seen, but when that moment came, I ended up saying only, "Yesterday I thoroughly checked out two ghost towns but found nothing noteworthy." In fact, I felt there was nothing new to tell them.
tr_translation: The next day at school, I found Ben talking with Lacey, Radar, and Angela in the shade of a low-branched tree next to the band room door. It was hard for me to listen while they talked about prom and how Lacey harbored animosity towards Becca. I was waiting for an opportunity to tell them what I had seen, but then when I finally got the chance and said, "I looked at two umbrellas for quite a long time but didn't find much," I realized there really wasn't anything new to say.
es_translation: The next day I found Ben by the rehearsal room door, chatting with Lacey, Radar, and Angela in the shade of a low-branched tree. I found it difficult to hear them talk about the dance, about Lacey having fought with Becca, or whatever else. I was waiting for the opportunity to tell them what I had seen, but when I finally had it, I realized that I actually had nothing new to tell. —I thoroughly reviewed two pseudovisions, but I found nothing.

en: No one even seemed that concerned, except Lacey. She shook her head as I talked about the pseudovisions, and then said, “I was reading online last night that people who are suicidal end relationships with people they’re angry with. And they give away their stuff. Margo gave me like five pairs of jeans last week because she said I could wear them better, which isn’t even true because she’s so much more, like, curvy.” I liked Lacey, but I saw Margo’s point about the undermining.
vi: Chẳng đứa nào có vẻ để tâm, trừ Lacey. Cậu ấy lúc lắc đầu khi tôi nhắc đến những khu đô thị ma, rồi nói, “Tối hôm qua tớ đọc trên mạng rằng những người chọn cách tự tử trước đó thường cắt đứt quan hệ với những ai từng khiến họ tức giận. Và họ đem cho đồ đạc của mình đi. Tuần trước Margo đã cho tớ năm cái quần jeans, cậu ấy bảo tớ mặc trông đẹp hơn, nhưng thực ra như vậy chỉ đãi bôi thôi, Margo có đường cong, ừm, chuẩn hơn tớ nhiều.” Tôi thấy thích Lacey, nhưng cũng nhớ lại những điều Margo đã nói về cô nàng thích “dìm hàng” bạn bè này.
tr: Hiç kimse o kadar da endişeli görünmüyordu, Lacey dışmda. Ben semtimsiler hakkında konuşurken başını salladı. “Dün gece internette, intihar eğilimi olan kişilerin kızgın olduğu insanlarla ilişkilerini bitirdiğini okudum. Ve eşyalarını hediye ediyorlarmış. Geçen hafta Margo bana beş tane falan kot pantolon verdi, bana daha iyi uyduklarını söyledi ki bu doğru bile değil, çünkü o çok daha, şey, kıvrımlı hatlara sahip.” Lacey’yi severdim ama Margo’nun bahsettiği şu Lacey’nin Margo’ya hep zarar vermeye çalışması meselesini anlıyordum.
es: Nadie pareció especialmente interesado, excepto Lacey, que meneaba la cabeza mientras contaba lo de las pseudovisiones. —Anoche leí en internet que los suicidas rompen relaciones con las personas con las que están enfadados. Y regalan sus cosas. La semana pasada Margo me dio cinco vaqueros porque me dijo que a mí me irían mejor, y no es verdad, porque ella tiene muchas más curvas. Lacey me caía bien, pero entendí lo que me había contado Margo de que siempre estaba menoscabándola.
vi_translation: None of them seemed to care, except for Lacey. She shook her head when I mentioned ghost towns, then said, "Last night I read online that people who choose to commit suicide often cut ties with those who have made them angry before. And they give away their belongings. Last week Margo gave me five pairs of jeans, she said I looked better in them, but actually, it was just flattery, Margo has, um, much better curves than I do." I liked Lacey, but I also remembered what Margo had said about her liking to "put down" her friends.
tr_translation: Nobody seemed that worried, except for Lacey. She nodded while I talked about my neighborhood friends. "Last night on the internet, I read that people with suicidal tendencies end relationships with those they are angry with. And they give away their belongings. Last week, Margo gave me about five pairs of jeans, saying they fit me better, which isn't even true because she's much more, well, curvy." I liked Lacey, but I understood what Margo meant about Lacey always trying to harm her.
es_translation: Nobody seemed particularly interested, except for Lacey, who was shaking her head while recounting the pseudovisions. —Last night I read on the internet that people who commit suicide break off relationships with those they are angry with. And they give away their things. Last week Margo gave me five pairs of jeans because she said they would fit me better, and it's not true, because she has a lot more curves. I liked Lacey, but I understood what Margo had told me about her always undermining her.

en: Something about telling us that story made her start to cry, and Ben put an arm around her, and she tucked her head into his shoulder, which was hard to do, because in her heels she was actually taller than him.
vi: Hình như kể lại chuyện đó khiến Lacey quá xúc động nên bắt đầu nước mắt ngắn nước mắt dài. Ben vòng tay qua Lacey và cô nàng dụi đầu vào vai nó, như vậy thực ra hơi khó vì khi đi giày cao gót thì Lacey cao nhỉnh hơn Ben.
tr: Bize bu hikâyeyi anlatmasıyla ilgili bir şeyler ağlamaya başlamasına neden oldu, Ben kolunu ona doladı ve Lacey başını Ben’in omzuna dayadı, bunu yapması zordu çünkü topuklularıyla Lacey, Ben’den uzundu.
es: Al contárnoslo, empezó a llorar. Ben le pasó un brazo por la cintura, y ella apoyó la cabeza en su hombro, lo que no le resultó fácil, porque con tacones era más alta que él.
vi_translation: It seems that recounting that story made Lacey so emotional that she started to cry. Ben put his arm around Lacey and she rested her head on his shoulder, which was actually a bit difficult because when wearing high heels, Lacey was slightly taller than Ben.
tr_translation: Something about telling us this story made her start crying, Ben put his arm around her and Lacey rested her head on Ben's shoulder, which was difficult because in her high heels, Lacey was taller than Ben.
es_translation: When she told us, she started to cry. Ben put an arm around her waist, and she rested her head on his shoulder, which was not easy for her because, with heels, she was taller than him.

en: “Lacey, we just have to find a location. I mean, talk to your friends. Did she ever mention paper towns? Did she ever talk about a specific place? Was there some subdivision somewhere that meant something to her?” She shrugged into Ben’s shoulder.
vi: “Được rồi mà Lacey, tụi mình chỉ phải tìm đúng nơi thôi. Cậu thử nói chuyện với tụi bạn xem sao. Không biết Margo đã từng nói với ai về những thành phố giấy chưa? Không biết cậu ấy có nhắc đến địa điểm cụ thể nào không? Liệu có một tiểu khu nào đó, ở đâu đó, đặc biệt có ý nghĩa với Margo không?” Lacey dụi sâu hơn vào vai Ben.
tr: “Lacey, sadece bir konum bulmamız gerekiyor. Yani, arkadaşlarınla konuş. Hiç kâğıttan kentlerden bahsetti mi? Hiç belirli bir yerden bahsetti mi? Onun için bir anlamı olan bir semt var mıydı?” Omuzlarını silkip Ben’in omzuna gömüldü.
es: Ben le pasó un brazo por la cintura, y ella apoyó la cabeza en su hombro, lo que no le resultó fácil, porque con tacones era más alta que él. —Lacey, tenemos que encontrarla. En fin, habla con tus amigos. ¿Habló alguna vez de ciudades de papel? ¿Habló de algún lugar en concreto? ¿Había alguna urbanización en alguna parte que significara algo para ella? Lacey se encogió de hombros, todavía apoyada en Ben.
vi_translation: “It's okay, Lacey, we just have to find the right place. Try talking to our friends and see what they say. Did Margo ever mention anything about the paper towns to anyone? Did she ever talk about any specific locations? Is there a particular subdivision somewhere that holds special meaning for Margo?” Lacey nestled deeper into Ben's shoulder.
tr_translation: “Lacey, we just need to find one location. So, talk to your friends. Did he ever mention paper towns? Did he ever mention a specific Did he mention the place? Was there a neighborhood that had any meaning for him?" She shrugged and buried herself in Ben's shoulder.
es_translation: —Lacey, we have to find her. Anyway, talk to your friends. Did she ever talk about paper towns? Did she talk about any specific place? Was there any subdivision somewhere that meant something to her? Lacey shrugged, still leaning on Ben.

en: “Bro, don’t push her,” Ben said. I sighed, but shut up.
vi: “Thôi, đừng hối Lacey quá,” Ben nói. Tôi thở dài, không nói gì nữa.
tr: “Kardeşim, onu zorlama,” dedi Ben. İç çektim ama çenemi kapattım.
es: —Colega, no la presiones —me advirtió Ben. Suspiré, pero no dije nada.
vi_translation: “Alright, don't rush Lacey too much,” Ben said. I sighed, saying nothing more.
tr_translation: “Brother, don't force him,” said Ben. I sighed but kept my mouth shut.
es_translation: —Colleague, don't pressure her —Ben warned me. I sighed, but I didn't say anything.

en: “I’m on the online stuff,” Radar said, “but her username hasn’t logged on to Omnictionary since she left.”
vi: “Tôi có theo dõi trên mạng,” Radar nói, “nhưng tên truy cập của Margo không đăng nhập vào Toàn Thư Đủ Thứ kể từ khi cậu ấy bỏ đi.”
tr: “Ben internet işlerindeyim,” dedi Radar, “ama kullanıcı adı, gittiğinden beri Omnictionary’ye girmedi.
es: —Estoy en internet —dijo Radar—, pero su nombre de usuario no ha entrado en el Omnictionary desde que se marchó.
vi_translation: “I have been following online,” Radar said, “but Margo's username hasn't logged into Omnictionary since she left.”
tr_translation: “I’m in the internet business,” said Radar, “but the username hasn’t logged into Omnictionary since you left.”
es_translation: —I'm on the internet —said Radar—, but their username hasn't logged into Omnictionary since they left.

en: And then all at once they were back on the topic of prom. Lacey emerged from Ben’s shoulder still looking sad and distracted, but she tried to smile as Radar and Ben swapped tales of corsage purchasing.
vi: Rồi lập tức cả lũ lại trở về chủ đề dạ tiệc tốt nghiệp. Lacey ngóc đầu khỏi vai Ben, trông vẫn ỉu xìu và lơ đãng, nhưng cố gắng mỉm cười nghe Radar và Ben bàn ra tán vào chuyện đặt hoa cài áo.
tr: Ve birdenbire balo konusuna geri döndüler. Lacey hâlâ üzgün ve dikkati dağılmış görünerek Ben’in omzundan kalktı ama Ben ile Radar birbirlerine süs çiçeği alma hikâyelerini anlatırken gülmeye çalıştı.
es: Y de repente volvieron al tema del baile. Lacey levantó la cabeza del hombro de Ben con aire triste y distraído, pero intentó sonreír mientras Radar y Ben intercambiaban historias sobre la compra de flores.
vi_translation: Then immediately the whole group returned to the topic of the graduation party. Lacey lifted her head from Ben's shoulder, still looking downcast and distracted, but tried to smile as she listened to Radar and Ben discussing boutonnieres.
tr_translation: And suddenly they returned to the topic of the prom. Lacey, still looking upset and distracted, lifted her head from Ben's shoulder but tried to laugh while Ben and Radar shared stories about getting corsages for each other.
es_translation: And suddenly they returned to the topic of the dance. Lacey lifted her head from Ben's shoulder with a sad and distracted air, but tried to smile while Radar and Ben exchanged stories about buying flowers.

en: The day passed as it always did—in slow motion, with a thousand plaintive glances at the clock. But now it was even more unbearable, because every minute I wasted in school was another minute in which I failed to find her.
vi: Ngày hôm đó trôi qua như mọi ngày–tốc độ chậm, với cả ngàn lần ủ rũ liếc nhìn đồng hồ. Nhưng giờ thậm chí tất cả còn khôn kham hơn, vì mỗi phút tôi uổng phí ở trường và từng phút thất bại chưa tìm được Margo.
tr: Gün her zamanki gibi geçti... yavaş çekimde, saate binlerce ağlamaklı bakış atarak. Ama artık daha da katlanılmazdı çünkü okulda harcadığım her dakika, onu bulmakta başarısız olduğum başka bir dakikaydı.
es: El día transcurrió como siempre, a cámara lenta y con mil miradas lastimeras al reloj. Pero todavía era más insoportable, porque cada minuto que perdía en el instituto era otro minuto que no conseguía encontrarla.
vi_translation: The day passed like any other day—slowly, with a thousand weary glances at the clock. But now everything was even more unbearable, because every minute I wasted at school was another minute I failed to find Margo.
tr_translation: The day passed as usual... in slow motion, casting thousands of tearful glances at the clock. But now it was even more unbearable because every minute I spent at school was another minute I failed to find her.
es_translation: The day went by as usual, in slow motion and with a thousand pitiful glances at the clock. But it was even more unbearable, because every minute lost at the institute was another minute he couldn't find her.

en: My only vaguely interesting class that day was English, when Dr. Holden completely ruined Moby Dick for me by incorrectly assuming we’d all read it and talking about Captain Ahab and his obsession with finding and killing this white whale. But it was fun to watch her get more and more excited as she talked. “Ahab’s a madman railing against fate. You never see Ahab wanting anything else in this whole novel, do you? He has a singular obsession. And because he is the captain of his ship, no one can stop him. You can argue—indeed, you may argue, if you choose to write about him for your final reaction papers—that Ahab is a fool for being obsessed. But you could also argue that there is something tragically heroic about fighting this battle he is doomed to lose. Is Ahab’s hope a kind of insanity, or is it the very definition of humanness?” I wrote down as much as I could of what she said, realizing that I could probably pull off my final reaction paper without actually reading the book. As she talked, it occurred to me that Dr. Holden was unusually good at reading stuff. And she’d said she liked Whitman. So when the bell rang, I took Leaves of Grass from my bag and then zipped it back up slowly while everyone raced off either to home or to extracurriculars. I waited behind someone asking for an extension on an already late paper, and then he left.
vi: Giờ học duy nhất hơi hơi hào hứng với tôi ngày hôm đó là Quốc ngữ. Cô Holden hoàn toàn phá hủy Moby Dick trong tôi khi lầm tưởng rằng chúng tôi đều đã đọc tác phẩm. Cô hồn nhiên giảng về vị thuyền trưởng Ahab với đam mê tìm và diệt con cá voi trắng nào đó. Nhưng nhìn cô ấy càng giảng càng say sưa như vậy cũng hay. “Ahab là một kẻ điên dong buồm đi ngược số phận. Trong toàn bộ cuốn tiểu thuyết, các em không thấy ông ấy theo đuổi điều gì khác, phải không? Ông chỉ có một ám ảnh duy nhất. Và vì ông là thuyền trưởng, nên không ai trên tàu ngăn được ông. Các em có thể lập luận–hẳn là các em có thể đưa ra lập luận của mình nếu chọn viết về ông ấy trong bài luận cuối năm–rằng Ahab là gã ngốc điên dại vì đam mê ấy. Nhưng các em cũng có thể lập luận rằng có điều gì đó đầy tính anh hùng ca bi tráng khi Ahab dấn thân vào cuộc đấu mà ông cầm chắc chiến bại. Hi vọng của Ahab có phải là một dạng điên rồ quẫn trí không, hay đó là hiện thân hùng hồn của nhân tính?” Tôi ngoáy vội càng nhiều càng tốt những lời cô Holden nói, thầm phát hiện ra rằng tôi có thể chỉn chu nộp bài cuối kì mà không cần thực sự đọc hết tác phẩm. Trong khi nghe giảng, tôi chợt nhận ra cô Holden có khả năng đọc hiểu siêu phàm. Cô cũng từng nói rằng cô thích Whitman. Thế là khi chuông báo hết giờ, tôi lấy cuốn Những cánh cỏ ra và lật rất từ từ trong khi những đứa khác trong lớp ra về hoặc đi làm gì đó ngoại khóa. Tôi đợi sau một đứa đang hỏi xin cô gia hạn một bài tập đã trễ, rồi nó cũng ra khỏi lớp.
tr: O gün azıcık ilgi çekici olan tek dersim, dr Holden’m hepimizin Moby Dick’i okumuş olduğumuzu varsayarak Kaptan Ahab ile onun şu beyaz balinayı bulup öldürme saplantısını anlatarak kitabı benim için tamamen mahvettiği edebiyat dersiydi. Ama onun konuşurken gittikçe heyecanlanmasını izlemek eğlenceliydi. “Ahab kadere sövüp sayan çılgın bir adam. Romanda Ahab’m başka bir şey istediğini görmediniz, değil mi? Tek bir saplantısı var. Ve geminin kaptanı olduğu için kimse onu durduramıyor. Eğer final ödevlerinizde ondan bahsetmeyi seçerseniz saplantılı olduğu için Ahab’ın bir aptal olduğunu iddia edebilirsiniz... Ancak bu kaybetmeye mahkûm olduğu mücadeleyi devam ettirmesinde trajik biçimde kahramanca bir şeyler olduğunu da tartışabilirsiniz. Ahab’ın umudu delilik benzeri bir şey mi, yoksa tam da insanlığın tanımı mı?” Aslında kitabı okumadan final ödevini kıvırabileceğimi fark ederek söylediklerinden yazabildiğim kadarını yazdım. O konuşurken, dr Holden’m bir şeyler okumakta alışılmadık derecede iyi olduğu akhma geldi. Ve Whitman’ı sevdiğini söylemişti. Böylece zil çaldığında, Çimen Yapraklarım çantamdan çıkardım, şuura herkes aceleyle ya eve ya da dersle alakasız yerlere giderken çantanın fermuarım yavaşça çektim. Zaten geç kalmış bir ödev için fazladan vakit isteyen birinin arkasında bekledim, sonra çocuk gitti.
es: La única clase remotamente interesante aquel día fue literatura, cuando la doctora Holden me destrozó el final de Moby Dick dando por sentado, equivocadamente, que todos lo habíamos leído y hablando del capitán Ahab y de su obsesión por encontrar y matar a la ballena blanca. Pero fue divertido ver como se emocionaba a medida que hablaba. —Ahab es un loco que despotrica del destino. En toda la novela no se ve que quiera otra cosa, ¿verdad? Tiene una única obsesión. Y como es el capitán del barco, nadie puede detenerlo. Podéis argumentar (de hecho, tenéis que argumentar si decidís hacer el trabajo de final de curso sobre Moby Dick) que Ahab está loco porque está obsesionado. Pero también podríais argumentar que hay algo trágicamente heroico en librar una batalla que está condenado a perder. ¿Es la esperanza de Ahab una especie de locura o es el símbolo de lo humano? Tomé apuntes de todo lo que pude pensando que seguramente podría hacer el trabajo de fin de curso sin haber leído el libro. Mientras la doctora Holden hablaba, pensé que era una lectora fuera de lo corriente. Y me había dicho que le gustaba Whitman. Así que cuando sonó el timbre, saqué Hojas de hierba de la mochila y volví a cerrarla despacio mientras todo el mundo se marchaba corriendo a su casa o a las actividades extraescolares. Esperé detrás de un compañero que le pidió prórroga para entregar un trabajo.
vi_translation: The only somewhat exciting class for me that day was National Language. Ms. Holden completely ruined Moby Dick for me by assuming that we had all read the book. She innocently lectured about Captain Ahab with his passion for hunting down some white whale. But watching her get more and more engrossed in her lecture was quite interesting. “Ahab is a madman sailing against fate. Throughout the entire novel, you don’t see him pursuing anything else, right? He has only one obsession. And because he is the captain, no one on the ship can stop him. You could argue—and surely you could make your own argument if you choose to write about him in your final essay—that Ahab is a mad fool because of that passion. But you could also argue that there is something epic and tragic about Ahab engaging in a battle he is certain to lose. Is Ahab’s hope a form of desperate madness, or is it a powerful embodiment of humanity?” I quickly scribbled down as much as I could of Ms. Holden’s words, realizing that I could neatly submit my final paper without actually reading the entire book. While listening to the lecture, I suddenly realized that Ms. Holden had an extraordinary ability to understand literature. She also once mentioned that she liked Whitman. So when the bell rang, I took out Leaves of Grass and slowly flipped through it while the other students either left or went to do some extracurricular activities. I waited behind a student who was asking for an extension on a late assignment, and then they left the classroom.
tr_translation: The only slightly interesting class that day was my literature class where Dr. Holden, assuming we had all read Moby Dick, completely ruined the book for me by talking about Captain Ahab and his obsession with finding and killing that white whale. But it was fun to watch him get more and more excited as he talked. “Ahab is a madman who curses fate. In the novel, you didn't see Ahab want anything else, did you? He has a single obsession. And because he's the captain of the ship, no one can stop him. If you choose to write about him in your final papers, you can argue that Ahab is a fool because of his obsession... But you can also discuss that there is something tragically heroic in his continuing this doomed struggle. Is Ahab's hope something akin to madness, or is it the very definition of humanity?” Realizing that I could ace the final paper without actually reading the book, I wrote down as much as I could from what he said. As he spoke, it occurred to me that Dr. Holden was unusually good at reading things. And he had said he liked Whitman. So when the bell rang, I took out my Grass Blades from my bag, while everyone else hurriedly went either home or to places unrelated to class, I slowly zipped up my bag. I waited behind someone who was asking for extra time for an already late assignment, then the kid left.
es_translation: The only remotely interesting class that day was literature, when Dr. Holden spoiled the ending of Moby Dick by assuming, mistakenly, that we had all read it and talking about Captain Ahab and his obsession with finding and killing the white whale. But it was fun to see how excited she got as she spoke. —Ahab is a madman who rants about fate. Throughout the entire novel, it is clear he wants nothing else, right? He has a single obsession. And since he is the captain of the ship, no one can stop him. You can argue (in fact, you have to argue if you decide to do your final paper on Moby Dick) that Ahab is mad because he is obsessed. But you could also argue that there is something tragically heroic about fighting a battle he is doomed to lose. Is Ahab's hope a kind of madness or is it the symbol of what it means to be human? I took notes on everything I could, thinking that I would surely be able to do the end-of-term paper without having read the book. While Dr. Holden was speaking, I thought she was an extraordinary reader. And she had told me that she liked Whitman. So when the bell rang, I took Leaves of Grass out of my backpack and closed it slowly while everyone else ran off to their homes or extracurricular activities. I waited behind a classmate who asked for an extension to submit a paper.

en: “It’s my favorite Whitman reader,” she said.
vi: “Độc giả hâm mộ Whitman của tôi đây,” cô nói với tôi.
tr: “İşte en sevdiğim Whitman okuyucusu,” dedi.
es: —Mi lector de Whitman favorito —me dijo la doctora Holden cuando el alumno salió.
vi_translation: “Here is my Whitman fan reader,” she said to me.
tr_translation: “Here is my favorite Whitman reader,” he said.
es_translation: —My favorite Whitman reader —Dr. Holden told me when the student left.

en: I forced a smile. “Do you know Margo Roth Spiegelman?” I asked.
vi: Tôi nặn ra một nụ cười. “Cô có biết bạn Margo Roth Spiegelman không ạ?” tôi hỏi.
tr: Zorlanarak gülümsedim. “Margo Roth Spiegelman’ı tanıyor musunuz?” diye sordum.
es: Forcé una sonrisa. —¿Conoce a Margo Roth Spiegelman? —le pregunté.
vi_translation: I forced a smile. "Do you know Margo Roth Spiegelman?" I asked.
tr_translation: I smiled with difficulty. “Do you know Margo Roth Spiegelman?” I asked.
es_translation: I forced a smile. —Do you know Margo Roth Spiegelman? —I asked him.

en: She sat down behind her desk and motioned for me to sit. “I never had her in class,” Dr. Holden said, “but I’ve certainly heard of her. I know that she ran away.”
vi: Cô ngồi xuống bàn và dịch sang một bên cho tôi cũng có chỗ. “Margo chưa bao giờ đăng kí học giờ của tôi,” cô Holden nói, “nhưng chắc chắn tôi có nghe nói đến em ấy. Tôi cũng biết em ấy đã bỏ đi.”
tr: Masasına oturup benim de oturmam için işaret etti. “Hiç dersime girmedi,” dedi dr Holden, “ama kesinlikle duydum. Evden kaçtığını biliyorum.
es: Se sentó a su mesa y me indicó con un gesto que me sentara también yo. —Nunca la he tenido en clase —me contestó la doctora Holden—, pero he oído hablar de ella, claro. Sé que se ha escapado.
vi_translation: She sat down at the table and moved aside to make room for me. "Margo never registered for my class," Ms. Holden said, "but I certainly have heard of her. I also know that she has left."
