vi_translation: I switched the flashlight to one hand, held the nail polish bottle in the other, and observed carefully. The red color was so dark it almost looked black. I had seen this red color before. On the dashboard of the minivan that night. Suddenly, the large creatures lurking on the roof and the creaking sounds in the building no longer mattered–I just felt a strange exhilaration. Of course, I couldn't know if it was the same bottle of polish, but it was definitely the same shade.
tr_translation: I took the flashlight in one hand and the nail polish in the other, and looked closely at the bottle. It was so red that it was almost black. I had seen this color before. This nail polish was on the panel of the minivan that night. Suddenly, the scurrying in the rafters and the creaking inside the building became insignificant... I felt a perverse excitement. Of course, I couldn't know if it was the same bottle, but it was definitely the same color.
es_translation: I grabbed the flashlight with one hand, the nail polish with the other, and observed it closely. It was so red that it almost looked black. I had seen that color before that night. On the dashboard of the minivan. Suddenly, the running on the beams and the creaking of the building became irrelevant. I felt a perverse euphoria. I couldn't know if it was the same bottle, of course, but it was definitely the same color.

en: I rotated the bottle around and saw, unambiguously, a tiny smear of blue spray paint on the outside of the bottle. From her spray-painted fingers. I could be sure now. She’d been here after we parted ways that morning. Maybe she was still staying here. Maybe she only showed up late at night. Maybe she had taped up the particleboard to keep her privacy.
vi: Tôi xoay xoay cái lọ và thấy, không nghi ngờ gì nữa, một vết bé xíu sơn xanh da trời lem trên vỏ lọ. Lem từ ngón tay dính sơn xanh da trời của Margo. Bây giờ tôi có thể chắc chắn được rồi. Cô ấy đã đến đây sau khi chúng tôi tạm biệt nhau buổi sáng hôm ấy. Có lẽ cô ấy còn ở đây. Có lẽ phải khuya cô ấy mới xuất hiện. Có lẽ cô ấy đã dán băng dính lên tấm gỗ ép để bảo toàn sự riêng tư.
tr: Şişeyi etrafında döndürdüm ve şişenin dışında, tartışmasız bir şekilde, mavi sprey boyanın lekesini gördüm. Onun sprey boyayla boyanmış parmaklarından geliyordu. Artık emin olabilirdim. O sabah yollarımızı ayırdıktan sonra Margo buraya gelmişti. Belki de hâlâ burada kalıyordu. Belki de yalnızca gece geç saatte ortaya çıkıyordu. Belki de mahremiyetini korumak için levhayı o bantlamıştı.
es: Giré el frasco y vi sin el menor género de duda una diminuta mancha de espray azul en la parte externa del vidrio. De sus dedos manchados de espray. Entonces estuve seguro. Había estado allí después de que nos separáramos aquella mañana. Quizá todavía estaba allí. Quizá solo salía por la noche. Quizá había puesto la cinta en el conglomerado para mantener la privacidad.
vi_translation: I rotated the jar and saw, without a doubt, a tiny smudge of sky-blue paint on its surface. Smeared from Margo's sky-blue paint-stained finger. Now I could be certain. She had come here after we said goodbye that morning. Perhaps she was still here. Perhaps she would only appear late at night. Perhaps she had taped the plywood to maintain her privacy.
tr_translation: I turned the bottle around and saw, undeniably, the stain of blue spray paint on the outside of the bottle. It was coming from her spray-painted fingers. Now I could be sure. After we parted ways that morning, Margo had come here. Maybe she was still staying here. Maybe she only appeared late at night. Maybe she had taped the sign to protect her privacy.
es_translation: I turned the jar and saw without the slightest doubt a tiny blue spray stain on the outside of the glass. From his spray-stained fingers. Then I was sure. He had been there after we parted that morning. Maybe he was still there. Maybe he only came out at night. Maybe he had put the tape on the conglomerate to maintain privacy.

en: I resolved right then to stay until morning. If Margo had slept here, I could, too. And thus commenced a brief conversation with myself.
vi: Tôi lập tức quyết định mình sẽ ở lại đây đến sáng. Nếu Margo ngủ được ở chỗ này thì tôi cũng ngủ được. Và thế là một cuộc tự vấn chóng vánh diễn ra.
tr: Tam o anda, sabaha kadar orada kalmaya kesin olarak karar verdim. Eğer Margo burada uyumuşsa ben de uyuyabilirdim. Böylece kendimle aramda kısa bir sohbet başladı.
es: En aquel momento decidí quedarme hasta el día siguiente. Si Margo había dormido allí, también yo podría hacerlo. Y así empezó una breve conversación conmigo mismo.
vi_translation: I immediately decided that I would stay here until morning. If Margo could sleep in this place, then I could sleep too. And thus, a brief self-examination took place.
tr_translation: At that moment, I made a firm decision to stay there until morning. If Margo had slept here, I could sleep too. Thus, a brief conversation began between myself and me.
es_translation: At that moment, I decided to stay until the next day. If Margo had slept there, I could do it too. And so began a brief conversation with myself.

en: Me: But the rats.
vi: Tôi: Còn lũ chuột đấy.
tr: Ben: Ama fareler.
es: Yo: Pero hay ratas.
vi_translation: Me: There are still those rats.
tr_translation: Ben: But mice.
es_translation: Me: But there are rats.

en: Me: Yeah, but they seem to stay in the ceiling.
vi: Tôi: Ừa, nhưng hình như chúng chỉ duyệt binh trên trần thôi.
tr: Ben: Evet ama tavanda kahyor gibi görünüyorlar.
es: Yo: Sí, pero parece que se quedan en el techo.
vi_translation: Me: Yeah, but it seems like they only parade on the ceiling.
tr_translation: Ben: Yes, but they look like they're melting on the ceiling.
es_translation: Me: Yes, but it seems they stay on the roof.

en: Me: But the lizards.
vi: Tôi: Thằn lằn nữa.
tr: Ben: Ama kertenkeleler.
es: Yo: Pero hay lagartijas.
vi_translation: Me: More lizards.
tr_translation: Ben: But lizards.
es_translation: Me: But there are lizards.

en: Me: Oh, come on. You used to pull their tails off when you were little. You’re not scared of lizards.
vi: Tôi: Thằn lằn nữa. Tôi: Ôi dào, hồi bé vẫn kéo đứt đuôi thằn lằn đấy thôi. Thằn lằn thì sợ gì.
tr: Ben: Ah, haydi ama. Küçükken kuyruklarım koparırdın. Kertenkelelerden korkmazsın.
es: Yo: Oh, vamos. De pequeño les cortabas la cola. Las lagartijas no te dan miedo.
vi_translation: Me: More lizards. Me: Oh well, when I was a kid, I used to pull off lizard tails. What is the lizard afraid of?
tr_translation: Ben: Oh, come on. When you were little, you used to pull off my tails. You're not afraid of lizards.
es_translation: Me: Oh, come on. When you were little, you used to cut off their tails. Lizards don't scare you.

en: Me: But the rats.
vi: Tôi: Nhưng còn chuột.
tr: Ben: Ama fareler.
es: Yo: Pero hay ratas.
vi_translation: Me: But what about the mouse?
tr_translation: Ben: But mice.
es_translation: Me: But there are rats.

en: Me: Rats can’t really hurt you anyway. They’re more scared of you than you are of them.
vi: Tôi: Dù gì thì chuột làm đau được ai chứ. Chuột sợ mình hơn là mình sợ chuột nhiều.
tr: Ben: Fareler seni gerçekten yaralayamaz nasılsa. Onlar senden, senin onlardan korktuğundan daha çok korkuyorlar.
es: Yo: Pero las ratas no pueden hacerte daño. Les asustas más tú a ellas que ellas a ti.
vi_translation: Me: After all, who can a mouse hurt? Mice are more afraid of us than we are of them.
tr_translation: Ben: Mice can't really hurt you anyway. They are more afraid of you than you are of them.
es_translation: Me: But the rats can't hurt you. You scare them more than they scare you.

en: Me: Okay, but what about the rats?
vi: Tôi: Ờ, thế còn lũ chuột thì sao?
tr: Ben: Peki ama fareler ne olacak?
es: Yo: Vale, pero ¿qué pasa con las ratas?
vi_translation: Me: Well, what about the rats?
tr_translation: Ben: But what about the mice?
es_translation: Me: Okay, but what about the rats?

en: Me: Shut up.
vi: Tôi: Thôi ngay.
tr: Ben: Kapa çeneni.
es: Yo: Cállate.
vi_translation: Me: Stop it right now.
tr_translation: Ben: Shut your mouth.
es_translation: Me: Shut up.

en: In the end, the rats didn’t matter, not really, because I was in a place where Margo had been alive. I was in a place that saw her after I did, and the warmth of that made the minimall almost comfortable. I mean, I didn’t feel like an infant being held by Mommy or anything, but my breath had stopped catching each time I heard a noise. And in becoming comfortable, I found it easier to explore. I knew there was more to find, and now, I felt ready to find it.
vi: Cuối cùng, lũ chuột thực sự cũng chẳng hề gì, vì tôi đang ở nơi Margo từng ở. Tôi đang ở nơi đã được chiêm ngưỡng cô ấy sau khi tôi được chiêm ngưỡng, và sự ấm áp từ suy nghĩ đó khiến khu mua sắm mini này trở nên gần như dễ chịu. Tôi không cảm thấy mình như đứa trẻ con, động làm gì cũng có mẹ theo sát, nhưng tôi vẫn nín thở mỗi khi nghe thấy tiếng động lạ. Và vì cảm giác dễ chịu, nên nơi này thành ra dễ khám phá hơn. Còn nhiều điều để khám phá, và giờ, tôi đã sẵn sàng.
tr: Sonuçta fareler pek önem taşımadı çünkü Margo’nun hayatta olduğu bir yerdeydim. Onu benden sonra gören bir yerdeydim ve bunun sıcaklığı bu küçük alışveriş merkezini neredeyse rahat bir hale getirdi. Yani, anneciği tarafından kucaklanan bir bebek falan gibi hissetmedim ama artık nefesim her ses duyduğumda kesilmiyordu. Ve rahat olunca araştırma yapmak daha kolay geldi. Bulunacak daha fazla şey olduğunu biliyordum ve şimdi onları bulmaya hazır hissediyordum.
es: Al final no importó que hubiera ratas, al menos no mucho, porque estaba en un sitio en el que Margo había estado viva. Estaba en un sitio que la había visto después de mí, y aquella calidez hacía que el centro comercial fuera un lugar casi cómodo. Bueno, no me sentía como un niño en brazos de su mamá, pero ya no me quedaba sin respiración cada vez que oía un ruido. Y al sentirme más cómodo, me resultó más fácil explorar. Sabía que quedaban cosas por encontrar, y ya estaba listo para encontrarlas.
vi_translation: In the end, the actual rats didn't really matter because I was where Margo had been. I was in a place that had seen her after I had seen her, and the warmth from that thought made this mini-mall almost pleasant. I didn't feel like a child, always having my mother close by, but I still held my breath whenever I heard a strange noise. And because of the pleasant feeling, this place became easier to explore. There was much to discover, and now, I was ready.
tr_translation: In the end, the mice didn't matter much because I was in a place where Margo was alive. I was in a place where she had been seen after me, and the warmth of that made this small shopping mall almost comfortable. So, I didn't feel like a baby being hugged by its mother or anything, but my breath no longer stopped every time I heard a sound. And being relaxed made it easier to do research. I knew there was more to be found, and now I felt ready to find it.
es_translation: In the end, it didn't matter that there were rats, at least not much, because I was in a place where Margo had been alive. I was in a place that had seen her after me, and that warmth made the mall an almost comfortable place. Well, I didn't feel like a child in his mother's arms, but I no longer ran out of breath every time I heard a noise. And as I felt more comfortable, it became easier for me to explore. I knew there were still things to find, and I was ready to find them.

en: I left the office, ducking through a Troll Hole into the room with the labyrinthine shelves. I walked up and down the aisles for a while. At the end of the room I crawled through the next Troll Hole into the empty room. I sat down on the carpet rolled against the far wall. The cracked white paint crunched against my back. I stayed there for a while, long enough that the jagged beam of light coming through a hole in the ceiling crept an inch along the floor as I let myself become accustomed to the sounds.
vi: Tôi rời văn phòng, chui qua một Lỗ Quỉ sang căn phòng mê hồn trận những giá sắt. Tôi đi tới đi lui theo lối đi giữa các dãy giá trong chốc lát, đến cuối căn phòng, qua Lỗ Quỉ tiếp theo sang gian phòng trống. Tôi ngồi xuống tấm thảm đã cuộn lại, dựa vào tường ở góc phòng. Lớp sơn trắng loang lổ nghe giòn và nứt nẻ hơn sau lưng tôi. Tôi ngồi thế một lúc, đủ lâu để chùm sáng duệch doạc từ trên trần rọi xuống bò được vài phân trên sàn, trong khi tôi dần thích nghi với những âm thanh.
tr: Labirent gibi rafları olan odaya giden bir Cüce Deliği’nden sürünerek ofisten çıktım. Bir süre aralarında ileri geri yürüdüm. Odanın sonunda, sonraki Cüce Deliği’nden boş odaya doğru emekledim. Karşı duvarın önündeki sarılmış halının üstüne oturdum. Çatlak beyaz boya sırtımın arkasında çıtırdadı. Bir süre orada kaldım; ben kendimi seslere alışmaya bırakırken tavandaki delikten gelen ışık hüzmesinin yerde birkaç santimetre kayacağı kadar uzun bir süre.
es: Me metí por un Agujero de Trol y llegué a la sala del laberinto de estanterías. Recorrí los pasillos un buen rato. Al final me metí en el siguiente Agujero de Trol y gateé hasta la sala vacía. Me senté en la moqueta enrollada contra la pared del fondo. La pintura blanca desconchada crujió al apoyar la espalda. Me quedé allí un rato, el tiempo suficiente para que el rayo dentado de luz que entraba por un agujero del techo se desplazara tres centímetros por el suelo mientras me acostumbraba a los sonidos.
vi_translation: I left the office, crawled through a Devil's Hole into the maze-like room of iron shelves. I walked back and forth along the aisle between the rows of shelves for a moment, reached the end of the room, and through the next Devil's Hole into an empty room. I sat down on the rolled-up carpet, leaning against the wall in the corner of the room. The patchy white paint behind me sounded more brittle and cracked. I sat there for a while, long enough for the slanted beam of light from the ceiling to crawl a few inches across the floor, while I gradually adapted to the sounds.
tr_translation: I crawled out of the office through a Dwarf Hole leading to a room with labyrinth-like shelves. I walked back and forth among them for a while. At the end of the room, I crawled through the next Dwarf Hole into an empty room. I sat on the rolled-up carpet in front of the opposite wall. The cracked white paint crackled behind my back. I stayed there for a while; long enough for the beam of light coming through the hole in the ceiling to shift a few centimeters on the floor as I let myself get used to the sounds.
es_translation: I went through a Troll Hole and arrived at the labyrinth of shelves room. I walked through the aisles for a good while. Eventually, I went into the next Troll Hole and crawled to the empty room. I sat on the rolled-up carpet against the back wall. The chipped white paint creaked as I leaned my back against it. I stayed there for a while, long enough for the jagged ray of light coming through a hole in the ceiling to move three centimeters across the floor as I got used to the sounds.

en: After a while, I got bored and crawled through the last Troll Hole into the souvenir shop. I rifled through the T-shirts. I pulled the box of tourist brochures out from under the display case and looked through them, looking for some hand-scrawled message from Margo, but I found nothing.
vi: Một lúc sau, tôi chán, chui qua Lỗ Quỉ cuối cùng vào phòng lưu niệm. Tôi đảo qua đám áo phông. Lôi cái hộp đựng sách lữ hành dưới tủ trưng bày ra và xem một lượt, tìm xem Margo có ngoáy dăm ba chữ vào không, nhưng tôi không thấy gì.
tr: Bir süre sonra sıkılıp son Cüce Deliği’nden emekleyerek hediyelik eşya dükkânına geçtim. Hızlıca tişörtlere baktım. Turist broşürlerinin kutusunu vitrinin altından çekip Margo’dan elle karalanmış bir mesaj arayarak broşürleri inceledim ama hiçbir şey bulamadım.
es: Al rato me aburrí y gateé por el último Agujero de Trol hasta la tienda de souvenirs. Rebusqué entre las camisetas. Saqué la caja de folletos turísticos de la vitrina y los hojeé en busca de algún mensaje escrito a mano de Margo, pero no encontré nada.
vi_translation: After a while, I got bored and crawled through the last Ghost Hole into the souvenir room. I browsed through the T-shirts. I pulled out the travel book box from under the display case and looked through it, searching to see if Margo had scribbled a few words, but I found nothing.
tr_translation: After a while, I got bored and crawled through the last Dwarf Hole to the gift shop. I quickly looked at the t-shirts. I pulled the box of tourist brochures from under the display and examined the brochures, looking for a handwritten message from Margo, but I found nothing.
es_translation: After a while, I got bored and crawled through the last Troll Hole to the souvenir shop. I rummaged through the T-shirts. I took the box of tourist brochures from the display case and leafed through them looking for any handwritten message from Margo, but I found nothing.

en: I returned to the room I now found myself calling the library. I thumbed through the Reader’s Digests and found a stack of National Geographics from the 1960s, but the box was covered in so much dust that I knew Margo had never been inside it.
vi: Tôi quay trở lại căn phòng bây giờ tôi đặt tên là thư viện. Giở qua đống tạp chí Reader’s Digest, tôi thấy một tập mấy tờ National Geographic từ những năm 1960. Nhưng mấy món này bụi chồng bụi chất nên tôi biết Margo chưa từng xem qua.
tr: Kendimi artık kütüphane diye adlandırırken bulduğum odaya geri döndüm. Parmağımla Reader’s Digesfva sayfalarını çevirdim ve 1960’lardan kalma bir National Geographic yığını buldum ama kutu o kadar tozla kaplanmıştı ki Margo’nun kutuya hiç dokunmadığını biliyordum.
es: Volví a la sala que me descubrí a mí mismo llamando la biblioteca. Hojeé los Reader’s Digests y encontré una pila de National Geographics de la década de 1960, pero la caja estaba tan cubierta de polvo que estaba claro que Margo no había sacado su contenido.
vi_translation: I returned to the room I now call the library. Flipping through the pile of Reader’s Digest magazines, I found a stack of National Geographic issues from the 1960s. But these items were covered in layers of dust, so I knew Margo had never looked through them.
tr_translation: I returned to the room I now found myself calling the library. I flipped through the pages of Reader’s Digest with my finger and found a stack of National Geographic from the 1960s, but the box was so covered in dust that I knew Margo had never touched it.
es_translation: I returned to the room that I found myself calling the library. I flipped through the Reader’s Digests and found a stack of National Geographics from the 1960s, but the box was so covered in dust that it was clear Margo hadn't taken out its contents.

en: I began to find evidence of human habitation only when I got back to the empty room. On the wall with the rolled-up carpet, I discovered nine thumbtack holes in the cracked and paint-peeled wall. Four of the holes made an approximate square, and then there were five holes inside the square. I thought perhaps Margo had stayed here long enough to hang up some posters, although there were none obviously missing from her room when we searched it.
vi: Phải đến khi quay lại căn phòng trống, tôi mới thu được bằng chứng cho thấy sinh hoạt của con người. Trên mảng tường gần cuộn thảm, tôi phát hiện ra chín lỗ găm ghim mũ trên nền tường sơn đã tróc và nứt nẻ. Bốn lỗ dựng thành một hình tương đối vuông, và trong hình vuông đó có năm lỗ nữa. Tôi đoán có lẽ Margo đã ở đây từ khá lâu, đủ thời gian để muốn treo tấm áp-phích nào đó lên chẳng hạn, dù chúng tôi không thấy thiếu gì khi tìm trong phòng cô ấy.
tr: Ancak boş odaya geri döndüğümde insan yerleşimine dair delil bulmaya başladım. Sarılmış haknın olduğu, çatlak ve boyası soyulmuş duvarda dokuz tane raptiye dehği keşfettim. Deliklerin dördü kareye yakın bir şekil oluşturuyordu, sonra beş debk de karenin içinde vardı. Margo’nun burada birkaç poster asacak kadar uzun süre kalmış olabileceğini düşündüm ancak aradığımızda odasında belirgin olarak kayıp bir şey yoktu.
es: No empecé a encontrar indicios de que alguien había estado allí hasta que volví a la sala vacía. En la pared desconchada de la moqueta descubrí nueve agujeros de chincheta. Cuatro agujeros formaban una especie de cuadrado, y los otros cinco estaban dentro del cuadrado. Pensé que quizá Margo había pasado allí tiempo suficiente como para colgar algún póster, aunque a primera vista no pareció que faltara ninguno cuando inspeccionamos su habitación.
vi_translation: It wasn't until I returned to the empty room that I found evidence of human activity. On the wall near the rolled-up carpet, I discovered nine pinholes on the cracked and peeling painted surface. Four holes formed a relatively square shape, and within that square, there were five more holes. I guessed that Margo had probably been here for quite a while, long enough to want to hang some kind of poster, although we didn't find anything missing when we searched her room.
tr_translation: However, when I returned to the empty room, I began to find evidence of human habitation. I discovered nine thumbtack holes in the cracked and peeling wall where a poster had been hung. Four of the holes formed a shape close to a square, and then five more were inside the square. I thought that Margo might have stayed here long enough to hang a few posters, but when we searched, there was nothing noticeably missing from her room.
es_translation: I didn't start finding signs that someone had been there until I returned to the empty room. On the chipped wall of the carpet, I discovered nine thumbtack holes. Four holes formed a sort of square, and the other five were inside the square. I thought that maybe Margo had spent enough time there to hang some posters, although at first glance it didn't seem like any were missing when we inspected her room.

en: I unrolled the carpet partway and immediately found something else: a flattened, empty box that had once contained twenty-four nutrition bars. I found myself able to imagine Margo here, leaning against the wall with musty rolled-up carpet for a seat, eating a nutrition bar. She is all alone, with only this to eat. Maybe she drives once a day to a convenience store to buy a sandwich and some Mountain Dew, but most of every day is spent here, on or near this carpet. This image seemed too sad to be true—it all struck me as so lonely and so very unMargo. But all the evidence of the past ten days accumulated toward a surprising conclusion: Margo herself was—at least part of the time—very unMargo.
vi: Tôi trải tấm thảm được nửa chừng thì phát hiện ra còn có thứ khác nữa: một hộp rỗng, gấp phẳng, từng đựng hai mươi tư thanh dinh dưỡng tổng hợp. Tôi bắt đầu tưởng tượng được Margo đã ở đây, dựa lưng vào tường, trên tấm thảm ẩm mốc cuộn lại làm chỗ ngồi, ăn một thanh dinh dưỡng. Cô ấy hoàn toàn một mình, chỉ có thứ này để ăn. Có thể hàng ngày Margo vẫn lái xe đến cửa hàng tiện lợi mua bánh mì kẹp và vài chai Mountain Dew, nhưng hầu hết thời gian trong ngày là ở đây, ở trên hoặc gần tấm thảm. Hình dung đó dường như quá ảm đạm, khó có thể là thật được–tất cả đều dựng nên trong tâm trí tôi một Margo quá cô đơn và quá không-giống-Margo. Nhưng mọi bằng chứng từ mười ngày qua đều tụ đến một kết luận đáng ngạc nhiên: chính Margo–chí ít là cũng có lúc–rất không giống Margo.
tr: Hakyı kısmen açtım ve anmda başka bir şey buldum: bir zamanlar yirmi dört tane gofret içeren düzleşmiş, boş bir kutu. Margo’yu burada, küflü halıyı koltuk olarak kullanıp duvara yaslanırken ve bir gofret yerken hayal edebiliyordum. Yapayalnız ve yiyecek olarak yalnızca bu gofretlerden var. Belki de günde bir defa bir sandviç ile birkaç Mountain Dew almak için bir markete gidiyor ama günlerinin çoğunu burada, bu halının üstünde ya da yanında geçiriyor. Bu hayal gerçek olamayacak kadar içler acısı görünüyordu... bütün bunların çok yalnız ve çok fazla naMargo olduğu dikkatimi çekti. Fakat son on günün bütün delilleri birikince şaşırtıcı bir sonuç ortaya çıkıyordu: Margo’nun kendisi bileen azından bazı zamanlarçok naMargo’ydu.
es: Desenrollé parte de la moqueta e inmediatamente encontré algo más: una caja chafada que en su momento había contenido veinticuatro barritas de cereales. Me descubrí a mí mismo imaginando a Margo allí, sentada en la moqueta enrollada y enmohecida, apoyada contra la pared y comiéndose una barrita de cereales. Está sola y no tiene otra cosa que comer. Quizá una vez al día va en coche a una tienda a comprarse un bocadillo y algún Mountain Dew, pero la mayor parte del día la pasa en esta moqueta o cerca de ella. Me pareció una imagen demasiado triste para ser real. Demasiado solitaria y nada propia de Margo. Pero los indicios de los últimos diez días parecían conducir a una sorprendente conclusión: Margo era —al menos buena parte del tiempo— muy poco propia de Margo.
vi_translation: I had spread the carpet halfway when I discovered something else: an empty, flat-folded box that had once contained twenty-four synthetic nutrition bars. I began to imagine Margo had been here, leaning against the wall, sitting on the musty rolled-up carpet, eating a nutrition bar. She was completely alone, with only this to eat. Maybe every day Margo still drove to the convenience store to buy sandwiches and a few bottles of Mountain Dew, but most of the time she was here, on or near the carpet. That image seemed too bleak to be true–it all conjured up in my mind a Margo who was too lonely and too unlike-Margo. But all the evidence from the past ten days pointed to a surprising conclusion: Margo–at least at times–was very unlike Margo.
tr_translation: I partially opened the drawer and found something else inside: a flattened, empty box that once contained twenty-four wafers. I could imagine Margo here, using the moldy carpet as a seat, leaning against the wall, and eating a wafer. Completely alone, with only these wafers as food. Maybe she goes to a market once a day to get a sandwich and a few Mountain Dews, but she spends most of her days here, on or beside this carpet. This vision seemed too pitiful to be real... it struck me that all of this was very lonely and very unMargo-like. But when all the evidence of the last ten days was accumulated, a surprising result emerged: even Margo herself was, at least sometimes, very unMargo-like.
es_translation: I unrolled part of the carpet and immediately found something else: a crushed box that had once contained twenty-four cereal bars. I found myself imagining Margo there, sitting on the rolled-up and moldy carpet, leaning against the wall and eating a cereal bar. She is alone and has nothing else to eat. Maybe once a day she drives to a store to buy herself a sandwich and some Mountain Dew, but she spends most of the day on this carpet or near it. It seemed too sad an image to be real. Too lonely and not at all like Margo. But the clues from the last ten days seemed to lead to a surprising conclusion: Margo was —at least a good part of the time— very unlike Margo.

en: I rolled out the carpet farther and found a blue knit blanket, almost newspaper thin. I grabbed it and held it to my face and there, God, yes. Her smell. The lilac shampoo and the almond in her skin lotion and beneath all of that the faint sweetness of the skin itself.
vi: Tôi trải nốt tấm thảm ra và thấy một cái chăn len đan màu xanh da trời, mỏng gần như giấy báo. Tôi vội cầm lấy và đưa lên mặt, phải rồi, ơn Chúa, đúng vậy. Mùi của Margo. Dầu gội đầu mùi tử đinh hương và kem dưỡng da mùi hạnh nhân, lẩn quất trong đó thoáng chút ngọt ngào của làn da.
tr: Halıyı daha fazla açtım ve neredeyse kâğıt inceliğinde mavi örgü bir battaniye buldum. Battaniyeyi alıp yüzüme doğru tuttum ve orada, Tanrım, evet... Margo’nun kokusu. Leylaklı şampuan, bademli cilt losyonu ve bütün bunların altında teninin bayıltıcı tatlılığı.
es: Desenrollé un poco más la moqueta y encontré una manta azul de punto, casi tan fina como un periódico. La cogí, me la llevé a la cara y sí, sí. Su olor. El champú de lilas y la loción de almendras, y más allá, la débil suavidad de su piel.
vi_translation: I spread out the rest of the carpet and saw a sky-blue knitted wool blanket, thin almost like newspaper. I hurriedly grabbed it and brought it to my face, yes, thank God, that's right. The scent of Margo. Lilac-scented shampoo and almond-scented lotion, with a faint sweetness of skin lingering within.
tr_translation: I opened the carpet further and found an almost paper-thin blue knitted blanket. I took the blanket and held it up to my face and there, my God, yes... Margo's scent. Lilac shampoo, almond skin lotion, and beneath it all, the intoxicating sweetness of her skin.
es_translation: I unrolled the carpet a bit more and found a blue knitted blanket, almost as thin as a newspaper. I picked it up, brought it to my face and yes, yes. Its smell. The lilac shampoo and almond lotion, and beyond that, the faint softness of her skin.

en: And I could picture her again: she unravels the carpet halfway each night so her hip isn’t against bare concrete as she lies on her side. She crawls beneath the blanket, uses the rest of the carpet as a pillow, and sleeps. But why here? How is this better than home? And if it’s so great, why leave? These are the things I cannot imagine, and I realize that I cannot imagine them because I didn’t know Margo. I knew how she smelled, and I knew how she acted in front of me, and I knew how she acted in front of others, and I knew that she liked Mountain Dew and adventure and dramatic gestures, and I knew that she was funny and smart and just generally more than the rest of us. But I didn’t know what brought her here, or what kept her here, or what made her leave. I didn’t know why she owned thousands of records but never told anyone she even liked music. I didn’t know what she did at night, with the shades down, with the door locked, in the sealed privacy of her room.
vi: Tôi tưởng tượng lại về cô ấy: hàng đêm Margo trải tấm thảm này ra nửa chừng để hông không bị tì lên bê-tông cứng khi cô ấy nằm nghiêng. Cô ấy cuộn mình dưới tấm chăn này, gối lên đoạn thảm không trải ra hết, và nhắm mắt ngủ. Nhưng tại sao lại ở đây? Chỗ này có gì tốt hơn ở nhà? Nếu thích ở đây đến thế, sao còn ra đi? Những điều đó tôi không thể tưởng tượng được, tôi nhận ra mình không thể tưởng tượng vì mình không hiểu Margo. Tôi biết cô ấy thơm như thế nào, tôi biết cô ấy cư xử ra sao trước mặt tôi, tôi biết cô ấy cư xử ra sao trước mặt những người khác, tôi biết cô ấy thích Mountain Dew, thích phiêu lưu và những trò kịch tích, tôi cũng biết cô ấy hài hước, thông minh, nhìn chung là vượt trội những đứa còn lại trong chúng tôi. Nhưng tôi không biết điều gì đã khiến Margo tới đây, điều gì đã khiến cô ấy nán lại đây, điều gì đã khiến cô ấy ra đi. Tôi không biết tại sao cô ấy có hàng ngàn đĩa ghi âm nhưng không bao giờ kể với ai rằng cô ấy thích âm nhạc đến thế nào. Tôi không biết những gì cô ấy làm hàng đêm, sau tấm rèm buông kín đáo, sau cánh cửa khóa, trong không gian riêng tư bất khả xâm phạm là căn phòng của cô ấy.
tr: Ve onu yine gözümde canlandırabiliyordum: Her gece halıyı yarıya kadar açıyor, böylece yan tarafının üstüne yatarken kalçası yalın betona dayanmıyor. Battaniyenin altına emekliyor, balının geri kalanını yastık olarak kullanıyor ve uyuyor. Ama neden burada? Burası evden nasıl daha iyi olabilir? Ve madem o kadar harika, neden terk ediyor? Bunlar tasavvur edemeyeceğim şeyler ve fark ediyorum ki bunları Margo’yu tanımadığım için tasavvur edemiyorum. Nasıl koktuğunu biliyordum, benim önümde nasıl davrandığını biliyordum, başkalarımn önünde nasıl davrandığım biliyordum, Mountain Dew’u, macerayı ve dramatik jestleri sevdiğini biliyordum, eğlenceli, zeki ve geri kalanımızdan genellikle daha fazla olduğunu biliyordum. Ama onu neyin buraya getirdiğini ya da neyin burada tuttuğunu ya da neyin gitmesine sebep olduğunu bilmiyordum. Neden binlerce plağı olduğunu, buna rağmen kimseye müziği sevdiğini bile söylemediğini bilmiyordum. Geceleri, jaluzileri kapalı, kapısı kilitliyken, odasının gizli mahremiyetinde ne yaptığını bilmiyordum.
es: Y volví a imaginármela: desenrolla parte de la moqueta todas las noches para no clavarse la cadera en el hormigón cuando duerme de lado. Se mete debajo de la manta, utiliza el resto de la moqueta como almohada y se duerme. Pero ¿por qué aquí? ¿Por qué está aquí mejor que en su casa? Y si está tan bien, ¿por qué marcharse? Es lo que no conseguía imaginar, y caigo en la cuenta de que no podía imaginármelo porque no conocía a Margo. Conocía su olor, y sabía cómo actuaba conmigo, y sabía cómo actuaba con los demás, y sabía que le gustaba el Mountain Dew, la aventura y los gestos dramáticos, y sabía que era divertida, inteligente y en general superior a todos nosotros. Pero no sabía qué la había llevado allí, o qué la había retenido allí, o qué había hecho que se marchara de allí. No sabía por qué tenía miles de discos, pero nunca había dicho a nadie que le gustaba la música. No sabía qué hacía por las noches, en la oscuridad, con la puerta cerrada, en la sellada privacidad de su habitación.
vi_translation: I imagine her again: every night Margo spreads this rug halfway so that her hip doesn't press against the hard concrete when she lies on her side. She curls up under this blanket, resting her head on the part of the rug that isn't fully spread out, and closes her eyes to sleep. But why here? What is better about this place than home? If she liked it here so much, why did she leave? Those things I can't imagine, I realize I can't imagine because I don't understand Margo. I know how she smells, I know how she behaves in front of me, I know how she behaves in front of others, I know she likes Mountain Dew, likes adventure and dramatic games, I also know she is funny, smart, and generally superior to the rest of us. But I don't know what brought Margo here, what made her stay here, what made her leave. I don't know why she has thousands of records but never tells anyone how much she loves music. I don't know what she does every night, behind the discreetly drawn curtains, behind the locked door, in the inviolable private space that is her room.
tr_translation: And I could picture her again: Every night she would roll the carpet halfway open, so that when she lay on her side, her hip wouldn't rest on the bare concrete. She would crawl under the blanket, her honey uses the rest as a pillow and sleeps. But why is she here? How could this place be better than home? And if it’s so great, why is she leaving? These are things I can’t imagine, and I realize that I can’t imagine them because I don’t know Margo. I knew how she smelled, I knew how she behaved in front of me, I knew how she behaved in front of others, I knew she loved Mountain Dew, adventure, and dramatic gestures, I knew she was fun, smart, and generally more than the rest of us. But I didn’t know what brought her here, or what kept her here, or what made her leave. I didn’t know why she had thousands of records, yet never told anyone she loved music. I didn’t know what she did at night, with the blinds closed, the door locked, in the secret privacy of her room.
es_translation: And I imagined her again: she unrolls part of the carpet every night so she doesn't dig her hip into the concrete when she sleeps on her side. She gets under the blanket, uses the rest of the carpet as a pillow, and falls asleep. But why here? Why is it better here than at her house? And if it's so good, why leave? That's what I couldn't imagine, and I realize that I couldn't imagine it because I didn't know Margo. I knew her smell, and I knew how she acted with me, and I knew how she acted with others, and I knew she liked Mountain Dew, adventure, and dramatic gestures, and I knew she was funny, smart, and generally superior to all of us. But I didn't know what had brought her there, or what had kept her there, or what had made her leave there. I didn't know why she had thousands of records, but had never told anyone she liked music. I didn't know what she did at night, in the dark, with the door closed, in the sealed privacy of her room.

en: And maybe this was what I needed to do above all. I needed to discover what Margo was like when she wasn’t being Margo.
vi: Và có lẽ hơn hết đây chính là điều tôi cần làm. Tôi cần khám phá xem Margo ra sao khi cô ấy không phải là Margo.
tr: Ve belki de bu, her şeyden önce yapmam gereken şeydi. Margo’ nun, Margo olmazken neye benzediğini keşfetmem gerekiyordu.
es: Y quizá era lo que necesitaba más que nada. Necesitaba descubrir cómo era Margo cuando no estaba siendo Margo.
vi_translation: And perhaps more than anything, this is what I need to do. I need to find out what Margo is like when she is not being Margo.
tr_translation: And maybe this was what I needed to do before anything else. I needed to discover what Margo looked like when she wasn't being Margo.
es_translation: And maybe it was what I needed more than anything. I needed to discover what Margo was like when she wasn't being Margo.

en: I lay there with the her-scented blanket for a while, staring up at the ceiling. I could see a sliver of late-afternoon sky through a crack in the roof, like a jagged canvas painted a bright blue. This would be the perfect place to sleep: one could see stars at night without getting rained on.
vi: Tôi nằm đó một lúc trong tấm chăn mang mùi Margo, chong chong nhìn lên trần. Vạt trời chiều chạng vạng buông qua vết nứt trên mái, như tấm toan tước ra một dải xanh nhạt. Đây hẳn là nơi hoàn hảo để chìm vào giấc ngủ: đêm được ngắm sao trời mà không sợ ướt mưa.
tr: Bir süre orada, onun gibi kokan battaniyeyle birlikte, tavana bakarak uzandım. Çatıdaki bir çatlaktan, ikindi vakti gökyüzünden ince bir parça görebiliyordum, parlak maviye boyanmış pürüzlü bir tuval gibiydi. Burası uyumak için kusursuz bir yer olurdu: İnsan, geceleri üstüne yağmur yağmadan yıldızları görebilirdi.
es: Me tumbé un rato con la manta que olía a ella y miré el techo. Por un agujero veía un trocito del cielo de la tarde, como un lienzo dentado pintado de azul. Era el sitio perfecto para dormir. Podían verse las estrellas por la noche sin mojarte si llovía.
vi_translation: I lay there for a while in the blanket that smelled of Margo, staring up at the ceiling. The twilight sky filtered through the crack in the roof, like a canvas torn to reveal a pale blue strip. This must be the perfect place to fall asleep: at night, you can watch the stars without fearing the rain.
tr_translation: I lay there for a while, staring at the ceiling with a blanket that smelled like him. Through a crack in the roof, I could see a thin piece of the sky in the afternoon, like a rough canvas painted bright blue. This would be a perfect place to sleep: One could see the stars at night without getting rained on.
es_translation: I lay down for a while with the blanket that smelled like her and looked at the ceiling. Through a hole, I could see a small piece of the afternoon sky, like a jagged canvas painted blue. It was the perfect place to sleep. You could see the stars at night without getting wet if it rained.

en: I called my parents to check in. My dad answered, and I said we were in the car on the way to meet Radar and Angela, and that I was staying with Ben overnight. He told me not to drink, and I told him I wouldn’t, and he said he was proud of me for going to prom, and I wondered if he would be proud of me for doing what I was actually doing.
vi: Tôi gọi điện về nhà để báo an. Bố nghe máy, tôi nói chúng tôi đang trong xe, trên đường đến chỗ Radar và Angela, và tôi sẽ ở lại với Ben cả đêm. Bố dặn tôi đừng uống tạp nham, tôi đáp tôi sẽ không như vậy, và bố bảo bố rất vui vì tôi đã đi dạ tiệc. Còn tôi tự hỏi không biết bố có vui nếu thực sự biết những gì tôi đang làm hay không.
tr: Haber vermek için annemle babamı aradım. Babam cevap verdi, Radar ve Angela’yla buluşmak için arabayla yolda olduğumuzu ve gece Ben’de kalacağımı söyledim. İçki içmememi söyledi, ben de ona içmeyeceğim dedim, baloya gittiğim için benimle gurur duyduğunu söyledi, ben gerçekte yaptığım şey için benimle gurur duyup duymayacağını merak ettim.
es: Llamé a mis padres. Contestó mi padre y le dije que estábamos en el coche, que íbamos a buscar a Radar y a Angela, y que me quedaría con Ben toda la noche. Me pidió que no bebiera, le dije que no bebería, me dijo que estaba orgulloso de mí por haber decidido ir al baile de graduación y me pregunté si lo estaría por haber decidido hacer lo que en realidad estaba haciendo.
vi_translation: I called home to report my safety. Dad answered the phone, I said we were in the car, on the way to Radar and Angela's place, and I would stay with Ben all night. Dad told me not to drink recklessly, I replied I wouldn't, and he said he was very happy that I went to the prom. And I wondered if he would still be happy if he really knew what I was doing.
tr_translation: I called my mom and dad to inform them. My dad answered, I told him that we were on the road with Radar and Angela and that I would stay at Ben's place for the night. He told me not to drink, and I told him I wouldn't, he said he was proud of me for going to the prom, and I wondered if he would be proud of me for what I was actually doing.
es_translation: I called my parents. My father answered, and I told him that we were in the car, that we were going to pick up Radar and Angela, and that I would stay with Ben all night. He asked me not to drink, I told him I wouldn't, he said he was proud of me for deciding to go to the prom, and I wondered if he would be proud of me for deciding to do what I was actually doing.

en: This place was boring. I mean, once you got past the rodents and the mysterious the-building-is-falling-apart groans in the walls, there wasn’t anything to do. No Internet, no TV, no music. I was bored, so it again confused me that she would pick this place, since Margo always struck me as a person with a very limited tolerance for boredom. Maybe she liked the idea of slumming it? Unlikely. Margo wore designer jeans to break into SeaWorld.
vi: Nơi này chán ngắt. Một khi đã trên cơ bè lũ gặm nhấm và bắt bài những rên rỉ bí ẩn tòa-nhà-sập-đến-nơi-rồi vẳng ra từ những bức tường, thì chẳng còn gì để làm nữa. Không Internet, không ti-vi, không nhạc nhẽo. Tôi thấy chán, thế nên tôi càng không hiểu tại sao Margo lại chọn nơi này, cô ấy luôn để lại ấn tượng rằng mình dành rất ít khoan dung cho những nhàm chán. Hay cô ấy thích cảnh điêu tàn xập xệ này chăng? Có lí nào. Với cô Margo diện quần jeans điệu đột nhập vào SeaWorld đó.
tr: Burası sıkıcıydı. Yani kemirgenleri ve gizemli “bina parçalanıyor” sızlanmalarını bir kez atlatınca, yapacak hiçbir şey yoktu. İnternet yoktu, televizyon yoktu, müzik yoktu. Sıkılıyordum, bu yüzden onun burayı seçmiş olması tekrar kafamı karıştırdı; çünkü Margo her zaman can sıkıntısına karşı sınırlı toleransı olan bir insan olarak dikkatimi çekmişti. Bir harabede yaşama fikrini mi sevmişti? Pek mümkün değildi. Margo SeaWorld’e izinsiz girerken tasarımcı markalı bir kot pantolon giyiyordu.
es: El sitio era un aburrimiento. Quiero decir que en cuanto pasabas de los roedores y del misterioso crujido de las paredes, como si fuera a caerse el edificio, no había nada que hacer. Ni internet, ni tele, ni música. Me aburría, así que seguía despistándome el hecho de que hubiera elegido ese lugar, porque Margo siempre me había parecido una persona con una tolerancia muy limitada al aburrimiento. Quizá le gustaba la idea de vivir en plan pobre. Lo dudo. Margo llevaba vaqueros de marca cuando nos colamos en el SeaWorld.
vi_translation: This place is boring. Once you've gotten the upper hand over the gang of rodents and deciphered the mysterious groans of the building-about-to-collapse echoing from the walls, there's nothing left to do. No Internet, no TV, no music. I'm bored, so I don't understand why Margo chose this place; she always gave the impression that she had very little tolerance for boredom. Or does she like this dilapidated scene? Could it be. With that Margo who wore stylish jeans to break into SeaWorld.
tr_translation: This place was boring. I mean, once you got past the rodents and the mysterious "building is falling apart" creaks, there was nothing to do. No internet, no television, no music. I was bored, so the fact that he had chosen this place puzzled me again; because Margo had always caught my attention as a person with limited tolerance for boredom. Did she like the idea of living in a ruin? It was quite unlikely. Margo was wearing designer jeans while sneaking into SeaWorld.
es_translation: The place was a bore. I mean that once you got past the rodents and the mysterious creaking of the walls, as if the building was about to collapse, there was nothing to do. No internet, no TV, no music. I was bored, so it kept puzzling me that she had chosen that place, because Margo had always seemed to me like someone with a very limited tolerance for boredom. Maybe she liked the idea of living like a poor person. I doubt it. Margo wore brand-name jeans when we snuck into SeaWorld.

en: It was the lack of alternative stimuli that led me back to “Song of Myself,” the only certain gift I had from her. I moved to a water-stained patch of concrete floor directly beneath the hole in the ceiling, sat down cross-legged, and angled my body so the light shone upon the book. And for some reason, finally, I could read it.
vi: Chính tình cảnh thiếu những kích thích thay thế đã khiến tôi quay lại với “Tự khúc,” món quà chắc chắn duy nhất tôi nhận từ Margo. Tôi đến khoảng sàn nhà loang lổ vết nước đã khô róc từ lâu, thẳng dưới lỗ hổng trên trần, ngồi xếp chéo chân, nghiêng người để ánh sáng soi xuống trang sách. Rút cục, không hiểu sao, tôi đã đọc trôi được nó.
tr: Beni Kendi Şarkım’a, ondan aldığım tek hediyeye geri döndüren alternatif bir uyarıcının eksikliğiydi. Tavandaki deliğin tam altında, beton zeminin su lekeli bir parçasına geçtim, bağdaş kurup oturdum ve ışık kitabı aydınlatsın diye vücudumun açısını ayarladım. Ve nedense, sonunda şiiri okuyabildim.
es: La ausencia de estímulos alternativos me llevó de nuevo al «Canto de mí mismo», el único regalo que sin duda había dejado para mí. Me trasladé a una zona del suelo de cemento que tenía manchas de agua, exactamente debajo del agujero del techo, me senté con las piernas cruzadas e incliné el libro para que el rayo de luz le cayera justo encima. Y por alguna razón pude por fin leerlo.
vi_translation: It was the lack of alternative stimuli that brought me back to "Self-Elegy," the only certain gift I received from Margo. I went to the floor, stained with long-dried water marks, directly under the hole in the ceiling, sat cross-legged, and leaned to let the light shine down on the page. In the end, somehow, I managed to read through it.
tr_translation: It was the lack of an alternative stimulus that brought me back to My Own Song, the only gift I received from it. I moved to a water-stained part of the concrete floor, directly under the hole in the ceiling, sat cross-legged, and adjusted my body angle so that the light would illuminate the book. And somehow, I was finally able to read the poem.
es_translation: The absence of alternative stimuli led me back to "Song of Myself," the only gift that had undoubtedly been left for me. I moved to a spot on the cement floor that had water stains, directly under the hole in the roof, sat cross-legged, and tilted the book so that the ray of light fell directly on it. And for some reason, I was finally able to read it.

en: The thing is that the poem starts out really slowly—it’s just sort of a long introduction, but around the ninetieth line, Whitman finally starts to tell a bit of a story, and that’s where it picked up for me. So Whitman is sitting around (which he calls loafing) on the grass, and then:
vi: Vấn đề ở chỗ bài thơ mở đầu cực kì chậm chạp–khúc vào đề kéo dài lê thê, tới đâu tận dòng thứ chín, rút cục Whitman mới chịu hé ra câu chuyện, và đó là chỗ tôi bắt đầu thấy vỡ vạc ra. Vậy là Whitman đang ngồi suông (mà ông gọi là an nhiên) trên cỏ, thì:
tr: Mesele şu ki, şiir çok yavaş başlıyor... Bir tür uzun giriş bölümü var fakat doksanıncı dize civarında Whitman, sonunda birazcık da olsa hikâye anlatmaya başlıyor ve burası benim için şiirin hızlandığı yer. Sonuçta Whitman çimenlerin üstünde boş boş oturuyor (ki kendisi bunu aylaklık etmek olarak adlandırıyor) ve sonra:
es: El caso es que el poema empieza muy lento, con una especie de larga introducción, pero hacia el verso noventa Whitman empieza por fin a contar una historia, así que empecé por ahí. Whitman está sentado en la hierba (él dice tendido), y entonces:
vi_translation: The problem is that the poem starts extremely slowly—the introduction drags on and on, and it isn't until the ninth line that Whitman finally begins to reveal the story, and that's where I started to understand. So Whitman is sitting idly (which he calls being at ease) on the grass, then:
tr_translation: The thing is, the poem starts very slowly... There is a kind of long introduction, but around the ninetieth line, Whitman finally starts telling a bit of a story, and this is where the poem picks up pace for me. In the end, Whitman is sitting idly on the grass (which he calls loafing) and then:
es_translation: The thing is that the poem starts very slowly, with a sort of long introduction, but around verse ninety Whitman finally begins to tell a story, so I started from there. Whitman is sitting on the grass (he says lying down), and then:

en: A child said, What is the grass? fetching it to me with full
vi: Một đứa trẻ lên tiếng, Cỏ là gì ạ? và mang đến cho ta một nắm đầy tay;
tr: Bir çocuk dedi ki, Çimen nedir? ellerine doldurup getirerek bana;
es: Un niño me preguntó: ¿Qué es la hierba?, trayéndola a manos llenas,
vi_translation: A child spoke up, What is grass? and brought us a handful;
tr_translation: A child said, What is grass? bringing it to me in his hands;
es_translation: A child asked me: What is grass?, bringing it in handfuls,

en: How could I answer the child? . . . . . . I do not know what
vi: Biết trả lời cháu bé sao đây?... Ta không biết rộng hơn những gì cậu bé biết.
tr: Nasıl cevap verebilirdim çocuğa? Ne olduğunu bilmiyorum
es: ¿Cómo podría contestarle? Yo tampoco lo sé.
vi_translation: How should I answer the child?... I don't know much more than what the child knows.
tr_translation: How could I answer the child? I don't know what it is
es_translation: How could I answer him? I don't know either.

en: it is any more than he.
vi: Ta không biết rộng hơn những gì cậu bé biết.
tr: ondan daha fazla.
es: Yo tampoco lo sé.
vi_translation: I don't know much more than what the child knows.
tr_translation: more than him/her/it.
es_translation: I don't know either.

en: I guess it must be the flag of my disposition, out of hopeful
vi: Có lẽ đó hẳn là ngọn cờ thiên lương của ta, dệt bằng màu xanh hi vọng.
tr: Sanırım, yaratılışımın işareti olmalı, umut verici yeşilliğin örgüsünden çıkan dışarı.
es: Sospecho que es la bandera de mi carácter tejida con esperanzada tela verde.
vi_translation: Perhaps that is surely our flag of virtue, woven with the color of hope.
tr_translation: I suppose it must be a sign of my creation, emerging from the weave of promising greenery.
es_translation: I suspect that it is the flag of my character woven with hopeful green fabric.

en: There was the hope Dr. Holden had talked about—the grass was a metaphor for his hope. But that’s not all. He continues,
vi: Đây là hi vọng mà cô Holden đã nhắc đến–cỏ là ẩn dụ của hi vọng. Nhưng không chỉ có thế, nhà thơ tiếp:
tr: dr Holden’m bahsettiği umut işte buydu... Çimen Whitman’m umudu için bir metafordu. Ama hepsi bu değil. Şöyle devam ediyor:
es: Ahí estaba la esperanza de la que me había hablado la doctora Holden. La hierba era una metáfora de la esperanza. Pero eso no es todo. Sigue diciendo:
vi_translation: This is the hope that Ms. Holden mentioned–grass is a metaphor for hope. But that's not all, the poet continues:
tr_translation: This was the hope that Dr. Holden talked about... The grass was a metaphor for Whitman's hope. But that's not all. It continues as follows:
es_translation: There was the hope that Dr. Holden had told me about. The grass was a metaphor for hope. But that's not all. It goes on to say:

en: Or I guess it is the handkerchief of the Lord,
vi: Hay có lẽ đó là tấm khăn tay của Người,
tr: Ya da sanırım o Tanrının mendili,
es: O el pañuelo de Dios,
vi_translation: Or perhaps that is the handkerchief of the Person,
tr_translation: Or maybe I think it's God's handkerchief,
es_translation: Or the handkerchief of God,

en: A scented gift and remembrancer designedly dropped,
vi: Món quà mang hương thơm, kỉ vật Người ban xuống.
tr: Kokulu bir hediye ve kasıtlı olarak düşürülen bir yadigâr,
es: una prenda fragante dejada caer a propósito,
vi_translation: The gift carries a fragrance, a keepsake bestowed by Him.
tr_translation: A fragrant gift and a deliberately dropped keepsake,
es_translation: a fragrant garment deliberately dropped,

en: Like grass is a metaphor for God’s greatness or something. . . .
vi: Kiểu như cỏ là ẩn dụ cho sự vĩ đại của Chúa Trời, và còn nữa... Hay có lẽ cỏ chính là trẻ thơ...
tr: Sanki çimen Tann’mn yüceliği gibi bir şey için bir metafor gibi...
es: La hierba es una metáfora de la grandeza de Dios, o algo así.
vi_translation: It's like grass is a metaphor for the greatness of God, and there's more... Or perhaps grass is just like children...
tr_translation: As if the grass is a metaphor for something like the grandeur of God...
es_translation: The grass is a metaphor for the greatness of God, or something like that.

en: Or I guess the grass is itself a child . . . .
vi: Hay có lẽ cỏ chính là trẻ thơ...
tr: Ya da sanırım çimenin kendisi bir çocuk...
es: O sospecho que la hierba misma es un niño…
vi_translation: Or perhaps grass is just like children...
tr_translation: Or maybe I think the grass itself is a child...
es_translation: Or I suspect that the grass itself is a child...

en: And then soon after that,
vi: Và ngay sau đó,
tr: Ve bundan biraz sonra,
es: Y algo después:
vi_translation: And right after that,
tr_translation: And a little after this,
es_translation: And something later:

en: Or I guess it is a uniform hieroglyphic,
vi: Hay có lẽ cỏ là tượng hình đồng nhất,
tr: Ya da sanırım o yeknesak bir hiyeroglif,
es: O un jeroglífico uniforme,
vi_translation: Or perhaps grass is a uniform pictogram,
tr_translation: Or perhaps I think it is a monotonous hieroglyph,
es_translation: A uniform hieroglyph,

en: And it means, Sprouting alike in broad zones and narrow
vi: Vươn lên giữa đại ngàn và từ góc hữu hạn,
tr: Ve bunun anlamı, Fark gözetmeden geniş alanlarda ve dar alanlarda filizlenmek,
es: que significa: crezco por igual en las regiones vastas y en las estrechas,
vi_translation: Rising up amidst the vast forest and from a limited corner,
tr_translation: And this means to sprout in wide areas and narrow areas without discrimination,
es_translation: what it means: I grow equally in the vast regions and in the narrow ones,

en: Growing among black folks as among white.
vi: Xanh mọc giữa những bằng hữu đen cũng như những người bạn trắng.
tr: Beyaz halkların arasında olduğu gibi siyah halkların içinde de büyümek.
es: crezco por igual entre los negros y los blancos.
vi_translation: Green grows among black friends as well as white friends.
tr_translation: Growing up among white people as well as within black communities.
es_translation: I grow equally among blacks and whites.

en: So maybe the grass is a metaphor for our equality and our essential connectedness, as Dr. Holden had said. And then finally, he says of grass,
vi: Vậy có lẽ cỏ là ẩn dụ cho sự bình đẳng và liên hệ mật thiết giữa chúng ta, như cô Holden đã nói. Và những lời cuối của Whitman về cỏ:
tr: Yani belki de çimen bizim eşitliğimiz ve temeldeki bağlanmışlığımız için bir metafor, tıpkı dr Holden’m dediği gibi. Ve sonra sonunda, çimen için şöyle diyor:
es: Así que quizá la hierba es una metáfora de que somos iguales y estamos básicamente conectados, como me había dicho la doctora Holden. Y luego dice de la hierba:
vi_translation: So perhaps grass is a metaphor for equality and the close connection between us, as Ms. Holden mentioned. And Whitman's final words about grass:
tr_translation: So maybe grass is a metaphor for our equality and fundamental interconnectedness, just as Dr. Holden said. And then finally, he says this about the grass:
es_translation: So maybe the grass is a metaphor that we are equal and basically connected, as Dr. Holden had told me. And then it says about the grass:

en: And now it seems to me the beautiful uncut hair of graves.
vi: Và giờ với ta, cỏ là làn tóc mộ chí buông không buồn cắt.
tr: Ve şimdi bana mezarların kesilmemiş güzel saçları gibi görünüyor.
es: Y ahora se me figura que es la cabellera suelta y hermosa de las tumbas.
vi_translation: And now to me, the grass is the hair of the grave, hanging loose without the sorrow of cutting.
tr_translation: And now it seems to me like the uncut beautiful hair of graves.
es_translation: And now it seems to me that it is the loose and beautiful hair of the tombs.

en: So grass is death, too—it grows out of our buried bodies. The grass was so many different things at once, it was bewildering. So grass is a metaphor for life, and for death, and for equality, and for connectedness, and for children, and for God, and for hope.
vi: Như vậy cỏ cũng là cái chết–mọc lên từ những thân xác đã chôn vùi. Có quá nhiều lớp lang ý nghĩa trong hình ảnh cỏ, thật đúng là rối mòng mòng. Tóm lại cỏ là ẩn dụ chỉ sự sống, cái chết, sự bình đẳng, mối liên kết, ám chỉ cả trẻ thơ, Chúa Trời và hi vọng.
tr: Yani çimen aynı zamanda ölüm... gömülmüş bedenlerimizden dışarı çıkarak büyüyor. Çimen aynı anda o kadar farklı şeyleri ifade ediyordu ki hayret vericiydi. Yani çimen yaşam için, ölüm için, eşitlik için, bağlanmışlık için, çocuklar için, Tanrı için ve umut için bir metafordu.
es: Así que la hierba es también la muerte. Crece encima de nuestros cuerpos enterrados. La hierba era muchas cosas diferentes a la vez. Era desconcertante. La hierba es una metáfora de la vida, y de la muerte, y de la igualdad, y de que estamos conectados, y de los niños, y de Dios, y de la esperanza.
vi_translation: Thus, grass is also death–growing from the buried bodies. There are too many layers of meaning in the image of grass; it truly is a tangled mess. In summary, grass is a metaphor for life, death, equality, connection, and it alludes to children, God, and hope.
tr_translation: So, grass at the same time is death... growing out from our buried bodies. Grass simultaneously expressed so many different things that it was astonishing. So, grass was a metaphor for life, for death, for equality, for connectedness, for children, for God, and for hope.
es_translation: So the grass is also death. It grows above our buried bodies. The grass was many different things at once. It was bewildering. The grass is a metaphor for life, and for death, and for equality, and for our interconnectedness, and for children, and for God, and for hope.

en: I couldn’t figure out which of these ideas, if any, was at the core of the poem. But thinking about the grass and all the different ways you can see it made me think about all the ways I’d seen and mis-seen Margo. There was no shortage of ways to see her. I’d been focused on what had become of her, but now with my head trying to understand the multiplicity of grass and her smell from the blanket still in my throat, I realized that the most important question was who I was looking for. If “What is the grass?” has such a complicated answer, I thought, so, too, must “Who is Margo Roth Spiegelman?” Like a metaphor rendered incomprehensible by its ubiquity, there was room enough in what she had left me for endless imaginings, for an infinite set of Margos.
vi: Tôi chưa luận ra được điều gì trong những hình ảnh trên, nếu có, là cốt lõi của bài thơ này. Nhưng nghĩ đến cỏ và những cách nhìn nhận khác nhau về nó khiến tôi nghĩ đến tất cả những cách tôi đã nhìn và nhìn-nhầm Margo. Chẳng thiếu cách để nhìn cô ấy. Tôi đã quá tập trung vào những gì trở thành cô ấy, nhưng bây giờ, khi cố gắng hiểu tính đa biểu hiện của cỏ, khi mùi Margo từ tấm chăn vẫn còn vương vít trong cổ họng tôi, tôi nhận ra rằng câu hỏi quan trọng nhất chính là: tôi đang muốn tìm ai. Nếu “Cỏ là gì?” cần câu trả lời phức tạp đến vậy, thì điều tương tự ắt cũng đúng với câu “Margo Roth Spiegelman là ai?” Như một ẩn dụ không thể tức khắc được truyền tải trọn vẹn bởi những tầng đa nghĩa đồng hiện của nó, trong những gì Margo để lại cho tôi, có đủ chỗ cho những tưởng tượng bất tận, cho một chuỗi không giới hạn những Margo khác nhau.
tr: Bu fikirlerden hangisinin, eğer herhangi biriyse, şiirin özü olduğunu anlayamamıştım. Ama çimeni ve onu anlayabilmenin tüm o farklı yollarını düşünmek bana Margo’yu anladığım ve yanlış anladığım bütün yolları düşündürttü. Onu görebilmek için yol eksikliği yoktu. Onun başına gelenler üzerine odaklanmıştım ama şimdi çimenin çeşitliliğini anlamaya çalışan aklımla ve hâlâ burnumda olan battaniyedeki kokusuyla kimi aradığımın en önemli soru olduğunu fark ediyordum. Eğer “Çimen nedir?” sorusunun böylesine karmaşık bir cevabı varsa, “Margo Roth Spiegelman kim?” sorusunun da öyle olduğunu düşündüm. Her yerde bulunduğu için anlaşılmaz hale gelen bir metafor gibi, onun bana bıraktıklarında, sonsuz hayaller ve sınırsız bir Margo’lar grubu için yeterince yer vardı.
es: No lograba descubrir cuál de estas ideas era el meollo del poema, suponiendo que alguna lo fuera. Pero pensar en la hierba y en las diferentes maneras de verla me hizo pensar en todas las maneras en que había visto y mal visto a Margo. Las maneras de verla no eran pocas. Me había centrado en lo que había sido de ella, pero allí, intentando entender la multiplicidad de la hierba y con el olor de la manta todavía en la garganta, me daba cuenta de que la pregunta más importante era a quién estaba buscando. Pensé que si resultaba tan complicado responder a la pregunta «¿Qué es la hierba?», también debía de ser complicado responder a la pregunta «¿Quién es Margo Roth Spiegelman?». Como una metáfora inasible por su amplitud, en lo que me había dejado había lugar para imaginar infinitamente, para una serie infinita de Margos.
vi_translation: I have yet to figure out what, if anything, in these images is the essence of this poem. But thinking about grass and the different ways of perceiving it makes me think of all the ways I have seen and mis-seen Margo. There is no shortage of ways to look at her. I was too focused on what she became, but now, as I try to understand the multifaceted nature of grass, with Margo's scent still lingering in my throat from the blanket, I realize that the most important question is: who am I trying to find. If "What is grass?" requires such a complex answer, then the same must be true for the question "Who is Margo Roth Spiegelman?" Like a metaphor that cannot be instantly conveyed in its entirety by its simultaneous layers of meaning, in what Margo left for me, there is enough room for endless imaginations, for an unlimited series of different Margos.
tr_translation: I couldn't understand which of these ideas, if any, was the essence of the poem. But thinking about the grass and all the different ways to understand it made me think about all the ways I understood and misunderstood Margo. There was no lack of ways to see her. I had focused on what had happened to her, but now, with my mind trying to understand the variety of the grass and the scent of the blanket still in my nose, I realized that the most important question was whom I was searching for. If the question "What is grass?" has such a complex answer, I thought that the question "Who is Margo Roth Spiegelman?" must be the same. Like a metaphor that becomes incomprehensible because it is everywhere, in what she left for me, there was enough room for endless dreams and an unlimited group of Margos.
es_translation: I couldn't figure out which of these ideas was the crux of the poem, assuming any of them were. But thinking about the grass and the different ways of seeing it made me think about all the ways I had seen and misseen Margo. The ways of seeing her were not few. I had focused on what had become of her, but there, trying to understand the multiplicity of the grass and with the smell of the blanket still in my throat, I realized that the more important question was who I was looking for. I thought that if it was so complicated to answer the question "What is the grass?", it must also be complicated to answer the question "Who is Margo Roth Spiegelman?". Like a metaphor elusive in its breadth, in what she had left me, there was room to imagine infinitely, for an infinite series of Margos.

en: I had to narrow her down, and I figured there had to be things here that I was seeing wrong or not seeing. I wanted to tear off the roof and light up the whole place so that I could see it all at once, instead of one flashlight beam at a time. I put aside Margo’s blanket and shouted, loud enough for all the rats to hear, “I Am Going To Find Something Here!”
vi: Tôi phải thu hẹp cô ấy lại, và tôi hiểu ra rằng ở nơi này, ắt có những điều tôi đã nhìn sai đi hoặc không nhìn thấy. Tôi những muốn xé toang trần mái phía trên, rọi sáng mọi ngóc ngách để đồng thời thấy được tất cả, chứ không phải chỉ nhìn theo ánh đèn pin rời rạc quét qua quét lại. Tôi đặt tấm chăn của Margo sang một bên và hét lên, đủ lớn để tất cả bè lũ gặm nhấm phải nghe thấy, “Tôi Sẽ Tìm Ra Điều Gì Đó Ở Nơi Này!”
tr: Margo’yu daraltmak zorundaydım ve burada yanlış anladığım ya da anlamadığım şeyler olması gerektiğini düşünüyordum. Çatıyı tutup koparmak ve bir seferde tek fener ışığı yerine, her yeri aynı anda görebileyim diye bütün bu yeri aydınlatmak istedim. Margo’nun battaniyesini bir kenara koyup tüm farelerin duyacağı kadar yüksek sesle, “Burada Bir Şeyler Bulacağım!” diye bağırdım.
es: Tuve que acotarla, y supuse que tenía que haber cosas que estaba viendo mal o que no estaba viendo. Quería arrancar el techo para que entrara la luz y verlo todo a la vez, no cada cosa por separado con la linterna. Aparté la manta de Margo y grité lo bastante alto para que me oyeran las ratas: —¿Voy a encontrar algo aquí?
vi_translation: I have to narrow her down, and I realize that in this place, there must be things I have seen incorrectly or not seen at all. I want to tear open the roof above, illuminating every corner to see everything at once, rather than just following the scattered flashlight beams sweeping back and forth. I set Margo's blanket aside and shouted, loud enough for all the gnawing creatures to hear, "I Will Find Something In This Place!"
tr_translation: I had to narrow Margo down and I thought there must be things here that I misunderstood or didn't understand. I wanted to hold and tear off the roof and light up this whole place so I could see everything at once instead of just one lantern light at a time. Putting Margo's blanket aside, I shouted loud enough for all the mice to hear, "I Will Find Something Here!"
es_translation: I had to narrow it down, and I assumed that there had to be things I was seeing wrong or not seeing at all. I wanted to tear off the roof so that the light could come in and I could see everything at once, not each thing separately with the flashlight. I pulled Margo's blanket aside and shouted loud enough for the rats to hear me: —Am I going to find something here?

en: I went through each desk in the office again, but it seemed more and more obvious that Margo had used only the desk with the nail polish in the drawer and the calendar set to June.
vi: Tôi dò lại từng bàn làm việc trong văn phòng, càng tìm càng thấy rõ rằng Margo chỉ dùng cái bàn có lọ sơn móng tay trong ngăn kéo và tờ lịch dừng ở tháng Sáu.
tr: Ofisteki her masaja tekrar gözden geçirdim fakat Margo’nun, yalnızca çekmecesinde oje olan ve takvimi hazirana ayarlanmış masayı kullandığı gittikçe daha aşikâr görünüyordu.
es: Volví a las mesas del despacho, pero cada vez parecía más obvio que Margo solo había utilizado la del cajón con el pintaúñas y el calendario en el mes de junio.
vi_translation: I checked each desk in the office, and the more I searched, the clearer it became that Margo only used the desk with the nail polish bottle in the drawer and the calendar stopped at June.
tr_translation: I reviewed every desk in the office again, but it was becoming increasingly apparent that Margo only used the desk with nail polish in the drawer and the calendar set to June.
es_translation: I returned to the desks in the office, but it seemed increasingly obvious that Margo had only used the one with the nail polish and the calendar set to the month of June.

en: I ducked through a Troll Hole and made my way back to the library, walking again through the abandoned metal shelves. On each shelf I looked for dustless shapes that would tell me Margo had used this space for something, but I couldn’t find any. But then my darting flashlight happened across something atop the shelf in a corner of the room, right near the boarded-up storefront window. It was the spine of a book.
vi: Tôi chui qua Lỗ Quỉ, quay lại thư viện, một lần nữa đi dọc các giá sắt bỏ không. Trên mỗi giá tôi căng mắt tìm xem có chỗ nào không dính bụi, chứng tỏ Margo đã dùng vào việc gì không, nhưng tôi không thấy gì. Rồi đèn pin của tôi tình cờ lướt qua thứ gì đó trên nóc một giá ở góc phòng, ngay gần cửa sổ mặt tiền được chắn bằng gỗ ép. Đó là gáy một cuốn sách.
tr: Bir Cüce Deliği’nden çömelerek geçtim ve terk edilmiş rafların arasında tekrar jdirüyerek geri dönüp kütüphanede ilerledim. Her rafta bana Margo’nun o alanı bir şey için kullandığını gösteren tozsuz şekiller aradım ama hiçbir şey bulamadım. Fakat sonra süratle hareket eden fenerim, mağazanın tahta çakılmış ön penceresinin hemen yarımda, odanın bir köşesindeki rafın tepesinde bir şeye rastladı. Bu bir kitabın sırtıydı.
es: Gateé por un Agujero de Trol, volví a la biblioteca y recorrí de nuevo las estanterías metálicas abandonadas. Busqué en todos los estantes marcas sin polvo que indicaran que Margo los había utilizado para algo, pero no encontré ninguno. Pero de repente el foco de la linterna pasó por algo que estaba en un estante de una esquina de la sala, justo al lado del escaparate con la plancha de conglomerado. Era el lomo de un libro.
vi_translation: I crawled through the Devil's Hole, returned to the library, and once again walked along the empty iron shelves. On each shelf, I strained my eyes to see if there was any spot not covered in dust, indicating that Margo had used it for something, but I saw nothing. Then my flashlight happened to sweep over something on top of a shelf in the corner of the room, right near the front window blocked by plywood. It was the spine of a book.
tr_translation: I crouched through a Dwarf Hole and walked back through the abandoned shelves, then proceeded in the library. I looked for dust-free shapes on each shelf that would show me Margo had used that area for something, but I found nothing. But then, my swiftly moving flashlight caught something at the top of a shelf in a corner of the room, just to the side of the store's boarded-up front window. It was the spine of a book.
es_translation: I crawled through a Troll Hole, returned to the library, and once again wandered through the abandoned metal shelves. I searched all the shelves for dust-free marks that would indicate Margo had used them for something, but I found none. But suddenly, the flashlight beam passed over something on a shelf in a corner of the room, right next to the display case with the particle board. It was the spine of a book.

en: The book was called Roadside America: Your Travel Guide, and had been published in 1998, after this place had been abandoned. I flipped through it with the flashlight crooked between neck and shoulder. The book listed hundreds of attractions you could visit, from the world’s largest ball of twine in Darwin, Minnesota, to the world’s largest ball of stamps in Omaha, Nebraska. Someone had folded down the corners of several seemingly random pages. The book wasn’t too dusty. Maybe SeaWorld was only the first stop on some kind of whirlwind adventure. Yes. That made sense. That was Margo. She found out about this place somehow, came here to gather her supplies, spent a night or two, and then hit the road. I could imagine her pinballing among tourist traps.
vi: Cuốn sách có tựa đề Men theo nước Mĩ: Cẩm nang du lịch, xuất bản năm 1998, sau khi nơi này bị bỏ hoang. Tôi kẹp đèn pin giữa cổ và vai, tay giở qua các trang sách. Cuốn sách liệt kê hàng trăm thắng cảnh có thể ghé thăm, từ cuộn dây thừng lớn nhất thế giới ở Darwin, bang Minnesota, tới quả cầu tem lớn nhất thế giới ở Omaha, bang Nebraska. Ai đó đã gấp mép vài trang có vẻ là ngẫu nhiên. Cuốn sách không mấy bám bụi. Có lẽ SeaWorld chỉ là điểm dừng chân đầu tiên của cơn lốc xoáy những cuộc phiêu lưu. Đúng vậy. Như thế có lí lắm. Thế mới là Margo. Bằng cách nào đó cô ấy đã phát hiện ra nơi này, đến đây sửa soạn hành lí, ngủ lại một, hai đêm, rồi thế là lên đường. Tôi có thể hình dung được cô ấy nảy qua nảy lại giữa những địa danh hút hầu bao khách du lịch.
tr: Kitabın üstünde “Yol Boyu Amerika: Seyahat Rehberiniz” yazıyordu ve 1998’de yayımlanmıştı, bu yer terk edildikten sonra. Boynum ile omzumun arasına sıkıştırdığım fenerle kitabın sayfalarını çevirdim. Kitapta ziyaret edilebilecek yüzlerce ilgi çekici yer sıralanıyordu; Darwin, Minnesota’daki dünyanın en büyük iplik yumağından, Omaha, Nebraska’daki dünyanın en büyük pul topuna. Birisi görünüşte rastgele birçok sayfanın köşesini kıvırmıştı. Kitap çok tozlu değildi. Belki SeaWorld bir macera kasırgasının yalnızca ilk durağıydı. Evet. Bu mantıklı geliyordu. Bu Margo’ydu. Bir şekilde bu yeri keşfetmiş, malzeme toplamak için buraya gelmiş, bir iki gece geçirmiş ve sonra yola koyulmuştu. Turist tuzakları arasında oradan oraya gittiğini hayal edebiliyordum.
es: El libro se titulaba Roadside America y se había publicado en 1998, después de que se abandonara aquel lugar. Lo hojeé sujetando la linterna entre el cuello y el hombro. El libro ofrecía una relación de cientos de atracciones turísticas, desde la bola de cuerda más grande del mundo, en Darwin, Minnesota, hasta la bola de sellos más grande del mundo, en Omaha, Nebraska. Alguien había doblado las esquinas de varias páginas, al parecer al azar. El libro no tenía mucho polvo. Quizá el SeaWorld había sido solo la primera parada de una especie de torbellino de aventuras. Sí. No era ninguna tontería. Así era Margo. De alguna manera descubrió aquel sitio, fue a recoger provisiones, pasó una noche o dos y siguió su camino. Me la imaginaba dando tumbos entre trampas para turistas.
vi_translation: The book is titled Following America: A Travel Guide, published in 1998, after this place was abandoned. I wedged the flashlight between my neck and shoulder, flipping through the pages with my hands. The book lists hundreds of attractions to visit, from the world's largest ball of twine in Darwin, Minnesota, to the world's largest ball of stamps in Omaha, Nebraska. Someone had dog-eared a few pages seemingly at random. The book wasn't very dusty. Maybe SeaWorld was just the first stop in the whirlwind of adventures. Indeed. That makes a lot of sense. That's so Margo. Somehow she had discovered this place, came here to pack her bags, stayed a night or two, and then hit the road. I can picture her bouncing from one tourist trap to another.
tr_translation: The book had "Along the Road America: Your Travel Guide" written on it and was published in 1998, after this place was abandoned. I turned the pages of the book with the flashlight I had wedged between my neck and shoulder. The book listed hundreds of interesting places to visit; from the world's largest ball of twine in Darwin, Minnesota, to the world's largest ball of stamps in Omaha, Nebraska. Someone had seemingly randomly dog-eared many pages. The book wasn't very dusty. Maybe SeaWorld was just the first stop in a whirlwind adventure. Yes. This made sense. This was Margo. Somehow she had discovered this place, come here to gather supplies, spent a night or two, and then set off. I could imagine her going from one tourist trap to another.
es_translation: The book was titled Roadside America and had been published in 1998, after that place had been abandoned. I flipped through it holding the flashlight between my neck and shoulder. The book offered a list of hundreds of tourist attractions, from the world's largest ball of twine, in Darwin, Minnesota, to the world's largest ball of stamps, in Omaha, Nebraska. Someone had dog-eared several pages, seemingly at random. The book wasn't very dusty. Maybe SeaWorld had just been the first stop in some kind of whirlwind of adventures. Yes. It wasn't nonsense. That was Margo. Somehow she discovered that place, went to gather supplies, spent a night or two, and moved on. I imagined her wandering between tourist traps.

en: As the last light fled from the holes in the ceiling, I found more books above other bookshelves. The Rough Guide to Nepal; The Great Sights of Canada; America by Car; Fodor’s Guide to the Bahamas; Let’s Go Bhutan. There seemed to be no connection at all among the books, except that they were all about traveling and had all been published after the minimall was abandoned. I tucked the Maglite under my chin, scooped up the books into a stack that extended from my waist to my chest, and carried them into the empty room I was now imagining as the bedroom.
vi: Trong khi chùm sáng cuối cùng mảnh dần qua cái lỗ trên trần, tôi tìm thấy thêm mấy cuốn sách trên các giá khác. Sơ lược hành trình đến Nepal; Canada hùng vĩ; Rong ruổi bằng ô-tô trên đất Mĩ; Cẩm nang của Fodor đến Bahamas; Bhutan thẳng tiến. Dường như không có liên hệ nào giữa những cuốn sách, trừ việc tất cả đều là sách hướng dẫn du lịch và đều được xuất bản sau khi khu mua sắm mini này bị bỏ hoang. Tôi kẹp đèn pin dưới cằm, xếp tất cả sách thành một chồng từ thắt lưng cao đến ngực, bê hết sang gian phòng trống mà bây giờ tôi hình dung là phòng ngủ.
tr: Son ışık, tavandaki deliklerden kaçarken, diğer kitap raflarının üstünde başka kitaplar buldum. “Nepal Gezi Rehberi”; “Kanada’nın ()nemli Manzaraları”; “Arabayla Amerika”; “Fodor’un Bahamalar Rehberi”; “Haydi Bhutan’a Gidelim”. Bütün bu kitaplar arasında hiçbir bağlantı yok gibi görünüyordu, hepsinin seyahat hakkında olması ve hepsinin alışveriş merkezi terk edildikten sonra yayımlanmış olması dışında. Maglite’ı çenemin altına sıkıştırdım, kitapları belimden göğsüme kadar uzanan bir yığın halinde kucaklayıp artık yatak odası olarak hayal ettiğim boş odaya taşıdım.
es: Mientras los últimos rayos de luz entraban por los agujeros del techo, encontré más libros en otros estantes: Guía general de Nepal, Grandes atracciones de Canadá, América en coche, Guía Fodor de las Bahamas y Vamos a Bután. No parecía que hubiera la menor relación entre los libros, excepto que todos eran de viajes y la fecha de publicación era posterior al abandono del edificio. Me metí la linterna debajo de la barbilla, cargué en los brazos la pila de libros, que me llegaba desde la cintura hasta el pecho, y los llevé a la sala vacía, que entonces imaginaba que era el dormitorio.
vi_translation: As the last beam of light gradually faded through the hole in the ceiling, I found a few more books on the other shelves.
