en: He waited to talk until I’d said, “And then Ben called me and I left for that party.”
vi: “Rồi Ben gọi điện và tôi đến đám tiệc. Radar chờ đến khi tôi kết thúc mới lên tiếng, “Ông có cuốn sách ấy ở đây không?
tr: “Ondan sonra Ben aradı, ben de partiye gittim,” diyene kadar konuşmak için bekledi.
es: No dijo nada hasta que le comenté: —Y entonces Ben me llamó y fui a la fiesta.
vi_translation: “Then Ben called and I went to the party.” Radar waited until I finished speaking before asking, "Do you have that book here?"
tr_translation: “Then Ben called, and I went to the party,” he waited to speak until he said.
es_translation: He didn't say anything until I mentioned: —And then Ben called me and I went to the party.

en: “Do you have that book, the one with the turned-down corners?” he asked. I got up and fished for it under the bed, finally pulling it out. Radar held it above his head, squinting through his headache, and flipped through the pages.
vi: Cuốn có mấy trang bị gấp mép ấy?” nó hỏi. Tôi nhỏm dậy bới trong đống chăn mền, cuối cùng cũng mò ra cuốn sách. Radar giơ cuốn sách lên cao quá đầu, nheo nheo mắt vì đầu óc còn váng vất, và giở qua các trang sách.
tr: “O kitap sende mi, köşeleri kıvrılmış olan?” diye sordu. Kalkıp yatağın altmda kitabı aradım, sonunda çekip çıkardım. Radar kitabı başının üstüne kaldırdı, baş ağrısıyla gözlerini kısarak sayfalan çevirdi.
es: —¿Tienes ese libro, el de las esquinas dobladas? —me preguntó. Me levanté, lo busqué con la mano debajo de la cama y lo saqué. Radar lo levantó, entrecerró los ojos por el dolor de cabeza y lo hojeó.
vi_translation: "The one with the dog-eared pages?" it asked. I sat up and rummaged through the pile of blankets, finally finding the book. Radar held the book high above its head, squinting because it was still groggy, and flipped through the pages.
tr_translation: “Do you have that book, the one with the folded corners?” he asked. I got up and searched for the book under the bed, finally pulling it out. Radar lifted the book above his head, squinting at the pages with a headache.
es_translation: —Do you have that book, the one with the folded corners? —he asked me. I got up, searched for it with my hand under the bed, and took it out. Radar picked it up, squinted his eyes due to the headache, and flipped through it.

en: “Write this down,” he said. “Omaha, Nebraska. Sac City, Iowa. Alexandria, Indiana. Darwin, Minnesota. Hollywood, California. Alliance, Nebraska. Okay. Those are the locations of all the things she—well, or whoever read this book—found interesting.” He got up, motioned me out of the chair, and then swiveled to the computer. Radar had an amazing talent for carrying on conversations while typing. “There’s a map mash-up that allows you to enter multiple destinations and it will spit out a variety of itineraries. Not that she’d know about this program. But still, I want to see.”
vi: “Ông viết lại đi,” nó nói. “Omaha, bang Nebraska. Sac City, bang Iowa. Alexandria, bang Indiana. Darwin, bang Minnesota. Hollywood, bang California. Alliance, bang Nebraska. Xong nhé. Trong cả mớ thông tin, đấy là những nơi mà Margo–chà, hoặc bất cứ ai đọc cuốn sách này– thấy lí thú.” Nó nhỏm dậy, xua tôi ra khỏi ghế, ngồi xuống và xoay qua máy tính. Radar có biệt tài kì diệu vừa nói chuyện vừa đánh máy được. “Có một chương trình máy tính tích hợp bản đồ cho phép ông nhập vào một số địa danh, nó sẽ vạch ra được nhiều lộ trình khác nhau. Không rõ Margo có biết đến chương trình đó không. Cơ mà, tôi muốn thử xem sao.”
tr: ‘Yaz şunu,” dedi. “Omaha, Nebraska. Sac City, Iowa. Alexandria, Indiana. Darwin, Minnesota. Hollywood, Kaliforniya. Alliance, Nebraska. Tamam. Margo’nunşey, ya da bu kitabı kim okuduysa onunilginç bulduğu bütün yerler bunlar.” Yataktan kalkıp beni sandalyeden kaldırdı ve sandalyede dönerek bilgisayara geçti. Radar’m bilgisayara yazı yazarken sohbeti devam ettirmekte şaşırtıcı bir yeteneği vardı. “Birçok istikameti girmene izin veren bir mashup10 harita uygulaması var ve bu program çeşitli güzergâhlar 10 Birden fazla veri kaynağını kullanarak yeni bir uygulama veya arayüz oluşturma tekniği, (ç. n. gösteriyor. Margo’nun bu programı bileceğinden değil... ama yine de görmek istiyorum.
es: —Apunta —me dijo—: Omaha, Nebraska. Sac City, Iowa. Alexandria, Indiana. Darwin, Minnesota. Hollywood, California. Alliance, Nebraska. Ya está. Son los lugares que a Margo —bueno, o a quien leyera este libro— le parecieron interesantes. —Se incorporó, me levantó de la silla y se giró hacia el ordenador. Radar tenía un talento increíble para seguir hablando mientras tecleaba—. Hay un grupo de mapas que te permite entrar múltiples destinos y te ofrece diversos itinerarios. No creo que Margo conociera el programa, pero quiero echar un vistazo.
vi_translation: “Rewrite it,” she said. “Omaha, Nebraska. Sac City, Iowa. Alexandria, Indiana. Darwin, Minnesota. Hollywood, California. Alliance, Nebraska. Done. Among all the information, those are the places that Margo—or, well, anyone reading this book—would find interesting.” She stood up, pushed me out of the chair, sat down, and turned to the computer. Radar had the amazing talent of being able to talk and type at the same time. “There’s a computer program with an integrated map that allows you to input several locations, and it will outline different routes. Not sure if Margo knew about that program. But, I want to give it a try.”
tr_translation: ‘Write this down,” he said. “Omaha, Nebraska. Sac City, Iowa. Alexandria, Indiana. Darwin, Minnesota. Hollywood, California. Alliance, Nebraska. Okay. These are all the places that Margo or whoever read this book found interesting.” He got out of bed, lifted me from the chair, and sat down at the computer. Radar had an amazing ability to keep a conversation going while typing on the computer. “There’s a mashup map application that lets you enter multiple destinations, and this program offers various routes The technique of creating a new application or interface using multiple data sources, (e. g.) shows. Not that Margo would know this program... but I still want to see it.”
es_translation: —Write this down —he told me—: Omaha, Nebraska. Sac City, Iowa. Alexandria, Indiana. Darwin, Minnesota. Hollywood, California. Alliance, Nebraska. That's it. These are the places that Margo —well, or whoever read this book— found interesting. —He stood up, lifted me from the chair, and turned towards the computer. Radar had an incredible talent for continuing to talk while typing—. There is a group of maps that allows you to enter multiple destinations and offers you various routes. I don't think Margo knew about the program, but I want to take a look.

en: “How do you know all this shit?” I asked.
vi: “Sao ông biết tuốt tuồn tuột như vậy?” tôi hỏi.
tr: “Bütün bunları nereden biliyorsun?” diye sordum.
es: —¿Cómo sabes toda esa mierda? —le pregunté.
vi_translation: "How do you know everything so thoroughly?" I asked.
tr_translation: “How do you know all this?” I asked.
es_translation: —How do you know all that crap?

en: “Um, reminder: I. Spend. My. Entire. Life. On. Omnictionary. In the hour between when I got home this morning and when I hurled in the shower, I completely rewrote the page for the Blue-spotted Anglerfish. I have a problem. Okay, look at this,” he said. I leaned in and saw several jagged routes drawn onto a map of the United States. All began in Orlando and ended in Hollywood, California.
vi: “Ừm, nhắc lại nhé: Tôi. Hiến. Đời. Mình. Cho. Toàn. Thư. Trong một tiếng từ khi về nhà sáng nay đến lúc phi vào nhà tắm, tôi đã hoàn toàn viết lại mục bài về cá Anglerfish đốm xanh. Tôi có vấn đề đấy. Được rồi, nhìn xem này,” Radar gọi. Tôi nhoài sang và thấy mấy tuyến đường gấp khúc được vạch ra trên bản đồ nước Mĩ. Tất cả đều xuất phát từ Orlando và kết thúc ở Hollywood, bang California.
tr: “Hımm, hatırlatma notu: Ben. Bütün. Hayatımı. Omnictionaıy’de. Geçiriyorum. Bu sabah eve gitmem ve çabucak duşa girmem arasındaki saatte, mavi benekli fener balığı sayfasını tamamen yeniden yazdım. Bir sorunum var. Tamam, şuna bak,” dedi. Eğildim ve Birleşik Devletler haritasına çizilmiş bir sürü girintili çıkıntılı güzergâh gördüm. Hepsi Orlando’da başhyor ve Hollywood, Kaliforniya’da bitiyordu.
es: —¿Cómo sabes toda esa mierda? —le pregunté. —Uf, recuerda que me paso la vida entera en el Omnictionary. En la hora desde que he llegado a casa esta mañana y me he metido en la ducha, he reescrito de arriba abajo la página de los peces abisales Lophiiformes. Tengo un problema. Vale, mira esto. Me incliné y vi varias rutas trazadas en un mapa de Estados Unidos. Todas empezaban en Orlando y terminaban en Hollywood, California.
vi_translation: “Um, let me repeat: I. Dedicate. My. Life. To. Omnictionary. From the moment I got home this morning until I rushed into the bathroom, I completely rewrote the article on the blue-spotted Anglerfish. I have issues. Alright, look at this,” Radar called. I leaned over and saw several winding routes marked on the map of the United States. They all started from Orlando and ended in Hollywood, California.
tr_translation: “Hmm, reminder: Me. The Whole. My life. At Omnictionaıy. I spend it. In the hour between getting home this morning and taking a quick shower, I completely rewrote the blue spotted anglerfish page. I have a problem. Okay, look at this,” he said. I leaned down and saw a bunch of uneven routes drawn on a map of the United States. They all started in Orlando and ended in Hollywood, California.
es_translation: —I asked him. —Ugh, remember that I spend my entire life on the Omnictionary. In the hour since I got home this morning and got into the shower, I have completely rewritten the page on abyssal fish Lophiiformes. I have a problem. Okay, look at this. I leaned over and saw several routes drawn on a map of the United States. They all started in Orlando and ended in Hollywood, California.

en: “Maybe she’ll stay in LA?” Radar suggested.
vi: “Margo ở Los Angeles chăng?” Radar đặt giả thuyết.
tr: “Belki Los Angeles’ta kalacaktır?’ diye bir fikir öne sürdü Radar.
es: —¿Estará en Los Ángeles? —sugirió Radar.
vi_translation: “Is Margo in Los Angeles?” Radar hypothesized.
tr_translation: “Maybe he will stay in Los Angeles?” suggested Radar.
es_translation: —Will she be in Los Angeles? —suggested Radar.

en: “Maybe,” I said. “There’s no way to tell her route, though.”
vi: “Có thể,” tôi đáp. “Nhưng chẳng cách nào biết được Margo đi tuyến nào nhỉ.”
tr: “Belki,” dedim. “Güzergâhım bilmenin yolu yok yine de.
es: —Puede ser —le contesté—. Pero no hay manera de saber su ruta.
vi_translation: “Maybe,” I replied. “But there's no way to know which route Margo took.”
tr_translation: “Maybe,” I said. “There's no way to know my route, though.”
es_translation: —It could be —I replied—. But there is no way to know their route.

en: “True. Also nothing else points to LA. What she said to Jase points to New York. The ‘go to the paper towns and never come back’ points to a nearby pseudovision, it seems. The nail polish also points to maybe her still being in the area? I’m just saying we can now add the location of the world’s largest ball of popcorn to our list of possible Margo locales.”
vi: “Ừ. Cũng chẳng có gì ám chỉ Los Angeles cả. Căn cứ vào lời Margo nói với Jase, có thể là New York. Còn thông điệp ‘sẽ đi đến những thành phố giấy và sẽ không bao giờ trở lại’ hình như nhắm đến những khu đô thị ma quanh đây. Lọ sơn móng tay có thể ngụ ý rằng Margo vẫn chưa đi xa chăng? Chúng ta có thể thêm cả địa danh có viên bỏng ngô lớn nhất thế giới vào danh sách những nơi có khả năng Margo sẽ đến.”
tr: “Doğru. Ayrıca başka hiçbir şey Los Angeles’ı işaret etmiyor. Jase’e söylediği şey New York’u işaret ediyor. ‘Kâğıttan kentlere git ve asla geri dönme’ ise yakınlardaki bir semtimsiyi gösteriyor gibi. Oje belki de hâlâ buralarda olduğunu gösteriyor, ne dersin? Olası Margo bölgeleri listemize artık dünyanın en büyük patlamış mısır topunun yerini de ekleyebiliriz diyorum.
es: —Cierto. Y ninguna otra pista apunta a Los Ángeles. Lo que le dijo a Jase apunta a Nueva York. El «irás a ciudades de papel y nunca volverás» parece apuntar a una pseudovisión de esta zona. El pintaúñas, ¿no apunta también a que quizá sigue por aquí? Creo que ya solo nos falta añadir la localización de la bola de palomitas más grande del mundo a nuestra lista de posibles localizaciones de Margo.
vi_translation: “Yeah. There's nothing that specifically points to Los Angeles. Based on what Margo told Jase, it could be New York. And the message ‘will go to the paper towns and will never come back’ seems to be aimed at the ghost towns around here. The nail polish bottle might imply that Margo hasn't gone far yet? We can also add the place with the world's largest popcorn ball to the list of possible places Margo might go.”
tr_translation: “Correct. Also, nothing else points to Los Angeles. What she told Jase points to New York. ‘Go to the paper towns and never come back’ seems to indicate a nearby suburb. Maybe the nail polish still shows that she is around here, what do you think? I think we can now add the location of the world's largest popcorn ball to our list of possible Margo areas.”
es_translation: —True. And no other clue points to Los Angeles. What she told Jase points to New York. The "you will go to paper towns and never come back" seems to point to a pseudo-vision of this area. The nail polish, doesn't it also suggest that maybe she's still around here? I think we just need to add the location of the world's largest popcorn ball to our list of possible locations for Margo.

en: “The traveling would fit with one of the Whitman quotes: ‘I tramp a perpetual journey.’”
vi: “Hành trình du lịch khớp với ý thơ Whitman: ‘Ta dấn mình vào chuyến đi miên viễn.
tr: “Seyahat etmek Whitman’ın sözlerinden birine uyuyor: ‘Ebedî bir yolculukta ağır ağır ilerliyorum.
es: —El viaje coincidiría con una de las citas de Whitman: «El viaje que he emprendido es eterno».
vi_translation: “The travel journey aligns with Whitman's verse: ‘I embark on the perpetual journey.’’”
tr_translation: “Traveling aligns with one of Whitman's sayings: ‘I am slowly advancing on an eternal journey.”’
es_translation: —The journey would coincide with one of Whitman's quotes: "The journey I have undertaken is eternal."

en: Radar stayed hunched over the computer. I went to sit down on the bed. “Hey, will you just print out a map of the U.S. so I can plot the points?” I asked.
vi: Radar vẫn lui cui bên máy tính. Tôi ngồi xuống giường. “Này, ông in bản đồ ra để tôi định vị các nơi được không?” tôi hỏi.
tr: Radar bilgisayarın önünde kambur bir halde kaldı. Yatağa oturmaya gittim. “Hey, sadece ABD’nin haritasını çıkarabilir misin, böylece bu noktaların yerlerini belirleyebilirim,” dedim.
es: Radar siguió encorvado delante del ordenador, y yo fui a sentarme en la cama.
vi_translation: Radar was still busy with the computer. I sat down on the bed. "Hey, can you print out the map so I can locate the places?" I asked.
tr_translation: Radar remained hunched over in front of the computer. I went to sit on the bed. "Hey, can you just pull up a map of the USA so I can pinpoint these locations," I said.
es_translation: Radar remained hunched over the computer, and I went to sit on the bed. —Hey, can you print a map of the United States so I can mark the points?

en: “Yeah, but I want to be able to look at it.” The printer fired up a few seconds later and I placed the U.S. map next to the one with the pseudovisions on the wall. I put a tack in for each of the six locations she (or someone) had marked in the book. I tried to look at them as a constellation, to see if they formed a shape or a letter—but I couldn’t see anything. It was a totally random distribution, like she’d blindfolded herself and thrown darts at the map.
vi: “Ừ, nhưng tôi muốn nhìn trực tiếp hơn.” Mấy giây sau máy in kêu rò rè, và tôi treo bản đồ nước Mĩ lên tường, cạnh tấm bản đồ các khu đô thị ma. Tôi đính ghim mũ lên từng nơi trong số sáu địa điểm mà Margo (hoặc ai đó) đã đánh dấu trong sách. Tôi cố gắng quan sát như thể đó là một chòm sao, xem chúng có tạo thành hình thù hay chữ nghĩa gì không–nhưng tôi chẳng nhận ra gì cả. Những địa danh rải rác ngẫu nhiên, như thể cô ấy đã tự bịt mắt rồi phóng phi tiêu lên bản đồ vậy.
tr: “Evet ama haritaya bakabilmek istiyorum.” Birkaç saniye sonra yazıcı çalıştı ve ABD haritasını, duvardaki semtimsilerin işaretlendiği haritanın yanma yerleştirdim. Margo’nun (ya da başka birinin) kitapta işaretlediği altı yerin her biri için haritaya bir raptiye koydum. Bir şekil ya da harf oluşturup oluşturmadıklarını görmek için onlara bir takımyıldız gibi bakmaya çalıştım... ama hiçbir şey göremedim. Tamamen rastgele bir dağılımdı, sanki Margo gözlerini bağlayıp haritaya dart okları fırlatmış gibi.
es: —Ya, pero me gustaría tener el mapa a la vista. La impresora arrancó a los dos segundos y colgué el mapa de Estados Unidos al lado del de las pseudovisiones. Clavé una chincheta en cada uno de los seis lugares que Margo (o alguien) había señalado en el libro. Intenté mirarlos como si formaran una constelación, descubrir si formaban una forma o una letra, pero no vi nada. La distribución era totalmente azarosa, como si se hubiera vendado los ojos y hubiera disparado dardos al mapa.
vi_translation: “Yes, but I want to see it more directly.” A few seconds later, the printer whirred, and I hung the map of the United States on the wall, next to the map of ghost towns. I pinned thumbtacks on each of the six locations that Margo (or someone) had marked in the book. I tried to observe it as if it were a constellation, to see if they formed any shapes or letters—but I couldn't see anything. The locations were scattered randomly, as if she had blindfolded herself and thrown darts at the map.
tr_translation: “Yes, but I want to be able to look at the map.” A few seconds later, the printer started working, and I placed the map of the USA next to the map on the wall where the neighborhoods were marked. I put a pin on the map for each of the six places marked in the book by Margo (or someone else). I tried to look at them like a constellation to see if they formed a shape or letter... but I couldn't see anything. It was a completely random distribution, as if Margo had blindfolded herself and thrown darts at a map.
es_translation: —Yeah, but I would like to have the map in sight. The printer started up after two seconds, and I hung the map of the United States next to the one of the pseudovisions. I stuck a thumbtack in each of the six places that Margo (or someone) had marked in the book. I tried to look at them as if they formed a constellation, to see if they made a shape or a letter, but I saw nothing. The distribution was completely random, as if she had blindfolded herself and thrown darts at the map.

en: I sighed. “You know what would be nice?” Radar asked. “If we could find some evidence that she was checking her email or anywhere on the Internet. I search for her name every day; I’ve got a bot that will alert me if she ever logs on to Omnictionary with that username. I track IP addresses of people who search for the phrase ‘paper towns.’ It’s incredibly frustrating.”
vi: Tôi thở dài. “Ông có biết nên thế nào bây giờ không?” Radar hỏi. “Giá mà có bằng chứng cho thấy Margo đã mở hộp e-mail hoặc truy cập đâu đó trên Internet. Ngày nào tôi cũng gõ tên cậu ấy để tìm. Tôi có một chương trình tự động, sẽ báo cho tôi nếu Margo đăng nhập vào Toàn Thư Đủ Thứ bằng tên truy cập của mình. Tôi lần theo những địa chỉ IP của những người tìm cụm từ ‘những thành phố giấy.’ Mệt mỏi kinh lên được.”
tr: İç çektim. “Ne iyi olurdu biliyor musun?” diye sordu Radar. “Eğer onun epostasını ya da internette herhangi bir yeri kontrol ettiğine dair bir kanıt bulabilseydik. Her gün adını arıyorum; Omnictionary’ye o kullanıcı adıyla girerse beni uyaracak otomatik bir programım var. ‘Kâğıttan kentler’ sözünü arayan kişilerin IP adreslerini takip ediyorum. İnanılmaz derecede sinir bozucu.
es: Suspiré. —¿Sabes lo que estaría bien? —me preguntó Radar—. Encontrar alguna prueba de que revisó su e-mail o cualquier otra cosa en internet. La busco todos los días. Tengo una alerta por si entra en el Omnictionary con su nombre de usuario. Y rastreo las IP de los que buscan las palabras «ciudades de papel». Es increíblemente frustrante.
vi_translation: I sighed. “Do you know what to do now?” Radar asked. “If only there was evidence showing that Margo had opened her email or accessed somewhere on the Internet. Every day I type her name to search. I have an automated program that will notify me if Margo logs into Omnictionary using her username. I track the IP addresses of people searching for the term 'paper towns.' It's exhausting.”
tr_translation: I sighed. “Do you know what would be great?” asked Radar. “If we could find any evidence that she checks her email or any place on the internet. I search for her name every day; I have an automatic program that will alert me if she logs into Omnictionary with that username. I track the IP addresses of people searching for the term ‘paper towns’. It's incredibly frustrating.”
es_translation: I sighed. —You know what would be nice? —Radar asked me—. Finding some proof that she checked her email or anything else on the internet. I look for her every day. I have an alert in case she logs into Omnictionary with her username. And I track the IPs of those who search for the words "paper towns." It's incredibly frustrating.

en: “I didn’t know you were doing all that stuff,” I said.
vi: “Tôi không ngờ ông lại lọ mọ làm tất cả đấy,” tôi nói.
tr: “Bütün bunları yaptığını bilmiyordum,” dedim.
es: —No sabía que estabas haciendo tantas cosas —le dije.
vi_translation: "I didn't expect you to go through all that trouble," I said.
tr_translation: "I didn't know you did all this," I said.
es_translation: —I didn't know you were doing so many things —I said to him.

en: “Yeah, well. Only doing what I’d want someone else to do. I know I wasn’t friends with her, but she deserves to be found, you know?”
vi: “Ờ, có gì đâu. Chỉ làm những gì tôi muốn người khác sẽ làm thôi mà. Tôi biết tôi không phải là bạn của Margo, nhưng cậu ấy xứng đáng được tìm thấy, ông hiểu ý tôi chứ?”
tr: “Evet, şey. Yalnızca başkasından yapmasını isteyeceğim şeyi yapıyorum. Onunla arkadaş olmadığımı biliyorum ama bulunmayı hak ediyor.
es: —Sí, bueno, solo hago lo que me gustaría que hicieran conmigo. Sé que no era amiga mía, pero se merece que la encontremos, ¿sabes?
vi_translation: “Well, it's nothing. I'm just doing what I would want others to do for me. I know I'm not Margo's friend, but she deserves to be found, you understand what I mean?”
tr_translation: “Yes, well. I'm only doing what I would ask someone else to do. I know I'm not friends with him, but he deserves to be found.”
es_translation: —Yes, well, I just do what I would like others to do for me. I know she wasn't my friend, but she deserves to be found, you know?

en: “Unless she doesn’t want to be,” I said.
vi: “Trừ phi Margo không muốn được tìm thấy,” tôi nói.
tr: “Bulunmak istediği sürece.
es: —A menos que no quiera —le dije.
vi_translation: “Unless Margo doesn't want to be found,” I said.
tr_translation: “As long as he wants to be found.”
es_translation: —Unless you don't want to —I said to him.

en: “Yeah, I guess that’s possible. It’s all still possible.” I nodded. “Yeah, so—okay,” he said. “Can we brainstorm over video games?”
vi: “Ừ, cũng có khả năng ấy. Mọi khả năng còn để ngỏ.” Tôi gật gật. “Ờ, vậy–được rồi.” Radar chuyển chủ đề. “Chúng ta tiếp tục động não bằng trò chơi điện tử nhé?”
tr: “Evet, sanırım istememesi mümkün. Hâlâ her şey mümkün.” Başımı salladım. “Evet, peki... tamam,” dedi. “Bilgisayar oyunu sırasında beyin fırtınası yapabilir miyiz?
es: —Sí, supongo que es posible. Todo es posible. Asentí. —En fin —siguió diciendo—, ¿podemos pasar a los videojuegos?
vi_translation: "Yes, that's also possible." "All possibilities are still open." I nodded. "Uh, well–alright." Radar changed the subject. "Shall we continue brainstorming with a video game?"
tr_translation: “Yes, I think it is possible that he doesn't want to. Everything is still possible.” I nodded. “Yes, well... okay,” he said. “Can we brainstorm during the computer game?”
es_translation: —Yes, I suppose it is possible. Everything is possible. I nodded. —In the end —he continued saying—, can we move on to video games?

en: “I’m not really in the mood.”
vi: “Tôi không có hứng.
tr: “Gerçekten havamda değilim.
es: —La verdad es que no estoy de humor.
vi_translation: “I'm not in the mood.”
tr_translation: “I'm really not in the mood.”
es_translation: —The truth is that I'm not in the mood.

en: “Can we call Ben then?”
vi: “Hay là gọi Ben?”
tr: “O zaman Ben’i arayabilir miyiz?
es: —Pues ¿llamamos a Ben? —No.
vi_translation: "How about calling Ben?"
tr_translation: “Then can we call Ben?”
es_translation: —Well, shall we call Ben? —No.

en: “No. Ben’s an asshole.”
vi: “Không. Ben là đồ bỉ bựa.
tr: “Hayır. Ben göt herifin teki.
es: Ben es un gilipollas.
vi_translation: "No. Ben is a jerk."
tr_translation: “No. I'm a complete asshole.”
es_translation: Ben is an asshole.

en: Radar looked at me sideways. “Of course he is. You know your problem, Quentin? You keep expecting people not to be themselves. I mean, I could hate you for being massively unpunctual and for never being interested in anything other than Margo Roth Spiegelman, and for, like, never asking me about how it’s going with my girlfriend—but I don’t give a shit, man, because you’re you. My parents have a shit ton of black Santas, but that’s okay. They’re them. I’m too obsessed with a reference Web site to answer my phone sometimes when my friends call, or my girlfriend. That’s okay, too. That’s me. You like me anyway. And I like you. You’re funny, and you’re smart, and you may show up late, but you always show up eventually.”
vi: Ben là đồ bỉ bựa. Radar nhìn nghiêng phía tôi. “Tất nhiên Ben bựa rồi. Nhưng ông có biết vấn đề của ông là gì không hả Quentin? Ông cứ mong đợi người khác không là chính họ. Thử nghĩ mà xem, tôi có thể quá ngán ông vì ông trễ giờ vô đối, chẳng hứng thú với bất cứ chủ đề gì trừ Margo Roth Spiegelman, hoặc, kiểu như chẳng bao giờ ỏ ê hỏi tôi với bạn gái tiến triển tới đâu rồi. Nhưng tôi không để bụng đâu, bồ tèo ạ, vì ông là ông. Bố mẹ tôi ôm khư khư cả tấn các ông già Noel da đen chẳng để làm gì, nhưng cũng chả sao. Bố mẹ là bố mẹ mà. Tôi quá ham một trang mạng tích trữ đủ thứ thông tin, đến nỗi không trả lời điện thoại khi bạn bè hoặc bạn gái tôi gọi. Nhưng như thế cũng không sao. Đó là tôi. Ông vẫn kết tôi mà. Tôi cũng kết ông. Ông ngộ ngộ, đầu óc hay hay, ông hay đến muộn thật, nhưng rút cục ông luôn có mặt là ổn.”
tr: Radar yan yan bana baktı. “Tabii ki öyle. Senin sorunun ne biliyor musun, Quentin? insanlardan kendileri gibi olmamalarını bekliyorsun. Yani, senin düzenli bir şekilde geç kalmandan, Margo Roth Spiegelman’dan başka hiçbir şeyle ilgilenmiyor olmandan ve hiçbir zaman bana kız arkadaşımla nasıl gittiğini falan sormamandan nefret edebilirdim ama umurumda değil dostum, çünkü sen sensin. Annemle babamın bir ton zenci Noel babası var ama bu da sorun değil. Onlar da onlar. Ben arkadaşlarım ya da kız arkadaşım aradığında bazen telefona cevap vermeyecek kadar bir referans sitesine saplantılıyım. Bu da sorun değil. Bu benim. Her halükârda beni seviyorsun. Ve ben de seni seviyorum. Eğlcnenli akıllısın ve geç gelebilirsin ama eninde sonunda gelirsin.
es: Radar me miró de reojo. —Por supuesto. ¿Sabes cuál es tu problema, Quentin? Siempre esperas que la gente no sea quien es. Quiero decir que yo podría odiarte por llegar siempre tarde, por preocuparte solo de Margo Roth Spiegelman y por no preguntarme nunca cómo me va con mi novia… pero me importa una mierda, tío, porque eres así. Mis padres tienen una tonelada de Santa Claus negros, pero está bien. Ellos son así. A veces estoy tan obsesionado con una página web que no contesto cuando me llaman mis amigos o mi novia, y también está bien. Así soy yo. Me aprecias igualmente. Y yo te aprecio a ti. Eres divertido e inteligente, y es verdad que apareces tarde, pero al final siempre apareces.
vi_translation: Radar looked askance at me. "Of course Ben is a jerk. But do you know what your problem is, Quentin? You keep expecting people not to be themselves. Think about it, I could be really annoyed with you for being incredibly late, having no interest in any topic except Margo Roth Spiegelman, or, like, never bothering to ask how things are going with my girlfriend. But I don't mind, buddy, because you are you. My parents hoard a ton of black Santas for no reason, but it's okay. Parents are parents. I'm so obsessed with a website that collects all sorts of information that I don't answer the phone when my friends or girlfriend call. But that's okay too. That's me. You still like me. I like you too. You're quirky, kind of weird, you're often late, but in the end, you're always there and that's what matters."
tr_translation: Radar looked at me intently. "Of course it is. Do you know what your problem is, Quentin? You expect people not to be themselves. I mean, I could hate that you are consistently late, that you are only interested in Margo Roth Spiegelman, and that you never ask me how things are going with my girlfriend, but I don't care, man, because you are you. My parents have a ton of black Santa Clauses, but that's not a problem either. They are who they are. Sometimes I am so obsessed with a reference site that I don't answer the phone when my friends or girlfriend call. That's not a problem either. That's me. Every In any case, you love me. And I love you too. You are fun and smart, and you may come late but eventually, you will come."
es_translation: Radar looked at me out of the corner of his eye. —Of course. Do you know what your problem is, Quentin? You always expect people not to be who they are. I mean, I could hate you for always being late, for only caring about Margo Roth Spiegelman, and for never asking me how things are going with my girlfriend… but I don't give a damn, man, because that's just how you are. My parents have a ton of black Santa Clauses, but it's okay. That's just how they are. Sometimes I'm so obsessed with a website that I don't answer when my friends or my girlfriend call me, and that's okay too. That's just how I am. You appreciate me anyway. And I appreciate you. You're funny and smart, and it's true that you show up late, but in the end, you always show up.

en: “Thanks.”
vi: “Cảm ơn ông.”
tr: “Teşekkürler.
es: —Gracias.
vi_translation: "Thank you, sir."
tr_translation: “Thank you.”
es_translation: —Thank you.

en: “Yeah, well, I wasn’t complimenting you. Just saying: stop thinking Ben should be you, and he needs to stop thinking you should be him, and y’all just chill the hell out.”
vi: “Ừ, rồi, tôi không có nịnh ông đâu. Nhưng mà này: đừng nghĩ rằng Ben nên là ông, nó cũng cần bỏ ý nghĩ rằng ông nên là nó, rồi hai ông lại tiếp tục quậy tưng thiên đường địa ngục cho coi.”
tr: “Evet, şey. Sana iltifat etmiyordum. Sadece söylüyorum: IkM senin gibi olması gerektiğini düşünmeyi bırak ve o da senin on| gibi olman gerektiğini düşünmeyi bıraksın ve lanet olsun, hc'pİ) sakinleşin.
es: —Sí, bueno, en realidad no estaba echándote piropos. Solo digo que tienes que dejar de pensar que Ben debería ser como tú, y Ben tiene que dejar de pensar que tú deberías ser como él, y a ver si os calmáis los dos de una puta vez.
vi_translation: "Okay, then, I'm not flattering you. But listen: don't think that Ben should be you, and he should also abandon the idea that you should be him, then you two will continue to cause chaos in heaven and hell."
tr_translation: “Yes, well. I wasn't complimenting you. I'm just saying: Stop thinking that IkM should be like you and let it stop thinking that you should be like it, and for heaven's sake, both of you calm down.”
es_translation: —Yes, well, actually I wasn't complimenting you. I'm just saying that you need to stop thinking that Ben should be like you, and Ben needs to stop thinking that you should be like him, and let's see if you both calm down for once.

en: “All right,” I said finally, and called Ben. The news that Radar was over and wanted to play video games led to a miraculous hangover recovery.
vi: “Được rồi mà,” rút cục tôi nói, và gọi điện cho Ben. Thông tin rằng Radar đang ở đây và muốn chơi điện tử chính là một liệu pháp giải say kì diệu.
tr: “Pekâlâ,” dedim sonunda ve Ben’i aradım. Radar’ın ImrtU olduğu ve bilgisayar oyunu oynamak istediği haberi akşamdı kalmalığının mucizevi bir şekilde iyileşmesini sağladı.
es: —Muy bien —dije por fin. Y llamé a Ben. La noticia de que Radar estaba en mi casa y quería jugar a videojuegos hizo que se recuperara de la resaca milagrosamente.
vi_translation: "It's okay," I finally said, and called Ben. The information that Radar was here and wanted to play video games was a miraculous hangover cure.
tr_translation: “Alright,” I said finally and called Ben. The news that Radar was ImrtU and wanted to play a computer game miraculously cured his evening stay.
es_translation: —Very well —I finally said. And I called Ben. The news that Radar was at my house and wanted to play video games made him miraculously recover from his hangover.

en: “So,” I said after hanging up. “How’s Angela?”
vi: “Vậy,” tôi nói sau khi ngắt điện thoại, “chuyện Angela thế nào rồi?”
tr: “Peki,” dedim telefonu kapattıktan sonra. “Angela nasıl?
es: —Bueno —dije después de colgar—, ¿qué tal Angela?
vi_translation: “So,” I said after hanging up the phone, “how is Angela doing?”
tr_translation: “Okay,” I said after hanging up the phone. “How is Angela?"
es_translation: —Well —I said after hanging up—, how's Angela?

en: Radar laughed. “She’s good, man. She’s real good. Thanks for asking.”
vi: Radar cười ngất. “Ổn cả, người anh em ạ, tốt đẹp cả. Cảm ơn ông đã có nhời hỏi thăm.”
tr: Radar güldü. “İyi, dostum. Gerçekten iyi. Sorduğun için şekkürler.
es: Radar se rió. —Muy bien, tío. Está muy bien. Gracias por preguntar.
vi_translation: Radar burst out laughing. "It's all good, brother, all good. Thank you for asking."
tr_translation: Radar laughed. "Good, my friend. Really good. Thanks for asking."
es_translation: Radar laughed. —Very well, uncle. It is very well. Thank you for asking.

en: “You still a virgin?” I asked.
vi: “Ông vẫn còn tân à?” tôi tò mò.
tr: “Hâlâ bakir misin?” diye sordum.
es: —¿Todavía eres virgen? —le pregunté.
vi_translation: "Are you still a virgin?" I asked curiously.
tr_translation: "Are you still a virgin?" I asked.
es_translation: —Are you still a virgin?

en: “I don’t kiss and tell. Although, yes. Oh, and we had our first fight this morning. We had breakfast at Waffle House, and she was going on about how awesome the black Santas are, and how my parents are great people for collecting them because it’s important for us not to presume that everybody cool in our culture like God and Santa Claus is white, and how the black Santa empowers the whole African-American community.”
vi: “Đây không chơi trò hun rùi đi buôn chuyện thế đâu nhé. Cơ mà, đúng, vẫn tân. Ờ, mà sáng nay hai đứa vừa giận nhau xong. Bọn tôi ăn sáng ở tiệm Waffle House, Angela cứ ca đi ngợi lại rằng những ông già Noel da đen thật tuyệt, rằng bố mẹ tôi là những con người mẫu mực đã lập bộ sưu tập đó, vì chúng ta cần tránh tư duy định kiến rằng những nhân vật hay ho như Chúa hay ông già Noel đều da trắng, và rằng ông già Noel da đen sẽ cố kết, đẩy mạnh cộng đồng người Mĩ gốc Phi ra sao.”
tr: “Mahremiyeti bozamam. Bununla beraber, evet. Ah ve sabah ilk kavgamızı ettik. Waffle House’ta kahvaltı ediyorduk V8İ Angela zenci Noel babaların ne kadar müthiş olduğunu, nnllf|| biriktirdikleri için annemle babamın ne kadar harika insnnlgM olduğunu çünkü Tanrı’nın ve Noel babamn beyaz olması gibi ka*ı nulan kültürümüzde herkesin kabul ettiğini varsaymamanın hiidlR j için ne kadar önemli olduğunu ve zenci Noel babamn bütün siyahi toplumunu nasıl güçlendirdiğini anlatıyordu.
es: —¿Todavía eres virgen? —le pregunté. —No quisiera ser indiscreto, pero sí. Uf, y esta mañana hemos tenido nuestra primera bronca. Hemos ido a desayunar a Waffle House y ha empezado a decir que los Santa Claus negros son fantásticos, que mis padres son geniales por coleccionarlos, porque es importante no dar por sentado que toda la gente guay de nuestra cultura, como Dios y Santa Claus, es blanca, y que los Santa Claus negros fortalecen a toda la comunidad afroamericana.
vi_translation: "We don't play the game of gossiping here." "But, yes, still new." "Yeah, and this morning the two of us just had a fight." "We had breakfast at Waffle House, and Angela kept praising how great Black Santas are, saying that my parents are exemplary people for having started that collection, because we need to avoid the stereotype that cool characters like Jesus or Santa are all white, and that Black Santas would strengthen and promote the African American community."
tr_translation: “I cannot violate privacy. However, yes. Oh, and we had our first argument this morning. We were having breakfast at Waffle House, and Angela was talking about how amazing black Santas are, how wonderful my parents are for collecting them, because it’s so important not to assume that everyone accepts the idea that God and Santa Claus are white in our culture, and how black Santas empower the entire black community.”
es_translation: —I asked her. —I don't want to be indiscreet, but yes. Ugh, and this morning we had our first argument. We went to have breakfast at Waffle House and he started saying that Black Santa Clauses are fantastic, that my parents are great for collecting them, because it's important not to take for granted that all the cool people in our culture, like God and Santa Claus, are white, and that Black Santa Clauses empower the entire African American community.

en: “I actually think I kind of agree with her,” I said.
vi: “Thực ra tôi cũng đồng tình với Angela mà,” tôi nói.
tr: “Sanırım bir bakıma ona katılıyorum,” dedim.
es: —La verdad es que creo que estoy de acuerdo con ella —le dije.
vi_translation: "Actually, I agree with Angela too," I said.
tr_translation: "I think I agree with him in a way," I said.
es_translation: —The truth is that I think I agree with her —I told him.

en: “Yeah, well, it’s a fine idea, but it happens to be bullshit. They’re not trying to spread the black Santa gospel. If they were, they’d make black Santas. Instead, they’re trying to buy the entire world supply. There’s this old guy in Pittsburgh with the second-biggest collection, and they’re always trying to buy it off him.”
vi: “Được thôi, xuất phát là một ý tưởng hay, nhưng thực tế diễn ra thì dẩm dớ. Bố mẹ tôi sẽ không truyền giảng sách phúc âm về ông già Noel da đen đâu. Nếu muốn thế thì họ đã tự làm ra các ông già Noel da đen rồi. Đằng này, họ chỉ tìm cách mua lại từ nguồn cung sẵn có thôi. Có một ông cụ ở Pittsburgh sở hữu bộ sưu tập lớn thứ hai, bố mẹ tôi suốt ngày gạ mua lại bộ sưu tập của ông cụ.”
tr: “Evet, şey, iyi bir fikir ama zırvalık. Ebeveynlerim zenci Nn*| babayı yaymaya çalışmıyor. Öyle olsaydı, zenci Noel baba yaparlarda Bunun yerine dünya stoğunun tamamım satm almaya çalışıyı ular. Pittsburgh’da dünyadaki en büyük ikinci koleksiyona sahip lıif adam var ve sürekli koleksiyonu ondan satm almaya çalışıyorlar,"
es: —Sí, bueno, como idea está bien, pero resulta que es una gilipollez. No pretenden expandir el dogma del Santa Claus negro. Si fuera eso, harían Santa Claus negros. Pero lo que hacen es intentar comprar todas las reservas mundiales. En Pittsburgh hay un viejo que tiene la segunda colección más grande del mundo, y siempre intentan comprársela.
vi_translation: “Alright, starting off is a good idea, but the actual execution is clumsy. My parents are not going to preach the gospel about a black Santa Claus. If they wanted that, they would have created black Santa Clauses themselves. Instead, they are just trying to buy from the existing supply. There is an old man in Pittsburgh who owns the second largest collection, and my parents are always trying to buy his collection.”
tr_translation: “Well, it's a good idea but nonsense. My parents are not trying to spread the black Santa Claus. If they were, they would make a black Santa Claus, but instead, they are trying to buy the entire world stock. There is a man in Pittsburgh who has the second largest collection in the world, and they are constantly trying to buy the collection from him,"
es_translation: —Yes, well, as an idea it's fine, but it turns out to be nonsense. They don't intend to expand the dogma of a black Santa Claus. If that were the case, they would make black Santa Clauses. But what they do is try to buy all the world's reserves. In Pittsburgh, there's an old man who has the second largest collection in the world, and they always try to buy it from him.

en: Ben spoke from the doorway. He’d been there a while, apparently. “Radar, your failure to bop that lovely honeybunny is the greatest humanitarian tragedy of our time.”
vi: Tiếng Ben réo rắt ở ngưỡng cửa, rõ là nó đã đứng đó được một lúc rồi. “Radar ơi, chiến bại trong việc xử nàng thỏ của ông chính là thảm họa nhân đạo khốc liệt nhất trong thời đại của chúng ta.”
tr: litMi lui|>ı ('. şiğinden seslendi. Bir süredir oradaydı anlaşılan, o ni'vimli tavşancığa çakmaktaki başarısızlığın çağımızdaki ^liyillı insanlık trajedisi.
es: Ben habló desde la puerta. Al parecer, llevaba un rato allí. —Radar, que no hayas conseguido zumbarte a esa pava es la mayor tragedia humana de nuestro tiempo.
vi_translation: Ben's voice was calling out at the doorway, clearly he had been standing there for a while. "Radar, your failure to handle the bunny lady is the most severe humanitarian disaster of our time."
tr_translation: litMi lui|>ı ('. He called out from the darkness. He had been there for a while, it seemed, the failure to capture that nimble little rabbit being a symbol of our era's human tragedy. "
es_translation: Ben spoke from the door. Apparently, he had been there for a while. —Radar, the fact that you haven't managed to hook up with that chick is the greatest human tragedy of our time.

en: “What’s up, Ben?” I said.
vi: “Lèm bèm gì thế Ben?” tôi hỏi.
tr: “Namlımı, Ben?” dedim.
es: —¿Qué hay, Ben? —le dije.
vi_translation: “What are you doing, Ben?” I asked.
tr_translation: "My reputation, Me?" I said.
es_translation: —What's up, Ben? —I said to him.

en: “Thanks for the ride last night, bro.”
vi: “Cảm ơn chiến hữu đêm qua đã xế tôi về nhà nhá.”
tr: "Ibin p. coo eve bıraktığın için teşekkürler, kardeşim.
es: —Gracias por llevarme a casa anoche, colega.
vi_translation: “Thanks, comrade, for giving me a ride home last night.”
tr_translation: "Thank you for leaving the package, brother."
es_translation: —Thanks for taking me home last night, buddy.

en: Even though we only had a week before finals, I spent Monday afternoon reading “Song of Myself.” I’d wanted to go to the last two pseudovisions, but Ben needed his car. I was no longer looking for clues in the poem so much as I was looking for Margo herself. I’d made it about halfway through “Song of Myself” this time when I stumbled into another section that I found myself reading and rereading.
vi: Dù chỉ còn một tuần trước kì thi cuối, cả buổi chiều thứ Hai tôi vẫn ngồi đọc “Tự khúc.” Tôi muốn đến nốt hai khu đô thị ma còn lại, nhưng Ben cần đi xe. Tôi không còn tìm kiếm những manh mối trong bài thơ như thể đang tìm kiếm chính Margo nữa. Lần này đọc được nửa chừng “Tự khúc,” tôi sa vào một phần mà tôi cứ trở đi trở lại.
tr: Sınavlara sadece bir hafta kalmasına rağmen, pazartesi gecesini Kendi Şarkım’ı okuyarak geçirdim. Son iki semtimsiye gitmek istemiştim ama arabayı Ben’in kullanması gerekiyordu. Artık şiirdeki ipuçlarını Margo’nun kendisini aradığım kadar aramıyordum. Kendimi tekrar tekrar okurken bulduğum başka bir bölüme geldiğimde, Kendi Şarkını \ bu sefer yarılamayı başarmıştım.
es: Aunque solo faltaba una semana para los exámenes finales, pasé la tarde del lunes leyendo el «Canto de mí mismo». Quería ir a las dos últimas pseudovisiones, pero Ben necesitaba su coche. Ya no buscaba pistas en el poema tanto como intentaba sobre todo buscar a la propia Margo. Esa vez había leído más o menos la mitad del «Canto de mí mismo» cuando me encontré con otra parte que me descubrí a mí mismo leyendo y releyendo.
vi_translation: Even though there was only one week left before the final exam, I still spent the entire Monday afternoon reading "Song of Myself." I wanted to visit the remaining two ghost towns, but Ben needed the car. I was no longer searching for clues in the poem as if I were searching for Margo herself. This time, halfway through reading "Song of Myself," I got stuck on a part that I kept coming back to.
tr_translation: Despite only one week remaining until the exams, I spent Monday night reading My Own Song. I had wanted to go to the last two semi-districts, but Ben had to drive the car. I was no longer searching for clues in the poem as much as I was searching for Margo herself. When I reached another section that I found myself reading over and over again, I had managed to get halfway through My Own Song this time.
es_translation: Although there was only one week left until the final exams, I spent Monday afternoon reading "Song of Myself." I wanted to go to the last two pseudovisions, but Ben needed his car. I was no longer looking for clues in the poem as much as I was mostly trying to find Margo herself. This time I had read about half of "Song of Myself" when I came across another part that I found myself reading and rereading.

en: “I think I will do nothing for a long time but listen,” Whitman writes. And then for two pages, he’s just hearing: hearing a steam whistle, hearing people’s voices, hearing an opera. He sits on the grass and lets the sound pour through him. And this is what I was trying to do, too, I guess: to listen to all the little sounds of her, because before any of it could make sense, it had to be heard. For so long, I hadn’t really heard Margo—I’d seen her screaming and thought her laughing—that now I figured it was my job. To try, even at this great remove, to hear the opera of her.
vi: “Ta nghĩ thời gian dài trước mắt ta sẽ chỉ lắng nghe,” Whitman viết như vậy. Và hai trang tiếp theo, ông chỉ nghe thôi: nghe suối róc rách, nghe tiếng người, nghe hòa nhạc opera. Ông ngồi trên cỏ và để âm thanh tràn qua mình. Có lẽ đấy cũng là điều tôi đang cố thực hiện: lắng nghe tất cả những âm thanh tinh tế nhất của cô ấy, vì trước khi hiểu được, thì phải nghe thấy đã. Đã quá lâu rồi, tôi không thực sự nghe thấy Margo–tôi đã thấy cô ấy la hét và ngỡ rằng cô ấy đang cười–nhưng giờ tôi nhận ra đó là việc cần làm. Cố gắng, thậm chí từ khoảng cách xa xôi diệu vợi này, nghe thấy bản opera của Margo.
tr: “Sanırım uzun bir süre dinlemekten başka hiçbir şey yapmayacağım,” diye yazıyor Whitman. Sonra iki sayfa boyunca sadece duyuyor: bir buharın ıslığım duyuyor, insanların sesini duyuyor, bir opera duyuyor. Çimenin üstünde oturuyor ve seslerin içinden geçip gitmesine izin veriyor. Ve bu benim de yapmaya çalıştığım şey sanırım: Margo’nun bütün küçük seslerini dinlemek. Çünkü hepsi bir şey ifade etmeden önce, duyulmak. Uzun süredir Margo’yu gerçekten duymamıştımonun çığlık attığım görmüş ve güldüğünü sanmıştımve şu anda bunun, bu muazzam uzaklıktan bile, onun operasım duymaya çalışmanın benim işim olduğunu anhyordum.
es: «Ahora no haré otra cosa que escuchar», escribe Whitman. Y en las dos páginas siguientes solo escucha: el pito de vapor, el sonido de la voz humana, el coro de la ópera… Se sienta en la hierba y deja que el sonido penetre en su cuerpo. Y eso es lo que también intentaba yo, supongo: escuchar todos los pequeños sonidos de Margo, porque antes de que alguno de ellos pudiera tener sentido había que escucharlo. Durante mucho tiempo no había escuchado realmente a Margo —la había visto gritando y había pensado que estaba riéndose—, y entonces descubría que era eso lo que tenía que hacer. Intentar, aun cuando nos separara una enorme distancia, escuchar su ópera.
vi_translation: “I think for a long time ahead, I will just listen,” Whitman wrote. And for the next two pages, he just listened: to the babbling brook, to people's voices, to the opera music. He sat on the grass and let the sounds wash over him. Perhaps that is also what I am trying to do: listen to all her most subtle sounds, because before understanding, one must first hear. It has been too long since I truly heard Margo—I saw her screaming and thought she was laughing—but now I realize that listening is what needs to be done. Trying, even from this vast distance, to hear Margo's opera.
tr_translation: “I guess I will do nothing for a long time but listen,” writes Whitman. Then for two pages, he just hears: he hears the whistle of a steam, he hears the voices of people, he hears an opera. He sits on the grass and lets the sounds pass through him. And I guess that’s what I’m trying to do too: listen to all of Margo’s little sounds. Because before they mean anything, they must be heard. I hadn’t really heard Margo for a long time—I had seen her scream and thought she laughed—and now I understood that it was my job, even from this immense distance, to try to hear her opera.
es_translation: “Now I will do nothing but listen,” writes Whitman. And on the next two pages, he only listens: the steam whistle, the sound of the human voice, the opera chorus… He sits on the grass and lets the sound penetrate his body. And that is what I was also trying to do, I suppose: to listen to all the little sounds of Margo, because before any of them could make sense, they had to be listened to. For a long time, I had not really listened to Margo—I had seen her shouting and thought she was laughing—and then I discovered that this was what I had to do. To try, even when separated by a great distance, to listen to her opera.

en: If I couldn’t hear Margo, I could at least listen to what she once heard, so I downloaded the album of Woody Guthrie covers. I sat at the computer, my eyes closed, elbows against the desk, and listened to a voice singing in a minor key. I tried to hear, inside a song I’d never heard before, the voice I had trouble remembering after twelve days.
vi: Nếu không nghe được Margo, ít nhất tôi có thể nghe những gì cô ấy từng nghe. Tôi bèn tải album những bản hát lại ca khúc của Woody Guthrie. Tôi ngồi bên máy tính, nhắm mắt, khuỷu tay tì lên bàn, lắng nghe giọng hát ở cung thứ. Tôi cố gắng nghe, trong bài hát tôi chưa từng nghe, một giọng nói tôi bắt đầu thấy khó nhớ sau mười hai ngày.
tr: Eğer Margo’yu duyamıyorsam, en azından onun bir zamanlar duyduğu şeyi dinleyebilirdim, bu yüzden Woody Guthrie şarkılarının yeniden düzenlendiği albümleri indirdim. Bilgisayarın başına oturdum, gözlerim kapalı, dirseklerim masaya dayalı halde, şarkı söyleyen sesi dinledim. Daha önce hiç duymadığım bir şarkının içinde, on iki gün sonra hatırlamakta zorluk çektiğim o sesi duymaya çalıştım.
es: Ya que no podía oír a Margo, al menos podía oír lo que ella había oído alguna vez, así que me descargué el álbum de versiones de Woody Guthrie. Me senté ante el ordenador, con los ojos cerrados y los codos en la mesa, y escuché una voz cantando con un tono menor. Intenté escuchar, en una canción que no había escuchado antes, la voz que después de doce días me costaba recordar.
vi_translation: If I couldn't hear Margo, at least I could hear what she used to hear. So I downloaded an album of Woody Guthrie cover songs. I sat by the computer, closed my eyes, elbows resting on the table, listening to the voice in the minor key. I tried to hear, in a song I had never heard before, a voice I was beginning to find hard to remember after twelve days.
tr_translation: If I couldn't hear Margo, at least I could listen to what she once heard, so I downloaded albums where Woody Guthrie's songs were rearranged. I sat at the computer, eyes closed, elbows resting on the table, listening to the singing voice. In a song I had never heard before, I tried to hear that voice which I struggled to remember twelve days later.
es_translation: Since I couldn't hear Margo, at least I could hear what she had once heard, so I downloaded the Woody Guthrie cover album. I sat in front of the computer, with my eyes closed and my elbows on the table, and listened to a voice singing in a minor key. I tried to listen, in a song I hadn't heard before, to the voice that after twelve days was hard for me to remember.

en: I was still listening—but now to another of her favorites, Bob Dylan—when my mom got home. “Dad’s gonna be late,” she said through the closed door. “I thought I might make turkey burgers?”
vi: Tôi vẫn đang nghe nhạc–bây giờ là một ca sĩ yêu thích khác của Margo, Bob Dylan–thì thấy mẹ về. “Hôm nay bố về muộn,” mẹ nói qua cửa phòng tôi vẫn đóng. “Mẹ làm bánh kẹp thịt gà tây nhé?”
tr: Annem eve geldiğinde hâlâ dinliyordum... ama artık bir başka favorisini, Bob Dylan’ı. “Baban geç gelecek,” dedi annem kapalı kapının arkasından. “Hindi köftesi yapabilirim diye düşündüm ama?..
es: Seguía escuchando, en ese momento otro de sus favoritos, Bob Dylan, cuando mi madre llegó a casa. —Papá llegará tarde —me dijo desde el otro lado de la puerta cerrada—. Estaba pensando en hacer hamburguesas de pavo.
vi_translation: I was still listening to music–now it was another one of Margo's favorite singers, Bob Dylan–when I saw Mom come home. "Dad will be home late today," she said through my still-closed door. "Shall I make turkey sandwiches?"
tr_translation: I was still listening when my mother came home... but now to another of her favorites, Bob Dylan. "Your father will be late," my mother said from behind the closed door. "I thought I could make turkey meatballs, but?.."
es_translation: I was still listening, at that moment another of his favorites, Bob Dylan, when my mother arrived home. —Dad will arrive late —she told me from the other side of the closed door—. I was thinking of making turkey burgers.

en: “Sounds good,” I answered, and then closed my eyes again and listened to the music. I didn’t sit up again until Dad called me for dinner an album and a half later.
vi: “Vâng, ngon ạ,” tôi đáp, rồi lại nhắm mắt nghe nhạc. Nghe thêm một album rưỡi nữa, tôi mới đứng lên khi bố gọi ra ăn tối.
tr: “Gayet güzel,” diye cevapladım, sonra tekrar gözlerimi kapayıp müziği dinledim. Babam ikinci albümün yarısına geldiğim sırada beni yemeğe çağırana kadar oturduğum yerde doğrulmadım.
es: —Suena bien —le contesté. Volví a cerrar los ojos y a escuchar la música. No me levanté de la silla hasta que mi padre me llamó para cenar, un álbum y medio después.
vi_translation: “Yes, it's delicious,” I replied, then closed my eyes to listen to music again. After listening to another one and a half albums, I got up when my father called me for dinner.
tr_translation: “Very nice,” I replied, then I closed my eyes again and listened to the music. I didn't straighten up from where I was sitting until my father called me for dinner when I was halfway through the second album.
es_translation: —Sounds good —I replied. I closed my eyes again and listened to the music. I didn't get up from the chair until my father called me for dinner, an album and a half later.

en: At dinner, Mom and Dad were talking about politics in the Middle East. Even though they completely agreed with each other, they still managed to yell about it, saying that so-and-so was a liar, and so-and-so was a liar and a thief, and that the lot of them should resign. I focused on the turkey burger, which was excellent, dripping with ketchup and smothered with grilled onions.
vi: Bữa tối, bố mẹ nói chuyện tình hình chính trị Trung Đông. Dù hoàn toàn đồng quan điểm với nhau, nhưng cả hai vẫn lớn tiếng chỉ trích, thế-này-thế-kia là đồ dối trá, thế-này-thế-kia là quân bịp bợm và cướp bóc, và rằng cả đám nên từ chức đi cho rồi. Tôi chăm chú vào bánh kẹp thịt gà tây, ngon tuyệt, đẫm tương cà chua và hành nướng thơm lừng.
tr: Yemekte annem ile babam Ortadoğu politikaları hakkında konuşuyorlardı. Birbirleriyle tamamen aynı fikirde olmalarına rağmen falancanın yalancı, filancanın yalancı ve hırsız olduğunu ve bunların çoğunun istifa etmesi gerektiğini söyleyerek bağırmayı yine de başarabiliyorlardı. Ketçap sürülmüş ve soğanlarla kaplanmış haliyle nefis olan hindi köftesine odaklandım.
es: Durante la cena mis padres hablaron de la política de Oriente Próximo. Aunque estaban perfectamente de acuerdo, se dedicaban a hablar a grito pelado y decir que fulano era un mentiroso, que mengano era un mentiroso y un ladrón, y que casi todos ellos debían dimitir. Me centré en la hamburguesa de pavo, que estaba buenísima, bañada en ketchup y cubierta de cebolla frita.
vi_translation: During dinner, my parents talked about the political situation in the Middle East. Even though they completely agreed with each other, they still loudly criticized, saying this-and-that was deceitful, this-and-that was fraudulent and thieving, and that the whole bunch should just resign already. I focused on my turkey sandwich, which was absolutely delicious, drenched in ketchup and fragrant grilled onions.
tr_translation: At dinner, my mom and dad were talking about Middle Eastern politics. Despite being in complete agreement with each other, they still managed to shout that so-and-so is a liar, so-and-so is a liar and a thief, and that most of them should resign. I focused on the turkey meatball, which was delicious with ketchup and covered in onions.
es_translation: During dinner, my parents talked about Middle Eastern politics. Although they were in complete agreement, they were yelling at the top of their lungs, saying that so-and-so was a liar, that so-and-so was a liar and a thief, and that almost all of them should resign. I focused on the turkey burger, which was delicious, drenched in ketchup and topped with fried onions.

en: “Okay, enough,” my mom said after a while. “Quentin, how was your day?”
vi: “Thôi, dừng ở đây nhé,” mẹ chốt lại sau hồi bàn luận. “Ngày hôm nay ra sao hả Quentin?”
tr: “Tamam, yeter,” dedi annem bir süre sonra. “Quentin, günün nasıldı?
es: —Bueno, basta —dijo mi madre al rato—. Quentin, ¿cómo te ha ido el día?
vi_translation: “Alright, let's stop here,” Mom concluded after a discussion. "How was today, Quentin?"
tr_translation: “Alright, that's enough,” said my mother after a while. “Quentin, how was your day?”
es_translation: —Well, that's enough —said my mother after a while—. Quentin, how was your day?

en: “Fine,” I said. “Getting ready for finals, I guess.”
vi: “Ổn ạ,” tôi đáp. “Sẵn sàng đi thi, con nghĩ thế ạ.”
tr: “iyi,” dedim. “Sınavlara hazırlanıyorum sanırım.
es: —Muy bien —le contesté—. Preparándome para los exámenes finales, supongo.
vi_translation: "I'm fine," I replied. "Ready for the exam, I think."
tr_translation: “Good,” I said. “I guess I'm preparing for the exams.”
es_translation: —Very well —I replied—. Preparing for the final exams, I suppose.

en: “I can’t believe this is your last week of classes,” Dad said. “It really does just seem like yesterday . . .”
vi: “Không tin nổi là con đi học tuần cuối ở trường,” bố nói. “Thực sự chỉ mới như hôm qua thôi...
tr: “Bunun okulunun son haftası olduğuna inanamıyorum,” dedi babam. “Gerçekten dünmüş gibi geliyor...
es: —No me puedo creer que sea tu última semana de clases —dijo mi padre—. Parece que fue ayer…
vi_translation: “I can't believe you're going to school for the last week,” Dad said. “It really feels like just yesterday...”
tr_translation: “I can't believe this is the last week of his school,” said my dad. “It really feels like it was just yesterday...”
es_translation: —I can't believe it's your last week of classes —said my father—. It seems like it was just yesterday…

en: “It does,” Mom said. A voice in my head was like: WARNING NOSTALGIA ALERT WARNING WARNING WARNING. Great people, my parents, but prone to bouts of crippling sentimentality.
vi: “Đúng vậy,” mẹ bùi ngùi. Một giọng nói trong đầu tôi đang gào lên: CẢNH BÁO CÓ NGƯỜI HOÀI CỔ CẢNH BÁO CẢNH BÁO CẢNH BÁO. Bố mẹ tôi tốt nhất quả đất, hiềm nỗi dễ mủi lòng xúc động sến sẩm kinh lên được.
tr: “Öyle,” dedi annem. Kafamda bir ses bağırmaya başladı: UYARI NOSTALJİ ALARMI, UYARI UYARI UYARI. Ebeveynlerim harika insanlar ama felç edici aşırı duygusallık gösterilerine meyilliler.
es: —Sí —dijo mi madre. En mi cabeza una voz dijo: ATENCIÓN NOSTALGIA ALERTA ATENCIÓN ATENCIÓN ATENCIÓN. Mis padres son buena gente, pero con tendencia a ataques de ingente sentimentalismo.
vi_translation: “That's right,” my mother said wistfully. A voice in my head was screaming: WARNING NOSTALGIA ALERT WARNING WARNING WARNING. My parents are the best in the world, but they are easily moved and sentimentally cheesy to an extreme.
tr_translation: “Yes,” said my mother. A voice in my head started shouting: WARNING NOSTALGIA ALARM, WARNING WARNING WARNING. My parents are wonderful people but they tend to show paralyzing displays of excessive sentimentality.
es_translation: —Yes —said my mother. In my head, a voice said: ATTENTION NOSTALGIA ALERT ATTENTION ATTENTION ATTENTION. My parents are good people, but prone to bouts of immense sentimentalism.

en: “We’re just very proud of you,” she said. “But, God, we’ll miss you next fall.”
vi: “Bố mẹ rất tự hào về con,” mẹ nói. “Nhưng Chúa ơi, mùa thu sang năm bố mẹ sẽ nhớ con lắm.”
tr: “Seninle gurur duyuyoruz,” dedi annem. “Tannm, önümüzdeki sonbaharda seni özleyeceğiz.
es: —Estamos muy orgullosos de ti —dijo mi madre—, pero, Dios, te echaremos de menos el próximo otoño.
vi_translation: “Your father and I are very proud of you,” said Mom. “But oh my God, we will miss you so much next fall.”
tr_translation: "We are proud of you," said my mother. "My God, we will miss you next fall."
es_translation: —We are very proud of you —said my mother—, but, God, we will miss you next fall.

en: “Yeah, well, don’t speak too soon. I could still fail English.”
vi: “Ơ, vâng, nhưng cũng không nói quá sớm được. Có khi con trượt môn Quốc ngữ đấy ạ.
tr: “Evet, şey, fazla erken konuşmayın. Hâlâ edebiyattan kalabilirim.
es: —Sí, bueno, no habléis antes de tiempo. Todavía puedo suspender literatura.
vi_translation: “Oh, yes, but it's also too early to say. I might fail the National Language subject.”
tr_translation: “Yes, well, don't speak too soon. I can still fail literature.”
es_translation: —Yes, well, don't speak too soon. I can still fail literature.

en: My mom laughed, and then said, “Oh, guess who I saw at the YMCA yesterday? Betty Parson. She said Chuck was going to the University of Georgia next fall. I was pleased for him; he’s always struggled.”
vi: Mẹ bật cười, rồi nói, “À, con có biết hôm qua mẹ gặp ai ở Hiệp Hội Thanh Niên Cơ-đốc không? Cô Betty Parson đấy. Cô ấy nói là mùa thu tới Chuck sẽ vào Đại học Georgia. Mẹ mừng cho Chuck, thằng bé đã nỗ lực nhiều.
tr: Annem güldü ve sonra; “Ah, dün Genç Hristiyan Erkekler Birliği’nde kimi gördüm tahmin et? Betty Parson. Gelecek sonbahar Chuck’m Georgia Üniversitesi’ne gideceğini söyledi. Onun için sevindim; hep mücadele etti.
es: Mi madre se rió y luego dijo: —Ah, adivina a quién vi ayer en la Asociación de Jóvenes Cristianos. A Betty Parson. Me dijo que Chuck irá a la Universidad de Georgia en otoño. Me alegré por él. Siempre ha luchado mucho.
vi_translation: Mom laughed, then said, "Oh, do you know who I met yesterday at the Christian Youth Association? It was Ms. Betty Parson. She said that this fall Chuck will be going to the University of Georgia. I'm happy for Chuck, the boy has put in a lot of effort."
tr_translation: My mom laughed and then said, "Ah, guess who I saw at the Young Men's Christian Association yesterday? Betty Parson. She said that Chuck will be going to Georgia University next fall. I'm happy for him; he always struggled."
es_translation: My mother laughed and then said: —Ah, guess who I saw yesterday at the Young Men's Christian Association. Betty Parson. She told me that Chuck is going to the University of Georgia in the fall. I was happy for him. He has always struggled a lot.

en: “He’s an asshole,” I said.
vi: “Nó chỉ được cái thúi hoắc thôi mà mẹ,” tôi nói.
tr: “Göt herifin teki,” dedim.
es: —Es un gilipollas —dije.
vi_translation: “It just stinks, Mom,” I said.
tr_translation: "What an idiot," I said.
es_translation: —He's an asshole —I said.

en: “Well,” my dad said, “he was a bully. And his behavior was deplorable.” This was typical of my parents: in their minds, no one was just an asshole. There was always something wrong with people other than just sucking: they had socialization disorders, or borderline personality syndrome, or whatever.
vi: “Chậc,” bố nói, “Chuck hay bắt nạt các bạn. Hành vi như thế cần được uốn nắn.” Đúng kiểu suy nghĩ của bố mẹ tôi: trong mắt họ, không có ai chỉ được cái thúi hoắc cả. Luôn có gì đó không ổn đối với mọi người, không phải tại họ bẩm sinh xấu xa: họ bị rối loạn giao tiếp xã hội, hội chứng nhân cách kẻ bên lề, đại khái thế.
tr: “Şey,” dedi babam, “zorbaydı. Ve davranışları içler acısıydı.” Bu ebeveynlerimin tipik haliydi: Onlara göre, kimse sadece boktan değildi, insanlarda sadece berbat olmaktan başka yanlış olan bir şeyler vardı: Sosyal adaptasyon bozuklukları vardı... ya da kişilik bozuklukları vardı ya da her neyse.
es: —Bueno —dijo mi padre—, era un matón. Y su conducta era deplorable. Típico de mis padres. Para ellos nadie era sencillamente un gilipollas. A la gente siempre le pasaba algo que iba más allá de ser un capullo: tenían trastornos de socialización, o trastorno límite de personalidad, o lo que sea.
vi_translation: "Sigh," Dad said, "Chuck often bullies his friends. Such behavior needs to be corrected." That's exactly how my parents think: in their eyes, no one is just plain bad. There is always something wrong with everyone, not because they are inherently evil: they have social communication disorders, borderline personality syndrome, something like that.
tr_translation: “Well,” said my father, “he was a bully. And his behavior was deplorable.” This was typical of my parents: According to them, no one was just lousy, there was always something else wrong with people besides just being awful: They had social adaptation disorders... or personality disorders or whatever.
es_translation: —Well —said my father—, he was a bully. And his behavior was deplorable. Typical of my parents. For them, no one was simply an asshole. People always had something going on that went beyond being a jerk: they had socialization disorders, or borderline personality disorder, or whatever.

en: My mom picked up the thread. “But Chuck has learning difficulties. He has all kinds of problems—just like anyone. I know it’s impossible for you to see peers this way, but when you’re older, you start to see them—the bad kids and the good kids and all kids—as people. They’re just people, who deserve to be cared for. Varying degrees of sick, varying degrees of neurotic, varying degrees of self-actualized. But you know, I always liked Betty, and I always had hopes for Chuck. So it’s good that he’s going to college, don’t you think?”
vi: Mẹ tiếp tục câu chuyện, “Nhưng Chuck có khó khăn trong khi học. Thằng bé gặp đủ vấn đề–như bất cứ ai. Mẹ biết bây giờ con không nhìn nhận bạn bè theo cách đó, nhưng khi nào trưởng thành hơn, con bắt đầu nhìn ra được–đứa ngoan, đứa hư, tất cả đám bạn bè–đều là con người. Đều là những người đáng được quan tâm. Với những mức độ khác nhau về thể trạng, tâm lí, khả năng hiện thực hóa bản thân. Nhưng con biết đấy, mẹ luôn mến cô Betty Parson, luôn đặt hi vọng vào Chuck. Cho nên thằng bé sẽ vào đại học là chuyện đáng mừng, con có nghĩ thế không?”
tr: Annem ipleri eline aldı. “Ama Chuck’m öğrenme zorluğu var. Her türlü sorunu var... tıpkı herkes gibi. Akranlarını bu şekilde görmek senin için zor biliyorum ama yaşlandığında onlarıkötü çocukları, iyi çocukları ve bütün çocuklarıinsan olarak görmeye başlarsın. Onlar sadece önemsenmeyi hak eden insanlar. Farklı derecelerde hasta, farklı derecelerde nörotik, farklı derecelerde kendini kanıtlamış. Ama biliyorsun, Betty’den her zaman hoşlandım ve her zaman Chuck için umudum vardı. Yani üniversiteye gidiyor olması iyi, sence de öyle değil mi?
es: Mi madre cogió el hilo. —Pero Chuck tiene dificultades de aprendizaje. Tiene todo tipo de problemas… como cualquiera. Sé que para ti es imposible ver así a tus compañeros, pero cuando te haces mayor, empiezas a verlos (a los malos chicos, a los buenos y a todos) como personas. Son solo personas que merecen cariño. Diferentes niveles de enfermedad, diferentes niveles de neurosis y diferentes niveles de autorrealización. Pero, mira, siempre me ha caído bien Betty y siempre he tenido esperanzas con Chuck. Así que está bien que vaya a la universidad, ¿no crees, Quentin?
vi_translation: Mom continued the story, "But Chuck had difficulties while studying. The boy faced all sorts of problems—like anyone else. I know you don't see your friends that way now, but when you grow older, you'll start to see it—the good ones, the bad ones, all your friends—they're all human. They all deserve to be cared for. With varying levels of physical, psychological, and self-actualization abilities. But you know, I always liked Ms. Betty Parson, always had hope for Chuck. So it's a good thing that the boy is going to college, don't you think?"
tr_translation: My mom took control. “But Chuck has learning difficulties. He has all sorts of problems... just like everyone else. I know it's hard for you to see your peers this way, but when you get older, you'll start to see the bad kids, the good kids, and all the kids as people. They are just people who deserve to be cared about. Different degrees of sick, different degrees of neurotic, different degrees of accomplished. But you know, I've always liked Betty and I've always had hope for Chuck. So it's good that he's going to college, don't you think?”
es_translation: My mother took the thread. —But Chuck has learning difficulties. He has all kinds of problems... like anyone else. I know it's impossible for you to see your classmates that way, but when you get older, you start to see them (the bad kids, the good ones, and everyone) as people. They are just people who deserve affection. Different levels of illness, different levels of neurosis, and different levels of self-actualization. But, look, I've always liked Betty and I've always had hopes for Chuck. So it's okay for him to go to college, don't you think, Quentin?

en: “Honestly, Mom, I don’t really care about him one way or another.” But I did think, if everyone is such a person, how come Mom and Dad still hated all the politicians in Israel and Palestine? They didn’t talk about them like they were people.
vi: “Mẹ ơi, thật ra con không thực sự quan tâm đến nó, bổ ngang hay bổ dọc cũng thế thôi ạ.” Nhưng tôi có nghĩ rằng, nếu ai cũng là con người, sao bố mẹ vẫn bức xúc đám chính khách ở Israel và Palestine nhỉ? Bố mẹ không nói về họ như thể họ cũng là con người.
tr: “Doğrusu, anne, öyle ya da böyle onu gerçekten umursamıyorum.” Ama şunu düşündüm, eğer herkes sadece insansa, nasıl oluyor da annemle babam hâlâ İsrail ve Filistin’deki bütün politikacılardan nefret edebiliyorlardı? Onlar hakkında insanmış gibi konuşmuyorlardı.
es: —Sinceramente, mamá, no me importa lo más mínimo. Pero pensé que si todo el mundo somos personas, ¿por qué mis padres odiaban tanto a los políticos de Israel y de Palestina? No hablaban de ellos como si fueran personas.
vi_translation: “Mom, actually I don't really care about it, whether it's cut horizontally or vertically, it's the same to me.” But I do wonder, if everyone is human, why are my parents still upset about the politicians in Israel and Palestine? My parents don't talk about them as if they are human too.
tr_translation: "Honestly, mom, one way or another, I don't really care about him." But I thought, if everyone is just human, how is it that my mom and dad still hated all the politicians in Israel and Palestine? They didn't talk about them as if they were human.
es_translation: —Honestly, mom, I don't care in the slightest. But I thought that if everyone is a person, why did my parents hate the politicians of Israel and Palestine so much? They didn't talk about them as if they were people.

en: My dad finished chewing something and then put his fork down and looked at me. “The longer I do my job,” he said, “the more I realize that humans lack good mirrors. It’s so hard for anyone to show us how we look, and so hard for us to show anyone how we feel.”
vi: Bố ngừng nhai gì đó, đặt dĩa xuống và nhìn tôi. “Càng làm việc,” bố nói, “bố càng nhận ra rằng con người thiếu những cái gương chuẩn. Thật khó để ai đó cho ta thấy trông ta thực sự thế nào, và thật khó để chính ta cho người khác hay ta cảm thấy ra sao.”
tr: Babam bir şeyleri çiğnemeyi bitirdi ve sonra çatalını indirip bana baktı. “İşimi ne kadar uzun süre yaparsam,” dedi, “insanların iyi aynalardan yoksun olduklarını o kadar fark ediyorum. Birinin bize nasıl göründüğümüzü göstermesi öyle zor ve bizim de birine nasıl hissettiğimizi göstermemiz öyle zor ki.
es: Mi padre terminó de masticar algo, dejó el tenedor en la mesa y me miró. —Cuanto más tiempo llevo en mi trabajo —me dijo—, más cuenta me doy de que los seres humanos carecemos de buenos espejos. Es muy difícil para cualquiera mostrarnos cómo se nos ve, y para nosotros mostrar a cualquiera cómo nos sentimos.
vi_translation: Dad stopped chewing something, put down the fork, and looked at me. "The more I work," Dad said, "the more I realize that people lack proper mirrors. It's really hard for someone to show us how we truly look, and it's really hard for us to tell others how we feel."
tr_translation: My father finished chewing something and then put down his fork and looked at me. "The longer I do my job," he said, "the more I realize that people lack good mirrors. It's so hard for someone to show us how we look and for us to show someone how we feel."
es_translation: My father finished chewing something, put the fork on the table, and looked at me. —The longer I work at my job —he told me—, the more I realize that human beings lack good mirrors. It is very difficult for anyone to show us how we are seen, and for us to show anyone how we feel.

en: “That is really lovely,” my mom said. I liked that they liked each other. “But isn’t it also that on some fundamental level we find it difficult to understand that other people are human beings in the same way that we are? We idealize them as gods or dismiss them as animals.”
vi: “Nghe hay quá anh ạ,” mẹ nói. Tôi thích kiểu bố mẹ tôi thích nhau như vậy. “Nhưng chẳng phải sâu xa trong lòng, ta thấy khó có thể hiểu được rằng những người khác là con người như chính ta cũng là con người sao? Ta lí tưởng hóa họ thành thánh thần hoặc liệt họ vào hàng động vật.”
tr: “Bu gerçekten çok hoş,” dedi annem. Birbirlerinden hoşlanmaları hoşuma gidiyordu. “Ama temelde, diğer insanların da bizim gibi insan olduğunu anlamak bize zor gelmiyor mu? Onları Tanrı olarak idealleştiriyor ya da hayvan olarak reddediyoruz.
es: —Muy bonito —dijo mi madre. Me gustaba que se gustaran entre sí—. Pero, en el fondo, ¿no es eso también lo que hace tan difícil que entendamos que los demás son seres humanos exactamente igual que nosotros? Los idealizamos como dioses o los descartamos como animales.
vi_translation: “It sounds so good,” Mom said. I like how my parents like each other like that. “But isn't it true that deep down, we find it hard to understand that others are human just as we are human? We idealize them as gods or categorize them as animals.”
tr_translation: “This is really nice,” said my mother. I liked that they liked each other. “But fundamentally, isn't it difficult for us to understand that other people are human just like us? We idealize them as gods or reject them as animals.”
es_translation: —Very beautiful —said my mother. I liked that they liked each other—. But, deep down, isn't that also what makes it so difficult for us to understand that others are human beings exactly like us? We idealize them as gods or discard them as animals.

en: “True. Consciousness makes for poor windows, too. I don’t think I’d ever thought about it quite that way.”
vi: “Đúng đấy. Nhận thức cũng làm nên những cửa sổ méo mó. Có lẽ anh đã không nghĩ nhiều theo hướng đó.
tr: “Doğru. Bilinç dar pencerelere de yol açıyor. Bunun hakkında hiç bu şekilde düşündüğümü sanmıyorum.
es: —Cierto. La conciencia también cierra ventanas. Creo que nunca lo había pensado en este sentido.
vi_translation: "That's right. Perception also creates distorted windows. Perhaps you haven't thought much in that direction."
tr_translation: “Correct. Consciousness also leads to narrow windows. I don't think I've ever thought about it this way.”
es_translation: —True. Consciousness also closes windows. I think I had never thought about it in this sense.

en: I was sitting back. I was listening. And I was hearing something about her and about windows and mirrors. Chuck Parson was a person. Like me. Margo Roth Spiegelman was a person, too. And I had never quite thought of her that way, not really; it was a failure of all my previous imaginings. All along—not only since she left, but for a decade before—I had been imagining her without listening, without knowing that she made as poor a window as I did. And so I could not imagine her as a person who could feel fear, who could feel isolated in a roomful of people, who could be shy about her record collection because it was too personal to share. Someone who might read travel books to escape having to live in the town that so many people escape to. Someone who—because no one thought she was a person—had no one to really talk to.
vi: Tôi ngồi sau. Tôi đang lắng nghe. Và tôi nghe thấy gì đó về cô ấy, những ô cửa sổ và gương. Chuck Parson là một con người. Giống như tôi. Margo Roth Spiegelman cũng là một con người. Và tôi chưa từng nghĩ về cô ấy theo cách đó, chưa thực sự; đó là sự thất bại của tất cả những tưởng tượng trước đây của tôi. Suốt thời gian dài–không chỉ sau khi cô ấy bỏ đi, mà cả thập kỉ trước đó–tôi đã tưởng tượng về Margo mà không lắng nghe, không biết rằng ô cửa sổ cô ấy dựng lên cũng dở ẹc như tôi. Do vậy, tôi không hình dung được cô ấy là một con người có thể cũng cảm thấy sợ hãi, cảm thấy bị cô lập giữa chốn đông người, xấu hổ cất giữ bộ sưu tập đĩa nhạc vì nó quá riêng tư để có thể chia sẻ được. Một người có thể đã đọc các cuốn sách du dịch để thoát khỏi đời sống ở một thành phố nơi có quá nhiều người đổ xô đến. Một người–vì không ai nghĩ rằng cô ấy là một con người–chẳng có ai thực sự nói chuyện cùng.
tr: Arkama yaslanıyordum. Dinliyordum. Ve Margo’ya dair, pencereler ve aynalarla ilgili bir şeyler duyuyordum. Chuck Parson bir insandı. Benim gibi. Margo Roth Spiegelman da bir insandı. Ve onun hakkında hiç bu şekilde düşünmemiştim, tam olarak değil; bu önceki bütün tasavvurlarınım başarısızlığıydı. Başından beriyalnızca gittiğinden beri değil, on yıl öncesinden beriMargo’yu, dinlemeden, onun benim kadar dar bir pencere yarattığını bilmeden hayal ediyordum. Ve bu yüzden onu bir insan olarak tasavvur edememiştim; korkabilen, bir oda dolusu insanın içinde dışlanmış hissedebilen, paylaşmak için fazla kişisel olduğundan plak koleksiyonu hakkında çekingen olabilen bir insan. Bir sürü insanın kaçtığı şehirde yaşamaya kaçabilmek için seyahat rehberleri okuyabilen biri. Kimse onun bir insan olduğunu düşünmediği için gerçekten konuşacak kimsesi olmayan biri.
es: Me apoyé en el respaldo de la silla y escuché. Escuchaba cosas sobre mi madre, sobre ventanas y sobre espejos. Chuck Parson era una persona. Como yo.
