Kasaya geri dönerken birkaç Starburst, bir Twinkies ve sınırsız sayıda GoFast gofreti için duruyorum. Koşarak geri dönüyorum. Ben, mezuniyet cübbesiyle orada durmuş, kadına tişörtleri ve dört dolarlık güneş gözlüğünü uzatıyor. Lacey litrelerce soda, enerji içeceği ve şişelerce suyla koşup geliyor. Büyük şişeler, Ben’in çişinin bile dolduramayacağı türden.
es: Entretanto, corro por los pasillos cogiendo todo lo de mi lista. Lacey está en las bebidas, Ben en los artículos no perecederos, y yo en la comida. Hago un barrido como si fuera un guepardo y las patatas fritas, gacelas heridas. Llevo al mostrador un puñado de bolsas de patatas, cecina y cacahuetes, y luego corro al pasillo de las golosinas. Un puñado de Mentos, un puñado de Snickers y… Oh, no está en la lista, pero lo cojo, me encantan los caramelos Nerds, así que añado tres cajas. Vuelvo atrás y me dirijo al expositor de la charcutería, formado básicamente por sándwiches rancios de pavo en los que el pavo parece jamón. Cojo dos. De vuelta a la caja me detengo para coger un par de paquetes de caramelos Starbursts, un paquete de pastelitos Twinkies y una indeterminada cantidad de barritas GoFast. Vuelvo a la caja. Ben, con su toga de graduación, le tiende a la mujer camisetas y gafas de sol de cuatro dólares. Lacey corre con litros de refrescos, bebidas energéticas y agua. Botellas grandes, de las que ni siquiera Ben puede llenar de una meada.
vi_translation: Meanwhile, I ran along the aisles to get the items on my list. Lacey was in charge of drinks, Ben handled non-perishables, and I got the groceries. I swept through the place as if I were a leopard and the packaged chips were a herd of wounded antelopes. I grabbed a bunch of potato chips, beef jerky, and peanuts, ran to the counter, then dashed to the candy section. A handful of Mentos, a handful of Snickers, and—oh, not on the list, but whatever, I like Nerds candy, so I grabbed three packs. I ran back to the checkout counter and continued with fresh food, including classic turkey sandwiches, where the turkey tasted just like bacon. I took two. On the way to the checkout counter, I stopped to grab some Starburst candy and Twinkies, plus an indeterminate amount of GoFast nutrition bars. I ran to the counter. Ben was standing there in his graduation gown, checking out a t-shirt and four-dollar sunglasses. Lacey ran over with several gallons of soda, energy drinks, and bottled water. Big bottles, the kind that even Ben's urine couldn't fill up.
tr_translation: Meanwhile, I am running between the aisles, grabbing the items on my list. Lacey is in the beverages section; Ben is in the durable goods section; and I am in the food section. I am sweeping through the market like a cheetah, devouring chips like they are wounded gazelles. With an armful of chips, dried meat, and peanuts, I run to the front register, then head back to the candy aisle. A handful of Mentos, a handful of Snickers, and... Oh, it's not on the list but who cares, I love Nerds... So I add three packs of Nerds. I run again and then head towards the appetizer section filled with ancient turkey sandwiches, where the turkey inside resembles ham too much. I take two. On my way back to the checkout, I stop for a few Starbursts, a Twinkies, and an unlimited number of GoFast wafers. I run back. There I am, standing in my graduation gown, handing the woman the t-shirts and the four-dollar sunglasses. is extending. Lacey comes running with liters of soda, energy drinks, and bottles of water. Large bottles, the kind that even Ben's pee couldn't fill.
es_translation: Meanwhile, I run through the aisles grabbing everything on my list. Lacey is on drinks, Ben on non-perishables, and I'm on food. I sweep through like a cheetah and the chips, wounded gazelles. I bring a handful of bags of chips, jerky, and peanuts to the counter, then run to the candy aisle. A handful of Mentos, a handful of Snickers and... Oh, it's not on the list, but I grab it, I love Nerds candies, so I add three boxes. I go back and head to the deli display, which is basically made up of stale turkey sandwiches where the turkey looks like ham. I grab two. Back at the checkout, I stop to grab a couple of packs of Starbursts, a pack of Twinkies, and an indeterminate amount of GoFast bars. I return to the checkout. Ben, in his graduation gown, hands the woman four-dollar t-shirts and sunglasses. Lacey runs with liters of sodas, energy drinks, and water. Big bottles, the kind that not even Ben could fill with one pee.

en: “ONE MINUTE!” Lacey shouts, and I panic. I’m turning in circles, my eyes darting around the store, trying to remember what I’m forgetting. I glance down at my list. I seem to have everything, but I feel like there’s something important I’ve forgotten. Something. Come on, Jacobsen. Chips, candy, turkey-that-looks-like-ham, pbj, and—what? What are the other food groups? Meat, chips, candy, and, and, and, and cheese! “CRACKERS!” I say, much too loud, and then I dart to the crackers, grabbing cheese crackers and peanut butter crackers and some of Grandma’s peanut butter cookies for good measure, and then I run back and toss them across the counter. The woman has already bagged up four plastic bags of groceries. Almost a hundred dollars total, not even counting gas; I’ll be paying back Lacey’s parents all summer.
vi: “MỘT PHÚT NỮA!” Lacey kêu lên và tôi phát hoảng. Tôi quay mòng mòng, đảo mắt khắp gian hàng, cố nhớ xem mình đã quên gì. Tôi liếc xuống danh mục của mình, có vẻ tôi đã có đủ, nhưng vẫn cảm thấy đang quên thứ gì đó rất quan trọng. Cái gì đó. Nhanh nào, Jacobsen. Khoai tây chiên, kẹo, gà-tây-trông-như-thịt-xông-khói, lạc, thịt bò khô, và–gì nữa? Còn một nhóm đồ ăn nữa là gì nhỉ? Thịt, khoai, kẹo, và, và, và, và pho-mát! “BÁNH QUI RÒN!” Tôi bật ra, hơi to, rồi xẹt đến giá bánh qui ròn, nhặt bánh qui pho-mát, bánh qui bơ lạc, thêm ít bánh bơ lạc hiệu Cụ Bà, rồi chạy lại và quăng hết xuống quầy. Bác thu ngân đã xếp đồ vào bốn túi. Tất cả khoảng gần một trăm đô-la, chưa kể tiền xăng; tôi sẽ phải trả lại cho bố mẹ Lacey trong cả mùa hè.
tr: “BİR DAKİKA!” diye bağırıyor Lacey ve paniğe kapılıyorum. Daireler çiziyorum, gözlerim dükkânı tarıyor, neyi unuttuğumu hatırlamaya çalışıyorum. Listeme bir göz atıyorum. Her şeyi almışım gibi görünüyor ama unuttuğum önemli bir şey varmış gibi geliyor. Haydi, Jacobserı. Cips, şeker, jambona benzeyen hindi, fiştik ezmesi ve jöleli sandviç ve... ne? Diğer besin grubu ne? Et, cips, şeker ve ve ve peynir! “KRAKER!” diyorum olması gerekenden yüksek sesle ve krakerlere atıhp peynirli kraker, fiştik ezmeli kraker ve fazladan Grandma’s kurabiyelerinden birkaç tane alıyorum, sonra koşarak geri dönüyorum ve elimdekileri kasaya doğru fırlatıyorum. Kadın dört naylon poşeti çoktan doldurmuş. Toplamda neredeyse yüz dolar, benzini bile hesaba katmadan; bu parayı yaz boyunca Lacey’nin ebeveynlerine geri ödeyeceğim.
es: —¡UN MINUTO! —grita Lacey. Casi me da un ataque. Doy vueltas buscando por la tienda, intentando recordar qué he olvidado. Echo un vistazo a mi lista. Parece que está todo, pero me da la impresión de que estoy olvidando algo importante. Algo. «Vamos, Jacobsen». Patatas fritas, golosinas, sándwiches de pavo que parece jamón… ¿y qué más? ¿Qué más tipos de comida hay? Carne, patatas fritas, golosinas y, y, y, ¡y queso! ¡CRACKERS!, exclamo en voz alta. Corro hacia las galletas saladas, cojo varios paquetes con queso y con mantequilla de cacahuete, y unas galletas de la abuela por si acaso, vuelvo corriendo a la caja y lo dejo todo en el mostrador. La mujer ya ha llenado cuatro bolsas de plástico. Casi cien dólares en total, sin contar la gasolina. Tendré que pasarme el verano devolviendo dinero a los padres de Lacey.
vi_translation: “ONE MORE MINUTE!” Lacey shouted, and I panicked. I spun around, eyes darting all over the stall, trying to remember what I had forgotten. I glanced down at my list; it seemed I had everything, but I still felt like I was forgetting something very important. Something. Come on, Jacobsen. Chips, candy, turkey-that-looks-like-bacon, peanuts, beef jerky, and–what else? What was the other food group? Meat, potatoes, candy, and, and, and, and cheese! “CRACKERS!” I blurted out, a bit loudly, then dashed to the cracker aisle, grabbed cheese crackers, peanut butter crackers, added some Grandma’s peanut butter cookies, then ran back and dumped everything on the counter. The cashier had packed everything into four bags. It all came to nearly a hundred dollars, not counting the gas; I would have to pay Lacey’s parents back all summer.
tr_translation: “ONE MINUTE!” shouts Lacey, and I panic. I draw circles, my eyes scan the store, trying to remember what I forgot. I take a look at my list. It seems like I got everything, but it feels like I forgot something important. Come on, Jacobs. Chips, candy, turkey that looks like ham, peanut butter and jelly sandwich, and... what? What’s the other food group? Meat, chips, candy and and and cheese! “CRACKERS!” I say louder than necessary and rush to the crackers, grabbing cheese crackers, peanut butter crackers, and a few extra Grandma’s cookies, then I run back and throw what I have onto the counter. The woman has already filled four plastic bags. Almost a hundred dollars in total, not even counting the gas; I will pay this money back to Lacey’s parents over the summer.
es_translation: —ONE MINUTE! —shouts Lacey. It almost gave me a heart attack. I wander around the store, trying to remember what I have forgotten. I take a look at my list. It seems like everything is there, but I have the feeling that I'm forgetting something important. Something. "Come on, Jacobsen." Chips, candies, turkey sandwiches that look like ham... and what else? What other types of food are there? Meat, chips, candies and, and, and, and cheese! CRACKERS!, I shout out loud. I run towards the crackers, grab several packs with cheese and with peanut butter, and some grandma's cookies just in case, run back to the counter and put everything on the counter. The woman has already filled four plastic bags. Almost a hundred dollars in total, not counting the gas. I'll have to spend the summer paying back Lacey's parents.

en: There’s only one moment of pause, and it’s after the woman behind the counter swipes Lacey’s BP card. I glance at my watch. We’re supposed to leave in twenty seconds. Finally, I hear the receipt printing. The woman tears it out of the machine, Lacey scribbles her name, and then Ben and I grab the bags and dash for the car. Radar revs the engine as if to say hustle, and we are running through the parking lot, Ben’s robe flowing in the wind so that he looks vaguely like a dark wizard, except that his pale skinny legs are visible, and his arms hug plastic bags. I can see the back of Lacey’s legs beneath her dress, her calves tight in midstride. I don’t know how I look, but I know how I feel: Young. Goofy. Infinite. I watch as Lacey and Ben pile in through the open sliding door. I follow, landing on plastic bags and Lacey’s torso. Radar guns the car as I slam the sliding door shut, and then he peels out of the parking lot, marking the first time in the long and storied history of the minivan that anyone anywhere has ever used one to burn rubber. Radar turns left onto the highway at a somewhat unsafe speed, and then merges back onto the interstate. We’re four seconds ahead of schedule. And just like with the NASCAR pit stops, we share high-fives and backslaps. We are well supplied. Ben has plenty of containers into which he can urinate. I have adequate beef jerky rations. Lacey has her Mentos. Radar and Ben have T-shirts to wear over their robes. The minivan has become a biosphere—give us gas, and we can keep going forever.
vi: Chỉ duy nhất một khoảnh khắc yên tĩnh sau khi bác thu ngân quét thẻ của Lacey. Tôi liếc đồng hồ. Chúng tôi cần lên đường trong vòng hai mươi giây nữa. Rút cục cũng nghe thấy tiếng hóa đơn được in ra. Bác gái xé hóa đơn khỏi máy in, Lacey kí ngoáy, Ben và tôi vớ đám túi và chạy bắn ra xe. Radar đã nổ sẵn máy như muốn nói nhanh lên, bọn tôi chạy qua bãi đỗ xe, áo chùng của Ben phồng lên trong gió nên trông nó hao hao giống một phù thủy hắc ám, trừ cẳng chân trắng xanh lộ ra và hai tay ôm túi. Tôi thấy bụng chân của Lacey dưới chân váy, bắp chân cậu ấy căng lên theo bước chạy. Tôi không biết trông tôi ra sao, nhưng tôi biết mình cảm thấy thế nào: Trẻ trung. Ngốc nghếch. Không giới hạn. Tôi nhìn Ben và Lacey lao dúi vào xe qua cánh cửa trượt đã mở sẵn. Tiếp đến tôi, hạ cánh xuống đám túi và người Lacey. Radar vọt xe đi khi tôi đóng sầm cánh cửa trượt, nó ngoặt tay lái ra khỏi bãi đỗ xe, lần đầu tiên ghi dấu trong lịch sử lâu dài của dòng xe minivan rằng có một người nào đó ở đâu đó đã lái đến sém cả lốp cao su. Radar rẽ trái vào đường cao tốc với một tốc độ không an toàn, rồi hòa trở lại cao tốc liên bang. Chúng tôi nhanh hơn dự kiến bốn giây. Và cũng giống như cảnh dừng lại ở đường pit trong đua xe NASCAR, chúng tôi đập tay và hồ hởi khen nhau. Vậy là xông xênh. Ben có đủ thứ để chứa trong trường hợp nó cần bài tiết. Tôi có đủ khẩu phần thịt bò khô. Lacey có kẹo Mentos. Radar và Ben có áo phông để mặc ra ngoài áo chùng. Chiếc minivan đã trở thành một sinh quyển–cứ đổ đầy xăng cho chúng tôi, cả bọn có thể đi mãi đến cùng trời cuối đất.
tr: Yalnızca tek bir duraksama anı oluyor; kasadaki kadın Lacey’nin BP kartım okuttuktan sonra. Saatime göz atıyorum. Yirmi saniye içinde gitmemiz gerekiyor. Sonunda makbuzun çıktığım duyuyorum. Kadın makbuzu makineden koparıyor, Lacey ismini karalıyor ve Ben’le poşetleri kapıp arabaya doğru fırlıyoruz. Radar acele edin dermiş gibi motora gaz veriyor ve park alanında koşuyoruz, Ben’in cübbesi rüzgârda dalgalandığından belli belirsiz bir şekilde karanlık bir büyücü gibi görünüyor; yalnız solgun, cılız bacakları görünüyor ve kollan naylon poşetlerle dolu. Elbisesinin altından, Lacey’nin bacaklarının arkasını görebiliyorum, baldırları uzun adımlarının ortasında sıkılaşıyor. Nasıl göründüğümü bilmiyorum ama nasıl hissettiğimi biliyorum: Genç. Şapşal. Sonsuz. Lacey ile Ben’i açık sürgülü kapıdan içeri dalarken izliyorum. Onlan takip ederek naylon poşetler ile Lacey’nin üzerine kapaklanıyorum. Ben sürgülü kapıyı gürültüyle kapatırken, Radar arabaya tam gaz veriyor, sonra hızla park alanından çıkıyor ve hiç kimsenin hiçbir yerde lastik izi bırakmak için hiç kullanmadığı minivanın, uzun ve hikâyelerle süslü tarihinde bir ilke imza atıyor. Radar pek güvenli olmayan bir hızda sola dönüp anayola çıkıyor, sonra eyaletler arası yola çıkıyor. Programın dört saniye önündeyiz. Ve tıpkı NASCAR pit duruşlarında olduğu gibi birbirimize beşlik çakıyoruz. Yeterince malzeme temin etmiş durumdayız. Ben’in işeyebileceği bir sürü kabı var. Benim yeterh miktarda kurutulmuş et payım var. Lacey’nin Mentos’u var. Radar ile Ben’in cübbelerinin yerine giyecekleri tişörtleri var. Minivan bir biyosfere dönüşmüş durumda... Bize benzin verin, böylece sonsuza dek gitmeye devam edebiliriz.
es: El único momento de pausa es después de que la cajera haya pasado la tarjeta de Lacey. Miro el reloj. Se supone que tenemos que salir en veinte segundos. Oigo por fin el tíquet imprimiéndose. La mujer lo arranca de la máquina, Lacey garabatea su firma, y Ben y yo cogemos las bolsas y corremos al coche. Radar revoluciona el motor, como diciéndonos que nos demos prisa, y corremos por el aparcamiento. Como la toga de Ben vuela al viento, tiene un ligero parecido con un brujo, salvo en que se le ven las piernas blancas y en que lleva bolsas de plástico en las manos. Veo la parte de atrás de las piernas de Lacey bajo su vestido, avanzando con las pantorrillas prietas. No sé qué aspecto tengo, pero sé cómo me siento: joven. Torpe. Infinito. Observo a Lacey y Ben entrando por la puerta corredera. Luego entro yo, que aterrizo encima de bolsas de plástico y en el torso de Lacey. Radar arranca mientras cierro la puerta y sale a toda pastilla del aparcamiento, lo cual señala la primera vez en la larga y notoria historia de los monovolúmenes que una persona los utiliza para quemar caucho. Radar gira a la izquierda en la autopista a velocidad poco segura y volvemos a meternos en la interestatal. Vamos cuatro segundos por delante de lo previsto. Y como en los boxes de NASCAR, nos chocamos las manos y nos damos palmaditas en la espalda. Estamos bien abastecidos. Ben tiene un montón de envases para mear. Yo tengo bastantes raciones de cecina. Lacey tiene sus Mentos. Radar y Ben tienen camisetas para ponérselas encima de la toga. El monovolumen se ha convertido en una biosfera. Con gasolina, podremos seguir avanzando eternamente.
vi_translation: Only a single moment of quiet after the cashier swiped Lacey's card. I glanced at the clock. We needed to be on the road in twenty seconds. Finally, we heard the receipt being printed. The cashier tore the receipt from the printer, Lacey scribbled her signature, Ben and I grabbed the bags and dashed to the car. Radar had the engine running as if to say hurry up, we ran across the parking lot, Ben's robe billowing in the wind making him look somewhat like a dark wizard, except for the pale legs showing and his arms full of bags. I saw Lacey's calves under her skirt, her muscles tensing with each stride. I didn't know how I looked, but I knew how I felt: Young. Foolish. Limitless. I watched Ben and Lacey dive into the car through the already open sliding door. Next was me, landing on the bags and Lacey. Radar sped off as I slammed the sliding door shut, he swerved the car out of the parking lot, marking the first time in the long history of minivans that someone somewhere had driven fast enough to screech the tires. Radar turned left onto the highway at an unsafe speed, then merged back onto the interstate. We were four seconds ahead of schedule. And just like a NASCAR pit stop, we high-fived and congratulated each other. So we were all set. Ben had everything he needed in case he had to relieve himself. I had enough beef jerky. Lacey had Mentos. Radar and Ben had t-shirts to wear over their robes. The minivan had become a biosphere—just keep filling it with gas and we could go on forever.
tr_translation: There is only a single moment of hesitation; the woman at the counter scans my BP card after Lacey. I glance at my watch. We need to leave within twenty seconds. I finally hear the receipt printing. The woman tears the receipt from the machine, scribbles Lacey's name, and Ben and I grab the bags and dash towards the car. Radar revs the engine as if urging us to hurry, and we run across the parking lot, Ben's robe fluttering in the wind, making him look vaguely like a dark wizard; only his pale, skinny legs are visible, and his arms are full of nylon bags. From under her dress, I can see the backs of Lacey's legs, her calves tightening mid-stride. I don't know how I look, but I know how I feel: Young. Foolish. Infinite. I watch Lacey and Ben dive into the open sliding door. Following them, I tumble onto Lacey with the nylon bags. As Ben noisily shuts the sliding door, Radar floors the gas pedal, then quickly exits the parking lot, and the minivan, which no one ever used to leave tire marks anywhere, long and full of stories is making a first in its ornate history. Radar turns left onto the main road at a speed that isn't very safe, then gets onto the interstate. We are four seconds ahead of schedule. And just like in NASCAR pit stops, we high-five each other. We have secured enough supplies. Ben has plenty of containers to pee in. I have my sufficient share of dried meat. Lacey has Mentos. Radar and Ben have t-shirts to wear instead of their robes. The minivan has turned into a biosphere... Give us gas, and we can keep going forever.
es_translation: The only moment of pause is after the cashier has swiped Lacey's card. I look at the clock. We are supposed to leave in twenty seconds. I finally hear the ticket printing. The woman tears it from the machine, Lacey scribbles her signature, and Ben and I grab the bags and run to the car. Radar revs the engine, as if telling us to hurry up, and we run through the parking lot. With Ben's gown flying in the wind, he has a slight resemblance to a wizard, except that you can see his white legs and he is carrying plastic bags in his hands. I see the back of Lacey's legs under her dress, moving forward with tight calves. I don't know what I look like, but I know how I feel: young. Clumsy. Infinite. I watch Lacey and Ben entering through the sliding door. Then I enter, landing on top of plastic bags and on Lacey's torso. Radar starts the car as I close the door and speeds out of the parking lot, marking the first time in the long and notorious history of minivans that someone uses one to burn rubber. Radar turns left onto the highway at an unsafe speed and we get back on the interstate. We are four seconds ahead of schedule. And like in a NASCAR pit stop, we high-five and pat each other on the back. We are well-stocked. Ben has a bunch of pee containers. I have plenty of beef jerky rations. Lacey has her Mentos. Radar and Ben have t-shirts to put over their gowns. The minivan has become a biosphere. With gasoline, we can keep going forever.

en: Hour Five
vi: Giờ thứ năm
tr: Beşinci Saat
es: HORA CINCO
vi_translation: Fifth hour
tr_translation: Fifth Hour
es_translation: FIVE O'CLOCK

en: Okay, maybe we are not that well provisioned after all. In the rush of the moment, it turns out that Ben and I made some moderate (although not fatal) mistakes. With Radar alone up front, Ben and I sit in the first bench, unpacking each bag and handing the items to Lacey in the wayback. Lacey, in turn, is sorting items into piles based on an organizational schema only she understands.
vi: Thôi được, có lẽ rút cục chúng tôi không được cung ứng tốt đến mức ấy. Trong phút vội vã, hóa ra Ben và tôi đã mắc chút sai lầm (dù không đến nỗi chết người). Chỉ mình Radar ở phía trước, Ben và tôi ngồi ở ngay sau, tháo từng túi và đưa đồ cho Lacey ở hàng cuối. Đến lượt Lacey, cậu ấy phân loại các món thành từng đống dựa trên một kết cấu có tổ chức mà chỉ Lacey mới hiểu.
tr: Tamam, belki her şeye rağmen o kadar da iyi hazırlanmış durumda değiliz. O anki aceleyle, Ben’le (ölümcül olmasa da) bazı hatalar yaptığımız ortaya çıkıyor. Radar önde tek başma, Ben ile önden ilk çift kişilik koltukta oturuyoruz, her poşeti boşaltıp aldıklarımızı arkadaki Lacey’ye veriyoruz. Lacey ürünleri, sırasıyla, sadece kendisinin anladığı bir şemaya dayah gruplara ayırıyor.
es: De acuerdo, pensándolo bien, quizá no estamos tan bien abastecidos. Con las prisas, resulta que Ben y yo hemos cometido varios errores leves (aunque no fatales). Radar va solo delante, y Ben y yo nos sentamos en la primera fila de asientos, sacamos las cosas de las bolsas y se las pasamos a Lacey, que va detrás. Por su parte, Lacey coloca las cosas en montones siguiendo un criterio de organización que solo ella entiende.
vi_translation: Alright, perhaps in the end we weren't supplied as well as that. In the rush, it turned out that Ben and I made a few mistakes (though not fatal ones). Only Radar was in the front, Ben and I sat right behind, unpacking each bag and handing items to Lacey in the back row. It was Lacey's turn to sort the items into piles based on an organized structure that only Lacey understood.
tr_translation: Okay, maybe despite everything, we are not that well-prepared. In the rush of the moment, it turns out that Ben and I made some mistakes (though not fatal). Radar is alone in the front, Ben and I are sitting in the first double seat, emptying each bag and handing what we got to Lacey in the back. Lacey sorts the items into groups based on a scheme that only she understands.
es_translation: Alright, on second thought, maybe we are not as well-stocked as we thought. In the rush, it turns out that Ben and I have made several minor (though not fatal) mistakes. Radar goes ahead alone, and Ben and I sit in the front row of seats, take things out of the bags, and pass them to Lacey, who is behind us. For her part, Lacey arranges the items into piles following an organizational system that only she understands.

en: “Why is the NyQuil not in the same pile as the NoDoz?” I ask. “Shouldn’t all the medicines be together?”
vi: “Sao NyQuil không ở cùng một chỗ với NoDoz?” tôi hỏi. “Không phải cả hai đều là thuốc sao?”
tr: “Neden NyQuiln NoDoz’la11 12 aynı yığında değil?” diye soruyorum. “Bütün ilaçların beraber olması gerekmez mi? “Q.
es: —¿Por qué el antihistamínico no va en el mismo montón que las pastillas de cafeína? —le pregunto—. ¿No deberían ir juntos todos los medicamentos?
vi_translation: “Why isn't NyQuil in the same place as NoDoz?” I asked. “Aren't they both medications?”
tr_translation: “Why isn't NyQuil in the same pile as NoDoz?” I ask. “Shouldn't all the medications be together?”
es_translation: —Why doesn't the antihistamine go in the same pile as the caffeine pills? —I ask—. Shouldn't all the medications go together?

en: “Q. Sweetie. You’re a boy. You don’t know how to do these things. The NoDoz is with the chocolate and the Mountain Dew, because those things all contain caffeine and help you stay up. The NyQuil is with the beef jerky because eating meat makes you feel tired.”
vi: “Q thân mến, chàng trai ngây thơ quá, làm sao hiểu được phạm trù này. NoDoz đi với sô-cô-la và Mountain Dew, vì những thứ đó đều có ca-phê-in và làm cậu tỉnh. NyQuil ở cùng thịt bò khô vì ăn thịt sẽ làm cậu mệt.”
tr: “Q. Tatlım. Sen bir erkeksin. Böyle şeylerin nasıl yapılacağını bilmezsin. NoDoz, çikolata ve Mountain Dew’la birlikte çünkü bunların hepsi kafein içeriyor ve uyanık kalmana yardımcı oluyorlar. NyQuil kurutulmuş etle birlikte çünkü et yemek yorgun hissetmene neden olur.
es: —Q, cariño, eres un crío. No sabes cómo van estas cosas. La cafeína va con el chocolate y el Mountain Dew, que también tienen cafeína, que sirve para mantenerte despierto. El antihistamínico, que da sueño, va con la cecina porque comer carne hace que te canses.
vi_translation: “Dear Q, you are too naive to understand this category. NoDoz goes with chocolate and Mountain Dew because they all contain caffeine and keep you awake. NyQuil goes with beef jerky because eating meat will make you tired.”
tr_translation: “Q. Sweetheart. You are a man. You don't know how to do these things. NoDoz, chocolate, and Mountain Dew together because they all contain caffeine and help you stay awake. NyQuil with jerky because eating meat makes you feel tired.”
es_translation: —Q, darling, you are a kid. You don't know how these things work. Caffeine goes with chocolate and Mountain Dew, which also have caffeine, which helps to keep you awake. The antihistamine, which makes you sleepy, goes with jerky because eating meat makes you tired.

en: “Fascinating,” I say. After I’ve handed Lacey the last of the food from my bags, Lacey asks, “Q, where is the food that is— you know—good?”
vi: “Hay ho thật,” tôi nói. Khi tôi đã đưa Lacey món cuối cùng trong túi đồ của mình, cậu ấy hỏi, “Q, nhóm đồ ăn mà–cậu biết đấy–lành mạnh đâu?”
tr: “Büyüleyici,” diyorum. Poşetlerimdeki yiyeceklerden sonuncusunu Lacey’ye uzattıktan sonra Lacey, “Q, şey olan... hani... iyi olan yiyecekler nerede?” diye soruyor. 11 Soğuk algınlığı semptomlarını azaltan bir ilaç, (ç. n. 12 Kafein içeren, uyana bir ilaç, (ç. n.
es: —Fascinante —le contesto. Le paso a Lacey la comida que queda en la última bolsa. —Q —me dice—, ¿dónde está la comida que… ya sabes… la comida?
vi_translation: “That's really funny,” I said. When I handed Lacey the last item from my bag, she asked, “Q, where's the healthy food–you know?”
tr_translation: “Fascinating,” I say. After handing the last of the food from my bags to Lacey, Lacey asks, “Q, the thing... you know... where is the good food?” 11 A medication that reduces cold symptoms, (exp. n.) 12 Caffeine-containing, a drug that makes one awake, (cf. n.)
es_translation: —Fascinating —I replied. I pass the remaining food in the last bag to Lacey. —Q —he says to me—, where is the food that… you know… the food?

en: “Huh?”
vi: “Hả?”
es: —¿Cómo?
vi_translation: "Huh?"
tr_translation: “What?”
es_translation: —How?

en: Lacey produces a copy of the grocery list she wrote for me and reads from it. “Bananas. Apples. Dried cranberries. Raisins.”
vi: Lacey đưa bản sao danh mục đã viết cho tôi ra và đọc, “Chuối. Táo. Nam việt quất khô. Nho khô.”
tr: Lacey benim için yazdığı alışveriş listesinin bir kopyasını çıkarıp okuyor. “Muz. Elma. Kurutulmuş yaban mersini. Kuru üzüm.”
es: Lacey saca una copia de la lista que hizo para mí y la lee. —Plátanos, manzanas, arándanos secos y uvas pasas.
vi_translation: Lacey handed me the written copy of the list and read, "Bananas. Apples. Dried cranberries. Raisins."
tr_translation: Lacey is reading a copy of the shopping list she wrote for me. “Bananas. Apples. Dried blueberries. Raisins.”
es_translation: Lacey takes out a copy of the list she made for me and reads it. —Bananas, apples, dried cranberries, and raisins.

en: “Oh.” I say. “Oh, right. The fourth food group wasn’t crackers.”
vi: “Ôi,” tôi than. “Ừ nhỉ. Nhóm đồ ăn thứ tư không phải là bánh qui ròn.
tr: “Ah,” diyorum. “Ah, doğru. Dördüncü besin grubu kraker değildi.” “Q!” diyor öfkeli bir şekilde.
es: —Ah —digo—. Ah, vale. El cuarto grupo no eran galletas saladas.
vi_translation: “Oh,” I lamented. “Oh right. The fourth food group isn't crunchy cookies.”
tr_translation: “Oh,” I say. “Oh, right. The fourth food group wasn't crackers.” “Q!” she says angrily.
es_translation: —Ah —I say—. Ah, okay. The fourth group wasn't salty crackers.

en: “Q!” she says, furious. “I can’t eat any of this!”
vi: “Q ơi là Q!” Lacey cáu. “Tớ không ăn được bất cứ thứ nào ở đây!”
tr: “Q!” diyor öfkeli bir şekilde. “Ben bunların hiçbirini yiyemem.”
es: —¡Q! —exclama furiosa—. ¡Yo no puedo comer nada de esto!
vi_translation: "Oh Q, oh Q!" Lacey snapped. "I can't eat anything here!"
tr_translation: The fourth food group wasn't crackers.” “Q!” she says angrily. “I can't eat any of these.”
es_translation: —What! —she exclaims furiously—. I can't eat any of this!

en: Ben puts a hand on her elbow. “Well, but you can eat Grandma’s cookies. They’re not bad for you. They were made by Grandma. Grandma wouldn’t hurt you.”
vi: Ben chạm vào khuỷu tay Lacey. “Xem nào, nhưng cậu có thể ăn bánh qui hiệu Cụ Bà mà. Cụ Bà không làm hại cậu đâu.”
tr: Ben elini onun dirseğine koyuyor. “Fıstık ezmeli Grandma’s kurabiyelerinden yiyebilirsin. Büyükanne eli değmiş gibiler. Büyükanne sana zarar vermez.
es: Ben la coge por el codo. —Bueno, pero puedes comer las galletas de la abuela. No te sentarán mal. Las ha hecho la abuela. Y la abuela nunca te haría daño.
vi_translation: Ben touched Lacey's elbow. "Come on, but you can eat Grandma's cookies. Grandma won't hurt you."
tr_translation: I put my hand on her elbow. “You can eat Grandma’s peanut butter cookies. They taste like Grandma made them. Grandma wouldn't harm you.”
es_translation: Ben grabs her by the elbow. —Well, but you can eat grandma's cookies. They won't make you feel bad. Grandma made them. And grandma would never hurt you.

en: Lacey blows a strand of hair out of her face. She seems genuinely annoyed. “Plus,” I tell her, “there are GoFast bars. They’re fortified with vitamins!”
vi: Lacey thổi một lọn tóc khỏi mặt, xem ra đúng là cáu thật. “Có mấy thanh GoFast mà,” tôi nói với Lacey. “Có bổ sung vi-ta-min đấy!”
tr: Lacey bir saç telini üfleyerek yüzünden çekiyor. Gerçekten sinirlenmiş gibi görünüyor. “Üstelik,” diyorum, “GoFast gofretleri var. Vitaminlerle güçlendirilmişler!
es: Lacey se aparta un mechón de la cara de un soplido. Parece muy mosqueada. —Además —le digo—, hay barritas energéticas. ¡Están reforzadas con vitaminas!
vi_translation: Lacey blew a strand of hair out of her face, clearly looking quite annoyed. “It's just some GoFast bars,” I said to Lacey. “They have added vitamins!”
tr_translation: Lacey blows a strand of hair away from her face. She really looks upset. “Besides,” I say, “they have GoFast wafers. They are fortified with vitamins!”
es_translation: Lacey blows a strand of hair away from her face. She looks very annoyed. —Besides —I tell him—, there are energy bars. They are fortified with vitamins!

en: “Yeah, vitamins and like thirty grams of fat,” she says.
vi: “Ừ, vi-ta-min và khoảng ba mươi gam chất béo,” Lacey đáp.
tr: “Evet, vitaminler ve otuz gram falan yağ,” diyor.
es: —Sí, vitaminas y como treinta gramos de grasa —me contesta.
vi_translation: “Yes, vitamins and about thirty grams of fat,” Lacey replied.
tr_translation: “Yes, vitamins and about thirty grams of fat,” he says.
es_translation: —Yes, vitamins and about thirty grams of fat —he replies to me.

en: From the front Radar announces, “Don’t you go talking bad about GoFast bars. Do you want me to stop this car?”
vi: Từ ghế trước Radar tuyên bố, “Đừng nói xấu mấy thanh GoFast nữa. Mấy bồ có muốn tớ dừng xe luôn không?”
tr: Ön taraftan Radar, “Sakın GoFast hakkında kötü konuşmaya başlamayın. Bu arabayı durdurmamı ister misiniz?’ diye duyuruyor.
es: —No sigáis hablando mal de las barritas energéticas —interviene Radar—. ¿Queréis que pare el coche?
vi_translation: From the front seat, Radar declared, "Stop badmouthing the GoFast bars. Do you guys want me to stop the car right now?"
tr_translation: From the front, Radar announces, "Don't start talking badly about GoFast. Do you want me to stop this car?"
es_translation: —Stop talking bad about energy bars —intervenes Radar—. Do you want me to stop the car?

en: “Whenever I eat a GoFast bar,” Ben says, “I’m always like, ‘So this is what blood tastes like to mosquitoes.’”
vi: “Lần nào ăn GoFast,” Ben nói, “tôi cũng có cảm giác ‘Hóa ra vị của thứ này cũng giống như vị máu đối với muỗi.
tr: “Ne zaman bir GoFast yesem,” diyor Ben, “aklıma ilk gelen, “Yani sivrisineklere kanın tadı böyle geliyormuş’ cümlesi oluyor.”
es: —Cada vez que me como una barrita —dice Ben— pienso que así sabe la sangre para los mosquitos.
vi_translation: "Every time I eat GoFast," Ben said, "I get the feeling 'So this is what blood tastes like to a mosquito.'"
tr_translation: “Whenever I eat a GoFast,” says Ben, “the first thing that comes to my mind is, ‘So this is what blood tastes like to mosquitoes.’”
es_translation: —Every time I eat a bar —says Ben— I think this is what blood tastes like to mosquitoes.

en: I half unwrap a fudge brownie GoFast bar and hold it in front of Lacey’s mouth. “Just smell it,” I say. “Smell the vitaminy deliciousness.”
vi: Tôi bóc nửa chừng một thanh GoFast vị sô-cô-la, huơ huơ trước miệng Lacey, “Cậu ngửi đi,” tôi nói. “Có mùi vi-ta-min bổ dưỡng đấy.”
tr: Yumuşak ve çikolatalı bir GoFast gofretinin birazım açıp Lacey'nin ağzının önünde tutuyorum. “Sadece kokla,” diyorum. “Vitaminli lezzeti kokla.
es: Desenvuelvo hasta la mitad una barrita de bizcocho de chocolate y dulce de leche y se la acerco a la boca a Lacey. —Huélela —le digo—. Huele el manjar vitaminado.
vi_translation: I unwrapped halfway a chocolate-flavored GoFast bar, waving it in front of Lacey's mouth, "Smell this," I said. "It has a nutritious vitamin scent."
tr_translation: I open a bit of a soft and chocolaty GoFast wafer and hold it in front of Lacey's mouth. “Just smell it,” I say. “Smell the vitamin-rich flavor.”
es_translation: I unwrap halfway a chocolate and dulce de leche sponge cake bar and bring it close to Lacey's mouth. —Smell it —I tell him—. Smell the vitamin-rich delicacy.

en: “You’re going to make me fat.”
vi: “Cậu sẽ làm tớ béo quay cho coi.”
tr: “Beni şişmanlatacaksınız.
es: —Vas a hacerme engordar.
vi_translation: "You're going to make me fat."
tr_translation: “You will make me fat.”
es_translation: —You're going to make me gain weight.

en: “Also zitty,” Ben said. “Don’t forget zitty.”
vi: “Và nổi mụn,” Ben bồi thêm. “Đừng quên đám mụn nhé.”
tr: “Ayrıca sivilceli,” diyor Ben. “Sivilceliyi unutma.
es: —Y a llenarte de granos —dijo Ben—. No olvides los granos.
vi_translation: “And pimples,” Ben added. “Don't forget the pimples.”
tr_translation: “Also, he has pimples,” says Ben. “Don't forget the pimples.”
es_translation: —And to get covered in pimples —said Ben—. Don't forget the pimples.

en: Lacey takes the bar from me and reluctantly bites into it. She has to close her eyes to hide the orgasmic pleasure inherent in GoFast-tasting. “Oh. My. God. That tastes like hope feels.”
vi: Lacey cầm thanh ngũ cốc từ tay tôi và miễn cưỡng cắn một miếng, phải nhắm mắt lại để che giấu sự sung sướng mê tơi khi nếm một thanh GoFast. “Ôi. Lạy. Chúa. Thứ này có vị giống như hi vọng vậy.”
tr: Lacey gofreti alıp isteksizce ısırıyor. GoFast tatmanın doğasmda yatan orgazma benzeyen zevki saklamak için gözlerini kapamak zorunda kalıyor. “Ah. Tanrım. Tadı tıpkı umut gibi hissettiriyor.
es: Lacey coge la barrita y le da un mordisco de mala gana. Tiene que cerrar los ojos para ocultar el placer orgásmico inherente a comerse una barrita energética. —¡Madre mía! Un sabor esperanzador.
vi_translation: Lacey took the cereal bar from my hand and reluctantly took a bite, having to close her eyes to hide the sheer delight of tasting a GoFast bar. "Oh. My. God. This tastes like hope."
tr_translation: Lacey reluctantly takes a bite of the waffle. She has to close her eyes to hide the orgasmic pleasure inherent in tasting GoFast. “Ah. My God. It tastes just like hope feels.”
es_translation: Lacey grabs the bar and takes a reluctant bite. She has to close her eyes to hide the orgasmic pleasure inherent in eating an energy bar. —My goodness! A hopeful taste.

en: Finally, we unpack the last bag. It contains two large T-shirts, which Radar and Ben are very excited about, because it means they can be guys-wearing-gigantic-shirts-over-silly-robes instead of just guys-wearing-silly-robes.
vi: Cuối cùng, chúng tôi mở đến túi cuối. Trong đó có hai cái áo phông cỡ lớn. Radar và Ben trông háo hức ra mặt vì sắp trở thành thanh-niên-mặc-áo-phông-rộng-lùng-thùng-ra-ngoài-áo-chùng-dẩm-dớ, không còn là thanh-niên-mặc-áo-chùng-dẩm-dớ nữa.
tr: Nihayet son poşeti de boşaltıyoruz. İçinde, Ben ile Radar’m görünce çok heyecanlandığı iki büyük tişört var, çünkü bu, “aptal elbiseler giyen adamlar” yerine “elbise yerine devasa tişörtler giyen adamlar” olabilecekleri anlamına geliyor.
es: Al final abrimos la última bolsa. Contiene dos camisetas grandes, que entusiasman a Radar y a Ben, porque les permitirán ser tipos con camiseta gigante encima de una absurda toga en lugar de solo tipos con una absurda toga.
vi_translation: Finally, we opened the last bag. Inside, there were two large-sized T-shirts. Radar and Ben looked visibly excited because they were about to become young-men-wearing-oversized-T-shirts-outside-baggy-clothes, no longer young-men-wearing-baggy-clothes.
tr_translation: Finally, we empty the last bag. Inside, there are two large T-shirts that Ben and Radar get very excited about when they see them, because it means they can be "guys who wear gigantic T-shirts" instead of "guys who wear stupid clothes."
es_translation: In the end, we opened the last bag. It contains two large t-shirts, which excite Radar and Ben, because they will allow them to be guys with a giant t-shirt over a ridiculous toga instead of just guys with a ridiculous toga.

en: But when Ben unfurls the T-shirts, there are two small problems. First, it turns out that a large T-shirt in a Georgia gas station is not the same size as a large T-shirt at, say, Old Navy. The gas station shirt is gigantic—more garbage bag than shirt. It is smaller than the graduation robes, but not by much. But this problem rather pales in comparison to the other problem, which is that both T-shirts are embossed with huge Confederate flags. Printed over the flag are the words HERITAGE NOT HATE.
vi: Nhưng khi Ben dỡ áo ra, có hai vấn đề nhỏ. Một là, hóa ra áo phông cỡ lớn ở trạm xăng tại Georgia không giống cỡ lớn tại, chẳng hạn, hiệu Old Navy. Áo phông cỡ lớn ở trạm xăng rộng khổng lồ–trông giống bao đựng rác hơn là áo phông. Mấy chiếc này đúng là nhỏ hơn áo chùng, nhưng không nhỏ hơn là bao. Nhưng vấn đề này trở nên lọt thỏm khi đặt cạnh một vấn đề khác: hai chiếc áo phông đều in hình cờ Liên Minh Miền Nam bự chảng. Phía trên lá cờ còn có dòng chữ DI SẢN KHÔNG HẬN THÙ.
tr: Ama Ben tişörtleri açtığında, iki küçük sorun ortaya çıkıyor. İlki, bir Georgia benzin istasyonundaki büyük beden bir tişörtün, mesela, Old Navy’deki büyük beden tişörtle aynı boyda olmadığı ortaya çıkıyor. Benzin istasyonundaki tişört devasa... Bir tişörtten ziyade çöp torbası. Mezuniyet cübbelerinden daha küçük ama çok da değil. Fakat bu sorun diğerine göre sönük kalıyor ki bu da, iki tişörtün de üstünde kabartmalı Konfederasyon bayraklannın olması. Bayrağın üzerine NEFRET DEĞİL MİRAS kelimeleri yazılmış.
es: Pero cuando Ben desdobla las camisetas, se encuentra con dos pequeños problemas. El primero, que resulta que una camiseta de talla grande de una gasolinera de Georgia no es del mismo tamaño que una camiseta de talla grande de, pongamos, unos grandes almacenes. La camiseta de la gasolinera es inmensa. Parece más una bolsa de basura que una camiseta. Es más pequeña que las togas, pero no mucho más. Pero este problema casi se queda en nada comparado con el otro, que es que las dos camisetas llevan estampada la bandera de la Confederación. Encima de la bandera se lee PATRIMONIO CULTURAL NO ODIO.
vi_translation: But when Ben took off the shirt, there were two small problems. One was that it turned out that a large T-shirt from a gas station in Georgia was not the same as a large from, say, Old Navy. The large T-shirt from the gas station was enormous—it looked more like a garbage bag than a T-shirt. These ones were indeed smaller than robes, but not by much. But this problem paled in comparison to another issue: both T-shirts had a huge Confederate flag printed on them. Above the flag was the phrase HERITAGE NOT HATE.
tr_translation: But when Ben unfolds the t-shirts, two small problems arise. The first is that an oversized t-shirt from a Georgia gas station, for example, it turns out that the plus-size t-shirt at Old Navy is not the same size. The t-shirt at the gas station is gigantic... More like a trash bag than a t-shirt. Smaller than graduation gowns but not by much. But this issue pales in comparison to the fact that both t-shirts have embossed Confederate flags on them. The words NOT HATE BUT HERITAGE are written on the flag.
es_translation: But when Ben unfolds the T-shirts, he encounters two small problems. The first is that it turns out a large-sized T-shirt from a gas station in Georgia is not the same size as a large-sized T-shirt from, say, a department store. The gas station T-shirt is enormous. It looks more like a garbage bag than a T-shirt. It's smaller than the togas, but not by much. But this problem almost pales in comparison to the other, which is that both T-shirts have the Confederate flag printed on them. Above the flag, it reads HERITAGE NOT HATE.

en: “Oh no you didn’t,” Radar says when I show him why we’re laughing. “Ben Starling, you better not have bought your token black friend a racist shirt.”
vi: “Ôi không chứ,” Radar thốt lên khi tôi chỉ cho nó thấy bọn tôi đang cười gì. “Ben Starling, ông không nỡ mua cho người bạn da đen đầy tính biểu tượng của ông một cái áo phân biệt sắc tộc thế chứ.”
tr: “Ah hayır, bu gerçek olamaz,” diyor Radar, ona neden güldüğümüzü gösterdiğimde. “Ben Starling, numunelik zenci arkadaşına ırkçı bir tişört almamış olsan iyi olurdu.
es: —Oh, no —dice Radar cuando le muestro por qué nos reímos—. Ben Starling, no deberías haber comprado una camiseta racista a la persona que cubre tu cuota de amigos negros.
vi_translation: “Oh no,” Radar exclaimed when I showed him what we were laughing at. “Ben Starling, you wouldn't buy your symbolically black friend a racist shirt, would you?”
tr_translation: “Oh no, this can't be real,” says Radar when I show him why we are laughing. “I hope you didn't get a racist t-shirt for your token black friend, Starling.”
es_translation: —Oh, no —says Radar when I show him why we are laughing—. Ben Starling, you shouldn't have bought a racist T-shirt for the person who covers your black friend quota.

en: “I just grabbed the first shirts I saw, bro.”
vi: “Người anh em, tôi chỉ nhanh tay vớ ngay cái đầu tiên nhìn thấy thôi mà.”
tr: “Sadece gördüğüm ilk tişörtleri kaptım, kardeşim.
es: —He cogido las primeras que he visto, colega.
vi_translation: "Brother, I just quickly grabbed the first thing I saw."
tr_translation: “I just grabbed the first t-shirts I saw, brother.”
es_translation: —I grabbed the first ones I saw, mate.

en: “Don’t bro me right now,” Radar says, but he’s shaking his head and laughing. I hand him his shirt and he wiggles into it while driving with his knees. “I hope I get pulled over,” he says. “I’d like to see how the cop responds to a black man wearing a Confederate T-shirt over a black dress.”
vi: “Lúc này đừng có mà anh em với tôi,” Radar nói, nhưng nó lúc lắc đầu và cười lớn. Tôi đưa áo cho Radar, nó tròng vào người trong khi lái xe bằng đầu gối. “Hi vọng tôi sẽ bị cảnh sát bắt dừng lại,” nó nói. “Tôi muốn xem các chú ấy sẽ phản ứng thế nào khi thấy một gã da đen mặc áo phông Liên Minh ra ngoài một cái váy đen.
tr: “Şu anda bana kardeşim deme,” diyor Radar ama başım sallayıp gülüyor. Tişörtü ona uzatıyorum, arabayı dizleriyle sürerken tişörtün içine girmeye çahşıyor. “Umarım beni kenara çekerler,” diyor. “Polisin siyah bir elbise üstüne Konfederasyon tişörtü giymiş bir zenciye nasıl tepki vereceğini görmek istiyorum.
es: —No me vengas ahora con colega —dice Radar, aunque mueve la cabeza y se ríe. Le paso su camiseta. Sujeta el volante con las rodillas y se la pone—. Ojalá me pare la poli. Me gustaría ver qué cara ponen al ver a un negro con una camiseta de la Confederación encima de una toga negra.
vi_translation: “Don't be all buddy-buddy with me right now,” Radar said, but he shook his head and laughed loudly. I handed the shirt to Radar, and he slipped it on while steering with his knees. “I hope I get pulled over by the cops,” he said. “I want to see how they react when they see a black guy wearing a Confederate flag T-shirt over a black skirt.”
tr_translation: “Don't call me brother right now,” says Radar, but I nod and smile. I hand him the T-shirt, and he tries to put it on while steering the car with his knees. “I hope they pull me over,” he says. “I want to see how the police will react to a black guy wearing a Confederate T-shirt over a black outfit.”
es_translation: —Don't come at me with "buddy" now —says Radar, though he shakes his head and laughs. I hand him his t-shirt. He holds the steering wheel with his knees and puts it on—. I hope the cops pull me over. I'd love to see the look on their faces when they see a Black guy with a Confederate t-shirt over a black toga.

en: Hour Six
vi: Giờ thứ sáu
tr: Altıncı Saat
es: HORA SEIS
vi_translation: The sixth hour
tr_translation: Sixth Hour
es_translation: SIX O'CLOCK

en: For some reason, the stretch of I-95 just south of Florence, South Carolina, is the place to drive a car on a Friday evening. We get bogged down in traffic for several miles, and even though Radar is desperate to violate the speed limit, he’s lucky when he can go thirty. Radar and I sit up front, and we try to keep from worrying by playing a game we’ve just invented called That Guy Is a Gigolo. In the game, you imagine the lives of people in the cars around you.
vi: Không hiểu sao dải cao tốc I-95 kéo dài ở phía nam Florence, Nam Carolina, lại là nơi để lái xe vào tối thứ Sáu. Chúng tôi tiến thoái lưỡng nan trong dòng xe kéo dài vài dặm. Dù Radar không mong gì có thể vượt tốc độ cho phép, vẫn may là nó còn xoay xở được ở ba mươi dặm một giờ. Radar và tôi ngồi phía trước, cố không lo lắng bằng cách chơi một trò bọn tôi vừa nghĩ ra, tên là Gã Đó Là Đồ Đào Mỏ. Trong trò này, người chơi phải tưởng tượng ra cuộc sống của những người ngồi trong các xe khác xung quanh.
tr: Nedense tam Florence, Güney Carolina’mn güneyindeki 195 bir cuma akşamı araba sürülecek moda yer. Birkaç kilometre boyunca trafiğe gömülüyoruz ve Radar’m hız sınırını ihlal etmekten başka çaresi olmamasına rağmen elliyle gidebilmesi bile şans. Radar’la önde oturuyor ve az önce icat ettiğimiz, Şu Adam Bir Jigolo adlı oyunu oynayarak endişeden uzak durmaya çalışıyoruz. Oyunda, etrafınızdaki arabalarda yer alan insanların hayatlarım hayal ediyorsunuz.
es: Por alguna razón, el tramo de la I-95 al sur de Florence, Carolina del Sur, es el lugar ideal para conducir un viernes por la noche. Nos quedamos varios kilómetros atascados entre el tráfico, y aunque Radar está desesperado por saltarse el límite de velocidad, con suerte puede ir a cincuenta. Radar y yo vamos delante e intentamos no preocuparnos jugando a un juego que acabamos de inventarnos y que se llama «Ese tío es un gigoló». Consiste en imaginar la vida de las personas de los coches que nos rodean.
vi_translation: For some reason, the stretch of I-95 extending south of Florence, South Carolina, is the place to drive on a Friday night. We were caught in a dilemma in a line of cars stretching for several miles. Even though Radar didn't expect to exceed the speed limit, it was fortunate that he could still manage thirty miles per hour. Radar and I sat in the front, trying not to worry by playing a game we just came up with, called That Guy Is a Gold Digger. In this game, the player has to imagine the lives of the people sitting in the other cars around us.
tr_translation: For some reason, Florence, South Carolina, south of 195, is the fashionable place to drive on a Friday evening. We are buried in traffic for a few kilometers, and although Radar has no choice but to violate the speed limit, it's lucky if he can even go fifty. I'm sitting in the front with Radar, and we are trying to keep our worries at bay by playing a game we just invented called This Guy Is a Gigolo. In the game, you imagine the lives of the people in the cars around you.
es_translation: For some reason, the stretch of I-95 south of Florence, South Carolina, is the ideal place to drive on a Friday night. We got stuck for several miles in traffic, and although Radar is desperate to exceed the speed limit, he can hopefully go fifty. Radar and I are in the front trying not to worry by playing a game we just invented called "That Guy is a Gigolo." It consists of imagining the lives of the people in the cars around us.

en: We’re driving alongside a Hispanic woman in a beat-up old Toyota Corolla. I watch her through the early darkness. “Left her family to move here,” I say. “Illegal. Sends money back home on the third Tuesday of every month. She’s got two little kids—her husband is a migrant. He’s in Ohio right now—he only spends three or four months a year at home, but they still get along really well.”
vi: Chúng tôi lái song song một cô người Hispanic[9] đi chiếc Toyota Corolla đã cũ. Tôi quan sát cô ấy khi trời bắt đầu nhập nhoạng. “Bỏ gia đình để đến đây,” tôi nói. “Cư trú bất hợp pháp. Gửi tiền về nhà vào thứ Ba của tuần thứ ba hàng tháng. Cô ấy có hai con nhỏ–chồng là dân di cư. Hiện giờ chú chồng đang ở Ohio–một năm chỉ ở nhà khoảng ba, bốn tháng, nhưng hai vợ chồng vẫn rất ổn.
tr: Oldukça eski bir Toyota Corolla’daki Hispanik bir kadınla yan yana gidiyoruz. Erken çöken karanlığın içinden kadım izliyorum. “Buraya taşınmak için ailesini terk etmiş,” diyorum. “Yasadışı. Her ayın üçüncü sah gününde eve para gönderiyor. İki küçük çocuğu var, kocası göçmen. Şu anda Ohio’da, yılda sadece üç dört ayı evde geçiriyor ama yine de gerçekten iyi geçiniyorlar.
es: Vamos al lado de una mujer hispana que conduce un viejo y destartalado Toyota Corolla. La observo en la temprana oscuridad. —Dejó a su familia para venirse aquí —digo—. Sin papeles. Manda dinero a su casa el tercer martes de cada mes. Tiene dos hijos pequeños. Su marido es inmigrante. En estos momentos vive en Ohio. Solo pasa tres o cuatro meses al año en su casa, pero su familia se las arregla bastante bien.
vi_translation: We drove alongside a Hispanic woman[9] in an old Toyota Corolla. I watched her as the sky began to darken. “Left her family to come here,” I said. “Living here illegally. Sends money home on the third Tuesday of every month. She has two small children–her husband is a migrant worker. Right now, her husband is in Ohio–he's only home about three or four months a year, but the couple is doing just fine.”
tr_translation: We are driving side by side with a Hispanic woman in a rather old Toyota Corolla. I am watching the woman through the early falling darkness. "She left her family to move here," I say. "Illegal. She sends money home on the third day of every month. Two small children Her husband is an immigrant. Currently, he is in Ohio, spending only three or four months a year at home, but they still get along really well.”
es_translation: We go next to a Hispanic woman driving an old and dilapidated Toyota Corolla. I observe her in the early darkness. —She left her family to come here —I say—. Without papers. She sends money home on the third Tuesday of every month. She has two small children. Her husband is an immigrant. At the moment, she lives in Ohio. She only spends three or four months a year at home, but her family manages quite well.

en: Radar leans in front of me and glances over at her for half a second. “Christ, Q, it’s not so melodratragic as that. She’s a secretary at a law firm—look how she’s dressed. It has taken her five years, but she’s now close to getting a law degree of her own. And she doesn’t have kids, or a husband. She’s got a boyfriend, though. He’s a little flighty. Scared of commitment. White guy, a little nervous about the Jungle Fever angle of the whole thing.”
vi: Radar ngả người về phía trước, liếc sang nhìn cô ấy nửa giây. “Trời ơi, Q, không bi thiết đến mức ấy đâu. Cô ấy là thư kí tại một công ti luật–nhìn bộ váy của cô ấy mà xem. Phải mất gần năm năm, nhưng bây giờ cô ấy sắp có bằng luật sư rồi. Cô ấy không có con, cũng chưa có chồng. Nhưng có người yêu. Chú ấy dễ dãi, thích bay nhảy, sợ phải cam kết. Một người da trắng, hơi lo lắng về hội chứng tình yêu đa sắc tộc trong toàn bộ chuyện này.”
tr: Radar önüme doğru eğilip yanın saniyeliğine kadına göz atıyor. “Tanrım, Q, o kadar melodratrajik değil. Bir hukuk firmasında sekreter... nasıl giyindiğine bak. Beş yılma mal olmuş ama şimdi kendine ait bir hukuk diploması almak üzere. Ve çocuğu ya da kocası yok. Bir erkek arkadaşı var gerçi. Adam biraz uçarı. Bağlanmaktan korkuyor. Beyaz tenli ve ‘zenci merakı’ var diye eleştirileceğinden korkuyor.
es: Radar se inclina hacia delante y la mira un segundo. —Venga, Q, no es tan melodramático como lo pintas. Es secretaria en un despacho de abogados. Mira cómo va vestida. Ha tardado cinco años, pero está a punto de sacarse el título de abogada ella también. No tiene niños ni marido. Pero tiene un novio que es algo inconstante. Le asusta el compromiso. Un tipo blanco al que le pone cachondo el rollo étnico.
vi_translation: Radar leaned forward, glancing at her for half a second. "Oh my God, Q, it's not that tragic." She is a secretary at a law firm—just look at her dress. It took nearly five years, but now she is about to get her law degree. She doesn't have children, nor is she married. But he has a lover. He is easy-going, likes to be free, afraid of commitment. A white person, slightly worried about the interracial love syndrome in this whole affair."
tr_translation: Radar leans forward and glances at the woman for a second. “My God, Q, it's not that melodramatic. A secretary in a law firm... look at how she's dressed. It took her five years, but now she's about to get her own law degree. And she doesn't have a child or a husband. She does have a boyfriend, though. The guy is a bit flighty. He's afraid of commitment. He's afraid of being criticized for having a 'fetish for black women' because of his pale skin.”
es_translation: Radar leans forward and looks at her for a second. —Come on, Q, it's not as melodramatic as you make it out to be. She is a secretary at a law firm. Look at how she's dressed. It took her five years, but she's about to get her law degree too. She has no kids or husband. But she has a boyfriend who is somewhat inconsistent. He's scared of commitment. A white guy who gets turned on by the ethnic vibe.

en: “She’s wearing a wedding ring,” I point out. In Radar’s defense, I’ve been able to stare at her. She is to my right, just below me. I can see through her tinted windows, and I watch as she sings along to some song, her unblinking eyes on the road. There are so many people. It is easy to forget how full the world is of people, full to bursting, and each of them imaginable and consistently misimagined. I feel like this is an important idea, one of those ideas that your brain must wrap itself around slowly, the way pythons eat, but before I can get any further, Radar speaks.
vi: “Cô ấy đeo nhẫn cưới cơ mà,” tôi nhận xét. Để tìm cách bảo vệ quan điểm của Radar, tôi quan sát cô ấy kĩ hơn. Cô ấy ở bên phải, thấp hơn tôi một chút. Tôi nhìn được qua cửa sổ kính mờ trên xe cô ấy, thấy cô ấy đang hát theo bài hát nào đó, mắt nhìn đường không chớp. Có quá nhiều người. Ta dễ quên mất thế giới này đông người đến mức nào, đông đến độ nổ tung lên được, ta có thể tưởng tượng về mỗi người, và thường xuyên tưởng tượng sai. Tôi cảm thấy đây là một ý quan trọng, một trong những suy nghĩ mà bộ óc ta phải từ từ tự cuộn lại, như loài trăn nuốt con mồi. Nhưng trước khi tôi nghĩ được xa hơn, Radar đã lên tiếng.
tr: “Alyans takıyor,” diye belirtiyorum. Radar’m savunmasına göre, benim ona uzun uzun bakabilme imkânım var. Sağımda, tam aşağımda. Koyu renk camlı penceresinden onu görebiliyorum ve bir şarkıya eşlik ederken kadım izhyorum, hiç kırpmadığı gözleri yolda. O kadar çok insan var ki. Dünyanın insanlarla dolu olduğunu unutmak o kadar kolay ki... patlayacak kadar dolu, o insanların her biri hayal edilebilir ve mütemadiyen yanlış hayal ediliyor. Bu, bana önemli bir fikirmiş gibi gebyor, bir piton yılanının avını yemesi gibi, beynin konuyu yavaşça sarmalaması gereken fikirlerden biri gibi ama daha ileri gidemeden Radar konuşuyor.
es: —Lleva anillo de casada —puntualizo. Debo decir, en defensa de Radar, que yo he podido observarla mejor. Está a mi derecha, justo debajo de mí. La veo a través de los cristales tintados de su coche. La observo cantando y mirando al frente sin pestañear. Hay mucha gente. Resulta sencillo olvidar lo lleno de personas que está el mundo, abarrotado, y cada una de ellas es susceptible de ser imaginada y, por lo tanto, de imaginarla mal. Me da la impresión de que es una idea importante, una de esas ideas a las que tu cerebro tiene que dar vueltas muy despacio, como las pitones cuando comen, pero antes de que haya podido avanzar un paso más interviene Radar.
vi_translation: “But she's wearing a wedding ring,” I remarked. To find a way to support Radar's point of view, I observed her more closely. She was on the right, a little shorter than me. I could see through the frosted window of her car, she was singing along to some song, eyes fixed on the road without blinking. There were too many people. It's easy to forget how crowded this world is, so crowded it could explode, we can imagine each person, and often imagine wrong. I felt this was an important idea, one of those thoughts that our brain has to slowly wrap around, like a python swallowing its prey. But before I could think any further, Radar spoke up.
tr_translation: “He’s wearing a ring,” I point out. According to Radar’s defense, I have the opportunity to look at him for a long time. To my right, just below me. I can see him through the dark-tinted window and watch him as he sings along to a song, his eyes never blinking, focused on the road. There are so many people. It’s so easy to forget that the world is full of people... so full that each of those people can be imagined and is continuously imagined incorrectly. This strikes me as an important idea, one of those ideas that the brain needs to slowly wrap around like a python eating its prey, but before I can go any further, Radar speaks.
es_translation: —She wears a wedding ring —I pointed out. I must say, in Radar's defense, that I have been able to observe her better. She is to my right, just below me. I see her through the tinted windows of her car. I watch her singing and staring straight ahead without blinking. There are a lot of people. It's easy to forget how full of people the world is, crowded, and each one of them is susceptible to being imagined and, therefore, imagined wrongly. I get the impression that it's an important idea, one of those ideas that your brain has to mull over very slowly, like pythons when they eat, but before I can take it a step further, Radar intervenes.

en: “She’s just wearing that so pervs like you don’t come on to her,” Radar explains.
vi: “Cô ấy đeo nhẫn như vậy để những gã dê cụ như ông không dám mon men lại gần,” Radar giải thích.
tr: “Senin gibi sapıklar üstüne gelmesin diye yüzük takıyor sadece,” diye açıklıyor Radar.
es: —Se lo pone para que los pervertidos como tú no se le acerquen —me explica. —Puede ser.
vi_translation: “She wears a ring like that so that creeps like you won't dare to come near,” Radar explained.
tr_translation: “She only wears the ring so creeps like you won't come onto her,” explains Radar.
es_translation: —She wears it so that perverts like you don't approach her —he explains to me. —It could be.

en: “Maybe.” I smile, pick up the half-finished GoFast bar sitting on my lap, and take a bite. It’s quiet again for a while, and I am thinking about the way you can and cannot see people, about the tinted windows between me and this woman who is still driving right beside us, both of us in cars with all these windows and mirrors everywhere, as she crawls along with us on this packed highway. When Radar starts talking again, I realize that he has been thinking, too.
vi: “Có thể đấy.” Tôi mỉm cười, cầm thanh GoFast ăn dở trong lòng lên cắn một miếng. Lại yên lặng một lúc, và tôi nghĩ về cách ta có thể và không thể nhìn thấy con người, về ô cửa sổ kính mờ giữa tôi và người phụ nữ đang lái xe bên phải bọn tôi. Cả tôi và cô ấy đều ở trong những chiếc xe với cửa sổ và gương soi khắp nơi, trong khi cô ấy rù rì chạy xe cạnh chúng tôi trên dải đường tắc nghẽn này. Khi Radar lên tiếng trở lại, tôi nhận ra nó cũng vừa suy nghĩ.
tr: “Olabilir.” Gülümsüyorum, kucağımda duran yarısı yenmiş GoFast gofretinden bir ısırık alıyorum. Bir süre sessiz kalıyoruz ve ben insanları görebilmenin ya da görememenin yollarını ve hâlâ tam yanımızda giden bu kadınla aramızdaki koyu renkli pencereleri düşünüyorum; bu dolu anayolda kadın bizimle birlikte ağır ağır ilerlerken ikimiz de bütün o pencereler ve aynalarla arabaların içindeyiz. Radar tekrar konuşmaya başladığında, onun da düşünmekte olduğunu fark ediyorum.
es: Sonrío. Cojo la media barrita energética que había dejado en mis rodillas y le doy un mordisco. Por un momento nos quedamos callados y pienso en cómo vemos y no vemos a las personas, en las ventanillas tintadas que me separan de esa mujer que conduce a nuestra derecha, en que los dos coches, con ventanas y espejos por todas partes, avanzamos juntos a paso de tortuga por esta autopista abarrotada. Cuando Radar empieza a hablar, me doy cuenta de que también él ha estado pensando.
vi_translation: “Maybe.” I smiled, taking a bite of the half-eaten GoFast bar in my lap. There was silence again for a moment, and I thought about how we can and cannot see people, about the frosted glass window between me and the woman driving to our right. Both she and I were in cars with windows and mirrors everywhere, while she murmured along driving next to us on this congested road. When Radar spoke up again, I realized it had been thinking too.
tr_translation: “Maybe.” I smile, taking a bite from the half-eaten GoFast wafer in my lap. We remain silent for a while, and I think about the ways of seeing or not seeing people and the dark-colored windows between us and the woman still walking right beside us; on this crowded highway, as the woman moves slowly with us, we are both inside the cars with all those windows and mirrors. When Radar starts talking again, I realize that he has been thinking too.
es_translation: I smile. I pick up the half energy bar that I had left on my knees and take a bite. For a moment we remain silent and I think about how we see and don't see people, about the tinted windows that separate me from that woman driving to our right, about how the two cars, with windows and mirrors everywhere, move together at a snail's pace on this crowded highway. When Radar starts to speak, I realize that he has also been thinking.

en: “The thing about That Guy Is a Gigolo,” Radar says, “I mean, the thing about it as a game, is that in the end it reveals a lot more about the person doing the imagining than it does about the person being imagined.”
vi: “Tinh thần của Gã Đó Là Đồ Đào Mỏ,” Radar nói, “ý tôi là tinh thần của trò chơi này, là ở chỗ rút cục nó hé lộ rất nhiều về người đang tưởng tượng hơn là người được tưởng tượng.
tr: “Şu Adam Bir Jigolo’daki olay,” diyor Radar, “yani, bir oyun olarak olayı, sonuçta hayal eden kişiyle ilgili, hayal edilen kişiden çok daha fazla şey açığa çıkartıyor olması.
es: —Lo que pasa con «Este tipo es un gigoló» —dice Radar—, bueno, quiero decir como juego en sí, es que al final dice mucho más de la persona que imagina que de la persona imaginada.
vi_translation: “The spirit of That Guy Is a Gold Digger,” Radar said, “I mean the spirit of this game, is that it ultimately reveals much more about the person imagining than the person being imagined.”
tr_translation: “The event in 'That Guy is a Gigolo',” says Radar, “I mean, as an event in a game, ultimately reveals much more about the person imagining it than the person being imagined.”
es_translation: —The thing about "This guy is a gigolo" —says Radar—, well, I mean as a game itself, is that in the end it says much more about the person imagining than the person being imagined.

en: “Yeah,” I say. “I was just thinking that.” And I can’t help but feel that Whitman, for all his blustering beauty, might have been just a bit too optimistic. We can hear others, and we can travel to them without moving, and we can imagine them, and we are all connected one to the other by a crazy root system like so many leaves of grass—but the game makes me wonder whether we can really ever fully become another.
vi: “Ừ,” tôi đáp. “Tôi cũng vừa nghĩ thế.” Và tôi không khỏi nghĩ rằng Whitman, vì tất cả vẻ đẹp dữ dội của mình, hẳn đã hơi quá lạc quan. Ta có thể nghe thấy người khác, có thể đến với họ mà không cần di chuyển, có thể tưởng tượng ra họ, và ta đều gắn bó với nhau bởi một hệ rễ điên rồ, như những cánh cỏ–nhưng trò chơi này khiến tôi tự hỏi, liệu ta có thể thực sự trở thành người khác một cách trọn vẹn được hay không.
tr: “Evet,” diyorum. “Ben de tam bunu düşünüyordum.” Ve Whitman’m tüm o korkunç güzelliğine rağmen biraz fazla iyimser olabileceğini düşünmekten kendimi alamıyorum. Başkalarım duyabilir, hareket etmeden onlara gidebilir, onlan hayal edebiliriz ve hepimiz bir sürü çimen yaprağı gibi, çılgın bir kök sistemiyle birbirimize bağlıyız... ama bu oyun, gerçekten tamamen başka biri olup olamayacağımızı merak etmeme neden oluyor.
es: —Sí —le contesto—. Estaba pensando lo mismo. Y no puedo evitar sentir que Whitman, por su belleza furiosa, quizá fue demasiado optimista. Podemos oír a los demás, y podemos viajar hasta ellos sin movernos, y podemos imaginarlos, y todos estamos conectados por un loco sistema de raíces, como hojas de hierba, pero el juego hace que me pregunte si en realidad podemos convertirnos totalmente en otro.
vi_translation: “Yes,” I replied. “I was just thinking the same thing.” And I couldn't help but think that Whitman, for all his fierce beauty, might have been a bit too optimistic. We can hear others, reach out to them without moving, imagine them, and we are all connected by a crazy root system, like blades of grass—but this game makes me wonder if we can ever truly become someone else completely.
tr_translation: “Yes,” I say. “I was just thinking the same thing.” And despite all of Whitman’s terrible beauty, I can’t help but think he might be a bit too optimistic. We can hear others, go to them without moving, imagine them, and like a bunch of blades of grass, we are all connected by a crazy root system... but this game makes me wonder if we can really become someone completely different.
es_translation: —Yes —I answered him—. I was thinking the same thing. And I can't help but feel that Whitman, for his furious beauty, might have been too optimistic. We can hear others, and we can travel to them without moving, and we can imagine them, and we are all connected by a crazy root system, like leaves of grass, but the game makes me wonder if we can really become totally another.

en: Hour Seven
vi: Giờ thứ bảy
tr: Yedinci Saat
es: HORA SIETE
vi_translation: Seventh hour
tr_translation: Seventh Hour
es_translation: HOUR SEVEN

en: We finally pass a jackknifed truck and get back up to speed, but Radar calculates in his head that we’ll need to average seventy-seven from here to Agloe. It has been one entire hour since Ben announced that he needed to pee, and the reason for this is simple: he is sleeping. At six o’clock exactly, he took NyQuil. He lay down in the wayback, and then Lacey and I strapped both seat belts around him. This made him even more uncomfortable, but 1. It was for his own good, and 2. We all knew that in twenty minutes, no discomfort would matter to him at all, because he would be dead asleep. And so he is now. He will be awoken at midnight. I have just put Lacey to bed now, at 9 P.M., in the same position in the backseat. We will wake her at 2 A.M. The idea is that everybody sleeps for a shift so we won’t be taping our eyelids open by tomorrow morning, when we come rolling into Agloe.
vi: Cuối cùng bọn tôi vượt qua một xe tải hạng nặng bị lật ngang, lấy lại được tốc độ cũ. Nhưng theo Radar nhẩm tính, chúng tôi cần chạy bảy mươi bảy dặm một giờ từ đây tới Agloe. Đã tròn một tiếng kể từ khi Ben tuyên bố rằng nó cần đi tiểu, và lí do thực đơn giản: Ben đang ngủ. Đúng sáu giờ, nó uống NyQuil[10]. Nó nằm xuống hàng ghế cuối. Lacey và tôi thắt cả hai đai an toàn quanh người nó. Vậy sẽ làm Ben thấy khó chịu hơn, nhưng 1. Như thế tốt cho chính nó, và 2. Chúng tôi đều biết rằng trong hai chục phút, không sự khó chịu nào làm gì được nó, vì Ben sẽ ngủ chết giấc. Và đúng là như vậy. Nó sẽ tỉnh dậy vào nửa đêm. Tôi vừa đặt Lacey vào chỗ ngủ, lúc 9 giờ tối, cùng tư thế như vậy ở ghế sau. Bọn tôi sẽ gọi Lacey dậy lúc 2 giờ sáng. Kế hoạch là mỗi đứa đều sẽ ngủ một chặp để sáng mai không phải lấy tay kéo hai mí mắt lên, khi chúng tôi tiến vào Agloe.
tr: Nihayet yan yatmış bir tırm yanından geçip tekrar hızlanıyoruz ama Radar kafasından, buradan Agloe’ya kadar ortalama yüz yirmi dördü yakalamamız gerekeceğini hesaplıyor. Ben’in çişini yapması gerektiğini bildirmesinin üstünden tam bir saat geçti ve bunun nedeni basit: uyuyor. Saat tam altıda NyQuil aldı. Arka tarafta uzandı, Lacey’yle iki emniyet kemerini de ona bağladık. Bu onu daha da rahatsız etti ama 1. Kendi iyiliği içindi ve 2. Hepimiz yirmi dakika içinde, hiçbir rahatsızlığın onun için önemli olmayacağını biliyorduk, çünkü ölü gibi uyuyor olacaktı. Ve şu anda tam da tahmin ettiğimiz pozisyonda. Geceyansında uyandırılacak. Lacey’yi daha şimdi yatırdım; akşam dokuzda, aynı pozisyonda, arka koltukta. Sabah ikide uyandıracağız. Fikir şöyle: Herkes dönüşümlü olarak uyuyacak, böylece Agloe’ya girmek üzere olacağımız yarm sabaha kadar göz kapaklarımızı bantlamak zorunda kalmayacağız.
es: Al final pasamos por delante de un camión al que se le había desenganchado el remolque y volvemos a acelerar, pero Radar calcula mentalmente que de aquí a Agloe tendremos que llevar una media de ciento veinticinco kilómetros por hora. Ha pasado una hora desde que Ben anunció que tenía que mear, y por una sencilla razón: está durmiendo. A las seis en punto se ha tomado un antihistamínico. Se ha tumbado en el asiento de atrás y Lacey y yo le hemos abrochado los dos cinturones de seguridad, lo que le ha hecho sentirse todavía más incómodo, pero 1) era por su bien, y 2) todos sabíamos que en veinte minutos no le importaría lo más mínimo estar incómodo, porque estaría durmiendo como un tronco. Y ahora mismo lo está. Lo despertaremos a las doce. Hace un momento, a las nueve, he colocado a Lacey para que duerma en el asiento de atrás, en la misma posición. La despertaremos a las dos. La idea es que todo el mundo duerma por turnos para que mañana, cuando lleguemos a Agloe, no nos caigamos de sueño.
vi_translation: Finally, we passed a heavy truck that had overturned, regaining our old speed. But according to Radar's calculations, we needed to drive seventy-seven miles per hour from here to Agloe. It had been exactly an hour since Ben declared he needed to pee, and the reason was quite simple: Ben was asleep. At exactly six o'clock, he drank NyQuil[10]. He lay down in the back row of seats. Lacey and I fastened both seat belts around him. That would make Ben more uncomfortable, but 1. It was better for him, and 2. We all knew that in twenty minutes, no discomfort would bother him, because Ben would be dead asleep. And that was exactly the case. He would wake up at midnight. I had just put Lacey to sleep at 9 PM, in the same position in the back seat. We would wake Lacey up at 2 AM. The plan was for each of us to get some sleep so that in the morning we wouldn't have to use our hands to prop our eyelids open as we entered Agloe.
tr_translation: Finally, we pass by a truck lying on its side and speed up again, but Radar calculates that we need to maintain an average of one hundred twenty-four from here to Agloe. It has been exactly one hour since Ben announced that he needed to pee, and the reason is simple: he is sleeping. He took NyQuil exactly at six o'clock. He lay down in the back, and Lacey and I fastened both seat belts on him. This made him even more uncomfortable but 1. It was for his own good and 2. We all knew that within twenty minutes, no discomfort would matter to him because he would be sleeping like the dead. And right now, he is in exactly the position we predicted. He will be woken up at midnight. I just put Lacey to bed; at nine in the evening, in the same position, in the back seat. We will wake her up at two in the morning. The idea is: Everyone will sleep in turns, so that by the time we are about to enter Agloe in the early morning, we won't have to tape our eyelids open.
es_translation: In the end, we passed by a truck whose trailer had become detached, and we accelerated again, but Radar mentally calculates that from here to Agloe we will have to maintain an average speed of one hundred and twenty-five kilometers per hour. It has been an hour since Ben announced that he needed to pee, and for a simple reason: he is sleeping. At six o'clock sharp, he took an antihistamine. He lay down in the back seat and Lacey and I fastened both seat belts for him, which made him feel even more uncomfortable, but 1) it was for his own good, and 2) we all knew that in twenty minutes he wouldn't care in the slightest about being uncomfortable, because he would be sleeping like a log. And right now he is. We will wake him up at twelve. A moment ago, at nine, I positioned Lacey to sleep in the back seat, in the same position. We will wake her up at two. The idea is that everyone sleeps in shifts so that tomorrow, when we arrive in Agloe, we won't be falling asleep.

en: The minivan has become a kind of very small house: I am sitting in the passenger seat, which is the den. This is, I think, the best room in the house: there is plenty of space, and the chair is quite comfortable.
vi: Chiếc minivan đã trở thành một mái nhà nho nhỏ: Tôi đang ngồi ở ghế cạnh lái xe, chỗ này là phòng thư giãn. Tôi nghĩ đây là phòng tốt nhất trong nhà: rất rộng rãi, ghế khá thoải mái.
tr: Minivan bir bakıma küçük bir eve dönüştü: Ben dinlenme odası olan ön koltukta oturuyorum. Bu bence evin en iyi odası çünkü geniş ve koltuk oldukça rahat.
es: El monovolumen se ha convertido en una especie de casa diminuta. Yo estoy sentado en el asiento del copiloto, que es la sala de estar. Creo que es la mejor habitación de la casa. Es amplia y el asiento es muy cómodo.
vi_translation: The minivan has become a small home: I am sitting in the passenger seat, this is the relaxation room. I think this is the best room in the house: very spacious, the seat is quite comfortable.
tr_translation: The minivan has in a way turned into a small house: I am sitting in the front seat, which serves as a lounge. I think this is the best room in the house because it is spacious and the seat is quite comfortable.
es_translation: The minivan has turned into a kind of tiny house. I am sitting in the passenger seat, which is the living room. I think it is the best room in the house. It is spacious and the seat is very comfortable.

en: Scattered about the carpet beneath the passenger seat is the office, which contains a map of the United States Ben got at the BP, the directions I printed out, and the scrap paper onto which Radar has scrawled his calculations about speed and distance. Radar sits in the driver’s seat. The living room. It is a lot like the den, only you can’t be as relaxed when you’re there. Also, it’s cleaner.
vi: Rải rác trên thảm dưới ghế trước cạnh lái xe là phòng làm việc, có bản đồ nước Mĩ mua ở trạm BP, bản hướng dẫn đường đi tôi đã in ra, và giấy nháp Radar đã viết những phép tính loằng ngoằng về vận tốc và quãng đường. Radar ngồi ở ghế lái xe. Phòng khách. Khá giống phòng thư giãn, chỉ có điều ngồi đó thì không thể thư giãn được. Và phòng khách thì sạch sẽ hơn.
tr: On koltuğun altındaki hainim üzerine bir şeyler dağıtılmış olan yer ofis, burada Ben’in BFden aldığı bir Birleşik Devletler haritası, benim yazdırdığım yol tarifi ve Radar’m hız ve mesafeyle ilgili hesaplarını üstüne karaladığı kâğıt var. Radar sürücü koltuğunda oturuyor. Oturma odası. Dinlenme odasma çok benziyor ancak oradayken o kadar rahat olamıyorsunuz. Ayrıca orası daha temiz.
es: Esparcido por la alfombra de debajo del asiento del copiloto está el despacho, que contiene un mapa de Estados Unidos que Ben ha cogido en la gasolinera, las rutas que yo he imprimido y el trozo de papel en el que Radar ha hecho los cálculos sobre la velocidad y la distancia. Radar está en el asiento del conductor. El comedor. Se parece mucho a la sala, pero en el comedor no puedes relajarte tanto. También está más limpio.
vi_translation: Scattered on the carpet under the front seat next to the driver were the office, a map of the U.S. bought at a BP station, the directions I had printed out, and the scratch paper on which Radar had scribbled calculations about speed and distance. Radar sat in the driver's seat. The living room. Quite similar to a relaxation room, except that sitting there, one cannot relax. And the living room is cleaner.
tr_translation: The office, where something had been spilled on the traitor under that chair, is the place where Ben received a United States from his BF There is a map, the directions I printed out, and a piece of paper on which Radar scribbled his speed and distance calculations. Radar is sitting in the driver's seat. Living room. It looks a lot like the lounge, but you can't be as comfortable there. Also, it's cleaner.
